abstract: At its annual convention in Birmingham, the party is energized by a leadership contest and seems largely undisturbed by broader questions over its electability.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s Conservative Party suffered the worst election defeat of its modern history less than three months ago. Yet one would be hard pressed to find much evidence of it at the party’s annual conference in Birmingham, where the drinks flowed, conversation crackled and the mood could be only described as light.

headline: Catholics Meet to Chart Path Forward, but Women’s Roles Remain Unclear
abstract: The ordination of female deacons is no longer on the agenda during a global assembly at the Vatican, but will be discussed separately.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis had the grandest of ambitions: to tackle some of the thorniest questions facing the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Walz Tells of Women Living Under Abortion Bans, Putting Vance on the Defensive
abstract: By recounting stories of women who have suffered dire health consequences since Roe’s overturning, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota embraced a Democratic strategy as he argued for abortion rights.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota was asked about the issue of abortion during the vice-presidential debate on Tuesday, he defended his state’s broad abortion-rights law and attacked former President Donald J. Trump’s record on the issue. Then he turned to the stories of women living with the consequences of the abortion bans that have been enacted in states across the country in the wake of the overturning of Roe v. Wade in 2022.

headline: Walz Calls Himself a ‘Knucklehead’ for Past Misstatements
abstract: Gov. Tim Walz said he “misspoke” about where he was during the Tiananmen Square massacre in June of 1989.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz said he “misspoke” about where he was during the Tiananmen Square massacre in June of 1989.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: Iran Fires 180 Missiles at Israel
abstract: Plus: In a lawsuit, words matter.
lead_paragraph: Iran fired several waves of ballistic missiles at Israel yesterday, raising the likelihood of a direct all-out war between two of the Middle East’s most powerful militaries. There were no reports of casualties in Israel. A Palestinian man was killed by falling shrapnel in the occupied West Bank.

headline: Vance Says Trump Delivered ‘Stability’
abstract: Senator JD Vance defended Donald J. Trump’s time in office during the vice-presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance defended Donald J. Trump’s time in office during the vice-presidential debate.

headline: The Politics of a Boring Suit
abstract: A night of few fireworks between the candidates was also a night of little sartorial flair. And that was the goal.
lead_paragraph: Before either Gov. Tim Walz or Senator JD Vance uttered a single word at Tuesday night’s debate, they’d already found consensus on one matter: They would appear unremarkable.

headline: Civility and Then a Clash Over Jan. 6: Seven Takeaways From the Debate
abstract: Senator JD Vance of Ohio and Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota sparred over immigration, abortion and foreign policy — and then on Donald Trump’s 2020 election loss.
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance of Ohio and Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota spent most of their only debate aiming not at each other but at their running mates, relitigating the last two administrations and eight years as each promised his ticket would deliver a new direction for the nation.

headline: A Wider War in the Middle East, From Hamas to Hezbollah and Now Iran
abstract: The main questions now are how much the conflict will escalate and whether the United States will get more directly involved in the defense of Israel.
lead_paragraph: The long-feared “wider war” in the Middle East is here.

headline: Taiwan Closes Schools and Workplaces as Typhoon Krathon Nears
abstract: The storm has already injured 46 people and forced thousands of evacuations, the authorities said, warning that torrential rain could cause landslides and flooding.
lead_paragraph: The authorities shut down schools and offices across Taiwan on Wednesday and grounded all domestic flights as Typhoon Krathon barreled toward the island, bringing torrential rain and strong winds. Thousands of people have been evacuated, and 46 have been injured, officials said.

headline: The Moment When Vance Dodged a Jan. 6 Question but Said Plenty
abstract: JD Vance sailed fairly smoothly through some 90 minutes of Tuesday’s debate with Tim Walz. Then the subject turned to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: JD Vance wanted to focus on the future, he said. His past, and his party’s, intervened.

headline: Who Won the Debate? A Crisp Vance Fends Off Walz
abstract: The vice-presidential candidates largely avoided personal attacks, with JD Vance showing a knack for revising history while Tim Walz appeared to battle nerves.
lead_paragraph: In the only vice-presidential debate of the 2024 election cycle, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota and Senator JD Vance of Ohio engaged in a policy-heavy battle of ideas, clashing on the economy, immigration, abortion and protecting American democracy.

headline: The Campaigns Need Younger People to Vote. Did the V.P. Debate Help?
abstract: At three colleges, there were snacks, big screens and homework assignments. But energy and enthusiasm were sparse — and by the end, even more so.
lead_paragraph: In the pivotal battleground of Wisconsin, where presidential elections are won or lost by only tens of thousands of votes, students like those at the University of Wisconsin-Parkside are highly sought after.

headline: Vance Strains to Sell a Softer Trump
abstract: From the opening handshake, the Republican vice-presidential nominee sought to reinvent and repackage the record and views of the former president.
lead_paragraph: Picture this: It’s the biggest moment of your professional life — performed before an audience of millions — and you have to defend your boss.

headline: Best, Worst and Most Unlikely Lines of the Vice-Presidential Debate
abstract: JD Vance gave a shout-out to his wife. Tim Walz sang the praises of Minnesota. Offstage, Donald Trump got distracted.
lead_paragraph: In a vice-presidential debate notable for its largely civil tone and serious focus, Senator JD Vance and Gov. Tim Walz managed to rewrite bits of history, studiously circumnavigate facts, land some zingers and sing the praises of Minnesota. There was a lot of Minnesota.

headline: Word of the Day: unscathed
abstract: This word has appeared in 180 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word unscathed has appeared in 180 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 26 in “Captain of Sunken Yacht Under Investigation in Deaths on Ship” by Emma Bubola and Jeffrey Gettleman:

headline: This Is Why MAGA Loves JD Vance
abstract: Trump’s running mate is no Mike Pence.
lead_paragraph: The most frustrating thing about the vice-presidential debate wasn’t the outcome. JD Vance was exactly as good as I expected. He can be an excellent, persuasive communicator. Like many good lawyers, he’s a chameleon. Depending on the audience, he can breathe fire — the way he does on MAGA podcasts or at Trump rallies — or he can present as a calm, reasonable man, completely at home in a lunchtime think tank discussion.

headline: Late Night Goes Live After a ‘Dull’ Vice-Presidential Debate
abstract: Stephen Colbert was unenthused by Tuesday’s discourse between Tim Walz and JD Vance.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Hurricane Helene
abstract: What is your reaction to this image? What does it tell you about the impact of the storm?
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Helene, a powerful Category 4 storm when it made landfall, carved out a devastating path through the Southeast, leading to destruction and record-level flooding that stretched more than 600 miles.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Prosecutors Warn of More Charges and Defendants in Adams Graft Case
abstract: Eric Adams, the New York City mayor, appeared before Judge Dale E. Ho as he fights off federal charges that he accepted luxury travel in exchange for favors.
lead_paragraph: Less than a week after Mayor Eric Adams pleaded not guilty to charges of bribery and fraud, federal prosecutors told a judge that they might bring additional charges against him and that charges against other people were likely.

headline: Here’s Where U.S. Forces Are Deployed in the Middle East
abstract: The Pentagon is preparing to send more troops and aircraft to the region. This is an overview of the U.S. military presence there.
lead_paragraph: As U.S. warships helped Israel shoot down missiles from an Iranian attack on Tuesday, the Pentagon was preparing to send thousands more U.S. troops, including three additional aircraft squadrons, to the Middle East.

headline: The Best Trend of Fashion Month. And the Worst.
abstract: Louis Vuitton, Chanel and Miu Miu bring Paris Fashion Week to a close with some important takeaways.
lead_paragraph: The Miu Miu show on the last day of fashion month opened with an art installation — Art Basel Paris starts in about two weeks — featuring a piece by Goshka Macuga, the Polish-born, London-based artist.

headline: Visiting a Disney Park? Here’s How to Spend Less Time in Line.
abstract: Long waits can take a bite out of the magic at places like Walt Disney World and Disneyland. There are ways to speed things up, but be prepared to pay more.
lead_paragraph: There’s no arguing with the global appeal of Mickey Mouse. Millions flock to parks like Walt Disney World, in Orlando, Fla., and Disneyland, in Anaheim, Calif., every year. Some visitors are practically regulars: Haydee Chachamovits, 43, of Aventura, Fla., has been to Disney World more than 50 times.

headline: New Mexico Is Where the Outlaw Artists Live
abstract: Over the past century, the state has provided refuge for renegades like Agnes Martin and Judy Chicago. It still does, even with a new wave of arrivals closing in.
lead_paragraph: BELEN, N.M., IS a sun-bleached stucco town set in a vast expanse of desert. From here to the horizon, there’s almost nothing taller than a telephone pole. Highway signs offer ominous haikus (“Notice / Do not pickup hitchhikers / Prison facilities”) and inadvertent riddles (“Dust storms may exist”). Although it’s only 35 miles south of Albuquerque, Belen feels utterly removed from the rhythms of urban life.

headline: Read Your Way Around Hawaii
abstract: To read Hawaii is to understand that much of it will never be accessible to the masses. The writer Megan Kamalei Kakimoto recommends books that illuminate the islands’ rich history and storytelling spirit.
lead_paragraph: It shouldn’t have to be said that Hawaii is not your paradise, but I’m saying it anyway. Please understand: This is not an attempt to erect a hostile barrier, but an entreaty to take the responsibility seriously. To read Hawaii is to understand that much of Hawaii will never, should never, be accessible to the masses.

headline: R.L. Stine’s Favorite Halloween Books Will Give Your Kids Goosebumps
abstract: As spooky season approaches, the master of children’s horror recommends creepy-crawly classics and modern thrills for young readers.
lead_paragraph: When you write scary stories for a living, everyone assumes that Halloween must be your favorite holiday. But when I think about Halloween, I often remember it as a day of heartbreaking disappointment.

headline: Where Literary Ghosts Linger: A Book Critic Goes to Dublin
abstract: The Irish city, once home to the likes of James Joyce and Oscar Wilde, is known for its bookstores, libraries and pubs, where writers found inspiration over pints of Guinness.
lead_paragraph: This summer, my wife, Cree, and I went to Dublin to celebrate our 30th wedding anniversary. We chose it over more exotic destinations because it made sense to us: I’m a book critic and she’s a writer. How could we not go to Dublin, perhaps the most literature-soaked city in the world? The literary ghosts still stalk the medieval streetscapes — so many ghosts that they collide into one another and seem to make up a spectral and talkative rugby team.

headline: Were We the ‘Fat Couple’?
abstract: When Courtenay was alone with her boyfriend, her body shame disappeared. But when they left the house, it felt different.
lead_paragraph: Courtenay Hameister worked hard to stop feeling shame about her body size, but she also had a cruel inner monologue that just wouldn’t leave her alone. At times, her internalized fatphobia was so powerful, she couldn’t think about romance at all. But when Courtenay started dating Jason, everything felt different. He was fat, too, as well as smart, funny, and handsome.

headline: This Pill Could Be the Next Tool to Help Smokers Quit
abstract: The medication, called cytisine, is already used elsewhere in the world. There are efforts to bring it to the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Darius Cohen drives a forklift at a food manufacturing plant in Chicago. It’s a noisy, fast-paced job that for Mr. Cohen, a self-described “stress smoker,” has made it harder to quit.

headline: Want a Better Scone? Try Adding Potatoes.
abstract: The humble spud has rarely been as sweet as in these sensible-yet-decadent delights.
lead_paragraph: In the world of anthropomorphic vegetables, potatoes loom large. For Americans, there is Mr. Potato Head of the blushing ears and startled eyebrows, the first toy ever featured in a TV commercial, in 1952. Early versions included face parts, felt hair and accessories (hats, glasses, pipe) but no potato; you had to provide your own. Investors initially feared that the toy would be seen as being in bad taste, not because turning potatoes into people is an eerie pastime but because the memory of wartime food shortages was still vivid. It seemed wrong to encourage wasting something that could make a meal.

headline: The People Fleeing Climate Disasters Are Going to Transform the American South
abstract: The exodus of the young means high-risk towns could enter a population death spiral.
lead_paragraph: This article is co-published with ProPublica, a nonprofit newsroom that investigates abuses of power.

headline: How Two Billionaire Preachers Remade Texas Politics
abstract: They control Republican politics in the state. Now they’re poised to take their theocratic agenda nationwide.
lead_paragraph: Last December, Sid Miller, the Texas commissioner of agriculture, posted a photo of himself brandishing a double-barrel shotgun on X and invited his followers to join him on a “RINO hunt.” Miller had taken to stumping in the March primary election against incumbents he deemed to be Republicans in Name Only. Not long after that, he received a text message from one of his targets, a state representative named Glenn Rogers. “You are a bought and paid for, pathetic narcissist,” it began. “If you had any honor, you would challenge me, or any of my Republican colleagues to a duel.”

headline: Want People to Embrace Public Health? Make It More Like Weather Forecasting.
abstract: Public health experts too often fail to sound the alarm.
lead_paragraph: In 1925, a tornado cut a track hundreds of miles long, flattening schools and houses across three Midwestern states. At points, the storm was nearly a mile wide and appeared to observers not as a thin funnel but as a wall of angry clouds. Nearly 700 people lost their lives, making it the deadliest tornado in U.S. history.

headline: ‘If Germany Can Do It, Why Can’t We?’
abstract: Germany’s unilateral decision to close its borders has angered its neighbors in Europe.
lead_paragraph: In 2015 when Angela Merkel, the former center-right chancellor of Germany, declined to shut her country’s doors to asylum seekers coming into Europe, she garnered bouquets from liberals, but also hoots from the far right and grumbling from European neighbors miffed that Germany was unilaterally taking the high ground without taking their interests into account.

headline: ‘Vance’s Excellent Reviews Will Enrage Trump’: 13 Writers on Who Won the Vice-Presidential Debate
abstract: Our columnists and contributors rate Tim Walz’s and JD Vance’s debate performances.
lead_paragraph: Times Opinion asked 13 of our columnists and contributors to watch the vice-presidential debate on Tuesday night and assess who won and who lost. We also asked them to weigh in on the quality of the debate. Were the candidates inspiring, or was their face-off a depressing sign of everything that’s wrong with American politics?

headline: You Can Stand Under My Umbrella, if You’re an Egg-Laying Locust
abstract: Male locusts have long been observed shielding mates from other males. Researchers say this behavior may also protect the females from desert temperatures.
lead_paragraph: It may seem like a hopeless place, but locusts find a way to breed in the scorching heat of the Sahara at midday.

headline: As Israel Invades Lebanon, an Embattled Christian Village Is Uprooted
abstract: Hundreds of residents of tiny Ain Ebel in southern Lebanon heeded the Israeli military’s warning to flee. Many sought shelter in a nearby monastery.
lead_paragraph: It began with a flurry of phone calls. First to the village doctor, then the local municipal chief. The man on the line identified himself as an Israeli officer and said they had 45 minutes to pack up their things and leave, or their lives would be in danger.

headline: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Betty Carter
abstract: Her intricate phrasing and live improvisational skills made her a cornerstone for artists of all sorts. Listen to songs chosen by 10 musicians and writers who consider her a north star.
lead_paragraph: We’ve spent five minutes with the likes of Alice Coltrane, Sarah Vaughan and Wayne Shorter; now, we’re taking time to highlight Betty Carter, the transcendent vocalist whose intricate phrasing and live improvisational skills made her a prominent figure in jazz, and whose mentorship of younger musicians fostered a new generation of like-minded singers and instrumentalists to craft music in her image. An entrepreneur, she started her own label, Bet-Car Records, in 1969 because of frustrations with the music business amid diminished interest in jazz, and released some of her most revered work through the imprint. Case in point: Four contributors this month chose songs from “The Audience With Betty Carter,” her epic 1980 album that properly showcased her mastery of performance and is considered one of the best jazz LPs of all time.

headline: A 400-Acre Movie Ranch Outside Los Angeles Is Listed for $35 Million
abstract: Sable Ranch, about 30 miles north of Hollywood, includes an Old West movie set. It has been used for productions like “American Horror Story” and “Oppenheimer.”
lead_paragraph: When Frank Vacek arrived at Sable Ranch in the 1970s, with its chaparral-covered hills bounded by the mountains of the Angeles National Forest, he instantly saw a California dream.

headline: Is R.T.O. Finally a Reality?
abstract: There are some signs of resurging office attendance since Labor Day, and some companies are demanding that workers show up five days a week.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at office attendance, an indicator of how New York City is faring. We’ll also find out what a 45-year-old union contract has to do with school bus delays and driver shortages.

headline: How Russians Serve the State: In Battle, and in Childbirth
abstract: President Vladimir Putin is throwing ever more resources at two interlocked priorities: recruiting more soldiers and encouraging bigger families.
lead_paragraph: What the Kremlin wants from Russians now boils down to two things.

headline: Doug Wheeler’s Celestial Wonder, Now Gallery-Size
abstract: Paint, plastic and flashbulbs: What the visionary artist achieves with those materials is astounding in its effect.
lead_paragraph: The materials checklist for “Day Night Day” (2024), the artist Doug Wheeler’s perception-bending, full-body freak-out at David Zwirner in Chelsea, barely gives anything away: reinforced fiberglass, flat white titanium dioxide latex, gloss white epoxy, LED light — plastic, paint and lightbulbs, essentially. A shopping list easily fulfilled at most local hardware stores. Yet what Wheeler achieves with those materials is astounding in its totalizing effect.

headline: $399,000 Homes in Minnesota, Massachusetts and Maryland
abstract: A sunny one-bedroom condo in Minneapolis, a ranch-style house in Williamstown, Mass., and a 19th-century townhouse in Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: This apartment is in a nine-story building from 2008 in Minneapolis’s Mill District. It is across the street from Mill Ruins Park, home to a museum about the area’s flour production history and a contemporary performing-arts center with views of the Mississippi River. The Commons, a park with play equipment for children and a spray area for warmer days, is a few blocks away. The Target Center, home of the NBA’s Minnesota Timberwolves and the WNBA’s Minnesota Lynx, is five minutes away by car.

headline: A Venture Capital Firm Does Something Rare: Give Money Back
abstract: CRV, based in Silicon Valley, plans to return to investors $275 million because the market for mature start-ups has soured.
lead_paragraph: Venture capital firms raise money — lots of it — and invest it in start-ups in hopes of generating big returns. One thing they rarely do is give the money back.

headline: Sally Rooney’s ‘Intermezzo,’ Reviewed
abstract: Why our critic couldn’t put this book down.
lead_paragraph: Sally Rooney’s highly-anticipated fourth novel, “Intermezzo,” is about the relationship between a pair of brothers in the wake of their father’s death — and about the women they come to love.

headline: Nicole Kidman Knows Exactly What She’s Doing
abstract: She’s everywhere, and she’s giving a lot of work to female talent. Is that such a bad thing?
lead_paragraph: In “The First Wives Club,” Goldie Hawn memorably outlined the three ages of women in Hollywood: “Babe, district attorney and ‘Driving Miss Daisy.’”

headline: Apple’s A.I. Is Landing Soon on iPhones. Here’s What It’s Like.
abstract: The initial version of Apple Intelligence focuses on helping you with words and photos. Prepare to be impressed and unnerved.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s most important new product of the year (sorry, it’s not a $3,500 headset) will arrive this month. Apple Intelligence, a suite of software tools bringing what Apple describes as artificial intelligence to its devices, will be released through free software updates for owners of some iPhones, Macs and iPads.

headline: Should We Abolish the Penny?
abstract: Each year the U.S. Mint produces billions of pennies. Many are hardly ever used. Are these small copper-colored coins worth the trouble?
lead_paragraph: Are you a fan of pennies? Or are you annoyed when a cashier hands one back to you with your change? When was the last time you used or even looked at one?

headline: Attitudes About Nasrallah Appear More Positive in Middle East Since His Death
abstract: Sentiment about the Hezbollah leader shifted after the Israeli strike that killed him, partly reflecting anger toward Israel, according to an analysis.
lead_paragraph: Public perceptions of Hassan Nasrallah, the Hezbollah leader who was assassinated by Israel last week, have grown more positive across the Middle East since his death, according to an analysis of social media and other internet posts.

headline: Why Trump Wants to Make America the ‘Crypto Capital of the Planet’
abstract: The former president’s views of virtual coins have shifted markedly in recognition of the emergence of this sector as a major player in campaign finance.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s views of the cryptocurrency industry have shifted markedly in recognition of the emergence of that sector as a major player in the world of campaign finance.

headline: Biden Surveys Wreckage From Helene and Deploys 1,000 Troops to Assist
abstract: Officials are still uncovering the extent of the devastation in western North Carolina, which President Biden took in from the air. The storm killed at least 183 people in six states.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Wednesday took an aerial tour of the devastation from Hurricane Helene and ordered the Pentagon to deploy up to 1,000 active-duty troops to assist with aid efforts as rescue workers continued dangerous rescue missions in remote mountain communities.

headline: Police See No Trace of a Serial Killer in Brooklyn. But 3 Deaths Chill Nightlife.
abstract: As rumors spin on social media, revelers in one of New York City’s most popular neighborhoods for nightlife are on higher alert.
lead_paragraph: Revelers streamed into the Brooklyn Mirage on a recent weekend to the steady pulse of electronic music. Diplo, the Grammy-winning D.J. playing that night, was not the only thing on their minds.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 480
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Oct. 3, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,202
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Oct. 3, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Walz-Vance Debate: Civility and Then a Clash
abstract: The vice-presidential candidates sparred over immigration, abortion and the Jan. 6 riot.
lead_paragraph: Just three weeks after Kamala Harris and Donald J. Trump engaged in a fiery and often hostile presidential debate, their running mates, Tim Walz and JD Vance, met for their own face-off — and struck a very different chord.

headline: Israel Vows Retaliation Against Iran, and Takeaways From the Debate
abstract: Plus, Mexico’s first female president.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Three Men Arrested After Explosions Near Israeli Embassy in Denmark
abstract: The arrests were made after two explosions, possibly from hand grenades, were reported near the embassy early on Wednesday morning, the police said.
lead_paragraph: The police in Copenhagen arrested three men in connection with two explosions that occurred near the Israeli Embassy just north of Copenhagen early Wednesday.

headline: A Vice-Presidential Debate
abstract: We explain the why the debate offered a snapshot of another era.
lead_paragraph: Last night’s vice-presidential debate between JD Vance and Tim Walz was calmer — and more typical of the pre-Trump political era — than the presidential debate last month. That calmness often made it easier to understand the policy differences between the two campaigns.

headline: Allies Say They Came to Israel’s Aid During Iran’s Missile Attack
abstract: Israel has said that Iran fired more than 180 missiles in the barrage on Tuesday, but that most were intercepted.
lead_paragraph: A number of Israel’s key allies came forward on Wednesday to say they were involved in helping to repel the wave of missiles that Iran launched at Israel overnight.

headline: Vance and Walz Spar Over Key Policy Issues
abstract: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota and Senator JD Vance of Ohio debated immigration, abortion and foreign policy — and then clashed over Donald Trump’s 2020 election loss. Jazmine Ulloa, a national politics reporter for The New York Times, highlights some standout moments.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota and Senator JD Vance of Ohio debated immigration, abortion and foreign policy — and then clashed over Donald Trump’s 2020 election loss. Jazmine Ulloa, a national politics reporter for The New York Times, highlights some standout moments.

headline: What Can Body Language Reveal on ‘Love Is Blind’?
abstract: As Season 7 begins, an expert says figuring out a participant’s motivation is both an art and a science.
lead_paragraph: Grab a golden goblet. The Netflix series “Love Is Blind” is back, with the first episode of its seventh season having been released on Wednesday, with the host Nick Lachey learning what a situationship is. The series that inspired drinking games (take a sip every time someone says the phrase “genuine connection”) — and is both a reality show and a social experiment — set up shop in Washington, D.C., this time to help 29 singles find love.

headline: Dozens Die After Smugglers Force Them Off Ships Into Open Waters
abstract: Many others are missing after Yemeni operators instructed hundreds of African migrants on two boats near the Djibouti coast to get off and swim, the International Organization for Migration said.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of people died and dozens of others were missing after smugglers forced them off two boats near the coast of Djibouti, making 2024 the deadliest year for migrants crossing between Africa and Yemen, the International Organization for Migration said on Wednesday.

headline: Why the Conflict Between Iran and Israel Has Raised Oil Prices Only Modestly
abstract: The fighting is increasing fears about oil supplies, but those worries are offset by greater global production and slowing demand in China.
lead_paragraph: The barrage of missiles that Iran fired at Israel overnight on Tuesday continued to lift oil prices on Wednesday, as investors worried that a wider conflict in the Middle East could disrupt global supplies.

headline: Ukraine Withdraws From Mining Town That Long Defied Russian Attacks
abstract: Vuhledar had been under assault for almost three years. Russian forces entered it after a furious battle, and Ukraine ordered troops to retreat.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian military said on Wednesday that it was ordering the last of its forces to retreat from the ruins of Vuhledar, a mining town that had served as a vital defensive bastion for nearly three years in eastern Ukraine, after it was stormed by Russian troops.

headline: Israel Declares U.N. Chief António Guterres Persona Non Grata
abstract: Foreign Minister Israel Katz said the U.N. secretary general had not condemned Iran’s missile attack on Israel in strong enough terms. For his part, Mr. Guterres said he condemned the attack.
lead_paragraph: Israel has barred the secretary general of the United Nations, António Guterres, from entering the country, Foreign Minister Israel Katz said on Wednesday, criticizing him for failing to forcefully condemn Iran’s latest missile attack.

headline: The Cost of a New War in the Middle East
abstract: An escalation of fighting between Israel and Iran could cause oil prices to spike and send a chill through the global economy.
lead_paragraph: Oil prices were up again on Wednesday morning after Israel vowed to retaliate against Iran for firing a barrage of ballistic missiles at the country, reviving fears that global energy supplies could be disrupted by full-scale war in the Middle East.

headline: Sarah Snook to Make Broadway Debut in One-Woman ‘Dorian Gray’
abstract: The “Succession” actress will play all 26 characters in a stage production of the Oscar Wilde novel.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Snook, the Australian actress who captivated and chilled television audiences as Siobhan Roy on “Succession,” will make her Broadway debut next year in a much-praised and technologically innovative adaptation of “The Picture of Dorian Gray.”

headline: Should I Press My Adult Son to Break Up With His Girlfriend?
abstract: A reader worries that her 29-year-old son is stringing along his girlfriend of nearly three years: She wants marriage and children, but he’s not sure she’s “the one.”
lead_paragraph: My 29-year-old son has been dating his girlfriend for nearly three years. She must be wondering when they’ll move in together and get engaged. My son is not sure that “she’s the one,” but he hasn’t told her that. His reluctance to take their relationship to the next level is an indication, of course, but apparently, his girlfriend does not see this as a red flag. I assume that’s because she thinks things will change. I am very concerned for her: She’s 30 and wants marriage and children. I have told my son that he should end the relationship if he cares about her. Still, it continues. My husband says that I should stay out of this, but I’m wondering if I should push harder for my son to end things. Your thoughts?

headline: The Misogyny of Gen Z Men Has Been Overstated
abstract: The majority of them support equality, even if they don’t call themselves feminists.
lead_paragraph: A major story line of this election season has been the gender gap among Gen Z voters, with young women expressing much more liberal views than young men. Sometimes it can sound like young men are all misogynist incels, addicted to video games and manosphere influencers like Andrew Tate. Young men, it seems, are bitter about their declining fortunes, and they’re taking it out on women.

headline: Tesla Sales Increase, Suggesting Electric Car Demand Is Rebounding
abstract: The automaker reported a gain of 6.4 percent for the latest quarter, its first such increase this year.
lead_paragraph: Tesla said Wednesday that its global sales of cars and trucks rose 6.4 percent in the third quarter, the first quarterly increase the company has reported this year and a sign that demand for electric cars may be recovering as interest rates fall.

headline: ‘Ring of Fire’ Solar Eclipse Will Be Visible in Parts of South America
abstract: Not everyone will be able to see the phenomenon, known as an annular eclipse, on Wednesday, though a partial solar eclipse may be visible in parts of Antarctica and Hawaii.
lead_paragraph: Sky watchers in parts of South America are in for a treat on Wednesday, when the moon will pass between the sun and Earth to produce an annular eclipse — an extraordinary moment that will create a “ring of fire” in the sky.

headline: Missing Out on Coldplay’s India Tickets, Some Fans Vented — Even to Police
abstract: When 13 million people tried to buy tickets for the band’s Mumbai shows, the ticketing site crashed. Many who came up short cried foul, both online and to the authorities.
lead_paragraph: When tickets for two Coldplay concerts in Mumbai, India, went on sale last month, about 13 million people visited an online ticketing platform to vie for around 90,000 seats. Within minutes, the show was sold out and the platform had crashed, only for the tickets to later be offered on other sites at steeply marked-up prices.

headline: If Trump Wins, Could He Really Use the Justice Department to Jail His Rivals?
abstract: How might a politically motivated prosecution actually unfold? These steps show exactly how Trump could make his threats real — all while staying within the constitutional limits on presidential power.
lead_paragraph: How might a politically motivated prosecution actually unfold? These steps show exactly how Trump could make his threats real — all while staying within the constitutional limits on presidential power.

headline: Israel Confirms First Military Deaths in Lebanon Invasion
abstract: The military identified the soldier as Capt. Eitan Itzhak Oster, 22, from central Israel, but did not specify where he was killed.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military said Wednesday that eight of its soldiers had been killed in combat in Lebanon, as Israeli ground troops and fighter jets pounded Hezbollah sites across a broad swath of southern Lebanon and the Lebanese militia lobbed dozens of rockets at towns in northern Israel.

headline: Inside a Pro-Harris Ad Telling Hispanic Voters She’s Friendlier Than Trump
abstract: An ad from two Democratic groups skates over Kamala Harris’s tough recent stance on border security and instead focuses on her more immigration-friendly plans.
lead_paragraph: Two Democratic groups — Somos PAC and Priorities USA Action — are running this 30-second ad on digital platforms in battleground states in support of Vice President Kamala Harris. The ad is targeted at Hispanic voters, and the two groups are spending $1 million on it as part of a $5 million campaign. It has both English- and Spanish-language versions.

headline: Did Apple Just Kill Social Apps?
abstract: Some app makers worry that a subtle change to the iPhone’s contact-sharing permissions could make it hard for them to get the fast growth they need to compete.
lead_paragraph: This year, when Apple announced iOS 18, the latest version of its mobile operating system, most of the attention went to its slate of new artificial intelligence features.

headline: Should You Exercise When You’re Sick?
abstract: If you have a cold, Covid or the flu, here’s how to determine whether it’s wise to work out.
lead_paragraph: It happens to all of us: Your alarm goes off for a morning workout and you roll over with a groan. You’re not just tired — your body feels off.

headline: How to Stop Straining Your Eyes
abstract: That achy, tired feeling comes from more than just screen time. Experts share tips for easing the discomfort.
lead_paragraph: After staring at your laptop for hours or scrolling through social media on your phone, you may sense a heavy achiness or bleary-eyed feeling creep in.

headline: After a Decade, Scientists Unveil Fly Brain in Stunning Detail
abstract: Scientists have mapped out how 140,000 neurons are wired in the brain of the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster.
lead_paragraph: A fruit fly’s brain is smaller than a poppy seed, but it packs tremendous complexity into that tiny space. Over 140,000 neurons are joined together by more than 490 feet of wiring, as long as four blue whales placed end to end.

headline: Hurricane Helene Deaths Will Continue for Years, Study Suggests
abstract: Research on hundreds of tropical storms finds that mortality keeps rising for more than a decade afterward, for reasons you might not expect.
lead_paragraph: Over the past week, the official death toll from Hurricane Helene has surpassed 100 as the vortex creeping inland from Florida submerged homes and swept away cars. But the full weight of lost lives will be realized only years from now — and it could number in the thousands.

headline: Vance and Walz’s Battle of the Network Co-Stars
abstract: In what could be the last prime-time showdown of the 2024 campaign, the supporting players performed against type.
lead_paragraph: If a presidential election is a TV series — and partly it is, like it or not — then the vice-presidential debate is usually a departure episode: an installment that briefly shifts focus to a couple of side characters. It might be memorable or forgettable, but it is generally skippable.

headline: When Artists Found Beauty in London’s Toxic Fog
abstract: Monet and Turner found something sublime in the polluted 19th-century city — and maybe something darker, too.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been to London recently (or ever) you’ll probably recognize Claude Monet’s description: “Today the weather was maddening, gusts of snow, then sunshine, fog and dark weather and clear, it was magnificent but all too changeable.”

headline: Victim’s Unsealed Testimony Reveals New Details in Epstein Case
abstract: The woman testified in a now-settled lawsuit against JPMorgan Chase on behalf of hundreds of Jeffrey Epstein’s victims.
lead_paragraph: One of Jeffrey Epstein’s many sexual abuse victims said the financier often had her followed and was so controlling that she felt she could not break free, according to a recently unsealed deposition in a now-settled class-action lawsuit against JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Orla Gartland Melds Honesty, Hooks and Noise
abstract: On her second album, the internet-native Irish songwriter makes a complicated relationship sound “squonky.”
lead_paragraph: The Irish songwriter Orla Gartland refuses to oversimplify romance on her new album, “Everybody Needs a Hero.”

headline: A Piccata With a Smart, Meatless Twist
abstract: That buttery, briny combination of lemon, butter and capers is awesome on cauliflower.
lead_paragraph: I’m back from my trip to Turkey and Kurdistan, where, you won’t be surprised to hear, I ate spectacularly well. I was treated to ripe figs and juicy melon; yogurt-swirled dips scooped up with homemade flatbread; singed grilled fish brushed with pomegranate molasses; meaty kebabs cut from every part of the cow and lamb; and so many honeyed, flaky pastries that I think I might have to go on a baklava break, at least for a day or two. Such abundance in all things — except for vegetables.

headline: Is It OK to Leave the U.S. if the Wrong Candidate Becomes President?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on modes of resistance to American electoral politics.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, American friends of mine bought a home in a European country in order to obtain an E.U. passport. (The country has an immigration program supporting this.) They state that they are doing so in case the United States presidential election goes as they fear.

headline: It All Seemed So Conventional. And Then Came Jan. 6.
abstract: JD Vance may well be thinking about 2028 and beyond. He will need a lot more than a fairly mild 90-minute debate to fully soften his image.
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance of Ohio was trying to un-weird himself.

headline: The Whiplash of a Major Fashion World Shake-up
abstract: Celine shocked the industry by announcing that Hedi Slimane, its top designer, is leaving. Hours later, it surprised many again by naming his replacement.
lead_paragraph: In one of the swiftest rounds of fashion musical chairs in recent memory, Celine announced on Wednesday that Hedi Slimane would be leaving his position as the label’s artistic director, but his post wasn’t vacant for long. Hours later, the brand named Mr. Slimane’s replacement: Michael Rider, a former design director at Celine who most recently oversaw Polo Ralph Lauren’s women’s wear.

headline: Review: ‘Good Bones,’ but Not Fleshed Out
abstract: A new play from James Ijames, who won a Pulitzer for his “Fat Ham,” has intriguing ideas about identity and community that never fully take shape.
lead_paragraph: In the immortal words of Joni Mitchell, “They paved paradise and put up a parking lot.” In James Ijames’s “Good Bones,” which opened on Tuesday at the Public Theater in Manhattan, it’s not a parking lot that’s the issue but a sports complex. This project is being nudged along by Aisha (Susan Kelechi Watson), a former local who is promoting the arena and building a luxe new home in her old hood as a way to revitalize it.

headline: Whole Foods Tried to Change This Cake Recipe. Customers Lost It.
abstract: The grocery chain’s Berry Chantilly cake has a cult following and an extremely vocal fan base.
lead_paragraph: When Lisa Younes visited her local Whole Foods Market in Berkeley, Calif., last month she expected to walk out with a slice of her beloved Berry Chantilly cake: With its lofty layers of almond-scented cake and fluffy mascarpone frosting dotted with fresh mixed berries, it had become her go-to sweet treat for the past year.

headline: Vance vs. Walz: The Debate Reviews Are In
abstract: Readers offer assessments of the candidates’ performances while praising the debate’s civility. Also: A college president’s resignation; storm relocation.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: On Child Care, Vance Tests a Talking Point Democrats Also Embrace
abstract: Both vice-presidential candidates say the government should spend more on child care, a rare point of agreement. But there are still major differences in how they talk about families and gender roles.
lead_paragraph: In a Tuesday vice-presidential debate studded with surprising points of agreement between two starkly different candidates, an extended discussion of child care stood out.

headline: Iran’s Strikes on Israel Look Calculated to Shore Up Regional Alliance
abstract: Iran’s second missile barrage against Israel is unlikely to deter its foe, experts say, but may help retain the support of the “Axis of Resistance” it has built up over years.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s barrage of missiles against Israel may have inflicted minimal military damage on its regional foe, but analysts say that Tehran saw it as a critical move to shore up regional support — and a signal to Western powers that without quick diplomatic pressure the conflict could spiral even further.

headline: JD Vance’s Old Yale Law Classmates Raise Money for Springfield’s Haitian Residents
abstract: Some donors said they were seeking to repair damage the Trump-Vance campaign, and Mr. Vance himself, had caused by spreading bogus rumors that migrants were harming pets.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of former classmates of Senator JD Vance of Ohio spent Tuesday night’s vice-presidential debate donating money to a fund for Haitian immigrants in Springfield, Ohio, raising more than $10,000.

headline: What Black Voters Are Saying About Eric Adams Since His Indictment
abstract: Some Black New Yorkers are sticking by the mayor’s side after he was charged with bribery. Many expressed disappointment in him.
lead_paragraph: He danced to gospel-tinged music as the churchgoers sang in unison. The crowd cheered as he told a story about growing up poor in Queens, about six miles from the church event on Monday evening.

headline: OpenAI Completes Deal That Values Company at $157 Billion
abstract: The A.I. start-up’s valuation has risen by more than $70 billion in nine months.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI said on Wednesday that it had completed a $6.6 billion fund-raising deal that nearly doubles the high-profile company’s valuation from just nine months ago.

headline: At Least 60 Dead After Boat Capsizes in Nigeria
abstract: The boat was carrying about 300 people on the Niger River. Rescuers continued to search for survivors.
lead_paragraph: At least 60 people drowned on Tuesday when a boat carrying hundreds of mostly women and children capsized on the Niger River in Nigeria, a spokesman for the local government said. At least 80 people were still missing by Wednesday as rescue workers scrambled to find more survivors.

headline: Pete Rose Never Changed, but Baseball Did
abstract: It has begun to acknowledge what Rose knew: That sports are deeply intertwined with gambling.
lead_paragraph: During the 1970s, the era of peak Pete Rose, Major League Baseball still maintained an air of innocence. Nary a betting booth was to be found in a stadium, game broadcasts had not a single FanDuel ad, and the leagues lacked an Official Sports Betting Partner.

headline: Review: Finding the Right Rep for a Repertory Company
abstract: Dayton Contemporary Dance Company brought a mixed bill to the Joyce Theater, including a Paul Taylor classic and a dance by the great Rennie Harris.
lead_paragraph: Since it was founded in 1968, Dayton Contemporary Dance Company has often been compared with Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, founded 10 years before. And with Philadanco and Dallas Black Dance Theater, which started up soon after. These troupes share a focus on the African American experience but also, perhaps less obviously, a model. They are repertory companies, which means they are forever facing the question: What repertory will best serve their dancers and audiences?

headline: Flare-Up in Israel-Iran Conflict Leaves Harris Unable to Avoid the Subject
abstract: Missiles over Tel Aviv fed Donald Trump’s narrative of a world in chaos and vaporized any hopes of an end to the war. In the near term, that poses political problems for Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Six months ago, President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris — caught between a left flank demanding punishment for Israel and moderate voters pleading with them to stand by their ally — could only hope that the war in Gaza would exhaust itself, or even that Israel’s right-wing leader would choose a legacy-defining peace over an endless armed conflict.

headline: Ozzie Virgil Sr., First Dominican-Born Major Leaguer, Dies at 92
abstract: An outstanding fielder though never an All-Star, he broke that barrier with the Giants in 1956 and later became the Tigers’ first Black player.
lead_paragraph: Ozzie Virgil Sr., who became the first Dominican native in major league baseball when he played third base for the New York Giants in 1956, and who took the field two years later as the Detroit Tigers’ first Black player, died on Sunday at his home in Monte Cristi, a city near the Dominican Republic’s border with Haiti. He was 92.

headline: What Happens Next in Hunter Biden’s Criminal Cases
abstract: The president’s son now confronts a daunting and uncertain process that could result in serious time behind bars when he is sentenced in his tax and gun cases in mid-December.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Biden was relieved, at least for a while, after pleading guilty to tax offenses in Los Angeles on Sept. 5 — sparing him the ordeal of a second criminal trial.

headline: Soaring Temperatures Give San Francisco an ‘Extreme’ Second Summer
abstract: It’s hot in Northern California this week, and some places won’t see relief for days.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco, where even the postcards feature fog, rarely sees temperatures over 90 degrees. Even more rarely does the coastal California city see such temperatures in October.

headline: Penn Station Takes Up Two Blocks. Railroads Say They Must Have More.
abstract: After studying other ways to double capacity at the busy transit hub, the railroads that use it say they have concluded that it needs to be expanded.
lead_paragraph: After what they describe as an exhaustive study of the alternatives, Amtrak and the commuter railroads that use Pennsylvania Station in New York City say they have no choice but to take some property in Midtown Manhattan to make the station bigger.

headline: Biden Says He Won’t Support an Israeli Strike on Iran’s Nuclear Sites
abstract: His comments reflected a renewed effort by his administration to seek restraint from Israel to try to avoid a growing war in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said on Wednesday that he would not support a strike by Israel on Iranian nuclear sites in retaliation for Tuesday’s missile attack, signaling an effort to restrain Israel from responding with such force that it could trigger a wider regional war.

headline: After Helene, Lawyers Gear Up for Battles Over Who Should Pay
abstract: As storms intensify, so do the legal clashes with insurers, aid agencies and others over compensation, rebuilding and even scams.
lead_paragraph: As the colossal scale of damage wrought by Hurricane Helene becomes clear, legal aid groups are steeling themselves for yearslong battles to help people rebuild their lives and homes.

headline: Biden Says He Won’t Support Israeli Attack on Iranian Nuclear Sites
abstract: President Biden told reporters that leaders of the Group of 7 countries agreed that Israel had a right to respond to Iran’s missile attack, but that it should do so proportionally.
lead_paragraph: President Biden told reporters that leaders of the Group of 7 countries agreed that Israel had a right to respond to Iran’s missile attack, but that it should do so proportionally.

headline: London’s Once-Tidy Green Spaces Are Going Wild, On Purpose
abstract: In response to concerns over climate change and plummeting biodiversity, a shift is afoot in the city’s parks. Manicured is out; rugged is in.
lead_paragraph: London’s parks and gardens have long been peaceful escapes for residents and visitors alike, but lately there’s been a revolution afoot. While the phrase “London garden” might call to mind images of carefully manicured lawns, the city’s green spaces appear to have entered their wild era.

headline: Tim Walz as a Harris Ally: Folksy, Factually Sloppy and Far Less Visible
abstract: The Minnesota governor has brought his charm to the campaign trail, but his debate was uneven and he has so far been scarcely seen on national television. His team says that may be changing.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota traded the harsh lights of the debate stage for the more comfortable environment of a campaign bus tour on Wednesday through central Pennsylvania.

headline: Sleeping Through Hurricane Helene
abstract: Extreme climate was supposed to shock us into action. What happened?
lead_paragraph: Last week, warning about the imminent arrival of Hurricane Helene, the National Weather Service in Tallahassee, Fla., used the word “unsurvivable.”

headline: Like Trump, Vance Wavers on What to Do With Obamacare
abstract: JD Vance seemed to back away from a proposal to separate healthy and sick people in insurance markets, which could cause major disruption for people with pre-existing conditions.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks before Tuesday’s vice-presidential debate, Senator JD Vance sounded like someone who wanted to repeal the Affordable Care Act.

headline: After Missile Attack, Israel May Be Ready to Risk All-Out War With Iran
abstract: Israel seems ready to respond in a much more forceful and public way with Iran after Tehran launched its second massive missile attack on Israel this year, analysts and officials say.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates as Israel launches retaliatory strikes against Iran.

headline: A Shift Among Democrats: Embrace Record Levels of Oil and Gas
abstract: Tim Walz said climate change is real, but boasted about high U.S. levels of oil and gas production. JD Vance called climate change “weird science.”
lead_paragraph: JD Vance and Tim Walz on Tuesday both avoided talking about the main cause of global warming that is powering the kind of violent weather that struck the Southeast this week: the burning of fossil fuels.

headline: A Survivor of Clerical Sex Abuse Tells His Harrowing Tale at St. Peter’s
abstract: As a child, Laurence Gien was abused by a priest in South Africa. Decades later, he became the first survivor to recount his pain at the Basilica in front of Pope Francis and dozens of cardinals and bishops.
lead_paragraph: A professional baritone, Laurence Gien has sung in some of the most storied opera houses in the world. So, he wasn’t particularly daunted by the glitter and gold of St. Peter’s Basilica.

headline: Officials Cast Doubt on a Dementia Drug, but Human Trials Continue
abstract: The S.E.C. alleged shortcomings in research said to support the drug, and its developer agreed to a $40 million settlement. Some experts wonder why clinical trials have not been stopped.
lead_paragraph: A drug touted by a small pharmaceutical company as a treatment for Alzheimer’s disease has had a turbulent bid for regulatory approval.

headline: In Beirut’s Once-Bustling Suburbs, Smoking Rubble and Eerie Quiet
abstract: Airstrikes targeting members of Hezbollah have brought the Dahiya neighborhoods south of Beirut to a standstill, its residents fleeing and businesses shuttering.
lead_paragraph: There is little life left in the southern suburbs of Beirut.

headline: Mayorkas Warns of Funding Shortfall for Rest of Hurricane Season
abstract: The homeland security secretary said FEMA, which is dealing with the destruction from Hurricane Helene, would need more money to respond to another major storm.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Emergency Management Agency does not have enough funding to ride out the remainder of the hurricane season, Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, said on Wednesday.

headline: Stranded in North Carolina’s Mountains, ‘You Can’t Tell That the World’s Going On’
abstract: With no way for cars to get into Bat Cave, N.C., food and water have been dropped off by helicopters or carried over the river on foot or by a raft.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Ladlee and her fiancé loaded their backpacks with supplies and began a journey up the mountain that, a week ago, would have taken about five minutes by car.

headline: Beyoncé Released a Song and Levi’s Saw Its Moment
abstract: The denim brand was looking for ways to sell more apparel to women, and the megastar gave them a natural spokeswoman thanks to a song on “Cowboy Carter.”
lead_paragraph: Kenny Mitchell, the chief marketing officer at Levi Strauss & Co., knew his team needed to move fast after Beyoncé released the track list for her album “Cowboy Carter” in March. Out of the 27 songs listed, one provided the denim brand’s marketing department with a huge opportunity: “Levii’s Jeans.”

headline: Judge Unseals New Evidence in Federal Election Case Against Trump
abstract: Judge Tanya Chutkan made public portions of a filing by prosecutors setting out their argument for why the case should go forward despite the Supreme Court’s ruling on presidential immunity.
lead_paragraph: When told by an aide that Vice President Mike Pence was in peril as the rioting on Capitol Hill escalated on Jan. 6, 2021, President Donald J. Trump replied, “So what?”

headline: How a Judge Will Weigh Immunity in Trump’s Jan. 6 Case
abstract: How does the Supreme Court’s presidential immunity ruling apply to former President Donald J. Trump’s election-interference case? Here’s how Judge Tanya S. Chutkan will decide.
lead_paragraph: How does the Supreme Court’s presidential immunity ruling apply to former President Donald J. Trump’s election-interference case? Here’s how Judge Tanya S. Chutkan will decide.

headline: Trump’s Insults to Harris’s Intelligence? Jokes, Lara Trump Claims.
abstract: During rallies and on social media, former President Donald J. Trump has repeatedly disparaged Vice President Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: As the Republican Party strains to cast Donald J. Trump in a gentler light ahead of the fall election, Lara Trump volunteered a novel interpretation of the former president’s frequent, crude attacks on Vice President Kamala Harris’s intelligence: He’s kidding.

headline: With No Phones or Wi-Fi, North Carolina Revives the Town Meeting
abstract: Modern technology has been slow to return to mountain towns after Helene. Whiteboards and gatherings are helping residents find missing people and much-needed supplies.
lead_paragraph: How do community leaders provide vital updates when the power is down and cellphone service is out? One North Carolina town devastated by Hurricane Helene has brought back a decidedly low-tech solution: the town meeting.

headline: What to Know About the Israel-Hezbollah War
abstract: An Israeli ground operation targeting Hezbollah forces in Lebanon recalls previous wars and raises fears of worse to come.
lead_paragraph: Israel and Hezbollah troops were fighting at close range in southern Lebanon on Wednesday, after Israel launched a ground invasion earlier in the week.

headline: The V.P. Debate Might Boost Vance and Walz, but It Probably Won’t Shift the Polls
abstract: Voters may view JD Vance and Tim Walz more positively after Tuesday’s debate. But it’s unlikely to have much impact on their choices for president.
lead_paragraph: When Senator JD Vance of Ohio and Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota took the debate stage Tuesday night, a significant share of Americans had not yet formed opinions about either vice-presidential candidate, according to recent polls.

headline: Thursday Briefing: Israeli Troops Clashed with Hezbollah
abstract: Plus, what we learned from fashion month.
lead_paragraph: Israel and Hezbollah said their troops were fighting at close range in southern Lebanon, as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu weighed a military response to Iran for firing ballistic missiles at Israel.

headline: Trump Did Not ‘Save’ Obamacare. He Just Failed to Kill It.
abstract: By trying to repeal and replace the law while president, he wound up making it popular.
lead_paragraph: On Donald J. Trump’s first day as president, he signed an executive order to repeal Obamacare.

headline: Read the Special Counsel’s Newly Unsealed Evidence Against Trump
abstract: A sprawling legal brief by the special counsel, Jack Smith, lays out his case for why former President Donald J. Trump is not immune from prosecution on federal charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election. It adds new details of how Mr. Trump tried to cling to power.
lead_paragraph: A sprawling legal brief by the special counsel, Jack Smith, lays out his case for why former President Donald J. Trump is not immune from prosecution on federal charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election. It adds new details of how Mr. Trump tried to cling to power.

headline: Curious About How The Times Is Covering the Election? Send Us Your Questions.
abstract: The election is fast approaching. New York Times editors and reporters want to answer your questions about how we will cover one of the biggest nights in news.
lead_paragraph: The 2024 election is just weeks away, and nearly everyone at The New York Times is contributing to coverage in at least some small way. Reporters are on the campaign trail with the candidates, sharing insights along the way; data editors are breaking down the results from the latest polls; software engineers are ensuring The Times’s website is ready to handle a surge of traffic on election night.

headline: JD Vance and Tim Walz Debate Draws 43 Million Viewers
abstract: The figure is significantly lower than the vice-presidential debate in 2020.
lead_paragraph: The vice-presidential debate between JD Vance and Tim Walz drew 43.1 million viewers on Tuesday night, significantly fewer than the face-off between the vice-presidential candidates in 2020, according to Nielsen.

headline: New Evidence Was Unsealed in the Federal Election Case Against Trump
abstract: Also, Biden ordered 1,000 troops to help areas destroyed by Helene. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Washington made public portions of a sprawling legal brief in which prosecutors provided the fullest picture yet of what they found in their investigation of Donald Trump’s attempts to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘She Literally Ran From the Room’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: As a child, I was given rocks and fossils in jewelry-sized boxes. I’d always hoped for tourmaline, the rainbow stone that generates electrical charge. Right before I moved to a new city, my best friend came to see me. My family moved often enough that I knew it might be the last time we ever spoke. Perhaps that’s why I acted on my feelings, which I hadn’t yet categorized but recognized as electric. I tried to kiss her. She literally ran from the room. As an adult, I’m still studying that moment of erosion, still admiring rainbows from afar. — Cassandra Lewis

headline: Her Pension Checks Vanished. The Doorman Stole Them, Prosecutors Say.
abstract: A doorman at a building near Columbia University was charged with taking nearly $500,000 from a 91-year-old former resident while she lived in a nursing home.
lead_paragraph: A doorman at an Upper Manhattan building was charged on Wednesday after prosecutors said he embezzled $477,685 from a retired schoolteacher after she left the building for a nursing home and later died.

headline: Outrage in South Africa Over Farmers Accused of Feeding Slain Women to Pigs
abstract: The grisly allegations have set off debate over some of the country’s most explosive issues, including race, gender-based violence and farm ownership.
lead_paragraph: The white-owned farm was well known to residents of a rural community in South Africa as a place where they could get discarded food. But when two Black women ventured onto the farm several weeks ago, they never made it back.

headline: The V.P. Debate Came Down to One Moment
abstract: JD Vance’s response to a question about challenging this year’s election results was telling.
lead_paragraph: The most consequential and revealing exchange during the vice-presidential debate on Tuesday came toward the end, when JD Vance was asked whether he would seek to challenge this year’s election results. That one moment proved that he can’t be trusted with the office he seeks.

headline: Man Who Set Fire to Cabin in the Grand Canyon Gets 20 Months in Prison
abstract: The 21-year-old was arrested in May, shortly after he set fire to his former girlfriend’s residence in the park, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: An Arizona man who set fire to a cabin where his ex-girlfriend was living in Grand Canyon National Park was sentenced last week to 20 months in prison and forced to pay over $20,000 in restitution, according to court documents.

headline: 36 Hours in Edinburgh
abstract: Fall is the ideal time to explore the ruggedly beautiful Scottish capital, which turns 900 this year.
lead_paragraph: Fall is the ideal time to explore the ruggedly beautiful Scottish capital, which turns 900 this year.

headline: A Veep Star Vibe-Checks the Debate
abstract: “This is not a date, it’s a debate!”
lead_paragraph: “This is not a date, it’s a debate!”

headline: What Starts Conversation at a Brooklyn Girl Dinner?
abstract: Inside an intimate gathering with New York’s creative crust to celebrate a colorful shoe.
lead_paragraph: As the vice-presidential debate buzzed over the airways, a lower-stakes debate unfolded in Brooklyn. Adam Brody: cute, hot or handsome?

headline: A ‘Veep’ Star Vibe-Checks the Vance-Walz Showdown
abstract: “This is not a date, it’s a debate!”
lead_paragraph: In the hours since Tim Walz and JD Vance squared off in the only vice-presidential debate of 2024, many journalists, pundits and citizens of the internet have come forth to challenge and fact-check the assertions lobbed by both candidates.

headline: Eugene Gold, Brooklyn D.A. Who Led the ‘Son of Sam’ Case, Dies at 100
abstract: He prosecuted high-profile cases in the 1970s and championed Soviet Jews, but, after retiring, he ran afoul of the law himself, charged with a sex offense.
lead_paragraph: Eugene Gold, a former tough-on-crime Brooklyn district attorney who in the late 1970s spearheaded the successful prosecution of David Berkowitz, the so-called Son of Sam serial killer, died on Aug. 5 at his home in Woodstock, N.Y. He was 100.

headline: Harris Visits Georgia After Hurricane Helene, Promising Federal Help
abstract: The vice president said federal money would play a major role in storm recovery efforts as she met with local officials in Augusta, Ga., and helped hand out food and snacks.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris surveyed damage from Hurricane Helene on Wednesday in Georgia, promising residents that the federal government was rushing to help with the recovery.

headline: The Jewish New Year Is Far More Bitter Than Sweet in Israel
abstract: On Rosh Hashana, many Israelis longed for a return to normalcy after a year of escalating wars for the country.
lead_paragraph: Jews around the world traditionally usher in Rosh Hashana by dipping apples in honey in the hope of sweet times ahead. But Israelis’ celebrations were muted on Wednesday evening amid the nation’s escalating conflicts.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein on the V.P. Debate
abstract: The Oct. 2, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Claire Gordon about the vice-presidential debate between JD Vance and Tim Walz. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: After Flooding, FEMA Aid Is Arriving. But Some Are Still on Their Own.
abstract: Six days after Hurricane Helene, North Carolina was getting help from the Federal Emergency Management Agency and others. But officials still faced obstacles reaching some areas.
lead_paragraph: In the western mountains of North Carolina outside of Asheville, the small communities of Cruso and Canton, wrecked by Hurricane Helene, were not waiting for help from the state or the federal government.

headline: Israel Says at Least 8 Soldiers Are Killed in Clashes With Hezbollah
abstract: The cross-border fighting appeared to be the first direct ground confrontation between the two sides since Israel invaded Lebanon this week.
lead_paragraph: Israeli troops and Hezbollah militants said on Wednesday that they were fighting at close range in southern Lebanon, in what appeared to be the first direct ground confrontation between the two sides since the Israeli invasion began.

headline: Israeli Strikes on Gaza Schools and an Orphanage Kill Scores of Palestinians, Officials Say
abstract: The Palestinian Authority’s official news agency said the Israeli military operation had included an incursion by ground troops and airstrikes.
lead_paragraph: Israeli forces stepped up their attacks on the Gaza Strip overnight and into Wednesday, killing scores of people at several school buildings and homes across the enclave and at an orphanage sheltering displaced civilians, local officials and the Gaza Health Ministry said.

headline: To Build a Nuclear Bomb, Iran Would Need Much More Than Weeks
abstract: Nuclear experts see Tehran as facing up to a year of hard work to master the knotty basics of building a deliverable atom bomb.
lead_paragraph: The first question of the vice-presidential debate on Tuesday night was whether the candidates would support or oppose a pre-emptive strike on Iran by Israel. It framed the issue for Gov. Tim Walz and Senator JD Vance as urgent to consider because Tehran has “drastically reduced the time it would take to develop a nuclear weapon,” cutting its acquisition time to “one or two weeks.”

headline: Gilead Agrees to Allow Generic Version of Groundbreaking H.I.V. Shot in Poor Countries
abstract: Many middle-income countries are left out of the deal, widening a gulf in access to critical medicines.
lead_paragraph: The drugmaker Gilead Sciences on Wednesday announced a plan to allow six generic pharmaceutical companies in Asia and North Africa to make and sell at a lower price its groundbreaking drug lenacapavir, a twice-yearly injection that provides near-total protection from infection with H.I.V.

headline: A Storm, a Strike and War Abroad Pose Challenges for Harris
abstract: Scenes of striking workers, hurricane devastation in the Southeast and missiles over Israel represent a rare moment of turbulence for Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris has cast herself as a candidate of the future, but she has been yanked back by the problems of the present as the Middle East lurches toward a wider war, a longshoremen’s strike threatens to undermine the country’s economy and Americans across the Southeast struggle to recover from a deadly hurricane.

headline: Walz Spoke of Gun Violence Affecting His Son. Here’s an Account of the Shooting.
abstract: At Tuesday’s debate, Gov. Tim Walz said that his son, Gus Walz, witnessed a shooting at a community center. A volleyball coach said Gus helped other young players to safety.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz has spoken before of a shooting last year at a recreation center in St. Paul, Minn., that he said had an impact on his teenage son, Gus. But in the vice-presidential debate with Senator JD Vance of Ohio on Tuesday night, Mr. Walz went further in saying that his son witnessed the shooting, which left one teenager seriously wounded.

headline: ‘There’s No Safety’: Decision to Leave Ends in Tragedy for Lebanese Family
abstract: Zahraa Badreddine fled Nabatieh in southern Lebanon as Israeli airstrikes intensified, hoping to find safety in a predominantly Christian area closer to the coast. But last Sunday, an airstrike near Sidon killed her two children.
lead_paragraph: Zahraa Badreddine fled Nabatieh in southern Lebanon as Israeli airstrikes intensified, hoping to find safety in a predominantly Christian area closer to the coast. But last Sunday, an airstrike near Sidon killed her two children.

headline: Four Takeaways From Jack Smith’s Brief in the Trump Election Case
abstract: The special counsel provided new details that help flesh out how Donald Trump sought to remain in power, while setting out his argument for the case to survive the Supreme Court’s immunity decision.
lead_paragraph: The special counsel who has charged former President Donald J. Trump with a criminal conspiracy over his attempt to overturn his loss of the 2020 election has filed a lengthy brief laying out his key evidence along with an argument for why the case should be able to go forward despite the Supreme Court’s ruling in July on presidential immunity.

headline: Lahaina Inferno Emerged From Smoldering Remnants of Quelled Fire
abstract: Federal investigators have concluded that hidden embers remained from a morning fire in the Hawaii town of Lahaina. They reignited later into a fire that destroyed much of the town.
lead_paragraph: The inferno that consumed the Hawaii town of Lahaina last year emerged from the remnants of a brush fire that firefighters had believed they had contained and extinguished, federal investigators concluded in a report released Wednesday.

headline: Treasurer for Little-Known Brooklyn Candidate Is Charged in Fraud Scheme
abstract: Erlene King sent thousands of dollars to associates and told them to distribute the funds to others who would then donate to the campaign she worked for, federal prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: The treasurer of an ill-fated 2021 campaign for Brooklyn borough president was charged Wednesday with organizing a fraudulent donation scheme in an attempt to access at least $400,000 in public matching funds.

headline: Leaf Maker
abstract: Rena Cohen makes her New York Times Crossword debut, and that’s the truth.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: David Banks, N.Y.C. Schools Chancellor, Moves Up His Departure
abstract: The chancellor, who previously announced that he would step down at the end of December, will instead leave the job on Oct. 16. Melissa Aviles-Ramos, a top deputy, will succeed him.
lead_paragraph: David C. Banks will step down as the New York City schools chancellor on Oct. 16, months earlier than he had previously said he would, City Hall announced on Wednesday.

headline: Mexican Military Fatally Shoots Six Migrants
abstract: The country’s defense ministry said the military officers who opened fire might have mistaken the migrants for cartel members.
lead_paragraph: At least six migrants were killed in southern Mexico on Tuesday night after military officers shot at the vehicle they were traveling in. The episode called attention to a growing concern in Mexico — ever more powerful armed forces that operate with little oversight — and a continuing one, the dangers faced by migrants in the country.

headline: Quote of the Day: As Dockworkers Strike for Higher Wages, Truckers Worry About Their Own Pay
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, October 3, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “It was really creepy, if I can be honest with you. It was dead silent. I’ve never seen that in my entire life.”

headline: In Japan’s Countryside, Century-Old Firms Learn to Embrace Foreign Workers
abstract: Japan’s regional economies are facing severe labor shortages. Their survival depends on their ability to persuade foreign workers to stay.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Hizatsuki Confectionery hired its first foreign workers.

headline: Krathon Slams Taiwan, Bringing Flooding and Landslides
abstract: Two people have been killed and more than 10,000 evacuated, the authorities said. The drenching rain brought damage and widespread power outages from the storm, downgraded to a depression.
lead_paragraph: Tropical Depression Krathon slammed into Taiwan’s populous southwestern coast on Thursday, the authorities said, bringing torrential rain and heavy winds that have caused landslides, floods and power outages. Two people had been killed and over 200 have been injured.

headline: Thursday Briefing: Strikes Leave 6 Dead in Beirut
abstract: Plus, new evidence in the Trump election case.
lead_paragraph: After a day in which Israeli and Hezbollah troops fought at close range in southern Lebanon, Israel kept up its bombing campaign.

headline: Putin Keeps Threatening to Use Nuclear Weapons. Would He?
abstract: Last week the president of Russia appeared to lower the threshold for his country’s use of nuclear weapons. It wasn’t subtle, and it wasn’t meant to be.
lead_paragraph: Last week, President Vladimir Putin announced a plan to change Russia’s nuclear doctrine. He said Russia would be prepared to use a nuclear weapon in response to an attack with conventional weapons that creates a “critical threat to our sovereignty” and would treat “aggression against Russia by any nonnuclear state, but with the participation or support of a nuclear state,” as a “joint attack on the Russian Federation.”

headline: Former Singapore Minister Gets Year in Prison in Rare Graft Case
abstract: The sentence for S. Iswaran, a former transportation minister who pleaded guilty last week, was longer than what prosecutors had sought.
lead_paragraph: A former government minister in Singapore was sentenced to one year in prison on Thursday in a rare graft case that has transfixed the affluent city-state.

headline: Word of the Day: aphorism
abstract: This word has appeared in 20 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word aphorism has appeared in 20 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 17 in “Want to Go Viral? Tell Your Story in 22 Parts” by Madison Malone Kircher:

headline: Late Night Sums Up a Strangely Chill V.P. Debate
abstract: Jimmy Fallon said viewers “were expecting a horror movie, but instead, they got a Hallmark movie.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Typhoon Krathon Makes Landfall in Taiwan
abstract: The deadly storm battered the island with strong winds and heavy rain as it roared ashore near the major southern port city of Kaohsiung.
lead_paragraph: The deadly storm battered the island with strong winds and heavy rain as it roared ashore near the major southern port city of Kaohsiung.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Why Deaths From E-Bike Fires Are Declining in New York City
abstract: Though the fires are occurring about as frequently as they were last year, fewer are happening inside buildings. And there are signs that new safety measures are having an effect.
lead_paragraph: In between food deliveries, Christian Acajabon rode his e-bike to a bustling outdoor plaza in the East Village neighborhood of Manhattan.

headline: Laughing Emojis
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
