abstract: A New Jersey couple sued Uber after a crash left them severely injured. An appeals court ruled that they had agreed to settle disputes out of court when they used the Uber Eats app.
lead_paragraph: A New Jersey couple was heading home from dinner in an Uber in March 2022 when their driver T-boned another car, leaving them with serious injuries, including spine and rib fractures.

headline: Woman With Flowers
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration, or describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: Why Eric Adams Is Nothing Like David Dinkins
abstract: Facing a raft of corruption charges, New York’s second Black mayor is flattering himself by invoking the fate of its first.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks before he was indicted in a federal corruption investigation, Eric Adams, New York City’s second Black mayor, began regularly comparing himself to David Dinkins, the city’s first Black mayor — a pairing so misaligned it could put you in mind of Donald Trump likening himself to someone like Jimmy Carter. The apparent point was to warn New Yorkers that if they did not back his bid for re-election, the city would reprise its racist past, denying another Black mayor a second term. Mr. Dinkins lost his re-election effort to a race-baiting Rudy Giuliani, while the most serious threats to an Adams win — beyond a criminal prosecution — are coming from the progressive left and include candidates like Zellnor Myrie, a Black state senator with immigrant parents.

headline: Late Night Heaps Scorn on Trump’s Latest Defense
abstract: Jimmy Kimmel said Donald Trump was “partially right” in denying interference in the 2020 election: “He tried to rig the election and failed to rig the election.’
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Four Weeks To Go: “The Daily” Politics Roundtable
abstract: With Kamala Harris and Donald Trump locked in the tightest of races, who will come out on top? Listen to our political round table on the 2024 election.
lead_paragraph: With Kamala Harris and Donald Trump locked in the tightest of races, who will come out on top? Listen to our political round table on the 2024 election.

headline: A Near Exact Tie in the Polls
abstract: After an eventful week for the presidential race, the candidates are even in the polls. The Times journalists Nate Cohn, Michael Barbaro, Maggie Haberman and Shane Goldmacher discuss the state of the race, with the Nov. 5 election nearly a month away.
lead_paragraph: After an eventful week for the presidential race, the candidates are even in the polls. The Times journalists Nate Cohn, Michael Barbaro, Maggie Haberman and Shane Goldmacher discuss the state of the race, with the Nov. 5 election nearly a month away.

headline: We Want to Know Your Questions About Theater, Film, Music and Culture
abstract: Your culture and entertainment questions answered by New York Times journalists and experts.
lead_paragraph: When you work on arts and entertainment coverage, and part of the job is keeping up with what’s on TV, or Broadway, or at the Met (both the museum and the opera house), people in your life invariably have questions: What should I watch? What should I read? What do I need to see while I’m in town?

headline: A Compact Weekend House Filled With Comfort
abstract: A couple bought a second home with friends, and then decided that being neighbors would be much more fun.
lead_paragraph: Aya Maceda and Kurt Arnold really didn’t want a second home in the country — or so they thought. But that was before the pandemic coaxed them into sampling rural life in upstate New York.

headline: These Are Boom Times for ‘Degrowth’
abstract: The term has recently begun taking root in popular culture and policy.
lead_paragraph: There’s long been one mantra in mainstream economics: Growth is good.

headline: Just How Much Control Can an Artist Have Over Their Work?
abstract: Cady Noland, who became the darling of the art world, has tested the limits.
lead_paragraph: “WHAT AM I looking at?”

headline: Once More Unto the Breach: A New Take on Henry V Showcases His Contradictions
abstract: In a comprehensive biography, the historian Dan Jones tries to reconcile the hero of legend with the complicated young monarch of reality.
lead_paragraph: Why read a new, 400-page biography of England’s King Henry V? Because, writes the best-selling historian and television journalist Dan Jones, while Henry ruled for less than a decade, “his reign is a case study in the art of leadership in a time of crisis, which feels especially apposite as I write these words today.”

headline: The War’s Toll on Sick Ukrainian Children
abstract: Sonya, a young Ukrainian girl, was being treated for eye cancer. Then Russia invaded Ukraine. Lynsey Addario, a photographer on assignment for The New York Times who has covered every major war and humanitarian crisis of her generation, tells Sonya’s story.
lead_paragraph: Sonya, a young Ukrainian girl, was being treated for eye cancer. Then Russia invaded Ukraine. Lynsey Addario, a photographer on assignment for The New York Times who has covered every major war and humanitarian crisis of her generation, tells Sonya’s story.

headline: Too Scared to Watch Horror Movies? These 5 Tips May Help.
abstract: How to get into the season, even if you’re squeamish.
lead_paragraph: The October ritual of watching horror movies in the lead-up to Halloween can be exhilarating. Unless, of course, you can’t quite stomach the gory and gruesome, or even the spooky and spine-tingling.

headline: 5 Picture Books About Space, From the Sublime to the Silly
abstract: Works by Ada Limón and Peter Sís, Randy Cecil, Lucy Ruth Cummins and more depict the poetry, wonder and droll humor inspired by the great beyond.
lead_paragraph: These are lines from a poem by Ada Limón that has been engraved on Europa Clipper, the space probe NASA will launch on Oct. 10, if all goes well. (One suspects the two American astronauts now enjoying an unplanned stay on the International Space Station will not be holding their breaths.) Limón, the United States poet laureate since 2022, may give humanity too much credit when it comes to our capacity for constant awe, but I suppose positive thinking is part of the job description when you are commissioned to write a poem that will drift around the cosmos for eons and could serve as our calling card. Anne Sexton might be a little dark for impressionable ETs.

headline: How John Lewis Became a Moral Force in America
abstract: In his new biography, David Greenberg tells the full story of the civil rights hero who became a long-serving U.S. representative.
lead_paragraph: John Lewis was enrolled in a seminary in the Jim Crow city of Nashville when he embraced the belief that allowing himself to be beaten nearly to death in public would hasten the collapse of Southern apartheid.

headline: As America’s Marijuana Use Grows, So Do the Harms
abstract: The drug, legal in much of the country, is widely seen as nonaddictive and safe. For some users, these assumptions are dangerously wrong.
lead_paragraph: In midcoast Maine, a pediatrician sees teenagers so dependent on cannabis that they consume it practically all day, every day — “a remarkably scary amount,” she said.

headline: Kamala Harris Is Doing Something Brilliant Up There on the Tightrope
abstract: She’s strong. But she’s warm. That makes all the difference.
lead_paragraph: Given that Kamala Harris is running for the world’s most powerful elected office, it’s no surprise to see voters and pundits commenting on her “power moves” and “boss energy.” What’s remarkable is that they mean it as a compliment. That’s a far cry from the experience of many women — in politics and beyond — who have dared to assert themselves.

headline: She Was Having Bouts of Vision Loss. Why?
abstract: The young woman had been seeing specialists about her symptoms for nearly her entire life. Eighteen years in, she got a diagnosis that made sense.
lead_paragraph: The 22-year-old woman gripped the thick, battered notebook on her lap. It contained her medical records dating back to when she first got sick 18 years earlier. Her parents had always been the ones to bring the notebook to her medical visits. But she had just moved to New York City to go to nursing school, and this was the first time she was seeing a doctor without them. She had an appointment to meet a new physician at the N.Y.U. Langone Multiple Sclerosis Comprehensive Care Center with the hope that he would help her manage the illness she’d been dealing with for as long as she could remember. And maybe even figure out a mystery that none of the many doctors she’d seen had been able to solve: What exactly was wrong with her?

headline: The Supreme Court Should Stop the Glossip Execution
abstract: When prosecutors admit they were wrong in a death penalty case, courts should listen.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 90 years ago, in a case involving prosecutorial misconduct, the Supreme Court laid down its view of a prosecutor’s duty, one that has been widely repeated in court decisions ever since. The prosecution’s interest in a criminal prosecution, the court wrote succinctly, “is not that it shall win a case, but that justice shall be done.”

headline: Bucking Trends, an Opera Company in Atlanta Is Growing
abstract: Under the leadership of Tomer Zvulun, Atlanta Opera powered through the pandemic, has tripled its budget and is producing ambitious work.
lead_paragraph: Walking through a repurposed industrial space in Atlanta one recent afternoon, Tomer Zvulun gestured toward a cafe table in the middle of a wraparound stage covered in graffiti.

headline: In ‘La Máquina,’ Gael García Bernal and Diego Luna Get a Rematch
abstract: For their first screen roles together since 2012, the longtime friends undertook a Spanish-language series about a boxer who must fight for his life.
lead_paragraph: Sitting cross-legged on the floor at the Château Marmont in Los Angeles, Gael García Bernal stared with admiration at his lifelong friend and fellow actor Diego Luna. Just the night before, they had walked onstage at the Peacock Theater and, as expected, presented the Emmy for best director of a limited or anthology series or TV movie.

headline: Farm to Table to Screen: A Close Look at How America Feeds Itself
abstract: “Food and Country” argues that our food production systems don’t work and offers potential solutions.
lead_paragraph: In the early days of the pandemic, I accidentally ordered five chickens and three dozen giant, fragrant Amalfi Coast lemons. I thought I’d ordered one five-pound chicken and three lemons from a local restaurant supplier who’d had to quickly pivot to home cooks like me. But between my frazzled, stressed brain and their usual order quantities, wires got crossed.

headline: DNA Reveals the Origin Stories of America’s Captive Tigers
abstract: Scientists have wondered if the many captive tigers in the United States could one day help restore the species in the wild.
lead_paragraph: In 2020, the Netflix documentary series “Tiger King” introduced the world to America’s large population of captive tigers. Estimates by experts suggest there may be as many as 7,000 of the big cats in the United States today, while only around 5,500 tigers survive in the wild in other countries.

headline: $650,000 Homes in Nova Scotia
abstract: Three takes on a water lifestyle in Canada’s eastern province: A shingled home by the bay, a chic cabin and a contemporary bungalow.
lead_paragraph: This two-unit 1979 home, with a total of seven bedrooms and three baths, is in the community of Barton and sits on a knoll overlooking St. Mary’s Bay, which eventually empties into the Bay of Fundy off Nova Scotia’s west coast. The town of Digby, with a population of about 2,000, is 10 miles east on Annapolis Basin, also off the Bay of Fundy, and offers shopping and dining particularly themed around Digby scallops, for which the town is known. Whale watching is the other popular tourism activity here.

headline: A Death in Childbirth Raises New Questions About a Hospital
abstract: Bevorlin Garcia Barrios, 24, is the third woman to die during childbirth at Woodhull Medical Center in Brooklyn since 2020.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll explore deepening concerns over maternal health care at a Brooklyn hospital where three women have died during childbirth since 2020. We’ll also look at a hearing in the case of Daniel Penny, who choked Jordan Neely to death in a subway last year.

headline: Where to Drink Wine in Montreal
abstract: It’s hard to go wrong in this city, but at these nine casual restaurants and bars, you’ll find exceptional lists of natural wines.
lead_paragraph: Montreal is one of the best cities in North America to drink wine. Great lists are plentiful and relatively inexpensive, particularly for Americans who will benefit from a favorable exchange rate. And invariably, in many of the best wine bars and restaurants, the wine is natural.

headline: Kamala Harris and the Influence of an Estranged Father Just Two Miles Away
abstract: Donald J. Harris rarely speaks to his famous daughter, who lives nearby. But he helped shape who she became.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris recalled a childhood memory of her father in her convention speech two months ago, when she said he exhorted her in an unnamed park to “Run, Kamala, run. Don’t be afraid. Don’t let anything stop you.”

headline: Is Nighttime Depression Really a Thing?
abstract: There are lots of reasons your mood might tank at night. Here’s how to address the bedtime blues.
lead_paragraph: It’s not uncommon for our minds to unleash a torrent of difficult feelings under the cover of darkness: sadness and negative thoughts may surface at night, making sleep hard to come by.

headline: The House That Malin+Goetz Built (And Built Again)
abstract: Follow the journey of Matthew Malin and Andrew Goetz as they recreate their dream house destroyed by fire.
lead_paragraph: Follow the journey of Matthew Malin and Andrew Goetz as they recreate their dream house destroyed by fire.

headline: Pandemic Start-Ups Are Thriving, and Helping to Fuel the Economy
abstract: A record surge in new businesses has helped drive job growth, and could have longer-term benefits.
lead_paragraph: Hector Xu was on track for a career in academia when the pandemic upended his plans.

headline: The World’s Oldest Termite Mound Is 34,000 Years and Counting
abstract: Scientists recently found the planet’s longest continuously occupied termite colony in an arid region of South Africa. It dates to the time of the Neanderthals.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Michele Francis, an environmental scientist at Stellenbosch University in South Africa, relocated to central Connecticut only to discover that her new home showed signs of termite damage. When an exterminator suggested setting out traps, Dr. Francis demurred. “I wondered if I could persuade the termites to eat the trees around my house rather than the house itself,” she said. “I hold termites in high esteem.”

headline: Unpacking the Role JD Vance Played on That Debate Stage
abstract: Neither candidate engaged with the core criticisms facing their parties.
lead_paragraph: This week the hosts discuss what was obscured by the civility of the V.P. debate, and consider what JD Vance and Tim Walz really offer their running mates and their parties’ futures.

headline: 5 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: Directed by Todd Phillips, this crime-thriller-musical follows Joker (Joaquin Phoenix) as he stands trial for murder and falls for Harley Quinn (Lady Gaga) in Arkham Asylum.

headline: What to Know About the 2024 Nobel Prize Winners
abstract: Here are the winners of the six Nobel Prizes awarded this year.
lead_paragraph: Every October, committees in Sweden and Norway name laureates in a variety of prizes related to science, literature and economics, as well as peace work. In total, six prizes are awarded.

headline: Can California Regulate A.I.? + Silicon Valley’s Super Babies + System Update!
abstract: “In the United States, we have 50 laboratories of democracy and they’re called states.”
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California vetoed Senate Bill 1047, an A.I. safety bill that would have curtailed the growth of the technology. What received a lot less attention were the 18 other important A.I. bills he signed into law over the past month. We walk through what is in them and what they mean for the rest of the country. Then, The Information’s Julia Black joins to discuss the baby craze that’s sweeping Silicon Valley, including investment in some wild new fertility technologies. And finally, it’s time for a system update! We get into OpenAI’s massive fund-raising deal and the senator who hopped on a call with a “deepfake” former Ukrainian official.

headline: Oliver Sacks Archive Heads to the New York Public Library
abstract: The voluminous papers of the celebrated neurologist include letters, notebooks, drafts and other traces of a man who couldn’t stop writing.
lead_paragraph: For his 75th birthday, friends of the writer and neurologist Oliver Sacks gave him a printout of his brain scan inscribed with well wishes. Alongside it was a mock-scientific text describing a newly identified condition: “Brilliant Bi-Hemispheric Cortical Balance syndrome.”

headline: The Economy Is at a Hinge Moment
abstract: The economist Jason Furman discusses the economic fights that the next presidential administration will face.
lead_paragraph: We have hit a hinge moment in the economy. For the past few years, there has been one problem on policymakers’ minds: inflation. But in mid-September, the Federal Reserve called an end to that era when it cut interest rates by half a percentage point. Inflation, it was saying, is no longer the problem. It has come down from around 9 percent annually to around 2.5 percent. But unemployment is creeping up again. There are some signs of economic stress. Having spent the past year cooling the economy down, the Fed now feels it’s both safe and necessary to heat it back up, at least a bit.

headline: The One Thing Not Named Trump That Trump Cares About
abstract: For the former president, removing millions of undocumented immigrants is the solution to most of the nation’s most pressing challenges.
lead_paragraph: The centerpiece of Donald Trump’s second-term domestic agenda is the mass deportation of what he and his campaign say are 20 million or even 25 million undocumented immigrants.

headline: ‘It Took Over Everything’: Stories of Marijuana’s Little-Known Risks
abstract: A growing number of marijuana users in the U.S. are experiencing severe health problems like these.
lead_paragraph: As marijuana legalization spreads across the country, people are consuming more of the drug, more often and at ever-higher potencies. Most of the tens of millions of people using marijuana, for health benefits or for fun, don’t experience problems. But a growing number, mainly heavy users, have experienced addiction, psychosis and other harmful effects, The New York Times found.

headline: What Does College Football Have to Do With College?
abstract: The question isn’t new. But seismic changes to college sports, embraced by Coach Deion Sanders and his University of Colorado Buffaloes, have made it more relevant than ever.
lead_paragraph: The black sky emptied as about 50,000 rain-soaked University of Colorado football fans exhaled in improbable joy at Folsom Field. This was after the Hail Mary pass caught as time expired, after the game-clinching fumble that squirted out of the end zone in overtime.

headline: Researchers Find Cannibalized Victim of 19th-Century Arctic Voyage
abstract: A new study offers clues to a 179-year-old mystery that killed more than 100 explorers on the Franklin expedition in the Canadian Arctic.
lead_paragraph: Into the frozen fray they went, the explorer Sir John Franklin and his crew of 128 men, sailing from England in 1845 in search of the Northwest Passage. And there, in the unforgiving expanse of the Canadian Arctic, they perished. No one knows exactly what happened.

headline: Democrats Have a Corruption Problem. They Can’t Keep Ignoring It.
abstract: For the sake of their electoral fortunes and the country, Democrats must show voters a plan to curb corruption — including within their own ranks.
lead_paragraph: For the past eight years and across two impeachment trials, the Democratic Party has defined itself in opposition to Donald Trump’s corruption, assailing the ways he abused the presidency for his own financial and political benefit. But with Mayor Eric Adams of New York fighting a federal corruption indictment, former Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey awaiting sentencing for a similar fraud and bribery scheme and numerous California officials sitting in federal prison, it’s hard to deny that corruption is a bipartisan problem.

headline: Is Katy Perry’s ‘143’ Really That Bad?
abstract: Our critic says it’s complicated.
lead_paragraph: Katy Perry released her seventh studio album, ”143,” last week to nearly universal critical disdain. But the magnitude and gleeful nature of the vitriol were not caused by her bland new music alone.On today’s episode of “The Culture Desk,” Melissa Kirsch, deputy editor of culture and lifestyle, talks with the pop music critic Lindsay Zoladz about why the reaction to “143” has been especially intense in this current cultural moment.

headline: How to Stage a Viral Fashion Show
abstract: The French house Coperni closed Paris Fashion Week with a show at Disneyland Paris, capped off with a surprise runway appearance by Kylie Jenner.
lead_paragraph: On the final night of Paris Fashion Week, everyone went to Disneyland.

headline: 4 Ways to Turn Around a Bad Day
abstract: There’s still time to salvage it.
lead_paragraph: When I hit midlife, I discovered that you can pull a muscle in all kinds of new ways: sneezing, parking a car. And, as I found out last week, you can tweak your back just getting out of bed.

headline: Every Election Has Big Swings, Even in a Polarized Country. This One Will Too.
abstract: In just the last few years, any number of issues might have led people to reconsider their loyalties.
lead_paragraph: In today’s polarized era, it’s easy to assume that nothing ever matters in American politics — that every four years, the same election happens over and over, with the same demographic groups lining up behind the same candidates in the same states.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Oct. 4, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the sequel “Joker: Folie à Deux.”
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the sequel “Joker: Folie à Deux.”

headline: Obama, Democrats’ Elder Statesman, Will Stump for Harris in Final Election Push
abstract: Mr. Obama, the first Black president, had cast Vice President Kamala Harris as the inheritor of his political movement in a speech at the Democratic convention.
lead_paragraph: Former President Barack Obama, the popular elder statesman of the Democratic Party, will stump for Vice President Kamala Harris in battleground states in the month before Election Day, beginning with a campaign stop next Thursday in Pittsburgh.

headline: The Bold. The Beautiful. The Fat Bear.
abstract: Ten years in, Fat Bear Week has drawn millions of viewers to a live webcam in Alaska to follow along and vote for the chonkiest brown bear at Katmai National Park.
lead_paragraph: Voters have a lot to weigh: leadership qualities, policy agenda, experience. But over the past decade, one race has been defined by the amount of wild salmon that can be smashed into a mouth.

headline: ‘Mom, I Want to Live’: A Young Girl Battles War and Cancer
abstract: Sonya Liakh was diagnosed with eye cancer at age 2. After Russia’s invasion of Ukraine disrupted her treatment, her family faced a desperate struggle.
lead_paragraph: Splayed out on a pink bedspread, wearing a pink tank top and surrounded by stuffed pink unicorns, 6-year-old Sonya Liakh unscrewed the port to the catheter in her chest. She took a pre-filled syringe of morphine from the tray held by the nurse beside her, deftly inserted the syringe into her port, and pushed the contents into her jugular vein.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,204
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Oct. 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 482
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Oct. 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Four Weeks to Go
abstract: With Kamala Harris and Donald Trump locked in the tightest of races, who will come out on top? Watch or listen to our political round table on the 2024 election.
lead_paragraph: With Election Day fast approaching, polls show the race between Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump to be the closest in a generation.

headline: Oil Prices Rise on Biden’s Offhand Remarks, and U.S. Ports Reopen
abstract: Plus, the top trends from fashion month.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Europe Raises Tariffs on China’s E.V.s, Confronting a Key Trade Partner
abstract: European Union officials say the duties are meant to protect the region’s automakers from what they say are unfair trade practices in China.
lead_paragraph: The European Union voted on Friday to impose higher tariffs on electric vehicles imported from China, risking tensions with an important trading partner in an effort to protect an industry crucial to Europe’s economy.

headline: Labor Market Shows Unexpected Strength
abstract: U.S. employers added 254,000 jobs in September, a sign that economic growth remained solid. The unemployment rate fell to 4.1 percent.
lead_paragraph: Many have doubted it. Even the optimists have worried about it. But despite the hand-wringing, the American economy appears to be in remarkably good shape.

headline: A Crackdown
abstract: We explain the Biden administration’s shift on immigration.
lead_paragraph: For much of the Biden administration’s first three years in office, migration surged at the Mexican border. Administration officials frequently argued that the problem was beyond their control — a reflection not of U.S. policy but of global forces pushing people toward the border.

headline: FIFA Limits on Player Transfers Are Illegal, Europe’s Top Court Rules
abstract: A decision could force soccer’s governing body to rewrite the regulations that govern the sport’s multibillion-dollar transfer market.
lead_paragraph: Europe’s top court ruled on Friday that some elements of soccer’s multibillion-dollar global player trading market are illegal, a decision that is likely to force changes to the way thousands of athletes move between teams around the world every year.

headline: Israel Expands Evacuation Warnings in Southern Lebanon After Renewed Strikes
abstract: Israeli soldiers were also waging a ground invasion in southern Lebanon targeting what military officials said were Hezbollah sites in the rugged border area.
lead_paragraph: Israel appeared to expand its military operations in Lebanon on Friday, issuing new evacuation warnings across the south and bombing a border crossing with Syria, hours after a series of airstrikes shook the outskirts of the Lebanese capital, Beirut.

headline: Would You Want to Be a Child Star?
abstract: Jenna Ortega tells Times readers about the joys and the challenges of stardom at a young age. What can we learn from her experience?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever dreamed of being a child star?

headline: Exploring Your Political Identity and Values: A How-To Guide for Our 2024 Coming of Age Contest
abstract: Four steps to figuring out what you want to say and how you would like to say it, with inspiration from 31 teen-created works across genres.
lead_paragraph: What can you show or tell us to help explain what it’s like to grow up in this political moment?

headline: Jobs and Oil Prices Are Keeping Markets on Edge
abstract: Friday’s jobs report could bolster the view that the American economy is holding steady, but an oil price shock could undercut that sense of calm.
lead_paragraph: With just over a month to go until Election Day, Friday’s jobs report, set to be published at 8:30 a.m. Eastern, has outsize importance. Investors will look for clues to what the Fed might do next with interest rates, as well as how the economy is doing.

headline: Britain Backs Plan to Store Carbon Dioxide Under the Sea
abstract: Two proposals in Northern England, led by the energy giants BP and Eni, aim to establish an industry in burying emissions from industrial plants.
lead_paragraph: The British government said Friday that it would back two large proposals to capture carbon dioxide emissions from industrial plants and bury the gas beneath the sea.

headline: At Least 16 Die as Floods Sweep Through Bosnia
abstract: A severe overnight rainstorm in the Balkans left several towns and villages flooded. Record summer temperatures had caused a drought that hampered the absorption of floodwaters.
lead_paragraph: A night of heavy rainfall left at least 16 people dead and large parts of southern Bosnia under water or smothered by landslides, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: In a Rare Sermon, Iran’s Supreme Leader Praises Oct. 7 Attacks as ‘Logical’ and Warns Israel
abstract: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who led Friday prayers for the first time in years, called for pan-Muslim unity against Israel and the United States at a memorial service for Hassan Nasrallah.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, led Friday prayers for the first time in almost five years, delivering a sermon during a memorial service in Tehran for Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, in which he railed against Israel and warned of further retaliation, if necessary, for its actions.

headline: How States Are Enticing Employers to Help Their Workers Save for College
abstract: With college costs high, at least eight states now offer tax credits or deductions for employers that contribute to workers’ 529 accounts.
lead_paragraph: As higher education becomes ever more expensive, some states are giving employers incentives to contribute to 529 college savings accounts for their workers.

headline: Meta Unveils Instant A.I. Video Generator That Adds Sounds
abstract: The tech giant is among the many companies building technology that could remake Hollywood — or help spread disinformation.
lead_paragraph: In February, the artificial intelligence start-up OpenAI unveiled technology called Sora that let people generate photorealistic videos — like woolly mammoths trotting through a snowy meadow — simply by typing a sentence into a box on a computer screen.

headline: The Jobs Report Is Good News for the Fed
abstract: The data reversed recent signs of a labor market slowdown, probably taking away the argument for a big rate cut at the Federal Reserve’s next meeting.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials have been watching the job market closely, wary that it might be cracking under the pressure of high interest rates. The September employment report does a lot to alleviate those concerns.

headline: Gender Identity Changes Must Be Recognized Across E.U. Borders, Court Rules
abstract: A man who changed his name and gender identity in Britain successfully challenged to have them legally recognized by Romania. “I’m representing everyone who is affected.”
lead_paragraph: The European Union’s top court on Friday said governments in the bloc must recognize legal changes to a person’s gender identity and name made in other E.U. nations, a milestone ruling that rights campaigners say will give transgender people more freedom to live and work around the region.

headline: China Buys Nearly All of Iran’s Oil Exports, but Has Options if Israel Attacks
abstract: China has strategic reserves and alternatives like electric cars, should oil imports ever be interrupted.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s oil infrastructure has been pushed to the center of the escalating conflict in the Middle East, but an Israeli strike on Iran’s energy facilities would also affect China directly.

headline: Scientists Found a Surprising Way to Make Fungus Happy
abstract: The discovery that sound improves the growth rate of beneficial fungus suggests that dirges in the dirt may help restore forests.
lead_paragraph: The soil beneath our feet, home to fungi, bacteria, beetles and worms, may not seem like the most jazzy environment. But if you stuck a powerful enough microphone in the soil, you’d be surprised at how hopping it is, acoustically speaking. That has led some microbiologists to wonder: Are there sounds that actually encourage microorganisms to grow? And could serenading a fungus make it twist and shout?

headline: Saoirse Ronan Has Lived, and Acted, Through a Lot
abstract: At 30, the Irish actress has already spent two decades in front of the camera, collecting many awards. Her two latest projects are also generating Oscars buzz.
lead_paragraph: “I wish I could live through something,” says the teenage title character in the 2017 movie “Lady Bird,” yearning for a life beyond suburban Sacramento.

headline: In Georgia, Black Men’s Frustration With Democrats Creates Opening for Trump
abstract: Most Black men in the key battleground will back Vice President Kamala Harris — but the Trump campaign has made an effort to capitalize on a sense of dissatisfaction some voters have expressed.
lead_paragraph: Over the last month, Freddie Hicks, 23, has received dozens of Republican mailers addressed to him at his home in deep-blue DeKalb County, an Atlanta suburb.

headline: The Job Market Is Chugging Along, Completing a Solid Economic Picture
abstract: After months of wobbling, a fresh jobs report showed that hiring and wage growth are strong, aligning with other robust economic data.
lead_paragraph: For months, the economy has been like a jigsaw with one mismatched piece: Consumer spending has been holding up and overall growth has been solid, but the job market has looked treacherously wobbly.

headline: Jobs Report Adds to Economic Momentum for Harris
abstract: Recent reports have shown inflation slowing and the economy growing at a robust clip. The Fed has also cut interest rates, bringing mortgage rates down.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris probably could not have hoped for a better run of pre-election economic data than what the United States has enjoyed over the last month.

headline: Supreme Court to Decide Whether Mexico Can Sue U.S. Gun Makers
abstract: The justices will consider whether a 2005 law that gives gun makers broad immunity applies in the case, which accuses them of complicity in supplying cartels with weapons.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide whether Mexico may sue gun manufacturers in the United States for aiding in the trafficking of weapons used by drug cartels.

headline: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include cool fighter pilots, a feminist queen and urban turf wars.
lead_paragraph: “Born to Fly,” a flashy, adrenaline-pumping film from the Chinese director Liu Xiaoshi, has a lot in common with “Top Gun.” Like Tom Cruise’s Maverick, Lei Yu (Wang Yibo) is a cocky fighter pilot with big potential. Yu is sent to a flight school for exceptional test pilots, who fly next-generation planes to their breaking points. The academy then gathers data from the extreme flights to train combat fliers. Yu, again with echoes of Maverick, starts out declaring, “No one knows the limits better than I do,” before becoming a team player.

headline: 5 New Horror Movies to Stream for Halloween
abstract: Out this week, a period possession movie starring Sarah Paulson, a chef-driven supernatural thriller starring Ariana DeBose and more.
lead_paragraph: A mother braves the elements, and evil, in this busy but hackneyed feature debut from the directors Karrie Crouse and Will Joines.

headline: Orange Beef Will Cure What Ails You
abstract: It’s takeout-style Chinese American cooking brought into your home kitchen, where you can get as creative as you’d like.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The way things usually work for me this time of year: Weekdays are beautiful, crisp and clear. Guides I know text me at work with shots of beautiful fish caught by their grateful clients.

headline: Adapting to the Champions League’s New Reality
abstract: This year more than ever is showing that the competition means different things to different clubs. And that’s a good thing.
lead_paragraph: Lille’s players lingered on the field at the Stade Pierre-Mauroy, communing with their fans. The stands were still full, long after the game had finished, and the party was showing no signs of ending. Ethan Mbappé — famous name, if not quite a familiar face — wore the broad grin of a man who was going to take considerable pleasure in messaging his brother later.

headline: Arts District, Decades in the Making, in Ruins After Helene
abstract: The hurricane damaged an estimated 80 percent of the buildings in the River Arts District of Asheville, N.C., and upended the lives of artists who had recast the city as a cultural force.
lead_paragraph: The French Broad River provided a scenic backdrop as an industrial neighborhood in Asheville transformed over the past 40 years into the River Arts District, a vibrant creative hub for art studios and galleries.

headline: At Least 70 People Dead in Gang Attack in Haiti
abstract: The assault took place in a key agricultural region, which has seen a surge in gang violence.
lead_paragraph: The gang members, armed with automatic weapons, stormed into the small town of Pont-Sondé in central Haiti at around 3 a.m. on Thursday.

headline: Extreme Weather Gives Video Games a Powerful Adversary
abstract: Designers are increasingly able to render weather conditions as not just evocative visual effects but phenomena that physically affect the player.
lead_paragraph: The storms start off small in the vehicular survival game Pacific Drive. Raindrops fall on the windshield, as lightning cracks ominously in the distance. In a few minutes, the pristine Olympic Peninsula will shake with nature’s full terrible force.

headline: Engaging With a Conservative on Campus
abstract: Responses to a conservative professor’s guest essay. Also: JD Vance at the debate; caring for child caregivers; smaller restaurant portions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Undecided Voters Tell Us About Their Biggest Worries
abstract: Donald J. Trump and Kamala Harris are starkly different presidential candidates. So why are so many voters —  roughly 1 in 6 — still unsure of their choice?
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Kamala Harris are starkly different presidential candidates. So why are so many voters —  roughly 1 in 6 — still unsure of their choice?

headline: What Game Theory Tells Us About the Threat of an Israel-Iran War
abstract: Each side must predict how the other will react to avoid mutual destruction.
lead_paragraph: For years, the conflict between Israel and Iran had unofficial but fairly clear rules, allowing the enemies to maintain an uneasy equilibrium in the Middle East.

headline: 69 Percent of New Yorkers Think Eric Adams Should Resign, Poll Shows
abstract: Just 26 percent of New York City residents approve of the mayor and a majority want him to step down, according to a poll taken after his indictment on corruption charges.
lead_paragraph: Most New York City residents think Mayor Eric Adams broke the law, is doing a bad job as mayor and should resign, according to a poll released Friday, the first since he was indicted last week on bribery and corruption charges.

headline: Supreme Court Lets Biden Plans on Mercury and Methane Move Forward
abstract: Republican-led states and industry groups argued that the Environmental Protection Agency had moved too fast and imposed onerous regulations.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court said on Friday that it would not stop the Biden administration from enforcing rules to reduce emissions of two pollutants: mercury, a hazardous neurotoxin, and methane, a potent greenhouse gas.

headline: Nibi the Beaver’s Future Reached the Courts. Then the Massachusetts Governor Stepped In.
abstract: Nibi the beaver was saved by a wildlife rescue. But then she was ordered released into the wild. Her fate was on the line.
lead_paragraph: This is a story about wildlife, about bureaucracy, about politics, about the internet.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: This week, the hosts focused mostly on the vice-presidential debate but took a moment to discuss recent inflammatory comments by former President Trump.
lead_paragraph: This week, the hosts focused mostly on the vice-presidential debate but took a moment to discuss recent inflammatory comments by former President Trump.

headline: New Los Angeles Police Chief Is a Conventional Choice
abstract: Mayor Karen Bass named Jim McDonnell as the new Los Angeles Police Department chief, one of the nation’s highest-profile law enforcement jobs.
lead_paragraph: As Mayor Karen Bass of Los Angeles spent the last few months talking to police officers at daily roll calls, a consistent theme emerged: Morale is so low that rank-and-file officers are unwilling to recruit others to their depleted department.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg Tries His Hand at Fashion
abstract: Et tu, Zuck?
lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg would like us all to know that learning is best achieved through suffering.

headline: How Does Your Facial Hair Make You Feel?
abstract: We want to hear about how women’s experiences of having visible facial hair impact their day-to-day.
lead_paragraph: Many women have visible facial hair. It can be a part of our appearances from a young age or can increase as we get older. Sometimes it’s caused by hormone imbalances, but in most cases it’s simply a part of life. But despite its prevalence, some women feel shame around it.

headline: 3 Warming Dishes for Crisp Fall Days
abstract: Carolina Gelen, a cookbook author and video personality, shares cozy vegetable recipes from her childhood in Romania.
lead_paragraph: I remember the first time my mother allowed me to bake by myself: I must’ve been 6 or 7 when I made poppy seed-coated pretzel bagels. Of course, I forgot the salt in the dough, and they ended up a little bland. But I had found my passion.

headline: Hamas Leader Is Holding Out for a Bigger War, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: Yahya Sinwar is increasingly fatalistic, has blocked a cease-fire deal and, so far, been frustrated that Hezbollah and Iran have not come to his aid, officials said.
lead_paragraph: The leader of Hamas, Yahya Sinwar, has become fatalistic after nearly a year of war in Gaza and is determined to see Israel embroiled in a wider regional conflict, U.S. officials said.

headline: Bring Up the Bodies in 4 New Crime Novels
abstract: Our crime columnist on books by Kate Atkinson, Nicholas Meyer, Marcie R. Rendon and Nilanjana Roy.
lead_paragraph: Kate Atkinson has been dazzling readers ever since her 1995 debut, “Behind the Scenes at the Museum,” about a spectacularly dysfunctional Yorkshire family. She embraced speculative fiction with “Life After Life,” spy fiction with “Transcription,” historical adventure with “Shrines of Gaiety” and crime fiction with her series featuring the private investigator Jackson Brodie.

headline: Capturing a Community in Ruin
abstract: After years of documenting the effects of climate change in his home state of North Carolina, a photographer found himself in the path of a hurricane.
lead_paragraph: It was 4 a.m. and my wife and I lay awake as the rain hammered our metal roof. The trees silhouetted against the night sky whipped violently back and forth.

headline: Inside a Republican Ad Accusing Jon Tester of Flip-Flopping on Immigration
abstract: A Republican group is using misleading language about the Montana senator’s support for a bipartisan immigration bill in 2013 to accuse him of selling out to the Washington establishment.
lead_paragraph: The Republican political action committee American Crossroads has spent just over $2 million on this 30-second television advertisement supporting Tim Sheehy, the Republican candidate for Senate in deep-red Montana who is trying to unseat Senator Jon Tester, the Democratic incumbent. The outcome of the race could determine control of the chamber, and both parties are spending in accordance with the high stakes. American Crossroads began airing this particular spot in late September, according to AdImpact.

headline: Severe Rainstorm Floods Parts of Southern Bosnia
abstract: Heavy rainfall left multiple towns and villages flooded across southern Bosnia.
lead_paragraph: Heavy rainfall left multiple towns and villages flooded across southern Bosnia.

headline: Lauren Mayberry’s Lush Pop Ecstasy, and 13 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Bartees Strange, the Smile, Ela Minus and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: The Savannah Bananas Needed a Bigger Stage
abstract: Everyone’s favorite dancing baseball team is taking its act almost exclusively to M.L.B. and football stadiums in 2025, with even more extreme changes on the horizon.
lead_paragraph: Getting tickets to Savannah Bananas games over the last few years has been so difficult that the barnstorming baseball team has drawn comparisons to Taylor Swift. And like Ms. Swift, the Bananas, who have danced their way to national stardom, will be taking their act from intimate venues to almost exclusively giant stadiums in 2025.

headline: 10 Unforgettable Kris Kristofferson Covers
abstract: Many of his songs are better known by other singers’ interpretations, like Janis Joplin’s “Me and Bobby McGee,” Johnny Cash’s “Sunday Morning Coming Down” and more.
lead_paragraph: “You can look at Nashville pre-Kris and post-Kris,” Bob Dylan once said of Kris Kristofferson, who died on Saturday, “because he changed everything.”

headline: Disaster Funding Has Its Own Perils
abstract: Congressional leaders deferred a debate over sending federal money to respond to Hurricane Helene until after the election, delaying a potentially messy political fight.
lead_paragraph: When congressional leaders decided not to call lawmakers back from the campaign trail for an emergency session to fund relief and rebuilding efforts after Hurricane Helene, they cited practical considerations.

headline: Syria, Russia Remain Silent on Reported Airstrikes Near a Russian Base in Syria
abstract: A weapons facility near a Russian air base in a coastal Syrian city was destroyed on Thursday, according to a monitoring group.
lead_paragraph: Airstrikes hit an ammunition warehouse near a large Russian air base in northern Syria, a Britain-based monitoring group and a Russian military blogger close to Moscow’s defense ministry said on Thursday.

headline: As Bird Flu Spreads, Two New Cases Diagnosed in California
abstract: Both patients were dairy workers whose illnesses were mild. Investigators are continuing to evaluate the contacts of a Missouri patient who had no exposure to animals.
lead_paragraph: Two more people were diagnosed with bird flu this week, even as scientists in Missouri continued to investigate a possible cluster of infections in that state, federal health officials said at a news briefing on Friday.

headline: Conservative Activists Are Monitoring, and Filming, Voter Registration Sites
abstract: In Arizona and other states, the activists are accusing Latino advocacy groups of registering undocumented immigrants. Canvassers are growing concerned about safety.
lead_paragraph: One sweltering morning in Phoenix, four workers from a Latino nonprofit stood with clipboards outside a motor-vehicle office to do the grunt work of democracy: persuading reluctant Americans to register to vote.

headline: Jean Hanff Korelitz on ‘The Sequel’
abstract: The writer discusses her follow-up to her best-selling 2021 novel “The Plot.”
lead_paragraph: In 2021, the novelist Jean Hanff Korelitz had a hit with “The Plot,” a book that was partly a mystery, partly a thriller and entirely a delicious sendup of the publishing industry. It told the tale of a once-promising writer, Jacob, who steals somebody else’s story idea and reaches undreamed-of levels of success before things go very badly for him.

headline: Biden Will Allow Legal Permission to Lapse for Migrants From 4 Countries
abstract: The decision comes as political pressure mounts to cut down on programs that allow migrants to stay in the United States temporarily, even without a visa or green card.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration said Friday it would allow the temporary legal permission for migrants from Cuba, Venezuela, Haiti, and Nicaragua to lapse, forcing hundreds of thousands of people to find other methods to stay in the country or face deportation.

headline: I’m a Queer Man Who Had a Fling With Another Guy. Should His Girlfriend Be Told?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on who has the right and responsibility to reveal an affair.
lead_paragraph: I’m a man who recently had a fling with a man who is in a monogamous heterosexual relationship. We had sex twice. While I am in a nonmonogamous relationship myself, I respect the practice of monogamy. Normally I wouldn’t get involved with someone who is unfaithful. But here I felt my moral obligations to a struggling member of my own queer community were greater than those to his partner.

headline: ‘Megalopolis’ and the Vexations of Decadence
abstract: A story that’s grist for big debates without necessarily being a good movie.
lead_paragraph: “Megalopolis,” the 85-year-old Francis Ford Coppola’s $140 million passion project, is not by any stretch of the imagination a good movie. It’s easy to understand why he had to fund it largely out of his own pocket, notwithstanding his name and reputation. And as with many later Coppola movies, it’s hard to understand how the artist who made “The Godfather,” “The Conversation” and “Apocalypse Now” could also be responsible for some of his newest film’s creative choices.

headline: The Dollar Is Too Strong for America’s Own Good
abstract: Weakening the dollar is a good idea. How to do it is another question.
lead_paragraph: The economist Richard Koo built pianos in Hong Kong for his father-in-law for a year and a half between college and graduate school. Now he is the chief economist of Nomura Research Institute in Japan.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, October 5, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: ‘The Franchise’ Review: Cutting Marvel Down to Size
abstract: A new HBO comedy takes a jaundiced look at the making of a second-rate superhero film.
lead_paragraph: The new HBO series “The Franchise” satirizes the making of a superhero movie by a fictional movie studio that is Marvel in all but name. (The actual fictional name is Maximum Studios.) Warner Bros. Discovery, HBO’s parent, is Marvel’s bitter rival in the superhero field, so you might expect the show to offer an extra measure of savage mockery.

headline: Biden Says the Election Will Be Fair. But He’s Not Sure It Will Be Peaceful.
abstract: President Biden’s remarks underscore the concerns in the government about the possibility of violence during or after the election.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said Friday he was not sure next month’s election would be peaceful if former President Donald J. Trump lost his bid for another term in the White House.

headline: Iran’s Foreign Minister Reaches Out to Arab Leaders in Lebanon, Qatar
abstract: Iran’s top diplomat appeared eager to convey Iran’s readiness to support a joint cease-fire in Lebanon and in Gaza — even as Iran’s supreme leader at home expressed readiness to fight Israel.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, was in Lebanon on Friday after meetings with leaders of Gulf countries earlier in the week in Qatar, where he and Iran’s President Masoud Pezeshkian endeavored to shore up relations with some of Iran’s closest neighbors.

headline: A Pentagon Debate: Are U.S. Deployments Containing the Fighting, or Inflaming It?
abstract: Military officials discuss whether sending more force to the Middle East is helping to prevent a much wider war, or emboldening Israel.
lead_paragraph: As the Israeli offensive in Lebanon expands to include ground incursions and intensifying airstrikes, senior Pentagon officials are discussing whether the enhanced U.S. military presence in the region is containing a widening war, as they had hoped, or inflaming it.

headline: Trump’s Return to Butler Is Sure to Be a Spectacle. Is It Safe?
abstract: At a time of increased security risks, the former president has urged thousands of supporters to return with him to the place a gunman tried to take his life.
lead_paragraph: Five days after being shot by a would-be assassin in Butler, Pa., former President Donald J. Trump stood onstage at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, surrounded by images of his blood-streaked face. “I will tell you exactly what happened, and you’ll never hear it from me a second time,” he said, “because it’s actually too painful to tell.”

headline: A Once-Dormant Hurricane Season Is Spinning Into Action
abstract: Technically, the hurricane season has fallen short of the “hyperactive” forecast, but in some ways it hasn’t.
lead_paragraph: There are just under two months left before the official Atlantic hurricane season ends in November, and with millions of people across the Southeast United States still assessing the damage of Hurricane Helene and two more storms churning at sea, experts are warning it isn’t over yet. It may even last into December.

headline: For Savannah, It’s Not Just a Port. It’s an Economy.
abstract: The Georgia city is a picturesque tourist destination. It’s also the No. 2 ocean cargo hub on the East Coast, and the dock strike’s quick end was a relief.
lead_paragraph: Viewed through a narrow lens, Savannah is a popular tourist destination with a seemingly aesthetic profile, accentuated by its Revolutionary War history, historic Black churches and colorful Victorian homes surrounded by Spanish moss.

headline: Harris Ad to Showcase Support of Liz Cheney and Other Republicans
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris has been seeking to give Republicans who dislike the former president a permission structure to support her instead.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign will air a new ad in battleground states featuring endorsements from a retired general, former members of the Trump administration and former Representative Liz Cheney.

headline: Death Penalty, Nuclear Waste and More: Supreme Court Rounds Out Coming Term
abstract: Three cases all stem from the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, which often finds itself to the right of the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Friday added more than a dozen cases to the docket for its new term, which begins next week.

headline: Trump Takes Aim at Legal Immigration
abstract: The former president and his allies, who often decry undocumented immigrants, are targeting programs that allow millions of people to enter the country lawfully.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump, who is seeking re-election on the same hard line against undocumented immigrants that helped carry him to power in 2016, has said he is not opposed to legal immigration into the United States.

headline: Joe D. Bryan, 84, Dies; His Murder Conviction Raised Troubling Questions
abstract: After serving 33 years in prison, he was released in the wake of a cascade of questions about the soundness of the forensic testimony against him.
lead_paragraph: Joe D. Bryan, a former high school principal who was released from prison in Texas after serving 33 years for a murder conviction based on expert testimony that was later discredited, and whose claims of innocence drew intense media scrutiny, died on Sept. 22 at his home in Houston. He was 84.

headline: In Key Nevada County, Harassment of Election Workers Takes a Toll
abstract: Republicans this year attempted to block certification of local elections in Washoe, a critical swing county — a worrying sign for what could be ahead, the Democratic secretary of state said.
lead_paragraph: Cari-Ann Burgess, the interim registrar of voters for Nevada’s Washoe County, was the third top elections official the county had seen in four years.

headline: Ex-OceanGate Employee’s Remarks Hint at Titan Disaster Lawsuits to Come
abstract: A former Coast Guard specialist’s testimony capped two weeks of hearings into the implosion of a submersible that killed five during an attempt to explore the Titanic.
lead_paragraph: It happened in 2017 at the Scuttlebutt Family Pub down by the docks in Everett, Wash., just steps from where OceanGate was building a new kind of undersea craft. The low-cost submersible was to be so large and strong that it could take five people down miles to see the Titanic up close.

headline: Biden Voices Concern That the Election May Not Be ‘Peaceful’
abstract: President Biden said he was confident next month’s election would be free and fair, but that he was concerned about what former President Donald J. Trump and his supporters would do if he lost his bid for another term.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said he was confident next month’s election would be free and fair, but that he was concerned about what former President Donald J. Trump and his supporters would do if he lost his bid for another term.

headline: Ports Rush to Reopen After First Major Strike in Decades Is Suspended
abstract: Days after tens of thousands of longshoremen along the East and Gulf Coasts walked out, their union and their bosses reached a tentative agreement on wages.
lead_paragraph: Hours after a longshoremen’s union on the East and Gulf Coasts agreed to suspend its strike, major ports rushed to reopen on Friday and get cargo to businesses that have spent the last few days racked with fear over lost sales.

headline: Trump Falsely Promotes Endorsement From Banker Who Hasn’t Endorsed Him
abstract: As the campaign reaches its final month, the Republican nominee is intensifying his pattern of making false and outlandish statements.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump announced what would have been groundbreaking news on Wall Street, in a post on his social media website, Truth Social, on Friday afternoon. At 1:56 p.m., Mr. Trump published, alongside a siren emoji, a claim that he’d been endorsed by America’s most influential banker, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, Jamie Dimon.

headline: In Rare Visit to White House Press Briefing, Biden Cautions Israel
abstract: The president suggested that Israel should consider alternative ways to retaliate against Iran.
lead_paragraph: A day after President Biden said the United States was “in discussion” about the possibility that Israel might strike Iran’s vast oil fields, he suggested that Israel should consider alternative ways to retaliate against Iran.

headline: U.S. Conducts Strikes Against Houthis in Yemen
abstract: The Houthis have been attacking ships in the Red Sea in solidarity with Hamas, and the U.S. attacks were aimed at securing international waterways.
lead_paragraph: The United States Central Command said on Friday that it struck Houthi targets in Yemen, including “Houthi offensive military capabilities,” in an effort to secure international waterways.

headline: Entire Chicago Education Board to Resign Amid Tensions Between Mayor and Schools Chief
abstract: Mayor Brandon Johnson has been at odds with the head of Chicago Public Schools over his plan to fill a $1 billion gap in the district’s budget.
lead_paragraph: All of Chicago’s board of education members announced their resignations on Friday amid tense disagreements between Mayor Brandon Johnson and the chief executive of Chicago Public Schools over the school district’s budget next year.

headline: Yoga to the People Founder Pleads Guilty to Tax Evasion
abstract: Gregory Gumucio, the founder and co-owner of Yoga to the People, which provided yogis with cheap classes in an atmosphere of bohemian glamour, faces up to five years in prison.
lead_paragraph: The founder and co-owner of Yoga to the People, a wildly successful chain of studios that began in the East Village of Manhattan and later spread to nearly half a dozen states outside New York before closing in 2020, pleaded guilty to federal tax evasion on Friday.

headline: The Economy Looks Strong After the Latest Jobs Report
abstract: Also, Trump is returning to the site where he was shot. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: The American labor market, which for months has worried even some optimistic economists, looked in remarkably good shape today after the government released a new employment report. Businesses added 254,000 jobs last month, far outpacing expectations. The unemployment rate declined to 4.1 percent and wage growth remained strong.

headline: Judge Halts Biden Student Debt Plan Right After It Was Allowed to Proceed
abstract: The ruling was the latest instance of legal whiplash for the over 27 million borrowers who could qualify, and yet another blow to the president’s pledge to provide mass student debt relief.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Missouri temporarily blocked a Biden administration plan to cancel student debt less than a day after another judge had allowed it to proceed, throwing into uncertainty the fate of a program that could affect more than 27 million borrowers.

headline: Richard Mayhew, Painter of Abstract Landscapes, Dies at 100
abstract: He drew from his Black and Native American heritage, as well as his own memory, to find an emotional resonance behind the beauty of nature.
lead_paragraph: Richard Mayhew, a painter of Black and Native American heritage who was known for his explosively colorful abstract landscapes — he called them “mindscapes” — that traced the emotional contours of nature as well as his forebears’ historical relationship to the land, died on Sept. 26 at his home in Soquel, Calif., on the northern coast. He was 100.

headline: Still Searching for Their Loved Ones, a Week After Hurricane Helene
abstract: The storm’s death toll has climbed past 225, but many people remain unaccounted for and searching for them is complicated. Their families are desperate for answers.
lead_paragraph: The last time Drew McLean’s parents saw him, he was marveling at the power of Tropical Storm Helene as it washed over their home in the mountains of North Carolina.

headline: Shock in French Court Shown Videos of Men Accused of Raping Drugged Woman
abstract: Gisèle Pelicot fought for the graphic videos made by her husband to be shown publicly in court, insisting they were essential evidence in a rape case against him and 50 other men.
lead_paragraph: A leaden silence descended upon the courtroom as the videos began to play over three screens.

headline: Biden Cautions Israel on Striking Iranian Oil Fields
abstract: President Biden said Israel should consider alternative ways of retaliating against Iran, a day after he said the United States was “in discussion” about the possibility of Israel striking Iran’s oil fields.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said Israel should consider alternative ways of retaliating against Iran, a day after he said the United States was “in discussion” about the possibility of Israel striking Iran’s oil fields.

headline: Her 8-Year-Old Drove Herself to Target and Became an Internet Star
abstract: Tangie Wilson was sleeping when her daughter Zoe sneaked out of the house and drove to the store. The tale of how it all unfolded is as relatable as it is incredible.
lead_paragraph: When Tangie Wilson’s 8-year-old daughter, Zoe, asked to use her iPad early one Sunday morning in September at their home in Bedford, Ohio, she assumed her child had settled into her room or on the couch with the device, so she went back to sleep.

headline: Trump Campaign Distributes Raised Funds to Victims in Butler, Pa.
abstract: The recipients included the families of those killed and wounded, and a Trump supporter who lost income when his rental cranes were stuck at the site.
lead_paragraph: The Trump campaign said on Friday that it was distributing $6.6 million that others donated to a GoFundMe account that it set up for victims of the July 13 assassination attempt on the former president in Butler, Pa.

headline: What to Know About the Verdict in the Tyre Nichols Case
abstract: Three former Memphis police officers were found guilty on Thursday of federal witness tampering charges in the fatal beating of Tyre Nichols, a 29-year-old Black man. They were acquitted of the more serious charge of violating his civil rights by causing his death. Emily Cochrane, a New York Times reporter who covers the American South, explains.
lead_paragraph: Three former Memphis police officers were found guilty on Thursday of federal witness tampering charges in the fatal beating of Tyre Nichols, a 29-year-old Black man. They were acquitted of the more serious charge of violating his civil rights by causing his death. Emily Cochrane, a New York Times reporter who covers the American South, explains.

headline: Reporter Asks Biden if He Would Reconsider Dropping Out of the Race
abstract: President Biden, who reluctantly surrendered his bid for a second term, has wanted to be president for most of his adult life.
lead_paragraph: He was almost out the door.

headline: It’s Not World War III. But Foreign Conflicts May Get Uglier Before Election Day.
abstract: Rarely do foreign crises and a presidential election collide like they have in the past few days.
lead_paragraph: Good evening! Tonight, my colleague David Sanger, a White House and national security correspondent, has a look at what the widening conflict in the Middle East might mean for the presidential campaign. Plus, a Times photographer explains what she saw in Georgia this week with Vice President Harris. — Jess Bidgood

headline: Trump’s False Claims About the Federal Response to Hurricane Helene
abstract: The former president falsely accused the Biden administration of spending disaster funding on migrants, neglecting areas that had voted for Republicans and ignoring a call from a Republican governor.
lead_paragraph: After Hurricane Helene battered several Southeastern states last week, former President Donald J. Trump wasted no time in criticizing President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris for the federal government’s response — often making false accusations.

headline: Israel Expands Attacks on Hezbollah as Iran Warns of Retaliation
abstract: Israel is drastically widening its fight against the Lebanese militant group that is backed by Iran, whose supreme leader said that “any strike on the Zionist regime is a service to humanity.”
lead_paragraph: Less than a week after Israel killed Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, Israeli warplanes bombarded areas south of Beirut around midnight on Thursday, this time targeting his presumed successor.

headline: Oklahoma Schools Need 55,000 Bibles. Trump-Endorsed Book Fits the Bill.
abstract: The bid details for new Bibles the state is buying seem to point to a version promoted by former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: When the education superintendent of Oklahoma, Ryan Walters, ordered this year that every public school classroom in the state must have a Bible in the classroom, he didn’t mention any special requirements.

headline: Harris, in Michigan, Tries to Head Off Trump’s Attacks Over Gas Cars
abstract: Kamala Harris, who has faced a flurry of Trump ads in Michigan misleadingly arguing that she wants to ban gas cars altogether, promised, “I will never tell you what kind of car you have to drive.”
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris on Friday sought to rebut a frequent argument from former President Donald J. Trump that she would mandate the end of gasoline-powered cars, issuing a rare direct response to her White House rival’s exaggerations and misleading claims.

headline: Instructor at Troubled Skydiving Spot Gets 2 Years After Faking Credentials
abstract: The facility near Lodi, Calif., where he trained people in tandem jumping, has come under scrutiny amid more than two dozen deaths since 1985.
lead_paragraph: A skydiving instructor who used someone else’s credentials to train people in tandem jumping at a troubled facility near Lodi, Calif., was sentenced this week to two years in prison.

headline: 2 Men Sentenced to Prison for Attacking Officers at Jan. 6 Riot
abstract: One of the men, from New Jersey, referred to lawmakers as “traitors” and encouraged other rioters to drag them out of the building by their hair, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A man from New Jersey and another from New York were sentenced to prison on Friday after federal prosecutors said they had breached the U.S. Capitol building and attacked law enforcement officers during the riot on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: Aides Say Trump Resisted Sending Federal Funds After California Wildfires
abstract: He changed his mind after being shown data that his supporters in the state had been affected, the former officials said. One called his approach “red states vs. blue states.”
lead_paragraph: As California battled the deadliest wildfire in its history in 2018, Donald J. Trump, then the president, initially opposed unlocking federal funding for the state, according to two former Trump administration officials.

headline: In North Carolina Town Hall, Trump Makes a Series of Promises to Appeal to Veterans
abstract: Donald J. Trump answered preselected questions from a pro-military crowd who echoed his false claims and approved of his vow to conduct massive deportations of undocumented immigrants.
lead_paragraph: At the end of his town hall in North Carolina on Friday, former President Donald J. Trump was asked by a former Air Force pilot whether he would create a panel to keep “woke generals” out of the Defense Department.

headline: A Deluge of Rain Poured Out of the Heavens. But There’s Still No Drinking Water.
abstract: City officials have refused to provide estimates of when the devastated water system in Asheville, N.C., will be back in operation.
lead_paragraph: Since their home lost running water around 2 p.m. on Sept. 27 from Hurricane Helene, Etiska Jackson and her husband, Jayme, have been driving back and forth between their home in Asheville, N.C., and her brother’s in Madison County, about 25 miles north. There, they wash their clothes, take showers and fetch water from a well to flush their toilet.

headline: There Are Layers to This
abstract: Natan Last goes toe to toe with us in this challenging puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: 5 Takeaways From Melania Trump’s Book
abstract: Shining a little more light on her mysterious life, her memoir details her support for abortion rights, her doubts about the 2020 election and her explanation for that “I really don’t care” jacket.
lead_paragraph: Melania Trump’s new memoir offers a few new glimpses into a life she has carefully walled off from the public, but readers hoping to understand one of the most mysterious first ladies in modern history will not make it past the gilded front gate.

headline: Biden Urges Congress to Replenish Disaster Relief Funds Quickly
abstract: The president said a Small Business Administration program needed to help business owners recover from Hurricane Helene was set to run out of money in weeks, before Congress reconvenes.
lead_paragraph: President Biden urged members of Congress on Friday to provide emergency funding for the Small Business Administration, saying the agency is critically low on money needed to help people in communities devastated by Hurricane Helene.

headline: Quote of the Day: Assistance Slow to Reach Hard-Hit Latino Communities
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 5, 2024
lead_paragraph: “We don’t have a lot right now, but we have each other.”

headline: Behind Trump’s Views on Ukraine: Putin’s Gambit and a Political Grudge
abstract: The roots of Donald Trump’s animus toward Ukraine — an issue with profound consequences should he be elected again — can be found in a yearlong series of events spanning 2016 and 2017.
lead_paragraph: On July 7, 2017, after President Donald J. Trump and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia shook hands in Hamburg, Germany, to conclude their first face-to-face meeting, Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson walked out of the sterile conference room, removed notes from his pocket and gave anxious White House aides a summary.

headline: Villages Spared a Soviet Nuclear Plant Are Split Over a U.S. One
abstract: A plan to place American-made reactors on a picturesque coastline has broad support in Poland — and in Washington — but the geopolitical calculations have run into local opposition.
lead_paragraph: It appeared to be a typical harvest festival on Poland’s picturesque Baltic coast, with women in traditional dress singing folk songs and local farmers displaying their wares.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: How a Gardener at a Brooklyn Park Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Eve Brooks, the gardener at Herbert Von King Park, spends her day tending to her pet turtle, listening to Sam Cooke and getting down in the dirt at the park.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, Eve Brooks was unemployed and looking for help. A caseworker mentioned that the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation had several job training programs, including a six-month horticulture program. She immediately enrolled.

headline: Big Business Saw an Ally in Eric Adams, and Overlooked His Issues
abstract: New York’s business community threw its support behind Mr. Adams, and continued backing him even as his legal problems began to threaten the governance of the city.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t quite love at first sight, but it did not take New York’s business elite long to embrace Eric Adams.

headline: Ukraine’s Donbas Strategy: Retreat Slowly and Maximize Russia’s Losses
abstract: The idea is to use rope-a-dope tactics, letting Russian forces pound away until they have exhausted themselves. It’s far from clear if the Ukrainian strategy will succeed.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the year, Ukraine has lost a series of cities, towns and villages in its eastern Donbas region to Russia, typically withdrawing its troops after hard-fought battles that sometimes lasted for months.

headline: Michigan Father Dies in Israeli Airstrike in Lebanon, Family Says
abstract: Kamel Ahmad Jawad, a U.S. citizen, was remembered by friends and relatives as someone who chose to stay behind to help others who couldn’t flee.
lead_paragraph: Kamel Ahmad Jawad remained calm, even as Israeli missiles rained down around him in his hometown in southern Lebanon, thousands of miles from his other home, Dearborn, Mich.

headline: Deadly Marburg Virus Hits Rwanda’s Doctors and Nurses Hard
abstract: The Health Ministry has reported that 80 percent of the infected are health care professionals.
lead_paragraph: Rwanda’s fragile health care system could become overwhelmed by the deadly Marburg virus, doctors fear, because most of those currently infected are medical professionals, and some have already died.

headline: A Nation of Homebodies
abstract: A recent study shows Americans are spending notably more time at home, a trend that started long before the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: It turns out we aren’t just bowling alone — we’re bowling at home.

headline: Can Hudson Square Reinvent Itself as New York City’s Next Hot Neighborhood?
abstract: Once known as a gritty, industrial area on Manhattan’s West Side, Hudson Square is now trying to lure new tenants and businesses, and create its own identity.
lead_paragraph: New York City is full of distinct neighborhoods, many competing for charm, hipness, quality of life and a good work-life balance. As a newcomer, and one that many city dwellers still haven’t heard of, Hudson Square is trying to create an identity separate from its culturally vibrant neighbors — SoHo to the east, the West Village to the north, TriBeCa to the south — that have long had curb appeal for businesses and new residents alike.

headline: Pro-Palestinian Group Is Relentless in Its Criticism of Israel, and It Isn’t Backing Down
abstract: Within Our Lifetime, a group formed by New York students, has galvanized pro-Palestinian activists who are calling for the end of Israel — and facing accusations of antisemitism.
lead_paragraph: Without even entering Grand Central Terminal’s soaring main hall on one Thursday evening in July, Nerdeen Kiswani and her pro-Palestinian protest group, Within Our Lifetime, managed to shut it down.

headline: Campus Protest Investigations Hang Over Schools as New Academic Year Begins
abstract: Dozens of discrimination complaints brought by conservative and pro-Jewish groups after the Oct. 7 attacks last year have spawned lengthy federal inquiries that some worry could chill free speech on campus.
lead_paragraph: With a new academic year well underway, more than 60 colleges and universities are still under federal investigation over antisemitic and Islamophobic incidents during the campus protests that swept the United States after the Oct. 7 attacks in Israel, according to the Department of Education.

headline: How Walmart’s Donna Morris Manages the Largest Work Force in America
abstract: With 1.6 million U.S. employees under her watch, the company’s chief people officer faced a unique challenge just weeks into her new job: a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: More than 30 years into a career that had brought her to California and then Arkansas from her native Canada, Donna Morris could not have chosen a more challenging time to take on the role of chief people officer of Walmart.
