It was February 2020 — a couple of weeks before the coronavirus pandemic upended the world and laid bare an uncertain future for both workers and the retail industry.

headline: A Menace to Motorists, but the ‘Noble’ Moose Is Adopted by Newfoundland
abstract: Introduced to the island 120 years ago, moose are involved in hundreds of collisions each year. But the huge animal is an accepted part of life here. “I suspect that they got squatters’ rights.”
lead_paragraph: Running into a moose when driving a car or truck is bad enough, but crashing into the giant animal while riding on two wheels can be worse.

headline: GloRilla, Hip-Hop’s Master Motivator, Rounds Out Her Message
abstract: Self-empowerment rhymes catapulted her onto rap’s A-list. On “Glorious,” her debut LP, she’s hoping that showing more sides of her personality will help her stay there.
lead_paragraph: GloRilla is always on the clock these days. Last month, the rapper born Gloria Hallelujah Woods stomped and bounced through her hits “Yeah Glo!” and “TGIF” at the MTV Video Music Awards, then spent the next morning at a photo shoot.

headline: Get Your Mind Into the Gutter
abstract: Autumn is for addressing one of the most neglected parts of your home.
lead_paragraph: Last winter, after finding big puddles in our New Jersey home’s cellar for the third time, my wife and I called a local plumber. He gave the cellar a once-over, confirmed that our sump pump was in working order, and then surprised us by suggesting we take a look outside the house.

headline: Ella Purnell Is a TV Star Who Hasn’t Lost Touch With Her Barista Roots
abstract: “Sometimes, before I go to bed,” the “Sweetpea” actress and executive producer said, “I think about how good my coffee’s going to be in the morning.”
lead_paragraph: You might think twice about overlooking the office wallflower after watching Ella Purnell play a sad sack gone sadist on the new Starz dramedy “Sweetpea.”

headline: Will the ‘SmartLess’ Podcast Be the Biggest Role of Their Careers?
abstract: Started during the pandemic, this venture is the first step in a media empire being built by the actors Sean Hayes, Will Arnett and Jason Bateman.
lead_paragraph: It’s a warm Saturday afternoon in the middle of August, and the actors Jason Bateman, Sean Hayes and Will Arnett are gathered on the stage of the Stephen Talkhouse, a popular music venue in the Long Island summer resort town of Amagansett, telling stories and swapping insults with Howard Stern, the longtime radio personality.

headline: As Lawmaker Claims Trump’s Shooting Was Inside Job, G.O.P. Indulges Him
abstract: Representative Eli Crane, a first-term Arizona Republican, has emerged as the chief right-wing voice pushing conspiracy theories about the Trump assassination attempts.
lead_paragraph: He posits that there is a mole within Donald J. Trump’s Secret Service detail and warns that the former president should bolster his private security to “watch the watchers.”

headline: Can My Building Replace Our Keys With QR Codes and Facial Scans?
abstract: New York’s tenant data privacy law specifically addresses landlords’ use of ‘smart’ entry and intercom systems. Here’s what it says.
lead_paragraph: Q: The owner of my Manhattan apartment building is implementing an access system that unlocks doors only with QR codes, biometrics data, or facial scans. This system compromises tenants’ privacy and restricts access to dog walkers and other contractors. It is said to be susceptible to hacking, exposing us to burglaries. We are concerned about the collection, destination, and privacy of our data. Can our landlord force us to adopt this system?

headline: Campaigning for Harris, Women Share Their Abortion Stories With Neighbors
abstract: The Harris campaign is trying to transform women in battleground states into an organizing force who can drive their friends and family to the polls.
lead_paragraph: One by one, the women shared their stories.

headline: Supporters Who Watched as Trump Was Shot Prepare to Welcome Him Back
abstract: Donald J. Trump is returning to Butler, Pa., to hold another rally at the site where he was nearly assassinated in July in an attack that killed a man and wounded two others.
lead_paragraph: When the balloons descended on Donald J. Trump at the finale of the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, Jondavid Longo, the mayor of Slippery Rock, Pa., was on the floor of the arena. As a few balloons popped, he glanced at the other Pennsylvania delegates he knew who, like him, had been at Mr. Trump’s rally in Butler, Pa., five days earlier. More than one of them winced at the sound.

headline: As Israel Attacks, Many Lebanese Feel Dragged Into Someone Else’s War
abstract: In a crisis-racked country where sectarian tensions simmer, many worry that the conflict between Israel and the Shiite militia Hezbollah will end in more destruction for all.
lead_paragraph: When Hezbollah announced that its longtime leader, Hassan Nasrallah, had been killed in an Israeli airstrike, the talk among many of the group’s Shiite Muslim followers was of defiance and vengeance.

headline: The Espresso Martini Has Nothing on These 2 Drinks
abstract: Make (or buy) cold brew, and put it to use in a nonalcoholic coffee tonic or a rich caffé amaro.
lead_paragraph: Despite its name (and temperature), cold brew’s season extends far beyond summer’s last breath — especially when put to use behind the bar.

headline: 30 Days Out, the Harris and Trump Campaigns Brace for ‘Trench Warfare’
abstract: With tight contests in all seven battleground states, the candidates are pressing for a few thousand votes that could sway the outcome of the entire election.
lead_paragraph: As Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump begin the final 30-day push for the White House, they are locked in a neck-and-neck race from the Rust Belt to the Sun Belt.

headline: How Gender Became the Election’s Crucial Fault Line
abstract: Harris could be the first female president. But it’s Trump and Vance who are playing the gender card.
lead_paragraph: In an alternate universe, Nikki Haley is running for president against Kamala Harris in the true Year of the Woman. In our world, Haley is on the sidelines wishing Republicans would stop alienating a large swath of voters. “Donald Trump and JD Vance need to change the way they speak about women,” Haley said on “Fox & Friends” in September, when she was asked why Trump and Vance were trailing by 14 points among female voters. “When you call even a Democrat woman dumb, Republican women get their backs up, too.”

headline: Where Trump and Harris Stand on the Economy
abstract: Here’s where Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump stand on economic issues like inflation, taxes and more. Maggie Astor, who covers politics for The New York Times, looks at the candidates’ views, proposals and records.
lead_paragraph: Here’s where Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump stand on economic issues like inflation, taxes and more. Maggie Astor, who covers politics for The New York Times, looks at the candidates’ views, proposals and records.

headline: With ‘Megalopolis,’ the Flop Era Returns to Cinemas
abstract: Plenty of movies bomb, but Francis Ford Coppola’s latest is part of a different class of box office failures.
lead_paragraph: Just before previews began at a Lower Manhattan theater on a recent Saturday night, Tazer Army reflected on the Francis Ford Coppola movie “Megalopolis” before even seeing it.

headline: Hit by Disaster? How to Get What You Deserve From Insurers or FEMA
abstract: Experts offered plenty of advice about ways to make the disaster-recovery process work. Here’s what to do and what to avoid.
lead_paragraph: If your home was damaged or destroyed by Hurricane Helene, the most daunting challenge may still be ahead: Getting your insurance company, or the federal government, to give you the money you’re entitled to receive.

headline: Good News if You Want to Look ‘Demure’
abstract: Many brands in their spring 2025 collections offered ladylike alternatives to the flashy and revealing clothing that has proliferated in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Oversize bows where six months ago there was cleavage. Flouncy, lacy, columnar dresses instead of skintight styles. More knee-length shorts, fewer micro mini skirts.

headline: In Final Stretch, Biden Faces Some of the Biggest Crises of His Presidency
abstract: Even as President Biden recedes from view, some of the most consequential days of his term may be ahead of him.
lead_paragraph: President Biden was in the White House Situation Room on Tuesday morning, watching on video monitors as Iran fired waves of ballistic missiles at Israel. The wider war in the Middle East, which Mr. Biden had spent much of his presidency trying to avert, had arrived.

headline: Paris Hilton Is Becoming a Fixture at Walmart
abstract: A new line of handbags expands the offerings of her brand at the big-box chain. Plus, rare Birkenstocks and a pink suit you may have seen.
lead_paragraph: Paris Hilton is associated with many things — being an heiress, an entrepreneur, an activist and a Y2K fashion inspiration — but living on a budget is not often among them.

headline: Experian Wants You to Carry Its Debit Card Around. Be Wary.
abstract: There’s not a lot of love for the credit bureaus, so why would you want one of them in your wallet? Experian’s pitch: A slightly better credit score. Maybe.
lead_paragraph: In what universe would anyone want to whip out a debit card with the name of a credit bureau on it?

headline: Al Pacino Is Still Going Big
abstract: A conversation with the legendary actor about, well, everything.
lead_paragraph: Al Pacino has been one of the world’s greatest, most influential actors for more than 50 years. He’s audacious. He’s outrageous. He’s Al Pacino, and I’m pretty sure you know what that entails.

headline: After Helene’s ‘Historic’ Damage, Appalachian Trail May Need Years to Recover
abstract: Downed trees and flooding have left the trail impassable in many of the 14 states on its route.
lead_paragraph: As the scope of devastation caused by Hurricane Helene comes into focus, an American landmark that dozens of towns benefit from is facing historic destruction: the Appalachian Trail.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,205
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Oct. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 483
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Oct. 6, 2024
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Ever-Shrinking Condos Are the Choice of Investors in Toronto and Vancouver
abstract: A new report shows that small condo units are preferred by investors and that a lack of investor buyers may now be delaying new buildings.
lead_paragraph: There is a group of Canadians who want to see house prices continue to soar: investors. A report from Statistics Canada released this week details their outsize influence on the condominium markets in Vancouver and Toronto. And it’s an influence that may now be thwarting some new construction.

headline: Fear Factors
abstract: Sometimes the scariest movies are the ones that depict the ordinary horrors of life.
lead_paragraph: I was fascinated to discover recently that each October, my friend Alex undertakes a spooky-season film festival, endeavoring to watch one horror flick for each day of the month. I do not expect that his roster includes the 2012 documentary “Part of Me,” a chronicle of the musician Katy Perry’s California Dreams concert tour. But I happened to watch that film this week, and it made me contemplate what, exactly, makes a movie frightening.

headline: Adoptions by Foreign Parents
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay by a Chinese adoptee.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: To Understand Trump vs. Harris, You Must Know These American Myths
abstract: It’s as if we are living in two different countries, each with a different understanding of who counts as American.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump are making their appeals to the American electorate on the basis of personality, character and policy. But they are also framing themselves as actors in the American story — the events of the recent past and the deeper narrative of U.S. history carried by the symbol-rich stories of our national mythology.

headline: JD Smirks His Way Into the Future
abstract: The misogynist ticket takes a shot at Kamala for dancing — and being a woman.
lead_paragraph: When I’ve covered the campaigns of women on presidential tickets, the question invariably arises: “Is she tough enough to be commander in chief?”

headline: Benny Gantz: What the World Needs to Understand About Iran
abstract: Now is the time to bolster regional cooperation and make a broad effort to confront Iran.
lead_paragraph: Oct. 7, 2023, marked the worst tragedy for the state of Israel and the Jewish people since the Holocaust. Some 1,200 people were murdered in Israel, and approximately 250 people were taken hostage on a single day; 101 of those souls are still held captive in Gaza. Hezbollah in Lebanon began its attack on the north of Israel the very next day, forcing nearly 70,000 Israelis from their homes. Iran, launching attacks first on April 13 and again on Oct. 1, has sent millions of Israelis into the safety of their shelters.

headline: Biden Sought Peace but Facilitated War
abstract: Netanyahu repeatedly rolled the American president, leading us all to the precipice of a much larger war.
lead_paragraph: When Israel defied America’s appeals for restraint by invading Lebanon a few days ago, a reporter asked President Biden if he was comfortable with what had unfolded.

headline: America Needs a President
abstract: The sidelining of the White House in global crisis spots is a big red flag.
lead_paragraph: Last week’s column was devoted to uncertainties about how the next president would handle the deteriorating situation in Ukraine, where America’s proxy and ally is slowly losing ground to Russia, while the United States seems trapped by its commitment to a maximal victory and unable to pivot to a strategy for peace.

headline: I’m a Doctor. ChatGPT’s Bedside Manner Is Better Than Mine.
abstract: My job is no longer safe.
lead_paragraph: As a young, idealistic medical student in the 2000s, I thought my future job as a doctor would always be safe from artificial intelligence.

headline: The Troubling Quiet of North Carolina’s Cell Service Outages
abstract: Service has been restored in some areas after Hurricane Helene, but many people are still unable to communicate by phone, which has hampered relief efforts, worried loved ones and complicated daily life.
lead_paragraph: John Tressler stood next to what was left of his storm-battered deli, part of which had collapsed in the torrents of a raging river, and waited to meet a relief crew bringing a much-needed supply of food into Swannanoa, N.C.

headline: 2 Books About Old Flames
abstract: Stephen McCauley’s novel about ex-spouses reuniting, in a sense; Jim Shepard’s noir about a fateful hit-and-run.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: What to Know: How Israel Could Retaliate Against Iran
abstract: Iran has a number of sensitive sites, including oil infrastructure, military installations and nuclear facilities.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates as Israel launches retaliatory strikes against Iran.

headline: What an Escalating Middle East Conflict Could Mean for the Global Economy
abstract: The biggest risk is a sustained increase in oil prices.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a year since the Hamas attack on Israel on Oct. 7 and the start of the fighting in Gaza, investment strategists have warned that a wider war could break out in the Middle East, crimping the world’s oil supply and sending shock waves throughout the global economy.

headline: ‘Nobody Wants This’ Pits Jewish Women Against ‘Shiksas.’ Nobody Wins.
abstract: Except maybe Jewish men.
lead_paragraph: The derisive word for a male gentile is “shegetz.” I didn’t know the term until I married one. Even though my family is 100 percent Jewish and my brother took a DNA test to prove it, up to that point, I had heard only the female equivalent of the word: “shiksa.”

headline: Former Gov. David Paterson of New York Assaulted in Manhattan
abstract: Mr. Paterson and his stepson suffered minor injuries in a street attack on Friday. The former governor was not believed to have been targeted in the assault, the police said.
lead_paragraph: David A. Paterson, a former governor of New York, and his stepson were injured in an assault on a Manhattan street on Friday evening, the Police Department said.

headline: Trump Did Nothing to Stop the Mob
abstract: “Stop the Steal” is about not trusting voters.
lead_paragraph: One of the key points in the unsealed legal filing presented by the special counsel Jack Smith in the criminal case against Donald Trump for conspiracy to subvert the 2020 presidential election is that both Trump and his allies were well aware that he had lost the election. The evidence, Smith says, shows that Trump knew he didn’t have a case. But rather than accept the verdict of the voting public, Trump led the effort to pressure officials to overturn election results.

headline: My Go-To Weeknight Dinners
abstract: Grocery-store ice cream makes the list.
lead_paragraph: Hello, and thank you to Mia Leimkuhler for taking time off so I can go on and on about my favorite thing: recipes!

headline: Hundreds of Storm-Ravaged Roads, and No Timeline for Fixing Them
abstract: Repairing the roads in the region near the North Carolina-Tennessee border could take months. Some residents worry about the impact on the local economy.
lead_paragraph: The small roads made of dirt and rock had been there for generations, twisting byways that carried families up and down the mountains of western North Carolina. The asphalt highways were newer, built along cliffs and over rivers to connect the region with South Carolina and Tennessee.

headline: The Problem With the Hurricane Category Rating
abstract: After Helene, it may be time to rethink how to communicate the risks posed by storms, especially extreme rain.
lead_paragraph: By the time Hurricane Helene reached western North Carolina a week ago, causing devastating floods, it was no longer a hurricane.

headline: Milton Tracker: Latest on Storm's Path, Power Outages and Winds
abstract: See the likely path, evacuation orders and wind arrival times for Milton.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path, evacuation orders and wind arrival times for Milton.

headline: David Burnham, Times Reporter Who Exposed Police Graft, Dies at 91
abstract: Tipped off by the detective Frank Serpico, he wrote an explosive series on police corruption in New York City, sparking an investigation by the Knapp commission.
lead_paragraph: David Burnham, a former investigative reporter for The New York Times whose exposé of corruption in the New York City Police Department in 1970 led to public hearings; tarnished top officials, including the mayor; and inspired the movie “Serpico,” about Mr. Burnham’s chief source, Detective Frank Serpico, died on Tuesday at his home in Spruce Head, Maine. He was 91.

headline: Marvin Schlachter, Record Executive Who Championed Disco, Dies at 90
abstract: In the 1960s, he helped get wide exposure for Black artists like Dionne Warwick. A decade later, he brought dance music from the clubs to radio success.
lead_paragraph: Marvin Schlachter, a music executive who helped launch Dionne Warwick and the Shirelles in the 1960s and who a decade later created one of the world’s most influential disco labels, bringing acts like Musique and France Joli to the masses, died on Sept. 19 in Manhattan. He was 90.

headline: Security Is Tighter for Trump Rally at Site of July Assassination Attempt
abstract: The Secret Service has deployed large forces to protect former President Donald J. Trump as he prepares to hold a rally in Butler, Pa., where a gunman attacked him in July.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Secret Service has deployed hundreds of agents and local law enforcement officials to guard former President Donald J. Trump when he returns to Butler, Pa., for a rally Saturday evening, hoping to seal up the holes that left him vulnerable to a would-be assassin at the same venue in July.

headline: James Magee, Creator of a Mysterious Desert Monument, Dies at 79
abstract: For 40 years, he built a group of stone and steel buildings in the West Texas desert to house his own monumental work. Only a few have been lucky enough to see it.
lead_paragraph: James Magee, an enigmatic and idiosyncratic artist and poet who spent four decades building a starkly beautiful monument of stone and steel in the West Texas desert that may be the most significant artwork most people have never heard of, died on Sept. 14 at his home in Fremont, Mich. He was 79.

headline: From Melania Trump: Modeling, Motherhood and a Brazen Whitewash of a Presidency
abstract: Slim and full of obfuscations, her memoir touches on business ventures and raising her son, but barely grapples with the mysteries of her marriage.
lead_paragraph: White House memoirs tend to go on a bit. Melania Trump’s is slim, as befits an erstwhile fashion model who prepared for her husband’s 2017 inauguration with “strong espresso and a light breakfast of fruit,” but gravely out of shape.

headline: As 23andMe Struggles, Concerns Surface About Its Genetic Data
abstract: A plummet in the company’s valuation and a recent board resignation have raised questions about the future of genetic data collected from millions of customers.
lead_paragraph: The genetic testing company 23andMe, once valued at $6 billion, is facing an uncertain future after a drop in share prices, a recent board resignation and a data breach last year that affected nearly seven million customers.

headline: Widow of Man Killed in July Attack on Trump Returns for Rally
abstract: Helen Comperatore, whose husband, Corey Comperatore, was killed when a gunman tried to assassinate former President Donald J. Trump, returned to honor her husband’s memory.
lead_paragraph: Helen Comperatore, the widow of Corey Comperatore, the former volunteer fire chief who was killed when a gunman tried to assassinate former President Donald J. Trump on July 13 at a rally in Butler, Pa., returned to the venue on Saturday when Mr. Trump came back for another rally.

headline: Macron Calls for Halting Weapons to Israel for Gaza Conflict
abstract: The French leader’s comments drew the condemnation of Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and reflected the growing international concern over Israel’s expanding conflicts in the region.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France called for an “immediate and lasting” cease-fire in Lebanon and said countries should stop shipping weapons to Israel for use in Gaza, adding to international pressure on Israel to do more to protect civilians and work toward an end to fighting in the region.

headline: Missing People, Power Outages, Ruined Roads: Issues Across the Southeast After Helene
abstract: The worst fallout from the hurricane is in western North Carolina, but at least five other states are grappling with their own intractable problems.
lead_paragraph: More than a week after Hurricane Helene made landfall as a Category 4 storm, state officials across the Southeast are scrambling to repair damaged electrical lines, roads and bridges affecting tens of thousands across the path of destruction.

headline: Teacher’s Marks
abstract: John Kugelman makes the grade.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Kamala Harris Visits North Carolina to Check on Hurricane Response
abstract: The vice president visited Charlotte, N.C., for an update on relief efforts after Hurricane Helene ravaged wide swaths of the Southeast.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris met with North Carolina and federal emergency officials on Saturday in Charlotte as she continued to help oversee the disaster response in the Southeast after Hurricane Helene.

headline: Israel Steps Up Attacks in Lebanon as Fighting Spreads
abstract: With the region on edge about a possible Israeli retaliatory strike on Iran, U.S. Central Command hit targets in Yemen, and Israel ordered evacuations in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: As Israel escalated its fight against Hezbollah in Lebanon on Saturday, much of the Middle East was on edge, with many expecting an Israeli retaliatory strike on Iran as payback for its missile barrage on Israel earlier this week.

headline: Harris Meets With Arab and Muslim Leaders in Michigan
abstract: The meeting, which took place backstage, came as Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign ramped up efforts to appeal directly to Arab and Muslim voters in the final weeks before the election.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris on Friday met with Arab and Muslim leaders while campaigning in Michigan, a crucial battleground state where roiling discontent over the United States’ backing of Israel’s war in Gaza and its escalating attacks in Lebanon could threaten her support.

headline: Elon Musk Leaps to Trump’s Side in Rally Appearance
abstract: Mr. Musk, the world’s richest man and the leader of Tesla and X,  delivered a dark warning during an animated appearance at former President Donald J. Trump’s rally.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the billionaire head of Tesla and SpaceX, strode onto the stage to cheers at Donald J. Trump’s rally on Saturday night, lifted his arms above his head and jumped into the air — twice — exposing his navel as his shirt rode up.

headline: No Corrections: Oct. 6, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Sunday, Oct. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Trump’s Return to Scene of Attack Was a Do-Over in More Ways Than One
abstract: The former president returned to the stage where a gunman tried to kill him in July and tried to recapture some of the momentum he had before President Biden dropped out.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump returned to Butler, Pa., on Saturday for a massive rally at the fairgrounds where he was struck in July by a would-be assassin’s bullet, an event envisioned by his campaign as a show of strength and a memorial for the former volunteer fire chief who was killed during the attack.

headline: Corrections: Oct. 5, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sept. 29 about the death of the Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah referred incompletely to the circumstances that led to military exchanges between Israel and Hezbollah starting last October. Hezbollah began firing on Israeli positions in solidarity with Hamas after the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attack on Israel that ignited the war in Gaza.

headline: Tunisia’s Autocratic Leader Is Poised to Steamroll to Election Victory
abstract: President Kais Saied, who has jailed opponents and consolidated power, is almost certain to win Sunday’s election in the North African country, the birthplace of the Arab Spring movement.
lead_paragraph: For many Tunisians, there seems to be little point to the presidential election on Sunday. There are barely any candidate posters, no debates and not much suspense. The president, Kais Saied, appears so sure of victory that he has not even issued any policy proposals.

headline: Quote of the Day: After Helene’s Deluge, Ashville’s Water Crisis Has No End in Sight
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I’m not going to provide a timeline, and I’m not going to provide a timeline on when I’ll provide a timeline.”

headline: Gaza’s Schools Are for Learning, Not for Dying
abstract: Schools across Gaza have turned into refugee centers, and Israeli attacks on them have killed hundreds.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to include news developments.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Revisits the Vice-Presidential Debate
abstract: The comic Nate Bargatze hosted an episode that opened with another political sketch featuring the guest stars Dana Carvey, Jim Gaffigan, Maya Rudolph and Andy Samberg.
lead_paragraph: Last week, America got the answer to the question: Who would play the presidential and vice-presidential nominees this season on “Saturday Night Live”?

headline: ‘I Was on an Uptown 1 Coming Home From My Job at a SoHo Restaurant’
abstract: A briny snack on the subway, love in the air in Park Slope and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The 3 Brothers at the Center of the Bribery Inquiry Rocking City Hall
abstract: David Banks and Philip Banks III eclipsed their younger brother by rising to help run New York City. Then federal prosecutors seized the phones of all three men.
lead_paragraph: It was an ordinary Friday at City Hall, and Mayor Eric Adams was at the microphone, flanked by two men who each commanded his own vast corner of New York City government.

headline: From the Sidelines, Joy and Empowerment on Full Display
abstract: Sui-Lee Wee, the Southeast Asia bureau chief, reported on women who had fled Myanmar and found refuge — and the delight of soccer — in Thailand.
lead_paragraph: Last year, I was in the Thai city of Mae Sot interviewing a Burmese rock star turned filmmaker when I stumbled across a website that belonged to a nonprofit based in Thailand. The group was helping empower Burmese women migrants — through soccer.

headline: How Hedi Slimane Changed Fashion
abstract: He has just left his fourth job at a big brand. Maybe it’s time he start one of his own. Would you buy that?
lead_paragraph: It took only minutes after LVMH announced that Hedi Slimane would be leaving Celine for the Chanel speculation to start. The brand that Coco built has been without a creative director since June, when Virginie Viard stepped down, and who will get the post has become the hottest guessing game in fashion. Mr. Slimane’s name has been in the mix for months. His status as a free agent gave the rumors more juice.

headline: Israel Was Prepared for a Fight With Hezbollah. Ending It Will Be Harder.
abstract: Lessons learned from a 2006 invasion of Lebanon have guided Israel in its current one. Security experts say a political deal is needed to restore calm.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s last war with Hezbollah, in 2006, was considered a failure within much of the Israeli security establishment.

headline: Freeports, Free Zones and Other Places With Perks — for the Rich
abstract: In “The Hidden Globe,” the journalist Atossa Araxia Abrahamian examines the rise of spaces where wealthy countries and companies bend rules and regulations to their advantage.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1960s, an American named Richard Bolin, who was working for the consulting firm Arthur D. Little, pitched an idea to the Mexican government. What if it put factories along its border with the United States and allowed them to produce goods that could be exported duty-free? The goal was to jump-start the economy in the border region while at the same time encouraging free trade. The factories built under this plan, called maquiladoras, exist to this day. The concept behind them — that you could siphon off part of a country and allow it to play by different rules — has spread globally.

headline: In Salt Lake City, Sports Drive a New Vision for Downtown
abstract: A proposal to remake the area would please the owner of the city’s N.B.A. and N.H.L. teams. But others, including classical musicians, aren’t so thrilled.
lead_paragraph: In late April, about 60 members of the Utah Symphony were on break during a rehearsal of Massenet’s opera “Thaïs” when the organization’s chief executive, Steve Brosvik, matter-of-factly told them that the county was considering demolishing Abravanel Hall, their world-renowned home, as part of a plan to revamp downtown Salt Lake City.

headline: In Ukraine, Small, Fluffy Dogs Offer Wartime Comfort
abstract: Dog ownership has surged over the past two years as people seek companionship. In Kyiv, Yorkies, poodles and bichons frisés now rule the streets.
lead_paragraph: For two days last month, a vision of canine paradise emerged in the heart of a city regularly pounded by Russian drones and missiles.

headline: Cement Is a Big Polluter. A Plant in Norway Hopes to Clean It Up.
abstract: Heidelberg Materials is betting it can profit from an expensive process that will reduce the carbon dioxide emitted from one of the world’s most polluting industries.
lead_paragraph: Even in the idyllic Norwegian summer, with anglers casting for mackerel from nearby piers, the century-old cement plant on the edge of the harbor town of Brevik is a forbidding place. The screeching of gulls echoes off the mud- and dust-caked passageways between concrete walls, which rise on the edge of the water like the ramparts of a medieval fortress.

headline: How Oct. 7 Changed American Jews
abstract: In a year of trauma, many Jews have found support in the deep wells of history, community and faith.
lead_paragraph: The turning point came during spring finals, when Abigail Fixel got back to her dorm room at Barnard College and found a small Palestinian flag slapped onto her door frame, where her mezuza should have been.

headline: A Ghostly Life for Those Trickling Back to Villages Attacked on Oct. 7
abstract: Along Israel’s border with Gaza, reminders of the trauma of the Hamas-led assault are inescapable as the few who have returned try to start anew.
lead_paragraph: Before Oct. 7, Naama Giller let her children roam freely through her Israeli village on the border with Gaza. Her front door was rarely locked. She liked living in a place animated by communal festivities, outdoor life, the din of boys and girls playing.

headline: A Changing Climate Is Scorching the World’s Biggest River
abstract: As a punishing drought dries up stretches of the Amazon River, Brazil is resorting to dredging to try to keep food, medicine and people flowing along the watery superhighway.
lead_paragraph: The world’s largest river is parched.

headline: Melinda French Gates’s New Life: Abortion Politics and Kamala Harris
abstract: After her divorce from Bill Gates, Ms. French Gates came into her own billions of dollars, with which she could do whatever she chose. She used to insist on appearing nonpartisan, but no more.
lead_paragraph: When Melinda French Gates was running the world’s biggest philanthropy with her husband, Bill Gates, she insisted on staying on the sidelines of politics. She was half of one of America’s most celebrated couples, and she did not want to invite backlash from governments around the globe, to say nothing of getting crosswise with Washington by endorsing someone who could lose.

headline: Bruised Supreme Court Returns to Bench With Possible Election Cases Looming
abstract: Aside from major disputes on issues like transgender rights and guns, the docket is fairly routine. That could change fast if the presidential race is contested.
lead_paragraph: The new Supreme Court term, which starts as the justices return to the bench on Monday, already features cases on transgender rights, untraceable “ghost guns” and whether Mexico may sue American firearms manufacturers. The coming months may also bring voting disputes that could decide the presidential election.

headline: A Master Storyteller, at the End of Her Story
abstract: At 96, Lore Segal is approaching death with the same startling powers of perception she brought to her fiction.
lead_paragraph: In June, in the sort of portentous tableau that would not have been out of place in her own fiction, a leak opened in the ceiling of Lore Segal’s apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. For hours, water splashed across the kitchen countertops and onto the tiled floor, collecting in murky puddles and defying all efforts by Segal and her part-time nursing aide to catch it with buckets or stanch it with spare towels. Only when the building superintendent managed to locate the source of the problem — faulty pipes in the unit above — was the flood finally halted. Segal and the aide and Segal’s grandson Isaiah were left to mop up the mess.

headline: How the Push to Avert a Broader War in Lebanon Fell Apart
abstract: Diplomats thought both Israel and Hezbollah supported a call for a temporary cease-fire. Then Israel killed Hezbollah’s leader.
lead_paragraph: Everything appeared to be heading in the right direction for a breakthrough in Middle East peacemaking, to avert a spiraling war that would embroil the region.

headline: Some Scientists May Never Win a Nobel, but They Still Deserve Big Prizes
abstract: The Nobel Foundation offers prizes in only three scientific disciplines, but other awards have been created to honor scientists in different fields.
lead_paragraph: Every October, scientists eagerly await the announcement of the Nobel Prizes in physics, chemistry and medicine. But many researchers outside of those fields may miss out on opportunities for the international acclaim that comes with being named a laureate of the Nobel, the most prestigious award in science.

headline: A Year After Feinstein’s Death, Her Life’s Belongings Are for Sale
abstract: Senator Dianne Feinstein collected fine jewelry, paintings and a trove of political mementos. Because of her trust, many of those items are available for public inspection — and purchase.
lead_paragraph: In 1990, Dianne Feinstein retreated to a beach house on the coast of Northern California after she lost a grueling race to become the state’s governor. She was 57, and her political career appeared to have peaked at “mayor of San Francisco.” She told friends that she was thinking about leaving public life for good.

headline: The Fight for Rural America
abstract: One in five Americans identifies as rural, and since the 1960s, their votes have become increasingly Republican. Astead W. Herndon, a politics reporter and the host of the New York Times podcast “The Run-Up,” examines how Republicans expanded their rural advantage to historic levels and whether Democrats can remain competitive.
lead_paragraph: One in five Americans identifies as rural, and since the 1960s, their votes have become increasingly Republican. Astead W. Herndon, a politics reporter and the host of the New York Times podcast “The Run-Up,” examines how Republicans expanded their rural advantage to historic levels and whether Democrats can remain competitive.

headline: Trump’s Speeches, Increasingly Angry and Rambling, Reignite the Question of Age
abstract: With the passage of time, the 78-year-old former president’s speeches have grown darker, harsher, longer, angrier, less focused, more profane and increasingly fixated on the past, according to a review of his public appearances over the years.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump vividly recounted how the audience at his climactic debate with Vice President Kamala Harris was on his side. Except that there was no audience. The debate was held in an empty hall. No one “went crazy,” as Mr. Trump put it, because no one was there.

headline: How Trump’s Speeches Raise Questions About Age
abstract: With President Biden out of the 2024 election, former President Donald J. Trump at 78 is now the oldest major party nominee in U.S. history. Peter Baker, senior White House correspondent at The New York Times, explains the change he found in the former president’s speech after reviewing his rallies, interviews, statements and social media posts.
lead_paragraph: With President Biden out of the 2024 election, former President Donald J. Trump at 78 is now the oldest major party nominee in U.S. history. Peter Baker, senior White House correspondent at The New York Times, explains the change he found in the former president’s speech after reviewing his rallies, interviews, statements and social media posts.

headline: How One Polling Decision Is Leading to Two Distinct Stories of the Election
abstract: A methodological choice has created divergent paths of polling results. Is this election more like 2020 or 2022?
lead_paragraph: Over the last month, one methodological decision seems to have produced two parallel universes of political polling.

headline: At a Tennessee Plastics Plant, Sorrow and Uncertainty in Helene’s Wake
abstract: More than a week after workers fled flooding outside their factory, much remains unclear, including how many died.
lead_paragraph: The few details that are known about Bertha Mendoza’s last moments are heartbreaking.

headline: Harris Will Appear in a Whirlwind of Interviews, Most of Them Friendly
abstract: After mostly avoiding interviews as her campaign began, the vice president will hold several this week, including with Howard Stern, Stephen Colbert and the hosts of “The View.”
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris will engage in a media blitz this week, sitting for a series of mostly friendly interviews as her campaign shifts into exhorting her supporters to make sure they cast their votes.

headline: ‘Joker’ Sequel Falls Far Short of Original at the Box Office
abstract: The bleak musical drama is on track to open to around $40 million, significantly less than what the 2019 version made on its first weekend.
lead_paragraph: The original “Joker,” in 2019, earned 11 Oscar nominations, $1 billion in global box office receipts and created a cultural phenomenon. So it was inevitable that Warner Bros. would make a sequel, with the same director, Todd Phillips, and star, Joaquin Phoenix.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,206
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Oct. 7, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Sexiest Year of My Life Involved Zero Sex
abstract: When I removed the option of romance, my sensual relationship to all the other aspects of my life deepened.
lead_paragraph: A friend confided to me recently that she was burned out on dating. Cruising the apps in midlife felt humiliating, and she repeatedly confronted the same obstacles in her relationships.

headline: One Big Decision Awaits the Supreme Court
abstract: Will the court resume or refrain from injecting itself into the country’s culture wars?
lead_paragraph: The most important decision the Supreme Court’s justices will make in the new term that begins on Monday transcends the questions presented in any of its many cases. It is whether the court will resume or refrain from injecting itself into the country’s culture wars.

headline: JD Vance and the Prophets of Trumpism
abstract: For this group of Christians, “Trump is good. He’s been baptized by their theology.”
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 28, JD Vance spoke at a Christian political event hosted by the most influential religious leader you’ve probably never heard of.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 484
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Oct. 7, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Kamala Harris Is Turning a Trump Tactic on Its Head
abstract: Trump wants to position himself as the nation’s protector. But Harris is offering real-world, practical protection on the issues that matter.
lead_paragraph: It’s a truism that female candidates for high office face obstacles that men don’t. Less acknowledged is that women face different obstacles each from the other. Individually and generationally, women confront their own particular impossible dilemmas.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Blind Side’ Made Him Famous. But He Has a Different Story to Tell.
abstract: The football player Michael Oher believes his early life was misrepresented by the Oscar-winning movie and the book it was based on.
lead_paragraph: It was an overcast Monday afternoon in late April, and Michael Oher, the former football player whose high school years were dramatized in the movie “The Blind Side,” was driving Michael Sokolove on a tour through a forlorn-looking stretch of Memphis and past some of the landmarks of his childhood.

headline: The Robotic Future of Pro Sports
abstract: We explore a looming change in sports officiating.
lead_paragraph: For most of sports history, there was no recourse when a referee made a bad call. Fans could boo and players could complain, but the game went on. Instant replay changed that a few decades ago, allowing coaches to challenge a call and ask the referees to review it. That made games fairer, but it also made them slower.

headline: Ship in Need of Repairs Has Explosive Cargo, but No Dock
abstract: The MV Ruby has meandered around Europe’s northwestern coastline under a cloud of suspicion over its thousands of tons of Russian fertilizer.
lead_paragraph: The MV Ruby has languished off the coast of Britain for more than a week, its hull cracked, its propeller damaged. Yet no port will let the ship dock, fearing that the thousands of tons of Russian fertilizer it carries could lead to a disastrous explosion.

headline: Fear and Uncertainty Overshadow Oct. 7 Memorial Preparations
abstract: Amid the chaos and the war that followed the Hamas-led assault, Israel has not yet held a national day of mourning for the 1,200 people who were killed.
lead_paragraph: People in Israel were bracing on Sunday to mark the first anniversary of the deadly Hamas-led assault on southern Israel, entering a heavily charged week that promises to be filled with mourning as well as fighting.

headline: U.K. Prime Minister’s Chief of Staff, Sue Gray, Resigns
abstract: Ms. Gray said intense media scrutiny of her role meant she “risked becoming a distraction” to the new Labour government.
lead_paragraph: Sue Gray, the chief of staff to Britain’s prime minister, Keir Starmer, resigned abruptly on Sunday after weeks of speculation about turf wars in Downing Street, a media storm over her pay and questions over responsibility for a series of political errors.

headline: An Artist Rethinks Climate Change in Words and Pictures
abstract: We need to act as a single, unified force to find ways to strike a lasting balance with our natural world.
lead_paragraph: All we are as people is a collection of stories — those we are told, those told about us, those we tell to ourselves and others. They explain our identity and express our values, and they’ve long shaped societies — Sparta as a culture of warriors, America as the land of the free and so on. But when several conflicting stories are being told, they can also limit us, delude us and divide us. Too often they suit only the teller, not the audience.

headline: Pope Names 21 New Cardinals, Reaching Far Beyond Europe
abstract: The appointments cement Francis’ imprint on the group that will choose his successor, and reflect his vision of a more truly global Roman Catholic Church.
lead_paragraph: In announcing on Sunday that he would appoint 21 new cardinals, Pope Francis once again elevated clerics from far beyond Catholicism’s traditional centers of power, in line with his vision of a more global, less Eurocentric church. It also further cemented his imprint on the men who will one day choose his successor.

headline: Tacita Dean Draws Her Way Into the Menil
abstract: In the artist’s first major U.S. museum survey, she bonds with Cy Twombly through works on paper, films and photographs.
lead_paragraph: During a residency at the Menil Collection in Houston last February, the British artist and filmmaker Tacita Dean spent the night in the Cy Twombly Gallery.

headline: A Cryptic Letter With a Clear Warning
abstract: A domestic terrorist group sent a note to The New York Times admitting to detonating a bomb in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 50 years ago, on Jan. 29, 1975, a bomb exploded inside the State Department’s headquarters in Washington, D.C., damaging the building but causing no injuries. A bomb was discovered that same day at a federal office building in Oakland, Calif., and was safely detonated.

headline: Mississippi Roast Two Ways
abstract: Go with the internet-famous version, or make our from-scratch recipe. Both are objectively fantastic.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’ve been making Mississippi Roast for the better part of a decade now, ever since reporting out a story about its origins for The Times.

headline: Do Careerism and College Mix?
abstract: Readers respond to a guest essay by a recent college graduate. Also: New York City’s new outdoor dining program; how immigrants built America.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: On Social Media, Gazans Share Advice for Those Under Fire in Lebanon
abstract: A woman known as Chef Hala, who has had to evacuate three times since Israel invaded Gaza, is among those offering practical tips and messages of solidarity.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s invasion of southern Lebanon has forced thousands of people there to grapple with some urgent questions: What should I pack before I evacuate? What should stay behind? And where can I go that might be safe?

headline: Peter Jay, Headline-Making British Ambassador to the U.S., Dies at 87
abstract: His appointment sparked criticism and charges of nepotism. He later achieved unwanted attention as a character in the novel “Heartburn.”
lead_paragraph: Peter Jay, a British journalist, broadcaster and diplomat whose tenure as ambassador to the U.S. began and ended in controversy, died on Sept. 22 at his home in Woodstock, England. He was 87.

headline: In Talking About ‘Freedom,’ Harris Hopes She Has a Winning Message on Guns
abstract: The vice president is talking about firearms in a new way for a Democrat — by co-opting the language of Republicans.
lead_paragraph: When President Bill Clinton asked House Democrats to pass an assault weapons ban in 1994, their leaders begged him to back off, fearing the vote would cost them their seats. They were right. Democrats lost the House for the first time in 40 years, blamed the assault weapons ban and let it expire. They have struggled ever since to figure out a winning gun safety message.

headline: Another Hurdle in Recovery From Helene: Misinformation Is Getting in the Way
abstract: In North Carolina and other states, a barrage of conspiracy theories and false claims over efforts to bring relief after Hurricane Helene is alarming and disheartening officials and workers.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of Hurricane Helene’s devastation in western North Carolina, the public meeting in Rutherford County last Wednesday was essential business. Officials from several shellshocked communities convened to talk about the extensive damage and ongoing search-and-rescue efforts.

headline: Susie Maxwell Berning, Hall of Fame Golfer, Is Dead at 83
abstract: She often took time away from the tour for her family. But she tallied 11 championships, including three in the U.S. Women’s Open.
lead_paragraph: Susie Maxwell Berning, a three-time champion of the United States Women’s Open golf tournament who was known for her tenacity on the fairway and her grace off it, died on Wednesday at her home in Indio, in Southern California. She was 83.

headline: 4 Charged in Manhattan Assault on Former Gov. David Paterson
abstract: Two adults and two boys, ages 12 and 13, were charged in the attack on the former New York governor and his stepson, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A man and a woman were arrested and charged on Monday with assaulting David A. Paterson, a former governor of New York, and his stepson, the police said, two days after the arrests of two boys who were also charged in the street attack.

headline: Review: Philharmonic Returns to Classics, at Its Own Expense
abstract: Led by Manfred Honeck, the orchestra all too quickly revisited Beethoven’s Seventh Symphony and, with Vikingur Olafsson, Brahms’s Piano Concerto No. 1.
lead_paragraph: A risk of programming standard repertory works over and over is that an orchestra is practically begging to be compared with its own recent performances — not to mention a huge and ever-growing body of recordings. Why should someone buy a ticket to a concert if they just heard the same group do the same piece, or if they can stay home and listen to dozens of masterly versions online?

headline: Tim Walz Makes First Sunday Show Appearance Since Joining Ticket
abstract: Mr. Walz, who has kept a relatively low profile since becoming Vice President Kamala Harris’s running mate, appeared on Fox News Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota fielded tough questions on abortion, immigration, the economy and his own past misstatements in an interview on “Fox News Sunday,” that was mainly noteworthy because it was his first appearance on a Sunday news program since becoming Vice President Kamala Harris’s running mate.

headline: Christopher Ciccone, Who Dished About His Sister Madonna, Dies at 63
abstract: An artist, designer, choreographer and dancer, he was best known for writing a grudge-settling memoir about his formerly close bond with the pop star.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Ciccone, who devoted himself to his older sister Madonna — living with her, warning her of impending arrest and directing her world tours of the early 1990s — but who later, after feeling cast aside, wrote a memoir chronicling experiences that he described as abuse, died on Friday. He was 63.

headline: Pakistan Bans Protest Movement in Renewed Crackdown on Dissent
abstract: Analysts say the military is expanding its efforts to squash opposition.
lead_paragraph: The Pakistani government on Sunday banned an ethnic Pashtun rights movement that has long criticized the country’s powerful military, the latest sign of a renewed crackdown on public dissent and political opposition.

headline: Antisemitic Incidents Reach New High in the U.S., Report Finds
abstract: The Anti-Defamation League has found that cases of antisemitism have surged in the wake of the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas against Israel last year.
lead_paragraph: The number of antisemitic episodes in the United States surged to the highest recorded in a one-year period in the wake of the Hamas attack on Israel last year, the Anti-Defamation League said on Sunday.

headline: A ‘Hallowed Place,’ With a Whiff of Onion Rings and Sun Block
abstract: Donald Trump returned to the site where he was shot in the ear. For some of his supporters, it was a religious event as much as a campaign rally.
lead_paragraph: “We have fought together,” former President Donald J. Trump told his supporters on Saturday evening. “We have bled together.”

headline: At North Carolina Churches After Helene, a Time to Grieve and a Time to Hope
abstract: Worshipers gathered on Sunday, many for the first time since the storm decimated their communities, “to cry and pray and process.”
lead_paragraph: As people headed toward First Baptist Church Swannanoa on Sunday, it was impossible to forget what had happened to their small mountain community in western North Carolina. Scattered across the landscape were broken pieces of life before the remnants of Hurricane Helene barreled through: chunks of asphalt, shredded trees, fragments of home foundations. Nearby, a search-and-rescue team clambered over debris.

headline: Monday Briefing: Reflecting on a Year of War
abstract: Plus, Paris Fashion Week’s closing fantasia.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a year since the Hamas-led attacks in Israel on Oct. 7, when officials say 1,200 people were killed and roughly 250 more were kidnapped. Since then, health officials say more than 41,000 Palestinians, many of them civilians and children, have been killed in the subsequent war. The fighting has widened to three fronts, and the path to reaching a cease-fire seems uncertain. To reflect on the past year of war in the Middle East, I spoke to Isabel Kershner, who has been covering Israeli and Palestinian affairs for decades and is based in Jerusalem.

headline: Harris Hits Back at G.O.P. Criticism of Childless Women on ‘Call Her Daddy’ Podcast
abstract: “All of us understand that this is not the 1950s anymore,” Vice President Kamala Harris told the host of the podcast “Call Her Daddy,” which is popular with millennial and Gen Z women.
lead_paragraph: For the first time, Vice President Kamala Harris dismissed criticism from some Republicans that she does not have biological children, saying in a podcast interview on Sunday that much of the commentary was “meanspirited” and misunderstood women who either can’t have children or simply did not want to.

headline: Israel Steps Up Attacks in Gaza and Lebanon Ahead of Oct. 7 Anniversary
abstract: Israel appeared to label much of northern Gaza as an evacuation zone and in Lebanon, Israeli airstrikes targeted Hezbollah strongholds, as the region also braced for Israel to hit back at Iran.
lead_paragraph: Israel intensified its fight on two fronts Sunday, stepping up operations against Hamas in Gaza and carrying out more airstrikes on Hezbollah in Lebanon, as the region braced for Israel to hit back at Iran for its barrage of ballistic missiles last week.

headline: Blueprint Detail
abstract: While away the hours with Desirée Penner and Jeff Sinnock.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Evacuation Orders Posted as Florida Braces for Hurricane Milton
abstract: The powerful, life-threatening hurricane is expected to make landfall on Wednesday even as residents continue to recover from Hurricane Helene.
lead_paragraph: Evacuations and storm preparations began on Sunday night as forecasters projected that Hurricane Milton would slam into Florida’s west coast on Wednesday as a major hurricane packing life-threatening winds and storm surge.

headline: 51 Days
abstract: Chen Almog-Goldstein was kidnapped along with her three youngest children on Oct. 7, 2023. She tells the story of life as a hostage in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: On This Week’s Episode:

headline: Robert Coover, Inventive Novelist in Iconoclastic Era, Dies at 92
abstract: Once called “probably the funniest and most malicious” of the postmodernists, his books reflected a career-long interest in reimagining folk stories, fairy tales and political myths.
lead_paragraph: Robert Coover, who along with Donald Barthelme, John Barth and others occupied the vanguard of postmodern American fiction in the 1960s and 1970s, and who went on to a long and prolific career writing and teaching, died on Saturday in Warwick, England. He was 92.

headline: Gulf Coast States Have Been Battered by Hurricanes This Year
abstract: Here’s a look at the storms that have hit the area.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Milton is expected to slam into Florida’s west coast on Wednesday as a major hurricane, packing life-threatening winds and storm surge. It would be the fifth to make landfall somewhere along the Gulf Coast of the United States this year.

headline: No Corrections: Oct. 7, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 7, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Fighting Myanmar’s Patriarchy, One All-Male Panel at a Time
abstract: Ying Lao has called out the pro-democracy movement for its frequent “manels,” arguing that the exclusion of women from such discussions is hurting the cause.
lead_paragraph: A panel discussion in Myanmar about female leadership had two speakers. Both were male.

headline: How E-Commerce Is Making China’s Deflation Worse
abstract: The push by Pinduoduo to lower prices has helped it become one of China’s fastest-growing e-commerce apps, and epitomizes a broader force plaguing the economy.
lead_paragraph: When Lin Yunyun started selling diapers two years ago on Pinduoduo, China’s fast-growing e-commerce site, she was not prepared for the relentless nagging about prices.

headline: Our Photographers in Israel and Gaza on the Images They Can’t Forget
abstract: Seven New York Times photojournalists describe moments that have defined a year of war.
lead_paragraph: The moment the first alarms sounded in Israel on Oct. 7, New York Times photographers began to document the unfolding crisis.

headline: Quote of the Day: A Changing Climate Is Scorching the World’s Biggest River
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 7, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Here, the rivers are our streets.”

headline: The War That Won’t End: How Oct. 7 Sparked a Year of Conflict
abstract: As war in the Middle East spreads, the original conflict between Israel and Hamas has persisted. This is why.
lead_paragraph: Yaniv Hegyi, an Israeli community organizer, fled his home last Oct. 7, after terrorists from Gaza overran his village in southern Israel. “I was sure that by January we would go back,” Mr. Hegyi said.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: Reflecting on a year of war in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: It has been a year since the Oct. 7 surprise attack on Israel led by Hamas, in which officials say 1,200 people were killed and about 250 others kidnapped.

headline: I Was a Best-Selling Novelist. Then I Went Back to School.
abstract: A writer reconsiders the value of literature and goes back to school to study behavioral change — and maybe change himself.
lead_paragraph: By the last page of my last novel, the doubts had become a certainty: I couldn’t keep writing fiction.

headline: I’m a Great Grandmother, and a Former Hostage of Hamas. Bring The Rest Home.
abstract: My name is Yaffa Adar. I’m 86 years old. I was a hostage of Hamas.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 7, 2023, my freedom, security and peace were brutally taken from me. That day, I was kidnapped from my home in Kibbutz Nir Oz. The rolling fields and beautiful farmland of our kibbutz turned into a battlefield as hordes of terrorists raided our homes, murdering, kidnapping, burning and looting. A quarter of the community that I was a part of for 56 years was either murdered or kidnapped. I am 86 years old; in my life, I had never experienced this sort of horror.

headline: What I’m Thinking About on the First Anniversary of the War
abstract: One year after being attacked, Israel has not won the battle on the ground or the battle for a good story to tell about itself and this war.
lead_paragraph: So what am I thinking about on this first anniversary of the Hamas-Hezbollah-Iran-Israel war? Something my strategy teacher, Prof. John Arquilla of the U.S. Naval Postgraduate School, taught me: All wars come down to two basic questions: Who wins the battle on the ground? And who wins the battle of the story? And what I am thinking about today is how, even after a year of warfare, in which Hamas and Hezbollah and Israel have inflicted terrible pain on one another’s forces and civilians, no one has decisively won the battle on the ground or the battle for the story. Indeed, one year after Oct. 7, this is still the first Arab-Israeli war without a name and without a clear victor — because neither side has a clear win or a clean story.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Below Deck Sailing Yacht’ and ‘Abbott Elementary’
abstract: Bravo airs its reality show about “yachties,” and ABC is back with its Emmy-winning sitcom.
lead_paragraph: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, Oct. 7-13. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Word of the Day: initiative
abstract: This word has appeared in 1,445 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word initiative has appeared in 1,445 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 30 in “Vintage Shopping Is Booming. Banana Republic and Others Get In on the Action” by Linda Baker:

headline: Convoy Carrying Chinese Workers Is Attacked in Pakistan
abstract: Emergency workers tended to the injured after the attack near an airport in Karachi. At least two Chinese nationals were killed.
lead_paragraph: Emergency workers tended to the injured after the attack near an airport in Karachi. At least two Chinese nationals were killed.

headline: China Calls for Tighter Security After Workers Are Killed in Pakistan
abstract: Two Chinese nationals were killed and another was injured after a convoy was attacked in Karachi on Sunday. A separatist group claimed responsibility.
lead_paragraph: Two Chinese nationals were killed and another was injured after a convoy was attacked in Karachi, the largest city in Pakistan, on Sunday, adding to concerns over the safety of Chinese workers involved in major projects in the South Asian nation.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Climbers Are Rescued After Three Nights at 20,000 Feet
abstract: The two women, one American and one British, became stranded on a Himalayan mountain when their food and equipment fell into a ravine, Indian officials said.
lead_paragraph: Two climbers, one American and one British, were rescued from a Himalayan mountain after being stranded for three nights at nearly 20,000 feet, Indian officials said.

headline: What’s a ‘Slaveroad’? A Bridge Across Oceans and Generations.
abstract: John Edgar Wideman’s new book connects reflections on his own life to imaginative studies of historical figures.
lead_paragraph: Early in “Slaveroad,” John Edgar Wideman observes that one of the book’s main figures, William Henry Sheppard, a descendant of enslaved Virginians turned Presbyterian missionary, arrived in the Belgian Congo in 1890 around the same time that Joseph Conrad did.

headline: How Oct. 7 Upended One Man’s Diary
abstract: In “Diary of a Crisis,” Saul Friedländer takes the violence and upheaval in Israel day by day.
lead_paragraph: “What sort of diary should I like mine to be?” Virginia Woolf asked — in her diary — in 1919, before attempting an answer: “Something loose knit, & yet not slovenly, so elastic that it will embrace any thing, solemn, slight or beautiful that comes into my mind.” The immediacy of writing without much time for reflection ensured a welcome mode of unthinking, Woolf observed. A diary, she had written a few months earlier, “sweeps up accidentally several stray matters which I should exclude if I hesitated, but which are the diamonds of the dustheap.”

headline: Reckoning With Israel’s Past Is Hard. The Present Is Harder.
abstract: An Oct. 7 survival memoir and a chronicle of theft in 1948 grapple with the history of a war-torn region.
lead_paragraph: Last autumn, in the weeks after Hamas’s brutal attack on Israel and the start of Israel’s crushing retaliation, it suddenly seemed as if everyone was talking about what Palestinians call the Nakba.

headline: How Can I Get ‘Forever Chemicals’ Out of My Life?
abstract: They’re almost everywhere. And they’re bad. But there are some things you can do to avoid them.
lead_paragraph: “Forever chemicals,” also known as PFAS, are everywhere. They’re in our water, our soil and in everyday items like cookware, mascara or waterproof clothing.

headline: Growing Cannabis and Opium Poppies May Be Key to U.S. Supply Chains
abstract: After supply chain disruptions that made critical medicines scarce, a federal effort is underway to ensure domestic stocks of pharmaceutical ingredients.
lead_paragraph: Never mind that everyone calls him Groovy, or that the company he oversees — Bright Green — is preparing to grow cannabis and opium poppies inside greenhouses on the high desert of New Mexico. Gurvinder Singh would like it known that his business is a rigorous scientific enterprise.

headline: Can a Vegetarian Dine Well in New York? We Put Some Top Menus to the Test.
abstract: Even the city’s best restaurants deal with meat-averse customers in a variety of ways, from discouraging them to welcoming them.
lead_paragraph: More times than I can count, I’ve heard the same refrain from my vegetarian relatives visiting New York: This is not a friendly city for the meat-averse. Restaurants don’t offer enough meatless options, they say, especially dishes that are as filling and interesting as the nonvegetarian ones.

headline: To Really See Peru, Hop on (and Off) the Bus
abstract: Most travelers fly between cities like Lima, Cuzco and Arequipa, but if you want to explore beaches, deserts and mountains at your own pace, try a hop-on, hop-off bus.
lead_paragraph: I was in a dune buggy perched atop a sandy ridge near the small oasis town of Huacachina, Peru, looking down a nearly 60-foot drop. As the driver gunned the engine, I began to question my decision to sign up for this tour.

headline: Add ‘I’m Getting a Little Older’ to the Challenges of Apartment Hunting
abstract: Finding a rental is one thing, but moving into it is no picnic either. These days, a “senior move manager” can help streamline the process.
lead_paragraph: Apartment hunting in Brooklyn earlier this year was the predictable nightmare.

headline: The Tech Lobbying Group Helping to Broaden the First Amendment’s Reach
abstract: NetChoice, backed by tech giants including Meta and Google, has successfully argued in court that Big Tech hosts protected speech.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of a recent vote in Congress on a child safety bill, a powerful tech lobby representing Google, Meta and other major tech firms sent a forceful warning to lawmakers.

headline: On Israeli Apathy
abstract: The lawlessness and state violence directed at Palestinians for so long have at last started to seep into Jewish Israeli society.
lead_paragraph: At one of the recent mass demonstrations in Tel Aviv calling for a hostage deal and for early elections to replace the Israeli government, one protester held up a sign reading: “Who are we without them?” referring to the hostages. Another placard read: “Give me one reason to raise kids here.”

headline: The ‘Crypto Punks’ Behind Trump’s Murky New Business Venture
abstract: The serial entrepreneurs behind Donald J. Trump’s new cryptocurrency project have left a trail of lawsuits, unpaid debt and tax liens.
lead_paragraph: Chase Herro is an online salesman who proudly calls himself a “dirtbag of the internet,” able to sell anything to anyone. Zachary Folkman ran a company called Date Hotter Girls, offering advice under a pseudonym on how to pick up women at bars.

headline: Anthony Fauci: A Mosquito in My Backyard Made Me the Sickest I’ve Ever Been
abstract: What it’s like to get the neglected disease.
lead_paragraph: After I spent more than 50 years chasing and fighting viruses, one fought back and nearly took me down. I speak of the West Nile virus, delivered by the deadliest animal on the planet: the mosquito.

headline: Who Gets to Be a Daddy?
abstract: The best compliment a man — gay or straight, old or … not so old — can receive is to enter the pantheon of daddies.
lead_paragraph: I KNEW THE day would come, but I didn’t expect it to arrive with such savagery. It was a late spring evening. I was strolling down the street in Provincetown, Mass., with my husband when a car pulled up and a young, confident male voice — an unmistakably gay voice, and yes, there is such a thing — targeted both of us with stinging exactitude. “’Sup, daddies?” the voice said, the speaker barely bothering to conceal his sneer as the car sped away.

headline: How Everyone Got Lost in Netflix’s Endless Library
abstract: Ten years after Silicon Valley remade TV, it’s become clear how the streaming revolution distorted our collective viewing habits — and sense of the culture.
lead_paragraph: If you take a journey deep within Netflix’s furthest recesses — burrow past Bingeworthy TV Dramas and 1980s Action Thrillers, take a left at Because You Watched the Lego Batman Movie, keep going past Fright Night — you will eventually find your way to the platform’s core, the forgotten layers of content fossilized by the pressure from the accreted layers above. Down here, if you search hard enough, you will eventually find your way to “Richie Rich.”

headline: This Supreme Court Is Its Own Worst Enemy
abstract: If it loses its institutional credibility, it will be powerless when it matters most.
lead_paragraph: There are important cases among the 40 that the Supreme Court has agreed to hear in its new term beginning on Monday, but no blockbusters: nothing like last term’s ruling in the Donald Trump immunity case, or the affirmative action case from 2023, or the abortion and guns rulings from 2022.

headline: A Striking Ballet Gets a New Life. So Does a Budding Ballerina.
abstract: Olivia Bell, 20, a radiant member of New York City Ballet, reprises the role she knocked out of the park as a student: “I want to do it right.”
lead_paragraph: Olivia Bell walks to the front of the stage where a piano sits. She rests a hand on it and nods to the pianist for the music to start — the first sign in “Signs,” a ballet of mystery and depth. The curtain rises behind her; the dancing begins. Bell is the ballet’s unflappable leader, both lithe and resolute. She is its lighthouse, its anchor. “In a lot of the movements that I do, it’s kind of me controlling everyone, but not in a controlling way,” she said. “I’m the conductor of the ballet.”

headline: Flamenco Is the Lifeblood of ‘Ainadamar’ at the Met
abstract: Osvaldo Golijov’s opera about Federico García Lorca makes its Met debut in a dance-heavy production, directed by the choreographer Deborah Colker.
lead_paragraph: Rippling scales of Spanish guitar, the howls of a raspy-voiced singer, thunderous clapping and stamping — the sounds could have been coming from a tavern in Andalusia, home of flamenco. But this was the Metropolitan Opera House during a recent rehearsal for its new production of “Ainadamar.”

headline: Rent Was $325 a Month and the Piano Fit
abstract: A couple briefly considered moving to one of the newer market-rate buildings in New York City and paying more for a splashier place. Then they got real.
lead_paragraph: David Hedges and Joel Auville recently considered moving. There’s a lot of large-scale, long-term construction right outside their windows. “With this new building,” Mr. Auville said, “we were depressed, thinking we were going to lose light.”

headline: The 25 Best Restaurants in Nashville Right Now
abstract: With barbecue, haute Southern cooking, innovative Chinese cuisine and even a revelatory fried fish shop, the food scene in Music City as vibrant as it’s ever been.
lead_paragraph: In the Where to Eat: 25 Best series, we’re highlighting our favorite restaurants in cities across the United States. These lists will be updated as restaurants close and open, and as we find new gems to recommend. As always, we pay for all of our meals and don’t accept free items.

headline: Scoops, Dupes and Kooks: A History of The New York Post
abstract: A new book chronicles the last 50 years of a notorious American tabloid.
lead_paragraph: “Where are the reporters of yesteryear?” a character asks in Annie Proulx’s novel “The Shipping News.” “The nail biting, acerbic, alcoholic nighthawk bastards who truly knew how to write?” Some of them are here, filing drunkenly on deadline and then vomiting onto their editors’ desks, in a lively and sprawling new book, “Paper of Wreckage: An Oral History of The New York Post, 1976-2024,” by Susan Mulcahy and Frank DiGiacomo.

headline: For Some Children, Hurricane Helene’s Ruin ‘Could Take Years to Get Over’
abstract: School closures and traumatic experiences could affect children long after schools reopen. Experts worry that similar scenarios are happening with much more frequency because of climate change.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of children across the Southeast remain out of their classrooms one week after Helene, the deadliest hurricane to strike the mainland United States since Katrina. They are cut off from academics, friends and stabilizing routines.

headline: She and Her Husband Were Taken by Hamas. She Was Freed. He’s Still in Gaza.
abstract: A year after their home in Israel was torched and her family was taken by attackers on Oct. 7, a wife and mother clings to the hope that her husband might still come home alive.
lead_paragraph: Since Sharon Aloni Cunio was released from captivity in Gaza last November, she has struggled to enjoy basic comforts: eating as much as she wants, using the bathroom when she wants, rolling cigarettes beside her cats in her childhood home.

headline: Who Most Inspires You?
abstract: A guest essay argues that Shohei Ohtani and his magnificent baseball season can reconnect us all to our own potential for greatness. Who does that for you?
lead_paragraph: Have you been following Shohei Ohtani’s record-breaking season for the Los Angeles Dodgers? In the guest essay “What Shohei Ohtani and His Magnificent Season Mean for You,” Brad Stulberg explains what makes it so exceptional:

headline: Nowhere to Go: How Gaza Became a Mass Death Trap
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of civilians have been prevented from fleeing the narrow strip of land even as bombs have rained down, famine has loomed and disease has spread.
lead_paragraph: Of all the grim distinctions of the yearlong war in Gaza that followed the savage Hamas attack on Israel last Oct. 7, one may stand out for its deadly singularity: Palestinian civilians there have nowhere to go. Barricaded by barbed-wire fences, tanks and soldiers, they have been effectively imprisoned for 12 months in a 141-square-mile strip of land between Egypt and Israel that has become a killing zone.

headline: ‘Ghost Guns’ Case Before Supreme Court Has Major Implications for Industry in Flux
abstract: The number of untraceable homemade guns recovered at crime scenes has fallen since the enactment of rules restricting the sale of the weapons, according to law enforcement statistics.
lead_paragraph: A small company operating out of a warehouse on the edge of a sagebrush airstrip near Carson City, Nev., temporarily halted its operations this summer, which gun control groups hailed as a major victory in their fight to stem the spread of unregulated firearms in America.

headline: State of the Race: A Big Week in News, but a Quiet One in Polling
abstract: The polls are still so close that neither candidate has a significant advantage.
lead_paragraph: With four weeks to go until the election, the race for the White House is as tight as it’s been for the last two weeks.

headline: $1.35 Million Homes in California
abstract: A 1958 midcentury-modern house in Palm Springs, a 1947 ranch-style house in Los Angeles, and a 1926 Craftsman-style house in Berkeley.
