lead_paragraph: This house, designed by the architects Dan Palmer and William Krisel and built by the Alexander Construction Company, retains many of its original details from 1958, including a stone fireplace and tongue-and-groove wood ceilings. The in-ground saltwater swimming pool is a more recent addition. The home, which has been used as a vacation rental, is available fully furnished.

headline: How Big Should a Handbag Be?
abstract: A reader wonders if it’s better to carry a small bag or a large one. Our critic explains the relationship between purse size and power.
lead_paragraph: Remember that famous scene from Season 4 of “Succession,” in which Cousin Greg brings a date to Logan Roy’s party and she’s carrying what Tom calls a “ludicrously capacious bag”? It pretty much sums up the situation.

headline: There Is No Climate Haven. We All Live in Florida Now.
abstract: Hurricane Helene has reminded us. Climate change has stacked the deck against all of us.
lead_paragraph: Watching as Hurricane Helene slammed into Tennessee, distant friends kept checking in on us here in Nashville, but we were fine. Better than fine, in truth: After weeks of drought, we were finally getting some desperately needed rain. Helene made landfall on the Big Bend coast of Florida on a Thursday night; by Saturday, Nashville had already gotten enough rain to erase the entire year’s rainfall deficit, and it was still coming down.

headline: New Yorkers Are Getting the Message on Storing E-Batteries
abstract: Fewer of the fires are starting indoors, which suggests that New Yorkers are heeding warnings and storing the batteries outside.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at why fires involving e-bike batteries — which have prompted warnings from fire officials in the last couple of years — are causing fewer fatalities in New York City.

headline: A Year After Oct. 7 Massacre, Jewish Anxiety Peaks in Pennsylvania
abstract: Jewish voters in Pittsburgh feel squeezed by intolerance on the left and the right, and torn by presidential candidates seeking their support in a vital battleground state.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday evening, as Rosh Hashana began in Pittsburgh’s heavily Jewish neighborhood of Squirrel Hill, Rabbi Daniel Fellman stepped up to the pulpit of Temple Sinai and lamented: “Our American Jewish community cries out in despair.”

headline: How Could the Election Be This Close?
abstract: No one said it was going to be easy for Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Gail, why isn’t Kamala Harris running away with the election? The race in the battleground states is basically a tie, despite Harris spending three times as much money as Donald Trump and having a much bigger ground game — and despite Trump putting in a terrible debate performance and generally making a spectacle of himself, or worse, every time he opens his mouth.

headline: At the New York Film Festival, the Most Innovative Work Is Nonfiction
abstract: In epic takes like “My Undesirable Friends” and playful biopics like “Pavements,” the vital art of the documentary is on full display.
lead_paragraph: Documentaries face a great paradox in 2024: They proliferate, but most nonfiction filmmakers will tell you they’re also harder to get made. Streaming services groan under the weight of true crime and biographical films, but most feel fast, formulaic and shoddy, designed specifically to throw on while watchers scroll on their phones. Meanwhile, directors who aspire to challenge audiences and craft art from reality say that they struggle to find money and distribution — and that it’s gotten markedly tougher in just the past few years.

headline: Trump’s Plans Could Increase U.S. Debt While Raising Costs for Most Americans
abstract: A new analysis finds that Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump’s plans would both add to the deficit, but Mr. Trump’s proposals could create a fiscal hole twice as big.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s economic proposals could inflame the nation’s debt burden while ultimately raising costs for a vast majority of Americans, according to a pair of new economic analyses that are among the most in-depth studies to date of the Republican nominee’s plans.

headline: I Live in Israel. I Never Hear About What My Country Is Doing to Gaza.
abstract: Mairav Zonszein argues there will be a cost to her country’s “indifference” toward Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: Israeli anger toward Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been building in the year since the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks. Mairav Zonszein, an Israeli-American journalist and analyst, argues that this anger does not extend to the plight of the Palestinians living in Gaza and the West Bank. More than 41,000 people have been killed in Gaza, and yet, she says, Israelis are stuck in a cycle of “apathy” and “indifference,” unable to fully realize the devastation befalling their neighbors.

headline: Campuses Are Calmer, but They Are Not Normal, Students and Faculty Say
abstract: A year of war in Gaza has left college students and faculty feeling shaken and angry, with the world and with each other.
lead_paragraph: On the surface, the scene on Columbia University’s campus appeared to have returned to normal after a spring semester rocked by pro-Palestinian encampments and police crackdowns. Students ate lunch on green lawns last week and tapped a volleyball back and forth under sunny skies.

headline: In a World Changed by Oct. 7, Hatred Is Winning
abstract: Peace in the Middle East seems more elusive than ever, with Oct. 7 setting off a battle over not just land but the narrative itself.
lead_paragraph: A year has passed in Israel and Gaza like some nightmare from which there is no awakening. Hatred is the only winner. It towers over the corpse of a two-state Israeli-Palestinian peace and threatens to spread across the Middle East.

headline: Israelis Mourn Nova Music Festival Victims
abstract: Families of the victims organized the dawn memorial ceremony at the Re’im forest one year after the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack on Israel.
lead_paragraph: Families of the victims organized the dawn memorial ceremony at the Re’im forest one year after the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack on Israel.

headline: Remembering the Nova Festival Victims, With the Sounds of War as a Backdrop
abstract: After hearing the dance track that was playing a year ago when the Hamas-led assault began, the hundreds who had gathered stood for a minute of silence, broken by a bereaved mother’s cries.
lead_paragraph: The dawn memorial ceremony in a clearing at the Re’im forest, the site of the Nova music festival where more than 380 people were killed in the Hamas-led assault against Israel a year ago, took place under heavy security and against a backdrop of continued war.

headline: Discovery in Tiny Worm Leads to Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for 2 Scientists
abstract: The prize was awarded to Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun for their discovery of microRNA, which helps determine how cells develop and function.
lead_paragraph: Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun were awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine on Monday for the discovery of microRNA, a tiny class of RNA molecules that play a crucial role in determining how organisms mature and function — and how they sometimes malfunction.

headline: A Haunted House, Psychedelic Cats and Shrimp: Inside Nutter Butter’s Fever Dream
abstract: The cookie sandwich brand’s videos — funny, disturbing, fever-dreamlike — rack up tens of millions of views. The secret is lots of lore without much sense, the campaign’s strategists explain.
lead_paragraph: Cassie Fitzwater hadn’t thought about Nutter Butter in years — until she saw the brutal crime scene photos.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,207
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Oct. 8, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 485
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Oct. 8, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: European Space Mission Launches to Investigate an Asteroid Crash Site
abstract: The Hera spacecraft, which took flight late Monday morning, is part of a broader effort to bolster humanity’s planetary defense readiness.
lead_paragraph: In humanity’s latest bid to avoid going the way of the dinosaurs, a European spacecraft soared away from the coast of Florida on Monday. The mission, Hera, will visit an asteroid that NASA deliberately struck with another spacecraft two years ago.

headline: Israel Commemorates Oct. 7 Anniversary Amid Strikes on Gaza and Lebanon
abstract: Plus, misinformation is hampering the Helene aid effort.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The Year Since Oct. 7
abstract: Two men in Israel and Gaza talk about how their lives have changed.
lead_paragraph: Warning: this episode contains strong language, descriptions of war and trauma.

headline: Palestinians in Gaza Reflect on One Year of Israel’s War With Hamas
abstract: The war has killed tens of thousands and devastated entire cities, leaving many in Gaza without a home and fueling a humanitarian catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: Last October, Fadi Abu Kheir of southern Gaza had big plans. He was going to be engaged to the woman he loved. After they got married, he said, they would move in together, into an apartment that he spent years building.

headline: One Year Later
abstract: We’re covering the anniversary of the Oct. 7 attack — and how it has reshaped the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Many Israeli families were starting their weekend routines — on a Saturday, the Jewish sabbath, one year ago — when the first signs of trouble appeared. Hamas sent explosive drones and fired thousands of rockets from Gaza into Israel.

headline: Hostages’ Families Endure Surreal Wait on Anniversary of Oct. 7 Attacks
abstract: More than 60 living hostages, and the bodies of about 35 others who are believed to be dead, are still in Gaza, according to the Israeli authorities.
lead_paragraph: The families of Israeli hostages held in the Gaza Strip have spent 12 months in a kind of suspended animation, trapped in the amber of last Oct. 7 while the rest of the world spins forward to new if related crises: Iranian missile attacks, targeted assassinations of militant leaders and the outbreak of war in Lebanon.

headline: Ex-Philippine President, Under Investigation for War on Drugs, Returns to Politics
abstract: Rodrigo Duterte, who retired in 2022 after a six-year term as president, filed papers to run for mayor of Davao, his family’s political stronghold.
lead_paragraph: Before Rodrigo Duterte became president of the Philippines and ordered a war on drugs in which tens of thousands of innocent people are estimated to have died, he was the mayor of the southern city of Davao. It was where he first sponsored the deadly tactics for extrajudicial killings that would go on to ravage the country for years.

headline: Philip Banks and 2 Other Aides Leave Adams Administration
abstract: Mr. Banks, the deputy mayor for public safety and a close friend of Mayor Eric Adams, resigned. He is among the officials whose phones were seized by investigators.
lead_paragraph: Hours after Mayor Eric Adams announced the resignation of New York City’s deputy mayor for public safety on Monday, officials said two lower-level aides who have also figured prominently in federal investigations swirling around City Hall were departing.

headline: Are Today’s Tax Credits the Best Way to Get Americans to Buy E.V.s?
abstract: The Inflation Reduction Act was a compromise between competing priorities. Evaluating the law on the effectiveness of the $7,500 tax credit for E.V.s is tricky.
lead_paragraph: A team of economists has taken on a central component of the Inflation Reduction Act: the $7,500 tax credit for U.S.-made electric vehicles.

headline: Two Tech Moguls Split on Trump
abstract: Elon Musk appeared onstage at a rally for the former president this weekend, but Silicon Valley was abuzz about Ben Horowitz’s U-turn on backing the Republican candidate.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than a month away, but that’s still plenty of time for surprises to shake up the excruciatingly tight race. The past few days brought some from the tech community.

headline: ‘The Big Gay Jamboree’ Review: A Golden-Age Fantasia on Steroids
abstract: The goofball spirit that made Marla Mindelle’s “Titaníque” a hit is missing from her equally campy new show drenched in pop-culture references.
lead_paragraph: When “Titaníque” opened in a cramped basement space two years ago, few would have imagined that the show, a commingling of the James Cameron disaster movie and the Celine Dion songbook, would amount to more than a short-lived lark. Yet it is still running — in a proper, aboveground theater — and has spawned productions in Britain, Canada and Australia.

headline: Porn Industry Jumps Into the Presidential Campaign, Targeting Project 2025
abstract: In seven swing states, the industry’s websites will feature ads decrying the conservative policy blueprint’s proposed ban on pornography.
lead_paragraph: Just when you thought everyone had already jumped into the 2024 campaign, here come the porn stars.

headline: Russia Sentences 72-Year-Old American on Charges of Fighting for Ukraine
abstract: Stephen James Hubbard, a native of Big Rapids, Mich., whose family says is an English teacher, was sentenced to six years and 10 months in a penal colony.
lead_paragraph: A 72-year-old U.S. citizen, whose family says is an English teacher, was sentenced by a Moscow court Monday to six years and 10 months in a penal colony on charges of serving as a mercenary in Ukraine, becoming the latest in a list of Americans serving time in Russia.

headline: Fears of a Global Oil Shock if the Mideast Crisis Intensifies
abstract: The threat of an escalating conflict between Israel and Iran has created an “extraordinarily precarious” global situation, sowing alarm about the potential economic fallout.
lead_paragraph: As the world absorbs the prospect of an escalating conflict in the Middle East, the potential economic fallout is sowing increasing alarm. The worst fears center on a broadly debilitating development: a shock to the global oil supply.

headline: Victims of a $7 Billion Fraud May Soon Be Paid. For Some, It’s Too Late.
abstract: Not having much insight into what may happen next in the case of a fraud orchestrated by Robert Allen Stanford, many of the victims sold the rights to any future payout.
lead_paragraph: It has been 15 years since Thomas Swingle first learned that about $1 million of his family’s savings had gone up in smoke, after the financier Robert Allen Stanford was exposed for having sold billions in fraudulent certificates of deposit to investors around the world.

headline: Key Events During a Year of Middle East War
abstract: Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack on Israel and the 12 months of conflagration that has followed.
lead_paragraph: Near dawn one year ago, the militant group Hamas began an assault from Gaza into Israel.

headline: Do You Know These Books That Were Adapted Into Broadway Flops?
abstract: Popular literature has often been the source of a big-budget musical, but not every show is a hit. Can you identify these five short-lived productions?
lead_paragraph: Popular literature has often been the source of a big-budget musical, but not every show is a hit. Can you identify these five short-lived productions?

headline: Lore Segal, Mordant Novelist of Émigré Life, Dies at 96
abstract: Transported to safe haven in England as a Jewish child in 1938, she explored themes of displacement with penetrating wit in autobiographical fiction like “Other People’s Houses.”
lead_paragraph: Lore Segal, a virtuosic and witty author of autobiographical novels of her life as a young Jewish Viennese refugee in England and as an émigré in America, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 96.

headline: Oct. 7: For Jews in America, a Time of Reflection
abstract: Readers respond to a column by Bret Stephens. Also: Republicans’ plans to challenge the election; Vanderbilt’s leader, on flawed college rankings.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Have We Reached Peak Human Life Span?
abstract: After decades of rising life expectancy, the increases appear to be slowing. A new study calls into question how long even the healthiest of populations can live.
lead_paragraph: The oldest human on record, Jeanne Calment of France, lived to the age of 122. What are the odds that the rest of us get there, too?

headline: When Two Sea Aliens Become One
abstract: Primitive animals called comb jellies can fuse their bodies and nervous systems together.
lead_paragraph: Comb jellies, the delicate bells that pulse their iridescent bodies through the ocean, are some of the strangest creatures on earth. “They are the aliens of the sea,” said Leonid Moroz, a neuroscientist at the Whitney Laboratory for Marine Bioscience in St. Augustine, Fla.

headline: Let’s Do a Donabe
abstract: Kay Chun’s chicken and vegetable donabe is soothing and mellow, ready to be perked up with citrusy ponzu and yuzu kosho.
lead_paragraph: As peak one-pot season draws near once again, it’s the perfect time to celebrate not only those cozy, soul-warming dishes, but the vessels that contain them: the sturdy cast-iron Dutch oven, the gleaming stainless-steel soup pot and the earthy donabe, a traditional Japanese clay pot, to name a few. All can be used to bubble up a plethora of savory meals. What’s more, these champions of coziness are often interchangeable. So feel free to pull out your Dutch oven or soup pot to cook Kay Chun’s chicken and vegetable donabe.

headline: Tunisia’s President Cruises to a Victory That Critics Say He Engineered
abstract: President Kais Saied’s apparent landslide re-election is the latest sign that authoritarianism has returned to the birthplace of the Arab Spring.
lead_paragraph: In Tunisia’s first presidential election since its authoritarian leader began dismantling the democracy Tunisians built after their 2011 Arab Spring revolution, the apparent winner came as little surprise: the incumbent himself.

headline: In London, a Pro-Palestinian Protest Disrupts the Launch of an American Mural
abstract: The U.S. ambassador Jane Hartley was en route to the dedication of a climate-themed mural in London by Shepard Fairey, who created the iconic Obama ‘Hope’ poster. But then a protest began.
lead_paragraph: It’s the kind of cultural exchange any diplomat would savor: A prominent American street artist paints a mural, dedicated to the cause of climate activism, on an apartment building in one of London’s hippest neighborhoods.

headline: Emirates bans pagers and walkie-talkies on flights after attacks.
abstract: The move comes after communication devices used by Hezbollah members exploded last month, killing dozens of people.
lead_paragraph: Emirates, Dubai’s flagship airline, has banned pagers and walkie-talkies from its flights following Israel’s recent attacks on such communication devices used by Hezbollah.

headline: The Casualties in North Carolina Include the Truth
abstract: An overflow of Trump-inspired misinformation on the disaster of Helene has impeded the recovery.
lead_paragraph: Over the past week, many Americans have turned their gazes toward North Carolina to behold gutting scenes of the damage and despair wrought by Hurricane Helene. They should keep looking, but for an additional reason: My state is a cautionary tale of what happens when no corner of our lives is cordoned off from partisan exploitation and we lose our tether to the truth.

headline: Missile Hits Near Ukrainian Air Base as Russia Expands Air Attacks
abstract: The strike is part of a broader campaign of air assaults by Moscow aimed at degrading Ukraine’s military infrastructure and wearing down its air defenses.
lead_paragraph: A Russian missile attack struck near a major Ukrainian military airfield on Monday morning, officials from Ukraine said, part of a broad campaign of assaults by Moscow aimed at degrading Ukraine’s military infrastructure and wearing down its air defenses.

headline: Is the Election Affecting Your Relationships?
abstract: If this political season is influencing your marriage, friendships or dating life, for better or worse, we want to hear about it.
lead_paragraph: The 2024 presidential election is less than a month away, and the strong opinions that come with it can shape our dynamics with friends, family, co-workers and romantic partners.

headline: Shopping for a Hard-to-Please Loved One? Ask T for Help.
abstract: Send us a question about a picky person on your holiday gift list and we’ll respond to the most intriguing ones with suggestions.
lead_paragraph: What do you get for a teenage nephew? A friend with impossibly expensive taste? A parent who insists, insincerely, they don’t want anything at all? We want to hear about the people stumping you ahead of the holiday gifting season — the more particular they are, the better.

headline: Dire Warnings for Storm-Weary Floridians as Hurricane Milton Approaches
abstract: Officials urged residents in the expected path of the hurricane, now a Category 5, to heed evacuation orders as the state mobilized resources to respond to the storm.
lead_paragraph: Weary Floridians steeled themselves on Monday for a second major hurricane in two weeks, wrestling with anxiety about whether to leave their homes and where the storm might go as Hurricane Milton took aim at much of the state’s battered Gulf Coast.

headline: Maggie Smith’s Face Has Something to Teach Us
abstract: Age is the ultimate luxury.
lead_paragraph: We see so few truly old faces in the media, especially old women’s faces.

headline: The Cases Against Sean Combs
abstract: A discussion of the accusations the music mogul faces, the court of public opinion and how the entertainment press covers morally complicated figures.
lead_paragraph: Last month Sean Combs — the hip-hop mogul known alternately as Puff Daddy, Puffy, Diddy and Love — was arrested on federal charges of racketeering conspiracy, sex trafficking, and transportation to engage in prostitution. He pleaded not guilty.

headline: Review: An Ambitious Work, as Flimsy as a House of Cards
abstract: Robert Lepage’s latest play, “Faith, Money, War and Love,” runs for five hours, and aims to depict Germany since the end of World War II.
lead_paragraph: The new theater season in Berlin has opened under a cloud of uncertainty, amid a proposal to drastically cut the city’s cultural budget that has raised alarm and drawn criticism. Against this gloomy backdrop, the Schaubühne playhouse’s decision to open its season with a five-hour-long world premiere by an internationally acclaimed director felt defiant.

headline: The Mideast War Threatens Harris in Michigan as Arab Voters Reject Her
abstract: A year after the Oct. 7 attacks, Kamala Harris faces deepening Democratic fractures in a crucial state. Interviews suggest that her support from Muslim and Arab Americans is drying up.
lead_paragraph: One year after the deadliest day for Jews since the Holocaust, the relentless and escalating violence in the Middle East is threatening the Democratic coalition in the United States. Arab American voters show signs of abandoning the Democratic ticket, while some Jews worry about their future in a party their families embraced for generations.

headline: Here’s How Fast Hurricane Milton Intensified
abstract: On Monday morning, the storm was a Category 1. It became a Category 5 by noon.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on Hurricane Milton.

headline: Tampa Residents Warned to Expect ‘Worst Hurricane in Their Lifetime’
abstract: The Tampa Bay area, long used to relative safety from big storms, faces what could be its first direct hit by a major hurricane in a century.
lead_paragraph: The Tampa Bay area has been brushed by many hurricanes in the last few decades, but more than a century has passed since the region, halfway down the length of Florida on the state’s Gulf Coast, has sustained a direct hit from a major hurricane.

headline: Georgia Supreme Court Restores State’s 6-Week Abortion Ban
abstract: The ban will resume while the court considers an appeal to a decision that had briefly allowed greater access to abortions in the state.
lead_paragraph: The Georgia Supreme Court reinstated on Monday a state law that prohibits abortions beyond six weeks of pregnancy while it considers an appeal to a lower-court decision that had briefly allowed greater access to the procedure.

headline: Chappell Roan Seeks the Line Between IRL and URL
abstract: The rising pop singer has been transparently navigating the demands of fame — onstage and online — as she’s grown from cult queer-pop hero to zeitgeist-shaping star.
lead_paragraph: For Chappell Roan, who has been toiling in the pop music trenches for several years now, the recent burst of acclaim she’s received has been overdue, affirming and more than a little disorienting. Perhaps the most energizing breakout star of this year, she has songs that center queer romance, a robust aesthetic gift and, most striking of all, an unusually moral sense of how a famous person should be treated.

headline: Why Israel’s Hostage Families Are Turning on Their Government
abstract: Family members of hostages held in Gaza are escalating their tactics to push for a cease-fire deal. They say the government is dragging out the war in Gaza for political reasons, and putting their family members’ lives at risk.
lead_paragraph: Family members of hostages held in Gaza are escalating their tactics to push for a cease-fire deal. They say the government is dragging out the war in Gaza for political reasons, and putting their family members’ lives at risk.

headline: In Mexico, a Mayor Is Brutally Killed Just Days After Taking Office
abstract: The gruesome killing represents yet another challenge for the country’s new president, who faces increasing pressure to show progress in the fight against violent cartels.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of a state capital in southwestern Mexico was killed on Sunday, less than a week after he took office. The public official’s death was the second in days in Chilpancingo, the capital of Guerrero state, and echoed some of the most gruesome days of the country’s drug war.

headline: One Year on, Israel’s Hostage Families Vow to Keep Fighting as War Escalates
abstract: Family members of hostages held in Gaza are escalating their tactics to push for a cease-fire deal.
lead_paragraph: One year after their relatives were kidnapped during the Hamas-led attacks of Oct. 7, 2023, the family members of hostages pushing for a cease-fire deal have become polarizing figures within Israel, as divisions over the goals of the war in Gaza have emerged.

headline: Back on the Bench, the Supreme Court Is Diligent and Dour
abstract: The justices considered a routine case on unemployment benefits in characteristic style, peppering the lawyers with questions and dropping hints about their views.
lead_paragraph: The last time the justices put on their robes and sat behind the Supreme Court’s majestic mahogany bench, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. announced that former President Donald J. Trump enjoyed substantial constitutional immunity from prosecution.

headline: As Major Hurricane Approaches Florida, FEMA Faces Severe Staffing Shortage
abstract: Fewer than 10 percent of the agency’s disaster workers are available to respond to Hurricane Milton and other calamities.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Emergency Management Agency is running out of staff to deal with the potential devastation of Hurricane Milton as it barrels toward Tampa with wind speeds that have reached 175 miles per hour.

headline: Pro-Israel and Pro-Palestinian Students at Columbia Hold Side-by-Side Protests
abstract: During tense but somber vigils on the university library steps, students and their supporters expressed outrage and sorrow.
lead_paragraph: Columbia University has been a focal point of anger and tensions over the Hamas-led attack on Israel on Oct. 7 last year and the war in Gaza that has followed. On Monday, the anniversary of the attack, it took on that role once again, as students and faculty held rallies, class walkouts and vigils to mourn the lives lost in both Israel and Gaza.

headline: Musk’s Super PAC Offers $47 to Those Who Help It Find Trump Voters
abstract: Musk’s group wants registered voters to sign a petition that it can use to target potential supporters of Donald Trump’s presidential campaign. It’s offering a cash reward for referrals.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk is dangling part of his fortune as part of a potentially expensive arrangement to identify likely voters for Donald Trump in seven battleground states.

headline: Hurricane Milton: Where People Are Evacuating in Florida
abstract: Updates on how the state is preparing for the storm’s arrival.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on Hurricane Milton.

headline: Kamala Harris Should Think Twice About Touting This Economy
abstract: The labor market isn’t as healthy as the September jobs report suggests. And Americans know it.
lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate is low, but it’s a tough time to find a job. I know, that sounds contradictory, but I can show that it’s true. And it’s not great for Vice President Kamala Harris, who is trying to chip away at many voters’ faulty perception that she and her boss haven’t been as good on the economy as former President Donald Trump was.

headline: Harris Often Sidesteps Her History-Making Potential. Walz Doesn’t.
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris rarely points out the fact that she would be the first female president or the first Black or Indian woman to hold the job. Her running mate embraces it.
lead_paragraph: Wedged inside a crowded cafe near downtown Atlanta last month, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota was powering through his usual talking points about protecting democracy and bolstering the economy, energizing a crowd of several dozen students from nearby historically Black colleges and universities.

headline: See the Ocean Heat Fueling Hurricane Milton, in One Chart
abstract: The waters of the Atlantic Ocean have been abnormally warm, providing copious amounts of energy that can intensify storms.
lead_paragraph: The waters of the Atlantic Ocean have been abnormally warm, providing copious amounts of energy that can intensify storms.

headline: Cissy Houston Dies at 91; Gospel Star Guided Daughter Whitney’s Rise
abstract: Hailing from a musical family, she won Grammys, sang backup to Elvis Presley and Aretha Franklin and helped shepherd Whitney Houston to superstardom.
lead_paragraph: Cissy Houston, a Grammy Award-winning soul and gospel star who helped shepherd her daughter Whitney Houston to superstardom, died on Monday at her home in Newark. She was 91.

headline: Elon Musk’s Giant Leap
abstract: When one of the richest men in the world made a surprise cameo at a Trump rally in Butler, Pa., he did so with the gusto of a meme exploding.
lead_paragraph: Oh, to feel this free.

headline: 4 Takeaways From ‘The Menendez Brothers,’ on Netflix
abstract: The documentary, based on extensive new interviews with Lyle and Erik Menendez, adds fresh nuance and details about their parents’ murders and the aftermath.
lead_paragraph: The true crime drama “Monsters: The Lyle and Erik Menendez Story” has been one of the most viewed series on Netflix since its Sept. 19 debut, driving enormous interest once again in the Menendez brothers, who in 1989 murdered their parents with shotguns inside the family’s Beverly Hills mansion.

headline: What Are Your Thoughts About a Year of War in Israel, Gaza and the Middle East?
abstract: A year into this devastating war, what are you feeling and thinking? How have your feelings changed over the course of the year?
lead_paragraph: One year ago, on Oct. 7, 2023, Hamas, the Palestinian militant group that controls the Gaza Strip, mounted a highly coordinated invasion of Israel. Terrorists attacked towns and killed people in their homes and in the streets. More than 1,100 Israelis died, including more than 100 young revelers who were dancing at an outdoor rave, and over 240 Israelis were taken hostage by Hamas. It was the deadliest attack on Israel since its founding.

headline: Viktor Bout Is Trying to Sell Weapons to the Houthis, Western Officials Say
abstract: The Russian arms dealer, who was freed in a prisoner exchange with the United States, is negotiating with the militant group in Yemen.
lead_paragraph: The Russian arms dealer Viktor A. Bout is trying to broker a deal with Houthi militants in Yemen, according to Western officials.

headline: Israel challenges U.N. court’s jurisdiction to issue a warrant for Netanyahu’s arrest.
abstract: Israel has rejected the International Criminal Court’s chief prosecutor’s request for arrest warrants for its prime minister and defense minister over their conduct of the war in Gaza, in filings to the court made late last month that were reclassified as public on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Israel has rejected the International Criminal Court’s chief prosecutor’s request for arrest warrants for its prime minister and defense minister over their conduct of the war in Gaza, in filings to the court made late last month that were reclassified as public on Friday.

headline: Behind the War of Words Between Macron and Netanyahu
abstract: The French leader said countries should stop supplying weapons to Israel, arguing that providing arms while demanding a cease-fire is inconsistent. That drew the Israeli leader’s fury.
lead_paragraph: When President Emmanuel Macron of France said over the weekend that countries should stop supplying Israel with weapons if they want a cease-fire, the reaction from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was swift and scathing.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Israelis and Palestinians Mourn a Year of Loss
abstract: Plus, Chappell Roan navigates the demands of fame.
lead_paragraph: Anger and pain dominated the vigils and protests held around the world yesterday to commemorate the first anniversary of the Oct. 7 attacks. Israelis held a solemn memorial in the Re’im forest, the site of a music festival where hundreds were killed. Families of the hostages gathered at a large public plaza in Tel Aviv known as Hostage Square.

headline: All the Good Economic News Vindicates Bidenomics
abstract: But not quite in the way you may think.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to overstate just how good recent economic numbers have been.

headline: How The New York Times Uses A.I. for Journalism
abstract: We don’t use A.I. to write articles, and journalists are ultimately responsible for everything that we publish.
lead_paragraph: As artificial intelligence gets more sophisticated, we’re increasingly finding uses for the technology in our journalism. We also have guidance and training in place to guard against the risks of using A.I., such as inaccuracy. Here are some ways we use A.I. today:

headline: Google Must Open Android to Other App Stores and Billing Options, Judge Rules
abstract: The internet giant was ordered by a federal judge to make a series of changes to address its anticompetitive conduct.
lead_paragraph: In December, a federal jury in San Francisco found that Google had violated antitrust law by imposing high fees and stringent rules on Epic Games and other app developers in Google’s app store.

headline: As a Massacre Unfolded, a Frantic Call: ‘Send for Help’
abstract: When a gang assaulted a town in central Haiti last week, one woman called a local community leader begging for assistance. The massacre left at least 78 civilians dead.
lead_paragraph: Bertide Horace, a community leader in central Haiti, was awoken in the wee hours last Thursday by a phone call from a woman who sounded desperate.

headline: Year After Oct. 7 Attack, Israel Faces 4-Front War
abstract: Gaza, Lebanon, Iran and Yemen: Israeli forces exchanged fire with militants backed by Tehran on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military kept up its strikes on two fronts Monday, with an intense barrage on southern Lebanon and a retaliatory attack targeting Hamas in southern Gaza, a sign of how significantly the fighting has spread in the year since Hamas’s cross-border assault.

headline: On Oct. 7 Anniversary, Vigils and Hope for ‘an End to This Horrible War’
abstract: Israelis gathered on Monday to mourn those killed or abducted on the deadliest day in the country’s history.
lead_paragraph: It was a day of vigils.

headline: One Year After Oct. 7, Peace Seems More Elusive Than Ever
abstract: Also, Hurricane Milton heads toward Florida as a Category 5 storm. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: On this day last year, Hamas militants stormed into Israel, killed more than 1,200 Israelis, committed atrocities and took more than 250 people back to Gaza as hostages. We are still living in the aftermath.

headline: Harris Honors Oct. 7 Dead as Victims of ‘Pure Evil’ and Vows to Defend Israel
abstract: Condemning the Hamas-led attacks a year ago and calling again for the release of hostages in Gaza, Vice President Kamala Harris also spoke of “the immense suffering of innocent Palestinians.”
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris on Monday commemorated the anniversary of the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack on Israel by planting a pomegranate tree, which she called “a symbol of hope and righteousness” in Judaism, at her official residence in Washington.

headline: Supreme Court Turns Down Biden’s Appeal in Texas Abortion Case
abstract: The administration said a state abortion law conflicted with a federal law requiring emergency care. The court similarly sidestepped a case from Idaho in June.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Monday turned down an appeal from the Biden administration urging the justices to allow some emergency abortions in Texas.

headline: ‘The Menendez Brothers’ Review: Reframing a Case
abstract: To the extent this documentary about Lyle and Erik Menendez has appeal, it is of the tabloid variety.
lead_paragraph: “The Menendez Brothers” doesn’t so much relitigate the case of Lyle and Erik Menendez as reframe it. In 1996, the brothers were convicted of murdering their parents, Jose and Kitty Menendez, in Beverly Hills in 1989. That was their second trial. The first had ended in 1994 with two deadlocked juries, each assigned to deliberate over one sibling.

headline: Washington Worries the Israelis Will Bomb Iran’s Nuclear Sites. But Can They?
abstract: For 22 years, Israeli forces have planned for this moment. But it seems unlikely that they will strike Iran’s nuclear facilities in the next round of retaliation, or that they would be successful without American help.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, dozens of Israeli fighter jets roared over the Mediterranean Sea, simulating a strike on Iran’s nuclear facilities, a drill the Israeli defense forces openly advertised as an exercise in “long-range flight, aerial refueling and striking distant targets.”

headline: Inside a Trump Ad Attacking Harris on Energy and the Environment
abstract: An ad in Michigan and Pennsylvania revives the vice president’s past positions on climate change and the environment.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign has been running this 30-second ad on television stations in Michigan and central and western Pennsylvania at a cost of $833,401 since Oct. 2, according to AdImpact.

headline: A Year Later, Biden Faces the Limits of U.S. Influence in the Mideast
abstract: In the immediate aftermath of the Hamas-led attacks on Oct. 7, the president stepped in to support Israel, counsel moderation and seek a lasting peace.
lead_paragraph: Ten days after Hamas terrorists killed more than 1,200 people and took 250 hostages last year, President Biden flew to Tel Aviv and vowed to protect Israel, minimize civilian deaths, deliver humanitarian aid and bring lasting peace to the region.

headline: Trump’s Ugly Closing Argument
abstract: He delivers a mix of disinformation, false claims about cheating in elections and personal attacks.
lead_paragraph: Never mind that he was in Wisconsin. Never mind that it was perfectly sunny, albeit windy. Former President Donald Trump was going to talk about hurricanes.

headline: The Price of a Mega Millions Ticket Will More Than Double to $5
abstract: Mega Millions officials said players’ odds would be increased and jackpot sizes would be bigger after the price increase next April.
lead_paragraph: Mega Millions players will have to pay $5 for a ticket — more than twice the current cost — beginning next April as part of an overhaul of the 22-year-old lottery game, Mega Millions announced on Monday.

headline: Gaza in Ruins After a Year of War
abstract: Much of Gaza has been destroyed by Israel’s relentless military campaign.
lead_paragraph: Much of Gaza has been destroyed by Israel’s relentless military campaign.

headline: While Disney Remains Open, Other Florida Parks Announce Closures
abstract: All of the major theme parks said they were closely monitoring Hurricane Milton and would be updating their closure plans as needed.
lead_paragraph: As Milton barreled toward Florida’s west coast as a Category 5 hurricane, some of the biggest theme parks in the Orlando area, including Walt Disney World Resort and Universal Orlando Resort, remained open as of Monday.

headline: Russia, China and Iran Intend to Stoke False Election Claims, Officials Warn
abstract: Intelligence officials said that foreign adversaries were planning to take advantage of another close U.S. election to undermine trust in the country’s democratic process.
lead_paragraph: Foreign efforts to undermine American democracy will continue after Election Day, U.S. intelligence officials said on Monday, with covert influence campaigns focused on questioning the validity of election results after polls close.

headline: Trump Says He’s Visited Gaza, but No Record of Such a Trip Exists
abstract: An aide, speaking on the condition of anonymity, pointed to the former president’s trip to Israel. But Gaza is not in Israel.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump suggested in a radio interview on Monday that he had visited war-torn Gaza in the past, a place there is no record of him visiting. When asked to clarify, a campaign aide said that Gaza is “in Israel” and that Mr. Trump has visited Israel.

headline: CBS Rebukes Anchor Over Tense Interview With Ta-Nehisi Coates
abstract: Executives said the interview, conducted by the morning show anchor Tony Dokoupil, had fallen short of network editorial standards.
lead_paragraph: CBS News on Monday rebuked one of its star morning anchors, Tony Dokoupil, over an interview that he conducted last week with the author Ta-Nehisi Coates, in which Mr. Dokoupil challenged Mr. Coates’s views about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

headline: Milton Is Already a Storm for the Record Books. Here’s What May Come Next.
abstract: The storm rapidly intensified on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on Hurricane Milton.

headline: Protest That the University of Maryland Sought to Prevent Goes On
abstract: The school, citing safety, had said no to an event planned on the anniversary of the Oct. 7 attack by a chapter of Students for Justice in Palestine, but a judge’s ruling last week allowed it to go ahead.
lead_paragraph: A pro-Palestinian student group gathered to mourn the lives lost in the war in Gaza on Monday, following a federal judge’s ruling last week against the University of Maryland’s plan to block it.

headline: In New York on Oct. 7, Honoring the Dead and Calling for an End to War
abstract: In the city, which is home both to the largest Jewish population outside Israel and to thousands of Palestinians, some gathered in protest and others in solemn remembrance.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people gathered across Manhattan on Monday to commemorate the first anniversary of Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack on Israel, with groups on both sides of the conflict expressing their collective grief and outrage over the past year of war.

headline: That Gun Harris Told Oprah Winfrey About? It’s a Glock.
abstract: “And I’ve had it for quite some time,” Vice President Kamala Harris said on “60 Minutes.”
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris has a Glock. And she has taken it to the shooting range.

headline: Give Some Lip
abstract: Justin Werfel edges toward the endgame.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: China’s Policy Reversal Sparks ‘Mind Boggling’ Stock Rally
abstract: The government has fired up investors by encouraging banks to lend more to buyers of stocks and real estate, but officials refrained on Tuesday from promising more stimulus.
lead_paragraph: Just a few weeks ago, many investors in China’s stock markets were ready to give up and eager to sell. Then late last month, traders rushed in to make bullish bets after the government’s leaders announced a series of steps to stimulate China’s faltering economy.

headline: 7 Takeaways From Harris’s Interview on ‘60 Minutes’
abstract: Pressed repeatedly, Kamala Harris stayed focused on the points she wanted to make. She also spoke about owning a Glock, and Tim Walz revealed she had told him to be a “little more careful” speaking.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris sat for an interview with “60 Minutes” that was broadcast on Monday night and, in a departure from some of her recent appearances on cable news and podcasts, she was repeatedly pressed on questions she did not initially answer.

headline: Trump Sees Antisemitism in Only One Direction: On the Left
abstract: At an event marking the anniversary of Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack on Israel, Donald Trump claimed that antisemitism existed within the Democratic Party but not the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump on Monday blamed Democrats for antisemitism at an event commemorating the Oct. 7 Hamas terrorist attack on Israel, then claimed there was no antisemitism in the ranks of the Republican Party, even as his own endorsed candidate for governor in North Carolina is at the center of a scandal involving antisemitic remarks.

headline: Quote of the Day: Gazans Are Trapped in a Prison That Was Decades in the Making
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, October 8, 2024
lead_paragraph: “The world is not a kind and generous place.”

headline: Corrections: Oct. 8, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Oct. 8, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about the ongoing tensions in the Middle East misstated the name of the Hamas political leader who was assassinated in Tehran. He was Ismail Haniyeh, not Islam.

headline: So, Are You Pregnant Yet? China’s In-Your-Face Push for More Babies.
abstract: The government is again trying to insert itself into women’s childbearing decisions, knocking on doors and making calls with questions some find downright invasive.
lead_paragraph: The first time a government worker encouraged Yumi Yang to have a baby, she thought little of it. She and her husband were registering their marriage at a local office in northeastern China, and the worker gave them free prenatal vitamins, which she chalked up to the government trying to be helpful.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Israelis and Palestinians commemorate a year of loss.
lead_paragraph: Anger and pain dominated vigils and protests held around the world yesterday to commemorate the anniversary of the Oct. 7 attack on Israel led by Hamas, which began a war that still rages.

headline: Lisa Marie Presley Makes Her Voice Heard, Once and For All
abstract: In a new memoir, “From Here to the Great Unknown,” Elvis Presley’s daughter and granddaughter take turns exploring a messy legacy.
lead_paragraph: “What is the point of an autobiography?”

headline: Trump Has an Edge With These 13 Undecided Voters. One Issue Is Tripping Him Up.
abstract: The participants discuss the vice-presidential debate and if and how it influenced their vote for president.
lead_paragraph: The participants discuss the vice-presidential debate and if and how it influenced their vote for president.

headline: Word of the Day: debacle
abstract: This word has appeared in 259 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word debacle has appeared in 259 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 29 in “Separated From Co-Workers, Man Endures Freezing Night in the Rockies Before Rescue” by Hank Sanders:

headline: Seth Meyers: Trump Rallies Are Like an Escape Room
abstract: “Generally speaking, if you’re at an event and the host of that event keeps insisting no one is going to leave, it is time to start worrying,” Meyers said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: How to See the ‘Once-in-a-Lifetime’ Comet Flaring in Our Night Skies
abstract: Comet Tsuchinshan-ATLAS is nearing Earth and getting brighter.
lead_paragraph: Look up, stargazers: A comet discovered last year is getting brighter as it makes its closest pass by Earth later this week, and this could be humanity’s last chance to see the comet before it disappears into the cosmic depths.

headline: An Old Clash Heats Up Over Oppenheimer’s Red Ties
abstract: As a group of historians and a top biographer square off, proponents of a middle path see a tangled life in which the superstar of science was, and was not, a true Communist at the same time.
lead_paragraph: J. Robert Oppenheimer teemed with contradictions. He was shy and bold, naïve and brilliant, a loyal husband who cheated, a gentle man whose bomb could kill millions.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Why a Measure to Protect Abortion Rights in New York May Be in Trouble
abstract: The statewide ballot measure, known as the Equal Rights Amendment, has become a target for Republican opponents who have cast it as an attack on family values.
lead_paragraph: New York, with its liberal bent and habit of electing Democrats, seems the sort of place where a statewide ballot measure to protect reproductive rights would be a shoo-in.

headline: Fall Video Games
abstract: What new games are you playing?
lead_paragraph: In September, The Times published a preview of the video games coming this fall. Here’s how it begins:

headline: An Artists’ Squat Fought New York City for Decades. Did It Just Win?
abstract: ABC No Rio was a vital, dangerous and confrontational art space on the Lower East Side. Decades after it opened, it has made a deal with the city for a new building of its own.
lead_paragraph: The New York art world is full of origin stories, and some of them are true. One begins on a winter night on the Lower East Side, with a bolt cutter in a guitar case, a snipped lock and a guerrilla art show in an abandoned building.

headline: Still Recovering From Helene, Florida Braces for Milton
abstract: Florida residents are preparing for Hurricane Milton while still cleaning up debris from Helene that some worry could get whipped up in strong winds.
lead_paragraph: Florida residents are preparing for Hurricane Milton while still cleaning up debris from Helene that some worry could get whipped up in strong winds.

headline: Cross-Tabs: October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of the Likely Electorate in Florida
abstract: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 622 likely voters in Florida from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 622 likely voters in Florida from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.

headline: Cross-Tabs: October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of the National Likely Electorate
abstract: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 3,385 likely voters from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 3,385 likely voters from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.

headline: Toplines: October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters in Florida
abstract: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 622 registered voters in Florida from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 622 registered voters in Florida from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.

headline: Toplines: October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters in  Texas
abstract: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 617 likely voters in Texas from Sept. 29 to Oct. 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 617 likely voters in Texas from Sept. 29 to Oct. 4, 2024.

headline: Cross-Tabs: October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of the Likely Electorate in Texas
abstract: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 617 likely voters in Texas from Sept. 29 to Oct. 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 617 likely voters in Texas from Sept. 29 to Oct. 4, 2024.

headline: Toplines: October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters Nationwide
abstract: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 3,385 registered voters from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 3,385 registered voters from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.

headline: How Book Bans Happen Under the Radar
abstract: Thousands of books have been publicly challenged and removed from libraries in the past couple of years. Elizabeth Harris, who covers books and the publishing industry for The New York Times, explains how books are being pulled from libraries in a quiet process called weeding. Weeding normally allows librarians to keep collections current, but some lawsuits argue that it has been used instead to remove books for content about racism, sexuality and gender.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of books have been publicly challenged and removed from libraries in the past couple of years. Elizabeth Harris, who covers books and the publishing industry for The New York Times, explains how books are being pulled from libraries in a quiet process called weeding. Weeding normally allows librarians to keep collections current, but some lawsuits argue that it has been used instead to remove books for content about racism, sexuality and gender.

headline: Is It Better to Eat Before a Workout or After?
abstract: How you time your meals can influence your performance and recovery, experts say. Here’s what the research suggests.
lead_paragraph: Q: I can never figure out how best to time my meals with my workouts. Should I be eating before I exercise or after?

headline: Reading With My Father
abstract: A conversation through books.
lead_paragraph: The last time I visited my parents, I borrowed a novel from the shelves in my old bedroom. Once, the books there belonged to me, but in the decades since I lived in this apartment, my father has commandeered the space.

headline: We Can Do Better Than ‘Positive Masculinity’
abstract: It doesn’t challenge stereotypes; it reinforces them.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps it’s a predictable irony that in an election cycle that could realistically deliver the first female president, so much of the commentary has been about men. Or rather, not about men exactly, but about “masculinity.” Because somehow, in 2024, we still find ourselves unable to talk about men and boys without using masculinity as the basic frame of reference.

headline: Her Face Was Unrecognizable After an Explosion. A Placenta Restored It.
abstract: The same qualities that make placentas so valuable during pregnancy make them profoundly useful for healing burns and wounds, too. So why do we throw so many away?
lead_paragraph: Marcella Townsend remembers looking around the kitchen in shock. In the silence just after the explosion, before the pain kicked in, she found herself almost in awe of the crushed stove and the caved-in cabinets.

headline: A Patchwork Satire of Ivory Coast, Pre- and Post-Independence
abstract: “Comrade Papa” is told from the perspective of two European arrivals to the West African country, nearly a century apart.
lead_paragraph: “Comrade Papa” — the second novel by the pseudonymous Ivorian author and newspaper editor GauZ’, published in France in 2018 and newly translated by Frank Wynne — alternates in setting between 19th-century colonial Ivory Coast and 1970s Amsterdam. The two strands don’t converge until the end, after a patchwork of legends, folk tales, revolutionary diatribes and expeditionary reports that come together to make a whimsical, satirical whirlwind of a historical narrative.

headline: As Hurricanes Strike, Insurance Costs Soar for Commercial Real Estate
abstract: Struggling landlords and developers are seeking leeway on coverage from their lenders — mostly in vain.
lead_paragraph: Postpandemic vacancies and surging debt payments have eaten away at commercial real estate for more than two years. Even as those threats start to fade, owners of strip malls, apartment buildings and office towers face a problem that could last much longer: soaring insurance costs.

headline: What Is the Sound of a Teardrop? You Can Hear It at MoMA.
abstract: Otobong Nkanga’s installations can seem simultaneously futuristic and primordial, apocalyptic and utopian. Her latest opens at the museum this week.
lead_paragraph: Gazing up at the 60-foot wall in the central atrium of the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Nigerian artist Otobong Nkanga felt both excited and terrified.

headline: The Living Room Should Be for Living
abstract: Designers show us how to turn what used to be the most formal area of a home into an inviting, multipurpose space.
lead_paragraph: The living room used to be considered a formal entertaining space — a room filled with fine furniture that was largely off-limits until the company arrived. But we’ve come a long way.

headline: 5 Irresistible Fall Train Trips
abstract: Why navigate crowded roads to get your fill of autumn colors when you can ride the rails and enjoy gorgeous scenery you can’t see from the highway?
lead_paragraph: The air is crisp, and the leaves are bursting into vivid hues. Maybe you’re planning a road trip to admire the beauty. But getting your fill of fall foliage from behind the wheel can turn into an awkward juggle between admiring the vistas and navigating traffic. If you hop on a train, you can give the scenery your full attention and view some sights you just can’t see from the highway. Here are five great American train rides that offer day trips for peak-autumn panoramas.

headline: Removing Books From Libraries Often Takes Debate. But There’s a Quieter Way.
abstract: Weeding, or culling old, damaged or outdated books, is standard practice in libraries. But in some cases it is being used to remove books because of the viewpoint they express.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of books have been removed from schools and libraries over the past several years, often accompanied by stormy public meetings and acrimonious debate. But there is a quieter way books have been pulled from libraries — a process called weeding.

headline: Statement Dressing Is Back
abstract: After seasons of pared-down styles, designers are once again ready to go bold with wild prints and big-night-out gowns.

headline: Black Men Are Waiting for a Democratic Party That Delivers for Them
abstract: Democrats have spent too much time drawing symbolic distinctions with Republicans without illuminating substantive differences.
lead_paragraph: Black men today face a unique reality that warrants consideration: Under nearly any relevant index for measuring the quality of American life — how far we get in school, our finances when compared with those of our white counterparts, and how long we will live — Black men consistently rank last or near last. There is not a Black man alive in this country right now who has ever seen Black male unemployment equal to or less than that of his white counterparts.

headline: Shaker Cradles for Adults? They Rocked Frances McDormand’s Mind
abstract: A soulful exhibition curated by the actress and her friend Suzanne Bocanegra, an artist, explores caregiving and community.
lead_paragraph: On a Thursday afternoon in late summer Frances McDormand, the actor, and Suzanne Bocanegra, a conceptual artist, were testing out a Shaker cradle for adults. The exhibit of these little-known furniture items that they put together for the Shaker Museum’s pop-up gallery was days from opening in the Kinderhook Knitting Mill — a converted historic space in Columbia County, N.Y.

headline: What Does Utopia Look Like for Black Americans?
abstract: Aaron Robertson’s grandparents had a farm in Promise Land, Tenn. In a new book, he explores the history and meaning of such utopian communities for African Americans.
lead_paragraph: Looked at from a certain surface-level perspective, the whole notion of Black utopianism can seem to entail a paradox. As the literary scholar Charles Scruggs put it more than 30 years ago in “Sweet Home: Invisible Cities in the Afro-American Novel,” “Given what we know about the position of Black Americans within a racist society, the idea of a Black utopian city may seem absurd on the face of it.”

headline: The Quick-Witted, Self-Lacerating James Blunt Would Like a Word
abstract: Twenty years after his hit “You’re Beautiful” turned him into an overnight star, the British singer and songwriter takes his music — and his haters — to task.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago this month, James Blunt was an unknown singer releasing his first album. The song that rapidly elevated him out of obscurity was “You’re Beautiful,” a lovelorn rhapsody about falling for a stranger on the subway while high on drugs, which hit No. 1 in 15 countries, including the United States. The smash helped turn his 2004 LP “Back to Bedlam” into a triple-platinum success.

headline: Biden’s Moral Failure in Israel
abstract: The American president promised equality. He didn’t deliver.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden’s presidency has a distinct origin story. As he tells it, he was done with politics, happily retired from public life. That changed after Donald Trump’s equivocal response to the 2017 white supremacist march in Charlottesville, Va. It was then that Mr. Biden realized that Mr. Trump and his allies threatened what he called the “soul of this nation”: its commitment to equality. So he re-entered the fray.

headline: For Many Israelis, Oct. 7 Never Ended
abstract: The Hamas-led attacks that day shattered Israelis’ faith in the state, and the year of war that followed has deepened society’s divisions. Yet many find hope in the people’s resilience.
lead_paragraph: Like other Israeli civilians, Geffen Yamin and Eyar Liv Halabi, project managers at Tel Aviv startups, rushed to fill gaps in the government’s initially paralyzed response when thousands of gunmen from Gaza poured over the border on Oct. 7.

headline: Grappling With the Talmud in the Midst of Crisis
abstract: What the words of ancient rabbis could and couldn’t teach me.
lead_paragraph: In late 2019, I came upon an article about Daf Yomi — the practice of reading a page of the Talmud every day over the course of seven and a half years — and decided to sign up for a daily email promising to shepherd me through the text, that famously dense compilation of arguments among ancient rabbis. My wife was diagnosed with cancer a year earlier, and after grappling with big questions about mortality and fate, I was looking for a bit of spiritual direction.

headline: Exposing the Violence of Empire in the Novels It Left Behind
abstract: For her new book, “Salvage,” the Trinidadian-born writer Dionne Brand rereads classic English novels, teasing out evidence of the ravages of colonialism.
lead_paragraph: Dionne Brand is a poet, novelist and essayist who was born in Trinidad and moved to Canada in 1970. She seeks, across all her work, to interrupt history. Or, as she puts it in her new book, “Salvage: Readings From the Wreck,” describing how the fiction writer John Keene blows “life into the collapsed world of coloniality,” she exposes histories that have not previously come to the surface, finding traces that were of little importance to the white writers of England’s colonial past.

headline: Why France’s Most Controversial Novelist Is Also Its Most Celebrated
abstract: Reviled as much as he is lauded, Michel Houellebecq holds up a mirror to a world we would rather not see.
lead_paragraph: Michel Houellebecq — arguably the most important French writer of the past quarter-century — was perched on the seat of his chair like a bird. We were sitting in his dim Paris apartment in August, a spectacularly beautiful day visible through his curtained windows, to discuss his new novel, “Annihilation,” which appears this week and returns to the themes of male loneliness and civilizational decline that have made his reputation. During our time together, Houellebecq, who is 68, would slump deeper and deeper in his chair, to the point where it seemed he would need help rising, only to pop back up, with unexpected agility, to balance once again on the balls of his feet. I had been trying to ask him about his life, but he was deftly deflecting personal questions — he had been answering them for decades and seemed done with that dance — until I asked him to tell me a little bit about his early life as a reader.

headline: The 10 Most Common Questions Teenagers Asked About the Election
abstract: Headway has received more than 500 questions from teens about this year’s presidential election. Here are their most frequently asked questions — and our answers.
lead_paragraph: Throughout 2024, Headway and Chalkbeat, a nonprofit news organization focused on education in America, have been in conversation with teenagers about the upcoming presidential election.

headline: What We’ve Heard From Teens About the 2024 Election
abstract: Since September, the Headway team has been asking teenagers across the country for their thoughts on the election. Here’s what we’ve heard so far.
lead_paragraph: Early in 2024, the Headway team, along with Chalkbeat, a nonprofit news organization focused on education in America, started talking with high school students about the upcoming presidential election. We wanted to understand how youth were processing an election in which age had become an issue, especially four years after young people turned out at among the highest levels since 18-year-olds received the right to vote.

headline: The $550 Million Question: How Does David Geffen Hall Sound?
abstract: The New York Philharmonic’s home underwent an extensive renovation that was finished two years ago. But that was only the beginning of the quest for the perfect sound.
lead_paragraph: When the New York Philharmonic English horn player and oboist Ryan Roberts performs at the renovated David Geffen Hall these days, he feels naked and exposed, as if he were appearing on a high-definition television screen.

headline: Waiting Hours for 3 Minutes in the Criterion Closet (Well, Van)
abstract: A mobile version of movie fans’ favorite stockroom drew hundreds of New York Film Festival visitors eager to experience what celebrities do in popular videos.
lead_paragraph: The hottest event at this year’s New York Film Festival isn’t a film at all. It’s a van.

headline: A Taste for Vibes, and Sometimes Wine
abstract: Some Gen Z-ers and young millennials say the culture and aesthetics of wine meld with their lifestyles, whether they’re drinking or not.
lead_paragraph: When Erika Veurink was planning her wedding, she knew she wanted the reception to be at Sauced, a wine bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, known for blasting hip-hop and its disco-ball-adorned dance room.

headline: Death Row Inmate in Oklahoma Has an Unusual Ally: The State’s Attorney General
abstract: Both sides told the Supreme Court that long-suppressed evidence about the state’s star witness undermined the case against the inmate, Richard Glossip.
lead_paragraph: There is no dispute about this basic fact in the death penalty case the Supreme Court will hear on Wednesday: On a chilly morning in January 1997, in Room 102 of the Best Budget Motel in Oklahoma City, a handyman named Justin Sneed beat the motel’s owner to death with a baseball bat.

headline: Is New York Ready to Forgive Andrew Cuomo?
abstract: History has presented Mr. Cuomo with an opportunity. But it’s one that New York voters may not swallow.
lead_paragraph: Throughout his long political career, Eric Adams seemed to float effortlessly above a constant drumbeat of reports questioning his ethical conduct. Just before he won the New York City Democratic mayoral primary in 2021, an aide predicted the city would come to appreciate him as a “lovable rogue.”

headline: I Was a Teacher in Gaza. This Is What Haunts Me Now.
abstract: Since Oct. 7, 80 percent of the schools in Gaza have been damaged or destroyed. Mosab Abu Toha reflects on what has been lost.
lead_paragraph: The last time Mosab Abu Toha, a poet and teacher, was in a classroom in Gaza, it was to shelter with his students and their families, all seeking refuge from Israeli airstrikes. Since then, he and his family have fled Gaza, and they temporarily reside in the United States. In this audio essay, he shares what it means when classrooms cease being places of learning and become a family’s only hope for survival.

headline: How Biden’s Middle East Policy Fell Apart
abstract: The journalist Franklin Foer traced the Biden administration’s diplomacy in the Middle East since Oct. 7 and emerged with an “anatomy of a failure.”
lead_paragraph: This episode is being published almost a year to the day after Hamas attacked Israel. I have tried writing different versions of this introduction, tried to write something up to that moment — and failed. Nothing I write is up to memorializing the horror of that day or of what has followed.

headline: The Real Housewives Weren’t There, but Their Fans Were
abstract: At a Bravo-themed brunch, we met some devoted watchers of “Vanderpump Rules,” “Below Deck” and other staples of reality television.

headline: New York Has 7 Million Trees. Here Are 120 Great Ones.
abstract: The Parks Department is releasing a list of “great trees” for the first time since 1985. The commissioner loves a willow in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out about a new list of “great trees” in New York City. We’ll also get details on the departures of a top official and two lower-level aides at City Hall.

headline: Peter Hujar’s Only Book Is Back in Print. His Friends Say It’s About Time.
abstract: John Waters, Fran Lebowitz and other friends of the photographer, who died in 1987, remember an artist impatient for the recognition he’s only recently begun to receive.
lead_paragraph: The subjects of Peter Hujar’s arresting black-and-white photographs from the 1950s through the 1980s were the citizens of his New York: the famous and niche-famous, beloved friends and sometime boyfriends, smoldering artists and playful drag performers, leather-clad lovers and distinguished pets. Mr. Hujar published only one monograph in his lifetime, “Portraits in Life and Death,” which features figures like John Waters, Fran Lebowitz and Susan Sontag alongside dozens of nameless remains from the Palermo catacombs.

headline: An Artist Who Loved the City Finds ‘Paradise’ Upstate
abstract: Take a tour of the place where Jules Feiffer said he found his “fire.”
lead_paragraph: Take a tour of the place where Jules Feiffer said he found his “fire.”

headline: Biden Requires Lead Drinking-Water Pipes to be Replaced Nationwide
abstract: The “historic” rule aims to eliminate a major source of lead poisoning and comes a decade after a drinking-water crisis in Flint, Mich.
lead_paragraph: Marking the 10th anniversary of the water crisis in Flint, Mich., President Biden on Tuesday gave water utilities 10 more years to replace virtually every lead pipe in the country, imposing the strictest limits to date on a neurotoxin that is particularly dangerous to infants and children.

headline: Ali Wong Dishes on Life After Divorce. Her Real Subject Is Fame.
abstract: Her gossipy portrait of singlehood as a celebrity is a sunny contrast to the darker view of her Netflix stablemate Hannah Gadsby.
lead_paragraph: The last time we saw Ali Wong doing standup, she was delivering an earnest tribute to her husband and their relationship. The final line of “Don Wong,” her 2022 special, went: “And that, single people, is what a healthy marriage looks like.”

headline: Poll Finds Harris Rising as She Challenges Trump on Change
abstract: A national Times/Siena poll found Kamala Harris with a slim lead over Donald J. Trump. Voters were more likely to see her, not Mr. Trump, as a break from the status quo.
lead_paragraph: Follow along with the latest updates on Trump, Harris and the 2024 election.

headline: Protein, Pickles and Purists: There Are Many Ways to Drink Diet Coke
abstract: Opinions abound on how to customize the popular soda. Purists, meanwhile, will see you at McDonald’s.
lead_paragraph: The latest battle in the soda wars isn’t Coke versus Pepsi. It’s Diet Coke versus Diet Coke, and the fandom is bubbling over on social media.

headline: This Year’s October Surprise May Be That There Isn’t One
abstract: The polls are very, very stable in spite of events.
lead_paragraph: The first time a movie ever really surprised me was the 1997 film “Contact.” In it, humans are sent plans for a machine that, once built and used, appears to transport Dr. Ellie Arroway — played marvelously by Jodie Foster — through a wormhole to an alien planet. She experiences what feels like nearly a day on this other planet, but on Earth it appears she never went anywhere at all. She is grilled by members of Congress over claims that her journey was an elaborate hoax.

headline: A Florida Poll That Should Change the Way You Look at the Election
abstract: A big Trump lead in the state paradoxically adds to evidence of a smaller Electoral College edge for him. And a choice by pollsters may be causing them to miss state shifts.
lead_paragraph: We have three new New York Times/Siena College polls this morning. Only two look “normal.”

headline: What Trump and Vance Want From Hurricane Helene
abstract: Trump has successfully trained millions of Americans to think of the truth as an obstacle to winning power.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump and JD Vance are lying about the federal government’s response to Hurricane Helene.

headline: Majority of Supreme Court Appears Receptive to Biden Administration Limits on ‘Ghost Guns’
abstract: At issue was how the Biden administration had interpreted a federal statute to regulate kits that could be assembled into homemade guns, skirting background checks.
lead_paragraph: A majority of the Supreme Court appeared sympathetic on Tuesday to the Biden administration’s restrictions on kits to make homemade guns that skirted background checks.

headline: The Role of New York’s Lauded Looted Art Unit Is Challenged in Court
abstract: The fight is over an Egon Schiele drawing held by the Art Institute of Chicago that the Manhattan district attorney’s office seized as Nazi loot. But it has wider implications.
lead_paragraph: In what has been a celebrated effort to right old wrongs, the Manhattan district attorney’s art trafficking unit has returned more than 4,600 artifacts and artworks to countries and heirs after finding they had been looted.

headline: A Cartel Double-Cross Turns a Mexican State Into a War Zone
abstract: An explosive deception has ripped apart one of Mexico’s most powerful criminal groups, the Sinaloa cartel, and ignited a war between the rival factions.
lead_paragraph: Bodies dumped on the side of the road. Gun battles in upscale neighborhoods. Tractor-trailers set aflame on the highway. People plucked from their cars by armed men in broad daylight.

headline: Japan Says It Manipulated a Photo of (Slightly) Unkempt Cabinet Ministers
abstract: The episode provided political fodder for Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba’s critics and highlighted the country’s generally high standard of dress.
lead_paragraph: The slightly disheveled appearance of the Japanese cabinet ministers who posed for an official photo last week — wrinkled trousers here, a triangle of exposed dress shirt there — was the sort of thing that some observers might overlook.

headline: Nobel Physics Prize Awarded for Pioneering A.I. Research by 2 Scientists
abstract: With work on machine learning that uses artificial neural networks, John J. Hopfield and Geoffrey E. Hinton “showed a completely new way for us to use computers,” the committee said.
lead_paragraph: John J. Hopfield and Geoffrey E. Hinton received the Nobel Prize in Physics on Tuesday for discoveries that helped computers learn more in the way the human brain does, providing the building blocks for developments in artificial intelligence.

headline: Mass Evacuations Clog Highways in Florida Ahead of Milton
abstract: Officials said the evacuation was likely the biggest the state has seen since Hurricane Irma in 2017, and warned residents to leave early to avoid heavy traffic.
lead_paragraph: Residents along Florida’s Gulf Coast were fleeing in droves on Tuesday ahead of Hurricane Milton’s predicted landfall, in what officials said was likely to be the biggest evacuation the state has seen since Hurricane Irma struck in 2017. Evacuees have faced hourslong traffic jams on highways and gas stations running out of fuel.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 486
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Oct. 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,208
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Oct. 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Poll Finds Harris Rising, and Florida Braces for Hurricane Milton
abstract: Plus, have we reached peak human life span?
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: How NAFTA Broke American Politics
abstract: Since its passage in 1993, the trade agreement has played an outsize role in presidential elections.
lead_paragraph: On the campaign trail, Donald Trump and Kamala Harris are constantly talking about trade, tariffs and domestic manufacturing.

headline: What Is Hamas Capable of After a Year of War?
abstract: The Palestinian militant group fired rockets at Israel on the anniversary of its Oct. 7 attacks.
