lead_paragraph: A year ago, Hamas’s deadly attacks on southern Israel prompted an Israeli military offensive against the group in Gaza. Tens of thousands of Palestinians have been killed in the Israeli attacks, including children; Israel says it has killed many Hamas fighters and commanders.

headline: Federal Debt and the Election
abstract: National debt may soon exceed G.D.P. We explore the causes — and possible solutions.
lead_paragraph: Sometime in the next two years, the federal debt will likely cross a worrisome threshold: It will exceed the size of the country’s annual economic output (or G.D.P.) for the first time since 1946.

headline: China to Penalize European Brandy Imports, Striking Back at Car Tariffs
abstract: Beijing’s action came days after European nations moved toward tariffs on electric vehicles from China, and it included a threat to also hit pork and car imports.
lead_paragraph: Raising the stakes in a trade dispute with the European Union, the Chinese government said on Tuesday it would impose temporary penalties on brandy from Europe and was mulling broader tariffs on European goods.

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: V.P. Debate, Middle East, Nibi the Beaver
abstract: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: How Google Was Forced to Open Up
abstract: A federal judge ordered the tech giant to let rival app stores onto its Android smartphone platform, adding to its growing list of legal headaches .
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Epic Games began efforts to disrupt the two major smartphone operating systems, Apple’s iOS and Google’s Android. While one of those fights largely sputtered, the other has yielded major results.

headline: After Key Town Falls in Ukraine’s East, Russian Forces Push Into Another
abstract: Russian troops have now entered Toretsk, a strategic hilltop city, and are pressing with assaults elsewhere in the Donetsk region.
lead_paragraph: A week after Russia captured Vuhledar, a town that anchored Ukraine’s defenses in the country’s southeast, Moscow’s forces are continuing to advance in the area, pushing into or flanking several towns as they try to break through Ukrainian lines.

headline: India’s Political Carnival Is Back in Season, With Mixed Results for Modi
abstract: Two closely watched elections, in Haryana and the turbulent Jammu and Kashmir, kept the surprises coming after this summer’s shocking national outcome.
lead_paragraph: In the first test of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s poll power since his party’s shocking loss of its majority in India’s national elections this summer, two closely watched elections on Tuesday kept the surprises coming.

headline: An Exquisite Queer Odyssey by a Literary Master
abstract: In Alan Hollinghurst’s new novel, “Our Evenings,” a Burmese English actor grapples with race and ambition, sexuality and love in a bigoted world.
lead_paragraph: Near the conclusion of Alan Hollinghurst’s languorous, elegant novel “Our Evenings,” the seventh from the Booker laureate, the elderly biracial narrator, Dave Win, a London actor famous for East Asian roles, bumps into Giles Hadlow, a Tory politician and dyed-in-the-wool nativist, at a literary festival held in a manor house. Both have just published books, but only one draws crowds. As a teenager Dave had benefited from the Hadlow Exhibition: a scholarship funded by Giles’s parents to attend Bampton, an eminent Berkshire public school (what we Yanks would call a prep school). Though Giles’s parents are Dave’s benefactors, Giles is not. Dave once spent a holiday at the Hadlow farm, where Giles, brawny and cruel, tormented him with slurs and half nelsons.

headline: Top Deputy Mayor to Eric Adams Resigns, Intensifying Wave of Departures
abstract: Sheena Wright, the first deputy mayor of New York City, became the seventh senior leader to leave City Hall in the past few weeks, as federal investigations into the Adams administration widen.
lead_paragraph: Sheena Wright, a longtime ally of Mayor Eric Adams, has resigned from her post as first deputy mayor, making her the seventh senior official to leave the administration during a time of crisis in New York City government.

headline: Welcome to Mike Kelley’s World: Beautiful, Ugly, Funny and Dumb
abstract: The American artist died in 2012, but a new exhibition in London shows how his deadpan-weirdo works continue to resonate today.
lead_paragraph: Fantasy birdhouses, monkey islands, U.F.O. abductions, poltergeist possessions, hillbillies, rockers, goths, stuffed animals, graffitied history books and colorful banners with humorous phrases (most of which can’t be printed in this newspaper): The work of the Detroit-born multimedia artist Mike Kelley has something for everyone.

headline: A U.N. Official’s Payments: Zero Interest Loans, a Mercedes and a Tennis Sponsorship
abstract: The official secretly took $3 million in gifts from a businessman to whom he steered the organization’s funds, a court ruled. The U.N. got a song about the ocean.
lead_paragraph: A high-ranking United Nations official secretly took $3 million in gifts from a British businessman while he steered more than $58 million of the organization’s money to the man’s companies, according to a ruling from an internal U.N. court.

headline: Studio Museum in Harlem to Open New Building in Fall 2025
abstract: The 82,000-square-foot structure on 125th Street will open with a show featuring the artist Tom Lloyd.
lead_paragraph: The Studio Museum in Harlem on Tuesday announced that it will open its new home on 125th Street in the fall of 2025. Its first show there will bring the museum full circle by focusing on the work of Tom Lloyd, the artist, educator and activist who was featured in the 1968 opening exhibition of the institution — which was then just a second-floor rented loft on upper Fifth Avenue.

headline: Book Revives Questions About Trump’s Ties to Putin
abstract: The journalist Bob Woodward cited an unnamed aide saying that Donald J. Trump had spoken to Vladimir V. Putin as many as seven times since leaving office. Multiple sources say they cannot confirm that report.
lead_paragraph: Just weeks ahead of an election, Americans are once again being confronted with a familiar if vexing question that has never been definitively resolved: What is up with former President Donald J. Trump and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia?

headline: TikTok Faces Barrage of Lawsuits Around Teens and Mental Health
abstract: More than a dozen states sued TikTok on Tuesday for creating an app designed to be addictive to children and teenagers.
lead_paragraph: Thirteen states and the District of Columbia sued TikTok on Tuesday, accusing the company of creating an intentionally addictive app that harmed children and teenagers while making false claims to the public about its commitment to safety.

headline: School Absences Rise as Special Education Fails Students, Suit Says
abstract: A class-action lawsuit argues that the New York City school system falls short in helping students with emotional disabilities, leaving them to miss too many school days.
lead_paragraph: New York City “regularly fails” to provide special education services to students with disabilities, leading to chronic absences, according to a class-action lawsuit filed Tuesday by the Legal Aid Society.

headline: Will Trump Get Jail Time? We Looked at Similar Cases to Find Out.
abstract: Donald J. Trump faces sentencing on Nov. 26. The election three weeks earlier may determine not only if he returns to the presidency, but if he ends up behind bars.
lead_paragraph: In November, after voters decide whether to return Donald J. Trump to the White House, the judge who oversaw his criminal trial could send him to jail.

headline: City Hall Official Charged With Witness Tampering in Adams Inquiry
abstract: Mohamed Bahi, who resigned Monday from the mayor’s office of community affairs, was accused of instructing witnesses to lie to federal authorities.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams’s former chief liaison to the Muslim community was arrested Tuesday on federal witness tampering and destruction of evidence charges that had grown out of the investigation that led to the mayor’s indictment last month.

headline: Our Book Is Here!
abstract: The cover star: Melissa Clark’s five-star skillet chicken with tomatoes, pancetta and mozzarella (a.k.a. pizza chicken).
lead_paragraph: Our cookbook has arrived! Today is the release of “Easy Weeknight Dinners: 100 Fast, Flavor-Packed Meals for Busy People Who Still Want Something Good to Eat,” inspired by this newsletter and all of you. I’m thrilled for you to see it. You can order your copy here.

headline: Harris Proposes Medicare Benefits for Home Care, Vision and Hearing
abstract: The vice president’s health care plan is meant to help Americans who are struggling to find affordable home care for themselves or aging relatives.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris outlined a new proposal for home health care on “The View” on Tuesday, describing a Medicare expansion plan that she said would help what is called the “sandwich generation” to take care of aging parents.

headline: Asheville, Tampa and Lessons From Hurricane Helene
abstract: Readers reflect on the devastation, the recovery and climate havens. Also: An ex-hostage’s plea; the women who accuse Donald Trump; a Trump rally.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Inside a Field Hospital in a North Carolina Mountain Town
abstract: After Hurricane Helene hit, a group of doctors and nurses quickly built a field hospital in Burnsville, N.C., to tend to patients and provide them with medical care.
lead_paragraph: After Hurricane Helene hit, a group of doctors and nurses quickly built a field hospital in Burnsville, N.C., to tend to patients and provide them with medical care.

headline: Iran Crisis Ignites New Debate About Trump’s Nuclear Deal Exit
abstract: President Donald J. Trump labeled it “the worst deal in history.” But critics of the withdrawal say it prompted Iran to accelerate its nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: With Israel preparing to respond to the ballistic missile attack by Iran last week, Biden administration officials are more worried than ever that the United States could be dragged into an all-out war between the two countries.

headline: Does My Home Have Lead Pipes? And What Can I Do About Them?
abstract: New rules will require utilities to replace lead pipes nationwide. That will take time, but you can protect yourself by taking these steps.
lead_paragraph: Lead is a potent neurotoxin that can cause irreversible damage to the nervous system and the brain. It poses a particular risk to infants and children, impairing their cognitive development and causing behavioral disorders.

headline: Biden Warns Floridians to ‘Evacuate Now’ as He Postpones Foreign Trip Over Hurricane Milton
abstract: President Biden had been scheduled to leave for Germany and Angola on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Tuesday warned those in the path of Hurricane Milton to “evacuate now, now, now,” as he canceled a diplomatic trip abroad so he could oversee his administration’s response to the storm barreling toward Florida’s west coast.

headline: Pro-Palestinian ‘Uncommitted’ Group Comes Out Firmly Against Trump
abstract: The organization that emerged from protests against the Biden administration’s Middle East policies now says a second Trump term would be far worse.
lead_paragraph: Uncommitted, the national group of Arab Americans, Muslim Americans and Palestinian rights activists that emerged from primary-season voters protesting President Biden’s Middle East policy, took a big step Tuesday toward encouraging supporters to vote for Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: Art or Trash? It Can Be a Fine Line.
abstract: Two beer cans were displayed in a Dutch museum. Then they were accidentally thrown out.
lead_paragraph: A work of art consisting of two empty beer cans was displayed at a museum. Quick quiz: What happened next?

headline: Acru, From the Atomix Team, Serves a Tasting Menu With an Australian Twang
abstract: Grand Army sets up shop in Threes Brewing, Ánimo! brings all-day Mexican breakfast to Midtown and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Word of this restaurant by Daniel Garwood began seeping out in early summer, but opening dates were postponed with clockwork regularity. Landmark status and permits were a factor, the chef said. Now it’s set for early next week. Mr. Garwood is from Tasmania and has worked in Asia, Scandinavia and Belgium before landing the job of sous chef at Atomix in 2022. His partner here is NA:EUN Hospitality Group, known for Atomix, Atoboy, Naro and Seoul Salon, and it’s its first non-Korean venture. Mr. Garwood’s seasonal five- to six-course tasting menu ($95) includes stops at lamb, tomatoes, carrots and dessert, some with Australian references. He plans to lose the tomatoes in place of squash soon. À la carte dishes are served at the bar. (Oct. 16)

headline: Luis Tiant, Crowd-Pleasing Pitcher Who Baffled Hitters, Dies at 83
abstract: Cuban-born and charismatic, with a personal tale caught up in politics, he was a dominant hurler with a quirky windup who helped lead the Red Sox to a pennant in 1975.
lead_paragraph: Luis Tiant, a Cuban-born right-hander who was one of baseball’s most entertaining and charismatic pitchers, and whose personal story was among the game’s most poignant, died on Tuesday. He was 83.

headline: Top Musk Lieutenant Joins Trump Super PAC for Final Push
abstract: Steve Davis is often called upon by Mr. Musk to help in all-hands-on-deck situations, such as after Mr. Musk’s purchase of Twitter.
lead_paragraph: One of Elon Musk’s most trusted lieutenants has joined the crew of people working for his pro-Trump super PAC, the latest sign of how Mr. Musk is investing his personal brand, energy and network into the group in the final weeks of the presidential campaign.

headline: How to Let People Down and Be OK With It
abstract: Setting boundaries often means disappointing others. We asked therapists for advice on how to do it — without feeling guilty.
lead_paragraph: In the last few years, several celebrities have captured the spotlight by stepping back to prioritize their mental health.

headline: 3% of American High Schoolers Identify as Transgender, First National Survey Finds
abstract: A survey by the C.D.C. found high rates of sadness, bullying and suicide attempts among transgender and gender-questioning teenagers.
lead_paragraph: About 3.3 percent of high school students identify as transgender and another 2.2 percent are questioning their gender identity, according to the first nationally representative survey on these groups, published by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Tuesday.

headline: Harris Should Offer to Debate Trump Again — on Fox
abstract: There’s only one venue where Harris would have another opportunity to speak to 67 million people at once.
lead_paragraph: In the latest New York Times/Siena College poll, Kamala Harris leads Donald Trump by three points. She’s made strategic appearances on the podcasts “Call Her Daddy” and “All the Smoke.” Her new direct-to-camera ad is strong.

headline: On Drug Prices, Harris Pushes for Deeper Cuts While Trump Offers Few Specifics
abstract: Both have campaigned for lower prescription costs. Kamala Harris has promised to expand President Biden’s policies. Donald Trump is a wild card.
lead_paragraph: Insulin for $35 a month. A limit of $2,000 a year in out-of-pocket drug costs for older Americans. Billions of dollars in savings for Medicare resulting from drug negotiations.

headline: On ‘The View,’ Harris Hits at Trump’s ‘Callousness’ in His Storm Response
abstract: In a wide-ranging interview, the vice president also she could not think of a way she would act differently from President Biden, and laid out a plan to help Americans take care of aging loved ones.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris, kicking off a daylong blitz of news media interviews, assailed former President Donald J. Trump for what she called his “callousness” in responding to the deadly storms that have ravaged southeastern states, and said she was still hoping to work with Gov. Ron DeSantis, Republican of Florida, as his state faces the latest monster hurricane.

headline: ‘Evacuate Now’: Biden Urges Floridians to Flee Hurricane Milton
abstract: President Biden called Hurricane Milton “a matter of life and death” for Florida residents.
lead_paragraph: President Biden called Hurricane Milton “a matter of life and death” for Florida residents.

headline: ‘La Máquina’ Is a Starry Mexican Boxing Drama
abstract: The Spanish-language Hulu drama, starring Diego Luna and Gael García Bernal, skews more loopy and mysterious than gritty.
lead_paragraph: Diego Luna and Gael García Bernal star in the Mexican boxing drama “La Máquina” (in Spanish, with subtitles, on Hulu) as a promoter and his boxer bestie. Andy (Luna), who copes with stress by giving himself facial injections, has been friends with Esteban (García Bernal), the popular boxer known as La Máquina (Spanish for “the machine”), since they were kids. He tends to Esteban’s every need — including fixing a fight or two along the way, without Esteban’s knowledge.

headline: France’s Government Survives a No-Confidence Vote
abstract: The outcome was not a surprise but signals a treacherous road ahead for the country’s divided legislature.
lead_paragraph: A no-confidence vote against the government of Prime Minister Michel Barnier of France was handily defeated on Tuesday. But there is more drama to come, as the lack of a legislative majority causes deep political uncertainty.

headline: Is It Too Late Now to Say Sorry? 8 Songs for the High Holy Days.
abstract: Apology, forgiveness, moving on: These are some of humanity’s richest themes, and they have rich songs to match.
lead_paragraph: As Lindsay mentioned on Friday, she’s out on book leave for the rest of the month. Starting next week, a series of knowledgeable Times staffers will sub in to provide thoughtfully curated playlists each Tuesday. This week, however, you are stuck with me: a reporter on the Culture desk who has written about Dylan and the Dead, and whose current Spotify rotation includes CoComelon’s “Wheels on the Bus” and the “Encanto” soundtrack (possibly Lin-Manuel Miranda’s finest work).

headline: Record Hot Water Is Fueling Hurricane Milton
abstract: Milton grew into a Category 5 hurricane in less than a day as it crossed warm oceans across the Gulf of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Milton gained strength over the Gulf of Mexico extremely quickly on Monday, going from a tropical storm to a Category 5 hurricane in under a day.

headline: Netanyahu Suggests Israel Killed Likely Replacements for Hezbollah’s Leader
abstract: Hashem Safieddine had been expected to succeed Hassan Nasrallah, his cousin. It was not immediately clear who “the replacement of the replacement” was.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu suggested in a video message released on Tuesday that Israel had not only killed the presumed successor of Hezbollah’s assassinated leader, Hassan Nasrallah, in airstrikes last week outside Beirut, but also the successor’s potential replacement.

headline: Ex-Houston Police Officer Gets 60 Years in Prison in Drug Raid Killings
abstract: A jury had found Gerald Goines guilty of felony murder in the deaths of two people who were fatally shot during a botched drug raid in 2019.
lead_paragraph: A former Houston police officer who lied to obtain a warrant for a drug raid that led to the shooting deaths of two people was sentenced on Tuesday to 60 years in prison for felony murder in a case that unveiled corruption in the city’s Police Department and drew scrutiny from federal officials.

headline: Russian Spies Seeking to ‘Generate Mayhem’ in Europe, MI5 Chief Says
abstract: The head of Britain’s domestic security service said Russia’s military intelligence service was pursuing “dangerous actions conducted with increasing recklessness.”
lead_paragraph: Russian intelligence agents are on a mission “to generate mayhem on British and European streets,” Britain’s spy chief said Tuesday in a wide-ranging speech that also warned of a rising threat from Iran and new efforts by the Islamic State to export terrorism.

headline: U.S. Budget Deficit Rises to $1.8 Trillion in 2024
abstract: New estimates from the Congressional Budget Office show continuing fiscal strain, despite steady economic growth.
lead_paragraph: America’s federal budget deficit rose to $1.8 trillion in the 2024 fiscal year, reaching the highest level in three years, according to new Congressional Budget Office estimates released on Tuesday.

headline: Our Planet’s Twin Crises
abstract: In her last newsletter for the Times, a Climate Forward reporter reflects on the intertwined problems of climate change and biodiversity loss.
lead_paragraph: The world’s largest river, the Amazon, has fallen to its lowest level on record in the past few weeks, a development that has shocked experts around the world.

headline: What We Know About the Israeli Forces Fighting in Lebanon
abstract: The Israeli military has sent troops from four divisions across the border into Lebanon, but has not publicly disclosed how many.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military announced on Tuesday that a new division of soldiers, the 146th, was operating in southern Lebanon, signaling that it could be ramping up the ground invasion of its neighbor.

headline: Qantas Apologizes for Showing R-Rated Film With Nudity to Entire Flight
abstract: The scenes played on every screen, according to comments from social media users. The airline has since said the movie “was clearly not suitable.”
lead_paragraph: Sit back, relax and enjoy the … nudity and sexting?

headline: Residents Flee Milton From Beach Towns Still Cleaning Up From Helene
abstract: A one-two punch along Florida’s Gulf Coast is confronting some residents with hard decisions, like whether to pack up for good.
lead_paragraph: On the barrier islands outside St. Petersburg, Fla., which were utterly crushed by Hurricane Helene’s storm surge two weeks ago, it was hard to tell where storm recovery ends and storm preparation for the approaching Hurricane Milton begins.

headline: Trump and Republicans Bet Big on Anti-Trans Ads Across the Country
abstract: Republicans have spent tens of millions of dollars on the ads, part of an attempt to help them win over suburban female voters.
lead_paragraph: With just four weeks until the election, Donald J. Trump and Republican candidates nationwide are putting transgender issues at the center of their campaigns, tapping into fears about transgender women and girls in sports and about taxpayer-funded gender transitions in prisons.

headline: Voting Wars Open a New Front: Which Mail Ballots Should Count?
abstract: Voting by mail is increasingly popular, but mail ballots are rejected far more often than in-person ones. In Pennsylvania and elsewhere, parties are battling over which ones to count — or not.
lead_paragraph: As Pennsylvania voters begin casting perhaps two million-plus mail ballots, Democrats and Republicans are in furious legal combat over a once-overlooked aspect of voting remotely: which ballots are counted, which are rejected as defective and which ones voters are allowed to correct.

headline: Cissy Houston Saw Music’s Peaks and Life’s Valleys
abstract: The singer, who died this week, was the mother of Whitney Houston and a contender for the greatest voice of the country, our critic says.
lead_paragraph: If you’re the sort of person who remains locked in a private, perpetual tug of war over whether the greatest singer this country’s ever known is Aretha Franklin or Whitney Houston, perhaps you’re also the sort of person who then spares a thought for Whitney’s mother, Cissy. Cissy Houston died at 91 on Monday, and she could sing, too. Let me try that again: Cissy Houston sang, first with the clarity of something just Windexed then, later, with a tone that acquired some protective, matured texture, some bark.

headline: Inside a Harris Ad in Which Ex-Trump Aides Blast Him as Unfit for Office
abstract: An attack ad from Kamala Harris’s campaign uses denunciations of Donald Trump by his own former top security lieutenants to portray him as too risky to restore to power.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign has spent more than $2.6 million running this 60-second ad across the country since Oct. 3, including six-figure buys in six of the seven battleground states, according to AdImpact.

headline: Vandals Deface Harvard Statue and U. of Michigan Leaders’ Homes
abstract: It was not clear who was responsible for the broken windows, fake blood and pro-Palestinian slogans.
lead_paragraph: A statue and an administration building at Harvard and the homes of two top administrators at the University of Michigan were vandalized, apparently by protesters sympathetic to the pro-Palestinian cause.

headline: Toronto Woman Is Accused of Murdering 3 in Serial Killings
abstract: Victims who were found in a span of three days in Canada last week included two men whom the police said the suspect had attacked at random.
lead_paragraph: The first victim was a woman whose body was found with visible trauma in a home in Toronto last Tuesday. On Wednesday, the police found a second victim, a man, dying of unspecified injuries in a Niagara Falls park, about 80 miles away. On Thursday, a third victim, also a man, was fatally stabbed in a parking lot in Hamilton, a city some 45 miles from there.

headline: Harris Spends an Hour in the Warm Embrace of Howard Stern
abstract: The shock jock has become a required stop for Democratic politicians.
lead_paragraph: Who says Kamala Harris’s unconventional media tour won’t reveal anything of note? On Tuesday, she did an hourlong sit-down with Howard Stern, the satellite radio host, and among the juicy bits we learned is that the V.P. isn’t a napper; that she digs Doritos and jigsaw puzzles; that her favorite F1 driver is Lewis Hamilton; that she went to see U2 at the Sphere; and that a rare area of musical agreement between her and Doug, her husband, is their love of Prince.

headline: Fears of Hurricane Milton Drive Millions From Their Homes in Florida
abstract: More than 5.5 million people were urged to leave Florida’s western coast, one of the largest evacuations in state history. Some who have stayed for previous storms decided to go this time.
lead_paragraph: The threat of Hurricane Milton to Florida’s densely populated Tampa Bay region led to one of the largest evacuations in the state’s history this week. Officials urged millions of people out of possible harm’s way.

headline: How Does It Feel to Win a Nobel Prize? Ask the ‘Godfather of A.I.’
abstract: The computer scientist Geoffrey Hinton spoke with The Times shortly after learning he had won the Nobel Prize for Physics.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, the scientists John J. Hopfield and Geoffrey E. Hinton received the Nobel Prize in Physics for discoveries that helped drive the development of artificial neural networks — a technology that is now essential to the operation of search engines like Google and online chatbots like ChatGPT from OpenAI.

headline: How Helene Has Upended North Carolina’s Election Plans
abstract: With 13 counties devastated by flooding, the state is trying to make sure that residents can still vote. Candidates have been forced to abandon door-knocking and phone banks.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the North Fork Voting House has served as the official polling place for nearly 600 residents in the small mountain community of Creston, N.C. The tiny cinder block building was recently updated with a freshly painted white door, handmade curtains for the voting booths and a new metal roof.

headline: Poll Finds Support for Florida’s Abortion Ballot Measure Is Falling Short
abstract: Earlier surveys have shown higher support, but the state’s Republican governor is working hard to defeat the initiative.
lead_paragraph: A ballot measure that would establish a right to abortion in the Florida Constitution is not on track to pass in November, according to a poll by The New York Times and Siena College.

headline: Greg Landry, Scrambling All-Pro Quarterback, Is Dead at 77
abstract: Known for his legs as well as for his arm, he was the last Detroit Lions quarterback to make the Pro Bowl for more than 40 years.
lead_paragraph: Greg Landry, who in the late 1960s and ’70s became a forerunner of the modern dual-threat quarterback and, after a glittering All-Pro season for the Detroit Lions in 1971, made the Pro Bowl — the last Lions quarterback to earn that distinction for more than 40 years — died on Friday in Detroit. He was 77.

headline: Florida Rushes to Clear Helene Debris Before Milton Hits
abstract: Worried about flying wreckage, Governor Ron DeSantis said that the state was trying to clear as much debris from Hurricane Helene as possible before Hurricane Milton strikes.
lead_paragraph: Florida officials are scrambling to clear out the flattened trees, mangled appliances and waterlogged furniture left behind by Hurricane Helene to prevent the debris from becoming projectiles in Hurricane Milton.

headline: Biden Excoriated Netanyahu on Israel’s Conduct in the War, Woodward Book Says
abstract: The book, “War,” lays bare just how frustrated the president has become with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu since the war in Gaza began.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has had a long and complicated relationship with Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu — one that has taken an especially intense turn in the year since the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attacks, as documented in a new book by the journalist Bob Woodward.

headline: On Florida’s West Coast, Airports, Amusement Parks and Hotels Close
abstract: Visit Florida, the state’s official tourism organization, warned that Hurricane Milton is expected to grow and remain “extremely dangerous.” The travel industry is taking extreme precautions.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on Hurricane Milton.

headline: 13 Things We Learned From Harris’s Interview With Howard Stern
abstract: In a lengthy sit-down, the veteran radio host extracted an array of new details about Kamala Harris’s life.
lead_paragraph: For over an hour, Vice President Kamala Harris and the radio host Howard Stern bantered on Tuesday about the state of the country, former President Donald J. Trump, Ms. Harris’s cereal and workout preferences, and her favorite musicians and racecar drivers.

headline: Israel’s Defense Minister Postpones Trip to Washington, U.S. Says
abstract: Yoav Gallant and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III were expected to discuss Israel’s response to the Iranian missile assault on Israel last week.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s defense minister, Yoav Gallant, postponed a visit to Washington on Wednesday to meet with Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III to discuss Israel’s military response to Iran’s recent missile barrage, the Pentagon said on Tuesday.

headline: Jobs and Housing Help Fuel Rapid Growth in Tampa
abstract: The region has been transformed by a number of economic and environmental factors, including its reputation for relatively few major storms.
lead_paragraph: For 10,000 years, people have relied on the natural resources of Tampa Bay, with its seagrass meadows, mangrove forests and diverse array of fauna.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: An Israeli Airstrike in Syria
abstract: Plus, revisiting Oppenheimer’s Communist ties.
lead_paragraph: Israel launched airstrikes yesterday on a residential building in the Syrian capital, Damascus, according to two Israeli officials who spoke anonymously. The attack, which landed near the Iranian Embassy, was an attempt by the Israeli military to assassinate a ranking Hezbollah official involved in weapons smuggling, they said.

headline: Brazil Unblocks X After Musk Backs Down
abstract: Brazil’s Supreme Court said Tuesday that Elon Musk’s social network could return in the country after a monthlong ban because the company had complied with the court’s orders.
lead_paragraph: Brazil lifted its ban on the social network X on Tuesday after its owner, Elon Musk, capitulated in his fight with the country’s Supreme Court, ending a five-week suspension of the platform across the nation of 200 million.

headline: Romney Won’t Endorse Harris, Saying He Wants to Keep His Voice in the Party
abstract: Senator Mitt Romney of Utah, the 2012 Republican nominee for president, says the party may need to be rebuilt.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitt Romney, the retiring Republican from Utah and onetime standard-bearer of a party that has shifted under his feet, said Tuesday that he would not endorse Vice President Kamala Harris in the election because it might hamper a critical role he could play in helping to rebuild the G.O.P. down the line.

headline: FEMA Chief: Hurricane Misinformation Is ‘Worst That I Have Ever Seen’
abstract: Deanne Criswell, who heads the agency, said the circulating falsehoods were hampering its work.
lead_paragraph: Disaster relief officials have issued several warnings this week that falsehoods and rumors spreading online about the government’s response to Hurricanes Helene and Milton have harmed relief efforts.

headline: Millions Are Fleeing Florida’s Gulf Coast Ahead of Milton
abstract: Also, the Supreme Court appeared open to limits on “ghost guns.” Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The threat of Hurricane Milton, a Category 5 storm now barreling toward Florida’s Gulf Coast, has prompted one of the largest evacuations in the state’s history. More than five million people have been ordered to find safer ground before Milton makes landfall tomorrow, causing a mass exodus that has clogged the highways and drained the area’s gas stations.

headline: Volunteers Aid Those Displaced by Israeli Attacks in Lebanon
abstract: Amid Israel’s offensive and Hezbollah’s decision to continue fighting, many have found themselves caught in the middle. In the southern coastal city of Sidon, young volunteers of diverse religious backgrounds have come together to help those affected by the conflict.
lead_paragraph: Amid Israel’s offensive and Hezbollah’s decision to continue fighting, many have found themselves caught in the middle. In the southern coastal city of Sidon, young volunteers of diverse religious backgrounds have come together to help those affected by the conflict.

headline: When a Television Meteorologist Breaks Down on Air and Admits Fear
abstract: John Morales, who has forecast weather for decades, went viral after choking up on air while discussing Hurricane Milton.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on Hurricane Milton.

headline: With Kennedy on the Ballot, Vance Talks Public Health in Michigan
abstract: Senator JD Vance of Ohio spoke of the occurrence of “weird childhood diseases” that may be caused by “weird stuff” in the food and water supply.
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance of Ohio echoed some of the language of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. on public health and the environment during a campaign rally on Tuesday in Michigan, a state where Mr. Kennedy — an ally of former President Donald J. Trump — was still on the ballot as a third-party presidential candidate and potential spoiler in the crucial battleground state.

headline: What Omarosa, John Kerry and Michael Cohen Have in Common
abstract: And why it matters in 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good evening! As former President Donald Trump threatens to prosecute his political rivals, my colleague Michael Schmidt, an investigative reporter, has an important look at how Trump deployed his power against his perceived enemies during his presidency. And we’re looking at the G.O.P.’s big bet on anti-trans ads. — Jess Bidgood

headline: Israel Sends More Soldiers Into Lebanon as Strikes Hit Beirut and Damascus
abstract: In an attack of its own, Hezbollah fired 180 “projectiles” into Israel, according to the Israeli military, which said most were intercepted.
lead_paragraph: Israel announced a new division had joined its invasion of southern Lebanon on Tuesday, signaling that it could be ramping up operations as it pounded the Beirut strongholds of Hezbollah. Two Israeli officials confirmed that Israel had also struck near the Iranian Embassy in Syria’s capital.

headline: We Should Want Israel to Win
abstract: Even supporters of Palestinian statehood should want Hamas and Hezbollah to lose.
lead_paragraph: The world had better hope that Israel wins its wars against Hamas, Hezbollah, the Houthis and their masters in Tehran. By “wins,” I mean that Israel inflicts such costs on its enemies’ capacity to wage war that they accept that their interests, irrespective of their desires, are no longer served by fighting.

headline: Jenna Fischer, ‘The Office’ Star, Reveals Breast Cancer Diagnosis
abstract: “I am now cancer free,’’ the actress announced on Instagram, noting that she was diagnosed with Stage 1 cancer in December and that early detection had played a key role in her successful treatment.
lead_paragraph: Jenna Fischer, the actress best known for her role as Pam Beesly in the popular television series “The Office,” said on Tuesday that she was diagnosed with Stage 1 triple-positive breast cancer in December but that she was now cancer free after successful treatment.

headline: Hurricane Milton’s Storm Surge Risk Across Florida
abstract: Updates with maps of the storm’s path, highlighting potential storm surge flooding across the coastline.
lead_paragraph: Updates with maps of the storm’s path, highlighting potential storm surge flooding across the coastline.

headline: In Florida, Day Laborers Have Become the Backbone of Hurricane Cleanup
abstract: While they work, they face many risks, like wage theft or breathing in harmful dust and mold. Sleeping in a vehicle for weeks at a time is not uncommon, either.
lead_paragraph: William Lopez was still cleaning debris and covering the roofs of homes damaged by Hurricane Helene about 40 minutes north of Tampa this week when the warnings about Hurricane Milton started to become dire.

headline: Small Business Administration Will Soon Exhaust Disaster Loan Funds
abstract: The agency has less than $100 million for new loans, according to officials, while Hurricane Milton is headed toward Florida and after Hurricane Helene devastated much of the Southeast.
lead_paragraph: Small Business Administration officials warned on Tuesday that the agency would “very soon” exhaust its funding for new disaster loans for homeowners and businesses in the wake of Hurricane Helene.

headline: Antisemitism and Threats Directed at Officials Over Storm Response
abstract: Some online posts have threatened violence against FEMA officials. A research group found that the X platform has been one of the main drivers of misinformation.
lead_paragraph: A wave of antisemitic rhetoric and online threats has been leveled at state and federal officials in North Carolina in recent days as they respond to the destructive aftermath of Hurricane Helene, according to a report released on Tuesday by a nonprofit research group that studies online platforms.

headline: In High Mountain Alaska, a Glacier’s Deep Secret Is Revealed at Last
abstract: A famed explorer was sure the ice hid something profound. Ninety years later, scientists have put forth the strongest evidence yet that he was right.
lead_paragraph: As his bush plane circled the craggy peaks of the Alaska Range, the explorer Bradford Washburn peered down and had a burning thought.

headline: A New Bitcoin Documentary Reopens the Search for Satoshi Nakamoto
abstract: The identity of the pseudonymous Bitcoin creator has eluded sleuths for years. But does finding the real Mr. Nakamoto really matter?
lead_paragraph: There are two ambitious missions behind “Money Electric: The Bitcoin Mystery,” a new documentary by the filmmaker Cullen Hoback that was released Tuesday by HBO.

headline: Afghan Man Arrested on Charges of Plotting Election Day Attack
abstract: It is not clear where the man intended to stage the attack, though the criminal complaint said he sought to inflict mass casualties on behalf of the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. has arrested an Afghan citizen in Oklahoma City on charges of plotting a suicide attack on Election Day, with the intent of inflicting mass casualties on behalf of the Islamic State, according to a criminal complaint filed on Tuesday.

headline: Harris Cracks a Beer With Colbert and Talks Foreign Policy and Trump
abstract: In a chat with Stephen Colbert, Kamala Harris suggested the Gaza war was unlikely to end soon, even as she urged optimism. And she condemned Donald Trump over reports that he sent rare Covid test machines to Russia.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris took her message from campaign-speak to conversational during an interview with the late-night host Stephen Colbert on Tuesday night, as she acknowledged fading hopes for a cease-fire in Gaza while keeping up her attacks on former President Donald J. Trump for his relationship with Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

headline: Seeking Release on Bail, Sean Combs Downplays Risk of Witness Tampering
abstract: In an appeal, lawyers for Mr. Combs wrote that a judge’s decision to withhold bail was not based on evidence that he had sought to interfere with the sex trafficking investigation.
lead_paragraph: Sean Combs, the embattled music mogul fighting racketeering and sex trafficking charges, filed an appeal on Tuesday of a judge’s decision to deny him bail, arguing that concerns he would intimidate witnesses if released from jail were unfounded.

headline: Walz Says the Electoral College ‘Needs to Go’
abstract: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota suggested at fund-raisers that he backed switching to a national popular vote. His spokesman clarified that this was not the position of Kamala Harris’s campaign.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota on Tuesday called for abolishing the Electoral College as a means of electing American presidents, reiterating a position he has articulated in the past while he and Vice President Kamala Harris are in the heat of a campaign for the White House.

headline: Episode Interruptions
abstract: Jeffrey Lease is struck by inspiration.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: The 9 Elements of a Trump Rally
abstract: The themes Donald Trump returns to again and again at his rallies
lead_paragraph: The themes Donald Trump returns to again and again at his rallies

headline: Slotkin and Rogers Attack Each Other’s Records in Michigan Senate Debate
abstract: Representative Elissa Slotkin, a Democrat, and former Representative Mike Rogers, a Republican, had bitter exchanges over abortion, war and China.
lead_paragraph: A debate between Representative Elissa Slotkin, the Democrat running for Michigan’s open Senate seat, and former Representative Mike Rogers, her Republican opponent, turned bitter on Tuesday night as the candidates sought to disqualify each other with attacks over their voting records in the House.

headline: U.S. Weighs Forcing Google to Break Off Parts of the Company
abstract: They include making Google’s data available to rivals and forcing it to break off parts of the company, the Justice Department said in a court filing.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said Tuesday night that it was considering asking a federal court to force Google to break off parts of the company or change its practices in order to eliminate its monopoly in search, moves that could redefine the $2 trillion company’s core business.

headline: Quote of the Day: Study of Life Spans Suggests Humans May Be at Their Peak
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, October 9, 2024
lead_paragraph: “We’re basically suggesting that as long as we live now is about as long as we’re going to live.”

headline: Volkswagen’s Woes Reflect a Stagnant German Economy
abstract: Germany’s largest automaker rode a wave of strong sales for years, but lagging demand and pressure from China are forcing it to consider layoffs.
lead_paragraph: No industry is more important to the German economy than automobiles. And no carmaker is more important than Volkswagen.

headline: Global Warming Made Helene More Menacing, Researchers Say
abstract: In cooler times, a similarly rare storm over the Southeast would have delivered less rain and weaker winds, a team of scientists concluded in an analysis.
lead_paragraph: As humans warm the planet, the soaking rains and lashing winds that Hurricane Helene brought last month are becoming increasingly likely occurrences in the Southeastern United States, scientists said Wednesday.

headline: How Harrods, London’s Luxury Emporium, Is Dealing With a Sexual Abuse Scandal
abstract: The 175-year-old department store is trying to make amends for alleged abuse by its former owner, Mohamed Al Fayed, even while shoppers seem undeterred.
lead_paragraph: Across the department store’s seven labyrinthine floors, visitors weave their way past designer bags, diamond-encrusted watches and columns carved with Egyptian hieroglyphics.

headline: ‘I’m Not Going to Wait’: Young Chinese Jump Into Stock Frenzy
abstract: Despite the risks of investing at a volatile time, investors see the recent stock rally as a rare opportunity to make money when China’s economy is sluggish.
lead_paragraph: Young people in China have jumped into stock trading in the past two weeks since Beijing took its most aggressive steps yet to revive economic growth and persuade consumers to start spending.

headline: In This Office, the Fading Dream of a Unified Korea Lives On
abstract: On paper, five South Korean officials are the governors of North Korean provinces. Their goal is reunification, but fewer and fewer Koreans share it.
lead_paragraph: Sohn Yang-Young was appointed governor of South Hamgyeong Province by South Korea’s president last year. The job came with a chauffeur-driven car, secretaries, a spacious office and a mahogany desk with a mother-of-pearl nameplate.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: An Israeli airstrike in Syria.
lead_paragraph: Israel carried out airstrikes on a residential building in Damascus, Syria, in an attempt to assassinate a Hezbollah official involved in weapons smuggling, according to two Israeli officials.

headline: As I Am: L.G.B.T.Q. in Japan
abstract: ‘We don’t want to send the message to the younger generation that we’re people who have to hide ourselves.’
lead_paragraph: In Japan, same-sex unions remain outlawed, and children who don’t conform to traditional gender norms are routinely bullied. Japanese who are gay, transgender or nonbinary must stake out their own distinctive paths.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel: Putin Is Trump’s ‘KGBFF’
abstract: Kimmel shared tidbits from Bob Woodward’s new book, including that Donald Trump had spoken with Vladimir Putin seven times since leaving office — “which is less than Ivanka, but more than Tiffany.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: exorbitant
abstract: This word has appeared in 158 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word exorbitant has appeared in 158 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 9 in “At the U.S. Open, a Quest for $100 Chicken Nuggets” by Matt Stevens and Jesus Jiménez:

headline: Andrew Garfield Believes Hearts Are Meant to Break
abstract: The actor speaks to Anna Martin, host of the Modern Love Podcast, about his new movie “We Live in Time,” and why heartbreak is a path to vitality.
lead_paragraph: The actor speaks to Anna Martin, host of the Modern Love Podcast, about his new movie “We Live in Time,” and why heartbreak is a path to vitality.

headline: Why This Rainbow Gel Manicure (With Chrome!) Costs $255
abstract: Pricing for soft gel nail extensions depends on the length, size and brand, as well as any nail art, and can run several hundred dollars.
lead_paragraph: For Ms. Pinto, who worked in art curation, nails are just another form of art.

headline: $160 Million Later, New Pool and Rink Will Replace Central Park Eyesore
abstract: The new Harlem Meer Center, opening early next year, will serve the largely Black and Latino communities surrounding the northern end of the park.
lead_paragraph: The ice rink looked like a toilet bowl with a tank on the back, so ugly that the stewards of Central Park built an island of sediment dredged from the Harlem Meer, a man-made lake, to try to hide it from joggers and cyclists speeding past.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Designer Dorm Rooms
abstract: What do you think of a new trend in which college students are hiring interior designers to makeover their dorm rooms?
lead_paragraph: According to a recent Times article, “a wave of undergraduates — especially in the southern states — are hiring interior designers to completely makeover their dorm rooms at a cost of thousands of dollars per room.”

headline: Mozambique’s 2024 National Elections: What to Know
abstract: Four candidates are vying for the presidency in a country that has faced a yearslong ISIS-backed insurgency. The election is also a test of the sway of former independence movements.
lead_paragraph: Voters in Mozambique go to the polls on Wednesday to elect a new president who will face the tall task of figuring out how to defeat a yearslong Islamic State-backed insurgency that is deepening grave humanitarian and economic problems.

headline: Trump Family Business Eyes Hotel Deals in Israel
abstract: The Trump Organization was in talks about Israeli hotels before the Hamas attack last year. It says it wants to resume them in the future, raising questions about the mingling of politics and money in the event of a second Trump term.
lead_paragraph: In the heart of Jerusalem, a short walk from the Israeli Supreme Court and prime minister’s office, Donald J. Trump’s family business spotted a moneymaking opportunity.

headline: In ‘The Witches of El Paso,’ Magic Is a Blessing and a Curse
abstract: In this family saga, a floundering lawyer must tap into her supernatural heritage to help her family in the past and present.
lead_paragraph: What does magic look like? Praying to God and getting a reply? A coyote’s tooth falling out of a woman’s mouth? Perhaps a time-traveling ancestor, or a formless “energy that enters you and uses you”? In Luis Jaramillo’s supernatural family saga, “The Witches of El Paso,” it is all of the above. But no matter what form it takes, “magic always complicates,” the novel’s heroine, Elena “Nena” Eduviges Montoya, says.

headline: Misreading the Moment, a Bra Empire Goes Bust
abstract: In “Selling Sexy,” two veteran fashion journalists examine how Victoria’s Secret fell from grace.
lead_paragraph: Did you know that the modern brassiere is a Buckminster Fuller-level feat of soft engineering requiring some 30 to 40 separately sourced pieces, “including underwires and strap-adjusting sliders”?

headline: Why Cakes Can Be a Powerful Form of Protest
abstract: A new generation of bakers are reviving an old tradition.
lead_paragraph: LONG BEFORE WOMEN finally — though incompletely — won the right to vote in the United States in 1920, they were finding ways to influence politics. In late 18th-century New England, colonial women would make muster cakes — spiced, doorstop-heavy confections flecked with candied fruit and soaked in alcohol — for soldiers being gathered (or “mustered”) to fight in the Revolutionary War. Later, women baked what became known as election cakes to potentially encourage voters to back causes that they cared about. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, suffragists included several such recipes in the cookbooks that they published — volumes that featured quotes from famous supporters alongside sometimes satirical recipes such as Pie for a Suffragist’s Doubting Husband, the crust of which was to be mixed with “tact and velvet gloves.” For the suffragists, cookbooks were “a tool largely to convince men that they had no plans of leaving the kitchen,” says KC Hysmith, 35, a North Carolina-based recipe developer and culinary historian. “The rhetoric used against them was: If women get the vote, they’re going to leave you to cook your own food.”

headline: A Camera in the East Village, Capturing the Now and the Long Ago
abstract: The photographer Susan Schiffman shoots rent-stabilized apartments in the neighborhood intended as portraits of the unseen tenants who live in them.
lead_paragraph: A large part of what’s made New York so, well, New York, is its rent-stabilized apartments. The city has over 960,000 rent-stabilized housing units, according to last year’s Housing and Vacancy Survey, and tenants living in them are protected from sharp rent hikes and are granted the right to renew their leases. This rent regulation system was enacted in 1969, and has allowed for generations of tenants, especially artists, musicians, writers and other creatives, to live in New York.

headline: Andrew Garfield Wants to Crack Open Your Heart
abstract: The actor knows life is fleeting, but he wants to hold onto every moment.
lead_paragraph: In the new movie “We Live in Time,” the actor Andrew Garfield plays a newly divorced man named Tobias who falls in love with a chef named Almut, played by Florence Pugh. Their story feels epic and expansive, but still intimate. It focuses on the small, everyday moments that make up a love story: washing dishes together after a dinner party, sharing biscuits, smelling fruit at a farmers’ market. These are the moments that sustain them through Almut’s excruciatingly difficult medical crisis.

headline: Some of the Web’s Sketchiest Sites Share an Address in Iceland
abstract: A Reykjavik building that houses a penis museum and an H&M is also the virtual home to an array of perpetrators of identity theft, ransomware and disinformation.
lead_paragraph: The modern office building near the harbor in Iceland’s capital, Reykjavik, is best known as the home of the Icelandic Phallological Museum, which displays 320 specimens of mammal penises.

headline: TV Medical Dramas Are Not Like Real Life. Maybe They Should Be.
abstract: On television, medical stories end with a diagnosis and a return to normalcy. In reality, they are far more complicated.
lead_paragraph: The classic medical story line has a few key ingredients. There is a likable protagonist with a set of perplexing and debilitating symptoms. There are clear stakes. Will the young patient be able to walk down the aisle at her wedding? There is a diagnosis, followed by a high-stakes surgery or a risky medication. And then there is the final act. The bride walks down the aisle. Life returns to how it once was.

headline: Jazz Has a New Home in Seattle. One Caveat: The Place Is ‘For Lease.’
abstract: The nonprofit Seattle Jazz Fellowship has carved out a performance space in the historic Globe Building — for now — and is putting its economic model to the test.
lead_paragraph: The Pacific Northwest might be synonymous with grunge rock, but Seattle’s music scene has historically maintained a rich undercurrent of jazz. Even in the 1990s, with plaid-clad darlings riding high on barre chords, the trumpeter Thomas Marriott recalls an ideal downtown scene for budding improvisers to “pay dues,” a sort of low-cost, low-pressure musician’s utopia where rent could be made in a single weekend’s worth of gigs, and “you could just take your horn, walk up and down the street and see people you knew.”

headline: Why Kamala Harris’s ‘Call Her Daddy’ Strategy Might Not Be Enough
abstract: Gen Z men could swing the election. Trump knows that.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has been on a tour of the Gen Z influencer ecosystem, from Theo Von to Adin Ross. In this episode of “The Opinions,” Daniel Pfeiffer, a senior adviser to former President Barack Obama, argues that Trump is trying to win the support of young men, a once loyal Democratic constituency. Mr. Pfeiffer says Democrats ignore these voters at their peril, for the 2024 election and beyond: “There is no post-Trump era if Gen Z men become firmly adherents of MAGA philosophy,” he explains.

headline: For ‘Disclaimer,’ Alfonso Cuarón Updates His Terms and Conditions
abstract: Cate Blanchett stars in the acclaimed director’s new TV series, a thriller about a woman whose life is upended by a mysterious novel.
lead_paragraph: About a decade ago, the writer-director Alfonso Cuarón was sent an advance copy of Renée Knight’s book “Disclaimer,” a thriller about a woman whose life is upended when she receives a novel by an unknown author that seems to lay bare her secrets. That novel begins with a disclaimer: “Any resemblance to persons living or dead is not a coincidence.”

headline: The 7-Minute Stress Workout
abstract: Sometimes moving the body can help quiet the mind.
lead_paragraph: The world is an unstable place. Whether it’s politics, your career or the appropriate length for jeans — the ground is constantly shifting. And if the world feels unstable long enough, your mind and body can enter a perpetual state of high alert.

headline: The Wilderness Hidden in the Heart of Toronto
abstract: A sprawling network of ravines threaded through Canada’s largest city offers urban explorers an oasis of birdsong, burbling creeks and whispering trees.
lead_paragraph: Dangling my feet over the bank of a fast-running creek, I watched the sunlight filter through a leafy canopy above me. Here, in the middle of a city of three million people, I felt utterly alone, and though I was loath to admit it, a little disoriented. But that was why I had come.

headline: Yolanda Robinson, Wife of Mark Robinson, Has Had Scandals of Her Own
abstract: North Carolina’s second lady helped make her husband’s political foray possible. But her ventures — a day care and a nonprofit — also caused problems.
lead_paragraph: The ad begins in a sunny kitchen. A woman in a dark blue top and a simple gold necklace pours herself a cup of coffee and speaks directly to the camera, a Bible on the table in front of her.

headline: 65 Doctors, Nurses and Paramedics: What We Saw in Gaza
abstract: “Nearly every day I was there, I saw a new young child who had been shot in the head or the chest, virtually all of whom went on to die.”
lead_paragraph: “Nearly every day I was there, I saw a new young child who had been shot in the head or the chest, virtually all of whom went on to die.”

headline: Should Famous People Be Telling Us This Much About Their Illnesses?
abstract: For some celebrities, revealing all is part of the product. For others, it looks like a deeply unpleasant chore.
lead_paragraph: This past summer, Celine Dion manufactured a breathtaking cultural moment. It was at the opening ceremony of the Paris Olympics, just after a long, daffy and highly maximalist buildup to the lighting of the Olympic cauldron. Suddenly, there she was, standing on a terrace of the twinkling Eiffel Tower in a scintillant Dior gown. As she sang, a swell of both applause and what sounded like a collective moan of pleasure rose from the audience. Celine Dion was alive and singing. And if you didn’t cry, it could only be because you didn’t know.

headline: How a ‘National Family Secret in France’ Inspired Her Novel
abstract: Cécile Desprairies’s novel, ‘The Propagandist,’ was also inspired by her mother, who made art and slogans for Vichy France and its Nazi leaders.
lead_paragraph: Cécile Desprairies’s novel, “The Propagandist,” is full of so many secrets that it’s a wonder she managed to write it at all.

headline: Mayor Adams’s Damage to New York Began With the Police
abstract: There are strong parallels between police misconduct and the indictments at City Hall.
lead_paragraph: As a stunned New York City comes to terms with the indictment of Mayor Eric Adams, it’s worth examining the idea, deeply embedded in the city’s psyche, that helped lead to his election: Keeping the city safe means allowing the Police Department to do whatever it wishes.

headline: What Good Is Great Literature?
abstract: As the Nobel Committee gets ready to admit a new writer into the pantheon, our critic asks: Is greatness overrated?
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the Swedish Academy will award the Nobel Prize in Literature, the pre-eminent — perhaps only — global arbiter of literary greatness.

headline: Court to Weigh Protections for Immigrants Brought to U.S. as Children
abstract: A federal appeals court will consider the future of DACA, which has allowed hundreds of thousands of undocumented young people to live and work in the United States.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court will hear arguments this week on the fate of hundreds of thousands of undocumented immigrants who arrived in the United States as minors and have been shielded from deportation and allowed to work legally.

headline: They Flew 7,000 Miles to Fight Haiti’s Gangs. The Gangs Are on Top.
abstract: Hundreds of Kenyan police officers are in Port-au-Prince, trying to take the capital back from gangs, but financing and personnel shortages have hampered the effort.
lead_paragraph: If the burned-out cars, bullet-riddled schools, demolished buildings and desolate streets in downtown Port-au-Prince weren’t enough evidence of the terrible things that happened here, someone left an even more ominous hint: skulls in the middle of the street.

headline: Inside the Battle for America’s Most Consequential Battleground State
abstract: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump are pouring more money, time and energy into Pennsylvania than anywhere else, waging an ad war as they crisscross the state.
lead_paragraph: When Vice President Kamala Harris rolled out her economic agenda, she went to Pittsburgh. When she unveiled her running mate, she went to Philadelphia. And when she had to pick a place for Barack Obama’s first fall rally this Thursday, it was back to Pittsburgh.

headline: $900,000 Homes in Pennsylvania, New York and Connecticut
abstract: A four-bedroom stone house in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., a 19th-century farmhouse in Germantown, N.Y., and am 18th-century Colonial in Essex, Conn.
lead_paragraph: This four-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath house is in the College Park section of Bala Cynwyd, a community in Lower Merion Township, around 20 minutes by car or 40 minutes by public transit from central Philadelphia. The local elementary and middle school are both a half-mile away, and Lower Merion High School is a 10-minute drive. The nearest SEPTA station is less a mile away.

headline: ‘La Haine’ Is Back (With Singing and Dancing This Time)
abstract: Mathieu Kassovitz has turned his cult 1995 movie into a stage musical. The France it represents is different — though much hasn’t changed.
lead_paragraph: Watching the musical “La Haine” is a bit like looking at a beloved’s face under water: It’s familiar, but distorted.

headline: ‘Nobody Wants This’ Knows What You Do Want
abstract: The Netflix rom-com checks every genre box, but it became a megahit by offering versions of everything you already like on TV.
lead_paragraph: Two leads with nostalgia power. A meet cute. A series of fish-out-of-water mishaps, some of which rely on an almost alarming level of ignorance or ineptitude. A party that goes awry — probably from too much stress. (Probably a wealthy, maybe even icy woman has caused this stress.) Her: Frazzled, into her phone. Him: Safe, sensitive, sage.

headline: Can Your Electric Vehicle Catch Fire During a Hurricane?
abstract: E.V. batteries that are submerged in saltwater can catch fire after the floods subside, but experts say it’s a rarity.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Florida warned residents to move their electric vehicles away from potential flood zones ahead of Hurricane Milton to avoid the risk that the cars could burst into flames after being submerged in saltwater for extended periods.

headline: Why Milton and Helene ‘Exploded’ in Strength
abstract: How did Hurricane Milton, and Hurricane Helene before it, get so strong, so fast? Raymond Zhong, a reporter focusing on climate and environmental issues for The New York Times, explains.
lead_paragraph: How did Hurricane Milton, and Hurricane Helene before it, get so strong, so fast? Raymond Zhong, a reporter focusing on climate and environmental issues for The New York Times, explains.

headline: Oh, the Horror: 8 Comics for Halloween
abstract: Otherworldly creatures, apocalyptic environments, serial killers, zombies and more haunt these suspenseful comic books and graphic novels.
lead_paragraph: For Halloween season, here is a selection of new spooky tales that include end-of-the-world scenarios, evil puppets and an ax-wielding Santa Claus.

headline: How Harris and Trump Are Battling for Pennsylvania
abstract: Pennsylvania is widely seen to be the tipping-point state of the 2024 election. Shane Goldmacher, a national political correspondent for The New York Times, explains what Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump are doing to win over voters there.
lead_paragraph: Pennsylvania is widely seen to be the tipping-point state of the 2024 election. Shane Goldmacher, a national political correspondent for The New York Times, explains what Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump are doing to win over voters there.

headline: Trump Holds Up Transition Process, Skirting Ethics and Fund-Raising Rules
abstract: Donald J. Trump has so far opted out of the official planning for a government handover, a move that allows him to avoid disclosing his donors to his transition effort.
lead_paragraph: Less than a month before Election Day, Donald J. Trump’s campaign has not yet participated in the government’s official presidential transition process, a significant break from past practice that could threaten the seamless transfer of power should the Republican nominee win election.

headline: Trump Has Something He’d Like to Sell You
abstract: The former president’s history of merchandising himself may be broadly revealing in unexpected ways.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has created a new category of politician, the presidential huckster in chief, treating major events — from an assassination attempt to criminal indictments — as opportunities to market everything from $59.99 “God Bless the USA” Bibles to swatches of the suit he wore when he was arrested in Georgia in 2023 (for a little over $4,600) to “truly special” diamond-encrusted Trump watches that can go for as much as $100,000.

headline: Hurricane Milton Is Terrifying, and It Is Just the Start
abstract: We need to be honest about what has become the most expensive and deadliest kind of natural disaster in the United States.
lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Milton roars toward Florida’s west coast with winds that spiked to a staggering 180 miles per hour, we are witnessing a new reality. Supercharged hurricanes are no longer outliers, freak disasters or storms of the century. Fossil fuel pollution has made them a fixture of life around the world, and they are going to get worse — with millions of people in their cross hairs.

headline: Jack Smith Owes Us an Explanation
abstract: The Justice Department should not have allowed revelations about the Trump Jan. 6 case to be disclosed so close to Election Day.
lead_paragraph: Last week a judge unsealed a 165-page redacted legal brief with damaging revelations about Donald Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 presidential election.

headline: 152 Years Ago, This Woman Ran for President
abstract: An opera looks at Victoria Woodhull, whose story centered on politics, sex and scandal.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll find out who’s singing about a presidential campaign with a woman at the top of the ticket. We’ll also get details on the latest resignation at City Hall.

headline: Months Before Ethiopian Crash, Boeing Turned Aside Carrier’s Questions
abstract: Ethiopian Airlines appeared to foresee the deadly confusion its pilots would face if flawed software in the Boeing 737 Max failed. Boeing chose not to provide the guidance that the carrier was seeking.
lead_paragraph: In late 2018, Ethiopian Airlines’ chief pilot sent an urgent message to Boeing, the manufacturer of the 737 Max airliner.

headline: The ‘Goth’ Volleyball Player Was Actually Toning Things Down
abstract: “I just wanted to look as much like myself as I could,” Nora Hayd said of the team headshot that made her an online sensation.
lead_paragraph: Nora Hayd’s eyeliner traced a dramatic path from her tear ducts to her eyebrow piercings. Her bangs were dyed hot pink, and a septum ring dangled from her nose.

headline: What Do Celebrities Owe Their Fans?
abstract: Many stars have long accepted fan misbehavior, intense pressure and intrusions into their personal lives as the price of fame. Should they?
lead_paragraph: Whether it is athletes, singers or movie stars, what celebrities are you a fan of?

headline: Can You Turn Off Big Tech’s A.I. Tools? Sometimes, and Here’s How.
abstract: Google, Microsoft and Meta are shoving A.I. chatbots into our faces. Sometimes, there’s a way out.
lead_paragraph: Big tech brands like Google, Apple, Microsoft and Meta have all unleashed tech that they describe as artificial intelligence. Soon, the companies say, we’ll all be using A.I. to write emails, generate images and summarize articles.

headline: From ‘S.N.L.’ to TikTok, George Washington Is Funny Now
abstract: The first president is not usually associated with comedy. As a recurring character on “Saturday Night Live” and a trend on TikTok, that may be changing.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Hamilton, Aaron Burr and Thomas Jefferson were the focus of “Hamilton.” John Adams had his own HBO mini-series, and Samuel Adams is a beer. Ben Franklin often appears experimenting with his kite when characters travel back in time to Colonial America.

headline: Iranian Official Heads to Saudi Arabia as Israel Postpones U.S. Meeting
abstract: The Biden administration is dealing with complex dynamics in the Middle East as it tries to keep conflicts involving Israel from escalating further.
lead_paragraph: As the Middle East remains on edge in anticipation of a possible retaliatory attack by Israel on Iran, the Iranian foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, arrived in Saudi Arabia on Wednesday as part of a diplomatic tour aimed at shoring up relations with Iran’s Arab neighbors.

headline: Nobel Prize in Chemistry Goes to 3 Scientists for Predicting and Creating Proteins
abstract: The Nobel, awarded to David Baker of the University of Washington and Demis Hassabis and John M. Jumper of Google DeepMind, is the second this week to involve artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded on Wednesday to three scientists for discoveries that show the potential of advanced technology, including artificial intelligence, to predict the shape of proteins, life’s chemical tools, and to invent new ones.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 487
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Oct. 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,209
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Oct. 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Floridians Rush to Evacuate, and Harris Outlines Home Health Care Plan
abstract: Plus, Brazil unblocks X after Elon Musk backs down.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The Parents Aren’t All Right
abstract: Parents report being more stressed than other adults, and the U.S. surgeon general now considers raising a family a health risk.
lead_paragraph: For years, research on hyper-attentive parenting has focused on all the ways that it can hurt children.

headline: Inside Donald Trump’s Rallies
abstract: We explain the nine main things that happen at each rally.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s rallies — freewheeling performances full of jokes and audience participation that his fans sometimes travel hours to attend — are a central part of his 2024 presidential campaign. He holds almost two per week, and they are where he often introduces and tests the themes that end up dominating his campaign.

headline: ‘Daytime Revolution’ Review: Coffee and Counterculture
abstract: John Lennon and Yoko Ono invade middle-American living rooms in this cute but shallow documentary.
lead_paragraph: For one largely forgotten week in 1972, John Lennon and Yoko Ono transformed the most popular show on daytime television into a forum for ideas that its unsuspecting audience rarely encountered. Joining as the co-hosts of “The Mike Douglas Show,” they repurposed entertainment as a Trojan horse for activist agendas (antiwar, pro-civil rights), briefly bridging the yawning chasm between mainstream America and a counterculture that the Nixon Administration was actively engaged in repressing.

headline: Meeting of Western Leaders on Ukraine Is Postponed, a Setback for Kyiv
abstract: A top-level gathering in Germany intended to show support for Ukraine was put off after President Biden canceled his trip to deal with Hurricane Milton.
lead_paragraph: A meeting of Western leaders who support Ukraine’s war effort against Russia has been postponed after President Biden canceled his participation to deal with the impact of Hurricane Milton.

headline: New Images Show Lebanese Border Villages Flattened in Israeli Invasion
abstract: Satellite images and videos offer an early glimpse of the devastation in southern Lebanon a week after Israeli ground troops moved in to confront Hezbollah militants.
lead_paragraph: Satellite images and videos offer an early glimpse of the devastation in southern Lebanon a week after Israeli ground troops moved in to confront Hezbollah militants.

headline: Why Breaking Up Google Would Be Hard to Do
abstract: The Justice Department could push for the tech giant to sell off a business to end its lock on online search. But a move would be tough to pull off.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has laid out potential remedies to stop Google from illegally monopolizing the online search business, and they include a nuclear option: breaking off parts of the tech giant.

headline: Flooding Ravages Thai District Known for Elephant Parks
abstract: Two people have died following the intense rains that inundated the city of Chiang Mai and surrounding areas that are popular with tourists.
lead_paragraph: Apple stuck her trunk out of the swollen river like a snorkel, paddling desperately to stay afloat. But the two ton, 15-year-old elephant was no match for the flooding that inundated Chiang Mai, Thailand’s second-largest city, last week. By the time a team of rescuers saw her, she had been swept more than a mile downriver.

headline: My Grandmother Paid for My Sister’s I.V.F. I Feel Ripped Off!
abstract: A reader is miffed to learn that $13,000 was earmarked in her grandmother’s will for a younger sister’s fertility treatments. Should the sister reimburse her siblings?
lead_paragraph: In her will, my grandmother divided her estate equally among my mother and her four adult grandchildren. But there was a separate bequest of $13,000 to my mother — before the calculation of anyone else’s share — to help my younger sister with her I.V.F. treatments. This means that most of us are about $3,000 worse off because of this bequest that none of us knew about. Is it reasonable to expect my sister to reimburse us for this sweetheart deal that we were not a part of? When I asked my mother and sister gently for an explanation, I got the runaround and felt that I was attacked for being confrontational. They think I should be more sensitive to my sister’s fertility issues. But I can’t help feeling ripped off!

headline: The Education Crisis Neither Candidate Will Address
abstract: Covid learning loss and chronic absenteeism aren’t going to fix themselves
lead_paragraph: It has been four and a half years since public schools across the country closed their doors to in-person learning. There is evidence that this generation of K-12 students has not fully recovered academically — and may never do so.

headline: Jonathan Groff, Fresh Off Tony Win, Will Return to Broadway as Bobby Darin
abstract: “Just in Time,” a new musical about the “Mack the Knife” pop singer, will open next spring at Circle in the Square in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Groff, who won his first Tony Award in June for starring in a hit revival of “Merrily We Roll Along,” will return to Broadway next spring to play Bobby Darin in a biomusical he has been developing for years.

headline: Corrections: Oct. 9, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Oct. 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about a new court filing by the special counsel Jack Smith misstated an element of the relationship between Eric Herschmann, a White House lawyer during the Trump administration, and Jared Kushner, former President Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law. Mr. Herschmann had known Mr. Kushner since Mr. Kushner was a child. The two were not childhood friends.

headline: Five People Die in Plane Crash on Catalina Island, Near Los Angeles
abstract: The wreckage of a twin-engine plane was found Tuesday night after the authorities received an emergency notification and GPS coordinates from a cellphone.
lead_paragraph: Five people were killed after a small plane crashed on Catalina Island, just off the coast of Los Angeles, on Tuesday night, the authorities said.

headline: Lily Ebert, Holocaust Survivor, Author and TikTok Star, Dies at 100
abstract: She survived Auschwitz, wrote a best-selling memoir, “Lily’s Promise,” and spoke to a following of 2 million fans on TikTok.
lead_paragraph: In July 1944, when Lily Ebert was 20 years old, she and most of her family were packed onto a train and sent to the Auschwitz concentration camp, where on arrival she watched as her mother and two of her siblings were led to a gas chamber. She would never see them again.

headline: Can a Start-Up Help Authors Get Paid by A.I. Companies?
abstract: Created by Humans, a company that aims to help writers license their works for use by A.I. companies, has struck a partnership with the Authors Guild.
lead_paragraph: The Authors Guild, the largest and oldest professional organization for writers in the United States, is teaming with a new start-up, Created by Humans, to help writers license rights to their books to artificial intelligence companies.

headline: A Gaza Family Separated by a Few Miles, and the War
