In addition to pieces that are completely see-through, a handful of the designs are rendered in black, as well as a smoky hue that changes in different lights. “It almost has a turquoise tint to it, which feels right to me because of the Mediterranean vibe,” says Jacobs, who splits her time between New York and Majorca. As with her porcelain pieces, Jacobs’s glass creations require a bit of mindfulness when worn, but she insists that they’re made for everyday use. “I wear them on the subway. I wear them biking. I wear them when I’m in Spain. When I go to the sea, I take them off and put them on a rock; I come back, they’re fine,” she says. From $190, arc-objects.com.

headline: Why Democratic Senate Control Seems to Be Slipping Away
abstract: A Times/Siena poll shows Jon Tester behind by seven points in Montana, while Colin Allred trails Ted Cruz by four in Texas.
lead_paragraph: The math for Senate control is pretty simple. For Democrats, it isn’t adding up.

headline: Supreme Court Reform Is in the Air
abstract: Say no to court packing — and yes to term limits.
lead_paragraph: This year, two prominent Democrats released two different plans for Supreme Court reform. One came from President Biden and is worth serious thought. The other, which came from Senator Ron Wyden (and a number of other Democratic legislators), would escalate the nation’s judicial wars and perhaps even harm our nation’s constitutional order. Biden is right to propose term limits for Supreme Court justices; Wyden is wrong to propose adding justices to the Supreme Court.

headline: Watch: ‘How Tennessee Keeps Nearly Half a Million People From Voting’
abstract: Should former felons have their right to vote restored?
lead_paragraph: “How Tennessee Keeps Nearly Half a Million People From Voting” is a five-minute Opinion video that explores how the state has become a national leader in voter disenfranchisement. Today, about 9 percent of Tennessee’s voting-age population is prohibited from voting because of felony convictions, with an astonishing 21 percent of Black adults barred from voting — the highest rate in the country. Among them is Sarah Bynum, profiled here, a community advocate convicted of a felony 30 years ago who has struggled to restore her voting rights. “Makes me feel like they are saying I’m not a citizen. You’re just here, like I’m a foreigner in my own country,” she laments in the video.

headline: Rubble, and Defiance
abstract: Once lively and densely packed, the area on the edges of Beirut that was hit by an Israeli strike is now vacant.
lead_paragraph: The Dahiya, a collection of neighborhoods on the southern outskirts of Beirut, Lebanon’s capital, was in ruins, smoke still rising from the rubble of destroyed buildings.

headline: Crane Collapses in Downtown St. Petersburg as Milton Batters Florida
abstract: City officials said the crane had collapsed onto a neighboring building, which houses the Tampa Bay Times newspaper offices.
lead_paragraph: A crane on a luxury building under construction in downtown St. Petersburg, Fla., fell onto a neighboring building late Wednesday as Hurricane Milton barreled across the state, causing sweeping damage and flooding.

headline: Consumer Price Increases Cooled, but Not as Much as Expected
abstract: The Consumer Price Index is moderating, but September’s report contained both good and bad news for policymakers.
lead_paragraph: Price increases slowed in September, but the cool-down was less than economists had expected, in the latest reminder that bringing inflation back under control remained a somewhat bumpy process.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,210
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Oct. 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 488
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Oct. 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: 25 Days To Go: ‘The Daily’ Politics Round Table
abstract: In the final sprint before Election Day, which voters matter most to the Harris and Trump campaigns? The Times journalists Michael Barbaro, Nate Cohn, Maggie Haberman and Astead Herndon discuss the latest in the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: In the final sprint before Election Day, which voters matter most to the Harris and Trump campaigns? The Times journalists Michael Barbaro, Nate Cohn, Maggie Haberman and Astead Herndon discuss the latest in the presidential race.

headline: Milton’s Path of Destruction, and a First Biden-Netanyahu Call in Months
abstract: Plus, the Kenyan police battle gangs in Haiti.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: 25 Days to Go
abstract: In the final sprint to Election Day, which voters matter most to the Harris and Trump campaigns? Watch or listen to our political round table.
lead_paragraph: In the campaign for president, this was the week when back-to-back natural disasters became an inescapable part of the race, when Vice-President Kamala Harris chose to meet the press and when Donald J. Trump faced new accusations of cozying up to Russia’s president.

headline: For Undecided Voters, What Will It Come Down To?
abstract: With Election Day less than a month away, the Times journalists Michael Barbaro, Nate Cohn, Maggie Haberman and Astead Herndon discuss some of the most pressing issues for undecided voters.
lead_paragraph: With Election Day less than a month away, the Times journalists Michael Barbaro, Nate Cohn, Maggie Haberman and Astead Herndon discuss some of the most pressing issues for undecided voters.

headline: Airstrikes in Beirut Kill at Least 22 and Level a Building, Lebanese Officials Say
abstract: Israel was behind the attack, Lebanon said, and it came on the same day that the U.N. said Israeli forces had fired on its peacekeepers, an episode that drew international condemnation.
lead_paragraph: Israeli airstrikes hit two buildings in a densely populated area of central Beirut on Thursday, Lebanon said, in what appeared to be the deadliest attack in the Lebanese capital in more than a year of fighting between Israel and Hezbollah.

headline: Hurricane Milton’s Destruction
abstract: We cover the latest on the storm.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Milton is tearing across Florida. It has flooded the state from coast to coast and knocked out power for more than three million homes and businesses. It spewed tornadoes that killed people far from the storm’s eye, destroyed homes and shredded the roof of the Tampa Bay Rays’ stadium. See a map of the storm’s path.

headline: More Than 3 Million Are Without Power in Florida
abstract: Downed power lines and scattered debris from Hurricane Milton caused widespread power outages that may prove difficult for utility companies to repair.
lead_paragraph: More than 3.2 million customers in Florida were without power early Thursday because of Hurricane Milton, according to poweroutage.us, which tracks data from utility companies.

headline: ‘Terrifier 3’ Review: Still Clowning Around
abstract: The deaths remain grisly, but the pacing uneven in this new installment in Damien Leone’s horror franchise.
lead_paragraph: Nobody is pushing horror boundaries quite like the writer-director Damien Leone. Eight years ago, his killer clown film “Terrifier” had gorehounds buzzing. Its 2022 sequel unexpectedly broke into the mainstream and to date has earned over $15 million, a huge haul for a blood-drenched exploitation slasher.

headline: ‘Mad About the Boy: The Noël Coward Story’ Review: In Blithe Spirits
abstract: A brisk documentary by Barnaby Thompson counters that the tuxedo-wearing playwright hid his insecurities under a platinum-plated veneer.
lead_paragraph: When Ian Fleming asked him to play the villainous Dr. No in the first 007 movie, Noël Coward, one of the defining theatrical talents of the 20th century, fired off this telegram: “No, no, no, a thousand times no!”

headline: Let’s Discuss: ‘Don’t Call It an “Ethnic” Grocery Store’
abstract: How can food feel like home? Read the article and post your comments and questions for our journalist Priya Krishna by Oct. 17.
lead_paragraph: Are there foods that feel like home to you? Perhaps a special dish your grandmother makes, a spice or flavor that reminds you of where your family is from, or a snack that brings you back to childhood?

headline: Han Kang Is Awarded Nobel Prize in Literature
abstract: The South Korean author, best known for “The Vegetarian,” is the first writer from her country to receive the prestigious award.
lead_paragraph: Han Kang, the South Korean author best known for her surreal, subversive novel “The Vegetarian,” was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature on Thursday — the first writer from her country to receive the award.

headline: Hurricane Milton and the Economy
abstract: The superstorm is expected to inflict costly and lasting damage in Florida, as the Federal Reserve is already keeping an eye on upcoming inflation data.
lead_paragraph: The economy and the stock market have been defying the low-growth doomers for more than a year. Mother Nature is now testing that record.

headline: With 100-Foot-Wide Trump Sign, a Sticker Company Dives Into Politics
abstract: The chief executive of Sticker Mule in Amsterdam, N.Y., set off a debate by displaying his support for Donald J. Trump in a massive sign atop the company’s headquarters.
lead_paragraph: Sticker Mule, a printing company known for novelty T-shirts and coasters, was not, until recently, a political animal.

headline: Social Security Benefits to Climb 2.5% in 2025
abstract: The annual cost-of-living adjustment will increase monthly checks for millions of beneficiaries, including retirees and disabled workers.
lead_paragraph: Tens of millions of Americans receiving Social Security benefits are poised to see a 2.5 percent increase in their monthly checks next year to keep pace with inflation, the Social Security Administration said on Thursday, an uptick that’s on a par with average annual increases in recent decades.

headline: She’s Only Playing a Therapist, but the Revelations Are Real
abstract: The designer Bella Freud — a great-granddaughter of Sigmund Freud — is using her podcast to “learn vicariously all the things I’ve secretly wanted to know” about celebrities.
lead_paragraph: “I haven’t read much of anything,” Bella Freud said when discussing the books written by her great-grandfather Sigmund Freud. “I’ve read the comic books.”

headline: Global Trade Grows but Remains Vulnerable to War and Geopolitics
abstract: New reports from the World Trade Organization and a Washington think tank showed how robust global trade could quickly be derailed by violence.
lead_paragraph: The global system of container ships and tankers that move tens of billions of dollars of products around the world each day mostly functions fluidly and without notice. But in a few parts of the world, shipping lanes shrink to narrow straits or canals, geographical choke points where an isolated disruption can threaten to throw much of international trade out of whack.

headline: One-Stop Shop, From Scary to Merry
abstract: Known for its pop-up stores — and its army of seasonal workers — Spirit Halloween will try its hand at a longer run and a bigger holiday.
lead_paragraph: For many fall enthusiasts, the season’s start is marked by the arrival of autumn leaves and apple picking. For others, it is marked by the emergence of the Borg-like retail empire that is Spirit Halloween, a Halloween goods purveyor that opens more than 1,500 locations across North America, only to shutter them in the days after Halloween.

headline: Corrections: Oct. 10, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Oct. 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about a new proposal for home health care that Kamala Harris outlined on “The View” misspelled, in on reference, the surname of a health policy professor at Harvard who studies long-term care. He is David Grabowski, not Grabowksi.

headline: Ukraine’s Parliament Approves Biggest Tax Increase of War to Support the Army
abstract: The authorities are resorting to a politically unpopular move as they scramble to raise funds for the grueling military effort against Russia.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian Parliament voted on Thursday to approve its biggest tax hike since Russia’s full-scale invasion began more than two years ago, resorting to a politically unpopular move to raise funds for its grueling war effort.

headline: As Deadline for Another Debate Passes, Trump Again Rejects a Rematch
abstract: CNN said the former president had until noon on Thursday to accept an invitation to an Oct. 23 showdown with Vice President Kamala Harris, who will do a town hall with the cable network instead.
lead_paragraph: The deadline CNN set for former President Donald J. Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris to agree to a second debate passed Thursday with no deal — making it all but certain that the candidates’ first debate in September would be their last.

headline: 4 New Novels Brimming With Historical Drama
abstract: In the hands of skilled novelists, the stories of an heiress, a prime minister and a literary mystery woman are brought to life.
lead_paragraph: There’s plenty of historical drama in Robert Harris’s latest novel, but the events that led Britain into the carnage of World War I serve mainly as a backdrop for the intimate maneuverings in PRECIPICE (Harper, 464 pp., $30). At its center is the actual clandestine liaison between the country’s 61-year-old prime minister, Herbert Asquith, and a 26-year-old aristocrat, Venetia Stanley, who became his sounding board and confidante as he faced mounting hostilities both within his government and throughout Europe.

headline: Here’s What It Was Like as Milton’s Eye Came Ashore
abstract: Our reporter’s account of a harrowing night in Sarasota, Fla. — far different from anything she has experienced as a native of New England.
lead_paragraph: Crickets chirped. Frogs croaked. Mosquitoes feasted on people who ventured outside to marvel at the clear sky and eerie calm.

headline: Elon Musk Shows Off Tesla ‘Robotaxi’ That Drives Itself
abstract: “You could fall asleep and wake up at your destination,” said Mr. Musk, Tesla’s C.E.O., but some experts are skeptical that such cars will be ferrying passengers soon.
lead_paragraph: After years of promises, Tesla on Thursday unveiled a car that Elon Musk, the company’s chief executive, said will be able to drive itself without human supervision. Mr. Musk has said the vehicle will add trillions of dollars to the company’s stock market value and fuel its growth.

headline: Israel’s Security Cabinet Met to Discuss Response to Iran Attack
abstract: The cabinet was expected to authorize initiating a retaliatory attack, officials said. They didn’t make their decision public.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s security cabinet convened on Thursday to discuss Israel’s response to an Iranian barrage of some 200 ballistic missiles that sent nearly the entire country into reinforced shelters last week, officials said.

headline: Bring on the Butternuts
abstract: Fall’s star squash shines in an adaptable pasta with kale and brown butter, roasted with an onion gravy or puréed into a soft velvety soup.
lead_paragraph: Remember how I said that I didn’t want summer to end, that I wasn’t ready for fall? Wow, do I ever take it back. As I write this, the fluorescent yellow leaves on the honey locust tree outside my window are fluttering in the breeze, chuckling and shaking their heads at me. Fall is great, and I was a dummy for thinking I could resist its bountiful produce.

headline: What, Exactly, Is ‘Moderate Drinking’?
abstract: That depends on whom you ask, and what country you live in. Here’s what the research suggests and how to think about it.
lead_paragraph: Over the past several years, there has been a rise in alcohol-related deaths and a steady wave of news about the health risks of drinking. Calls for people to drink only in moderation have become more urgent. But what, exactly, does that mean?

headline: Barbara Lynch, a Top Boston Chef, Will Close All Her Restaurants
abstract: She helped put her city on the modern culinary map, but many employees said they paid a price in workplace abuse.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Lynch, the celebrated chef who helped kick-start Boston’s modern fine-dining scene, announced Wednesday that her remaining restaurants were closing, ending a starry 30-year run that was shadowed in recent years by accusations of toxic working conditions in her kitchens.

headline: Residents of a Mobile Home Park Join Forces to Buy Their Community
abstract: The residents are the first in the state of Maine to successfully utilize a new law making it easier for them to compete with investors and gain ownership of the land their homes sit on.
lead_paragraph: Manufactured houses, widely known as mobile homes, are one of the most affordable options for homeownership in the United States, but they typically come with a big risk: You own the house; you don’t own the lot it sits on.

headline: Ethel Kennedy, Passionate Supporter of the Family Legacy, Dies at 96
abstract: She never remarried after the assassination of her husband, Senator Robert F. Kennedy, and she devoted herself to working on behalf of the causes he had championed.
lead_paragraph: Ethel Kennedy, the widow of Senator Robert F. Kennedy and a popular and vital force in the Kennedy political dynasty, died on Thursday. She was 96.

headline: Democrats Seize on Trump’s ‘You’re Rich as Hell’ Remarks to Donors
abstract: An ad from the main super PAC backing Kamala Harris casts Donald Trump as a tycoon who will give handouts to the rich, and the vice president as the candidate of working people.
lead_paragraph: Future Forward, the main super PAC backing Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign, is running this 30-second ad on television in states including Arizona and North Carolina this week at a cost of roughly $18 million, according to AdImpact.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Gen Alpha Slang
abstract: Is it low-key kinda bussin’ to use your teen’s slang? Or is it Ohio and cringe?
lead_paragraph: Maria writes: My 15-year-old daughter, Arina, would like an injunction against my use of Gen Alpha slang, such as “Ohio L rizz Skibidi toilet.” She says that hearing me use words like this is “physically painful.” But it makes me feel young and current.

headline: Review: A Fall Gala Where Women Led the Way
abstract: New York City Ballet dressed up its fall fashion gala with a program of female choreographers. This was history, even if the results were mixed.
lead_paragraph: The prospect of female choreographers sharing a New York City Ballet program has always been just that — a prospect divorced from reality. But on Wednesday night, dances by Gianna Reisen, Caili Quan and Tiler Peck made up the company’s first all-female repertory program.

headline: Review: Trust ‘Disclaimer’ When It Tells You Not to Trust It
abstract: The seven-part series from Alfonso Cuarón, about a familiar theme of the treachery of narratives, is easier to admire than to enjoy.
lead_paragraph: “Beware of narrative and form. Their power can bring us closer to the truth, but they can also be a weapon with a great power to manipulate.”

headline: Kamala Harris Puts Sarah Huckabee Sanders in Her Unhumble Place
abstract: Parents have no monopoly on modesty.
lead_paragraph: There’s a kind of holiday-season letter — I’m sure you’ve received one — that isn’t so much an update from the family who sent it as an advertisement for the brood’s glory.

headline: This Designer Turns ‘Trash’ Into Eccentric Bridal Looks
abstract: Timothy Westbrook, a former “Project Runway” contestant, who incorporates repurposed materials into his collection, wants to make wedding fashion more enjoyable and unique.
lead_paragraph: When the designer Timothy Westbrook was 3, he would dance and spin around the living room. His sister, then 6, recorded him one day, “And she’s like, ‘And there’s Timmy. The weird womanly thing,’” Mr. Westbrook recalled.

headline: What’s on the Menu? These Restaurants Aren’t Telling.
abstract: Some fine-dining establishments are sharing as few details as possible online in hopes that diners will let go and trust their chefs.
lead_paragraph: There are several bits of information you might wish to know before going to a restaurant. For example: When does it open? What can you eat there, and how much does it cost? These are just the sort of details that appear on a restaurant’s website, traditionally a digital repository of facts about your prospective meal.

headline: After a Harrowing Night, Clearwater, Fla., Faces Severe Flooding
abstract: Residents of one apartment building described fleeing a second-floor unit as water rose around them. After the storm, they are worried about those who lived below them.
lead_paragraph: Andreína Zapiaín and her family watched with growing desperation Wednesday night as the floodwaters rose outside their apartment complex in Clearwater, Fla. Hurricane Milton’s winds howled, whipping a palm tree against the wall of their second-floor unit.

headline: London Hosts Its Frieze Week in the Shadow of Paris
abstract: Plenty of business was done on the first day of the London fair, but much of the chatter was about the upcoming presentations at Art Basel Paris.
lead_paragraph: The geopolitics of the art world are shifting.

headline: ‘The Apprentice’ Review: An Origin Story for Donald J. Trump
abstract: In this ribald fictional telling of a young Trump’s rise, the man responsible is the lawyer Roy Cohn, played to sleazy perfection by Jeremy Strong.
lead_paragraph: Midway through “The Apprentice,” a gleefully vulgar fictional dramatization of the loves and deals of the young Donald J. Trump, the movie’s look changes. From the start, the images have had the grainy quality that you sometimes see in films from the 1970s, which is when the movie opens. Then suddenly, while Donald — a terrific Sebastian Stan — is giving a TV interview in 1980, faint horizontal lines begin slicing across the image, evoking the flicker in analog video. It’s a sly nod at the future and a brand-new reality: A (television) star is born.

headline: A Crane Hit Their Building, but the Journalists Were Out Reporting
abstract: Reporters at The Tampa Bay Times are covering their second hurricane in a month.
lead_paragraph: By the time Hurricane Milton caused a construction crane to crash onto the building that houses The Tampa Bay Times late on Wednesday, the newsroom’s journalists had already evacuated, fanning out across the region to cover the storm.

headline: How Back-to-Back Hurricanes Harm Mental Health
abstract: Research shows that experiencing repeated disasters makes people more vulnerable to mental health issues, and prolongs the time it takes to recover.
lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Milton battered Florida’s Gulf Coast on Thursday, Chloe Ottani followed the news with horror from her parents’ Connecticut home. She had just evacuated her apartment at the University of Tampa for the second time in two weeks.

headline: Chile Crisp Everything
abstract: Go ahead and buy the big jar for carrot risotto with chile crisp, one-pot tofu and broccoli rice and chile-oil noodles with cilantro.
lead_paragraph: Hello there! Mia here, the newsletter editor for New York Times Cooking, filling in for Tanya this week. You saw her excellent guide to the best takeaway at small New York City grocery stores, right? If not, take some time with that and I’ll meet you back here.

headline: Woman Calls 911 When 100 Aggressive Raccoons Show Up in Her Yard
abstract: The Washington State resident fed some friendly critters for years. Then, their mean friends turned up.
lead_paragraph: For more than 35 years, a woman in Washington State would leave some food in her yard for about a dozen resident raccoons.

headline: TD Bank Pleads Guilty and Pays $3 Billion to Settle Money-Laundering Case
abstract: Authorities cited joking by bank employees about crimes: “‘You guys really need to shut this down LOL.’”
lead_paragraph: TD Bank agreed to pay about $3 billion in fines to U.S. authorities and pleaded guilty on Thursday to money-laundering-related charges in a case brought by federal prosecutors, who said the Canadian bank made it “convenient” for criminals to open accounts, transfer funds and even deposit seven-figure sums of cash at its branches.

headline: 7 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: The enduring image of John Lewis in the American imagination comes from March 7, 1965 — a day known as “Bloody Sunday” — when Lewis suffered a fractured skull at the hands of police after leading a voting rights march on the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Ala. But as David Greenberg suggests in his substantial new biography of the civil rights leader and congressman, Lewis deserves to be recognized equally for the courage and determination he showed for decades as a member of the Washington establishment, a lesser-told tale that nevertheless constituted the bulk of Lewis’s impressive career. Maybe add Greenberg’s biography to your reading list this week?

headline: Garvey’s M.L.B. Teams Are Contenders. His Senate Campaign? Not So Much.
abstract: As his old teams — the Los Angeles Dodgers and the San Diego Padres — battle in the playoffs, the onetime all-star Steve Garvey finds himself an underdog in his Senate race against Adam Schiff.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Dodgers and the San Diego Padres are headed to a playoff elimination game on Friday, the latest chapter in what has become a fierce rivalry in Southern California.

headline: Florida IV Fluid Plant Spared From Storm, Company Says
abstract: Milton threatened a Daytona Beach site that produces one-fourth of the nation’s IV medical solutions, which were already in short supply because of storm damage in North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: The Daytona Beach plant that makes nearly a quarter of the IV fluids used in the United States is intact in the wake of Hurricane Milton’s tear across Florida, according to a company spokeswoman.

headline: Reasons to Vote for Harris, Not Trump
abstract: Readers respond to an editorial and critiques of the former president by those who have worked with him. Also: young voter outreach; L.G.B.T.Q. Jews; the war in Gaza; Robert Moses.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Separated’ Review: Interrogating a Policy
abstract: The latest documentary from Errol Morris looks at the Trump administration’s practice of taking children from their parents at the southern border.
lead_paragraph: When the great documentarian Errol Morris (“The Thin Blue Line”) has taken on overtly political subjects, he has rarely approached them from a position of express advocacy. His perspective tends to be more philosophical, even cosmic.

headline: September Was Deadly Month for Russian Troops in Ukraine, U.S. Says
abstract: More than 600,000 Russian troops have been killed or wounded since the war began in 2022.
lead_paragraph: September was the bloodiest month of the war for Russian forces in Ukraine, U.S. officials said, with the costly offensive in the east bringing the number of Russia’s dead and wounded to more than 600,000 troops since the war started.

headline: Who Are the U.N. Peacekeepers at Lebanon’s Border With Israel?
abstract: Established to maintain peace in southern Lebanon, the UNIFIL forces have been increasingly caught in the middle of the Israeli-Hezbollah war.
lead_paragraph: A U.N. peacekeeping mission operating along Lebanon’s border has come under Israeli fire several times over the past week, as Israeli soldiers move into Lebanon to clear Hezbollah militants from the region.

headline: ‘The Confidante’ Is a Layered French Drama About a Heartbreaking Scam
abstract: Streaming on Max, the series tells the story of woman who lies to a grief support group about her connection to the Paris terrorist attacks of 2015.
lead_paragraph: The four-part French mini-series “The Confidante,” beginning Friday, on Max (in French, with subtitles), is based loosely on a true story and follows a woman named Chris (Laure Calamy), who claims falsely that her best friend was a victim of the 2015 terrorist attacks in Paris. Chris ingratiates herself into a survivors’ support network, providing real time and energy but also catfishing other members and committing fraud. She posts constantly on Facebook, offering herself as a shoulder to cry on, fielding texts, chats and calls from bereaved, traumatized — legitimate — victims.

headline: What Students Are Saying About the Demands of High School
abstract: We asked teenagers if they were overscheduled, and how it would feel if they were able to slow down and do less.
lead_paragraph: “We have pushed high school students into maximizing every part of their days and nights,” Tim Donahue, a high school English teacher, writes in the guest essay “High Schoolers Need to Do Less So That They Can Do Better.” “We need to let them slow down.”

headline: France Unveils Tough Austerity Budget to Mend Its Finances
abstract: The French government is seeking deep spending cuts and higher taxes in an effort to tame its ballooning debt and deficit.
lead_paragraph: The French government on Thursday sought to head off a rapidly growing financial crunch, unveiling plans to plug one of the worst deficit and debt burdens in Europe with an austerity program involving deep spending cuts and hefty one-off taxes that would fall mostly on the rich and big corporations.

headline: Will Climate Change Transform the Florida Dream?
abstract: Millions of Americans have moved to the Sunshine State over the last several decades, only to see Florida’s future collide with climate change.
lead_paragraph: In 1957, my grandparents moved from Provincetown, Mass., to Stuart, Fla., bringing with them my mother, who was 11 at the time, and her three brothers. For the next half-century, my family lived the Florida dream.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 21, 2024
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Sean Combs’s Sex Trafficking Trial Is Set for May 5
abstract: The music mogul, wearing tan jail clothes at a court hearing, waved and smiled at six of his children and his mother in the gallery.
lead_paragraph: Sean Combs, the embattled music mogul, is scheduled to stand trial next May in New York, a federal judge said at a hearing on Thursday.

headline: Tornadoes Kill 6 in a Retirement Community in Eastern Florida
abstract: The Spanish Lakes Country Club Village, a community of mobile homes near Fort Pierce, was devastated by tornadoes that touched down on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Six people were killed in a retirement community by tornadoes spawned by Hurricane Milton that tore through St. Lucie County, on Florida’s Atlantic Coast, officials said on Thursday.

headline: How to Help Victims of Hurricane Milton
abstract: Here’s how to connect with verified aid groups working in the areas affected by the storm.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Milton carved a path of destruction across Florida, leaving at least five people dead and millions without power, and damaging homes, cars and infrastructure.

headline: Claudia Conway Declares Her Independence
abstract: The scion and sometimes antagonist of two figures in Republican politics has re-emerged as an independent aiming to sway her fellow Gen-Z voters.
lead_paragraph: Claudia Conway’s phone was buzzing. She was about to walk into a bagel shop in Lower Manhattan when her younger sister called. It was a Tuesday in mid-September and Claudia, 19, had come from her college, where she is a sophomore majoring in political science. She said she had been registering fellow students to vote as part of this year’s National Voter Registration Day.

headline: Sabrina Carpenter Had Her Fellow Honorees Talking at Time100 Next
abstract: The singer stayed out of sight before performing at a party celebrating young actors, musicians, politicians, doctors and more.
lead_paragraph: “Are you going to be singing for us this evening?” a woman asked the actor Ashley Park as she entered the party.

headline: It’s Indoor Dining Season In New York City
abstract: These are the kind of restaurant spaces you won’t want to leave.
lead_paragraph: Hey, you! How was your summer? Did you spend a lot of time eating outside in picnic-tabled backyards and charming, bike-lane patios? I hope you got it out of your system, because now it’s time to say goodbye to all that. It’s fully, decidedly October now, and we’re about to hit crispy weather, wear Lenny Kravitz-style chunky scarves and transfer subways three times to avoid walking outside.

headline: Bizarre Falsehoods About Hurricanes Helene and Milton Disrupt Recovery Efforts
abstract: Experts warn that weather-related disinformation can rapidly escalate into real-world risks and distract from aid.
lead_paragraph: Wildly improbable conspiracy theories about Hurricanes Helene and Milton have spread largely unchecked on social media. The storms were engineered to clear the way for lithium mining. They were sent to help the Democrats in next month’s election. They were formed by weather-controlling lasers.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Oct. 23, 2024
abstract: Two powerful hurricanes recently spun up in the Gulf of Mexico.  How has ocean heat in the Gulf changed over time?
lead_paragraph: Both Hurricane Milton this month and Hurricane Helene last month rapidly intensified over the warm waters of the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Billy Shaw, a Singular Hall of Fame Lineman, Dies at 85
abstract: He was the only inductee to play his entire career in the American Football League, where he helped the Buffalo Bills win two championships in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Billy Shaw, an offensive guard for the Buffalo Bills who was known as a Southern gentleman off the field but a terror on it, and who became the only member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame to play his entire career in the American Football League, died on Friday in Toccoa, Ga. He was 85.

headline: Hurricane Milton: Images From Florida, Before and After the Storm
abstract: See some of the wind and flood damage from the second major storm to hit Florida in the last two weeks.
lead_paragraph: The extent of the damage caused by Hurricane Milton in Florida was just being revealed on Thursday morning. The storm brought ferocious winds and heavy rains across wide swaths of the state, tearing roofs off homes and flooding neighborhoods.

headline: Biden Again Criticizes Trump Over Hurricane Misinformation: ‘Get a Life, Man’
abstract: The White House is juggling the response to two devastating storms in the past two weeks while trying to rebut false information from the former president.
lead_paragraph: President Biden warned on Thursday that Florida was in for “a long haul” after Hurricane Milton, and for a second day in a row he singled out former President Donald J. Trump for spreading misinformation, telling him to “get a life, man.”

headline: Man Pleads Guilty to Hate Crime for Vandalizing Rutgers Islamic Center
abstract: Officials said the man caused thousands of dollars’ worth of damage to religious artifacts after breaking into the New Jersey university’s Center for Islamic Life in April.
lead_paragraph: A New Jersey man who was charged with breaking into an Islamic student center at Rutgers University earlier this year and vandalizing religious artifacts pleaded guilty to committing a federal hate crime, officials said on Thursday.

headline: Tim Johnson, Senator Who Came Back From an Aneurysm, Dies at 77
abstract: One of the last Democrats from the Great Plains to be elected to national office, he built his career on delivering benefits to his home state, South Dakota.
lead_paragraph: Tim Johnson, a Democratic senator from South Dakota who suffered a brain aneurysm in 2006, throwing his party’s narrow majority into question for months, then not only returned to work but also won a third term, died on Tuesday in Sioux Falls, S.D. He was 77.

headline: Is a $910 Fleece Actually Worth It?
abstract: Camping’s favorite material gets a luxury overhaul.
lead_paragraph: This month Jonah Weiner made a purchase that was a cry for help. Or at least a new financial adviser.

headline: The Forecast: 832 Degrees in Brazil? Weather App Glitch Sends Extreme Weather to New Heights
abstract: No, it will not actually reach 832 degrees in Brazil’s capital this weekend.
lead_paragraph: The forecasts called for 13,000-mile-per-hour winds in Chicago, 832-degree temperatures in Brazil, and slightly higher ones in Kenya.

headline: Hurricane Milton’s Impact: What We Know So Far
abstract: Flooding, wind damage and power outages affected much of Florida. At least 14 deaths have been linked to the storm.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Milton flooded neighborhoods, flattened homes and knocked out power to millions of customers when it plowed through Florida on Oct. 9 and 10. Its path of destruction was uneven, though, and in many areas, officials were working to make repairs.

headline: Airstrikes in Beirut Kill at Least 22 and Injure Over 100, Lebanon Says
abstract: The attack, for which Lebanese officials blamed Israel, appeared to be the deadliest in the Lebanese capital in more than a year of fighting between the Israeli military and Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: Israeli airstrikes in a densely populated area of central Beirut on Thursday killed at least 22 people and wounded at least 117 others, Lebanese officials said, in what appeared to be the deadliest attack in the Lebanese capital in more than a year of fighting between Israel and Hezbollah.

headline: Milton Was an Impressive Storm. Here Are 5 Things Our Meteorologist Noticed.
abstract: Last month’s Hurricane Helene will be widely remembered for the rainfall in the Appalachians and the surge along Florida’s west shore. Milton will stand out for other reasons.
lead_paragraph: After the tree limbs are chopped up, the debris is swept away and the water subsides, Milton, like Helene, will be a hurricane that people, especially meteorologists, will remember and refer to for years to come.

headline: Jupiter’s Great Red Spot Moves Like the Solar System’s Biggest Kickball
abstract: A sequence of images captured by NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope showed how much the giant storm changed shape as it traveled within the planet’s atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: The Great Red Spot of Jupiter is one of the solar system’s most astonishing marvels. An elliptical storm with inky swirls of burnt orange and dulled copper, it is longer than the Earth is wide, and its winds screech through the tops of the planet’s clouds at 400 miles per hour.

headline: Friday Briefing: Florida Hurricane Kills at Least 7
abstract: Plus, Han Kang receives the Nobel Prize in Literature.
lead_paragraph: Search-and-rescue efforts were underway in Florida yesterday after Hurricane Milton spawned powerful tornadoes and low-lying coastal neighborhoods were swallowed by flooding.

headline: Trump Says He Was ‘Man of the Year.’ His Source Says It Isn’t True.
abstract: Fact-checkers have found no evidence over the years that former President Donald J. Trump once received the honor in Michigan.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump expressed irritation on Thursday that anyone would challenge his claim that he had been declared “man of the year” in Michigan many years ago. During a speech in Detroit, he triumphantly pulled out a news story to prove that he was right.

headline: Frances Conley, Neurosurgeon Who Protested Sexism, Dies at 83
abstract: She was the rare woman in her field, and a tenured professor. But when a sexist colleague was promoted, she quit, forcing a reckoning in her profession.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Frances Conley made national headlines in 1991 when she resigned from her position at Stanford University School of Medicine, saying that sexism had made her job untenable.

headline: Candidates Square Off on Courts, Policy and Party in Maryland Senate Debate
abstract: Larry Hogan, the Republican former governor, and Angela Alsobrooks, the Democratic Prince George’s County executive, sparred over whether to expand the Supreme Court and overhaul the legislative filibuster.
lead_paragraph: They clashed on altering the Supreme Court and abolishing the filibuster. Each accused the other of lying or misrepresenting the facts. They even disagreed on which professional football team to support.

headline: ‘Relentless’ Israeli Attacks on Gaza Medical Workers Are War Crime, U.N. Panel Says
abstract: The report, which does not have the force of law, found that the Israeli military had engaged in deliberate assaults on hospitals and other health care providers.
lead_paragraph: United Nations investigators on Thursday accused Israel of engaging in “relentless and deliberate attacks” on health care facilities, medical workers and wounded civilians in the Gaza Strip and said the actions amounted to war crimes and extermination, a crime against humanity.

headline: Millions Are Without Power After Milton Tore Through Florida
abstract: Also, Republicans appear poised to win control of the Senate. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Milton carved an uneven path of destruction across Florida. It maintained hurricane-strength winds from its landfall on the Gulf Coast last night until its exit this morning into the Atlantic Ocean. Coastal neighborhoods were swallowed by storm surge, inland towns were flooded with rain and nearly three million homes and businesses — about a quarter of the state — remain without power.

headline: A Modern Love Essay Moved Andrew Garfield
abstract: “Learning to Measure Time in Love and Loss,” by Chris Huntington, caused the actor Andrew Garfield to reflect on a universal longing for life. Garfield’s most recent film, “We Live in Time,” is also about love and loss.
lead_paragraph: “Learning to Measure Time in Love and Loss,” by Chris Huntington, caused the actor Andrew Garfield to reflect on a universal longing for life. Garfield’s most recent film, “We Live in Time,” is also about love and loss.

headline: Billy Joel Is Selling the Mansion He First Saw While Dredging Oysters
abstract: The celebrated musician has decided to part with the house of his wildest childhood dreams.
lead_paragraph: A teenager, then known as William Martin Joel, lived in the working-class suburb of Hicksville — his family so limited that they didn’t own a TV. He took a tiring minimum wage job dredging oysters.

headline: Warren Wilson, Pioneering Los Angeles TV Reporter, Dies at 90
abstract: In addition to covering the 1992 riots and other historically significant events, he helped facilitate the surrenders of 22 fugitives.
lead_paragraph: Warren Wilson, who in 1969 became one of the first Black television journalists hired in Los Angeles, and who used the trust he accumulated in his work to help fugitives surrender safely to the police, died on Sept. 27 in Oxnard, Calif. He was 90.

headline: In a Rambling Speech, Trump Offers Gripes and Yet Another Tax Cut
abstract: Even before this latest proposal, aimed at promoting car sales, an analysis found that the former president’s economic agenda could add $15 trillion to the nation’s debt over a decade.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump was roughly an hour and a half into a nearly two-hour speech to the Detroit Economic Club on Thursday afternoon before he got to his main new policy proposal: a call to make car loan interest fully tax deductible.

headline: While Others Fled, These TikTokers Posted Through Hurricane Milton
abstract: Millions waited for streams of updates from TikTok users in Florida, who broadcast from their damaged homes and neighborhoods and shared their evacuation journeys.
lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Milton barreled toward western Florida this week, viewers watched coverage of trees uprooted and lying in roads; roofs flying from strong gusts of wind; and streets turned into rivers amid driving rain. Millions tuned in from around the world for the firsthand accounts of the residents who stayed.

headline: Tropicana Field, Already Obsolete, Now Needs a New Roof
abstract: The home of the Tampa Bay Rays, generally disdained by players, was built to take the elements out of baseball. The elements struck back.
lead_paragraph: Tropicana Field, with its antiseptic atmosphere, synthetic grass, sparse crowds and outfield catwalks that spawned quirky ground rules, has endured as the home of the Tampa Bay Rays for 25 seasons.

headline: Ethel Kennedy: A Life in Pictures
abstract: Her life took a tragic turn when her husband, Senator Robert F. Kennedy, was assassinated, but she continued to engage in social advocacy and was recognized for her devotion to her family and nation.
lead_paragraph: Ethel Kennedy, the widow of Senator Robert F. Kennedy who died on Thursday at 96, was known for displaying grace and resilience after her husband’s murder as well as for her engagement with his political ambitions and the Kennedy family’s legacy.

headline: ‘Lonely Planet’ Review: Leaving Home to Find Yourself
abstract: Laura Dern and Liam Hemsworth star in a muddled romance without much to say.
lead_paragraph: One of the odder trends in 2024 cinema has involved romances, some of them steamy, between middle-aged women and much younger men. Anne Hathaway starred in one, Léa Drucker in another, and Nicole Kidman in not one but two more. This plot is hardly new, either in concept — Hollywood history is riddled with older men romancing ingénues — or in this specifically gendered execution, with examples from “The Graduate” to “May December” in the canon.

headline: How Harris Can Finish Strong
abstract: Some tips from novelists and screenwriters on how to keep audiences’ attention.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris had a great first act. She established a buoyant tone for her 2024 presidential campaign and rode a wave of polling momentum. But now her campaign has stalled. Undecided voters in a Times Opinion focus group were recently asked to describe her efforts. They responded with phrases like: “honeymoon’s over,” “the paint is wearing off,” “uninspired,” “absent,” “scared to talk directly to the American people.” Researchers who have been surveying voter sentiment as the campaign progresses found that there’s been a decline in how voters think about Harris, while sentiment toward Donald Trump has rebounded slightly since the September debate.

headline: Tim Walz Takes His Folksiness on the Road, Trying Not to Say ‘Stupid Things’
abstract: On a swing through the Southwest, the Democratic vice-presidential candidate received a warm welcome — and had to clean up his remarks about the Electoral College.
lead_paragraph: Tim Walz had scarcely set foot in Nevada on Tuesday afternoon — the third of four states he was to visit that day and the beginning of a high-stakes campaign blitz in the American Southwest — when he found himself, once again, in trouble.

headline: Conservative States Seek to End Protections for Immigrant ‘Dreamers’
abstract: An appeals court is considering a challenge that could end DACA, which has allowed hundreds of thousands of young undocumented immigrants to live and work in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Through decades of debate over illegal immigration, one group has been singled out for special protection. For the past 12 years, undocumented immigrants who arrived as children and grew up in the United States have enjoyed the ability to build careers and raise their own families without fear of deportation, thanks to the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, also known as DACA.

headline: Judge Approves Limited Further Release of Evidence in Trump Election Case
abstract: An appendix to a high-profile prosecutorial brief, released last week, could become public next week. But much of it would be redacted.
lead_paragraph: The federal judge overseeing the 2020 election case against former President Donald J. Trump on Thursday approved a limited release of a compilation of evidence against him, but stayed her order for a week in case Mr. Trump’s legal team wants to challenge the disclosure.

headline: 12 People Rescued at Gold Mine in Colorado After 1 Killed in Accident
abstract: An equipment failure at the Mollie Kathleen Gold Mine near Cripple Creek had stranded 12 people who were on a tour underground for hours.
lead_paragraph: Twelve people who had been trapped 1,000 feet below ground for hours were rescued at a historic gold mine in Colorado on Thursday evening after an equipment malfunction during a tour left one person dead, the authorities said.

headline: In the Middle (Class) of It All
abstract: Voters in Wisconsin are weighing which candidate better understands their economic anxieties.
lead_paragraph: It was a resplendent autumn morning in central Wisconsin this week, and I was doing what I do best: hanging out at a farmers’ market, admiring a $6 bunch of dahlias, and talking to strangers about the election.

headline: A Stern Obama Tells Black Men to Drop ‘Excuses’ and Support Harris
abstract: Before speaking at a rally for Vice President Kamala Harris in Pittsburgh, the former president spoke directly to Black male voters in an effort to bolster flagging support.
lead_paragraph: Former President Barack Obama traveled to Pittsburgh on Thursday to urge voters there to choose Vice President Kamala Harris in November, aiming a message at one group in particular: Black men.

headline: Dire Hurricane Warnings Got Floridians’ Attention, Saving Lives
abstract: The warnings from officials were dire, and they appear to have been effective.
lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Milton churned in the Gulf of Mexico and moved toward Florida this week, the warnings from officials were dire.

headline: Harris Walks Fine Line on Immigration at Univision Town Hall
abstract: The event in Las Vegas featured emotional questions from voters on health care and the economy — and displayed the balance Kamala Harris is seeking on tough border rules and paths to citizenship.
lead_paragraph: The woman was weeping as she told Vice President Kamala Harris about her mother, who she said died six weeks ago without having ever achieved legal status in the United States.

headline: Investigators Search N.Y.P.D. School Safety Offices in Bribery Inquiry
abstract: The search, and the seizure of a police official’s phone, were part of a welter of federal investigations into Mayor Eric Adams and his inner circle.
lead_paragraph: Federal agents searched the offices of the Police Department’s School Safety Division on Thursday as part of an inquiry into a possible bribery scheme involving city contracts, one of four federal investigations swirling around Mayor Eric Adams, people with knowledge of the matter said.

headline: Corrections: Oct. 11, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Oct. 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An obituary on Oct. 2 about the baseball star Pete Rose misstated the given name of one of his daughters. She is Morgan Erin Rubio, not Megan.

headline: Agony, and Relief, for Island Residents Who Were Hit Hard 2 Years Ago
abstract: Residents of Sanibel Island, Fla., feared the worst when they evacuated to safer ground before Hurricane Milton arrived.
lead_paragraph: The wait to return to Sanibel Island on Thursday was agonizing for residents and business owners, many of whom were still rebuilding from Hurricane Ian in 2022 and just digging out after Hurricane Helene two weeks ago.

headline: Stranded Mariner Seemingly Floated in the Gulf for Hours After the Hurricane
abstract: The Coast Guard rescued a fishing boat captain Thursday afternoon and said he survived winds as fierce as 90 miles per hour.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Coast Guard on Thursday rescued a man who had seemingly done the impossible: He survived for hours in the Gulf of Mexico with nothing but a life jacket and a cooler to cling to.

headline: What Hilarity Often Does
abstract: Billy Bratton opens our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: A Rare Sighting of Northern Lights Entrances Viewers in New York Area
abstract: The aurora borealis, which transformed the sky with startling streaks of pink and purple, arose from a magnetic storm.
lead_paragraph: As a girl in Michigan, Gabriela Aguilar sometimes went looking for the northern lights in the state’s Upper Peninsula. But it wasn’t until Thursday night, when she climbed to the roof of her apartment building in Harlem, that she finally saw them.

headline: Review: An ‘Our Town’ for All of Us, Starring Jim Parsons
abstract: The Thornton Wilder classic returns to Broadway, still brutal and avant-garde after 86 years.
lead_paragraph: The first act of “Our Town” takes place in Grover’s Corners on May 7, 1901. Nothing much happens in the fictional New Hampshire village that day, except that two local teenagers, George Gibbs and Emily Webb, fall in love completely unaware that they do so under the shadow of the granitic pillars of time.

headline: Quote of the Day: Lindor’s Heroics: Feeling Is Believing
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, October 11, 2024
lead_paragraph: “Everybody just lost it in the bullpen, and we were just a bunch of 5-year-olds. It almost brings you back to being a fan again.”

headline: Where Did Modern Love Come From?
abstract: The column’s founding editor and the former Styles editor discuss the origin of Modern Love (which wasn’t originally going to be called Modern Love).
lead_paragraph: On Halloween 2004, Modern Love debuted with an essay by Steve Friedman: “Just Friends? Let Me Read Between the Lines.” It was edited not by me, but by my wife, Cathi Hanauer, a novelist and former magazine editor.

headline: Letters to My Younger Self
abstract: We asked essayists to write a letter to the person they were when they published their Modern Love essay. Here’s what they shared.
lead_paragraph: In honor of Modern Love’s 20th anniversary, we asked a dozen essayists to write a letter to the person they were when they published their essays.

headline: Seven Ways to Love Better
abstract: Reading some 200,000 love stories has taught me a few lessons about love and life. Here are the ones that help me most.
lead_paragraph: Two decades ago, on Oct. 31, 2004, a short note appeared on the front page of this newspaper along with stories about Yasir Arafat’s health and the looming election between George W. Bush and John Kerry. It read: “Modern Love: Introducing a new weekly column about love and relationships. Today, Steve Friedman says he is just fine after getting dumped. Just fine. Really.”

headline: Stories That Changed Lives
abstract: For 20 years, Modern Love has recorded people’s lives. The column has also had real-life reverberations on readers.
lead_paragraph: “So what have you learned about love?” people often ask when they find out I’m an editor of Modern Love.

headline: Finding More Than Produce at the Farmer’s Market
abstract: Jake Fohn and Grace Stearns met a year and a half ago after signing up for an analog dating experience at one of the market’s booths.
lead_paragraph: In October 2022, Jake Edward Fohn was walking through the Clement Street Farmer’s Market in San Francisco when he heard someone yell at him that he looked single.

headline: For Two Years, a Scent of Love Had Lingered
abstract: As colleagues, Ariana Silvestro and Nicholas Kluender developed feelings for each other in 2016, but waited to pursue them.
lead_paragraph: Ariana Silvestro, a founder and chief executive of the fragrance company Scent Lab, spoke from the heart in 2018 when she told Nicholas Austin Kluender she thought they should revisit feelings they started exploring two years earlier.

headline: At 5:57 a.m., They Were Fighting. By 6 a.m., They Were Engaged.
abstract: Anthony Verderame and Julie Mollo had a deal to be engaged by the end of 2023. They made it — with a day to spare.
lead_paragraph: “You look like fun,” Julie Ann Mollo wrote in her first message to her future husband. “Are you an Anthony or a Tony?”

headline: From Wingman to Main Man
abstract: Wilson Payamps approached Cameron Kirk on behalf of a female friend. Lucky for him, she wasn’t Mr. Kirk’s type.
lead_paragraph: On a night out in July 2017, Wilson Payamps was playing wingman for a friend who thought Cameron Hall Kirk was cute. Their friend groups happened to merge at a rave at the Brooklyn Mirage, an event venue in East Williamsburg, where they were all dancing together. Mr. Payamps approached Mr. Kirk on behalf of his female friend.

headline: My Body Doesn’t Belong to You
abstract: In this essay from 2017, a young woman offers powerful testimony about the damaging effects of men’s possessiveness over women’s bodies.
lead_paragraph: In celebration of Modern Love’s 20th anniversary this month, we published a special package of articles about the column’s history and impact. To learn about the origin of Modern Love, read about seven ways to love better, see how the longtime illustrator creates his images, and much more, go to nytimes.com/modernlove. In this space, as each week’s Modern Love column, we are republishing four “classic” essays from earlier years that especially moved us.

headline: In the Wake of Hurricane Helene, Still Saying ‘I Do’
abstract: Peter Batinski and Keri Terenzio, who met in April 2020, are no strangers to crisis. But the Asheville, N.C., residents couldn’t have anticipated the latest: planning a wedding with no running water.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 29, in the wake of Hurricane Helene, Peter Hoffman Batinski and Justin Robbins, the brother-in-law of his fiancée, Keri Young Terenzio, went for a walk around the hard-hit Biltmore Village area of Asheville, N.C. As they surveyed the damage and checked on some friends’ businesses, Mr. Batinski noticed a man in a vest that said “media” taking photos.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: The aftermath of Hurricane Milton.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Milton cut an uneven path of destruction as it tore across Florida, largely sparing the densely populated cities around Tampa Bay but spawning deadly tornadoes far from its center. At least 12 people were killed, most in the eastern part of the state. Over three million people were still without power as of late Thursday night. Here’s the latest.

headline: Words of Wisdom
abstract: Selected quotes from 20 Years of Modern Love.
lead_paragraph: Selected quotes from 20 Years of Modern Love.

headline: Give Ukraine NATO Membership. Peace Depends on It.
abstract: Europe will not be secure — and will not be whole and free — until Ukraine is in NATO. Ukraine will not agree to end the war without membership.
lead_paragraph: In Washington and New York last month, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said his country’s people were fiercely committed to a just and lasting peace to end the war on their nation. This week in Kyiv, I heard a similar sentiment from every Ukrainian I spoke with, from senior officials to frontline soldiers. They want Russians out of their country and security guarantees to protect Ukrainian sovereignty.

headline: Word of the Day: robust
abstract: This word has appeared in 1,321 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word robust has appeared in 1,321 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 25 in “What to Know About New York City’s New Schools Chancellor” by Claire Fahy and Troy Closson:

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Debunks the Government-Hurricane-Control Theory
abstract: “The only person who can control the weather is Beyoncé,” Kimmel said on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Taiwanese Employees of Apple Supplier Detained in China
abstract: Taiwan’s government said that they had been accused of a breach of trust, but that their employer, Foxconn, had denied the company suffered any losses.
lead_paragraph: Chinese authorities have detained four employees of Foxconn, the Taiwanese manufacturer that makes Apple iPhones, Taiwan said, in the latest incident involving government scrutiny of the private sector in mainland China.

headline: Aurora Borealis Lights Skies
abstract: The northern lights spread an ethereal smear across the sky in parts of the United States and Britain.
lead_paragraph: The northern lights spread an ethereal smear across the sky in parts of the United States and Britain.

headline: A Woman Won South Korea’s First Literature Nobel. That Says a Lot.
abstract: While Han Kang’s victory was celebrated as a crowning cultural achievement for her country, her work also represents a form of rebellion against its culture.
lead_paragraph: The awarding of the Nobel Prize in Literature to Han Kang on Thursday stands as yet another validation of the outsize soft power of the South Korean cultural juggernaut.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Inside the Campaign Finance Program Eric Adams Is Accused of Defrauding
abstract: The New York City mayor, who is fighting corruption charges, is accused of taking part in a “straw donor” scheme. His latest fund-raising totals are set to be released Friday.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams of New York, already accused of federal crimes related to his 2021 campaign fund-raising, can expect more scrutiny when fund-raising figures from his 2025 re-election bid are filed on Friday.

headline: Stack of Food
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating? What news reports might it have illustrated?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? Why might it have been used as an illustration at the top of a news article this year? What is your personal relationship to these foods?

headline: Stalking the Numerous Yet Elusive Moose of Newfoundland
abstract: Reporting on the island’s invasive moose population was easy. But seeing the animal in the wild was a different story entirely.
lead_paragraph: While on assignment this year in the Canadian province of Newfoundland and Labrador for The New York Times, my attention turned to big game — moose, that is.

headline: A Democratic Boss Is in Prison. He Still Has 2 Public School Jobs.
abstract: The Democratic chairman of Hillside, N.J., is serving a six-month prison term. He got an $80,000 teaching job in the township after pleading guilty to tax fraud.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Salters, the powerful and well-connected chairman of the Democratic Party in Hillside, N.J., pleaded guilty in January to federal tax fraud. Three months later, Hillside’s school district hired him for a newly created, $80,000 job teaching homebound students.

headline: Elon Musk Unveils Tesla ‘Robotaxi’
abstract: The company’s chief executive said the new autonomous vehicle, which does not have a steering wheel, would cost less than $30,000, but the technology still faces hurdles.
lead_paragraph: The company’s chief executive said the new autonomous vehicle, which does not have a steering wheel, would cost less than $30,000, but the technology still faces hurdles.

headline: Nobuyo Oyama, the Japanese Voice of Doraemon, Dies at 90
abstract: Her alto timbre, for which she was teased as a child, and radiant laughter shaped how millions experienced the blue robot in the quintessential anime of the same name.
lead_paragraph: Nobuyo Oyama, the voice actress whose alto timbre and radiant laughter shaped how millions in Japan experienced Doraemon, the blue robot in the quintessential children’s anime of the same name, died on Sept. 29 in Tokyo. She was 90.

headline: Tourism Has Rebounded Worldwide. But Not in Hong Kong.
abstract: In 2018, Hong Kong received a record 65 million tourists. In 2023, it welcomed a little more than half that.
lead_paragraph: Airline ticket giveaways, elaborate drone and pyrotechnic shows, and invitations to thousands of influencers to visit and “tell a good story.” These are among the wide-ranging ways Hong Kong has tried to revive its international tourism industry, a crucial economic driver battered by years of pandemic restrictions and political upheaval.

headline: Take Me Into the Ballgame
abstract: In Kwame Alexander’s new verse novel and Karen L. Swanson’s nonfiction picture book, Black girls pursue their dreams of playing big-league baseball.
lead_paragraph: Baseball is America’s game, one of our most enduring and exuberant inventions. The speed and finesse of its stars have inspired generations of young people. In a pair of new books set about a century ago, baseball is thrillingly played by two Black girls pursuing their passion in the face of tremendous obstacles. Both “hold fast to dreams,” as Langston Hughes exhorted, as well as to the line drives they dive to catch.

headline: Why Politicians Ignore Abuses in India’s Sugar Industry: They Run It
abstract: Politicians run most of the mills in the state of Maharashtra. They deny or downplay evidence of coerced hysterectomies, debt bondage and child labor in the fields.
lead_paragraph: In the sweltering sugar fields of the western Indian state of Maharashtra, abusive practices such as debt bondage and child labor have long been an open secret. But in 2019, a state lawmaker named Neelam Gorhe documented a new level of brutality: Female workers were getting unnecessary hysterectomies at alarmingly high rates.

headline: The Supreme Court Has Grown Too Powerful. Congress Must Intervene.
abstract: Lawmakers must assert their power to reject the justices’ interpretations of the Constitution and enact their own.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s stunning decision this summer interpreting the Constitution to give presidents broad immunity from federal criminal laws is only the latest of its many opinions undermining Congress’s efforts to protect constitutional democracy, from its 19th-century invalidation of federal civil rights laws to its more recent curbing of the Voting Rights Act.

headline: Who Said Self-Care Was for Young People?
abstract: How aging has affected six older Americans’ view of wellness and staying healthy.
lead_paragraph: “While I don’t love my wrinkles and sags, I embrace them as a life well lived,” said Evelyn Block, 76. That’s not all she’s embraced. She dyes her hair an electric blue. And her retirement hobby? She’s a roller derby referee in Southern California.

headline: Personalizing a Rental Isn’t as Crazy as You Might Think
abstract: How else are you going to decorate with AstroTurf and plywood, or install your own ceramics studio?
lead_paragraph: “You don’t give up a 1,400-square-foot Upper West Side apartment,” said Tobi Wright, “not for a relationship, not for anything.” An advertising art director-turned-interior designer, Ms. Wright was speaking on the phone from the apartment in question, a 12th-floor rental in the West 100s she has occupied on and off since the age of 4.

headline: A Midcentury Turin Home Gets a Careful Update
abstract: What do you do to an apartment in a building designed by Ada Bursi, one of Italy’s first female architects? Add color and texture, but not so much as to distract from its history.
lead_paragraph: THE NORTHERN ITALIAN city of Turin has always embraced both high and low culture. For nearly 400 years, it was the seat of the Savoys, the royal family who ruled Italy from 1861 until 1946, when they were deposed by referendum. Their Baroque primary residence, Palazzo Reale, with its Versailles-inspired mirrored halls, still stands as a reminder of the city’s grandeur. In the 1960s, Turin was a center of the Arte Povera movement, which championed art made with commonplace materials, such as Mario Merz’s plastic-bag-and-soil igloos. It was also where the architect Ada Bursi, born in 1906 in Verona, became one of the first women in Italy to practice architecture, designing schools and public housing across the city. “[For her] beauty was not in the value of the materials — it was in how you worked with them,” says Andrea Marcante, 58, who runs the Turinese architecture studio Marcante-Testa with his longtime friend Adelaide Testa, 58. “Bursi believed in democratic luxury.”

headline: What Flying in a Wind Tunnel Reveals About Birds
abstract: Some birds migrate thousands of miles every autumn. How exactly do they manage it? Scientists built a flight chamber to find out.
lead_paragraph: It happens every fall: The days grow colder, the nights grow longer, the birds grow restless and then they take flight. In North America alone, billions of birds fly south for the winter, sometimes in enormous undulating flocks. It is one of nature’s great spectacles as well as an athletic feat: Some birds regularly migrate thousands of miles or stay aloft for days at a time.

headline: The Market Has Been Fabulous, Maybe Excessively So
abstract: You may not realize how great the stock market has been. But, our columnist says, it can’t keep rising at this pace for long.
lead_paragraph: September is typically a dicey month for the stock market. In many years, so are the weeks before a contentious election.

headline: ‘Founder Mode’ Explains the Rise of Trump in Silicon Valley
abstract: A trendy management style called “founder mode” illustrates Silicon Valley’s growing tilt toward authoritarianism.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley’s current fascination with a trendy management meme illustrates a broader and more troubling turn in certain powerful pockets of its culture — one that has seized our politics and could even unduly influence our election (again).

headline: They Were Loyal Republicans — Until Trump and Abortion Bans
abstract: Abortion is emerging as a major issue in this election, inspiring more women to show up to the polls and vote for Kamala Harris, while at the same time driving a wedge between some conservative women and Donald Trump. That dynamic is especially visible in Arizona, where abortion bans are being challenged on the ballot.
lead_paragraph: Abortion is emerging as a major issue in this election, inspiring more women to show up to the polls and vote for Kamala Harris, while at the same time driving a wedge between some conservative women and Donald Trump. That dynamic is especially visible in Arizona, where abortion bans are being challenged on the ballot.

headline: How We Investigated Political Ties to Abuse in India, and What We Found
abstract: Western companies such as Coca-Cola buy sugar from fields where workers suffer abuses. But the country has labor laws. Where was the government?
lead_paragraph: When my colleagues and I began investigating labor abuses among sugar cane cutters in the western Indian state of Maharashtra, we were startled by how open it all was.

headline: Missouri’s High School Athletes Can Make Money. It’s Paying Off for Mizzou.
abstract: A state law allowing high schoolers to earn from endorsements, if they commit to attending a public university in Missouri, has helped Mizzou attract blue-chip players.
lead_paragraph: In his four-year career as Missouri’s starting quarterback, Brady Cook has thrown for 7,603 yards and 43 touchdowns. He led the Tigers to a victory in last year’s Cotton Bowl. And even after an upset loss over the weekend, his team is in a position to compete for a spot in the College Football Playoff.

headline: Truly Scary Books for Halloween and Beyond
abstract: These terrifying tales by the likes of Stephen King and Shirley Jackson are more than good reads: They’ll freak you out, too.
lead_paragraph: Horror movies have a capacity to scare that seems almost unfairly powerful. Even a bad horror movie — an underwritten slasher, a lazy creature feature, a predictable serial killer thriller — can disturb you with a smash cut to gruesome violence or a montage of shocking imagery. That’s what makes horror movies, like roller coasters, so much fun: They might make you vomit, or even pass out, but it’s scarily good fun to go along for the ride.

headline: In ‘The Last of the Sea Women,’ Divers Face a Vanishing Way of Life
abstract: The film captures the arduous work of South Korean haenyeo, who harvest seafood without diving gear, and whose traditions may be ending.
lead_paragraph: In the South Korean province of Jeju lives a group of women who may, at first, sound as if they’re mythical creatures. The haenyeo (“sea women”) dive and swim in the depths of the ocean without any breathing gear, harvesting seafood like conch, urchin and octopus, which they sell to support their families. Often, haenyeo are the main earners in their households. They’ve done this for centuries.

headline: Aubrey Plaza’s Wilmington
abstract: The acerbic star of “The White Lotus” and “My Old Ass” is enthusiastic about her often-overshadowed Delaware hometown, which she calls a “magical little gem.”
lead_paragraph: Wilmington, Del., is often in the news as the hometown of President Biden and as a hub for corporate litigation, but it’s hardly on tourists’ radar. It has no theme park, no professional sports teams, no famous regional cuisine that demands a pilgrimage.

headline: Many Haitians Prospered in Springfield, Ohio. Then Came the Hate.
abstract: A young family came to love the city where they rebuilt their lives and bought a home. Since a false rumor spread, they have scrapped outings, even to the park.
lead_paragraph: Sadrac and Gerda Delva found happiness again in Springfield.

headline: 5 Children’s Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a star-studded DreamWorks sequel and the highest grossing film of 2024 so far.
lead_paragraph: The third installment in the DreamWorks “Trolls” franchise dives into boy band territory, which is fitting since Branch, the films’ main character, is voiced by Justin Timberlake, of ’N Sync fame. For years, Branch has kept his boy band past secret; he has four older brothers, we learn, and they had a group that broke up when Branch was just a baby. He’s been angry about it ever since.

headline: Middle East Conflict Creates a Volatile Moment for Oil Markets
abstract: Israel and Iran are fighting at a time when prices are under pressure because of weak demand in China and concerns about oversupply.
lead_paragraph: The spiraling conflict between Israel and Iran has sent shock waves through the oil market, increasing prices as investors grapple with potential disruptions to the global oil supply.

headline: These ‘Saturday Night Live’ Books Bring Studio 8H to Your Living Room
abstract: Oral histories and rollicking memoirs by former “S.N.L.” cast members like Molly Shannon and Leslie Jones take you behind the scenes of the comedy juggernaut.
lead_paragraph: “Saturday Night Live,” the late-night NBC comedy-variety show now in its 50th season, generally prefers to mine its material from other people’s dramas and the conflicts of everyday American life — as it is presently doing with its weekly satires of the 2024 presidential race.

headline: A Wrestling Match Over Control of the Chrysler Building
abstract: Legal maneuvers and an empire in tatters leave the ownership of the once grand Manhattan skyscraper up in the air.
lead_paragraph: The owners of the Chrysler Building in Manhattan are at risk of eviction after the real estate empire of one of its owners imploded amid allegations of financial impropriety.

headline: The Problem With This Conspiracy Theory Is Reality
abstract: It’s not indoctrination that’s keeping a majority of younger voters out of the Republican column.
lead_paragraph: According to Tim Sheehy, the Republican nominee for the U.S. Senate in Montana, young people have been “indoctrinated” on the issue of abortion.

headline: I Was Trump’s Ghostwriter. A New Biopic Gets the Most Important Thing Right.
abstract: Critics may argue about specific factual details, but a new account of Trump’s ascent jibes with everything I saw with my own eyes.
lead_paragraph: “The Apprentice,” a new movie that dramatizes the early years of Donald Trump’s career, ends with a scene between Mr. Trump and an actor who plays me. The year is 1986 and I’m interviewing Mr. Trump for the first time, to begin ghostwriting “The Art of the Deal,” a book that I view today as an unintended work of fiction.

headline: Why Was 1999 the Best Movie Year?
abstract: Wesley Morris explains.
lead_paragraph: The year 1999 is considered by many to be a fantastic one for movies. Some say it was, hands down, the best. It was also the year Wesley Morris began his career as a professional critic.

headline: Lego Leaps Into Documentaries, With Pharrell Williams as the Subject
abstract: The toymaker has found success in fictional films. But with “Piece by Piece,” about the life of Mr. Williams, it has gotten into a new genre.
lead_paragraph: In Lego, anything is possible — within limits. Just ask the documentary filmmaker Morgan Neville.

headline: 6 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: Florence Pugh and Andrew Garfield star as Almut and Tobias, a couple whose triumphs and tragedies play out over the course of three time periods in this weepy drama directed by John Crowley.

headline: Musk Is Going All In to Elect Trump
abstract: Elon Musk is planting himself in Pennsylvania, has brought his brain trust to help and may even knock on doors himself.
lead_paragraph: In the final weeks of the presidential campaign, the richest man in the world has involved himself in the U.S. election in a manner unparalleled in modern history.

headline: A Flood of A.I. Slop + Searching for Satoshi + the Hot Mess Express Returns
abstract: There’s just so much slop that at a certain point it makes the internet basically useless.
lead_paragraph: This week, in the wake of recent natural disasters, we dig into the rise of A.I.-generated slop that’s polluting the internet and disrupting rescue efforts. Then we talk with the investigative filmmaker Cullen Hoback about his new documentary on the history of Bitcoin and about why, after so many others have failed, he thinks he has found the real Satoshi Nakamoto. And finally, we hear the train whistle approaching, and that can only mean one thing: It’s once again time to board the Hot Mess Express.

headline: The Divisions Roiling Beneath the Democratic Party’s Joyful Exterior
abstract: Three columnists explore what Kamala Harris’s appeal to conservatives means for the left.
lead_paragraph: When Democrats coalesced around Kamala Harris this summer, they set their differences aside in the interest of preventing a second Trump presidency. But at what cost?

headline: Ta-Nehisi Coates on Israel: ‘I Felt Lied To’
abstract: The journalist discusses his experience visiting Israel and the West Bank.
