lead_paragraph: In his new book of essays, “The Message,” Ta-Nehisi Coates writes about a trip he took to Israel and the West Bank in May 2023. “I felt lied to,” he told me. “I felt lied to by my craft. I felt lied to by major media organizations.”

headline: The Wood That’s Starring in the Delacorte Theater Renovation
abstract: Wood from New York City water towers will be attached to the facade of the theater, where Shakespeare in the Park will return next summer.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll find out about where old wood from some apartment house water tanks is going. We’ll also find out about yet another corruption investigation involving City Hall.

headline: $1 Million Homes in Porto, Portugal
abstract: Offerings in the coastal city in northwest Portugal include a modern duplex penthouse, a restored stone house with vineyards, and a five-bedroom house in the historic center of town.
lead_paragraph: Airy and sunlit, with traditional decorative flourishes typical of Porto’s historic homes, this five-bedroom, five-bathroom villa is close to monuments, cultural attractions and the Douro River. The property, on a cobblestone street in Porto’s historic center, was built in 1937 and restored by the current owners in 2016.

headline: I’ve Covered Politics for 50 Years. Here’s Why So Much Hinges on Electing Kamala Harris.
abstract: The Democratic candidate would bring three things the country desperately needs: stability, unity and optimism.
lead_paragraph: In 1978, I visited my first war zone, Beirut. There were, in fact, several wars going on. The Israelis had made an incursion in the south, but there was chaos everywhere, with various local militias squaring off in the streets. Two of them had battled each other for control of the Holiday Inn. Imagine that. Beirut, clearly, had been a civilized and sophisticated city; parts of it still were — and yet it was descending into the unthinkable. The lesson was stark: My American soul, my life experience, had assumed that civilization was a rock-solid given, especially in historic cultural and commercial centers like Beirut. But it wasn’t. It was a tenuous state of grace. It needed to be nurtured, protected.

headline: How Trump Distorted a Claim About Migrant Children
abstract: Distorting, conflating and inflating government statistics, former President Donald J. Trump and his surrogates have repeatedly accused the Biden administration of losing tens of thousands of migrant children. The misleading claim’s evolution shows Mr. Trump’s penchant for exaggeration.
lead_paragraph: Distorting, conflating and inflating government statistics, former President Donald J. Trump and his surrogates have repeatedly accused the Biden administration of losing tens of thousands of migrant children. The misleading claim’s evolution shows Mr. Trump’s penchant for exaggeration.

headline: What’s Your Favorite Hate-Watch?
abstract: Do you ever watch, read or listen to content that you think is bad? Why do so many of us do this?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever continued to watch a TV show even though you thought it was bad? Something that irritated you or made you cringe, and yet, you couldn’t turn it off?

headline: In Wisconsin, Democrats Hope Competing Down Ballot Helps Harris, Too
abstract: For the first time in 13 years, Wisconsin Democrats are contesting a number of local races. Even a few thousand voters energized by the candidates at their door could make a difference in a tight presidential contest.
lead_paragraph: John Soletski’s brick Arts and Crafts house, with its Trump-Vance yard sign and its Trump flag festooned with guns, was not on the list as Jamie Wall, a Democratic candidate for Wisconsin’s State Senate, knocked on doors on Monday evening in a working-class neighborhood in Green Bay.

headline: How a Fox News host’s misleading question about migrant children morphed into a Trump talking point
abstract: The evolution of a misleading claim shows Mr. Trump’s penchant for exaggeration as well as his symbiotic relationship with Fox News.
lead_paragraph: The evolution of a misleading claim shows Mr. Trump’s penchant for exaggeration as well as his symbiotic relationship with Fox News.

headline: In Battered Lebanon, a Lone Gas Station Is a Lifeline in the East
abstract: Thousands have fled the town of Baalbek amid a barrage of Israeli airstrikes. For those who remain, Ali Jawad’s business is a critical piece of an informal safety net.
lead_paragraph: The gas station is nestled on the side of the road, a lone hive of liveliness in an otherwise deserted stretch of eastern Lebanon.

headline: One Thing Never to Say to a Grieving Friend
abstract: Some words hurt more than they help.
lead_paragraph: I have two friends who recently lost someone very close. As people have tried to comfort them, they’ve repeatedly heard the same phrase: “Everything happens for a reason.”

headline: ‘Everything Is Politicized’: Chris Christie on Trump, Harris and Hurricane Lies
abstract: How did we get here?
lead_paragraph: Frank Bruni, a contributing Opinion writer, talked by Zoom on Wednesday afternoon with Chris Christie, who was the Republican governor of New Jersey when Hurricane Sandy hit that state in 2012, about the differences between the political climate then and the one surrounding the devastation of Hurricanes Helene and Milton. Their conversation has been condensed and edited.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of “Disclaimer,” Alfonso Cuarón’s limited series for Apple TV+.
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of “Disclaimer,” Alfonso Cuarón’s limited series for Apple TV+.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Oct. 11, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Your Favorite Horror Movie Was a Much Scarier True Story
abstract: From “The Exorcist” to “The Lighthouse,” many lauded scary movies were based on terrifying true stories. Here’s what really happened.
lead_paragraph: We’re in the Spooky Season. Halloween costume shops have taken over vacant buildings, “Monster Mash” is on our playlists and, best of all, horror flicks are waiting to be watched.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 489
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Oct. 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,211
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Oct. 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Agony and Relief After Milton, and the Nobel Peace Prize Is Awarded
abstract: Plus, the W.N.B.A.’s record-breaking season.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Trump 2.0: A Presidency Driven by Revenge
abstract: As president, Donald Trump repeatedly tried to use his powers to penalize his enemies. What might a second term mean for American democracy?
lead_paragraph: In a special series, “The Daily” examines what a second Trump presidency would look like, and how it would challenge democratic norms.

headline: Rescuers Search for Survivors After Strikes Hit Central Beirut
abstract: Lebanese officials said at least 22 people were killed in an Israeli attack that reduced one of the capital city’s central intersections to a ruin.
lead_paragraph: Rescue workers on Friday searched for survivors after Israeli airstrikes rocked the heart of downtown Beirut overnight, killing at least 22 people and reducing one of the Lebanese capital’s central intersections to a smoldering ruin.

headline: Ukrainian Journalist Has Died in Russian Captivity, Ukraine Says
abstract: Viktoria Roshchina, a 27-year-old reporter, had been detained by the Russian authorities after reporting from occupied territories in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Viktoria Roshchina, a Ukrainian journalist who went missing in August 2023 while reporting from territories occupied by Moscow’s forces, has died in Russian custody, Ukrainian officials said.

headline: The Stakes on Climate
abstract: We cover each presidential candidate’s climate policies.
lead_paragraph: Will governments slash greenhouse gases enough to prevent the most dangerous impacts of global warming? Scientists say the next few years will provide the answer. The United States has pumped the most carbon dioxide into the atmosphere of any country since the Industrial Revolution, and that makes the next president’s energy choices enormously consequential.

headline: What Is Nihon Hidankyo, the Japanese Group Awarded the Nobel Peace Prize?
abstract: Those who lived through the nuclear attacks of 1945 have dedicated their lives to recounting their experiences of loss and the physical and emotional toll.
lead_paragraph: Some 200,000 people were killed when U.S. forces dropped atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki in the summer of 1945, leveling large swaths of both Japanese cities. But many more survived, some with life-changing injuries, others bearing the terrible emotional scars of the devastation and death they had witnessed.

headline: Wall St. Profits Surge Despite Questions About the Economy
abstract: JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo and BlackRock reported strong quarterly results to kick off earnings season, but concerns linger about the strength of the consumer.
lead_paragraph: Earnings season is underway, with Wall Street giants flying out of the gate this morning. JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo and BlackRock have each reported results that soundly beat analysts estimates, lifting shares in premarket trading.

headline: Israel Orders Gazans to Leave the North, but Most Are Staying Put
abstract: A woman in a town surrounded by Israeli troops said she and her family stayed away from the windows and prayed for relief: “That’s how we survive these dark days.”
lead_paragraph: For more than a year, as Israeli bombs pounded northern Gaza around Mariam Awwad’s home, she and her family of 11 have refused to leave.

headline: Witnesses Describe Chaotic Scenes After Strikes on Central Beirut
abstract: Lebanese officials said Israeli airstrikes killed at least 22 people and wounded more than 100. The Israeli military did not confirm the strikes.
lead_paragraph: Lebanese officials said Israeli airstrikes killed at least 22 people and wounded more than 100. The Israeli military did not confirm the strikes.

headline: Big Banks Steer Through ‘Treacherous’ Conditions
abstract: Profits fell at JPMorgan and Wells Fargo, but the lenders reported results that were largely better than had been expected, a sign that the economy remained solid — for now.
lead_paragraph: In an early test of the effect the Federal Reserve’s big interest rate cut has had on the finance business, the verdict is: mixed.

headline: What to Do if You Fall Behind on Auto Loan Payments
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau suggests that lenders may be overzealous in repossessing cars.
lead_paragraph: More automobile owners are falling behind on their payments, and a new report suggests that lenders have sometimes been overzealous in repossessing cars.

headline: For Atomic Bomb Survivors, Nobel Peace Prize Is a Bittersweet Victory
abstract: Many survivors of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki attacks have dedicated their lives to campaigning for nuclear disarmament. Their mission has grown more urgent as the number of living witnesses to the bombings has dwindled.
lead_paragraph: Toshiyuki Mimaki was just 3 when he saw the flash from the nuclear weapon that wiped out some 100,000 lives in Hiroshima, Japan, in 1945. Nearly eight decades later, as a leader of Nihon Hidankyo, a group of fellow atomic bomb survivors that received the Nobel Peace Prize on Friday, he renewed his plea to abolish nuclear weapons.

headline: Kamala Harris Made the Political Personal on Her Media Tour
abstract: The vice president’s whirlwind tour of talk shows and interviews revealed the kind of persona she wants to present as she seeks to become the election’s main character.
lead_paragraph: Apart from “60 Minutes,” most of the interviews on Kamala Harris’s media tour this week — a multiplatform circuit that ran from daytime TV to late-night, satellite to podcast — were not what you would call adversarial. Howard Stern endorsed her. Whoopi Goldberg introduced her as “the next president of the United States.” Stephen Colbert’s audience greeted her with a chant of “Ka! Ma! La!”

headline: Trump Aides Sought Enhanced Security for Closing Stages of Campaign
abstract: Susie Wiles, a top Trump campaign adviser, was in contact with the White House chief of staff and the head of the Secret Service seeking military assets and other steps.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s campaign has requested a series of additional security measures, including military assets, in conversations with the White House and the Secret Service because of continuing threats to his safety, according to four people briefed on the matter.

headline: Vance Refuses to Acknowledge That Trump Lost the 2020 Election
abstract: During an interview with Lulu Garcia-Navarro, host of “The Interview,” Senator JD Vance of Ohio repeatedly dodged a question on whether he believed Donald J. Trump lost the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: During an interview with Lulu Garcia-Navarro, host of “The Interview,” Senator JD Vance of Ohio repeatedly dodged a question on whether he believed Donald J. Trump lost the 2020 election.

headline: Vance, Given 5 Chances to Say Trump Lost in 2020, Takes None
abstract: In an interview with The New York Times, Senator JD Vance repeatedly refused to acknowledge Donald J. Trump’s defeat and said he would not have certified the 2020 results.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news from the Harris and Trump campaigns.

headline: James Carville on Aging, Edibles and His Anxieties About Harris
abstract: At 79, the Democratic commentator is the subject of a documentary that captures his musings — and his warning to President Biden — about the toils of age.
lead_paragraph: James Carville stretched out his legs and leaned far back in his chair behind a rooftop table at the Peninsula Hotel in Beverly Hills. The Peninsula is a gathering spot for Hollywood celebrities and executives but Mr. Carville, who is neither, was the object of attention on this afternoon.

headline: It’s Touring Season: Chappell, Sabrina and Mk.gee Hit the Stage
abstract: A roundup of some of the biggest and most impactful shows on the road this fall, and how live performances can shift the audience’s perception of an artist.
lead_paragraph: Grand-sized tours are everywhere you look right now. Sabrina Carpenter and Chappell Roan, young pop stars who’ve experienced sudden jolts of attention that reshaped their careers this year, are playing arenas and amphitheaters. In rooms slightly smaller, you can see the rising guitar hero Mk.gee, who’s become one of this year’s most unlikely breakout successes. Vampire Weekend, Cash Cobain, Bleachers and more are all on the road.

headline: U.S. Aims to Revive Failed U.N. Plan for Lebanon War
abstract: Biden administration officials are discussing whether a United Nations plan that ended Israel’s last invasion of Lebanon can be built to last this time.
lead_paragraph: At the heart of the frantic diplomatic efforts to halt Israel’s invasion of southern Lebanon is a decades-old United Nations resolution that was intended to demilitarize the area and protect Israel from cross-border attacks by Hezbollah.

headline: Harvey Awards Inducts 5 Comic Creators to Hall of Fame
abstract: The inductees are being recognized for work on G.I. Joe, Mad magazine, manga and mutants. They will be honored at New York Comic Con.
lead_paragraph: The annual Harvey Awards hall of fame ceremony is back next Friday at New York Comic Con, and is adding five members to its ranks.

headline: Hate the Dentist? You’re Not Alone.
abstract: Don’t skip appointments and risk your oral health. Try these strategies to manage dental anxiety instead.
lead_paragraph: For Hope Alcocer, the diagnosis was grim: 11 cavities. Inflamed gums. A tooth in need of a root canal.

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: Just in time for Halloween are new scary movies about a demon daddy, evil in the woods and ’90s television hell.
lead_paragraph: If you watch only one new horror film this Halloween, make it this demented but deeply humane meditation on fathers and sins.

headline: What to Do With That Apple-Picking Haul
abstract: Both the fruit and cider go into this supremely seasonal recipe for apple cider chicken with apples and parsnips.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It was a perfect weekend in New York City: dinner at Torrisi, no alarm in the morning, a late breakfast at Ba Xuyen, a long walk along the beach at Fort Tilden. Then, soft meatballs and freezing cold martinis at Cozy Royale, followed by Soul Coughing at Brooklyn Steel. Super bon bon.

headline: Hairballs Shed Light on Man-Eating Lions’ Menu
abstract: The Tsavo man-eaters terrorized railroad workers in British East Africa in the 19th century, but their tastes went well beyond human flesh.
lead_paragraph: In British East Africa in 1898, two lions living along the Tsavo River were hungry.

headline: Gustavo Dudamel Visits New York With Promise, and a Warning
abstract: The superstar conductor will take over the New York Philharmonic in 2026. Is his tour with the Los Angeles Philharmonic a preview?
lead_paragraph: Home is a slippery concept in classical music, a global art form of constant travel and jobs that require relocating for months or years at a time.

headline: North Korea Accuses the South of Sending Leaflet-Scattering Drones
abstract: Pyongyang threatened military action if the provocations continued, while the South advised its angry neighbor not to act “rashly.”
lead_paragraph: North Korea on Friday accused South Korea of sending unmanned drones to scatter propaganda leaflets over its capital city, Pyongyang, and threatened military action if the flights continued.

headline: 6 New Shows Our Theater Critics Are Talking About
abstract: The fall season is underway, and our reviewers think these productions are worth knowing about, even if you’re not planning to see them.
lead_paragraph: David Henry Hwang’s 2007 satire, directed by Leigh Silverman, arrives on Broadway starring Daniel Dae Kim as an Asian American playwright who protests yellowface casting only to inadvertently, and hilariously, cast a white actor as the Asian lead in his own play.

headline: How to Make Dinner Out of Anything in Your Pantry
abstract: Make those everyday staples anything but boring with these expert tips.
lead_paragraph: It’s coming up on five years since the pandemic lockdown instigated our collective spate of panic-buying groceries. And I’m pleased to report that I’ve finally gotten through my bulk order of canned sardines.

headline: How Global Warming Made Hurricane Milton More Intense and Destructive
abstract: Greenhouse gas emissions added rain, intensified winds and doubled the storm’s potential property damage, scientists estimated.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Milton walloped Florida with at least 20 percent more rain and 10 percent stronger winds than a similarly rare storm would have done in a world that humans hadn’t warmed by burning fossil fuels, scientists said on Friday.

headline: A Night of Love and Mischief With Stevie Wonder
abstract: At 74, the singer and songwriter returns to arenas with a message of healing and understanding. He’s using trademark exuberance and joy to deliver it.
lead_paragraph: It was a little after 9 p.m. Thursday night at Madison Square Garden, and Stevie Wonder was finally getting loose. He’d begun “You Are the Sunshine of My Life,” one of his defining anthems, with a hopped-up-hootenanny version of the country standard “You Are My Sunshine.” He almost giggled — it was light work.

headline: Harris to Appear on ‘The Breakfast Club’ With Charlamagne Tha God
abstract: The radio show hosted by the entertainer and author has long been a venue for candidates to appeal to Black voters.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris is set to attend a town hall-style event in Detroit on Tuesday hosted by the morning radio program “The Breakfast Club,” one of the show’s hosts, Charlamagne Tha God, said Friday.

headline: ‘Brat’ Autumn Has Begun
abstract: A performance and art installation by Charli XCX lured her fans out of the club and into nature.
lead_paragraph: Another artist might have taken the reddening leaves as a sign that her summer of fun was over. But Mother Nature’s gentle nudges were no match for Charli XCX.

headline: These Arizona Women Are Keeping Kamala Harris’s Hopes Alive
abstract: A conversation among “mom friends” in suburban Phoenix shows the depths of Donald J. Trump’s trouble with a key slice of female voters.
lead_paragraph: On Lisa Hoberg’s phone, the group chat with what she calls her “mom friends” is a politics-free zone. In the political hotbed of suburban Phoenix, it seemed safer that way. Why risk ruining 15 years of friendship by bringing up Donald J. Trump?

headline: Trump Blames Immigrant Surge for Housing Crisis. Most Economists Disagree.
abstract: The former president often implies that deportations will bring down housing costs. Reality is more complicated.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump and his running mate, Senator JD Vance, regularly blame America’s housing affordability crisis on a recent surge in immigration. They point to their plans for mass deportations of undocumented workers as part of the solution.

headline: Kim Jones Leaving Fendi
abstract: From fashion world rumor to reality, another industry shake-up.
lead_paragraph: The tectonic plates of the fashion world are shifting once again.

headline: Social Security: Why It Matters for Young People, Not Just Retirees
abstract: Despite fears about long-term solvency, millennials and Gen Z workers have a major stake in the program.
lead_paragraph: Paul Unnasch notices the $335 in payroll taxes coming out of his paycheck every month for Social Security, and wishes he could get those dollars back.

headline: The Premier League’s Fight With Manchester City Won’t End Well for Anyone
abstract: A decision about rules that left both sides claiming victory revealed the broken reality of the world’s richest competition.
lead_paragraph: One, single, lonely thing has become abundantly clear to English soccer after a week filled with jarring acronyms and dense legalese and furious, desperate spin: Manchester City’s ongoing courtroom struggle against the Premier League is not going to conclude with either side winning. At the end of all this, everyone involved is going to lose.

headline: Trump Agrees to a ‘Women’s Issues’ Event on Fox News, but Shuns Debate
abstract: The audience will be made up of women at the event, a town hall in Georgia to be taped on Tuesday and aired on Wednesday, the network said.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump turned down Fox News’s invitation to debate Vice President Kamala Harris on the air this month.

headline: Smoke Rises From U.N. Peacekeeper’s Base in Lebanon
abstract: U.N. officials said Israeli forces fired on one of the group’s observation towers in southern Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: U.N. officials said Israeli forces fired on one of the group’s observation towers in southern Lebanon.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: With the general election just weeks away, the hosts spent much of the week discussing former President Trump’s rallies, Trump’s ties to President Putin of Russia, and Vice President Harris’s media blitz.
lead_paragraph: With the general election just weeks away, the hosts spent much of the week discussing former President Trump’s rallies, Trump’s ties to President Putin of Russia, and Vice President Harris’s media blitz.

headline: As Trump Arrives, Aurora Insists It’s Not the ‘War Zone’ He Sees
abstract: The former president held rally in a Colorado city he falsely claims was overtaken by violent immigrants from Venezuela. The city’s leaders, Republicans and Democrats alike, tried to pre-emptively fact-check him.
lead_paragraph: Mike Coffman, the conservative Republican mayor of Aurora, Colo., had a message for former President Donald J. Trump before the Republican nominee for the White House came on Friday to a city he has repeatedly painted as having been taken over by vicious migrant street thugs.

headline: In Florida, Yom Kippur Services Adjust After Hurricane Milton
abstract: Some Rabbis are altering tradition slightly to account for dispersed congregations, power outages and flooded temples. For others, it’s business as usual.
lead_paragraph: The damage and displacement inflicted by Hurricane Milton has created uncertainty for Jews in Florida, many of whom evacuated and whose plans for Yom Kippur have been altered as synagogues close or adapt services. Rabbis from temples around the state are preparing for a starkly different Yom Kippur, similar to their approach after Hurricane Ian two years ago.

headline: A Choreographer’s Errands Into the Wilderness
abstract: The Greek-born choreographer Lenio Kaklea made her American debut at Governors Island, a fitting spot for work about the boundaries between nature and culture.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Lenio Kaklea, born and raised in Greece, has made her career in France. On Saturday she made her U.S. debut on the ball fields of Governors Island in New York Harbor. This was an apt port of entry, as the work she brought — and another she presented later in the week at New York Live Arts — focused on the boundaries between nature and culture. (Both works are part of L’Alliance’s Crossing the Line Festival.)

headline: An Award for the Vital Message of Nuclear Survivors
abstract: The Nobel Peace Prize recognized the dangerous path humanity is taking.
lead_paragraph: It was heartening to wake up to the news on Friday that Nihon Hidankyo, a Japanese grass-roots movement of atomic bomb survivors, won the 2024 Nobel Peace Prize.

headline: Charli XCX’s Starry ‘Brat’ Remixes, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Victoria Monét, Samara Joy, the Linda Lindas and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: Hurricanes, Climate Change and the 2024 Election
abstract: Readers discuss recent hurricanes and actions that citizens can take. Also: Jack Smith’s timing; the Supreme Court and the campaign; therapy as health care; a Trumpian character.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 5 Cities. 13 Schools. 47 First-Day Looks.
abstract: To find out what’s trending now, The New York Times for Kids visited middle schools across the country.
lead_paragraph: No matter where they live, the beginning of a new school year is an opportunity for kids to show the world who they are and what they think looks cool right now. But how much does where you live play into personal style? To see if we could spot any patterns in what kids are wearing around the country, The New York Times for Kids visited middle schools in five different cities — Los Angeles, San Antonio, Denver, Minneapolis and New York City — on the very first day of class. Some trends were obvious: cargo pants, stacked bracelets, brightly colored hair, ’90s everything. But the biggest trend we found? Wearing whatever you like. Here, 47 kids tell us what that means to them, and what they’re into now.

headline: 6 Takeaways From the Christopher Reeve Documentary ‘Super/Man’
abstract: The new film chronicles the life of the paralyzed star, covering his friendship with Robin Williams and gut-wrenching details about his care and family.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “Super/Man: The Christopher Reeve Story” traces the life of the Juilliard-trained actor who found megastardom in the 1970s and ’80s playing Superman, and in 1995 as a different kind of hero, after an accident left him paralyzed from the neck down. It features never-before-seen footage of Reeve, who died in 2004 at 52, chronicling his early days; his pivotal friendship with his Juilliard roommate, Robin Williams; and his transformation, in a wheelchair and on a ventilator, into a leading disability and research advocate. Friends like Glenn Close, Susan Sarandon, Whoopi Goldberg and John Kerry offer their observations; disability rights activists do, too. It’s a thought-provoking tear-jerker.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, October 12, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: ‘Pod Save America’ Won’t Quit
abstract: The hosts of the political podcast have outlasted the wave of anti-Trump #Resistance that made it popular. That’s where things get complicated.
lead_paragraph: It was past midnight on June 28, and four podcast hosts were wide awake in a hotel suite in Boston.

headline: Lebanon’s Prime Minister Calls for U.N. Resolution on an ‘Immediate’ Cease-Fire
abstract: It was the latest attempt by Najib Mikati’s embattled government to bring an end to the violence that has killed thousands and displaced nearly one million.
lead_paragraph: Lebanon’s caretaker prime minister, Najib Mikati, appealed to the United Nations on Friday to adopt a resolution calling for an “immediate” cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah, the latest attempt by his embattled government to bring an end to the violence in Lebanon that has killed thousands and displaced nearly one million.

headline: ‘Who Is That? What’s Happening?’: Decoding the Art World at Frieze
abstract: The London art fair can be a bewildering spectacle, where even the insiders are sometimes scrambling to keep up.
lead_paragraph: Every October, one of the world’s major art fairs takes place in a huge tent on the edge of Regent’s Park. For five days, the park’s year-round population — joggers, parents pushing buggies, teenagers playing soccer — is augmented by thousands of people at Frieze London seeking an encounter with contemporary art — or at least an encounter with the contemporary art world, which is just as much of a spectacle, in its way.

headline: Israeli and U.S. Defense Ministers Discuss Israel’s Expanding Conflicts in Mideast
abstract: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III spoke with his Israeli counterpart, Yoav Gallant, on Thursday, the Pentagon said.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III spoke on Thursday with his Israeli counterpart, Yoav Gallant, about Israel’s expanding military operations in Lebanon, the Pentagon said on Friday.

headline: For Atomic Bomb Survivors, a Nobel Prize and a Reckoning, 80 Years Later
abstract: Toshiyuki Mimaki, the chairman of Nihon Hidankyo, which was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, said his foremost wish was to “please abolish nuclear weapons while we are alive.”
lead_paragraph: Cities blasted to rubble. Burned bodies and flayed flesh. Invisible waves of radiation coursing through the air. And the indelible image of a mushroom cloud.

headline: In Texas Senate Race, Cruz and Allred Duel Over Youth Sports Without Saying ‘Trans.’
abstract: Ted Cruz’s re-election campaign has poured resources into attack ads that focus on transgender participation in youth sports. His Democratic opponent, Representative Colin Allred, responded with his own ad.
lead_paragraph: For weeks now, Texans watching television, including during prime time football games, have seen ads from the re-election campaign of Senator Ted Cruz declaring: “Boys in girls sports, that’s not right.”

headline: Tesla Loses Court Battle in Swedish Labor Dispute
abstract: A district court ruled that Sweden’s constitution prevented it from taking a side in a labor dispute between Tesla and local unions that has dragged on for 11 months.
lead_paragraph: A district court in Sweden ruled on Friday that it could not force a local postal company to resume deliveries to Tesla that had stopped nearly a year ago as part of a wider labor dispute aimed at getting the U.S. automaker to sign a collective bargaining agreement.

headline: Salman Rushdie Will Testify at Trial of Man Accused of Stabbing Him
abstract: Hadi Matar is charged with attempted murder and assault in connection with an attack in western New York that left the author blind in one eye.
lead_paragraph: The author Salman Rushdie, who was stabbed and blinded in one eye two years ago by an attacker who rushed him onstage in front of hundreds of people, will testify at the man’s trial, prosecutors said on Friday.

headline: Nevada Asked A.I. Which Students Need Help. The Answer Caused an Outcry.
abstract: The new system cut the number of students deemed “at risk” in the state by 200,000, leading to tough moral and ethical questions over which children deserve extra assistance.
lead_paragraph: Nevada has long had the most lopsided school funding in the country. Low-income districts there have nearly 35 percent less money to spend per pupil than wealthier ones do — the largest gap of any state.

headline: My Son Has a Gambling Problem. Do I Tell His Partner?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the risks of divulging a loved one’s addiction to someone who ought to know.
lead_paragraph: Our 30-something son has been seriously dating a smart, capable woman for more than a year. They seem very happy; they recently moved in together and are talking about their long-term future, including the possibility of having children. She fits in well with our family and is a good influence on our son. We support them and would like to encourage their relationship, but my spouse and I are concerned about something.

headline: Are They Not Famous, or Are You in a Bubble?
abstract: A social media post about the Hollywood Reporter’s “A-List” of influencers inspired quite a few jokes online. But part of that was a misunderstanding.
lead_paragraph: The Hollywood Reporter announced its list of the “top 50 most influential influencers” to relatively little fanfare earlier this week. The list included names like Alix Earle, Kai Cenat and Nara Smith, as well as YouTube stalwarts like Rhett and Link and the TikTok darling Charlie D’Amelio.

headline: In Michigan, Walz Assails Trump’s Record on Manufacturing
abstract: The Minnesota governor running for vice president on the Democratic ticket also had strong words for Elon Musk, the billionaire businessman who is working to get former President Donald J. Trump elected.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota took the stage in a Detroit suburb on Friday to offer a sharp rebuttal to former President Donald J. Trump, who had positioned himself as a savior of the auto industry at an appearance in Detroit a day earlier.

headline: What Do Liberals Believe About Late-Term Abortion?
abstract: How cognitive dissonance shapes both sides of the abortion debate.
lead_paragraph: Any productive debate about abortion — a rare thing, but worth pursuing — has to start by acknowledging each side’s strongest arguments and most sincerely held beliefs.

headline: Trump Is Said to Consider Brooke Rollins for White House Chief of Staff
abstract: Ms. Rollins, a conservative lawyer who ran domestic policy in the Trump administration, is said to be under consideration for the role should Donald J. Trump win the election.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has been privately asking confidants what they would think of his appointing his former White House domestic policy adviser, Brooke Rollins, as his chief of staff if he wins the election, according to three people with knowledge of his conversations.

headline: Northern Lights Animate Night Skies Around the Globe
abstract: An outburst from elevated solar activity created conditions on Thursday that kept people’s eyes glued to evening views all over the Northern Hemisphere.
lead_paragraph: Night skies came aglow on Thursday with the shimmering palette of the northern lights, or the aurora borealis if you prefer.

headline: Evan Gershkovich, U.S. Journalist Imprisoned in Russia, Will Publish a Memoir
abstract: The memoir, which will cover his time in prison and Russia’s move toward autocracy, will be published by Crown, an imprint of Penguin Random House.
lead_paragraph: Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal who was imprisoned in Russia for more than a year, is writing a memoir about his time in prison, his five years living in Moscow and Russia’s slide toward autocracy.

headline: Stanley Tucci on His New Book, ‘What I Ate in One Year’
abstract: The actor and renowned foodie talks about his eating habits and his food diary, and we look at the fiction and nonfiction titles up for the National Book Award.
lead_paragraph: The actor-director-producer Stanley Tucci is also, famously, an avid eater, who has explored his enthusiasm for food through his travel show “Searching for Italy” and through two books: “Taste,” in 2021, and now a food diary, “What I Ate in One Year,” which will be published on Oct. 15. In this week’s episode, Tucci discusses his new book with the host Gilbert Cruz and talks about bad meals, his food idol and his path to tracking a year’s worth of eating.

headline: Inside Donald Trump’s Shadow Presidency
abstract: In the years since he left the White House, former President Donald J. Trump has remained a force in international politics, meeting with a number of foreign leaders and operating out of his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida.
lead_paragraph: When Finland wanted to join NATO to ward off Russian aggression, it knew it had a friend living in the White House and could count on President Biden’s support. But to ensure that the U.S. Senate would ratify its membership bid, Finland’s government decided to also seek out the president living in Florida.

headline: Boeing Will Cut 17,000 Jobs in Bid to Slash Costs
abstract: A new chief executive is restructuring the aerospace manufacturer, which has been losing money for several years while struggling to improve production quality.
lead_paragraph: Boeing’s new chief executive on Friday announced plans to reduce its work force by 10 percent, or about 17,000 jobs, as he seeks to restructure the company in an effort to slash costs and improve production of planes, which has been plagued by numerous delays.

headline: When Your Partner’s Ex Is Your Biggest Fan
abstract: Doug Emhoff’s ex-wife is one of Kamala Harris’s most vocal supporters. Their relationship has brought new attention to blended families, but mutual admiration isn’t always a given.
lead_paragraph: A film producer and mother of two in California posted a short message of praise on Monday after Vice President Kamala Harris’s recent appearance on the “Call Her Daddy” podcast.

headline: A Nebraska Senate Ad Lets One Mechanic Throw a Wrench at Another
abstract: Deb Fischer, the Republican incumbent, faces a stiff challenge from a union leader, Dan Osborn, running as an independent. Her latest ad calls him a “Democrat in disguise.”
lead_paragraph: A fund-raising PAC supporting Senator Deb Fischer, Republican of Nebraska, has been running this 30-second ad attacking her independent opponent, Dan Osborn, on television stations across the state since Wednesday at a cost of more than $372,000 so far, according to the Fischer campaign.

headline: Funeral Home Sent a Grandmother’s Body to the Wrong Country, Suit Claims
abstract: Carmen Maldonado, 96, of Queens, died on May 18. She was supposed to be buried in Ecuador, but her body was sent to Guatemala, a lawsuit contends.
lead_paragraph: A Queens family filed a lawsuit this week against a funeral home, accusing it of sending their loved one’s body to the wrong country, according to court records.

headline: Joseph H. Reich, Charter School Pioneer, Dies at 89
abstract: When he and his wife opened the Beginning With Children school in Brooklyn to offer more educational opportunities to children, they set off a national trend.
lead_paragraph: Joseph H. Reich, a financier and philanthropist who with his wife created one of New York City’s first independently run public schools, proving that impoverished students could outperform expectations in such a setting — and which helped to kick-start the city’s charter-school movement — died on Sept. 29 at his home in Sheffield, Mass. He was 89.

headline: Why Nevada Latinos Are Losing Faith in Government
abstract: Democrats have found their popularity with the Nevada electorate slipping. The fallout from the pandemic, including a struggling economy, has fostered mistrust in the government.
lead_paragraph: Democrats have found their popularity with the Nevada electorate slipping. The fallout from the pandemic, including a struggling economy, has fostered mistrust in the government.

headline: Lebanon’s Leader Calls on U.N. for Cease-Fire Amid Search for Airstrike Survivors
abstract: Rescuers dug through rubble in Beirut as the caretaker prime minister implored the United Nations to adopt a resolution calling for an “immediate” truce between Israel and Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: Rescuers dug through piles of rubble in central Beirut on Friday, looking for survivors and bodies, a day after deadly airstrikes in two densely populated neighborhoods of the Lebanese capital spread fear that no place in the country was safe from the Israeli military onslaught against Hezbollah.

headline: Trump Scaled Up His Efforts to Stoke Immigration Fears
abstract: Also, the Nobel Peace Prize went to Japanese atomic bomb survivors. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: At a campaign rally this afternoon in Aurora, Colo., Donald Trump depicted America as a country “occupied” by immigrants. He promised the large crowd in attendance that he would save their communities by ridding them of illegal migrants. And he unveiled a plan to deport migrants suspected of being in a gang under a 1798 law that allows for removal of people from countries that have invaded the U.S.

headline: How Does Florida Insure Itself Against Hurricanes Like These?
abstract: The state has taken steps to shore up its insurance market, but researchers warn of looming risks.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Milton would have done more damage if it had made landfall a few dozen miles farther north. The southern side of the hurricane, with its Category 3 winds spiraling counterclockwise, would have driven a wall of seawater into downtown Tampa. Instead, Tampa Bay got hit by the northern side of the hurricane, whose winds traveling from east to west pushed water from the bay out to sea. It was what meteorologists call a “negative surge.”

headline: Swing State Voters: What’s in Your Mailbox?
abstract: Share images of your political correspondence with the On Politics newsletter.
lead_paragraph: If you live in one of the seven key battleground states, your mailbox is probably stuffed with political mailers from candidates up and down the ballot.

headline: Obama’s Admonishing Tone to Black Men Presents a Risk for Democrats
abstract: The former president’s remarks that some Black men are not “feeling the idea” of a female president were blunt and urgent, but also potentially alienating for a vital group of Democratic voters.
lead_paragraph: When former President Barack Obama admonished some Black men who he said were not “feeling the idea of having a woman as president,” some Democrats saw it as an urgent, necessary call to action to voters who are desperately needed to push Vice President Kamala Harris to victory.

headline: Federal Judge Questions Justice Department on Boeing Guilty Plea
abstract: After objections from the families of the victims of the two 737 MAX plane crashes, a federal judge will rule whether to accept a plea agreement reached by the Justice Department and Boeing.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Fort Worth heard arguments Friday but withheld a ruling on whether he would accept a guilty plea by Boeing in connection to the tragic crashes of two 737 Max jets that resulted in the loss of 346 lives.

headline: ‘Why Are We Out of Gas?’ A Fuel Crisis Leads to Long Lines in Florida.
abstract: Hurricane Milton left many gas stations without power and disrupted deliveries at ports. Mass evacuations before the storm also drained supplies.
lead_paragraph: Gasoline remained hard to find on Friday across the west coast of Florida, especially in the Tampa-St. Petersburg area, where power outages, port closures and mass evacuations had left many gas pumps without fuel or unable to operate.

headline: Overlooked No More: Mariama Bâ, Voice of African Feminism
abstract: She became a literary star in Senegal with novels that addressed women’s issues as the country, newly free from French colonial rule, was discovering its identity.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: All the Presidents’ Books: 6,500 Best Sellers and 100 Years of Jimmy Carter
abstract: A reporter counted every best seller about U.S. presidents published since The Times started tracking book sales in 1931. The process took some patience.
lead_paragraph: I was walking the dog when the news broke: Jimmy Carter, the 39th president of the United States, was going into hospice.

headline: As Floridians Return, Officials Size Up Milton’s Uneven Trail of Destruction
abstract: Power outages, gas shortages and pockets of flooding were among the lingering issues. But Gov. Ron DeSantis said the damage could have been worse.
lead_paragraph: Florida residents on Friday returned to neighborhoods stricken by power outages and filled with piles of soggy, stinking debris as tens of thousands of emergency workers began repairing the destruction caused by Hurricane Milton.

headline: Arizona Democrats Shut Down a Phoenix Campaign Office After Shootings
abstract: The office was hit three times after hours, once with a BB gun and twice with a firearm. No one was hurt, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The Arizona Democratic Party shut down a campaign office in suburban Phoenix after it was struck by gunfire and a BB gun on three occasions over the past month, said a local official, Lauren Kuby, on Friday.

headline: Scared by Helene, Everyone in This Florida Beach Town Evacuated for Milton
abstract: Over time, the question of whether to stay or go will likely become a question of whether to keep living in coastal or low-lying areas at all.
lead_paragraph: Chris Miller rode out Hurricane Helene just over two weeks ago inside his picturesque yellow home across from the Gulf of Mexico in Bradenton Beach, a tiny Florida city on a barrier island. As the storm surge rose, he readied a wet suit in case he needed to escape.

headline: A Retirement Community Prepared for a Hurricane. Tornadoes Came Instead.
abstract: Hurricane Milton’s death toll was highest far from the coast where it made landfall, in a retirement community where few were braced for destructive tornadoes.
lead_paragraph: Victor Linero was watching coverage of Hurricane Milton’s churn toward Florida when, suddenly, he saw a live video of a tornado near his grandfather’s home — hours before the hurricane was supposed to hit on the opposite side of the state.

headline: Milton Leaves Some Florida Animals in Limbo, Too
abstract: Florida’s animal shelters are struggling after the storm. Animal organizations are helping fly some pets to faraway shelters.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Milton has displaced people all over Florida. It left thousands of shelter animals in limbo, too.

headline: ‘Suffs’ Won Tony Awards for Best Score and Book. Now It’s Closing.
abstract: The musical, created by Shaina Taub, announced that it will play its final performance on Jan. 5 and start a national tour next fall.
lead_paragraph: “Suffs,” a new musical about the American women’s suffrage movement, has a lot going for it: Its producers include Hillary Rodham Clinton and Malala Yousafzai, it won Tony Awards for its score and its book, and its audiences seemed energized by how the show’s themes resonated with the candidacy of Kamala Harris.

headline: Trump Rally in Aurora, Colo., Is Marked by Nativist Attacks
abstract: The former president continued to make claims about the city that have been disputed by local officials, including its Republican mayor.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump escalated the nativist, anti-immigration rhetoric that has animated his political career with a speech Friday in Aurora, Colo., where he repeated false and grossly exaggerated claims about undocumented immigrants that local Republican officials have refuted.

headline: The OB-GYN Running on Abortion Rights in Conservative Wisconsin
abstract: Dr. Kristin Lyerly is looking to make inroads in a heavily Catholic part of the state.
lead_paragraph: It was 7:15 a.m. on Sunday, and a blood-orange sun had turned the sky lavender. Dr. Kristin Lyerly was getting ready to leave.

headline: Harris Says She Would Form Bipartisan Council of Advisers
abstract: The stop in Arizona was part of the Harris campaign’s strategy to court Republicans disaffected with former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: As Vice President Kamala Harris has sought to stake out ground in the political center that might appeal to swing voters, she has campaigned with former Representative Liz Cheney, the Wyoming Republican, and pledged to appoint a Republican to her cabinet if elected. Ms. Harris added to that strategy while visiting the battleground state of Arizona on Friday, saying she would convene a bipartisan council of advisers on policy if she wins the White House.

headline: Blissful Stretch
abstract: Katie Hoody makes a New York Times Crossword debut with feeling.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Katie Hoody’s first crossword for The New York Times. I always love it when a constructor debuts with a Friday or Saturday themeless grid, even though I know that there’s not always a direct correlation between the difficulty of solving puzzles and making them. (I still picture one of those children who go to an Ivy League university at 10 and get on the local news.)

headline: Mayor Adams’s Rivals Reveal Fund-Raising Totals. Mr. Adams? Who Knows.
abstract: With Mayor Eric Adams’s future in flux as he faces federal bribery charges, his challengers prepare for the possibility of an election before the June primary.
lead_paragraph: With Mayor Eric Adams facing a five-count federal indictment and at least four Democratic primary challengers next year, the quarterly fund-raising reporting deadline on Friday carried heightened intrigue.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Ta-Nehisi Coates
abstract: The Oct. 11, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Ta-Nehisi Coates. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: China Vows to Unleash More Borrowing to Spur Economy and Strengthen Banks
abstract: The finance minister said Beijing would sell bonds to supplement spending and help banks but did not detail how much.
lead_paragraph: China’s powerful Ministry of Finance said on Saturday that it would borrow more to help cash-short localities and put more money in the hands of state-owned banks, an effort to address a severe slowdown in real estate and shore up crumbling consumer confidence.

headline: Quote of the Day: A Nobel Honor To the Survivors Of Atom Bombs
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 12, 2024
lead_paragraph: “Please abolish nuclear weapons while we are alive.”

headline: Corrections: Oct. 12, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about the halt in the George J. Mitchell scholarship program because of funding difficulties misspelled the surname of a former speaker of the House. He was Tip O’Neill, not O’Neil.

headline: China’s ‘New Great Wall’ Casts a Shadow on Nepal
abstract: Nepalis have complained that China’s breaches of the border threaten their land and their way of life.
lead_paragraph: Nepalis have complained that China’s breaches of the border threaten their land and their way of life.

headline: Rise of the Dragons: Fire-Breathing Drones Duel in Ukraine
abstract: Drones are getting another new twist: Soldiers attach canisters to them to create weapons capable of spitting out molten metal that burns at 4,400 degrees.
lead_paragraph: It was a familiar and vexing problem: Russian soldiers were using the dense cover of tree lines to prepare to storm the Ukrainian trenches.

headline: One of the Loneliest Countries Finds Companionship in Dogs
abstract: They have become pampered family members in South Korea, which has the world’s lowest birthrate and where much of the population lives alone.
lead_paragraph: The deceased lay wrapped in a cotton blanket, surrounded by white roses and hydrangea, angelic figurines and lit candles and incense. A wall-mounted screen displayed photographs of him. His 71-year-old companion, Kim Seon-ae, convulsed with tears as she bid farewell, caressing his head and face. Next door, young uniformed morticians prepared for his cremation.

headline: What International Law Says About Israel’s Invasion of Lebanon
abstract: Explaining the issues of sovereignty, self-defense and humanitarian safeguards.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the Middle East crisis here.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: How Taryn Delanie Smith, TikTok’s Heaven Receptionist, Spends Sundays
abstract: Taryn Delanie Smith, a former Miss New York, takes a long stroll with her husband and Great Dane and cues up her Sunday playlist with an Ina Garten-inspired dinner.
lead_paragraph: Before Taryn Delanie Smith was crowned Miss New York in 2022, she worked at a call center. At one point, she said, she was only pretending to take calls.

headline: How Eric Adams Could Leave Office, and Who Hopes to Succeed Him
abstract: Mr. Adams’s political future is in doubt after federal prosecutors indicted him on corruption charges in one of several inquiries ensnaring City Hall.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Adams’s political future is in doubt after federal prosecutors indicted him on corruption charges in one of several inquiries ensnaring City Hall.

headline: City Hall Is in Crisis. Who’s Running New York?
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams is relying on a group of respected civil servants to run the city and a trio of advisers to salvage his political career. Some say it’s too late.
lead_paragraph: For Mayor Eric Adams, the challenge of leading New York City has taken on an almost absurd quality, with his administration peppered in recent weeks by a half-dozen significant resignations, four federal investigations and two federal indictments, including one against the mayor.

headline: Cross-Tabs: October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of the Black Likely Electorate
abstract: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 589 Black voters from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 589 Black voters from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.

abstract: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 808 likely voters in Arizona from Oct. 7 to 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 808 likely voters in Arizona from Oct. 7 to 10, 2024.

abstract: Results of a New York Times/Philadelphia Inquirer/Siena College poll conducted among 857 likely voters in Pennsylvania from Oct. 7 to 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a New York Times/Philadelphia Inquirer/Siena College poll conducted among 857 likely voters in Pennsylvania from Oct. 7 to 10, 2024.

abstract: Results of a New York Times/Philadelphia Inquirer/Siena College poll conducted among 857 registered voters in Pennsylvania from Oct. 7 to 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a New York Times/Philadelphia Inquirer/Siena College poll conducted among 857 registered voters in Pennsylvania from Oct. 7 to 10, 2024.

abstract: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 589 Black voters from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 589 Black voters from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.

headline: A Heroine Determined to Live Alone, and to Get Pregnant
abstract: The protagonist of Eva Baltasar’s novel “Mammoth” contains multitudes, and that’s the way she likes it.
lead_paragraph: Eva Baltasar’s “Mammoth” is a book of contradictions even before it begins. Despite its title, it is seemingly a featherweight, not a giant, clocking in at hardly 100 pages. But this is a surprising slim novel that trembles with the force of an approaching stampede.

headline: One of the World’s Most Immigrant-Friendly Countries Is Changing Course
abstract: Canada has long had one of the world’s most open immigration policies. Now, faced with a growing popular backlash, it’s changing the rules.
lead_paragraph: A late-night Uber ride from Toronto’s Pearson Airport into the city usually guarantees a good fare for the driver.

headline: How Roger Goodell Became the N.F.L.’s $20 Billion Man
abstract: Under the expansionist leadership of its commissioner, the National Football League is growing richer and richer. So, too, is Mr. Goodell.
lead_paragraph: As they met in the lobby of the Omni Viking Lakes Hotel in Minnesota in late August, Jerry Jones, the owner of the Dallas Cowboys, and Robert Kraft, the owner of the New England Patriots, greeted each other warmly, sharing fist bumps as a small entourage that included their oldest sons surrounded them.

headline: A Tender Ode to a 1960s ‘Women’s Hotel’
abstract: Daniel M. Lavery’s debut novel collects vignettes from inside the Biedermeier, a second-rate, rapidly waning establishment in midcentury New York City.
lead_paragraph: It’s the 1960s, and New York’s venerable Biedermeier hotel, a second-rate but genteel women’s residence, is, like the city around it, changing. Few patrons require the chaperones or house rules such institutions offer. Breakfast service has been suspended; rooms lie empty.

headline: California Tries ‘Trump-Proofing’ Its Climate Policies
abstract: A second Trump administration would be expected to shred climate policies. California officials are devising ways to insulate its environmental regulations.
lead_paragraph: California officials have been working for months on a plan to “Trump proof” the state’s leading edge environmental and climate policies, in the event that former President Donald J. Trump returns to the White House and follows through on his promise to gut them.

headline: Dreamtroit, a Low-Cost Bohemia for Artists, Revs Up in Motor City
abstract: The former Lincoln Motor factory is in the vanguard of new development poised to transform moribund automotive facilities into affordable housing and art studios.
lead_paragraph: Maurice Cox, the former planning director of the city of Detroit, remembers the first time Matthew Naimi wandered into his office in paint-splattered overalls in 2018, with fingernail polish, a kaffiyeh on his head, and his bare arms a constellation of tattoos. When Naimi told him that he wanted to develop a multimillion-dollar low-cost housing complex for artists out of one of the city’s most dilapidated automobile factories, long abandoned, “it was bordering on satire,” Cox recalled.

headline: Twitter Barred Them. What Happened When Elon Musk Brought Them Back?
abstract: Many users who were reinstated by X have continued to share the kinds of false narratives and conspiracies that once got them suspended.
lead_paragraph: After Hurricane Helene, Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, the hard-right conservative from Georgia, shared on X the widely debunked claim that government scientists could control the weather. “It’s ridiculous for anyone to lie and say it can’t be done,” she wrote in one post.

headline: In Detroit, Creating a New Hub for Innovation
abstract: Entrepreneurs once flocked to Motor City to build cars. Now, they’re building its mobility future.
lead_paragraph: David Medina Álvarez hopped on a four-wheeled vehicle that looked like a speeder bike from Star Wars. Donning a helmet and goggles, the 25-year-old designer zoomed down 15th Street, driving alongside the massive Michigan Central train station, built in 1913, which had just reopened after a gleaming $1 billion renovation.

headline: Lee Minho Needs His Notes App
abstract: “Whenever I get inspiration or feel something,” the “Pachinko” star said, “I go to my Notes app and write it down.”
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, the actor and singer Lee Minho was yearning for a shift in his career. It was around this time that he received the script for Season 1 of “Pachinko,” the drama that follows four generations of a Korean immigrant family, based on the novel by Min Jin Lee.

headline: Led by Believers in the City’s Future, Detroit Is on the Rebound
abstract: Once the largest city in the U.S. to declare bankruptcy, this Midwestern metropolis is now thriving. But some obstacles still remain.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny Friday morning last month, Mike Duggan, the mayor of Detroit, got behind the wheel of his black Jeep Grand Cherokee to give a tour of the city he has led for 10 years. Not far from Michigan Central Station, the former hulking ruin that was recently transformed into a gleaming office complex, he slowed to point to a construction site of vertical steel girders and yellow earth-moving machines. It will become a 600-room JW Marriott hotel, linked to the city’s convention center and scheduled to open by 2027, when college basketball’s Final Four will be played in Detroit.

headline: In This ‘Oval Office,’ Tourists Can ‘Solve or Start a World Crisis’
abstract: The White House Historical Association has opened a new museum that aims to provide insight into the difficult choices that presidents face.
lead_paragraph: For most of the last 75 years, it would have been impossible for a family touring Washington, D.C., to recreate the iconic photo of John F. Kennedy Jr. as a toddler, playing under the Resolute Desk in the Oval Office while his father directs the affairs of government.

headline: A Twist on the Celebrity-Interview Podcast: Add Two Civilians
abstract: In a podcast landscape where famous people are always talking to each other, “Podcrushed” tweaks the formula and, for good measure, adds some adolescent angst.
lead_paragraph: In the lush, softly lit studio where nearly 60 years ago the Beach Boys recorded “Pet Sounds” and changed pop music forever, the hosts of the “Podcrushed” podcast are preparing to interview their latest guest: Chase Stokes, star of the Netflix teen-treasure-hunting drama “Outer Banks.”

headline: The School for First Ladies Is Now in Session
abstract: It’s a highly visible role that usually comes with no job description or salary. This group aims to assist. (And yes, first gentlemen are welcome.)
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Sept. 24, just after noon, 15 first ladies from around the world gathered for a working lunch focused on public health in a top-floor conference room in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Tester’s Fight for Political Survival Is Democrats’ Last Stand on the Great Plains
abstract: Once able to win on the prairie, the Democratic Party sees the Senate race in Montana as a final test of whether it can still be successful in heavily rural states that have turned deep red.
lead_paragraph: When Senator Max Baucus, a Democrat and political fixture in Montana, was re-elected to a sixth term in 2008, all of the statewide offices down the ballot — governor, attorney general, secretary of state, state auditor and school superintendent — were won by fellow Democrats. A sole Republican took the state’s single seat in the House of Representatives.

headline: Scary Books for Scaredy-Cats
abstract: Looking to dip your toe into horror this Halloween season? Entry-level thrills by Shirley Jackson, Victor LaValle and T. Kingfisher are a good place to start.
lead_paragraph: Given the sheer volume of horror fiction published over the past decade, it can be hard for the sensitive yet curious reader to know where to start. Fear is heavily individual — what sends me screaming from the room might leave you unmoved — so it’s difficult to predict what will or won’t frighten, disturb or disgust any one person. But there are ways to dip a toe into the genre without scaring yourself silly.

headline: Composting Bin Dos and Don’ts: Can Your Building Restrict Your Access?
abstract: Every building is different. What to do with internal trash and recycling storage are up to the residents and managers.
lead_paragraph: Q: The management company for my New York City co-op is restricting our access to the new composting bins, which the city provides, to one 24-hour period every week. These “brown bins” are part of the city’s mandatory composting program. The city says there are no special days or limited hours for composting, but the management company says it is limiting the collection time to minimize pests and odors. I have a galley kitchen and cannot keep a week’s worth of food waste. I can use the orange smart bins on the street, but it’s frustrating that the management company is disregarding the purpose of the program. What can we do?

headline: Black Voters Drift From Democrats, Imperiling Harris’s Bid, Poll Shows
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris is on track to win a majority of Black voters, and has brought many back to her party since taking over for President Biden. Still, a significant gap in support persists.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris has improved her party’s standing among Black voters since President Biden left the presidential race, but she still significantly trails Mr. Biden’s 2020 share of that vital Democratic constituency, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll of Black likely voters.

headline: Christian Conservatives, Looking to Mobilize Women, Turn to a Biblical Queen
abstract: Alarmed by abortion and transgender rights, Christian activists are invoking the Old Testament story of Esther, the Jewish orphan who bravely saved her people.
lead_paragraph: The biblical story of Esther, the Jewish orphan who became queen and bravely saved her people, has been a potent symbol for women and girls, a call to lead a life of courage, sacrifice and purpose.

headline: Boris Johnson Makes a Case for Trump’s Return, and Perhaps, His Own
abstract: In his memoir, “Unleashed,” the former prime minister is “optimistic” about the possibility that Donald J. Trump could regain the White House.
lead_paragraph: Boris Johnson knows he’s often cast as Donald J. Trump’s populist twin, and he puts up a perfunctory protest. Analogies between Brexit, which he championed, and Trump’s MAGA movement are “pretty treacherous,” he said, and the caricature of himself as a louche, shambling, Eton-and-Oxford version of Trump does no favors to the once-and-maybe-future American president.

headline: Hurricanes Amplify Insurance Crisis in Riskiest Areas
abstract: After Helene and Milton, some small Florida companies risk bankruptcy. Larger ones will be in the hot seat with lawmakers and consumer groups.
lead_paragraph: Until late last month, there was optimism in the insurance industry. Hurricane season had been quiet and the number of wildfires was still below the yearly average. Insurers were beginning to hope that the cost of reinsurance — that is, insurance for insurers — would only inch up next year, instead of shooting higher as it did the previous two years.

headline: A Frustrated Trump Lashes Out Behind Closed Doors Over Money
abstract: Donald J. Trump is feeling aggrieved, unappreciated by donors and fenced in by security concerns in the final stretch of the race.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump took his seat at the dining table in his triplex penthouse apartment atop Trump Tower on the last Sunday in September, alongside some of the most sought-after and wealthiest figures in the Republican Party.

headline: Trump Leads in Arizona as Harris Holds an Edge in Pennsylvania, New Polls Show
abstract: The latest Times/Inquirer/Siena polls found Donald Trump with a six-point advantage in Arizona, and Kamala Harris with a four-point lead in Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: Two of the nation’s most-contested battleground states — Pennsylvania and Arizona — illustrate the difficulties each campaign faces in gaining a clear advantage in the final stretch of the 2024 race, with Kamala Harris maintaining a narrow lead in Pennsylvania but Donald J. Trump continuing to hold an advantage in Arizona, according to a new pair of New York Times/Philadelphia Inquirer/Siena College polls.

headline: 5 Takeaways From Vance’s Interview With The New York Times
abstract: Pressed to say if he thought the 2020 election was stolen, JD Vance repeatedly sidestepped. And he defended the sentiment behind his “childless cat ladies” comment, even as he regretted his word choice.
lead_paragraph: JD Vance keeps showing up.

headline: Resilience Has Taken Her From ‘The Hills’ to Brooklyn Heights
abstract: Glossier founder Emily Weiss attributes her success to never giving up. Plus, jewelry shopping from coast to coast and Wet Seal’s gilded age.
lead_paragraph: Speaking on the phone as she was driving through Manhattan, Emily Weiss turned the conversation to cocktails while discussing the fragrance offerings from Glossier, the beauty brand she founded 10 years ago this month.

headline: Daring Trump, Harris’s Campaign Releases Medical Information
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris released a letter from her doctor saying that she is in “excellent health,” as her campaign tries to capitalize on the lack of health information shared by her rival.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris released a letter on Saturday from her White House doctor, who said she is in “excellent health” and is successfully managing some minor health issues.

headline: ‘The Interview’: A Conversation With JD Vance
abstract: In this interview, Senator JD Vance, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, rejects the idea that he has changed, defends his rhetoric and still won’t say whether former President Donald J. Trump lost in 2020.
lead_paragraph: In this interview, Senator JD Vance, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, rejects the idea that he has changed, defends his rhetoric and still won’t say whether former President Donald J. Trump lost in 2020.

headline: A Conversation With JD Vance
abstract: The Republican vice-presidential candidate rejects the idea that he’s changed, defends his rhetoric and still won’t say if Trump lost in 2020.
lead_paragraph: From the moment JD Vance came onto the national stage, he was inextricably linked to Donald Trump. As the author of the best-selling book “Hillbilly Elegy,” Vance was initially the Trump whisperer, explaining the Trump phenomenon and 2016 win to shocked liberals. Back then, Vance didn’t like Trump. He called him an “idiot,” condemned what he saw as Trump’s dangerous rhetoric and wondered in a private message whether Trump could become “America’s Hitler.”

headline: Israeli Strikes on Northern Gaza Kill at Least 20, Aid Workers Say
abstract: Israel’s military said it was “operating with great force” against Hamas and allied groups and issued new evacuation orders, as it also continued its campaign in Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: The humanitarian crisis in the northern Gaza Strip deepened on Saturday as an Israeli bombardment killed at least 20 people, trapped thousands more and prompted one of the area’s last functioning hospitals to issue desperate pleas for assistance.

headline: These Americans Are Going Back to Mexico as Its Citizens
abstract: More than 25 years after Mexico began recognizing dual nationals, some U.S.-born children of Mexican immigrants are claiming citizenship in the country that their parents once left.
lead_paragraph: She hid with her four boys under the cover of darkness, the distant shouts of Border Patrol agents and a helicopter droning over the hills on the Tijuana-San Diego border. The agents threatened to end a one-way trip from Mexico to the United States with arrest and deportation.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 490
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Oct. 13, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,212
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Oct. 13, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: In British Columbia, a Political Party’s Collapse Echoes an Earlier Election
abstract: The end of a coalition of Conservatives and Liberals over 70 years ago led to a surprising election result and reshaped the province’s politics.
lead_paragraph: To anyone following politics recently in British Columbia, it sounds familiar: An alliance of Liberals and Conservatives collapses, and then a botched attempt to thwart the left wing ends up elevating a moribund party.

headline: Love Lessons
abstract: The editor of the long-running Modern Love column reflects on two decades of working with people’s deeply personal stories.
lead_paragraph: The Modern Love column debuted 20 years ago this month — on Halloween, scarily enough — with a story by a lifelong bachelor, Steve Friedman, who was trying to feel OK about being dumped. He wrote: “She dumped me. What’s important are not the details but the pronoun placement, ‘she’ preceding ‘me.’ But there is no villain here. My therapist suggests I repeat this mantra to myself. So I do. There is no villain here.”

headline: Why I Changed My Birth Certificate 25 Years After I Transitioned
abstract: I’m taking steps to secure my future in an uncertain time for trans people in America.
lead_paragraph: My wife was the one who told me that the birth certificate for Baby Girl Boylan had finally arrived in the mail in late summer. It had been a long time coming — 66 years, in fact — because Baby Girl Boylan, of course, was me.

headline: Quiet as Old as the Beginning of Time
abstract: Much of what’s still undeveloped offers some the best defenses against climate change.
lead_paragraph: A small, heart-shaped body of water aptly named Green Lake lies at just under 9,000 feet on the western side of the Tetons, deep within the Jedediah Smith Wilderness area of Wyoming. Mirroring the surrounding conifers, the surface of the lake rests perfectly still this fall evening.

headline: This Is Why Trump Imagines He Will Win
abstract: The way he is now running is the best window we have into what kind of president he will be in a second term.
lead_paragraph: If Donald Trump wins, the people who voted for him would have a range of reasons for putting him in office. There are a lot of potential Trump voters who don’t like him that much or who really like only parts of his personality or platform and tolerate the rest.

headline: This Election Will Need More Heroes
abstract: Honorable public servants of both parties upheld democracy after the 2020 election. America is counting on them again to do their duty.
lead_paragraph: True political courage — the principled stand, the elevation of country over party pressure, the willingness to sacrifice a career to protect the common good — has become painfully rare in a polarized world. It deserves to be celebrated and nurtured whenever it appears, especially in defense of fundamental American institutions like our election system. The sad truth, too, is the country will probably need a lot more of it in the coming months.

headline: ‘Are We Not Humans?’
abstract: My attempt at explaining the murder, rape and famine in Sudan.
lead_paragraph: After my reporting trip to the Chad-Sudan border and columns about the murder, rape and starvation that have devastated Sudan, readers wrote in with many thoughtful comments and questions. Here’s my effort to address some of them:

headline: Where Is the Fierce Urgency of Beating Trump?
abstract: The vice president needs to pull out all the stops to get out of her stall.
lead_paragraph: Barack Obama got blunt in Pittsburgh on Thursday. He chided Black men who are not supporting Kamala Harris, saying that some of “the brothers” were just not “feeling the idea of having a woman as president.”

headline: Who Are These People Interviewing Trump and Harris?
abstract: For the presidential candidates, the media future is now.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, Barack Obama submitted to interviews with three YouTube stars, one of whom was notable for eating cereal out of a bathtub. It was a moment that opened a window into the media landscape of the future, after the mainstream media as we have known it — while also making that future seem basically absurd.

headline: A Mystery Repeats: Harris Up 4 in Pennsylvania, and Trump Up 6 in Arizona
abstract: Being uncertain about our earlier poll results but finding almost the same numbers the next time around.
lead_paragraph: At the end of our last wave of post-debate battleground polls, there were two state poll results that didn’t seem to fit the rest.

headline: Executives and Research Disagree About Hybrid Work. Why?
abstract: Companies like Amazon have required a return to the office five days a week despite findings showing benefits to employers that allow some remote days.
lead_paragraph: Amazon’s C.E.O., Andy Jassy, made waves last month when he demanded that all employees return to the office five days a week. The proclamation seemed to validate similar demands made by executives like JPMorgan Chase’s Jamie Dimon and Goldman Sachs’s David Solomon. And it naturally raised the question of whether others might follow suit. (It appears some have.)

headline: The Cutting-Edge Hearing Aids That You May Already Own
abstract: Apple is preparing to turn its AirPods Pro 2 into easy-to-use aids for people with mild to moderate hearing loss.
lead_paragraph: In your pocket or purse, you may be toting around small devices that, with the help of new software authorized by the Food and Drug Administration, could soon become inexpensive hearing aids. Millions of people already own them.

headline: Political Uncertainty and Budget Reality Put France in a Financial Vise
abstract: A rating agency’s warning about the country’s ballooning debt comes as the prime minister tries to push an austerity budget through a divided Parliament.
