lead_paragraph: France has become one of the most financially troubled countries in Europe, with an outsize debt and deficit that are likely to keep ballooning despite efforts by a fragile new government to address the problem, the Fitch Ratings agency said on Friday.

headline: Secret Documents Show Hamas Tried to Persuade Iran to Join Its Oct. 7 Attack
abstract: The Times reviewed the minutes of 10 meetings among Hamas’s top leaders. The records show the militant group avoided several escalations since 2021 to falsely imply it had been deterred — while seeking Iranian support for a major attack.
lead_paragraph: For more than two years, Yahya Sinwar huddled with his top Hamas commanders and plotted what they hoped would be the most devastating and destabilizing attack on Israel in the militant group’s four-decade history.

headline: JD Vance: Not Having Kids Due to Climate Change Is ‘Crazy’
abstract: Senator JD Vance, the Republican vice-president nominee, said that considering climate change when deciding to have kids was a “bizarre way to think about the future.”
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance, the Republican vice-president nominee, said that considering climate change when deciding to have kids was a “bizarre way to think about the future.”

headline: Toplines: October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters in  Arizona
abstract: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 808 likely voters in Arizona from Oct. 7 to 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 808 likely voters in Arizona from Oct. 7 to 10, 2024.

headline: Letters in Song Lyrics and Poetry
abstract: These are some of our favorites from among more than 800 submissions in response to our request for variations on traditional letters.
lead_paragraph: Elections of Yore

headline: How to Fall in Love With Lentils
abstract: They’re cheap and quick to cook, and they make dishes like this one-pot chicken even more hearty and satisfying.
lead_paragraph: I had my first lentil as an adult, and I want to say it was somewhere in France. (My mom, a terrific Japanese home cook, didn’t keep dried or canned lentils in the pantry; they didn’t figure much into her cooking, nor mine when I moved out.) I think those first lentils came to me in a simple salad, pebbly little de Puys dressed in a mustardy vinaigrette, maybe with some carrot or onion in there. I can’t remember the specifics, just the lentils: tender but not mushy, earthy but not too beany, and adorably small.

headline: Allan Blye, 87, Dies; ‘Smothers Brothers’ Writer and ‘Super Dave’ Creator
abstract: In his wide-ranging career, he also helped write Elvis Presley’s comeback special and appeared on an early version of “Mister Rogers’ Neighborhood.”
lead_paragraph: Allan Blye, a television comedy writer and producer who helped cement the Smothers Brothers’ reputation for irreverence in the late 1960s and later collaborated with Bob Einstein to create the hapless daredevil character Super Dave Osborne, died on Oct. 4 at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 87.

headline: JD Vance’s Election Denialism Is Deepening
abstract: Fool me once? Shame on you. Fool me five times?
lead_paragraph: The first thing I thought of while watching Senator JD Vance of Ohio refuse to say whether Donald Trump lost the 2020 presidential election in a recent interview with this newspaper was “The Manchurian Candidate,” John Frankenheimer’s 1962 psychological thriller.

headline: David Garrard Lowe, Defender of Historic Architecture, Dies at 91
abstract: For over 50 years, as a historian, lecturer and author, he fought to protect Beaux-Arts buildings in New York and Chicago from falling to the developer’s wrecking ball.
lead_paragraph: David Garrard Lowe, a writer and architectural historian whose passion for historic preservation — and in particular for the Beaux-Arts mansions, museums and towers of the Gilded Age — helped stem the tide of urban renewal that was leveling large swaths of American cities in the decades after World War II, died on Sept. 21 in Manhattan. He was 91.

headline: Alex Salmond, Scotland’s Former First Minister, Dies at 69
abstract: He led the Scottish National Party twice, guiding it from a fringe political group into a powerful electoral force in Britain.
lead_paragraph: Alex Salmond, the former first minister of Scotland who campaigned for the country to leave the United Kingdom and led the nation during an independence referendum, died on Saturday after delivering a speech in North Macedonia. He was 69.

headline: Former U.S. Soldier Is Sentenced to 14 Years for Planning to Help ISIS
abstract: Pvt. Cole Bridges pleaded guilty last year to charges of attempting to provide material support to a foreign terrorist organization and attempting to murder U.S. military service members.
lead_paragraph: A former soldier in the U.S. Army was sentenced on Friday to 14 years in prison after pleading guilty to attempting to provide ISIS with information to help plan an ambush he thought would result in the deaths of U.S. soldiers in the Middle East, according to the U.S. Justice Department.

headline: Map: 6.2-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Near Costa Rica
abstract: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
lead_paragraph: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.

headline: Biden Declares Disaster From Milton Ahead of Florida Visit
abstract: The president will visit communities ravaged by Hurricane Milton on Sunday. The disaster declaration will enable funds for the state to be deployed.
lead_paragraph: President Biden approved a major disaster declaration for Florida for communities ravaged by Hurricane Milton, freeing up federal funding to assist in the state’s recovery and rebuilding.

headline: Manual Dexterity
abstract: Gary Larson and Doug Peterson’s puzzle already comes with instructions, but just in case. …
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: On the Trail, Vance Is Dogged by Questions About Trump’s Loss in 2020
abstract: Speaking at a factory for military vehicles in Johnstown, Pa., Senator JD Vance of Ohio again refused to acknowledge former President Donald J. Trump’s defeat in the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance of Ohio, who has faced renewed questions about the 2020 election since refusing at the vice-presidential debate this month to acknowledge that former President Donald J. Trump lost, falsely suggested on Saturday that the election had been “rigged.”

headline: California Rejects Bid for More Frequent SpaceX Launches
abstract: A commission denied a request to increase the number of rocket launches on the state’s central coast, citing environmental concerns.
lead_paragraph: A California state commission this week rejected the U.S. Space Force’s bid to increase the number of SpaceX rocket launches on the state’s central coast, citing concerns about the environmental impacts of the launches.

headline: Boot Found at Everest Could Be From Climber Who Vanished 100 Years Ago
abstract: When Sandy Irvine went on a pioneering expedition to Mount Everest’s summit in 1924, he and his partner vanished. The recent discovery may shed light on the ill-fated adventure.
lead_paragraph: A well-preserved boot found by a group of climbers on Mount Everest could be a clue to solving one of the most enduring adventure mysteries in the history of exploration of the world’s highest peak.

headline: F.A.A. Clears the Way for SpaceX to Hold Starship Launch on Sunday
abstract: The agency said the company had agreed to study the environmental impact of its launches in South Texas and ways to mitigate harm to wildlife.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration issued a new license on Saturday allowing Elon Musk’s SpaceX company to launch its Starship rocket again from South Texas, and it included new requirements to limit the harm to birds’ nests and other wildlife in an adjacent state park and National Wildlife Refuge.

headline: Trump Hits Coachella, Campaigning Once Again in a Blue State
abstract: The former president took a detour from the battleground states to hold a rally in the California desert, where temperatures hovered near 100 degrees.
lead_paragraph: Both presidential campaigns agree that seven swing states are likely to determine the outcome of this year’s election. California, which has not voted for a Republican in a presidential race since 1988, is not one of them.

headline: Texas Man Drops Suit Against Women Who Helped Ex-Wife Get Abortion Pills
abstract: The suit had accused the three women of wrongful death. It was part of a heated battle over the use of such pills in states with abortion bans.
lead_paragraph: A Texas man has dropped his lawsuit against three women who helped his ex-wife obtain abortion pills, a case widely seen as designed to discourage private citizens from aiding women in using the pills in states where abortion is all but banned.

headline: Roadblocked
abstract: How you can get around the West Bank depends on who you are. We took two bus trips, one with Palestinians and one with Israelis, that tell a story of separate and unequal roadways.
lead_paragraph: How you can get around the West Bank depends on who you are. We took two bus trips, one with Palestinians and one with Israelis, that tell a story of separate and unequal roadways.

headline: How Palestinians Are Roadblocked in the West Bank
abstract: Driving in the Israeli-occupied West Bank is an incredibly different experience depending on who you are. Ben Hubbard, international correspondent for The New York Times, rode along on two bus trips, one for Israelis, the other for Palestinians, that tell a story of separate and unequal roadways.
lead_paragraph: Driving in the Israeli-occupied West Bank is an incredibly different experience depending on who you are. Ben Hubbard, international correspondent for The New York Times, rode along on two bus trips, one for Israelis, the other for Palestinians, that tell a story of separate and unequal roadways.

headline: Quote of the Day: After Helene, Bradenton Beach Residents Left Town for Milton
abstract: Quotation of the Day for October 13, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I told him, ‘Bev’s house is headed your way.’”

headline: Silvio Berlusconi Died. But for Her, the ‘Bunga Bunga’ Scandal Lives On.
abstract: The woman at the center of revelations of bacchanals at the former Italian prime minister’s villa is still fighting a court case, and a negative public image, 14 years later.
lead_paragraph: Hardly a night goes by that Karima el-Mahroug does not think of what her life would be like if she had never met Silvio Berlusconi.

headline: When Trump Rants, This Is What I Hear
abstract: His hostility has taught me more about myself.
lead_paragraph: I’ve never considered “immigrant” my calling card, even though it’s one I’ve always carried.

headline: ‘We Would Take the Bus to Her Home on East 37th Street After School’
abstract: Remembering a best friend, packed into a subway car and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Filmed in New York, Hold the Taxis and Radiators
abstract: When independent movies like “Rosemead” travel to a state for tax incentives, they save money but add creative challenges.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy morning this past January, Roosevelt Avenue in the Flushing neighborhood of Queens was a stream of yellow cabs, honking buses and weaving cyclists. Nearby, a film crew peering out the windows of a Chinese pharmacy discussed how to make all of that invisible.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: She Was a Key Aide to Eric Adams. Her Ties to China Ran Deep.
abstract: Winnie Greco, a top fund-raiser and senior adviser for Mr. Adams, has long had dealings with people and groups connected to China’s communist regime. He kept her close even so.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams was riding high in the fall of 2022 when Winnie Greco, one of his best fund-raisers and a top adviser, led him into a glittering ballroom in Flushing, Queens, the heart of the Chinese diaspora in New York City.

headline: 50 Years of Broccoli (and Mockery): A Co-op Co-Founder Calls It Quits
abstract: In 1973, Joe Holtz helped start the Park Slope Food Co-op, a Brooklyn institution that is equally loved and ridiculed. Will it survive his retirement?
lead_paragraph: For a 74-year-old, Joe Holtz can cover a lot of ground very quickly. The ground he was covering the other day was the three adjoining carriage houses in Brooklyn that were subsumed by the Park Slope Food Co-op as it grew and became the largest, busiest and most argument-inducing single-store food cooperative in the United States. Every square foot, in the breakneck tour he gave, reminded him of an episode in the store’s history.

headline: How Can I Get My Boss to Notice Me?
abstract: When there are men in the room, a female colleague is made to feel invisible.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: Can the New York Liberty, the Best in the W.N.B.A, Finally Win It All?
abstract: The Liberty, an original W.N.B.A. franchise, have been to the finals five times and lost each time. But their fans can’t help believing, again, this year.
lead_paragraph: Barclays Center in Brooklyn shook with the roar of 17,700 basketball fans, almost all of them rooting for the New York Liberty. They have been waiting years for a team like this one, and on Thursday, with only five minutes left and the Liberty up by 15 points over the Minnesota Lynx in Game 1 of the W.N.B.A. finals, there was a sense that the team’s run of failures was going to be over.

headline: A Day in the Life of Tim Heidecker, Glendale Dad
abstract: Years after making his name with the sketch comedy series “Tim and Eric Awesome Show, Great Job!”, he’s singing wry ballads and watching the kids.
lead_paragraph: From the moment he showed up at Tim Heidecker’s house, the Chihuahua in the dragon costume seemed a little freaked out.

headline: A Test of Knowledge and a Winning Entrant
abstract: Can you guess which former New York Times critic won the newspaper’s intercollegiate contest as a student?
lead_paragraph: “Did you follow the news this week?” That’s how The New York Times News Quiz announces itself each weekend.

headline: On ‘S.N.L.,’ Harris and Trump Take Their Contest to ‘Family Feud’
abstract: It was also an especially music-filled evening, with Stevie Nicks as the musical guest and Ariana Grande, as host, breaking often into song.
lead_paragraph: Although former President Donald J. Trump refused invitations for a second debate with Vice President Kamala Harris, “Saturday Night Live” came up with another setting where both presidential nominees might share the stage: the game show “Family Feud.”

headline: Corrections: Oct. 13, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Oct. 13, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about the growth of the “SmartLess” podcast misspelled the surname of the CAA executive who helped expand the podcast’s brand. He is Josh Lindgen, not Lingen.

headline: Ladakh’s Local Hero Wants India to Pay Attention to His People
abstract: The activist Sonam Wangchuk is leading protests to demand more autonomy for India’s remote Ladakh region, which shares borders with China and Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: Sonam Wangchuk has worn many hats: as an engineer, an environmentalist and an education reformer.

headline: Russian Strikes on Ukrainian Ports Target Civilian Shipping
abstract: With the strikes in the Odesa region, Russia appears to be trying again to prevent Ukraine from exporting grain, harming its economy and pushing up world prices.
lead_paragraph: Russia has stepped up its assaults on Black Sea port infrastructure and civilian shipping in recent days, in what Ukraine says is an attempt to disrupt its exports and damage its economy.

headline: Cross-Tabs: October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of the Hispanic Likely Electorate
abstract: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 902 Hispanic voters from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 902 Hispanic voters from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.

headline: Cross-Tabs: October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Hispanic Registered Voters
abstract: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 902 Hispanic voters from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 902 Hispanic voters from Sept. 29 to Oct. 6, 2024.

headline: John F. Kennedy Jr.’s 1990s-Era Magazine Is Back, With a QAnon Twist
abstract: It is a reanimation story strange enough for a zombie movie, made possible by the fact that the original George trademark lapsed, only to be secured by a conservative lawyer.
lead_paragraph: On a Saturday morning in August, a few hundred people gathered at a convention center in Hot Springs, Ark., paying between $145 and $475 to hear from a cast of far-right speakers. They included a body builder-turned-pundit who carries a tomahawk and promotes an antisemitic conspiracy theory, and a pro-Trump preacher who has warned of threats posed by technologically sophisticated demon mermaids.

headline: The Author of ‘The Curious Incident’ Is Back With More Dogs
abstract: The new story collection by Mark Haddon takes inspiration from Greek myths, H.G. Wells and Snoopy.
lead_paragraph: The British writer Mark Haddon is best known for his 2003 novel “The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time,” in which a neurodivergent teenage boy solves a murder mystery and wins the reader’s heart. Haddon is equally accomplished at creating gripping narratives and sympathetic characters in his shorter fiction. The stories in this splendid new collection are inspired by an eclectic variety of sources, including a novel by H.G. Wells, Virginia Woolf’s first published story and, as with some of Haddon’s previous work, Greek mythology.

headline: Jokes and Offbeat Auctions for the Troops: Standup Comedy Sweeps Ukraine
abstract: Even as the conflict with Russia grinds on, a new generation of comics in Ukraine is trying to make people laugh — and raise money for the war effort.
lead_paragraph: Onstage in a Kyiv theater, Anton Tymoshenko tells a joke about Ukrainians who are never satisfied with the weapons their country gets from the West — if they got nuclear weapons, he says, they would probably grumble about the quality of the uranium. He mocks the Odesa mayor (for being allegedly pro-Russian) and the Kyiv one (for being allegedly pro-himself).

headline: The Secretive Dynasty That Controls the Boar’s Head Brand
abstract: The deli-meat company made its owners fabulously wealthy. But they have remained silent, even as the company faces the biggest scandal in its history.
lead_paragraph: In May 2022, the chief financial officer of Boar’s Head, the processed meat company, was asked a simple question under oath.

headline: Friends With Benefits, but Without Illusions
abstract: In “Don’t Be a Stranger,” Susan Minot once again explores female desire, staging a romantic collision between a divorced mother and a much younger musician.
lead_paragraph: If you loved Miranda July’s “All Fours,” Knopf suggests, try Susan Minot’s “Don’t Be a Stranger.” How depressing. Minot is an O.G. writer of female desire who published the spare and potent “Lust and Other Stories” in 1989, when July was still in knee socks and Sally Rooney just a glimmer in Mr. Rooney’s eye. Its neon-lettered cover blazed from every cool girl’s bookshelf.

headline: Can the Government Get People to Have More Babies?
abstract: Japan has been trying to boost its fertility rate for 30 years. Now the rest of the rich world is, too.
lead_paragraph: In 1989, Japan seemed to be an unstoppable economic superpower. Its companies were overtaking competitors and gobbling up American icons like Rockefeller Center. But inside the country, the government had identified a looming, slow-motion crisis: The fertility rate had fallen to a record low. Policymakers called it the “1.57 shock,” citing the projected average number of children that women would have over their childbearing years.

headline: Christopher Steele and the Mueller Team Are Still Trying to Set the Record Straight
abstract: Two new books explore the messy business of uncovering Russian interference in American elections.
lead_paragraph: Why is it that this year’s election feels encrusted with such déjà vu? Is it the outsize presence of Nate Silver? Former President Donald Trump’s presence on the ticket? Or maybe it’s because Kremlin interference appears to have been ramping up in recent months. In September, the U.S. State Department announced it was pulling out all the stops, offering $10 million for information on a group called Russian Angry Hackers Did It.

headline: On the Trail, Harris Turns to Her Experience Fighting Cross-Border Crime
abstract: As California’s attorney general, Kamala Harris prioritized the fight against traffickers of drugs and people. It’s a part of her biography she hasn’t always talked about.
lead_paragraph: As Vice President Kamala Harris vows to crack down on illegal immigration at the nation’s southern border, she has played up her experience as California’s attorney general pursuing criminal groups that traffic drugs, guns and people across the United States and Mexico.

headline: A Birth Scene So Taxing, Andrew Garfield and Florence Pugh Needed to Rest
abstract: The stars and director of “We Live in Time” explain how a delivery became an action sequence, complete with a real baby and a few unwelcome surprises.
lead_paragraph: You wouldn’t expect the romantic drama “We Live in Time” to have an action scene, but it does — at least that’s how Andrew Garfield sees it.

headline: A Hedgehog, a Centrifuge and Other Millennial Life-Improvement Splurges
abstract: Placing a high value on personal growth, millennials and Gen Z appear more likely than older generations to make hobbies and nonessential purchases a spending priority.
lead_paragraph: How much ongoing joy can you get from something that weighs eight ounces?

headline: Once Known for Death Row, San Quentin Hosts a Star-Studded Film Festival
abstract: The California prison used to house some of the state’s most violent criminals, but has become more known lately for creative pursuits.
lead_paragraph: The prizes were paper certificates. The red carpet measured just a few feet long. The catered lunch spread was state-issued bologna sandwiches wrapped in plastic.

headline: Who Is That You Are Chatting With? Oh, Just ChatGPT.
abstract: The artificial intelligence chatbot’s Advanced Voice Mode feature has delighted some users and weirded out others.
lead_paragraph: When you think of what a voice programmed by artificial intelligence would sound like, you might picture something robotic and stilted, with a staccato cadence incapable of capturing the inflections, speed and emotion required to sound even somewhat human. But this is 2024, and the robots have gotten a serious upgrade. Now they can imitate voices, accents and intonation to an almost creepy degree — for better or worse.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ and the Underappreciated Influence of Carol Burnett
abstract: A new film about the show doesn’t mention her. But in many ways her hit sketch series helped define the early vision of Lorne Michaels.
lead_paragraph: What makes Lorne Michaels laugh?

headline: GOP Is Making Inroads With Black and Hispanic Voters
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump has gained some ground since 2020 among Black and Hispanic voters, especially men. Ruth Igielnik, who conducts polls for The New York Times, explains.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has gained some ground since 2020 among Black and Hispanic voters, especially men. Ruth Igielnik, who conducts polls for The New York Times, explains.

headline: Harris Struggles to Win Over Latinos, While Trump Holds His Grip, Poll Shows
abstract: Latino voters said they were open to Donald J. Trump’s immigration policies and hungry for change. Many remain undecided.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s support among Hispanic voters is in dangerously low territory for Democrats, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll, while her rival, former President Donald J. Trump, has maintained his strength with the fast-growing group poised to play a key role in deciding control of the White House.

headline: Why Is Trump Gaining With Black and Hispanic Voters?
abstract: Five possible explanations for the increases in support, particularly among young men.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, Donald J. Trump became the Republican nominee and ultimately won the presidency after calling many Mexican immigrants rapists and falsely claiming that Barack Obama was not born in the United States.

headline: A Tale of Two Hurricanes Finds More That Differs Than Is the Same
abstract: Helene in North Carolina and Milton in Florida were very different storms in very different places.
lead_paragraph: Cindy Miller wasn’t sure where to begin the cleanup this weekend at her home in Englewood, Fla. Hurricane Milton had drenched her home and dumped debris everywhere. Much of it was not even hers. A sofa, doors and shoes littered the backyard, along with detritus that remained from Hurricane Helene, the deadliest hurricane to hit the U.S. mainland in nearly two decades.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 491
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Oct. 14, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,213
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Oct. 14, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Hezbollah Drone Strike Kills 4 Israeli Soldiers on Military Base
abstract: The strike, which wounded dozens, showed that the militant group remains a force.
lead_paragraph: A drone strike by Hezbollah on a military base in the north of Israel killed four soldiers and wounded dozens of other people, the Israeli military said Sunday.

headline: Lawyers Should Not Assist Trump in a Potential Power Grab
abstract: Lawyers should remember what they were taught in ethics class.
lead_paragraph: As the presidential campaign begins its final sprint, Donald Trump has made crystal clear how he will respond if he loses. He will refuse to accept the results; he will make baseless claims of voter fraud; and he will turn, with even more ferocity than he did in 2020, to the courts to save him.

headline: If the Pro-Life Movement Loses This One, Its Future Is in Danger
abstract: November’s second-most-important election is in Florida.
lead_paragraph: I’ll never forget the first time I heard my oldest daughter’s heartbeat. My wife was experiencing trouble in the first three months of pregnancy, and we were worried she was miscarrying. We rode together to her doctor’s office, full of anxiety. And then we heard the magical sound — the pulsing of our little girl’s tiny heart. We didn’t know if she would ultimately be OK, but there was one thing we knew: Our daughter was alive.

headline: Ignore the Polls
abstract: They can’t tell you what you want to know.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a bit of advice to help maintain your sanity over the next few weeks until Election Day: Just ignore the polls. Unless you’re a campaign professional or a gambler, you’re probably looking at them for the same reason the rest of us are: to know who’ll win. Or at least to feel like you know who’ll win. But they just can’t tell you that.

headline: A Shift in the World of Science
abstract: What this year’s Nobels can teach us about science and humanity.
lead_paragraph: Technology observers have grown increasingly vocal in recent years about the threat that artificial intelligence poses to the human variety. A.I. models can write and talk like us, draw and paint like us, crush us at chess and Go. They express an unnerving simulacrum of creativity, not least where the truth is concerned.

headline: Democrats to Fly Harris Ads Over N.F.L. Games in Swing States
abstract: Fans at games in four swing states will see skywriting or banners over their stadium on Sunday. The vice president’s campaign would like men in particular to look up.
lead_paragraph: As the Harris campaign continues to court male voters, it is dialing up a deep shot, targeting a venue where it thinks it will reach quite a few of them: professional football.

headline: SpaceX Advances Starship Program With a Launch and a Catch
abstract: The company completed a successful test flight of the most powerful rocket ever built. Some residents near the Texas site experienced shaking as the landing vehicle was caught by mechanical arms.
lead_paragraph: SpaceX pulled off a feat of technical wizardry on Sunday, not only flying a 233-foot rocket booster back to its launch site, but also catching it out of the air with two giant mechanical arms.

headline: New York Can Do Better Than Andrew Cuomo
abstract: Democrats should make it clear that Cuomo has no political future in New York — not in City Hall and not in Albany.
lead_paragraph: There are many ways for New York City to turn the page on Mayor Eric Adams.

headline: It’s OK if You Haven’t Gotten Your Flu Shot Yet
abstract: Public health agencies are pushing us to get flu vaccines too far ahead of the winter flu season.
lead_paragraph: Like many health care workers, I am required to receive my annual flu shot by the end of October. Every year, I wait until the last possible day to get vaccinated.

headline: Can We Please Just Find the Aliens Already?
abstract: NASA’s Europa Clipper mission represents something bigger than just the study of an icy moon of Jupiter.
lead_paragraph: Picture an ice-covered landscape, rough and rocky. Plumes of water vapor erupt from the surface. Tendrils of algae lurk in the bright white glaciers. Deep below the surface, microorganisms and other creatures cluster near hydrothermal vents, fissures in the ocean floor where life can thrive.

headline: This ‘Fake Sauce’ Is Truly Good
abstract: For your Sunday supper: hearty pasta al sugo finto, a vegetarian ragù that’s flavorful and frugal.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. There’s a term in Italian cooking, cucina povera. It translates literally as “kitchen of the poor,” but in practice means the kitchen of the frugal, the cooking of the thrifty and unwasteful. I think of it, myself, as the cuisine of the empty nester, of the dope who once again forgot to pick up sausages during the weekly shop, who doesn’t have a pound of ground beef in the freezer, who arrives at Sunday afternoon with only a decent pantry and a bunch of oldish vegetables in the crisper.

headline: I Write My Obituary, So I Can Live a Better Life
abstract: Readers offer their personal stories in response to a guest essay. Also: Trump and baseball; G.O.P. mirage machine; S.N.L. and Gerald Ford; unforeseen crises.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: SpaceX Achieves Its First-Ever ‘Chopsticks’ Landing
abstract: SpaceX launched and returned a large rocket booster to its Texas site, catching it with mechanical arms in its first-ever “chopsticks” landing.
lead_paragraph: SpaceX launched and returned a large rocket booster to its Texas site, catching it with mechanical arms in its first-ever “chopsticks” landing.

headline: Abdul Salaam, Quiet Member of the Jets’ ‘Sack Exchange,’ Dies at 71
abstract: A defensive tackle, he teamed with Joe Klecko, Mark Gastineau and Marty Lyons in the 1980s on a line that terrorized quarterbacks.
lead_paragraph: Abdul Salaam, an unassuming but important member of the ferocious Jets defensive line, known as the New York Sack Exchange, that preyed on quarterbacks in the 1980s, died on Tuesday in Cincinnati. He was 71.

headline: U.S. to Deploy Missile Defense System and About 100 Troops to Israel
abstract: The Pentagon announced it would send the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense battery and its crew as Israel considered retaliatory attacks against Iran.
lead_paragraph: The United States is sending an advanced missile defense system to Israel, along with about 100 American troops to operate it, the Pentagon announced on Sunday. It is the first deployment of U.S. forces to Israel since the Hamas-led attacks there on Oct. 7, 2023.

headline: After Hurricane Milton Left, My Town Revealed Itself
abstract: I had only recently moved to Tampa and before the storm didn’t feel connected to the place.
lead_paragraph: I spent most of my life in Green Bay, Wis., cheering on the Packers, frequenting supper clubs and becoming a pro in winter wardrobe layering. I was a Wisconsinite through and through and would have been happy to stay there the rest of my life.

headline: Review: Philharmonic Pays Tribute to Schoenberg
abstract: The New York Philharmonic under Matthias Pintscher brought dramatic urgency to “Pelleas und Melisande” in commemoration of the composer’s 150th birthday.
lead_paragraph: When Arnold Schoenberg conducted the premiere of “Pelleas und Melisande,” his symphonic poem based on the somber fairy-tale that inspired Debussy’s opera, in 1905, it was in front of a hostile Viennese audience. Reviews were “unusually violent,” the composer would later recall, with one critic suggesting he be committed to an asylum and banned from all access to music paper.

headline: Fisher-Price Recalls 2 Million ‘Snuga Swings’ After Five Infant Deaths
abstract: The U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission announced the recall, which one of its commissioners said was “doomed to fail.”
lead_paragraph: After at least five infants died while sleeping in a product made by Fisher-Price, the company has recalled more than two million of the product, the Snuga Swing, because it poses a suffocation risk, according to the recall.

headline: The Painter Titus Kaphar Wanted a Bigger Canvas, So He Made a Film
abstract: His first feature, “Exhibiting Forgiveness,” which opens Oct. 18, features paintings now on view at Gagosian in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: We often scrutinize an artist’s work, searching for autobiographical clues. But in Titus Kaphar’s recent paintings, and in his new film, “Exhibiting Forgiveness,” such close reading is unnecessary. His life experience is laid bare, in all its poignant and — sometimes agonizing — pain.

headline: Woman Who Tried to Smuggle 29 Turtles Wrapped in Socks Pleads Guilty
abstract: A resident of Hong Kong was caught while paddling across a lake from Vermont to Canada in an inflatable kayak with the Eastern box turtles in a duffle bag, according to court records.
lead_paragraph: A woman pleaded guilty on Friday to attempting to smuggle 29 Eastern box turtles, a protected species, that were individually wrapped in socks inside a duffle bag as she tried to paddle in an inflatable kayak across a lake from Vermont to Canada over the summer, officials said.

headline: The Ground Game: Harris’s Turnout Machine vs. Trump’s Unproven Alliance
abstract: Both parties are frenetically chasing votes in the counties that could very well decide the election. In many places, inexperienced conservative groups are going up against a more tightly organized Democratic operation.
lead_paragraph: In the final weeks of the 2024 election, Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump are staking their chances on two radically different theories of how to win: one tried-and-true, the other untested in modern presidential campaigns.

headline: Biden Calls for Bipartisan Effort to Help Areas Hit by Storms
abstract: The president surveyed damage in Florida and announced $612 million for projects to help the electric grid in areas affected by Hurricanes Helene and Milton.
lead_paragraph: Standing in front of one of the many houses wrecked by Hurricane Milton in Florida, President Biden said on Sunday that the storm was devastating for those who lost homes, businesses or relatives, even as he expressed relief that the storm was not as destructive as anticipated.

headline: Monday Briefing: The U.S. to Deploy Troops to Israel
abstract: Plus, 200,000 stories of Modern Love.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon said that it was sending an advanced missile defense system to Israel, along with about 100 American troops to operate it. It is the first deployment of U.S. forces to Israel since the Hamas-led attacks there on Oct. 7, 2023.

headline: Just Over the Border from Israel, a Hezbollah Cache of Explosives and Mines
abstract: Israel’s military showed journalists parts of what it said was Hezbollah’s deeply entrenched military infrastructure across the border in southern Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: We had entered southern Lebanon early Sunday afternoon in a convoy of armored vehicles through a gap punched by Israeli forces in the snaking border wall.

headline: One Who Walks the Walk
abstract: Dana Edwards makes his New York Times Crossword debut, and it’s a slam dunk.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Harris Sends a Secret Weapon to a Georgia Fish Fry: Bill Clinton
abstract: With early voting set to begin in Georgia, the Harris campaign is sending the former president to get out the vote in rural areas.
lead_paragraph: The smell of fried fish was lingering on Sunday afternoon, and there was Bill Clinton beneath a tree, wearing a Harris-Walz camouflage cap and edging closer and closer to his modest audience the longer he spoke.

headline: Harris Suggests Trump Is ‘Weak and Unstable’ in Pointed Challenge
abstract: Kamala Harris asked why Donald J. Trump had not released his medical records, appeared on “60 Minutes” or agreed to a second debate.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris challenged former President Donald J. Trump on Sunday for refusing to do what she has done in recent days: release a report on his health, sit for a “60 Minutes” interview and commit to another presidential debate.

headline: A Little Bit of Power
abstract: With enough power to make a small difference, but only that, what do you do?
lead_paragraph: On This Week’s Episode:

headline: Man Is Arrested on Weapons Charges Heading to Trump Rally in Coachella, Officials Say
abstract: Law-enforcement officials said that former President Donald J. Trump was not in any danger, and the man was released on bail.
lead_paragraph: A man was arrested and accused of illegal weapons possession as he was trying to enter former President Donald J. Trump’s rally in Coachella, Calif., on Saturday evening, the Riverside County sheriff’s office said on Sunday.

headline: China Holds War Games Encircling Taiwan in Warning to Island’s Leader
abstract: Scores of Chinese aircraft and dozens of ships surrounded Taiwan, after President Lai Ching-te rejected Beijing’s claim over the island.
lead_paragraph: China held large-scale military drills in the waters and skies surrounding Taiwan on Monday, a show of force that signaled the growing threat of Beijing’s ability to choke the self-governing island that China claims as its own.

headline: Harris Rallies in North Carolina
abstract: The vice president criticized former President Donald J. Trump, calling him “weak and unstable.”
lead_paragraph: The vice president criticized former President Donald J. Trump, calling him “weak and unstable.”

headline: Quote of the Day: Government Policies to Raise Fertility Rates Haven’t Led to Baby Booms
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 14, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Living with your mom is not the best romantic environment for finding your lifelong partner.”

headline: How Israel’s Army Uses Palestinians as Human Shields in Gaza
abstract: Israeli soldiers and Palestinian former detainees say troops have regularly forced captured Gazans to carry out life-threatening tasks, including inside Hamas tunnels.
lead_paragraph: After Israeli soldiers found Mohammed Shubeir hiding with his family in early March, they detained him for roughly 10 days before releasing him without charge, he said.

headline: No Corrections: Oct. 14, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 14, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Wranglers’ and ‘Elsbeth’
abstract: A CW documentary, inspired by the series “Yellowstone,” shows what real life in ranch country looks like. And “The Good Wife” spinoff is back for a second season.
lead_paragraph: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, Oct. 14-20 Details and times are subject to change.

headline: What China’s Leaders Grasp About Another Trump Term
abstract: Trump remains well outside a bipartisan consensus on competing with China.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of the Biden presidency, many of us serving in the National Security Council gathered to read the intelligence and reached a key conclusion: The 2020s would be what we called the “decisive decade” in U.S. competition with China.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: A Hezbollah attack on an Israeli military base.
lead_paragraph: A drone strike by Hezbollah on a base in northern Israel killed four soldiers and wounded dozens of other people, the Israeli military said yesterday, in what some saw as evidence of a worrisome gap in Israel’s air defense systems. Cross-border attacks by the militants have continued despite heavy Israeli bombardments aimed at Hezbollah targets in Lebanon.

headline: An Artist Signed Over His Career to Investors. Now He Wants It Back.
abstract: Bjarne Melgaard’s rise in the art world came with strings attached and an unusual contract with investors. Now he’s suing to regain control of his artwork.
lead_paragraph: The “Main Agreement” was supposed to be the final agreement, a contract to end all other contracts between two investors and Bjarne Melgaard, a provocative Norwegian artist who had drawn notice at the 2011 Venice Biennale with an exhibition about a fictional movement of gay terrorists.

headline: In Heated House Race, a Moderate Republican Goes Full Trump
abstract: Representative Marc Molinaro of New York, running against Josh Riley, a Democrat, has accused recent immigrants of committing violent crimes and killing pets.
lead_paragraph: Representative Marc Molinaro has spent his decades of public service building a reputation as a particular brand of New York Republican: a measured and courteous pragmatist more interested in responsible governing than in ideological battles.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: China’s Stock Markets Rebound on Promises to Help Businesses
abstract: Assurances from government officials on plans to strengthen the private sector offset a lack of specifics about economic stimulus.
lead_paragraph: Stock prices rose in China on Monday, as investors welcomed government signals of renewed attempts to counter weakness in the economy by borrowing more and easing oversight of the private sector.

headline: Israel Attacks Tent Camp at Gaza Hospital
abstract: People worked through smoke and darkness to extinguish fires and look through debris following the deadly attack on Deir al-Balah.
lead_paragraph: People worked through smoke and darkness to extinguish fires and look through debris following the deadly attack on Deir al-Balah.

headline: Learning a Language, and a Few Life Lessons, in France
abstract: After a painful breakup, the author travels to Provence for a language immersion homestay and learns the value of facing up to mistakes.
lead_paragraph: When I booked a one-on-one intensive language program in France, I envisioned a dreamy getaway, where I could practice French while getting to know Provence through the eyes of a local.

headline: Kash Patel: The Magical Rise of a Self-Described ‘Wizard’ in Trump World
abstract: The MAGA loyalist Mr. Patel aims to run the C.I.A. if Donald Trump wins the presidency. But critics say his swagger masks deep inexperience.
lead_paragraph: As President Donald J. Trump battled public outrage in the summer of 2019 over his effort to enlist Ukraine in digging up dirt on former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., he summoned a small group of top advisers to the Oval Office. Among them was Charles Kupperman, the deputy national security adviser, who was surprised to see a relatively low-level staff member in one of the four chairs arrayed before the president’s desk: Kashyap “Kash” Patel.

headline: Russia’s Latest Target in Africa: U.S.-Funded Anti-Malaria Programs
abstract: Scientists fighting the spread of infectious diseases on the continent have been targeted online by pro-Russian activists, part of an effort to spread fear and mistrust of the West.
lead_paragraph: The scientists sifting through thousands of genetically modified mosquito larvae in a laboratory in Burkina Faso were trying to stop the spread of malaria, one of the biggest killers on the African continent.

headline: Why ‘Unbalanced’ Muscles Can Cause You Pain
abstract: Repeatedly doing the same type of activity — whether it’s running, lifting or sitting — can have serious downsides.
lead_paragraph: When you head out for your daily run, with each stride you’re strengthening your quadriceps, your hamstrings and your upper calf muscles. The muscles on the sides of your hips, however, aren’t growing much.

headline: I Froze My Eggs to Reclaim My Right to Rest
abstract: As a Latina, I was taught that my purpose was to produce. But I needed a break.
lead_paragraph: I watched the ultrasound screen as my OB-GYN counted my follicles, the egg-producing sacs in my ovaries. They looked like the black holes in NASA images. I had more than 30 inside me. The sight unnerved me. My doctor seemed excited. “Those are some juicy-looking ovaries!” she said.

headline: How Healthy Is Broccoli?
abstract: The dinnertime standard is a nutritional multitasker.
lead_paragraph: Children may not want to hear this, but broccoli more than deserves its place on our plates. The florets and stems are filled with nutrients that help keep your heart and bones healthy — and may reduce the risk of cancer.

headline: Why Controlling Blood Sugar Is Crucial for Your Health
abstract: How often should you test your glucose and A1C? How do food, sleep and exercise affect blood sugar? Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: More than one in three adults in the United States has prediabetes, higher-than-normal blood sugar levels that can lead to Type 2 diabetes. And more than one in 10 has diabetes, characterized by still higher blood sugar levels that can eventually lead to eye problems, heart disease, a stroke, nerve damage and other serious health issues.

headline: A Fact Checker Reflects on Our Age of Political Lying
abstract: In “Beyond the Big Lie,” Bill Adair worries that the world of spin and fabrication in America has gotten out of hand.
lead_paragraph: In 2002, Bill Adair, who was then a political reporter for The St. Petersburg Times, took note of a new neighbor on his block in Arlington, Va. Mike Pence had recently become a congressman, and moved in four doors down. Their families became fast friends, and Adair came to respect Pence, especially as a politician willing to live in hostile territory: Pretty much everyone else on the block was a Democrat.

headline: In Rural Wisconsin, Race Is an Undercurrent of the Presidential Election
abstract: Former President Donald Trump’s recent attacks on his opponent could affect the vote. “It’s a stirring of the pot,” one voter said.
lead_paragraph: The signs are everywhere that Sauk County, Wis., is a divided place.

headline: Food Is What We Have In Common. Why Don’t We Hear More From the Candidates About It?
abstract: Food is the springboard to talk about a host of issues, including climate, economic justice, public health and labor.
lead_paragraph: In a surprising turn of events, the presidential candidates have been talking about food. Food can be a winning topic, but we need to hear much more.

headline: The Toxic Sludge That Ate Tennessee
abstract: The 2008 coal ash spill was among the biggest industrial disasters in U.S. history. In a new book, Jared Sullivan recounts the accident, the lawsuits and the lasting damage.
lead_paragraph: A concise summary of Jared Sullivan’s “Valley So Low” is offered halfway through the book by its hero, Jim Scott, a plain-talking, suspender-wearing, Skittles-addicted plaintiff’s lawyer: “They had a toxic tub of goop, and it blew up.”

headline: American Sign Language Brings New Layers to ‘American Idiot’
abstract: Performed simultaneously in sign language and sung English, a Los Angeles revival of the Green Day musical finds new ways to communicate rage and angst.
lead_paragraph: Inside the Mark Taper Forum in downtown Los Angeles on a recent Wednesday, the air was saturated with stage fog and preshow jitters. The first performance of a revival of Green Day’s “American Idiot” was just hours away, and the choreographer Jennifer Weber had some final instructions for the cast members, who were wearing their costumes — combat boots, eyeliner, enough artfully ripped jeans to fill a Hot Topic — while they ran through dance movements onstage. Weber, microphone in hand, sang the song “Homecoming” as she demonstrated choreography:

headline: A Painter With an Eye for the Ridiculous
abstract: The artist Ambera Wellmann’s work explores sex and climate change, while incorporating mermaids, tarot cards and memes.
lead_paragraph: When the Canadian artist Ambera Wellmann painted “Strobe” (2021), a Surrealist beach landscape measuring 30 feet in length, she had just moved to New York, where she’d found representation with Company Gallery. Before that, she’d produced relatively small works, but now she was thinking big. “New York loves sensationalism in a way that’s kind of refreshing,” she says. “People like to make a splash.”

headline: Killing of Japanese Boy Leaves Chinese Asking: Is This My Country?
abstract: Angry at what they view as China’s state-led xenophobia, taught in schools and prevalent online, some people are taking action, even at personal risk.
lead_paragraph: A Japanese boy was stabbed on his way to school in China on Sept. 18. That’s the date when, nearly a century earlier in 1931, Japan invaded China.

headline: Polio Threatens Gaza Today. Tomorrow, It Could Be Cholera.
abstract: The success of the polio vaccination campaign in Gaza shouldn’t obfuscate the threat of other diseases.
lead_paragraph: In August, health officials recorded the first case of polio in Gaza in more than 25 years, in an unvaccinated 10-month-old baby whose lower left leg became paralyzed by the virus. Sadness and frustration washed over me when I first heard the news. It is outrageous that polio — which is highly contagious and can cause paralysis, respiratory failure, cardiovascular collapse and even death — has been permitted to reappear in Gaza after being nearly eradicated across the globe.

headline: Formerly Classified Documents Get the Fine Art Treatment
abstract: Hundreds of declassified U.S. Army photos are featured in the new book “Fashion Army.”
lead_paragraph: While scouring the internet some years back for obscure images of foods from the 1970s, Matthieu Nicol, a photo researcher in Paris, happened upon a trove of freely available pictures recently declassified by the U.S. Army.

headline: A Reporter’s Shield Law Is Vital to Prevent Abuses of Power
abstract: The PRESS Act has unanimous support in the House, but a few senators are blocking it.
lead_paragraph: Governments often chafe at the presence of a free press. The reason is simple: A robust and independent news media keeps a sharp eye on government and, when necessary, exposes abuse of power, corruption, incompetence and waste.

headline: The 25 Best Restaurants in Portland, Ore., Right Now
abstract: The dining capital of the Pacific Northwest remains one of America’s great culinary cities.
lead_paragraph: In the Where to Eat: 25 Best series, we’re highlighting our favorite restaurants in cities across the United States. These lists will be updated as restaurants close and open, and as we find new gems to recommend. As always, we pay for all of our meals and don’t accept free dishes.

headline: How Wall St. Is Subtly Shaping the Harris Economic Agenda
abstract: The vice president has repeatedly incorporated suggestions from business executives into her economic agenda.
lead_paragraph: When two of Vice President Kamala Harris’s closest advisers arrived in New York last month, they were seeking advice. The Democratic nominee was preparing to give her most far-reaching economic speech, and Tony West, Ms. Harris’s brother-in-law, and Brian Nelson, a longtime confidant, wanted to know how the city’s powerful financiers thought she should approach it.

headline: America Needs More Children. JD Vance’s Shame Game Won’t Get Us There.
abstract: David French argues the solution is simpler than we think.
lead_paragraph: Despite concerns over the falling birthrate, especially on the right, the Times Opinion columnist David French recognizes that the push to have more families — and bigger ones — has become problematic. In this audio essay, French explains why he thinks the recent political conversation on the topic reveals “the worst form of natalism.”

headline: In a Tight Presidential Race, Third-Party Candidates Present a Wild Card
abstract: In every battleground state this year, there is at least one third-party or independent candidate on the ballot. The Democrats have been more openly concerned than Republicans.
lead_paragraph: With a month to go before what is widely expected to be an extraordinarily close election, an extra element of unpredictability looms: In every battleground state, there is at least one third-party or independent presidential candidate on the ballot.

headline: The Wildly Subversive Music of Soviet Ukraine
abstract: An archival label in the United States was going to release a huge compilation of records from the U.S.S.R. Then Russia invaded Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Eugene Hutz still owns his copy of “Slayed?,” a 1972 album released the year he was born by the British bad boys Slade that his father purchased on the Ukrainian black market. Its spine is now lined with tape, its cover deeply ringed by the record inside. But for Hutz, 52, it remains a powerful talisman of rock ’n’ roll’s transformative potential, even amid oppressive regimes.

headline: Russian Oil Flows Through Western ‘Price Cap’ as Shadow Fleet Grows
abstract: A report shows how Russia has largely evaded sanctions aimed at limiting its revenue from oil sales.
lead_paragraph: A plan hatched by wealthy Western nations to deprive Russia of oil revenue is largely faltering, a new report found, with the majority of the Kremlin’s seaborne oil exports evading restrictions that were supposed to limit the price of Russian crude.

headline: Isaac Hernández Brings Leading-Man Vibes to Ballet Theater
abstract: “He has it all,” said Susan Jaffe, the artistic leader of American Ballet Theater. Hernández, already a veteran star, is joining the company as a principal.
lead_paragraph: It was Isaac Hernández’s second week at American Ballet Theater, and he was feeling achy from rehearsals. But as soon as the pianist began to play, his body and eyes snapped to attention. It was his big entrance. He rushed across the studio in series of jumps, legs thwacking together in the air. He turned with one leg extended to the side. He did a circle of leaps that almost brushed the walls. He made the space feel small.

headline: $2 Million Homes in California
abstract: A 1924 Spanish Revival house in Los Angeles, a 1962 midcentury-modern house in San Rafael, and a recently remodeled 1916 house in Oakland.
lead_paragraph: This four-bedroom, three-bath house is in the Lafayette Square Historic Protection Overlay Zone, a semi-gated neighborhood in central Los Angeles recognized for its well-kept, stately homes showcasing popular architectural styles of the 1920s and 1930s. On this block are a mix of Tudor-revival, Mediterranean-revival and Spanish-revival homes. Public elementary and middle schools are nearby, as is a branch of the Los Angeles Public Library.

headline: They’re ‘Saturday Night Live’ … and You’re Not
abstract: With so many players involved in Jason Reitman’s new movie about “S.N.L.,” here’s a guide to the real-life personalities.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to get lost watching “Saturday Night”: Jason Reitman’s new film drops us backstage at a moment of maximum confusion — 90 minutes before the 1975 debut of a new NBC show called “Saturday Night.” At the center of all the hubbub is creator-producer Lorne Michaels (played by Gabriel LaBelle), who’s been the one constant at “S.N.L.” over most of the show’s 50 seasons. But what about all the other characters rushing about, wringing their hands over whether this show will actually make it to air? Here’s a guide:

headline: Growing Darkness, October Light: A Backyard Census
abstract: I wish you could see what happens to the magnificent colors of berry and bird and flower in the slanting autumn light.
lead_paragraph: There’s hardly a spot of color on the hardwood trees in our yard, but the light is glorious, as it always is in October, and the signs of fall are unmistakable. The pokeweed, in full berry-laden splendor at the end of September, has been reduced to drooping leaves and magenta stems. Likewise the beautyberry and arrowwood shrubs, each picked down to the woody stems by cardinals and blue jays and mockingbirds and all manner of other creatures in this small, teeming yard.

headline: Three Weeks to Go, and That’s All Anyone Is Sure Of
abstract: It’s been a long year. That won’t stop it from being a very long 22 days.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, Kamala Harris sure seems proud of her gun ownership, doesn’t she?

headline: Will Leopard Print Ever Go Out of Style?
abstract: A reader is puzzled by the popularity of animal print in women’s fashion. Our critic offers an explanation for its appeal.
lead_paragraph: Leopard print — indeed, all animal prints, including zebra, python, cow and many not actually found in nature — have been with us since our long-ago ancestors turned the pelts of the animals they killed for food into clothing. Its role as a signifier has changed according to time and context, but it has never really disappeared, even as fur itself has fallen out of favor. While the lion may be king of the jungle, the leopard, or at least the leopard’s spots, is the king of fashion.

headline: The Trump Voters Who Don’t Believe Trump
abstract: When the former president endorses violence and proposes using the government to attack his enemies, many of his supporters assume it’s just an act.
lead_paragraph: One of the more peculiar aspects of Donald J. Trump’s political appeal is this: A lot of people are happy to vote for him because they simply do not believe he will do many of the things he says he will.

headline: How Climate Disasters Are Making Mobile Homes a Huge Risk
abstract: Millions of Americans, many poor and vulnerable, live in mobile and manufactured homes. When catastrophe strikes, they’re often on their own.
lead_paragraph: By the time the murky brown water in the house reached his chest, Joe Rogers realized it was too late to leave safely. Then, in an instant, his mobile home shifted violently, creating a wave that swept up furniture and trapped his wife, Sandra, in their bedroom.

headline: OpenAI Could Be a Force for Good if It Can Address These Issues First
abstract: The artificial intelligence start-up behind ChatGPT needs a legal structure that ensures its commitments can be enforced.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI, the artificial intelligence start-up behind ChatGPT, is now worth as much as Goldman Sachs or AT&T. OpenAI has also said it intends to shed its status as a nonprofit to become a for-profit business within two years. Outside experts and its employees have expressed concern that as a result, the company will shy away from its founding purpose — to build safe A.I. to “benefit all of humanity” — in favor of earning profits for investors.

headline: Fitting In Was Never Randy Newman’s Jam
abstract: A biography of the singer behind “You’ve Got a Friend in Me” and “Short People” considers a complicated man with a satirical edge.
lead_paragraph: Randy Newman was a nepo baby, a sprig of musical royalty. Three of his uncles were Hollywood film composers. One received 45 Oscar nominations and won nine times.

headline: Can Charlotte, N.C., Deliver for Kamala Harris?
abstract: Mecklenburg County leans liberal but has broken Democrats’ hearts in past elections with low voter turnout. A new party leader wants to change that.
lead_paragraph: When Democrats try to explain why their party has lost every presidential and Senate race in North Carolina since 2008, they often point to an unexpected place: Mecklenburg County, which includes the deep-blue city of Charlotte.

headline: 4 Creepy Books to Read This Halloween
abstract: Gilbert Cruz, editor of The New York Times Book Review, recommends four of his personal favorite creepy books to read in October.
lead_paragraph: Gilbert Cruz, editor of The New York Times Book Review, recommends four of his personal favorite creepy books to read in October.

headline: Where Polls Can Mess Up (and What Pollsters Do About It)
abstract: Conducting a poll isn’t an exact science. The process is susceptible to lots of common problems and baked-in biases — more than just the “margin of error.”
lead_paragraph: With less than a month until Election Day, you may be paying more attention to political polls, and starting to wonder how much you ought to trust them.

headline: NASA Launches Europa Clipper to Explore an Ocean Moon’s Habitability
abstract: The spacecraft lifted off Monday on a SpaceX Falcon Heavy rocket, embarking on a nearly six-year journey to Jupiter.
lead_paragraph: Europa Clipper, the biggest interplanetary spacecraft that NASA has ever built, lifted off from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida early Monday afternoon.

headline: They Helped Build the Temple. Now, They’re Bringing It to the Screen.
abstract: Jeroboam Bozeman and Rennie Harris’s careers have wound through street and concert dance. The two shaped the movement in “Once Again (for the Very First Time).”
lead_paragraph: A man is falling from the sky. Even as he plummets, you can tell he’s a dancer: There is grace in the twisting of his wind-buffeted limbs. He lands not with a thud but a whisper, on the tips of his toes.

headline: Meteorologists Face Harassment and Death Threats Amid Hurricane Disinformation
abstract: Weather experts say the spiraling falsehoods, especially claims that the government is creating or controlling storms, have gotten out of hand.
lead_paragraph: A meteorologist based in Washington, D.C., was accused of helping the government cover up manipulating a hurricane. In Houston, a forecaster was repeatedly told to “do research” into the weather’s supposed nefarious origins. And a meteorologist for a television station in Lansing, Mich., said she had received death threats.

headline: State of the Race: A Close Race Gets Closer
abstract: There’s no sign that a deluge of surveys from Republican-aligned firms is meaningfully affecting the polling averages.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on the 2024 election.

headline: Harris Steps Up a Major Push for Black Voters
abstract: The vice president released a plan to help Black men financially, held interviews with two Black media outlets and put out targeted ads in battleground states.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris made a sweeping push on Monday to energize Black voters, among whom she faces slipping support, unveiling a plan to bolster the finances of Black men, appearing in interviews with two Black media outlets and releasing a pair of ads in battleground states targeted to that crucial voting group.

headline: Harris’s Final Challenge: Restore a Splintering Democratic Coalition
abstract: Defections from Black and Latino voters are making Kamala Harris more dependent on white, suburban voters — and complicating her path to victory.
lead_paragraph: In the final weeks of the presidential campaign, Vice President Kamala Harris is contending with erosion within the Democratic coalition that put Barack Obama and Joe Biden in the White House, and growing more dependent on white voters who historically aligned more with Republicans.

headline: Attention Kmart Shoppers: It’s Closing Time
abstract: As the last full-size Kmart in the continental United States prepares to close, shoppers reminisced about the store that once sold everything, everywhere.
lead_paragraph: When Chrissy Economos and Gloria McCourtney heard that the last full-size Kmart in the mainland United States was closing down, they knew they had to pay their respects, even if the store was more than 1,300 miles away.

headline: Three Receive Nobel in Economics for Research on Global Inequality
abstract: Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson and James Robinson shared the award for their work on explaining the gaps in prosperity between nations.
lead_paragraph: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences was awarded on Monday to Daron Acemoglu and Simon Johnson, both of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and to James Robinson of the University of Chicago.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 492
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Oct. 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,214
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Oct. 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Inside an Unprepared Secret Service
abstract: The protection agency is facing questions after two assassination attempts on former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: After the assassination attempt on former President Donald J. Trump in Butler, Pa., Congress held hearings on the failures of the Secret Service, and its director, Kimberly Cheatle, stepped down.

headline: U.S. to Send Troops to Israel, and a Splintering Democratic Coalition
abstract: Plus, SpaceX makes a tricky “catch.”
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: A Political Misdiagnosis
abstract: Democrats imagined that they would become the majority party as America became more racially diverse. It’s not working out that way.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic Party has spent years hoping that demography would equal destiny. As the country became more racially diverse, Democrats imagined that they would become the majority party thanks to support from Asian, Black and Hispanic voters. The politics of America, according to this vision, would start to resemble the liberal politics of California.

headline: Michigan Republican Blames ‘Proofing Error’ for Misleading Ad in Black-Owned Newspaper
abstract: The state’s legislative Black caucus has asked the attorney general and a county prosecutor to investigate Tom Barrett’s congressional campaign for potential voter disenfranchisement.
lead_paragraph: Black state lawmakers in Michigan are calling on the state’s attorney general and a local county prosecutor to investigate the congressional campaign of Tom Barrett, a Republican, for an ad in a Black-owned newspaper that incorrectly listed Election Day as Nov. 6.

headline: In Texas, Execution Looms Despite Questions in Shaken Baby Case
abstract: Robert Roberson could be the first person put to death in connection with shaken baby syndrome. The state’s highest criminal court ruled in another case that the science had changed.
lead_paragraph: Texas is preparing for the execution this week of an autistic man, Robert Roberson, who was convicted of killing his 2-year-old daughter in a case that has drawn intense scrutiny for its reliance on a questionable diagnosis of shaken baby syndrome.

headline: Can Wall St. Help Harris Win Pennsylvania?
abstract: The vice president has raised huge sums and has won over many business leaders. Despite that, the presidential race remains tight in battleground states.
lead_paragraph: Despite entering the presidential contest only about three months ago, Vice President Kamala Harris has shattered fund-raising expectations — in large part because she has managed to win over many of the business donors who had been lukewarm about President Biden.

headline: Most Voters Have Been Offended by Trump. It’s Not Always a Deal Breaker.
abstract: Voters who said they had been offended by Donald J. Trump, but not recently, supported him by a wide margin.
lead_paragraph: The vast majority of voters across the United States say they have been offended at some point by former President Donald J. Trump. But a sizable number of those voters say that has not stopped them from supporting him.

headline: Russia Is Clawing Back Land Taken by Ukraine This Summer
abstract: Moscow’s forces have been recapturing some villages and land taken in a Ukrainian incursion into Russia. The advances could undermine Kyiv’s hopes of pushing Russia to the negotiating table.
lead_paragraph: Russia has recaptured a few villages in its western borderlands that Ukraine invaded over the summer, threatening Kyiv’s hold on territory it views as crucial leverage for pushing Moscow toward negotiations to end the war.

headline: Lilly Ledbetter, Whose Fight for Equal Pay Changed U.S. Law, Dies at 86
abstract: Her lawsuit against Goodyear helped pave the way for the 2009 Fair Pay Act, which was signed into law by former President Barack Obama.
lead_paragraph: Lilly Ledbetter had worked for 19 years at a tire plant in Alabama when she was sent an anonymous note: her pay was as much as $2,000 a month less than what men were receiving in the same supervisory job.

headline: Canada Expels Indian Diplomats, Accusing Them of Criminal Campaign
abstract: The Canadian police said the Indian government had orchestrated homicides and extortion in Canada to intimidate Sikh separatists. India, in return, kicked out Canadian diplomats.
lead_paragraph: Canada accused the Indian government on Monday of homicide and extortion intended to silence critics of India living in Canada, escalating a bitter dispute that began last year with an assassination of a Sikh activist.

headline: ‘Literally the Quickest Dinner Ever’
abstract: Yasmin Fahr’s five-star recipe features sweet shrimp, spicy ginger and creamy coconut milk — and has received rave reviews.
lead_paragraph: Of all the frozen proteins you could thaw for an easy weeknight dinner, shrimp are about the speediest and most elegant. Just pour the icy crustaceans into a bowl of cool tap water and let them soften on the counter while you prep the rest of your ingredients. By the time the garlic has been chopped and the spices are lined up on your counter, all the shrimp need is a friendly pat dry with a clean kitchen towel and they’re ready to go.

headline: Doctors, A.I. and Empathy for Patients
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay about ChatGPT’s bedside manner. Also: Breast cancer screenings; Walz’s missteps; supporting the mental health of schoolchildren.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How to Apply Blush Like a Professional
abstract: Tips from a “Saturday Night Live” cast member, a ballet dancer and a makeup artist.
lead_paragraph: “Blush is trending,” says the makeup artist Ernesto Casillas, referring to the product’s ongoing popularity on TikTok. “A lot of people are calling it ‘blush blindness’ when someone overapplies it.” For advice on creating a more nuanced look, we turned to three people well attuned to the product’s capabilities: the comedian, actress and “Saturday Night Live” cast member Chloe Fineman, known for her uncanny impressions; the American Ballet Theatre principal dancer James Whiteside, who returns to the stage this month for the company’s fall season; and Casillas, whose clients include the actresses Zendaya and Ayo Edebiri. Here are their tips.

headline: Italian Court Overturns Women’s Acquittals in ‘Bunga Bunga’ Legal Saga
abstract: The ruling sets the stage for yet another trial related to the scandal involving Silvio Berlusconi, the former prime minister of Italy who died last year.
lead_paragraph: After 14 years, the 21 women accused of helping to cover up Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s evening bacchanals had hoped that their long legal saga over the so-called “Bunga Bunga” scandal might be over.

headline: Trump and Harris Both Like a Child Tax Credit, but With Different Aims
abstract: Kamala Harris’s campaign is pushing a version of the credit intended to fight child poverty, while Donald J. Trump sees the program primarily as a tax cut for people higher up the income scale.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris has made an expanded child tax credit central to her campaign, and former President Donald J. Trump boasts, “I doubled the child tax credit.” With a quick look, voters might think the child-rearing subsidy the rare matter on which the rival candidates agree.

headline: Deadly Hezbollah Strike on Army Base Shows Israel’s Weakness Against Drones
abstract: Israel has one of the world’s best defenses against missiles and rockets, but struggles to detect slower-moving unmanned aircraft, experts said.
lead_paragraph: Minutes before a deadly Hezbollah drone strike on an army base in northern Israel this weekend, Israeli police officers notified the Air Force about reports of a suspicious aircraft, the police said. They were told not to worry because the aircraft was Israeli, prompting the officers to close the case.

headline: Amid a Water Crisis, England Asks: Who Should Be in Charge?
abstract: Four decades after privatization, calls to nationalize the water industry have swept across England and Wales amid sewage spills and rising household bills.
lead_paragraph: On its journey to the North Sea, the River Thames runs through Henley, a picturesque middle-class town about 35 miles west of London. The river is central to the town’s identity, which is known for its annual royal regatta and for being the location of the first boat race between Oxford and Cambridge Universities.

headline: Kamala Harris Sets an Interview With a Not-So-Friendly Outlet: Fox News
abstract: The interview, to be conducted by the anchor Bret Baier in Pennsylvania, will air Wednesday at 6 p.m. Eastern.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris has agreed to an interview with Fox News, the network said on Monday.

headline: In Jordan, a ‘Stunning’ Discovery Under Petra’s Ancient Stone
abstract: A recent excavation has unearthed 12 human skeletons and a chamber of grave offerings near Petra’s Treasury building, a UNESCO World Heritage site.
lead_paragraph: By the time Dr. Richard Bates swept his radar device over the sandstone of Petra’s ancient Treasury building, it had been more than two decades since anyone had so deeply probed the stone city’s grounds.

headline: Italy Sends Boat to Albania With Migrants Who Were Bound for Italian Shores
abstract: The plan was heralded by the Italian government as an innovative model to manage and deter immigration, and criticized by human rights groups.
lead_paragraph: Italy sent its first boat carrying migrants to Albania on Monday, part of a plan to send migrants who are rescued in the Mediterranean by Italian ships to detention centers in the Balkan nation, where their asylum claims will be assessed.

headline: What is the THAAD Antimissile System the U.S. Has Sent to Israel?
abstract: It can intercept missiles above Earth’s atmosphere, and is being deployed to defend against Iranian attacks.
lead_paragraph: The United States has sent a THAAD advanced missile defense system to Israel to thwart more attacks by Iran and its allies. Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said on Monday that the system was in place and could be “put into operation very quickly.”

headline: NASA Launches Mission to Study Jupiter’s Moon
abstract: Europa Clipper will study whether Europa, Jupiter’s fourth-largest moon, possesses ingredients and conditions favorable for life.
lead_paragraph: Europa Clipper will study whether Europa, Jupiter’s fourth-largest moon, possesses ingredients and conditions favorable for life.

headline: N.J. Transit Train Hits Tree on Track, Killing 1 and Injuring 23
abstract: A light rail train traveling south from Trenton collided with a chunk of tree, killing the train’s operator.
lead_paragraph: One person was killed and nearly two dozen others were injured in South Jersey on Monday morning when a New Jersey Transit light rail train struck a tree on the tracks, the commuter rail said.

headline: Another Trump Clemency Recipient Faces Domestic Violence-Related Charges
abstract: Philip Esformes is at least the seventh person to be charged with new crimes after receiving a second chance in the last days of the Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: A Florida man who received a commutation of a 20-year fraud sentence from President Donald J. Trump in 2020 — only to plead guilty this year to a related crime — was arrested on Sunday on domestic violence-related charges in South Florida.

headline: New Jersey Transit Train Hits Tree on Track, Killing Train Operator
abstract: Nearly two dozen people were injured when the light rail train collided with a chunk of tree in South Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two dozen people were injured when the light rail train collided with a chunk of tree in South Jersey.

headline: Read the document
abstract: Here are the records from Miami-Dade jail where Mr. Esformes was held after his arrest.
lead_paragraph: Here are the records from Miami-Dade jail where Mr. Esformes was held after his arrest.

headline: Conservative Activist Seizes on Passages From Harris Book
abstract: A report by Christopher Rufo says the Democratic presidential nominee copied five short passages for her 2009 book on crime. A plagiarism expert said the lapses were not serious.
lead_paragraph: The conservative activist Christopher Rufo published claims on Monday that Vice President Kamala Harris had copied portions of her 2009 book “Smart on Crime,” citing five sections that he said were lifted from widely available sites including Wikipedia and news reports.

headline: How Door Knocking Is Going in a Wisconsin Swing County
