headline: There Is No Precedent for Something Like This in American History
abstract: This is no ordinary election, and we cannot act like it is.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of his tenure, Gen. Mark Milley, who was the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff from 2019 to 2023, told Bob Woodward of The Washington Post that Donald Trump was a fundamental threat to the safety and integrity of the United States.

headline: Hate Noisy Restaurants? Stick This in Your Ear.
abstract: Apple earbuds and others can help you hear dining companions. Here’s how to use them.
lead_paragraph: Booking a table for two at Tao Downtown, I hesitated when I got to the box asking whether I had a special request. I did, but I wasn’t sure how it would go down. Would I be the first customer in history to ask for a noisy table?

headline: These Undecided Michigan Voters Really Aren’t All That Undecided
abstract: Many people I spoke to seemed reluctant to admit — even, perhaps, to themselves — that they were really going to vote for that person.
lead_paragraph: Cindy Jager was the lone worker on duty in the crammed aisles of an old-fashioned variety store overflowing with hardware and party supplies and fake pumpkins.

headline: What Do You Splurge On?
abstract: Whether it’s a pair of sneakers, new makeup, a concert or something else, when you have some extra cash, how do you spend it?
lead_paragraph: What was the last item or experience you splurged on? That is, something you didn’t necessarily need, but really wanted, and were willing to spend some extra cash to get. Did it make your life better?

headline: 9 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: Based on the time the serial killer Rodney Alcala appeared on “The Dating Game” in the midst of his crime spree, Anna Kendrick directs herself as the woman Alcala is competing for.

headline: At CBS, Everything Old Is New Again, Including ‘NCIS’
abstract: This week the network rolled out an “NCIS” spinoff, a “Young Sheldon” spinoff, a “Good Wife” spinoff and … “Matlock”?
lead_paragraph: CBS is reconvening this week, premiering a dozen of its dramas and comedies, including 10 of last season’s 15 most-watched scripted shows. You might dismiss the network’s dominance of the broadcast ratings as a case of being the top dog on a small playground, but the seven million to 10 million viewers each of those shows drew — before any streaming numbers were added — probably don’t care much about your opinion.

headline: The Evidence for a Big Youth Gender Gap and a Right Turn for Young Men
abstract: Young men are much more Republican than young women, the best data suggests, and may wind up backing Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: In the year’s first wave of New York Times/Siena College battleground polls back in May, the No. 1 predictor of whether someone had defected from Joe Biden was whether the respondent was Middle Eastern or North African — a sign of the political toll of the war in Gaza.

headline: How to Set Boundaries (When It Doesn’t Come Naturally)
abstract: We have some useful tips from experts. But no worries if you’re not ready!
lead_paragraph: When I was in my early 20s, the apex of my people-pleasing years, I dated an aspiring poet.

headline: The Hidden Politics of Disorder
abstract: The crime researcher Charles Fain Lehman discusses why people feel unsafe, even as violent crime rates have dropped.
lead_paragraph: During the pandemic, there was a rise in violent crime. But by 2023, violent crime was near its lowest level in over 50 years. But that year, Gallup found that 77 percent of Americans said they believed that crime was increasing. I hear that in my everyday life. People talk to me about their sense that where they live is less safe, and they’re mad about it. This was constant when I lived in San Francisco. It’s constant in New York, where I live now.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Sean Baker’s latest film, “Anora.”
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Sean Baker’s latest film, “Anora.”

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Oct. 18, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Harris Will Campaign With the Obamas Next Week
abstract: Barack and Michelle Obama will make their first campaign appearances alongside Kamala Harris at rallies in Georgia and Michigan.
lead_paragraph: Here come the Obamas.

headline: U.S. Indicts 2 Linked to Oct. 7 Cyberattack on Israeli Warning System
abstract: The Justice Department has accused two Sudanese brothers of cyberattacks on U.S. infrastructure as well as preventing possibly lifesaving alerts from reaching Israelis as the Hamas attack unfolded.
lead_paragraph: It was early morning on Oct. 7, 2023, and Hamas fighters had just breached the Israeli border, when Ahmed Omer, a young Sudanese man with an aptitude for computers, launched a different kind of attack.

headline: 200 Years Later, Still Trying to Define the Midwest
abstract: From the geographic boundaries to the values and friendliness, people have debated what defines the region essentially since it was labeled the Midwest. It has taken on a renewed urgency this election year.
lead_paragraph: State fairs. Frozen custard. The jingle for the home-improvement chain Menards. Rolling corn fields, sweatshirts with shorts, steel plant smokestacks and swing-state politics.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,218
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Oct. 19, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 496
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Oct. 19, 2024
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: The Death of Yahya Sinwar, and Execution Halted in Shaken Baby Case
abstract: Plus, closing time for Kmart.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Israel Kills The Leader of Hamas
abstract: Yahya Sinwar, the leader of Hamas, was killed by Israeli forces in Gaza. What does that mean for cease-fire talks?
lead_paragraph: Yahya Sinwar, the leader of Hamas, played a central role in planning the deadly assault on Israel on Oct. 7, 2023, that set off the war in Gaza. His killing was a major win for Israel, and prompted calls from Israeli leaders for Hamas to surrender.

headline: Biden, in Germany, Urges Unwavering Support for Ukraine
abstract: The president, in a trip to Berlin that lasted barely a day, also joined Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany in expressing new optimism about the prospect for peace in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Sidelined at home in the waning days of the campaign to succeed him, President Biden made a brief return to the global spotlight on Friday, rallying allies in support of Ukraine, and basking in praise from the German government.

headline: The Death of Hamas’s Leader
abstract: Yahya Sinwar is dead. Could this be a turning point?
lead_paragraph: The killing of Yahya Sinwar — the chief architect of the Oct. 7 attack — is the most tangible victory that Israel has yet been able to claim in its more than yearlong war against Hamas. Almost as soon as the Oct. 7 attack happened, Israeli leaders vowed to hold Sinwar accountable. So long as he was still directing Hamas’s operations from the tunnels of Gaza, Israel could not credibly claim to have achieved its goals.

headline: The Ultrarich Descend on Paris as Art Basel Comes to Town
abstract: The inaugural edition at the restored Grand Palais featured works at price levels never seen before at Paris’s fall art fair.
lead_paragraph: Americans flocked to the city in droves. A warm fall sun shone through the vast glass roof. The dealers brought their very best pieces. And the Art Basel brand did what it does.

headline: Sinwar’s Death Could Shake but Not Topple Hamas, Experts Say
abstract: Analysts call the killing of several Hamas leaders, including Yahya Sinwar, a deep blow to the Palestinian militant group, but expect it to keep fighting.
lead_paragraph: He was there from the early days of Hamas, rose through the ranks to lead the organization and equipped it for the deadliest assault on Israel in its history.

headline: Impeachment of Kenya’s Deputy President Could Signal Further Turmoil
abstract: It’s the first impeachment under the country’s new Constitution, but some are now calling for a similar move against President William Ruto.
lead_paragraph: Kenya’s Senate has voted to impeach the country’s deputy president, an unprecedented move that risks stirring a major political crisis and potential unrest in an East African nation widely viewed as a stable democracy in an increasingly volatile region.

headline: What’s at Stake in a Strained Microsoft-OpenAI Partnership
abstract: The alliance between the technology giant and the company behind OpenAI has been hugely consequential — but a disruption could shake up the A.I. race.
lead_paragraph: Few partnerships in the technology world in recent history have been as transformative as Microsoft’s alliance with OpenAI, which paired a computing giant with a start-up that is among the leaders in artificial intelligence.

headline: Much of the Emerald Isle Is an Ecological Desert. He’s Trying to Change That.
abstract: Eoghan Daltun rewilded his land in West Cork and wants more of Ireland to do the same.
lead_paragraph: Is Ireland really all that green? Ecologically speaking, the answer is no, says Eoghan Daltun, a sculptor who restored a patch of native rainforest in the Beara Peninsula, on the country’s rugged southwestern coast.

headline: Money Market Rates Are Lower, Yes. But Compared to What?
abstract: Even with further Fed rate cuts likely, money market funds are a good alternative for stashing cash, and investors are still flocking to them, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: When money market interest rates broke above 5 percent last year, it was a wake-up call for many investors who had grown accustomed to getting almost nothing for their money at banks.

headline: Homeowners Tap Into Their Rising Home Equity
abstract: Balances on home equity lines of credit have risen along with home equity loans. Popular reasons for borrowing include home renovations and repairs and debt consolidation.
lead_paragraph: American homeowners have accrued hundreds of thousands of dollars in home equity and they’re increasingly borrowing against that value, even though interest rates remain high.

headline: J. G. Ballard, Secret Agent in Suburbia
abstract: A graphic tribute to the British novelist who documented the blight and brutality of the sleepy London outskirts from the 1970s into the 2000s.

headline: ‘It’s Florida, Man’ Reveals the Lives Behind Bizarre News Stories
abstract: The HBO series uses familiar comedic actors in cheeky re-enactments of real Florida events, most of them subjects of past viral news reports.
lead_paragraph: “It’s Florida, Man,” premiering Friday at 11 p.m., on HBO, takes a “Drunk History” approach to the intimacy and portraiture of “How To With John Wilson.” It uses familiar comedic actors in cheeky re-enactments of real events, but those events are all personal sagas; they are obscure and strange, sometimes disturbing and sometimes enchanting — and all very Florida.

headline: Judge Orders DeSantis Administration to Stop Threats Over Abortion-Rights Ad
abstract: The organization behind a campaign for an abortion-rights ballot measure sued the Florida governor’s administration over its threats of criminal prosecution against TV stations.
lead_paragraph: The administration of Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida must stop threatening television stations with criminal prosecution for airing a political ad in favor of enshrining abortion rights in the state’s Constitution, a federal judge ordered on Thursday.

headline: Tesla Self-Driving System Will Be Investigated by Safety Agency
abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said it was looking into what Elon Musk’s electric car company called the full self-driving system.
lead_paragraph: Tesla’s plan to build fleets of self-driving cars suffered a setback on Friday when the main federal auto safety regulator said it was investigating whether the technology was to blame for four collisions, including one that killed a pedestrian.

headline: Democrats’ Report Calls Trump Hotel Business Unethical and Unconstitutional
abstract: Democrats on the House Oversight Committee said the former president overcharged the Secret Service and accepted money from officials and people who were seeking pardons and appointments.
lead_paragraph: House Democrats on Friday accused former President Donald J. Trump of accepting “hundreds of unconstitutional and ethically suspect payments” through the Trump International Hotel in 2017 and 2018, moving weeks before the election to remind voters of the ethical issues raised by his refusal to divest from his businesses while in office.

headline: CVS Ousts C.E.O. as Sluggish Growth Spooks Investors
abstract: Shares of the health care conglomerate dropped after the sudden departure of Karen Lynch and a downbeat update on the state of the company’s finances.
lead_paragraph: CVS Health abruptly ousted its chief executive, Karen S. Lynch, on Friday as the pharmacy and health care conglomerate struggled with sluggish growth and faced pressure from investors.

headline: Before the First Kiss, Plenty of Drives Home
abstract: Jocelyn DeGroot-Lutzner grew up four blocks from Ephream Seyoum in West Philadelphia. But the two didn’t meet until she applied for a job at his family’s Eritrean restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Jocelyn Rose DeGroot-Lutzner was thinking about her father when she wandered into the West Philadelphia restaurant Dahlak in 2013 to apply for a bartending job.

headline: Thomas Tuchel and the Moral Maze
abstract: An outcry over the hiring of a German to lead England’s national team was predictable. But don’t dismiss every objection out of hand.
lead_paragraph: As a rule of thumb, it pays to look at the cast of characters already arrayed on one side of an argument before deciding to join them. When that list starts with Nigel Farage, swallows up Sam Allardyce and eventually sprawls across the editorial board of The Daily Mail, it should, really, serve as a burning red flag.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: With the general election just weeks away, the hosts discussed former President Trump’s health and his bizarre town hall in Pennsylvania, as well as Vice President Harris’s appearance on Fox News.
lead_paragraph: With the general election just weeks away, the hosts discussed former President Trump’s health and his bizarre town hall in Pennsylvania, as well as Vice President Harris’s appearance on Fox News.

headline: Trump Among New York’s Elites at a Charity Dinner: It Got Awkward
abstract: There were grudge matches and sycophancy in equal measure at the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation Dinner. “Isn’t it just exciting, what’s going on,” Donald Trump said.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and the assorted fat cats to whom he was speaking seemed to be processing many complicated emotions all at once.

headline: How to Spot the Most Common Skin Condition
abstract: Experts explain what causes eczema and how to deal with it.
lead_paragraph: When Oscar Brann imagined retirement, he pictured days spent fishing with his grandson, or doing yardwork at his home in Skowhegan, Maine.

headline: It’s Time for Tagine
abstract: Nargisse Benkabbou’s hearty and fragrant beef tagine with green beans, olives and preserved lemons, that is.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The texts are starting to come in, asking about Thanksgiving — who’s coming, how many birds, how many oysters, how many pies, what do we need? It’s exciting, a time to dream. I might fry a turkey this year, to go with the smoked one, to go with the oven-roasted one.

headline: France Struggles to Dry Out From Flash Flooding
abstract: Heavy rainfall and swollen rivers unleashed torrents of brackish water that cut off roads, swept away cars and swamped buildings.
lead_paragraph: Central and southern France were recovering on Friday from flooding that lashed the areas on Thursday, after heavy rainfall and swollen rivers unleashed torrents of muddy water that cut off roads, swept away cars and swamped buildings.

headline: Facing Murder Plot Accusations, India Aids U.S. but Is Stern With Canada
abstract: In both cases of plans targeting Sikh separatists, suspicions of New Delhi’s involvement have arisen. That has put India in a tight diplomatic position.
lead_paragraph: In a week of geopolitical intrigue, in which Canada broadened its accusations that India was plotting to kill Sikh citizens on its soil and the United States provided incriminating evidence in a similar case, one episode caused a furious rift and the other a more judicious response.

headline: JD Vance and the Fight for Pennsylvania’s Catholic Voters
abstract: The Republican vice-presidential nominee is the only Catholic on either national ticket. His politics resonate with many white conservative Catholics.
lead_paragraph: Three dozen Catholics from “Lebo,” as the Mt. Lebanon area of Pittsburgh is called, packed into Colleen Oxenreiter’s living room on a recent Friday evening. Lebo is a heavily Catholic neighborhood, and her home was the one with a giant Trump sign in the yard, by her pumpkins.

headline: Chianti Classico Riservas to Find Right Now
abstract: These longer-aged wines were once notable for being too oaky and powerful. Now, producers are letting the gorgeous purity of the sangiovese grape shine through.
lead_paragraph: I could not have imagined, 10 years ago, that I would be extolling the virtues of Chianti Classico Riserva. But times have changed and here I am, doing exactly that.

headline: After Sinwar: What Is the Future of Gaza?
abstract: Responses to the killing of the Hamas leader. Also: Guarding against authoritarianism; medical dramas; expressing sympathy to mourners; October light.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Yes, Ambassadors Can Get Away With Murder
abstract: Diplomatic immunity is one of the oldest and most respected rules of international law.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the Canadian government accused India’s High Commissioner, (the equivalent of an ambassador in commonwealth countries), and five other diplomats of participating in a vast criminal conspiracy that used homicide and extortion to silence critics of India living in Canada.

headline: Five International Movies to Stream Now
abstract: In this month’s picks, a shy vampire in Canada comes of age, two men in India spar over a parking spot and a Chilean secretary dreams of life as a killer.
lead_paragraph: Stream it on Netflix.

headline: Trump Defends Adams, Arguing Both Are Being ‘Persecuted’
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams, a Democrat, and Donald J. Trump, the Republican former president, are strange bedfellows as both face legal challenges.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams’s federal indictment on corruption charges has left him with few political friends, but he has found a kindred spirit and a surprisingly steadfast ally in Donald J. Trump.

headline: The Orionids Meteor Shower Is Peaking. Here’s How to Watch.
abstract: This event is linked to Halley’s comet, and occurs as another comet, Tsuchinshan-ATLAS, remains visible. But a nearly full moon could interfere with some views.
lead_paragraph: Our universe might be chock-full of cosmic wonder, but you can observe only a fraction of astronomical phenomena with your naked eye. Meteor showers, natural fireworks that streak brightly across the night sky, are one of them.

headline: It Is ‘All About the Fish’ on Park Ave.
abstract: Avid and influential anglers turned out to honor Bob Rich Jr. at the Bonefish & Tarpon Trust’s annual gala in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, on a quiet stretch of Park Avenue, some of the most illustrious figures in fly fishing, marine science, conservation and frozen food gathered to celebrate one of the things that brings them all together — the sea.

headline: Judge Releases Redacted Trove of Evidence in Trump Election Case
abstract: The former president’s legal team had objected to any release of material, saying it would amount to election interference.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Friday ordered the release of a heavily redacted trove of evidence supporting the contention by federal prosecutors that former President Donald J. Trump illegally sought to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: Trump’s Claims That Blame Migrants: False or Misleading
abstract: The Trump campaign has consistently pointed to unauthorized immigration as the cause of a series of problems it says plagues the country. That is rarely actually the case.
lead_paragraph: To former President Donald J. Trump and his running mate, the root cause of many of the issues in the United States is simple.

headline: In Rare Move, Judge Changes Mind After 27 Years and Frees Brooklyn Man
abstract: Judge Frederic Block said his ideas about punishment had evolved since he sentenced Walter Johnson to five life terms in 1997. At age 90, he decided to take action.
lead_paragraph: In 1997, Walter Johnson stood before Judge Frederic Block in a Brooklyn federal courtroom after being convicted of robbery, cocaine possession and witness tampering, just the latest in a troubling series of crimes that involved guns, drugs and violence.

headline: At Comic Con, Emergency Tailors Keep Cosplayers in Character
abstract: Armed with glue guns, Popsicle sticks, safety pins and more, a hub of costume repairers stands at the ready to make sure all goes according to fantasy.
lead_paragraph: When cosplayers descend on New York Comic Con, they’re looking to meet their favorite creators and show off their outfits — but they often end up in need of costume triage. Armed with glue guns, zip ties, Popsicle sticks and safety pins, the Paladins of Cosplay come ready to fix wardrobe malfunctions — like a dangling shoulder pad, an imploding jetpack or any number of hazards that costumed fans face.

headline: American Man Kidnapped, Taken Away on Boat in Philippines, Police Say
abstract: Four armed men shot and abducted a 26-year-old from Vermont in western Mindanao, the police said. He had been living in the area since May.
lead_paragraph: An American man living in the Philippines was shot and abducted from his home by armed men late on Thursday, according to the local authorities, who said on Friday that they were pursuing the kidnappers.

headline: In Swing Districts, Republicans Lean Into Anti-Crime Message to Court the Center
abstract: Representative Lori Chavez-DeRemer, a Republican in a tough re-election race in Oregon, is using a law-and-order pitch to appeal to a broad swath of voters and blunt concerns about the G.O.P. agenda.
lead_paragraph: Thirty minutes south of Portland, as rain pattered down from gray skies, Representative Lori Chavez-DeRemer, Republican of Oregon, was at a wedding venue railing against Democrats in her state for decriminalizing hard drugs and accusing them of failing to support local law enforcement.

headline: Mudslides, Misinformation and an Urgency to Vote in Western North Carolina
abstract: On the first day of early voting, residents of western North Carolina weighed which candidates would most help their yearslong recovery.
lead_paragraph: Carolyn Burgess, 71, drove on cracked and crooked roads in Black Mountain, N.C., to get to her polling place on Thursday, the state’s first day of early voting. Hurricane Helene had devastated her town, and its 8,500 residents were divided on the government response.

headline: FKA twigs’s Electro-Pop Enticement, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Haley Heynderickx, Cymande, Bonzie and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: Italian Judges Strike Down Request to Hold Migrants in Albania
abstract: The ruling was a major blow to the conservative government’s plan to have asylum claims heard in Albania instead of Italy.
lead_paragraph: Italian judges on Friday struck down a request by the government to hold a group of migrants in a detention center in Albania, ordering that they should be taken to Italy, in a major setback for Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni’s flagship policy of outsourcing asylum requests.

headline: Grieving Liam Payne on TikTok
abstract: In reaction videos, some users captured themselves learning about the young singer’s death in real time. At a time when the cameras are always rolling, it’s not so unusual.
lead_paragraph: Amelie Bowen and a friend were filming a dance video for TikTok in her bedroom on Wednesday when Ms. Bowen’s mother entered the room to deliver sad news. Liam Payne, former member of the boy band One Direction, had died.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, October 19, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Sinwar’s Death Highlights Israel’s Long Quest for Deterrence
abstract: Israel’s killing of the Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar is the latest expression of Israel’s belief that regional acceptance will be achieved only through strength.
lead_paragraph: A quarter-century before Israel was founded, the Zionist leader Zeev Jabotinsky articulated an idea that has come to define the way Israelis protect their country. A Jewish state, he wrote in 1923, would succeed only by projecting enough strength to force its enemies to accept it as a permanent reality.

headline: A ‘New Day’? Justices Step Back, Slightly, From an Aggressive Climate Stance.
abstract: The Supreme Court’s decision to not temporarily block an E.P.A. rule this week signals ‘rising influence’ of Justice Barrett, one analyst said.
lead_paragraph: The conservative-majority Supreme Court has taken an aggressive stance against many environmental rules in recent years, but three small victories for regulators this month have left some analysts wondering whether a shift is underway.

headline: A Candidate for U.S. Senate Says He Was Shot in War. Was He?
abstract: Tim Sheehy, a Republican running for U.S. Senate in Montana, says he has a bullet in his arm from Afghanistan. But new questions have been raised about his account.
lead_paragraph: In a book and in his campaign for the U.S. Senate in Montana, Tim Sheehy has talked about a bullet lodged in his forearm — an injury he says he suffered as a Navy SEAL during a firefight in Afghanistan.

headline: Sinwar’s Death Is a Tricky Opportunity
abstract: A ceasefire is unlikely, but Israelis and Palestinians have new reasons for hope.
lead_paragraph: Reading the news that Yahya Sinwar, Hamas’s pitiless leader, had been killed on Wednesday by Israeli forces in southern Gaza, I had the same sense of elation so many people felt when Osama bin Laden was killed. To take satisfaction in the violent end of another human being, even an enemy, is almost always wrong, but there are exceptions. Sinwar’s death — like bin Laden’s in 2011 or Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi’s in 2019 or Hassan Nasrallah’s last month — is among them.

headline: Israelis and Palestinians React to Assassination of Hamas Leader
abstract: While some Israelis expressed hope that the war might end soon, many Palestinians were doubtful that the death of Yahya Sinwar would lead to a cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: While some Israelis expressed hope that the war might end soon, many Palestinians were doubtful that the death of Yahya Sinwar would lead to a cease-fire.

headline: Power Outage Plunges All of Cuba Into Darkness
abstract: The Cuban government had just announced emergency measures to reduce electricity use — then the power went out across the entire nation.
lead_paragraph: Cuba’s power grid failed and the entire nation plunged into darkness Friday, less than a day after the government stressed the need to paralyze the economy to save electricity in the face of major gasoline shortages and large-scale, regular outages.

headline: Veterans Dept. Investigating Acadia Healthcare for Insurance Fraud
abstract: Several federal agencies are investigating whether the large chain of psychiatric hospitals held patients without medical justification.
lead_paragraph: The Veterans Affairs Department is investigating whether Acadia Healthcare, one of the country’s largest chains of psychiatric hospitals, is defrauding government health insurance programs by holding patients longer than is medically necessary, according to three people with knowledge of the inquiry.

headline: Is It OK to Name Our Dog for a God?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on canine naming conventions.
lead_paragraph: My family recently adopted a rescue dog. As we were going through a long list of possible names for our pup, two of the more charming possibilities were Odin (the king of the gods in ancient Norse mythology) and Zeus (the leader of the gods in ancient Greek mythology). I was concerned that naming our dog for someone else’s deity would be disrespectful. After all, would it be OK to name our pet Yahweh or Allah? I once had a friend with a cat named Shiva; I was a child at the time, so I thought nothing of it, but I wonder about it now. Does it make a difference whether anybody still worships the ancient Norse and Greek gods, as opposed to the gods and prophets of the very active Judeo-Christian, Islamic or Hindu religions? For that matter, is the answer different depending on which active religion we’re talking about? — Pablo Halpern

headline: When Opportunity Leaves, the Government Has Two Choices
abstract: Like people, places can fall on hard times. Do they also deserve help?
lead_paragraph: If you tramp through the woods of New England and upstate New York, you will see stone walls marking the borders of farms that have been abandoned for a century or two. You may see the foundation of a small house, the entrance to a mine or the crumbling walls of a mill. The people left when the opportunity to make a living ran out, leaving behind nothing but stones, bricks and ghosts.

headline: North Carolina Officials Report Record Turnout for First Day of Early Voting
abstract: The more than 353,000 ballots cast signaled enthusiasm in the battleground state, but the significance of the high turnout was unclear.
lead_paragraph: More than 353,000 ballots were cast in North Carolina on Thursday, a state record for the first day of early voting, signaling intense enthusiasm in a battleground state still reeling from the devastation of Hurricane Helene and where 16 presidential electoral votes are up for grabs. But early insights into the significance of such high voter turnout were unclear.

headline: Review: An Invitation to the Dance, Simple and Subtle
abstract: DD Dorvillier’s solo at the Chocolate Factory evokes a dream state as it digs into the same river of dance twice.
lead_paragraph: As soon as DD Dorvillier walked onto the stage of the Chocolate Factory Theater on Thursday night, you knew you were in the presence of somebody long immersed in her craft, capable of doing a lot with a little. Through the simple act of standing still and surveying the audience, she seemed to light a spark in the bare warehouse space, her enigmatic gaze bristling with minute shifts of awareness. It was the subtlest invitation into a dance made with the lightest touch.

headline: U.N. Peacekeeping Force in Southern Lebanon Will Remain, U.N. Official Says
abstract: Israel has demanded that the force, known as UNIFIL, pull out. But all the countries contributing troops and the U.N. Security Council decided unanimously that UNIFIL should stay.
lead_paragraph: U.N. peacekeepers in Lebanon have experienced a series of deliberate attacks by the Israeli military in recent days, but the peacekeeping force will maintain its positions along the border despite Israeli pressure to withdraw, according to a spokesman for the force, known as UNIFIL.

headline: Why Harris Remains Unlikely to Break From Biden on Israel and Gaza
abstract: Her advisers say the empathy she has expressed for Palestinians as vice president should not be confused with any willingness to break from U.S. foreign policy toward Israel as a presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: Last December, Vice President Kamala Harris flew to a climate conference in Dubai and quickly huddled with the leaders of three Arab nations to discuss Israel’s war against Hamas in the Gaza Strip.

headline: A Sherrod Brown Ad Seizes on an Unwise Remark About Women and Abortion
abstract: Bernie Moreno, his Republican rival, said women older than 50 are “crazy” for caring about abortion rights. A series of Ohio women who fit that description have much to say in response.
lead_paragraph: The re-election campaign of Senator Sherrod Brown, Democrat of Ohio, has been running this 30-second ad attacking his Republican opponent, Bernie Moreno, on television stations across his state at a cost of nearly $1.3 million so far, according to AdImpact.

headline: Sinwar’s Death Was a Victory for Israel. But Can the U.S. Persuade It to ‘Take the Win’?
abstract: Assassinating Yahya Sinwar was Israel’s Osama bin Laden moment. But getting a cease-fire deal done in the last three months of the Biden presidency is a much bigger reach.
lead_paragraph: Within hours of the death of the Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar on Thursday, President Biden and his aides scrambled to design one last push for a broad de-escalation of violence in the Middle East: a cease-fire and hostage deal in Gaza, a pullback from Israeli attacks on Hezbollah in Lebanon, a confident declaration of victory by Israel that might allow it to forgo a major retaliation against Iran.

headline: Israel Destroys Nearly All of a Lebanese Village, Photos and Videos Show
abstract: About two dozen buildings were demolished in the village, which The Times identified as Mhaibib, just over a mile from Israel’s northern border.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military destroyed most of a village in southern Lebanon this week with a series of explosions, according to videos verified by The New York Times and satellite images. About two dozen buildings were demolished in the village, which The Times identified as Mhaibib, just over a mile from Israel’s northern border.

headline: After Hush-Money Verdict, Trump Tried to Silence Stormy Daniels Again
abstract: Donald J. Trump was convicted in May of covering up a hush-money deal with Stormy Daniels. Just two months later, his lawyer offered another deal for her silence.
lead_paragraph: In May, Donald J. Trump was criminally convicted of covering up a hush-money deal with the porn star Stormy Daniels.

headline: Drone Captures Moment of Defiance, Which Israel Says Was Sinwar’s Last
abstract: In a war often seen from far away, the footage from an Israeli drone appears to capture a moment both pivotal and personal.
lead_paragraph: It was a pivotal moment of the war in Gaza and, in a surreal twist of modern warfare, Israel said it was filmed by a drone.

headline: In Michigan, Harris and Trump Fight for Blue-Collar and Arab Voters
abstract: Campaigning in the battleground on the same day, Kamala Harris cast herself as a friend to union workers while Donald Trump sought to capitalize on anger over the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump converged on Michigan on Friday as they fought for the small pool of undecided voters and Arab Americans who could decide a battleground state that has shot toward the top of the priority list for both campaigns.

headline: Charges Against Deaf Black Man Punched by Phoenix Police Are Dropped
abstract: The man, Tyron Scott McAlpin, who also has cerebral palsy, was repeatedly punched and shocked with a Taser by the police during an arrest in August. The arrest is under investigation.
lead_paragraph: A prosecutor in Arizona announced this week that she had dropped charges against a deaf Black man who has cerebral palsy after she reviewed details of his arrest, during which police officers repeatedly punched him and shocked him with a Taser.

headline: Biden Renewed Efforts to Reach a Cease-Fire in Gaza
abstract: Also, a power outage plunged all of Cuba into darkness. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said today that the killing of the Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar offered “an opportunity to seek a path to peace” in the Middle East. Speaking in Berlin, where he met with European leaders, Biden said he would send Secretary of State Antony Blinken to Israel in the coming days to discuss a plan to end the war in Gaza.

headline: How Fugetsu-Do Survived the Evolution of Little Tokyo
abstract: Fugetsu-Do, a mochi store in the Little Tokyo neighborhood of Los Angeles, has existed for 121 years, with a lasting impact on its community.
lead_paragraph: Since 1903, a Japanese confectionery called Fugetsu-Do has been making mochi in the Little Tokyo neighborhood of Los Angeles.

headline: Lebanon Issues Rare Criticism of Iran Over ‘Blatant Interference’
abstract: Lebanon’s caretaker prime minister, Najib Mikati, summoned Tehran’s envoy over reported comments by a senior Iranian official on a U.N. resolution deemed a precondition for a cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: Lebanon’s caretaker prime minister accused Iran on Friday of meddling in the country’s affairs, opening up a rare diplomatic spat after Iran’s parliament speaker remarked that his country was ready to help negotiate terms to bring about a cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah.

headline: What We Know About the Execution Pending in the Shaken Baby Case
abstract: Robert Roberson’s execution was put on hold after the Texas House subpoenaed him for testimony about the questionable diagnosis of shaken baby syndrome in his case.
lead_paragraph: The execution of Robert Roberson, an autistic Texas man convicted of killing his 2-year-old daughter, was halted at the last minute after a novel legal move by a bipartisan group of Texas House members who questioned the diagnosis of shaken baby syndrome that helped lead to his conviction.

headline: How a Blouse, a Bandage or a Handshake Might Sway a Voter
abstract: Our critics decode the political subtexts that matter in 2024 — and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Times readers often express surprise — and sometimes even outrage — in response to political coverage by our culture critics.

headline: These Americans Say They’ll Move Abroad if Their Candidate Loses
abstract: We spoke with Americans who are packing up and moving out.
lead_paragraph: Good evening! Lots of people muse about leaving the country if an election doesn’t go their way. My colleague, Ronda Kaysen, who covers real estate, spoke with Americans who say they’re actually planning to. Plus, we look at what it’s like to listen to a whole speech by former President Trump. — Jess Bidgood

headline: Why Israel Targeted Yahya Sinwar
abstract: What does the killing of Yahya Sinwar, mastermind of the Oct. 7 attack, mean for Israel and Gaza? Ronen Bergman, a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine who is based in Tel Aviv, explains.
lead_paragraph: What does the killing of Yahya Sinwar, mastermind of the Oct. 7 attack, mean for Israel and Gaza? Ronen Bergman, a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine who is based in Tel Aviv, explains.

headline: Nicholas Daniloff, 89, Dies; Reporter’s Arrest in Moscow Ignited a Firestorm
abstract: A veteran foreign correspondent during the Cold War, he was held on trumped-up espionage charges. He credited President Ronald Reagan with fighting for his release.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Daniloff, an American news correspondent whose 1986 arrest in Moscow on trumped-up espionage charges ignited a political firestorm in the United States and an international crisis in the latter stages of the Cold War, died on Thursday at an assisted living facility in Cambridge, Mass. He was 89.

headline: Fire in Oakland Hills Prompts Evacuations Under Gusty Conditions
abstract: Firefighters in Northern California on Friday responded to a blaze that burned two homes and 15 acres.
lead_paragraph: A brush fire erupted in Oakland, Calif., on Friday, forcing the evacuation of hillside neighborhoods and the brief closure of a major highway as high winds threatened to spread the blaze.

headline: Sinwar’s Final Moments: On the Run, Hurt, Alone, but Still Defiant
abstract: Israeli forces had been steadily closing in on Yahya Sinwar, the Hamas leader, for weeks before he was cornered and killed in a ruined house in the Gaza Strip.
lead_paragraph: At the end, the fearsome militant leader who had helped unleash a vicious war seemed barely a threat.

headline: Hamas Says Its Demands Are Unchanged as Biden Pushes for Gaza Cease-Fire
abstract: A top deputy to the killed Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar vowed that his “banner will not fall” and that the group would hold to its cease-fire conditions.
lead_paragraph: A top Hamas official vowed on Friday that the killing of the group’s leader, Yahya Sinwar, would change nothing for its war with Israel, saying that it would fight on even as President Biden pressed for a deal to stop the conflict in the Gaza Strip and free the remaining hostages there.

headline: California Man Is Charged With Drugging and Sexually Assaulting 9 Women
abstract: The man, Michael DiGiorgio, is also charged with murdering one of the women, who died after being drugged, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A 50-year-old California man has been charged with drugging and sexually assaulting nine women at his homes in the oceanfront cities of Hermosa Beach and Redondo Beach, and of murdering one of them who died after being drugged, prosecutors announced Friday.

headline: What Will Happen to Yahya Sinwar’s Body?
abstract: Uncertainty surrounds the fate of the Hamas leader’s corpse as experts say Israel will likely try to avoid having his resting place become a shrine.
lead_paragraph: The death of the Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar was confirmed Thursday by the Israeli authorities, but questions remain about the location of his body and what may happen to it in the future.

headline: Montana Camper Was the Victim of a Brutal Homicide, Not a Bear, Sheriff Says
abstract: Dustin Kjersem, 35, was found dead in his tent with “chop wounds” on Saturday, the authorities said. No arrests have been made.
lead_paragraph: A person who called the police near Bozeman, Mont., last Saturday reported that a man had been found dead in his tent from what appeared to have been a bear attack.

headline: New York Man Who Brought Knife to Jan. 6 Riot Pleads Guilty to a Felony
abstract: Christopher D. Finney was charged after federal investigators found images of him during a search of a “militia” group chat, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A New York man pleaded guilty on Friday to a felony charge of civil disorder for storming the U.S. Capitol while armed with a knife on Jan. 6, 2021, as supporters of former President Donald J. Trump sought to halt the certification of the 2020 presidential election results.

headline: Prosecutors Urge Judge Not to Dismiss Bribery Charge Against Eric Adams
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams has asked a judge to drop one of five counts against him and to discipline prosecutors, whom he has accused of improperly leaking information to the news media.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors argued on Friday against requests by Mayor Eric Adams that a judge throw out a bribery charge against him and issue sanctions against prosecutors he accused of improperly leaking information to the news media.

headline: Corrections: Oct. 19, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 19, 2024.
lead_paragraph: A Critic’s Notebook article on Friday about literary re-enactments by the Vancouver photographer Stan Douglas misspelled a reference to German history. It is Weimar Germany, not Weimer.

headline: Impressively Respectful Types
abstract: August Miller makes an imposing Saturday debut.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is August Miller’s third crossword for The New York Times, but it’s his first grid in more than two years and his themeless puzzle debut. It’s a solid Saturday; there are plenty of challenging clues and a layout that connects four corners with a few scant squares, making it difficult to find answers using letters from crossing entries.

headline: Trump Tries to Rewrite History of Jan. 6 in Campaign’s Final Stretch
abstract: Donald J. Trump amplified a conspiracy theory that the federal government had staged the Capitol attack and compared jailed rioters to people of Japanese descent in internment camps.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump on Friday tried to revise the history of the deadly attack on the Capitol by a pro-Trump mob, as new details in the federal prosecution against him were made public by the judge in the case.

headline: After More Than 2 Years, Guatemalan Journalist Leaves Prison
abstract: The case against José Rubén Zamora became a sign of crumbling democracy in Guatemala and a symbol of threats against press freedom across Latin America.
lead_paragraph: After spending more than 810 days in a cramped cell with little more than his books to keep him company, one of Guatemala’s most renowned journalists was released to house detention on Saturday night as he waits to find out whether he will be granted a new trial.

headline: Man Arrested in Japan After Attack on Governing Party Headquarters
abstract: An assailant tried to breach security at the office of the new prime minister, Shigeru Ishiba, the police in Tokyo said.
lead_paragraph: A man was arrested in Tokyo on Saturday and accused of throwing several incendiary devices at the headquarters of the governing Liberal Democratic Party and slamming his car into a security fence outside the nearby office of Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba, the police in Tokyo said.

headline: Quote of the Day: A Gnarly Free-for-All That Is, Finally, for All
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 19, 2024
lead_paragraph: “I think this will open a lot of people’s eyes and shut a lot of people’s mouths.”

headline: ‘Life Is Complicated’: How a Scourge of Oligarchs Fell in Love With One
abstract: Natalia Morari once reported on corrupt business in Moldova. Now she has upset many by having a son with a tycoon accused of corruption, and running against the pro-West president in elections.
lead_paragraph: Feted by many fellow journalists and Western diplomats as a fearless scourge of corrupt oligarchs, Moldova’s most popular television host torched her soaring career and stellar image three years ago with a startling life choice.

headline: Tropical Storm Nadine Weakens After Making Landfall in Belize
abstract: Now a tropical depression, Nadine was bringing heavy rain to Mexico, Belize and Guatemala this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Nadine weakened into a tropical depression on Saturday night after making landfall near Belize City, Belize, in the morning. It had formed about 12 hours earlier in the northwestern Caribbean Sea late on Friday.

headline: This Museum Is Old. But With $75 Million to Spend, Why Is It So Dingy?
abstract: Decades of mismanagement and financial neglect have turned the New York State Museum, a trove of national treasures, into a dreary place.
lead_paragraph: In the shadow of New York’s State Capitol, a 188-year-old state museum that once drew over a million visitors each year has become a confounding symbol of government neglect and mismanagement.

headline: A Mayor’s Crisis Stirs Hope for Delayed Street Projects
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams has stalled plans to build bus and bicycle lanes. With his leadership under threat, the projects’ supporters see an opening.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Mayor Eric Adams took office, his administration has been known to stall projects that would set aside a greater share of New York City’s crowded streets for pedestrians, bicyclists and bus riders.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Reinventing Concrete, the Ancient Roman Way
abstract: By learning the secrets of 2,000-year-old cement, researchers are trying to devise greener, more durable modern options.
lead_paragraph: In June, the Italian Ministry of Culture announced the excavation of a new room, not yet open to the public, in the ruins of Pompeii. A few weeks later, a group of archaeologists gathered to marvel at it: walls covered with bright blue paint — an expensive pigment reserved for special rooms — and detailed frescoes of agricultural images remarkably well preserved after almost 2,000 years.

headline: How Chris Perfetti of ‘Abbott Elementary’ Spends His Sundays
abstract: On his weeks off from shooting the ABC sitcom, the actor unwinds by whipping up “the biggest salad ever” and seeking out a Sunday-night show.
lead_paragraph: For the actor Chris Perfetti, who lives in a fifth-floor walk-up in Brooklyn Heights, every day is leg day.

headline: The Powerful Companies Driving Local Drugstores Out of Business
abstract: The biggest pharmacy benefit managers are profiting by systematically underpaying independent drugstores, creating “pharmacy deserts” across the country.
lead_paragraph: The small-town drugstore closed for the last time on a clear and chilly afternoon in February. Jon Jacobs, who owned Yough Valley Pharmacy, hugged his employees goodbye. He cleared the shelves and packed pill bottles into plastic bins.

headline: These Parkland Shooting Survivors Were Promised Visas. They’re Still Waiting.
abstract: A humanitarian program offers immigrant crime victims who cooperate with the police a chance to stay in the United States. But most spend years in legal limbo.
lead_paragraph: On Valentine’s Day 2018, Bruna Oliveira’s geography teacher was shot dead at her feet as he ushered students into his classroom to shield them from an approaching gunman. Crouched near his body, holding her breath, the girl feared she would be killed next — dead at 14. But the shooter moved down the hallway on his rampage.

headline: Want to Rent a Panda? Here Are 5 Things China Demands in Return.
abstract: Normally confidential contracts show that U.S. zoos are accepting increasingly strict terms governing panda cams and public statements.
lead_paragraph: Panda exchanges, like the one that sent two bears to Washington’s National Zoo this week, are governed by closely held contracts. In most countries, they are never released.

headline: Getting Older? It Might Be Time to Hire a Trainer.
abstract: Personal training isn’t just for the young — or the wealthy. Here’s how to make it work for you.
lead_paragraph: Karen Palmer, 76, travels frequently for pet-sitting and house-sitting jobs. That means packing and lugging suitcases, and having the strength to control skittish, heavy animals.

headline: Lynda Carter Never Played Wonder Woman: ‘I Was Always Just Diana’
abstract: The actress and singer talks about mom jokes, Muppets, making music and marching for women’s rights.
lead_paragraph: When Lynda Carter released the pop single “Pink Slip Lollipop” over the summer, she saw it as a way to give men who ghost and gaslight a candy-coated boot.

headline: A Ravishing Color Palette for a Silent Adventure
abstract: The visual influences of Neva, by the studio that made Gris, include the film “Princess Mononoke.”
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has seen “Princess Mononoke,” Hayao Miyazaki’s 1997 masterpiece about a young warrior and her wolf who battle to stave off an ecological disaster, will almost certainly discern its influence on the video game Neva. Both open against the backdrop of a once pristine natural environment that has been overrun with a dark, squirming substance capable of infecting and turning animals into maniacally focused killers.

headline: A Schizophrenia Diagnosis Sets Off a Reckoning With Mental Illness
abstract: In “No One Gets to Fall Apart,” the TV writer Sarah LaBrie follows the breadcrumbs of her mother’s disorder back to her childhood, and beyond.
lead_paragraph: In March 2017, Sarah LaBrie, a TV writer living in Los Angeles, received a phone call from her grandmother, who unspooled an alarming thread of calamities suggesting that LaBrie’s mother was suffering from severe mental illness. She had been found parked on the side of the freeway in Houston, the author’s hometown, “honking her horn, her car filled with notes in which she outlined federal agents’ plans to kill her.” These fears had been dogging her for a month, during which she sometimes “slept in her car, not going inside to shower or change,” the number of her imagined pursuers ballooning to the hundreds. After submerging her work computer in the bathtub, LaBrie’s mother had been fired from her job as a registered nurse.

headline: Through the Turnstile and Down the Aisle
abstract: Forget the picture-perfect setting; some couples are embracing the gritty, chaotic appeal of the subway system for their wedding ceremonies and receptions.
lead_paragraph: On July 2, one week after Esmy Valdez and Daniel Jean’s Brooklyn wedding, Mr. Jean told his wife to change into another white dress before heading to the Canarsie-Rockaway Parkway L train stop.

headline: A Soldier Chose a Radical Way to Publicize Troop Fatigue: He Deserted
abstract: Serhii Hnezdilov, a Ukrainian soldier, said he wanted to draw attention to the need to discharge worn-out soldiers and replace them with fresh conscripts.
lead_paragraph: For months, Serhii Hnezdilov, a Ukrainian soldier, pushed for troops exhausted by years of war with Russia to be replaced with fresh conscripts. He expressed his concerns in interviews, on social networks and in a podcast, drawing on his five years of fighting in an infantry brigade.

headline: The Fight Over Ballots Has Already Begun in Wisconsin
abstract: Drop boxes, which had been used for years in Wisconsin until they were mostly banned after Republicans mounted legal challenges, are back. They have become the subject of bitter debate.
lead_paragraph: Karen Cannestra does not like that drop box in front of West Bend City Hall.

headline: We Don’t Yet Understand What Warehouse Work Is Doing to Communities
abstract: Warehouses in Lehigh Valley, Pa. have been an economic boon for blue collar workers. But they have been a political bust.
lead_paragraph: No place symbolizes the profound shifts that have taken place in the U.S. economy like Bethlehem, Pa., a city that lost its mighty steel mill but has been reborn with the help of a casino, a hotel and a couple of Walmart distribution centers. Thanks to the rise of online shopping and the proximity to so many American doorsteps, warehouses have become a major source of blue-collar employment in Bethlehem and beyond. In Pennsylvania’s Lehigh Valley, more than 19,000 people work in the warehouses that prepare our packages. Thousands more drive the trucks that deliver them. The total number of workers in this industry almost replaces the number that Bethlehem Steel employed in the city during its heyday.

headline: A More Freewheeling Book Lives Inside Al Pacino’s Memoir
abstract: From Shakespeare to Strindberg to “Scarface”: The actor remembers all of it and talks about some of it in “Sonny Boy.”
lead_paragraph: Al Pacino was a young actor in 1968, rehearsing for a now-forgotten play called “Huui, Huui” at the Public Theater. One day the Public’s impresario, Joseph Papp, took him aside, told him, “You will be a great star one day,” and fired him. Just a few years later, while making “The Godfather,” his director, Francis Ford Coppola, summoned him to a restaurant where he was having dinner with his family. Without inviting Pacino to sit down, Coppola warned him, “You’re not cutting it.” Soon after, under threat of being fired by the studio, Pacino shot one of the classic scenes in film history, when Michael Corleone enters a restaurant bathroom, retrieves a hidden gun and becomes a killer. The intensity and fear on Michael’s face are still chilling.

headline: Mandatory Facade Repairs: What Does the Law Say, and What Can You Do?
abstract: Local Law 11 inspections and repairs are required every five years. But how much intrusion should building residents expect, and how much is too much?
lead_paragraph: Q: I live on the top floor of a New York City co-op, and I have a small terrace. Every five years, when there is Local Law 11 repair work scheduled, contractors set up caution tape, winches, ropes and scaffolding. The board is not vigilant, and the current repairs have dragged on for more than a year. I have no access, no enjoyment of part of my apartment for which I pay maintenance. The co-op’s proprietary lease says that some access to the outdoor space must be provided if necessary, but this has become excessive. Do I have any rights as a shareholder to limit access or the time that this equipment remains on my terrace?

headline: How White Greed Destroyed a Bank for the Newly Freed
abstract: A book by the historian Justene Hill Edwards charts the rise and fall of the Freedman’s Bank, founded at the end of the Civil War for the formerly enslaved.
lead_paragraph: There are at least two problems with burying your money in the ground. First, someone might steal it. Second, you might forget where you dug the hole.

headline: Costco Has a Magazine and It’s Thriving
abstract: Each month, 15.4 million copies of Costco Connection are mailed out to members. Another 300,000 are distributed via Costco warehouses. It is now the nation’s third largest magazine.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Kimmel swears he has never once asked his team to land him a lick of press — except for the time when he begged for the chance to be featured on the cover of Costco Connection.

headline: Harris Has Championed Family Policies. Now Trump Likes Them, Too.
abstract: It’s unclear whether the longtime Democratic goals are a priority for Donald Trump. Yet the fact that he’s talking about them at all is part of a recent shift on the right.
lead_paragraph: It’s no surprise that Vice President Kamala Harris thinks the government should do more to help parents raise children. Like many Democrats, she has long supported three big policy goals: a larger child tax credit, paid family leave and reducing the cost of child care.

headline: Split-Ticket Voters Buoy Democrats in Key Senate Races
abstract: In the battleground state of Arizona and other important pockets of the country, polling suggests that voters backing the former president are eschewing Republican Senate candidates.
lead_paragraph: On matters of substance and style, there is little distance between former President Donald J. Trump and Kari Lake, the bombastic former news anchor running for Senate in Arizona.

headline: Despite Israeli Bombs and Assassinations, Hezbollah Keeps Fighting
abstract: Extensive Israeli attacks have blown up Hezbollah munitions and killed many fighters and leaders, but the Lebanese militia is far from incapacitated, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: Israeli bombs have blown up its munitions stores and killed thousands of its fighters, including many seasoned commanders.

headline: How Maya Rudolph’s Impression of Kamala Harris Has Changed
abstract: As Ms. Harris rose to center stage, the actor playing her on “S.N.L.” modified her approach, turning the vice president into a no-nonsense boss, surrounded by dopey men.
lead_paragraph: When the actor Maya Rudolph first appeared as Kamala Harris on “Saturday Night Live,” in September 2019, she established a few motifs: Cocktail at the ready, Ms. Harris was America’s fun aunt (“I call that a ‘funt,’” she said) and a “smooth-talking lady lawyer” with sex appeal and subpoena power.

headline: Jahleel Weaver’s Rolex Wallet Chain
abstract: The lead stylist for Rihanna and Dua Lipa wears a watch not for its practicality, but for what it represents in his career.
lead_paragraph: Jahleel Weaver’s pocket watch no longer keeps time. At least, not in the traditional sense. (With every wear, he’d have to reset it.)

headline: Inside Wisconsin’s Fight Over Ballot Drop Boxes
abstract: Ballot drop boxes, used for years in Wisconsin until they were mostly banned after Republicans’ legal challenges, are back. Julie Bosman, the Chicago bureau chief for The New York Times, describes how the boxes have become the subject of bitter debate.
lead_paragraph: Ballot drop boxes, used for years in Wisconsin until they were mostly banned after Republicans’ legal challenges, are back. Julie Bosman, the Chicago bureau chief for The New York Times, describes how the boxes have become the subject of bitter debate.

headline: The Essential Italian Returns to America
abstract: The designer Giorgio Armani made a splashy comeback to celebrate his new store and residences in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: In what now seems like the Pleistocene epoch but which was just four years ago, long stretches of Madison Avenue, widely judged the premier retail rialto on the planet, were boarded up against vandals and all but abandoned.

headline: Are Those Jeans? Look Again.
abstract: Sales are thriving in the uncanny valley of printed denim.
lead_paragraph: Acne Studios, the Swedish fashion house, makes $800 jeans that look like something a roofer would wear to a rave.

headline: In a Bellwether Pennsylvania County, a Modest Loss Could Be a Win for Harris
abstract: In white, working-class places, Kamala Harris’s goal is simply to lose by less. Thirty interviews in Beaver County, Pa., offered signs that with some swing voters, she is holding the line.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, Barack Obama and his new running mate, Joe Biden, kicked off their general-election campaign in Beaver County, Pa., a culturally conservative area northwest of Pittsburgh where the shuttering of steel mills years earlier still stung.

headline: Welcome to the Era of the $20,000 Family Car Insurance Bill
abstract: Have several children, a driveway full of cars and a few moving violations? Good luck to you. There are some ways to lessen the financial pain.
lead_paragraph: If you’re 16 years old, live in California and just passed your driver’s license test, the first thing you should do is drive your family to In-N-Out Burger for a milkshake and some animal-style fries.

headline: The Biggest Expansion Yet for a Designer of Tiny Bags
abstract: A just-opened New York store is the first of three that the French brand Jacquemus plans to open by next spring.
lead_paragraph: The 3.3-inch-long Chiquito handbag that Simon Porte Jacquemus may be most widely recognized for has no correlation to the size of his ambitions.

headline: Trump Thinks the Border Got Him Elected in 2016. He’s Convinced It Will Do So Again.
abstract: Voters rank the economy and high cost of living as their top issue. Donald J. Trump believes immigration “beats out the economy,” and he’s made it his closing message.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump turned his back to the crowd and stared up at the screen. Ominous music rang out. For the next minute and a half, the former president and his audience in Atlanta stood and silently watched clips of news reports of undocumented immigrants committing horrific crimes.

headline: A Fan Discovers a New Story by the Author of ‘Dracula’
abstract: The work by Bram Stoker, previously unknown to scholars, will be read and included in a book launched during Dublin’s annual Bram Stoker Festival.
lead_paragraph: Brian Cleary, a clinical pharmacist in Dublin, was trawling through the archives at the National Library of Ireland a few years ago when he stumbled across something extraordinary: a virtually unknown short story by Bram Stoker, author of the Gothic masterpiece “Dracula.”

headline: Meet Me at the Sculpture of the Naked Guy
abstract: Artists, collectors and art lovers gathered at the Javits Center last month for the Armory Show, where the surprises abounded.

headline: An Alarming Glimpse Into a Future of Historic Droughts
abstract: Record dry conditions in South America have led to wildfires, power cuts and water rationing. The world’s largest river system, the Amazon, which sustains some 30 million people across eight countries, is drying up.
lead_paragraph: Electricity cuts across an entire nation. A capital rationing water. A mayor encouraging people to shower together to save precious drops. The world’s largest river system, the Amazon, which sustains some 30 million people across eight countries, is drying up.

headline: U.S. ‘Fusion Cells’ Assist in Israel’s Hunt for Hamas Leaders
abstract: American commandos and intelligence officers began helping Israel soon after the Oct. 7 attacks last year.
lead_paragraph: Days after Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7, 2023, the Pentagon quietly dispatched several dozen commandos to Israel to help advise on hostage recovery efforts, U.S. officials said.

headline: Harris and Liz Cheney Will Team Up for a Pitch to Blue-Wall Suburbs
abstract: The vice president and her top Republican surrogate will appear together for “moderated conversations” in the suburbs of Philadelphia, Detroit and Milwaukee.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris will travel through several suburban battlegrounds on Monday with Liz Cheney, the former Republican congresswoman who has become her most prominent conservative surrogate.

headline: ‘The Interview’: Mia Khalifa
abstract: Mia Khalifa became infamous online for an adult film she made in her early 20s. She found she couldn’t go back to being anonymous, so she joined OnlyFans and became an influencer on TikTok, X and Instagram, using her story as a cautionary tale.
lead_paragraph: Mia Khalifa became infamous online for an adult film she made in her early 20s. She found she couldn’t go back to being anonymous, so she joined OnlyFans and became an influencer on TikTok, X and Instagram, using her story as a cautionary tale.

headline: Mia Khalifa’s Messy World of Money, Sex and Activism
abstract: For the OnlyFans star and influencer, navigating the internet is a full-time job.
lead_paragraph: To be influential online is to confront difficult questions about self-presentation, public judgment, freedom of speech, power and money. Over the last decade or so, Mia Khalifa has been forced to try to find some answers.

headline: Halloween’s Mutation: From Humble Holiday to Retail Monstrosity
abstract: Americans once made their own costumes and candy. Now, the holiday has rapidly commercialized, transforming into an economic juggernaut.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 1, 1876, The New York Times declared Halloween “departed,” destined for the grave.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,219
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Oct. 20, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: With Unusually Forceful Words, Canada Charges India With a Criminal Conspiracy
abstract: Canada expelled six Indian diplomats after the police said they had evidence that India used intimidation and even murder to silence its critics in Canada.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving has never been the outsize family gathering time in Canada that it is in the United States. (In Atlantic Canada, it’s not even a holiday.) But this year, it was marked in an unusual way.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 497
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Oct. 20, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Drone Hits Building Near Netanyahu’s Home in Coastal Israel
abstract: The Israeli prime minister and his wife were not home at the time of the strike, his office said. The episode highlighted the challenge drones pose to Israel’s air defenses.
lead_paragraph: A drone from Lebanon struck a building near the private residence of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Saturday, his office said, highlighting the continuing challenge posed to Israel’s air defense by unmanned vehicles.

headline: Novelty Acts
abstract: We’re so accustomed to researching, planning and curating every millisecond of our lives that we rarely stop to consider the mental cost.
lead_paragraph: This summer, for the first time in my life, I was the — recipient? beneficiary? some (not me!) would say victim — of a surprise birthday party. It was a delight through and through, but the thing I keep marveling at is how genuinely surprising it all was, from the guest list to the menu to the activities. I knew ahead of time only the time and the place, and so was treated to the rare experience of nearly 24 hours of pure discovery. I arrived for the celebration full of anticipation but without expectation, an agenda-free participant in the unfolding of the day.

headline: Despite Sinwar’s Death, Mideast Peace May Still Be Elusive
abstract: Just about all of the actors in the region are looking for an “offramp” to the conflict, many analysts say. But Hezbollah and Hamas are talking tough, and Israel is not backing down.
lead_paragraph: The killing of Yahya Sinwar, the Hamas leader whose decision to attack Israel more than a year ago set off the ever-widening war tearing up the Middle East, could be the key to ending the bloodshed. Now that Israel has decapitated Hamas in Gaza, the thinking goes, it might be ready to declare victory and move on, while a demoralized Hamas might show greater flexibility in cease-fire talks.

headline: The Marijuana Landscape
abstract: Readers respond to a front-page article about the growing use of marijuana after legalization.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Oliver Sacks I Knew and Loved Once Saw Himself as a Failure
abstract: I was Oliver’s partner for the last six years of his life. What I learned from reading a forthcoming volume of his letters surprised even me.
lead_paragraph: The Oliver Sacks that most of the world knew — the one I fell in love with after we met in 2008, when he was 75 — was the beloved neurologist and the author of many best-selling books, admired worldwide. A forthcoming volume of Oliver’s letters, nearly 350 of them, spanning 55 years, from age 27 to 82, provides a more complicated picture of the man often referred to in his later years as “the poet laureate of medicine.” Even I, his partner for the last six years of his life, was surprised by what I read in many of these letters, which will be published next month for the first time. (A selection of excerpts from the letters will appear below this essay.)

headline: Biden Has an Opportunity Now in Gaza, but Only if He Pushes
abstract: Even with Sinwar gone, I’m doubtful Hamas will fold or that Israel will easily embrace Biden’s ideas for a peace deal.
lead_paragraph: The question now is: Can Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel be pressured to declare victory and end the war in Gaza?

headline: American Business Cannot Afford to Risk Another Trump Presidency
abstract: Donald Trump is not running as a champion of business. He is running as a tribune of populist grievance.
lead_paragraph: Throughout American history, business leaders have been able to assume that an American president of either party would uphold the rule of law, defend property rights and respect the independence of the courts. Implicit in that assumption is a fundamental belief that the country’s ethos meant their enterprises and the U.S. economy could thrive, no matter who won. They could keep their distance from the rough-and-tumble of campaign politics. No matter who won, they could pursue long-term plans and investments with confidence in America’s political stability.

headline: Is the World Ready for a Religious Comeback?
abstract: The world seems primed for religious arguments in the same way it was primed for new atheists 20 years ago.
lead_paragraph: The heyday of the new atheism in Western life, when anti-God tracts by Richard Dawkins and Christopher Hitchens bestrode best-seller lists, did not arrive because brilliant new arguments for God’s nonexistence were suddenly discovered.

headline: Trump’s Charity Toward None
abstract: The Catholic Church’s latest scandal: fawning over Donald.
lead_paragraph: The cardinal should go to confession.

headline: There Is No Safe Way to Turn Teenagers Into Megastars
abstract: How many more boy band tragedies do we need to see before we connect the dots?
lead_paragraph: Liam Payne was just 14 when he took his first shot at the big time, trying out for the hit star-making show “The X Factor.” He was 17 when the show’s judges teamed him up with Harry Styles, Zayn Malik, Niall Horan and Louis Tomlinson — all young, handsome, telegenic, relatable singer-dancers — and created One Direction, one of the biggest boy bands in history. They released five studio albums and 17 hit singles and went on four world tours, traveling with a portable recording studio so they could put together one album while promoting another.

headline: 2 Unexpected Books for Spooky Season
abstract: A haunted author; haunted dolls.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: This Young Lawmaker in Lebanon Confronts Fears of a Spreading War
abstract: Amid the growing Israel-Hezbollah conflict, Firas Hamdan regularly visits his hometown, Hasbaya, near the border with Israel. As part of a new generation of Lebanese politicians, he is addressing rising fears as Israeli strikes hit the surrounding area.
lead_paragraph: Amid the growing Israel-Hezbollah conflict, Firas Hamdan regularly visits his hometown, Hasbaya, near the border with Israel. As part of a new generation of Lebanese politicians, he is addressing rising fears as Israeli strikes hit the surrounding area.

headline: For Executives, ‘Defending Democracy’ Can Seem Risky
abstract: Even seemingly anodyne sentiments supporting fair elections have become politically charged.
lead_paragraph: Republicans have spent months laying the groundwork to challenge a defeat of Donald Trump in the presidential election. During a fund-raising call organized by corporate lawyers in September, Douglas Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris, asked for help if those efforts veer outside legal grounds.

headline: Rare Copy of U.S. Constitution Sells for More Than $11 Million
abstract: The document, which was sold to an anonymous bidder at an auction in North Carolina, was among the first copies of the Constitution ever printed, experts said.
lead_paragraph: A rare copy of the United States Constitution that was printed shortly after the Constitutional Convention in 1787 and played a role in the document’s adoption by the original 13 states sold for more than $11 million during a live auction on Thursday evening.

headline: What to Make When You Have Lots of Apples But Absolutely No Energy
abstract: Enter: Genevieve Ko’s apple crisp.
lead_paragraph: To paraphrase Benjamin Franklin, three things in life are certain: death, taxes and bringing home a huge bag of apples on Saturday morning thinking you’re going to make a pie and then realizing on Sunday night that you are definitely, absolutely not going to be making a pie.

headline: Libby Titus, Introspective Singer and Songwriter, Dies at 77
abstract: Her “Love Has No Pride” was widely recorded, and she had high-profile relationships with Levon Helm and Donald Fagen. But she was uneasy with life in the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: Libby Titus, a singer-songwriter known for her wistful ballad “Love Has No Pride,” covered by Linda Ronstadt and Bonnie Raitt, and for her collaborations with Burt Bacharach, Dr. John and her husband, Donald Fagen, of Steely Dan, died on Oct. 13. She was 77.

headline: Boeing Union Says It Will Vote on New Proposal to End Strike
abstract: The deal reached by the machinists union, which represents more than 33,000 workers, would cumulatively raise wages by nearly 40 percent over four years, according to details shared by the union.
lead_paragraph: Leaders of Boeing’s largest union said on Saturday that they had reached a “negotiated proposal” for a new contract and would put it up for a vote to end a long and expensive strike.

headline: One Thing About Trump I Am Not Worried About
abstract: This time around, it would be much harder for Trump to try to steal the election.
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance of Ohio finally has an answer for journalists who ask him who won the 2020 presidential election.

headline: Sammy Basso, Advocate for Progeria Research, Is Dead at 28
abstract: One of about 150 people known to have a rare condition that causes rapid aging, he sought to raise awareness and participated in the search for a cure.
lead_paragraph: Sammy Basso, an advocate for research into progeria, an ultrarare fatal disease that causes rapid aging in children, who was known for living with gusto and humor with the condition as he faced the certainty of premature death, died on Oct. 5 near his home in Tezze sul Brenta, in the Veneto region of northern Italy. He was 28.

headline: Toni Vaz, Stuntwoman and Founder of N.A.A.C.P. Image Awards, Dies at 101
abstract: She created a program to honor Black artistic success in the 1960s. But she spent decades trying to get its organizers to recognize her role.
lead_paragraph: Toni Vaz, who cut a path as one of the first Black stuntwomen in Hollywood, with appearances in more than 50 movies, and then created the N.A.A.C.P. Image Awards to recognize the often unsung work of Black writers and performers, died on Oct. 4 in Los Angeles. She was 101.

headline: Tracking the Remnants of Oscar
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Oscar.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Oscar.

headline: Hundreds of Frozen Waffle Products Are Recalled Over Listeria Risk
abstract: Some products were sold under the brands of major retailers like Kroger, Price Chopper and Walmart. No illnesses so far have been linked to the waffles.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 700 frozen waffle products, some of them sold under the brands of major retailers like Kroger, Target and Walmart, were recalled on Friday over concerns of potential contamination with the bacteria Listeria monocytogenes, according to their manufacturer.

headline: Harris to Court Moderates With a Onetime Right-Wing Provocateur
abstract: Charlie Sykes, the anti-Trump conservative commentator joining the vice president in Wisconsin on Monday, in the past amplified false claims of voter fraud and referred to Michelle Obama as “Mooch.”
