lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s efforts to showcase her campaign’s political embrace of Republicans have led to the endorsements of archconservatives like Liz Cheney and onetime Tea Party darlings like Adam Kinzinger.

headline: In Michigan, Trade Policies and the Water Crisis Loom Large for Voters
abstract: After years of challenges, voters in this crucial swing state say they feel let down by their leaders.
lead_paragraph: After years of challenges, voters in this crucial swing state say they feel let down by their leaders.

headline: Tensions Spike in Mozambique After Killing of 2 Political Activists
abstract: Leading supporters of the top opposition presidential candidate, Venâncio Mondlane, were fatally shot in their car following an election marred by allegations of fraud.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer and a party official for the leading opposition candidate in Mozambique’s recent presidential election were fatally shot in their car late Friday night, inflaming tensions in a southern African nation that was already on edge after the highly disputed vote this month.

headline: U.S. Defense Secretary Urges Israel to Scale Back Attacks in Beirut Area
abstract: Lloyd J. Austin lamented that civilian casualties during Israel’s war in Lebanon were “far too high.”
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said on Saturday that the number of civilian casualties in Lebanon was “far too high” and that he would “like to see Israel scale back some of the strikes it’s taking, especially in and around Beirut.”

headline: Iraq Suspends License of Saudi-Owned Television Channel, MBC Media Group
abstract: The action came after the channel aired a report describing a number of leaders of Iranian backed armed groups as terrorists.
lead_paragraph: Iraqi regulators have suspended the license of a Saudi-owned television channel and are taking steps to terminate its right to operate in Iraq after the channel aired a report describing former leaders of Hamas, Hezbollah and Iran’s Quds Force as “faces of terrorism.”

headline: Cuba Suffers Second Power Outage in 24 Hours, Realizing Years of Warnings
abstract: Fidel Castro once called Cuba’s power plants “prehistoric.” But the country still relies on them, contributing to the longest blackout since the collapse of its former patron, the Soviet Union.
lead_paragraph: The experts had warned for years: Cuba’s power grid was on the verge of collapse, relying on plants nearly a half-century old and importing fuel that the strapped Communist government could barely afford.

headline: Harris, Armed With a T-shirt and a Message, Sticks Up for Detroit Against Trump
abstract: After former President Donald J. Trump disparaged the city, Vice President Kamala Harris said her campaign was seeking the kind of “grit” and “excellence” the city’s residents possessed.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris let her T-shirt do the talking in Detroit on Saturday.

headline: Michael Valentine, 74, Who Helped Drivers Stay Under the Radar, Dies
abstract: An engineer who loved to drive fast, he helped build an industry-altering device that made its debut after the national speed limit of 55 m.p.h. became law.
lead_paragraph: Michael Valentine, an electrical engineer, loved to drive fast in his MGB sports car. But in 1974, after a national highway speed limit of 55 miles per hour was mandated as a fuel conservation measure, he believed that a “holy war” had begun: speed-seeking drivers against police officers trying to snare them with radar guns.

headline: Vulnerable Senate Democrat Promotes Trump Ties in New Ad
abstract: The spot, which says that Senator Bob Casey of Pennsylvania had “sided with Trump” on trade and tariffs, was quickly denounced by the Trump campaign.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bob Casey, Democrat of Pennsylvania, distances himself from the Biden administration and highlights his support of certain Trump administration policies in a new TV campaign ad that aired in parts of the state on Friday, signaling a last-minute appeal to the former president’s supporters in a crucial battleground state.

headline: Families of Israeli Hostages Call on Netanyahu to Return Their Loved Ones
abstract: In a televised statement, family members of people held in Gaza said the death of Hamas’s leader, Yahya Sinwar, was the moment for a cease-fire and hostage deal.
lead_paragraph: The families of several Israeli hostages held in Gaza issued a sharply worded televised statement on Saturday in which they called on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to seize the moment after this week’s killing of the Hamas leader, Yahya Sinwar, to reach a hostage and cease-fire deal to bring home their loved ones.

headline: Fighting Rages in Gaza and Lebanon, Despite Killing of Hamas Leader
abstract: Peace talks were nowhere in sight and, despite Yahya Sinwar’s death, the violence seemed only to increase, as Israel struck northern Gaza and Hezbollah fired dozens of projectiles.
lead_paragraph: Israeli forces pounded targets in the northern Gaza town of Jabaliya on Saturday, killing at least 33 people and injuring dozens of others in the bombardment, a Palestinian emergency services group said.

headline: Triple Features
abstract: Jerry Miccolis’s blockbuster Sunday puzzle is actually a sequel.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Leaked U.S. Intelligence Suggests Israel Is Preparing to Strike Iran
abstract: American officials are trying to determine the source of the leak, which describes military drills and weapons placement, and how damaging it might be.
lead_paragraph: The leak of a pair of highly classified U.S. intelligence documents describing recent satellite images of Israeli military preparations for a potential strike on Iran offers a window into the intense American concerns about Israel’s plans. It also has U.S. officials working to understand the size of the improper disclosure.

headline: Early In-Person Voting Begins in Nevada, as Obama Fires Up Democrats
abstract: Former President Barack Obama held a campaign rally for Vice President Kamala Harris in Las Vegas on Saturday, as early in-person voting got underway in a critical battleground state.
lead_paragraph: Tony Chavez and his wife, Elizabeth, came to Cardenas Market in East Las Vegas on Saturday to pick up a few essentials — bread, three dozen eggs and ingredients for tamales.

headline: Harris and Usher Make Abortion Rights the Focus at Atlanta Rally
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris, campaigning in the state with the most restrictive abortion law of any battleground, criticized former President Donald J. Trump’s record on abortion.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris, standing in the state with the most restrictive abortion law of any campaign battleground, excoriated former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday for his role in the unraveling of a nationally recognized right to abortion.

headline: Officials Search for Answers After Collapse of Dock in Georgia Kills 7
abstract: Overall, 20 people were forced into the water on Saturday by the accident on Sapelo Island, the site of a festival celebrating the heritage of descendants of enslaved people.
lead_paragraph: Officials on a Georgia island on Sunday were investigating the collapse of a ferry dock gangway the previous day that killed seven people and left three others hospitalized. The dock was carrying people gathered for an annual celebration of a community of descendants of enslaved people.

headline: Corrections: Oct. 20, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Oct. 20, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 12 this weekend about Randy Newman misstates the number of Grammy Awards he has won in competitive categories. It is seven, not six.

headline: The Scandal of the Indonesian Leader’s Son and the Private Jet
abstract: It was a major blow to the Everyman image cultivated by President Joko Widodo, who stepped down on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, it looked like so many other photos posted on social media, the kind taken by excited travelers en route. The wing of a plane, juxtaposed against fluffy white clouds, with the sun streaming through. The caption read: “U.S.A. here we go.”

headline: How Indonesia’s Transformative Leader Tarnished His Legacy
abstract: Joko Widodo rose from a slum to the presidency. But with his tenure ending, he is being accused of undermining democracy by trying to install a political dynasty.
lead_paragraph: The words “emergency warning” galvanized protesters in Indonesia in August. It was a rallying cry to protect the world’s third-largest democracy, which broke free from dictatorship less than 30 years ago. Thousands of protesters took to the streets. Some stormed the gates of Parliament, tearing one down in fury.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Ukrainian Soldier Says He Deserted To Help His Comrades
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 20, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “This is what I call the curse of the uniform. Once you put it on, you can’t take it off.”

headline: At a Pennsylvania Rally, Trump Descends to New Levels of Vulgarity
abstract: The G.O.P. nominee repeated crude insults, and his supporters relished each moment. But the display could alienate swing voters.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday spewed crude and vulgar remarks at a rally in Pennsylvania that included an off-color remark about a famous golfer’s penis size and a coarse insult about Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: Zumba Teacher? ‘Anti-Woke’ Cleric? 38 Candidates Line Up to Head Oxford
abstract: The role of chancellor at the University of Oxford has been around for 800 years. This year, a particularly broad range of people have applied.
lead_paragraph: One is an Anglican clergyman who presents himself as the “anti-woke candidate.” Another is a left-wing activist who boasts that he has never “invaded any Middle Eastern countries.” Still another is a Zumba teacher who says her cardio training would help her face the rigors of the job.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Welcomes Back Alec Baldwin
abstract: The longtime friend of “S.N.L.” made his first appearance on the show since an involuntary manslaughter case against him was dismissed. Michael Keaton was the host.
lead_paragraph: A contentious interview of Vice President Kamala Harris conducted on Wednesday by Bret Baier, the chief political anchor for Fox News, was an inevitable subject of satire on this week’s “Saturday Night Live.” The opening sketch that parodied this interview also marked the return of Alec Baldwin, a frequent “S.N.L.” guest and host who played former President Donald J. Trump in “S.N.L.” sketches during the 2016 presidential campaign and Trump’s time in office.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: ‘Her Needles Pulled a Single String of Yarn From a Bag on the Floor’
abstract: A knitter’s practiced hands draw attention, a solo on a windy day and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Number of Young People Accused of Serious Crimes Surges in New York City
abstract: A 37 percent rise in the number of young people accused in serious crimes mirrors a broader increase. But it has alarmed the police, who say young offenders could grow up to break the law again.
lead_paragraph: The number of people under 18 accused of major crimes, including murders, robberies and assaults, has increased sharply in New York City in the past seven years, Police Department figures show — a steep trajectory that has alarmed law enforcement officials.

headline: A Requiem for a Fictitious Congressman
abstract: Godfrey G. Gloom, who was frequently featured in The Times’s pages, met a colorful end in 1936.
lead_paragraph: The tragic death of Godfrey G. Gloom, an uncompromising congressman from Amity, Ind., made the front page of The New York Times on June 28, 1936. While crossing a street in Philadelphia, where the Democratic convention was being held, Mr. Gloom leaped out of the path of an oncoming vehicle carrying a radio commentator, only to be hit by a newspaper photographer on a motorcycle.

headline: Jill Stein Won’t Stop. No Matter Who Asks.
abstract: People in Stein’s life have implored her to abandon her bid for president, lest she throw the election to Donald Trump. She’s on the ballot in almost every critical state.
lead_paragraph: Jill Stein, the Green Party’s serial presidential candidate, has heard the pleading from strangers.

headline: Tugged Between East and West, Moldova Makes a Pivotal Choice
abstract: Voters were almost evenly split over whether to declare European Union membership a “strategic objective.” Russia has worked hard to sway the outcome.
lead_paragraph: A pivotal contest in Moldova between supporters of Russia and those who favor aligning with the West was too close to call on Monday morning, with voters almost evenly divided over proposed constitutional changes that would lock in the country’s exit from Moscow’s sphere of influence.

headline: U.S. Agencies Fund, and Fight With, Elon Musk. A Trump Presidency Could Give Him Power Over Them.
abstract: Mr. Musk, who holds billions in federal contracts, wants to be in charge of the regulators that oversee him if Donald Trump wins.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk’s influence over the federal government is extraordinary, and extraordinarily lucrative.

headline: Under an L.A. Freeway, a Psychiatric Rescue Mission
abstract: The crisis of homelessness is pushing American psychiatry to places it has not gone before — like sidewalk injections of antipsychotics.
lead_paragraph: In a downtown Los Angeles parking lot, a stretch of asphalt tucked between gleaming hotels and the 110 freeway, a psychiatrist named Shayan Rab was seeing his third patient of the day, a man he knew only as Yoh.

headline: Seeking ‘Warmth and Personality’ in the World of High-Priced Pens
abstract: For collectors and enthusiasts at the London Pen Show, the finest writing instruments can cost thousands of dollars. As one dealer put it, “This is art of the highest quality.”
lead_paragraph: When was the last time you wrote a letter to someone by hand? As we entrust our laptops and phones with more and more of our lives, the once-ubiquitous art of handwriting is seemingly in danger of going extinct. But at a London hotel on a recent Sunday morning, thousands of people turned up to demonstrate that the humble pen may be far from meeting the fate of the dinosaurs.

headline: Door-Knocks, Texts, and Ads, Ads, Ads: Life on the Swing-State Battlefield
abstract: This year’s campaign offers a vivid reminder of how much the playing field in presidential elections has shrunk, giving voters in a handful of states a disproportionate influence in the decision.
lead_paragraph: Electronic billboards along Route 22 in eastern Pennsylvania, usually a flickering procession of ads for car dealerships, are now flashing images of Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump. Billboards along Interstate 94 near Milwaukee feature Republican ads blaming Ms. Harris for rising prices.

headline: From the Golden Age to the Streaming Age, Hollywood Has Been Hell for Writers
abstract: Dorothy Parker worked on the script for “A Star Is Born,” but the tragic ending was all hers, while Bruce Eric Kaplan manages to find the laughs in today’s industry foibles.
lead_paragraph: This week the former magazine queen Tina Brown started a Substack called Fresh Hell, after an expression oft-attributed to Dorothy Parker. Of course I subscribed immediately, considering Brown’s book “The Vanity Fair Diaries” one of her crowning achievements. Chattiness is her idiom. But also because of the Parkerly promise.

headline: Harris May Be Catching Up on a Key Polling Question: Which Candidate Helps You?
abstract: Many voters believe Donald Trump’s policies have helped them, Times/Siena polls show. Kamala Harris has made up some lost ground on that question, though there are warning signs in the swing states.
lead_paragraph: If politics can feel like a game of what-have-you-done-for-me-lately, an important question in this election is whether voters believe former President Donald J. Trump or Vice President Kamala Harris has done, or would do, more for them.

headline: I Can’t Buy a House. I Can’t Shop. I’m Too Worried About the Election.
abstract: Election anxiety is causing many consumers to avoid big-ticket purchases like houses, weddings and cars. “Every four years this happens,” one former car dealer said.
lead_paragraph: In Westport, Conn., a 35-year-old who works for an investment firm is holding off on making any financial investments until after the election. Across the country, in Kenosha, Wis., a man who works in sales said he would love to buy a house and get out of his rental, but with Election Day less than a month away, he can’t possibly make such a colossal decision.

headline: A Mideast Shift Is Underway, Without Israel
abstract: Before Hamas’s Oct. 7 attacks, Saudi Arabia was open to forging stronger ties with the Israelis. Now, a year into the war in Gaza, it is warming up to its traditional enemy, Iran.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates as Israel launches retaliatory strikes against Iran.

headline: The Holocaust’s Grandchildren Are Speaking Now
abstract: Three generations on, filmmakers, writers and artists are making new meaning from ancestral trauma.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of “A Real Pain,” a movie written and directed by Jesse Eisenberg coming to theaters on Nov. 1, two first cousins played by Eisenberg and Kieran Culkin approach the house in a Polish town where their recently deceased grandmother had lived before the Holocaust.

headline: Jeff VanderMeer Writes His Strangest Novel Yet
abstract: Known for his blockbuster Southern Reach series, the author talks about his eerie new installment, “Absolution,” keeping mysteries alive and what people get wrong about alligators.
lead_paragraph: Jeff VanderMeer has been called “the poet laureate of weird fiction,” the “king of weird fiction” and “weird Thoreau.”

headline: At Homecoming, Howard Alumni Are Excited and Anxious for Harris
abstract: The H.B.C.U. celebrated its centennial homecoming this weekend, with many partygoers holding their breath for the school’s famous alumna, Vice President Kamala Harris, in the election’s homestretch.
lead_paragraph: As Vice President Kamala Harris fired up voters in Detroit and Atlanta this weekend, some of her most fervent backers were just two miles from her home in the District of Columbia, where her alma mater, Howard University, celebrated its 100th homecoming.

headline: Watch Parties, Clinics and Guinness: How the N.F.L. Builds a Fan Base in Ireland
abstract: The league is trying to ensure that sponsors, media partners and enthusiasm are in place before committing to playing a game in the country.
lead_paragraph: Shane De Lappe and Stephen Murphy arrived at Dublin’s Croke Park last month about an hour before the stadium gates opened. They weren’t going to see Gaelic football or hurling. Instead, the 30-something dads were there for a sold-out watch party hosted by the Pittsburgh Steelers.

headline: He Dreamed of Escaping Gaza. The World Watched Him Burned Alive.
abstract: A video of Shaaban al-Dalou burning to death after an Israeli strike at a hospital has stoked criticism from Israel’s allies and highlighted the plight of people trapped in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the Middle East crisis here.

headline: Four of Trump’s Most Meandering Remarks This Week
abstract: The former president says that his style is to “weave” from one subject to the next. Others see something more worrisome in his ramblings.
lead_paragraph: One of the truisms of Trump World is that being viewed as boring is a sin more deadly than being wrong.

headline: A 50-Mile Art Road Trip Celebrates the Culture in Agriculture
abstract: In Wisconsin, the Farm/Art DTour brings artists and farmers together and each get a fresh perspective.
lead_paragraph: It’s not every day that lifelong Wisconsin farmers take time out during the frenetic harvest season to do pirouettes and turns in their tractors like so many John Deere Baryshnikovs.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,220
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Mon., Oct. 21, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 498
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Oct. 21, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: There Is No Leadership Without Risk
abstract: Those in positions of leadership fear they will say the wrong thing, or say what they believe to be the right thing in the wrong way.
lead_paragraph: There has never been a more difficult time to lead anything — whether a publicly traded corporation or a nonprofit nongovernmental organization; whether a global university or a local, public school or classroom.

headline: This Hollywood Horror Film Hit Close to Home
abstract: I’ve seen the ways that show business can warp a young woman’s self-perception. I’ve even fallen prey to some of them.
lead_paragraph: As a little girl I had ears that stuck out like big butterfly wings. Some kids at my school in Los Angeles would make fun of them, and I’d often stare at myself in the mirror wishing my ears would lay flat against my head.

headline: College Officials Must Condemn On-Campus Support for Hamas Violence
abstract: Would school administrators be silent if there was a Ku Klux Klan gathering on their campus celebrating white supremacist violence?
lead_paragraph: Although college campuses are much quieter this fall than they were last spring, some of the anti-Israel language at some schools is frightening in its celebration of Hamas’s violence. What feels different is the repeated glorification of the Hamas massacre of more than 1,200 people last year on Oct. 7 in a surprise attack.

headline: I Don’t Want to Live in a Monoculture, and Neither Do You
abstract: Few things can change your perspective for the better more than being attacked from both sides of America’s culture war.
lead_paragraph: Few things can change your perspective for the better more than being attacked from both sides of America’s culture war.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘An Acerbic Young Writer Takes Aim at the Identity Era’
abstract: Tony Tulathimutte is a master comedian whose original and highly disturbing new book skewers liberal pieties.
lead_paragraph: There was something distinctly unrelaxed about the way that Tony Tulathimutte, one of the more talented young writers at work in America today, announced the publication of “The Feminist,” a new short story, back in the fall of 2019.

headline: How Elections Affect Our Shopping
abstract: We explore why consumers tend to get skittish about major purchases ahead of a general election.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks leading up to a general election, consumers tend to get skittish about major purchases like houses, cars, weddings and investments. After the election, regardless of the outcome, they open up their wallets and shop again.

headline: Dozens of Palestinians Are Dead or Missing After an Israeli Airstrike in Northern Gaza, Officials Say
abstract: The Israeli military renewed an offensive there earlier this month, saying it was trying to eliminate a regrouped Hamas presence in the area.
lead_paragraph: Rescuers were combing the rubble and searching for survivors on Sunday in the town of Beit Lahia, in northern Gaza, where Palestinian officials said an overnight Israeli airstrike hit a residential building and killed dozens of people.

headline: For Trump, a Lifetime of Scandals Heads Toward a Moment of Judgment
abstract: No major party presidential candidate, much less president, in American history has been accused of wrongdoing so many times.
lead_paragraph: When the history of the 2024 election is written, one of the iconic images illustrating it will surely be the mug shot taken of Donald J. Trump after one of his four indictments, staring into the camera with his signature glare. It is an image not of shame but of defiance, the image of a man who would be a convicted felon before Election Day and yet possibly president of the United States again afterward.

headline: Kamala Harris and McDonald’s: A College Job, and a Trump Attack
abstract: Donald Trump has claimed without evidence that Ms. Harris never worked at the fast-food chain. Her campaign and a friend say she did.
lead_paragraph: Birtherism, meet burgerism.

headline: Help Yourself to Pancakes
abstract: Put a platter of sour cream pancakes with cardamom apples on the table and watch everyone happily dig in.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. How are you doing? It’s a weird, uncertain time for many, parlous and dizzying, and sometimes it seems as if the last thing anyone wants to do is gather to eat and talk, to try to understand one another, to commune.

headline: Abortion as an Issue in the Election
abstract: Readers respond to a column by David French. Also: Veterans as poll workers; an immigrant’s story; political messages.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 2 Dead, Hundreds Rescued in ‘Historic’ New Mexico Floods
abstract: Roswell, N.M., received nearly a third of its annual rainfall total in just a few hours on Sunday. Rescue efforts were ongoing with more storms in the forecast.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of people were rescued in eastern New Mexico late Saturday and Sunday, as torrential rains dumped more than a third of the city of Roswell’s annual rainfall total in just a few hours, causing at least two deaths, officials said.

headline: Sally Butler, Nun Who Blew the Whistle on Sex Abuse, Dies at 93
abstract: In the 1960s, she worked with priests to serve residents of housing projects in Brooklyn. Decades later, she learned that those priests had been abusing young boys.
lead_paragraph: Sister Sally Butler, a nun, social worker and activist who blew the whistle on the sexual abuse of children in the Brooklyn parish where she once worked, died on Oct. 6 at the residence of her order, the Sisters of St. Dominic of Amityville, in Suffolk County, N.Y. She was 93.

headline: Cher, A Tribe Called Quest and Dave Matthews Band Join the Rock Hall
abstract: Gratitude flowed at the 39th induction ceremony in Cleveland, where Mary J. Blige, Peter Frampton, Ozzy Osbourne and the bands Foreigner and Kool & the Gang were honored.
lead_paragraph: Superstar power arrived early at the 39th Rock & Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony in Cleveland on Saturday night, as Cher strode onstage and joined Dua Lipa in a duet of “Believe,” the 1998 dance-pop smash that revitalized Cher’s career.

headline: A Must-Watch Night for New York Sports Fans: Here’s What to Know
abstract: The Mets and the Liberty will each look to secure a crucial championship win, while the Jets will bring together two stars in an effort to reverse a losing streak.
lead_paragraph: Sunday night will have a lineup that New York sports fans could hardly have imagined even a few months ago, with two championships on the line and a prime-time reunion of two of football’s biggest names.

headline: Protesters in Israel Demand a Cease-Fire and Hostage Deal
abstract: Thousands joined families of hostages held in Gaza during a protest in Tel Aviv to call on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government to reach a cease-fire deal and to push for the release of hostages.
lead_paragraph: Thousands joined families of hostages held in Gaza during a protest in Tel Aviv to call on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government to reach a cease-fire deal and to push for the release of hostages.

headline: Review: A Choir Stands Out in a Multimedia Performance
abstract: The Crossing is one of many elements in “Can We Know the Sound of Forgiveness,” which links pieces by Gabriela Ortiz in a five-movement meditation.
lead_paragraph: “Can We Know the Sound of Forgiveness,” which had its New York premiere on Friday evening at Zankel Hall, jams a lot into its 75 minutes.

headline: Confronted With Facts on Fox News, Trump Claims Ignorance
abstract: In an interview that aired Sunday, Donald Trump defended his recent falsehoods about immigrants and the Capitol riot by claiming, implausibly, that he did not know or had “not heard” the truth.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has largely avoided interviews where he will be fact-checked in real time. But on Sunday, he sat for an interview on Fox News, where he was challenged directly on some of his most glaring falsehoods of the campaign.

headline: Starring in Kamala Harris’s Closing Argument: Donald Trump
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris has made a notable shift in strategy to paint Donald Trump as unfit and dangerous as Democrats grow anxious about the closeness of the race just two weeks out.
lead_paragraph: With the presidential race a dead heat two weeks before Election Day, Vice President Kamala Harris is moving aggressively to make sure voters in the battlegrounds remember precisely why they rejected Donald J. Trump four years ago.

headline: Musk’s $1 Million Offer Raises New Legal Questions
abstract: Some election lawyers said the giveaway may run into laws that prohibit paying people to register to vote.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk is dramatically ratcheting up his effort to use his fortune to help Donald Trump win Pennsylvania — and inviting some new legal scrutiny along the way.

headline: A Swing District in Red Nebraska Hosts a Hotly Contested House Race
abstract: Tony Vargas, a Democrat vying to become the state’s first Latino representative, lost to Don Bacon, the Republican incumbent, in 2022. But the presidential election could help him in his rematch.
lead_paragraph: The crowd of 1,400 people gathered on Saturday at an outdoor amphitheater in Omaha was waiting for Tim Walz, the jocular Minnesota governor running for vice president. But it was another Democrat looking to make history who drew the first standing ovation of the evening.

headline: Trump Cooks and Serves Fries at a McDonald’s in Pennsylvania
abstract: During his trip to the battleground state, former President Donald J. Trump repeated his unsubstantiated claim that Vice President Kamala Harris lied about working at a McDonald’s in her college days.
lead_paragraph: During his trip to the battleground state, former President Donald J. Trump repeated his unsubstantiated claim that Vice President Kamala Harris lied about working at a McDonald’s in her college days.

headline: Hundreds Rescued From New Mexico Floods
abstract: At least two were killed and hundreds were rescued as torrential rains poured an “historic” amount on eastern New Mexico.
lead_paragraph: At least two were killed and hundreds were rescued as torrential rains poured an “historic” amount on eastern New Mexico.

headline: Trump, Slinging Fries and Smearing Harris, Takes Turn Behind a McDonald’s Counter
abstract: At a campaign photo op, the candidate worked the drive-through window, slammed his opponent and acknowledged a weakness. “I love salt,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump walked into one of his favorite restaurants on Sunday and declared he was “looking for a job.”

headline: Monday Briefing: Israel Escalates War Against Hezbollah
abstract: Plus, the French town shaken by a rape trial.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military launched a wave of airstrikes across Lebanon yesterday targeting branches of Al-Qard al-Hasan, a financial association associated with Hezbollah.

headline: Fans Mourn Liam Payne at Vigil in London
abstract: His death has been particularly profound in Britain, where Payne, a member of the boy band One Direction, first achieved fame. “We don’t know loss like this,” one fan said.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of fans gathered in Hyde Park on Sunday afternoon to mourn Liam Payne, 31, a member of the British group One Direction, who died after falling from a hotel balcony in Buenos Aires last week.

headline: Harris Says Trump’s Behavior ‘Demeans’ the Presidency After Vulgar Remarks
abstract: In an interview with the Rev. Al Sharpton on MSNBC, the vice president reacted to her opponent’s behavior at rallies, saying Americans “deserve so much better.”
lead_paragraph: In an interview on Sunday with the Rev. Al Sharpton, Vice President Kamala Harris responded to a profanity-laden insult that former President Donald J. Trump used about her tenure as vice president, saying he had “not earned the right” to hold office again.

headline: 2 Who Went Missing After Crash Near Mount Rainier Are Dead, Navy Says
abstract: Two crew members were onboard a Navy aircraft when it crashed during a routine training flight on Oct. 15 in Washington State, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Two U.S. Navy crew members who were missing after their aircraft crashed near Mount Rainier in Washington State during a training flight last week were declared dead on Sunday, according to Navy officials.

headline: In the Future
abstract: Stick to your instincts as you solve Neil Padrick Wilson’s crossword puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Israel Strikes Hezbollah-Affiliated Financial Institution in Lebanon
abstract: Branches of Al-Qard al-Hasan, which functions as Hezbollah’s de facto banking arm but also operates as an alternative bank for Lebanese, were targeted around Beirut and across the country’s south and east.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military conducted a wave of airstrikes across Lebanon on Sunday, targeting branches of Al-Qard al-Hasan, a financial association associated with the militant group Hezbollah.

headline: French Cuffs and French Fries at Donald Trump’s McDonald’s Gig
abstract: No hairnet in sight as the former president doled out meals at a campaign stop in Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday afternoon, former President Donald J. Trump traded his blue sport coat for a yellow-trimmed apron.

headline: A Crack, a Shift, Then Screams: Witnesses Describe Georgia Dock Collapse That Killed 7
abstract: Investigators have begun looking for reasons behind the failure at a ferry dock on Sapelo Island, the site of a festival celebrating the heritage of descendants of enslaved people.
lead_paragraph: They had come to Sapelo Island, just off the curve of the Georgia coast, for a celebration of resilience, of a people, of a culture that for generations had been so fragile but could not be broken.

headline: How Aleksei Navalny’s Prison Diaries Got Published
abstract: In his posthumous memoir, compiled with help from his widow, Yulia Navalnaya, Navalny faced the fact that Vladimir Putin might succeed in silencing him. The book will keep “his legacy alive,” Navalnaya said.
lead_paragraph: Aleksei A. Navalny knew he would likely die in prison.

headline: This Is the Case of Henry Dee
abstract: Listening in on one case before a parole board.
lead_paragraph: On This Week’s Episode:

headline: Quotation of the Day: How Halloween Retail Became Its Own Monster
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 21, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “If you’re a kid, who wouldn’t rather be Superman at Halloween than yet another thief made up from your dad’s old clothes out of the attic?”

headline: John Kinsel Sr., Navajo Code Talker in World War II, Dies at 107
abstract: He was among the last surviving members of a group that transmitted a code, crafted from the Navajo language, that U.S. forces used to confuse the Japanese.
lead_paragraph: John Kinsel Sr., a World War II veteran who was one of the last surviving Navajo Code Talkers, a group of Marines whose encrypted wartime messages based on the Navajo language helped secure an Allied victory in the Pacific, died on Saturday. He was 107.

headline: In ‘Sunset Boulevard,’ Nicole Scherzinger Is 23 Feet Tall
abstract: A fascinating Broadway revival of the bombastic 1994 musical blows it up even further.
lead_paragraph: Despite Norma Desmond, who famously declares in the film “Sunset Boulevard” that it’s not her but “the pictures that got small,” the opposite is true on Broadway these days. In musicals especially, video and projections have grown ever more dominant. Perhaps it is not so much an irony as an inevitability, then, that at the St. James Theater, where a revival of the musical based on “Sunset Boulevard” opened on Sunday, the pictures — live video streamed onto an LCD screen more than 23 feet tall — are so big they almost blot out the show below.

headline: Helicopter Crashes Into Houston Radio Tower
abstract: Police officers urged onlookers to clear the site of the accident as smoke and fire filled the air.
lead_paragraph: Police officers urged onlookers to clear the site of the accident as smoke and fire filled the air.

headline: Multiple Deaths After Helicopter Crashes Into Houston Radio Tower
abstract: The authorities said a child was among several who died onboard. It was not immediately clear if any of the three other people in the helicopter survived.
lead_paragraph: A helicopter crashed into a radio tower in Houston on Sunday night, falling to the ground in a fireball and killing people onboard including a child, officials said.

headline: Dock Collapse Kills Several in Georgia
abstract: Bystanders and rescue teams searched for victims after the gangway at a ferry dock in Sapelo Island collapsed into the water.
lead_paragraph: Bystanders and rescue teams searched for victims after the gangway at a ferry dock in Sapelo Island collapsed into the water.

headline: How a TV Hit Sparked Debate About Having Too Many Babies
abstract: The Sani family in northern Nigeria has six children, more than the parents can afford but fewer than their own parents had. Birthrates, and the decisions couples make about family size, are changing across Africa.
lead_paragraph: Five young sisters and their brother crowded around a small television in their modest cement house, a wriggling, giggling pile of skinny limbs and abandoned homework. Like families across northern Nigeria, the Sani family had been waiting all week for Thursday night to watch the latest episode of their favorite show, a comedy drama called “Gidan Badamasi.”

headline: In His Memoir, Aleksei Navalny Speaks From the Grave
abstract: The Russian opposition leader, who died in an Arctic penal colony earlier this year, tells the story of his struggle to wrest his country back from President Vladimir Putin.
lead_paragraph: Aleksei Navalny did not set out to write a posthumous memoir. He began the project in 2020 as a conventional autobiography propelled by an “intriguing thriller about uncovering an assassination attempt.” Of course, he was the victim of the assassination attempt — a nerve agent laced into his clothing took hold on a flight from Siberia to Moscow that summer as Navalny was sitting beside his wife, Yulia, and watching an episode of the sci-fi cartoon “Rick and Morty” on his laptop. He stumbled to the airplane bathroom. Thanks to Yulia, he came to in a hospital in Berlin.

headline: Harris Sets Record for Biggest Fund-Raising Quarter Ever
abstract: Donald Trump is raising less money than he did during his run in 2020, building a far smaller campaign than Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign set a record for the biggest fund-raising quarter ever this fall, raising $1 billion in the three-month period that ended Sept. 30.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: Israel escalates its attacks in Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has survived more scandals than any major presidential candidate, much less president, often turning them on their head and casting himself as a serial victim rather than a serial violator. Any one of those scandals, by itself, would typically have been enough to derail another politician.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Seth Meyers: Dad Man Walking’ and Spooky Movies
abstract: The comedian’s standup special airs on HBO. Various networks show horror films.
lead_paragraph: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, Oct. 21-27 Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Austin Condemns Kremlin ‘Apologists’ in Pledging Support for Ukraine
abstract: The trip by the U.S. defense secretary comes as Russian forces steadily gain territory in eastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III on Monday offered full-throated support for Ukraine’s fight against Russia and delivered biting criticism of naysayers who might seek to end the conflict on Moscow’s terms.

headline: Word of the Day: exodus
abstract: This word has appeared in 281 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word exodus has appeared in 281 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 8 in “Millions Are Fleeing Florida’s Gulf Coast Ahead of Milton” by Matthew Cullen:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Trial Begins in Fatal Choking of Homeless Man on Subway
abstract: Daniel Penny, who put the man, Jordan Neely, in a chokehold last year, told investigators that Mr. Neely posed a deadly threat. The killing polarized New York.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Penny has admitted he put a homeless man in a chokehold in a subway car on May 1, 2023.

headline: Trump Ratchets Up Threats on the Media
abstract: Presidents are not all-powerful, but, if elected, Donald Trump would have some influence with the federal regulators who oversee major television networks.
lead_paragraph: Threatening the news media is nothing new for former President Donald J. Trump. He has accused major news outlets of defamation, blocked journalists from rallies and White House events, goaded followers into profane chants about CNN and popularized the term “fake news,” now embraced by autocrats around the world.

headline: Liberty Finally Give New York City a Basketball Championship
abstract: New York got its first basketball championship in 48 years, as the Liberty beat the Minnesota Lynx in front of exuberant fans in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: As the final second ticked off the clock, Breanna Stewart turned to her teammate Jonquel Jones for a long-awaited championship hug, as streamers floated down on the court and thousands of fans screamed, danced and recorded the moment on their phones.

headline: The 9/11 Defendants Were Captured Two Decades Ago. Why Hasn’t a Trial Started?
abstract: A new court, a death penalty case and even the weather have contributed to the go-slow process at Guantánamo Bay.
lead_paragraph: The five men who are accused of conspiring in the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks were captured two decades ago, but a trial is still unlikely to start before 2026.

headline: Do Hair Growth Supplements Work?
abstract: Online, videos abound of people saying the supplements make hair thicker, healthier and shinier. Do they really?
lead_paragraph: Online and off, many people have credited supplements with helping them overcome hair loss. Videos abound on TikTok of people saying that brands like Nutrafol and Viviscal made their hair thicker, healthier and shinier.

headline: How Can I Slash Halloween Waste?
abstract: We’ve got tips to make the holiday more sustainable, and maybe more fun, too.
lead_paragraph: Halloween shoppers in the United States are expected to spend more than $11 billion this year on candy, costumes and decorations like giant cobwebs, skeletons and enormous inflatable ghouls.

headline: A Cheapskate in Manhattan
abstract: Pop-up art, cheap theater tickets, Chinese food and a well-situated, if noisy, hotel: How to see Manhattan (and a bit of Brooklyn) on a budget.
lead_paragraph: People go to New York for the street life, restaurants, cultural treasures and more. I go to New York because it makes me think, which is how I found myself on a beautiful September morning walking the High Line on the West Side of Manhattan, marveling at the resilience of nature, the engineering of tall buildings and how people can afford to live here.

headline: An Exile Revisits the Squalor and Grandeur of 1960s Italy
abstract: Recounting the time his family spent in a former Italian brothel, André Aciman’s new memoir, “Roman Year,” picks up where 1994’s “Out of Egypt” left off.
lead_paragraph: About a third of the way through André Aciman’s “Roman Year” — an account of the time his family spent there when he was 16, exiled from his native Egypt for being Jewish — an uncle visits from New York, looks around the former brothel that is the Acimans’ new apartment and immediately urges them to move to America. “I wonder why it had never occurred to me,” Aciman writes, “or for that matter to either of my parents, that ours was not a life.” At its heart, this memoir is a search for that life from the limbo of dislocation.

headline: Who’s Afraid of William Shakespeare?
abstract: We will always need the works of the Bard, especially in moments of conflict and unrest.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, theater lovers in the Bay Area got some very bad news. California Shakespeare Theater, the beloved nonprofit company that has operated there for 50 years, announced that it would soon close in the face of an “insurmountable financial impasse.” As the artistic producer at the Shakespeare Theatre Company in Washington, I take losses like this to heart. And they worry me, too. It sometimes seems the American theater’s relationship to the Bard might be fraying.

headline: 5 Books to Help You Understand the Economy Before Voting
abstract: The brightest minds explore the issue at every level, from the levers that control inflation to the best way to achieve work-life balance.
lead_paragraph: Voters are forever worried about the economy — the price of homes and groceries, the rise and fall of the stock market, and, of course, taxes — but the economic policies that affect these things often seem unapproachable. Donald Trump wants to cut taxes and raise tariffs. Kamala Harris wants to raise taxes on high-income households and expand the social safety net. But what does that mean? And what are they hoping to achieve?

headline: Should We Be More Concerned About the Growing Use of Marijuana?
abstract: Cannabis is now legal in much of the United States. As its use increases, so do its harms. Is that a problem?
lead_paragraph: Please note: We ask that adults respect the intent of our Student Opinion questions and refrain from posting here. While there are many other places on nytimes.com for adults to have their say, this is the only forum that explicitly invites the voices of young people.

headline: Biden to Propose That Insurers Cover Over-the-Counter Birth Control
abstract: The new rules under the Affordable Care Act would include emergency contraception, a newly approved nonprescription birth control pill, spermicides and condoms.
lead_paragraph: The White House announced on Monday that it would propose new rules under the Affordable Care Act that would require insurers to cover over-the-counter birth control at no cost to patients, as it seeks to expand access to contraception and cut out-of-pocket costs.

headline: Scientists Are Mapping Landslide Risk in Alaska. Some Homeowners Don’t Want to Know.
abstract: Deadly landslides are increasing around the world. But in parts of Alaska, maps of the hazards remain controversial.
lead_paragraph: James and Bill Montivér had just finished boxing up their home on a steep road in Ketchikan, a fishing community turned cruise ship stop in southeast Alaska, when they heard a screech like a jet engine over the sounds of pouring rain.

headline: How Kamala Harris Should Put America First — for Real
abstract: As president, she can create a foreign policy fit for the 21st century.
lead_paragraph: If Kamala Harris reaches the Oval Office, she will inherit a dilemma larger than the sum of all the international conflicts and crises that will land on her desk: What is the purpose of American power now?

headline: Daniel Nigro Fronted an Emo Band. Now He Makes Pop Smashes.
abstract: The songwriter and producer has helped craft huge albums with Chappell Roan and Olivia Rodrigo. What’s the key to his success? “Dan always believed in me,” Roan said.
lead_paragraph: When Daniel Nigro and Chappell Roan wrote and recorded “Pink Pony Club” back in 2019, Nigro knew they had something special. The problem was, no one believed him.

headline: Why Chinese Are Rushing Into a ‘Casino’ Stock Market
abstract: Steps to bolster the economy have set off a stock buying frenzy. Our columnist spoke to Chinese investors about why they are jumping in knowing the risks.
lead_paragraph: They call China’s stock market a “casino,” yet they are rushing in. They are betting money that the government really does want to finally crawl out of the hole it has dug. They are speculating, looking for short-term gains, with a great degree of uneasiness.

headline: How the Writer André Aciman Learned to Live in Exile
abstract: When he was a teenager, Aciman’s family was turned out of Egypt and landed in Italy. In a beguiling new memoir, “Roman Year,” he revisits a lost era.
lead_paragraph: Give André Aciman a piece of fruit, and he will tell you a story. His 2007 debut novel, “Call Me By Your Name,” famously made great erotic hay of a peach — a proxy object of lust for his yearning teenage protagonist, ripe with juicy metaphor.

headline: Where Harris and Trump Stand on Abortion
abstract: In the first presidential election since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump bring sharply different records on abortion. Maggie Astor, a political reporter for The New York Times, describes where the candidates stand on the issue.
lead_paragraph: In the first presidential election since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump bring sharply different records on abortion. Maggie Astor, a political reporter for The New York Times, describes where the candidates stand on the issue.

headline: Kamala Harris Has an Unexpected Ally
abstract: If Trump wins, we’re going to be saddled with an isolationist and nativist conservative movement for generations to come.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Please don’t tell me you’re going to ask how I’m going to vote.

headline: The House Race Where Democrats Desperately Want the ‘Democrat’ to Lose
abstract: A write-in campaign appears to be Democrats’ only hope in a Georgia congressional district after a lawyer with extreme right-wing views won the party’s primary.
lead_paragraph: In a congressional race in the northern suburbs of Atlanta, Democrats have been spending the precious final days of the campaign making an urgent appeal: Do not vote for the “Democrat.”

headline: Can Trump really defund public schools that recognize transgender students?
Inside the Last-Ditch Hunt by Harris and Trump for Undecided Voters
abstract: Both campaigns are digging through troves of data to find these crucial Americans. They both think many are younger, Black or Latino. The Harris team is also eyeing white, college-educated women.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump are carrying out a virtual house-to-house hunt for the final few voters who are still up for grabs, guided by months of painstaking research about these elusive Americans.

headline: The 25 Best Restaurants in Atlanta Right Now
abstract: There’s no shortage of Southern virtuosity in the 404, but don’t miss the outstanding Indian, Italian and Thai cooking — or the amazing wings from an unexpected spot.
lead_paragraph: In the Where to Eat: 25 Best series, we’re highlighting our favorite restaurants in cities across the United States. These lists will be updated as restaurants close and open, and as we find new gems to recommend. As always, we pay for all of our meals and don’t accept free dishes.

headline: The Gadfly Journalist Who Punched Far Above His Weight
abstract: With a weekly newsletter and plenty of charm, the left-wing writer Claud Cockburn became a crucial polemical voice of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: One hundred years ago, Claud Cockburn was in his third year at Oxford. He would grow up to become a merry and piratical left-wing journalist, a horsefly on England’s body politic. For now, he was merely the most charming person many people had ever met. Friends and family competed to introduce him to well-known bores, knowing he could draw out anyone.

headline: Trump’s Bro Whispering Could Cost Democrats Too Many Young Men
abstract: Trump’s play for Generation Z men could peel enough away from the Democratic Party to transform the country’s electoral math for years to come.
lead_paragraph: Generation Z is poised to flex its growing political muscle in the 2024 presidential election, and in my surveys and focus groups with these voters, I’m seeing the strong potential for a turning point in American political alignment. Unlike other recent Republican presidential nominees, Donald Trump is making young men a central focus of his campaign. If effective, his effort could peel enough away from the Democratic Party to transform the country’s electoral math for years to come.

headline: ‘Sleep No More’ Megafans Face End of an Addictive Show
abstract: The immersive theater experience in Chelsea has been running since 2011. Now it is scheduled to shut in late November.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. James Barron is off today. We’ll meet superfans who have seen the interactive theater experience “Sleep No More” not once, not twice, but hundreds of times.

headline: $900,000 Homes in California
abstract: A 1922 bungalow in West Hollywood, a four-bedroom house from 1898 outside Monterey, and a two-story midcentury house in the Bay Area.
lead_paragraph: This two-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath house is a few blocks from a bustling stretch of Santa Monica Boulevard, and also from Plummer Park, which has tennis courts, a playground and space for picnicking. Sunset Boulevard is less than a mile away, putting the home within walking distance of landmarks like the Chateau Marmont hotel and the Laugh Factory comedy club.

headline: Bad News: We’ve Lost Control of Our Social Media Feeds. Good News: Courts Are Noticing.
abstract: A case involving TikTok may have opened the door to holding platforms liable for the damage they cause.
lead_paragraph: During a recent rebranding tour, the Meta chief Mark Zuckerberg, sporting Gen Z-approved tousled hair, streetwear and a gold chain, let the truth slip: Consumers no longer control their social-media feeds. Meta’s algorithm, he boasted, has improved to the point that it is showing users “a lot of stuff” not posted by people they had connected with and he sees a future in which feeds show you “content that’s generated by an A.I. system.”

headline: A Major Push to Protect Nature Is Happening Now
abstract: Delegates from around the world are meeting in Colombia in what is expected to be the biggest U.N. biodiversity conference in history.
lead_paragraph: On the agenda is life on earth, in all its forms and diversity. The big question is how far nations will go to stop the disastrous declines underway.

headline: Sean Combs’s Legal Woes Are Growing. So Are His Streaming Numbers.
abstract: The embattled music mogul is facing federal sex trafficking charges and a slew of lawsuits. Curious listeners and fans are keeping his catalog in rotation.
lead_paragraph: In the 11 months since the singer Cassie accused Sean Combs in a lawsuit of sexual assault and years of physical abuse, the mogul’s once-booming music career has largely fallen apart.

headline: Sorry, Trump: ‘There Is No American Race or Blood That Outsiders Can Pollute’
abstract: Identity-first arguments are flawed. The former president forced me to make one.
lead_paragraph: Since coming down the escalator to announce his bid for president in 2015, Donald Trump has disparaged and dehumanized immigrants. In this episode of “The Opinions,” the Opinion columnist Carlos Lozada, an immigrant from Peru, reflects on what it means to not just discuss the issue but to be at the center of it.

headline: States Revive Lawsuit to Sharply Curb Access to Abortion Pill
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled in June that the original plaintiffs, anti-abortion doctors and groups, did not have standing to sue. Now three states are trying to continue the legal fight.
lead_paragraph: A lawsuit seeking to sharply restrict the abortion pill mifepristone — a case the Supreme Court threw out this year — has re-emerged in a version that presents new challenges for abortion-rights supporters and the federal government’s ability to regulate abortion medication.

headline: Why Does This Building by the Subway Need 193 Parking Spots? (Yes, Exactly 193.)
abstract: New York and cities across the country reconsider decades-old parking rules.
lead_paragraph: New York and cities across the country reconsider decades-old parking rules.

headline: In ‘Smile 2’ and ‘Trap,’ Pop Stardom Looks Pretty Terrifying
abstract: At a time when the business of being Taylor Swift or Beyoncé is booming, these films examine toxic fandom and what can seem like mass hysteria.
lead_paragraph: This article contains spoilers.

headline: Putin Brings Together Economies He Hopes Will Eclipse the West
abstract: The Russian leader hopes to use the meeting of the so-called BRICS group, which includes China and India, as a counterweight to the West.
lead_paragraph: After Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022, the West imposed sweeping economic sanctions, cut its access to the global banking system, and sought to isolate Russia diplomatically from the rest of the world.

headline: A Writer Sees Leniency in the Supreme Court’s Approach to Public Corruption
abstract: A Georgetown law professor argues that five rulings by the justices in recent years have allowed behavior that is “sketchy as hell” and meant to make the judiciary look good by contrast.
lead_paragraph: Eight years ago, before revelations about luxury travel and gifts accepted by Justices Clarence Thomas and Samuel A. Alito Jr., the Supreme Court considered the case of a politician who had been prosecuted for public corruption after receiving similar benefits. The court threw out his conviction. In the years since, the court has overturned four other convictions in public corruption cases.

headline: Trump, Harris and the Enduring Symbolism of McDonald’s
abstract: McDonald’s tells a story about what both candidates think is possible for working people.
lead_paragraph: In presidential politics, you have to meet potential voters where they are. So every four years, churches, college campuses and even barbershops become the mainstays of the presidential campaign circuit. But, this year, the contenders have added the McDonald’s fry station. On Sunday, Donald Trump walked into a Bucks County, Pa., McDonald’s and told the store owner that he was looking for a job, explaining that “I’ve always wanted to work at McDonald’s.”

headline: State of the Race: A Slight Shift Toward Trump but Still No Clear Favorite
abstract: The polls are not precise enough for a 0.2-point edge to convey meaningful information.
lead_paragraph: With two weeks to go, the polls of the presidential election are starting to run out of room to get any closer.

headline: Events That Led to Close Call on Trump’s Life Were Preventable, Committee Finds
abstract: A House task force report included detailed accounts from law enforcement at the Butler, Pa., rally, including an officer who confronted the gunman.
lead_paragraph: The House task force on the attempted assassinations of former President Donald J. Trump released its first preliminary report on Monday, chastising the Secret Service for poor planning and a communications breakdown that resulted in a fatal shooting at Mr. Trump’s rally in Butler, Pa.

headline: Why Are Hospital Gowns So Ugly?
abstract: Curious why medical patient attire is so unflattering, a reader asks our fashion critic if it’s intentional.
lead_paragraph: Whoever named that garment traditionally associated with being a medical patient a “gown” surely deserves an award for irony. In truth, that shapeless schmatta that ties in the back leaving one’s rear end hanging out for the world to see, is, as you point out, one of the most unappealing items of clothing ever made. So unappealing, in fact, that no one has actually laid claim to its invention. (If you investigate, what comes up is “Seymour Butts.” Which is, ahem, not an actual name.)

headline: Meet the Florida Billionaire Who Wants to Be a Newspaper Baron
abstract: David Hoffmann has already bought 5 percent of one of America’s largest newspaper companies. Now, he wants to control the whole thing.
lead_paragraph: The newspaper industry has decayed so much in recent years that even Warren Buffett — the world-famous investor whose annual meetings have included a newspaper toss — has declared the business “toast.”

headline: Fethullah Gulen, Turkish Cleric and Erdogan Rival, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Gulen, who lived in the United States, was accused of plotting a coup against President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Fethullah Gulen, the preacher who founded an international Islamic movement and was a major ally of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey before being accused of plotting a coup against him in 2016, has died. He was 83.

headline: Judicial Overhaul Squeaks Through After High Political Drama in Pakistan
abstract: Supporters of the constitutional amendments said they would curb judicial activism. Critics said judicial independence had been damaged.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of intense political maneuvering, Pakistan’s Parliament has passed a set of constitutional amendments that will overhaul the process for appointing the country’s chief justice. Critics called it an effort to rein in the Supreme Court as it has emerged as a political force in its own right and challenged Pakistan’s powerful military establishment.

headline: After 43 Years, Yankees and Dodgers Resume Their World Series Rivalry
abstract: Even as the sport and the country have changed, the rivalry has produced some of baseball’s most memorable moments.
lead_paragraph: From the Bronx to Brooklyn to Los Angeles, the Yankees-Dodgers rivalry has produced some of baseball’s most memorable moments: spectacular catches, batting fireworks, even a perfect game. The franchises have met 11 times in the World Series, the most of any two teams.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 499
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Oct. 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,221
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Oct. 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: A Final Hunt for Undecided Voters, and Israel Escalates Its War in Lebanon
abstract: Plus, New York Liberty are W.N.B.A. champions.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: What Happens in Vegas Could Decide the Election
abstract: Exploring the impact of the housing crisis in Nevada, a swing state the Democrats have counted on for nearly two decades.
lead_paragraph: For millions of Americans, the housing crisis defines the U.S. economy. In the swing state of Nevada, it could soon define the election.

headline: Blinken to Visit Israel in Latest Push for Gaza Cease-Fire
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken is expected to depart on Monday in a renewed effort to bring calm to the region. The State Department did not say which other countries he might stop in.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken will depart on Monday for another trip to the Middle East that will include a stop in Israel, as the Biden administration makes a renewed effort to bring calm to the region after the death of the Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar.

headline: ‘You Are Not Our King’: Charles III Heckled in Australia’s Parliament
abstract: King Charles, visiting the former British colony where he retains the ceremonial title of head of state, was shouted at by an Indigenous Australian senator.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after King Charles III had finished making remarks in Australia’s Parliament on Monday, a voice rang out from the back of the hall. “You are not our king,” shouted Lidia Thorpe, an Indigenous senator and activist for Aboriginal rights. “Give us our land back. Give us what you stole from us.”

headline: Is Donald Trump an Isolationist?
abstract: We explore the stakes of another Trump presidency in terms of foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is often described as an isolationist, and there is a lot of truth in that label. Trump embraces the slogan “America First.” He criticizes military aid for Ukraine. He can be withering about America’s closest allies.

headline: U.S. Missile Defense System Arrives in Israel
abstract: The Terminal High Altitude Area Defense system was in place, Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said on Monday. The deployment comes as Israel prepares for retaliatory attacks against Iran.
lead_paragraph: An advanced missile defense system sent by the United States to Israel to thwart more attacks by Iran and its allies has arrived in Israel along with troops to operate it, Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said on Monday.

headline: Why the Oil and Gas Industry Is So Afraid of Kamala Harris
abstract: The Democratic candidate’s agenda takes climate change seriously.
lead_paragraph: When Donald Trump invited about 20 prominent oil and gas executives to dine with him at Mar-a-Lago in April, he made a breathtakingly corrupt proposal: If they raised a billion dollars to help him retake the White House, he would roll back any policy they didn’t like when he took office. Several fossil fuel companies and their executives have since answered his call with brio, becoming among the top donors to the Trump campaign and Trump-aligned super PACs.

headline: Read the Task Force’s Report
abstract: The House task force on the attempted assassinations of former President Donald J. Trump released its first preliminary report.
lead_paragraph: The House task force on the attempted assassinations of former President Donald J. Trump released its first preliminary report.

headline: Elon Musk’s $1 Million Giveaways Test the Bounds of Election Law
abstract: Legal experts question the billionaire’s plan to hand out huge payments in battleground states as part of a get-out-the-vote drive.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk made a name and a fortune for himself by questioning the status quo and bending rules. It’s an approach that helped Tesla and SpaceX achieve new breakthroughs and behemoth valuations.

headline: Disney Says It Will Hire a New C.E.O. in ‘Early 2026’
abstract: In a board shake-up, James Gorman, a director in charge of planning for a successor to the chief executive, Robert A. Iger, will become chairman on Jan. 2, 2025.
lead_paragraph: Disney said on Monday that it would name a new chief executive in “early 2026,” which is later than many in Hollywood had expected.

headline: Sinwar Is Dead, but a Palestinian State Seems More Distant Than Ever
abstract: A two-state solution remains the goal of the United States and the West, but many in the region say the devastation in Gaza and the lack of effective Palestinian leadership make it a remote prospect.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the Middle East crisis here.

headline: Vietnam Revives Power-Sharing Arrangement With New President
abstract: The move restores a “four pillar” government structure that divides top-level duties to avoid the rise of a single strongman.
lead_paragraph: Vietnam’s National Assembly approved a new president on Monday, restoring a power-sharing arrangement among four high-level leaders that has defined the country’s approach to Communist government for decades.

headline: Chappell Roan’s Rocket-Ship Year
abstract: The pop star’s ascent has tested the boundaries of contemporary pop, and may create a template for a next generation.
lead_paragraph: Chappell Roan has become one of the biggest breakout pop stars of the past year, and made it happen in novel fashion: creating grand-scale, 1980s-influenced pop refracted through a queer lens; building a drag-inspired performance character; and calling into question the way that fans worship their heroes while rapidly accumulating fans online and in real life.

headline: Life Without Sickle Cell Beckons Boy Who Completed Gene Therapy
abstract: After 44 days, Kendric Cromer, 12, left the hospital. While his family feels fortunate that he was the first to receive a treatment, their difficult experiences hint at what others will be up against.
lead_paragraph: Kendric Cromer, 12, left Children’s National Hospital in a wheelchair on Wednesday, wearing a T-shirt and cap printed with designs from the anime series “Naruto” and a black face mask. Staff lined the hallway, cheering and waving noisemakers. He had just become the first patient to receive a gene therapy for sickle cell since it was approved — a therapy that is expected to free him from the ravages of the disease.

headline: Texas House Postpones Testimony of Death Row Inmate in Shaken Baby Case
abstract: Robert Roberson, whose execution was postponed last week, had been subpoenaed to appear before a committee of the State House. A juror from his trial says she now believes he is innocent.
lead_paragraph: Robert Roberson, the Texas death row inmate whose execution in a strongly disputed shaken baby murder case was postponed last week, had been scheduled to testify on Monday before a committee of the State House, but his appearance was canceled in a dispute over whether he would be allowed to testify in person.

headline: How to Sell a Haunted House (or Not)
abstract: Even the most skeptical real estate agents say they think twice about the existence of ghosts, especially after unusual encounters.
lead_paragraph: A real estate agent, Mike Fabbri, still remembers the chill of opening the door of an apartment near Washington Square Park in Manhattan.

headline: Moldovans, Very Narrowly, Choose to Look Toward Europe, Not Russia
abstract: A referendum that constitutionally enshrines a national objective to join the E.U. passed by a thin margin. The incumbent pro-E.U. president won the most votes in a concurrent election, but faces a runoff.
lead_paragraph: A referendum in Moldova intended to put an end to decades of swerving between East and West yielded a microscopic win on Monday for voters who favor amending the Constitution to lock in alignment with Europe rather than Russia.

headline: Can You Find These 14 Hidden Book Titles in This Puzzle?
abstract: Look closely to uncover the recent memoirs lurking in this passage of text.
lead_paragraph: Look closely to uncover the recent memoirs lurking in this passage of text.

headline: An Easy, Five-Star Salad to Convert the Lentil-Skeptical
abstract: Paired with roasted sweet potatoes, tossed in a brown butter vinaigrette and showered with tangy goat cheese, the humble lentil becomes “absolutely superb.”
lead_paragraph: I have thoughts about lentils. Generally speaking, my first thought is that they’re awfully nice when simmered into a soup, broken down until the broth is thick and the lentils slurpable.

headline: Why Does Mental Illness Raise the Risk of Severe Covid?
abstract: People with psychiatric conditions are more likely to be hospitalized or die of the virus. Scientists have ideas about why that might be the case.
lead_paragraph: It’s been clear since the early days of the pandemic: People with mental illness are more likely to have severe outcomes from Covid. Compared to the general population, they’re at higher risk of being hospitalized, developing long Covid or dying from an infection.

headline: As Trump Served Up McDonald’s Fries, Vitriol Boiled Outside
abstract: In Pennsylvania, a critical swing state, supporters of Donald Trump and Kamala Harris, some in weird costumes, gathered along a roadside and screamed at one another.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday afternoon, former President Donald J. Trump dropped by a McDonald’s in Bucks County, Pa. He had cooked up a stunt to troll Vice President Kamala Harris, who has talked about having worked at McDonald’s one summer during college. Inside the restaurant, Mr. Trump wore an apron and dropped French fries into a vat of gurgling oil. Across the street, something much unhealthier was bubbling up.

headline: The Menendez Brothers Could be Released From Prison. Here’s What to Know.
abstract: Prosecutors have recommended that the brothers be resentenced, which could lead to their release from prison.
lead_paragraph: Over 35 years ago, Lyle and Erik Menendez — then 21 and 18 years old — walked into the den of their Beverly Hills mansion and fired more than a dozen shotgun rounds at their parents.

headline: Ralph Jennings, 86, Dies; Built Up Fordham’s Public Radio Station
abstract: He transformed WFUV from “a sandbox” into a professional operation, increasing its listenership nearly tenfold.
lead_paragraph: Ralph Jennings, who gave stature, stability, prosperity and broad influence to WFUV, Fordham University’s radio station, died on Oct. 9 in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Andrew V. Schally, 97, Dies; Scientist Shared Nobel Glory With Rival
abstract: His two-decade quest to find elusive brain hormones became a race against Roger Guillemin, a onetime colleague and an eventual fellow prizewinner.
lead_paragraph: Andrew V. Schally, an endocrinologist who was awarded a Nobel for discovering the hormones used by the brain to control growth, reproduction and other bodily functions, sharing the prize with his bitter rival, the neuroscientist Roger Guillemin, died on Thursday at his home in Miami Beach. He was 97.

headline: When Critic vs. Choreographer Ignited a Cultural Firestorm
abstract: Thirty years ago, Bill T. Jones presented “Still/Here,” and the critic Arlene Croce responded with an explosive essay. Now the work is returning to the Brooklyn Academy.
lead_paragraph: It landed like a bomb.

headline: ‘Monotonous and Filthy’: Paul Whelan’s Life in a Russian Prison
abstract: The former U.S. Marine describes the moment of his arrest and the long years waiting for his release.
lead_paragraph: Paul Whelan was in Moscow that day at the storied Metropole Hotel, getting ready for the wedding of a fellow U.S. Marine, when a longtime Russian friend, a junior officer in the frontier guards, dropped by unexpectedly.

headline: Mark Proksch, of ‘What We Do in the Shadows,’ Gets Into the Swing of It
abstract: As an “energy vampire,” the comic actor has been the most relatable menace in the FX comedy, which begins its final season.
lead_paragraph: On a recent evening, the actor Mark Proksch watched as a pirate ghost cavorted on a video monitor. “I love their idea of what counts as haunted,” he said.

headline: Why Severed Hands Are Haunting Contemporary Art
abstract: Painters and sculptors are exploring agency and femininity by depicting floating appendages.
lead_paragraph: In the London-based artist Paloma Proudfoot’s sculpture “Threaded” (2024), a disembodied hand with cherry-red fingernails loops a vein, as smooth as a ribbon, around an exposed spinal cord. The work is made of glazed ceramic, its delicacy contrasting with the gruesomeness of its subject matter. Proudfoot, 32, is inspired by anatomical models, and “Threaded” is part of a series of sculptures in which she explores the paternalistic experiments that informed the field of hypnotherapy and the treatment of hysteria in 19th-century France. While the field was pioneered by a man, Jean-Martin Charcot, in Proudfoot’s sculptures, the hands that manipulate the bodies and minds of the works’ female subjects are women’s — severed at the wrist, their nails neatly manicured.

headline: Corrections: Oct. 21, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 21, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: ‘Blade Runner 2049’ Producers Sue Elon Musk Over ‘Robotaxi’ Imagery
abstract: Alcon Entertainment, the Hollywood company behind “Blade Runner 2049,” said it had denied a request to use images from the movie but that Mr. Musk did so anyway.
lead_paragraph: The Hollywood company behind “Blade Runner 2049” sued Elon Musk for copyright infringement on Monday, accusing him of illegally using imagery from that film to promote Tesla’s new “robotaxi.”

headline: Israel Dismantles Iranian Spy Network and Arrests Seven People, Authorities Say
abstract: The suspects, all Israeli citizens, conducted intelligence missions for two years under the direction of two Iranian agents, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli authorities said on Monday that they have dismantled a spy network made up of seven Israelis who were gathering intelligence for Iran, adding that the seven had been arrested. It’s one of the largest such cases involving Iran since the war in Gaza began more than a year ago.

headline: Harris’s Faith, Inside and Outside the Black Church
abstract: Her biography embodies the multifaith, pluralistic and increasingly secular America she is bidding to lead.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Dr. Amos Brown was taking his usual Sunday afternoon nap in late July when a longtime congregant, Vice President Kamala Harris, called.

headline: Can a Synthetic Voice Be Taught to Sing Opera?
abstract: “The Other Side of Silence,” a new work in development, is experimenting with giving operatic voice to a text-to-speech synthesizer.
lead_paragraph: The opera opened with amplified breathing: gasps, hisses, labored inhalations. A string quartet introduced spidery harmonics that consolidated into brighter chords and were joined, over time, by radiant voices. Exuberantly lyrical, their lines unfolded in stark contrast with those of the protagonist, who, strapped into a wheelchair center stage, had thus far contributed only some short comments in the machine tones of a text-to-speech synthesizer.

headline: The Deeply Personal Price Women Must Pay for Abortion Bans
abstract: Exceptions to save a mother’s life don’t matter when doctors fear performing the procedure.
lead_paragraph: In Florida one day this spring, Megan Palmese and her husband put their two small children in the car and raced toward New York, hoping to arrive before her uterus ruptured and she bled to death.
