headline: What We Know About the Gangway Collapse That Killed 7 in Georgia
abstract: Disaster struck at the end of an annual cultural celebration on Sapelo Island. Twenty people went into the water, including seven people over the age of 70 who died.
lead_paragraph: Seven people died on Saturday when a gangway collapsed at a ferry dock on a Georgia island, the site of a festival celebrating the heritage of the Gullah Geechee, a community of descendants of formerly enslaved people in the Southeast.

headline: The Captain Jack Sparrow of Baking
abstract: A breakout contestant on “The Great British Baking Show” is drawing style comparisons to characters from “Pirates of the Caribbean,” “The Princess Bride” and more.
lead_paragraph: Long hair, strong eyebrows, silver hoop earrings, a goatee and the occasional bandanna makes Dylan Bachelet’s style feel both unique and uncannily familiar.

headline: As Harris Courts Sun Belt, Housing Costs Stand in Her Way
abstract: Shuttered factories and trade deals helped turn working-class Midwesterners against Democrats. Will the high cost of housing do the same in the Sun Belt?
lead_paragraph: The promise of the American dream has shimmered in Las Vegas for as long as the city has existed. That hope of a stable middle-class life has attracted would-be homeowners from California, sun-seekers from the East and immigrants from all over the world.

headline: On X, the Definition of ‘Blocking’ Is About to Change
abstract: A change in how the site works will allow people to see posts by users who have them blocked. The company claims it is for “transparency,” but some people are worried about abuse.
lead_paragraph: A lot has changed on the social media platform formerly known as Twitter since Elon Musk bought it two years ago. The company, renamed X, is on the verge of yet another major shift, with changes coming for what happens when one user blocks another.

headline: The Lawsuits Against Sean Combs
abstract: The music mogul, who faces federal sex trafficking and racketeering charges, has been accused in civil court of raping and drugging people. He has denied the allegations.
lead_paragraph: In November 2023, the R&B singer Cassie filed a lawsuit against the hip-hop mogul Sean Combs, her former record label head and boyfriend, accusing him of rape, of forcing her to participate in sexual encounters he called “freak-offs” and of ongoing physical abuse for about a decade. Mr. Combs, who is also known as Puff Daddy or Diddy, has “vehemently” denied the allegations.

headline: Liz Cheney and Harris Make a Play for G.O.P. Women in ‘Blue Wall’ Suburbs
abstract: As the pair campaigned together in suburban areas of battleground states, the Republican former congresswoman served as Ms. Harris’s ambassador to conservative women.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris made a concerted effort on Monday to appeal to Republican women in the nation’s suburbs, using former Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming as her ambassador to conservatives during events in well-to-do suburbs of the biggest cities in three important battleground states.

headline: Arkansas May Have Vast Lithium Reserves, Researchers Say
abstract: Federal and state researchers said there might be five million to 19 million tons of lithium, more than enough to meet the world’s demand for the battery ingredient.
lead_paragraph: Researchers at the United States Geological Survey and the Arkansas government announced on Monday that they had found a trove of lithium, a critical raw material for electric vehicle batteries, in an underground brine reservoir in Arkansas.

headline: Central Park 5 Sue Trump for Defamation Over Debate Comments
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s remarks during the presidential debate are part of a “continuing pattern” of false statements designed to “make the men suffer,” the lawsuit charged.
lead_paragraph: Five Black and Latino men who were wrongly convicted as teenagers and later exonerated in the rape and assault of a jogger in Central Park sued former President Donald J. Trump in federal court on Monday, saying he defamed them during a nationally televised debate.

headline: Trump’s Behavior at the Al Smith Dinner
abstract: Readers respond to a Maureen Dowd column and a Campaign Notebook. Also: The need to vote; the education crisis; dead trees; Juan Soto’s magic.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Old School Glamour at the Met Gala of the West Coast
abstract: The Academy Museum Gala delivered what red carpets are made for.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time there was the Oscars: the most star-spangled red carpet event of the year. Then the Met Gala became the “Oscars of the East Coast,” an even more eye-popping entrance outfit event. And now there is the Academy Museum Gala, which only four years in is starting to look a lot like … well, the Met Gala of the West Coast.

headline: People Keep Making These Six Mistakes About Inflation
abstract: Thanks to human nature, we misunderstand the pain, and sometimes the purpose, of rising prices.
lead_paragraph: It is entirely possible that former President Donald Trump will get back into the White House in large part because Americans misunderstand inflation.

headline: Nicole Scherzinger, Kit Connor Headline a Week of Buzzy Broadway Openings
abstract: Actors, directors and influencers gathered for a Gen-Z-infused “Romeo + Juliet,” and a stripped-back revival of “Sunset Boulevard.”
lead_paragraph: Two much-anticipated Broadway revivals opened this week: “Romeo + Juliet,” a clubby, neon version of Shakespeare’s play, and a stripped-back production of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s 1993 musical “Sunset Boulevard.” See the opening-night celebrations for both that lasted until the early hours of the morning.

headline: How Media Outlets on the Left and Right Covered Trump’s Stop at McDonald’s
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump’s campaign event at a McDonalds in Pennsylvania was described by right-leaning outlets as a brilliant move. Left-leaning publications called it weird.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump worked the fryer at a McDonald’s in Pennsylvania on Sunday — an unusual campaign stop that fueled an onslaught of coverage from media outlets across the political spectrum.

headline: Trump Says He Has Seen No Evidence of Cheating in the Election, but Nonetheless Sows Doubts
abstract: The former president, asked at a news conference in storm-damaged North Carolina if he had seen anything to suggest the election would be unfair, said, “I have not seen that.”
lead_paragraph: With early voting underway in many states, former President Donald J. Trump acknowledged Monday that he had seen no signs of cheating, even as he continued to sow doubts about the integrity of the election during a campaign swing through North Carolina.

headline: Brazilian Fossil Hints at Older Origin for All Dinosaurs
abstract: The discovery may push back the emergence of the reptiles that once ruled the Earth, and clarify how dinosaurs like the Triceratops and Stegosaurus emerged.
lead_paragraph: A dog-size reptile slipped through fern-choked forests 237 million years ago in what is today Paraíso do Sul, Brazil. The animal had the body of a greyhound, a long neck and tail, and a small, nipping beak. Running on four, upright legs, the reptile looked remarkably like an early dinosaur. Yet it lived almost 10 million years before any other known dinosaurs.

headline: What Is Al-Qard al-Hasan, the Hezbollah-Linked Finance Group Targeted by Israel?
abstract: The de facto bank is the largest microcredit organization in a country where the traditional banking sector is in shambles.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military conducted a wave of airstrikes across Lebanon on Sunday, targeting multiple branches of Al-Qard al-Hasan, a financial organization that functions as a bank and is associated with the Iranian-backed militant group Hezbollah.

headline: Olivia Nuzzi and New York Magazine Part Ways
abstract: Ms. Nuzzi, a political writer for the magazine, had been on leave since she disclosed a personal relationship with Robert F. Kennedy Jr. last month.
lead_paragraph: The star political writer Olivia Nuzzi of New York magazine, who has been embroiled in scandal since she disclosed a personal relationship with the former presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr., has left the magazine.

headline: Paul Di’Anno, Early Iron Maiden Frontman, Dies at 66
abstract: He sang with the band in its early years before being replaced by Bruce Dickinson. He later worked with other bands and pursued a solo career.
lead_paragraph: Paul Di’Anno, an English singer who was an early frontman for the popular heavy metal band Iron Maiden in the 1970s and ’80s, has died at his home in Salisbury, England. He was 66.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Two Weeks Until Election Day
abstract: Plus, Aleksei Navalny’s memoir.
lead_paragraph: With two weeks to go before the Nov. 5 vote,  polls show Donald Trump and Kamala Harris are running neck and neck, Nate Cohn, The Times’s chief political analyst, writes.

headline: Trump Took a Turn at the Fryer. McDonald’s Workers Have Thoughts.
abstract: After Donald J. Trump served fast food during a campaign stop at a McDonald’s, several workers said the candidate showed a willingness to learn but should stick to his day job.
lead_paragraph: Inside a McDonald’s in Lower Manhattan, David Ye, who has worked at the fast-food outpost for three years, knew in just a few seconds that something was off.

headline: Bruce Ames, 95, Dies; Biochemist Discovered Test for Toxic Chemicals
abstract: The Ames Test offered a fast and inexpensive way to identify carcinogens, leading to the banning of chemicals linked to cancer and birth defects.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Nathan Ames, a biochemist who discovered a revolutionary method of detecting potential carcinogens, paving the way for the banning of many commonly used chemicals, died on Oct. 5 in Berkeley, Calif. He was 95.

headline: Ward Christensen, Early Visionary of Social Media, Dies at 78
abstract: Housebound during a 1978 blizzard, he and a friend began devising the first computer bulletin board, a forerunner of online services like Reddit, TikTok and Facebook.
lead_paragraph: Ward Christensen, a computer scientist who helped build the first online bulletin board, a forerunner of the internet messaging apps and social media services that would become a staple of modern life, died on Oct. 11 at his home in Rolling Meadows, Ill. He was 78.

headline: The Mets Gave My Son With Autism a Gift. Now Is a Good Time to Say Thank You.
abstract: This team had a lot going for it, in all the ways that matter.
lead_paragraph: “What a story, right?”

headline: Harris Is Searching for Precious Swing Voters
abstract: Also, the first sickle cell gene therapy patient left the hospital. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris hit the road today for campaign events in the three battleground states that make up her clearest possible path to victory: Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin. In each state, Harris is holding sit-down discussions with the former congresswoman Liz Cheney, her most prominent conservative surrogate.

headline: A Nationwide Blackout, Now a Hurricane. How Much Can Cuba Endure?
abstract: The repeated failure of the power grid and a hurricane that has swamped the island’s eastern end has many Cubans fed up, posing a challenge to the Communist government.
lead_paragraph: The lights came back on Sunday night in Lidia Núñez Gómez’s Havana neighborhood — the first time since Friday morning — so she rushed to use her electric cooker to save the frozen chicken legs and pork her son had sent her from the United States.

headline: Deaths of 3 Lebanese Soldiers Draw Apology From Israel
abstract: The deaths showed the complexity of Israel’s fight with Hezbollah: Lebanon’s army is not a party to the conflict, but it is taking place in its territory.
lead_paragraph: Three Lebanese soldiers were killed on Sunday by Israeli troops in southern Lebanon, drawing condemnation from the Lebanese Armed Forces and prompting Israel’s military to apologize for what it called “these unwanted circumstances.”

headline: Republican Official in Arizona Pleads Guilty in Election Certification Case
abstract: Peggy Judd, a county supervisor in Cochise County, a hotbed of election conspiracy theories, had tried to delay certifying the 2022 election results.
lead_paragraph: A Republican county official in Arizona who delayed certification of the 2022 election pleaded guilty Monday to a misdemeanor charge of failing or refusing to perform her duty as an election officer.

headline: Trump on the Civil War, in His Own Words
abstract: It’s hard to compromise with those who consider any criticism a threat.
lead_paragraph: This is the third in an occasional series about Donald Trump’s statements and language and what’s at stake in the election.

headline: U.S. Tries to End War in Lebanon That Biden Envoy Calls ‘Out of Control’
abstract: Israel and Hezbollah say they will keep up attacks in an escalating conflict that has devastated Gaza, is causing misery in Lebanon and could draw Iran deeper into the fighting.
lead_paragraph: As Israel vowed to continue its attacks against the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah, a White House emissary visiting Lebanon on Monday said the conflict had “escalated out of control” and called for the enforcement of a United Nations resolution that ended the previous major war between them, in 2006.

headline: What Is ‘Pink Cocaine’?
abstract: The drug cocktail can contain ketamine, Ecstasy and meth — but rarely cocaine itself.
lead_paragraph: A powder called “pink cocaine,” made up of a revolving group of drugs, has become a dangerous and increasingly popular part of the club scene in U.S. cities, according to the Drug Enforcement Administration and epidemiologists who study recreational drug use.

headline: What Is the U.N. Resolution That Tried and Failed to Keep the Peace in Lebanon?
abstract: U.N. Security Council Resolution 1701 was intended to create a buffer zone between Israel and Hezbollah. Here’s a look at why it didn’t and what lies ahead in efforts to end the conflict in Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: A 2006 resolution by the United Nations Security Council ended the previous Israel-Hezbollah war but failed to keep the peace. Now, diplomats are fighting an uphill battle to revive the measure and pull the Middle East back from the brink of all-out war.

headline: Harris Wants Moderate Republicans to Back Her. Are They Out There?
abstract: It’s an unusual effort that reflects just how close the race is.
lead_paragraph: Stella Sexton, a lifelong Democrat, did something yesterday that at another time in American political history might have felt kind of weird.

headline: Liz Cheney Campaigns for Harris
abstract: Appearing side by side at a campaign event in Michigan, the Republican former congresswoman expressed her support for Vice President Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: Appearing side by side at a campaign event in Michigan, the Republican former congresswoman expressed her support for Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: In Trump Ad, ‘Not a Thing That Comes to Mind’ Ties Harris to Biden’s Liabilities
abstract: Kamala Harris’s hesitancy to put daylight between her and President Biden gave Donald Trump’s campaign a big opening.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign is running this 30-second ad on television stations across the battleground states, spending more than $10 million on it over the past six days, according to AdImpact.

headline: Would Harris’s Expanded Child Tax Credit Be Worth the Cost?
abstract: Some Republicans, including JD Vance, are also on board.
lead_paragraph: Some Republicans, including JD Vance, are also on board.

headline: Tracking Tropical Storm Kristy
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Kristy.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Kristy.

headline: The Election Has Taken Over TikTok. Here’s What It Looks Like.
abstract: Tens of thousands of videos are posted to TikTok each week about the presidential election, including dances set to songs made from speech snippets, comedic impersonations, pranks and even news commentary.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of videos are posted to TikTok each week about the presidential election, including dances set to songs made from speech snippets, comedic impersonations, pranks and even news commentary.

headline: Tracking Tropical Depression Trami
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Trami.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Trami.

headline: Dock Tragedy Strikes a Georgia Community Fighting to Protect Its Culture
abstract: The deaths of seven people on Sapelo Island have brought to the fore longstanding frustrations among its Gullah Geechee community.
lead_paragraph: The dozens of descendants of enslaved people who form the backbone of the Gullah Geechee community on Sapelo Island, off the coast of Georgia, have fought for years to protect their homes and traditions from the erosion of time and development.

headline: Understanding the BRICS Summit
abstract: The group, which seeks to rebalance the global order away from the West, will meet on Tuesday. Here’s a primer.
lead_paragraph: Leaders of BRICS, a group of emerging market nations that represent about half of the world’s population, will meet for a high-profile summit on Tuesday, their first since a major expansion last year.

headline: End of the Line, Maybe
abstract: Barbara Lin finds a creative way to get to the bottom of things.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Thelma Mothershed Wair, 83, Dies; One of 9 Who Integrated a School
abstract: In 1957, she and eight other Black students — the Little Rock Nine — enrolled in a high school in the face of racist mobs and a resistant Jim Crow governor.
lead_paragraph: Thelma Mothershed Wair, one of nine Black students who became known as the Little Rock Nine for integrating a high school in 1957 in an explosive confrontation during the civil rights struggle, died on Saturday in Little Rock, Ark. She was 83.

headline: With Election Day 2 Weeks Away, 17 Million Voters Have Already Cast a Ballot
abstract: Democrats have dominated early voting in the past. In some key states, Republicans have begun to make gains.
lead_paragraph: With two weeks until Election Day, more than 17 million people have already cast their ballots, the clearest sign yet that voting habits were forever changed by the coronavirus pandemic and that early voting has become a permanent feature of the American democratic process.

headline: Elon Musk Donates Legal Maximum to Trump Campaign
abstract: Mr. Musk, a megadonor, had flummoxed some Trump advisers by previously declining to write a “super max” check directly to the former president’s campaign.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk may have started a super PAC and poured over $75 million into supporting former President Donald J. Trump, but for months he wouldn’t do something far cheaper and less glamorous: donate the legal maximum to Mr. Trump’s campaign.

headline: Jayland Walker’s Family Settles With Akron for $4.8 Million Over Police Shooting
abstract: The family had filed a lawsuit against the Ohio city and its police department after Mr. Walker was fatally shot by eight police officers in 2022.
lead_paragraph: The family of a Black man who was fatally shot by eight police officers after an attempted traffic stop in Ohio in 2022 settled a wrongful-death lawsuit with the city of Akron for $4.8 million, the mayor’s office announced on Monday.

headline: Trump Courts Christian Voters, Days After Vulgar Remarks at a Rally
abstract: In a nearly hourlong speech before a crowd that included evangelical leaders, he claimed that only he could protect Christian voters. He did not mention abortion once.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump on Monday used the language of persecution to make a sweeping claim that only he could protect Christian voters, darkly warning religious communities that they would come under legal, cultural, political and global assault if he lost in November.

headline: Quote of the Day: Good Reason to Cry Foul Over the Poor Officiating
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, October 22, 2024
lead_paragraph: “Officiating, it’s not that hard.”

headline: Corrections: Oct. 22, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Oct. 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: A theater review on Friday about the show “Our Town” misstated the gender of the geologist character in this production. The character is a woman, not a man. (The geologist is a man in the play’s original script.)

headline: Four Years in Jail Without Trial: The Price of Dissent in Modi’s India
abstract: A Muslim protest leader has become a symbol of a wide-ranging clampdown on opponents of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government.
lead_paragraph: The family gathers around the laptop in New Delhi once a week. Sometimes, relatives dial in from north India, or even the United States. They wait for Umar Khalid, 37, an Indian political activist, to appear on the screen from jail.

headline: A Radical Approach to Flooding in England: Give Land Back to the Sea
abstract: When a huge tract of land on the Somerset coast was deliberately flooded, the project was slammed as “ridiculous” by a local lawmaker. But the results have been transformative.
lead_paragraph: The rain has fallen for what feels like two years straight: in drizzles, in showers and, with troubling regularity, in downpours. The weather has always been Britain’s favorite topic of conversation. The clouds are familiar. Increasingly, though, they are also a threat.

headline: The Coup Attempt That Set Turkey on a Path to Authoritarianism
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and Fethullah Gulen, the powerful preacher who died this week, began as allies. But their falling out brought bloodshed and an Erdogan crackdown.
lead_paragraph: It was a spectacular falling out.

headline: In a Malaysian Pop-Up City, Echoes of China’s Housing Crash
abstract: Forest City was an audacious $100 billion project by a top Chinese developer. Today, the project is a fraction of what had been planned and the developer is broke.
lead_paragraph: It was an audacious real estate project undertaken a decade ago by a Chinese developer: a $100 billion city in Malaysia built on sand and shrubby mangroves and sold as a luxury “dream paradise” for China’s middle class.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Two weeks to the U.S. election.
lead_paragraph: With two weeks to go before Americans head to the polls, Donald Trump and Kamala Harris are running neck and neck, Nate Cohn, The Times’s chief political analyst, writes.

headline: China Turns Up the Heat on Taiwan With Live-Fire Drills
abstract: The drills were the latest show of force by China, which claims Taiwan as its territory and has protested Western support for the island.
lead_paragraph: China said it would carry out live-fire military drills in the Taiwan Strait on Tuesday, the latest in a recent drumbeat of military activity that has once again heightened tensions in the region.

headline: Word of the Day: holistic
abstract: This word has appeared in 176 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word holistic has appeared in 176 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 30 in “The Plan to Save Frank Lloyd Wright’s Only Skyscraper Isn’t Going as Planned” by Annie Aguiar:

headline: Late Night Mocks Trump for His McDonald’s Photo Op
abstract: The ex-president’s stint at the drive-through window was “blue-collar drag,” said Stephen Colbert. “But with more makeup.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Why New York’s Orthodox Jewish Voters Could Tip the Battle for the House
abstract: In three key swing districts in New York’s Hudson Valley, candidates are pressing for the support of ultra-Orthodox Jews, who tend to vote as a bloc.
lead_paragraph: Representative Pat Ryan of New York is locked in one of the country’s toughest races. So it was especially noteworthy when the Democrat recently traveled hours outside his upstate district to visit an unusual set of influencers, Hasidic rabbis.

headline: The Person Leading The Times’s Politics Team
abstract: That the election cycle has been turbulent may be the understatement of the century. And David Halbfinger is overseeing coverage of every twist and turn through Election Day and its aftermath.
lead_paragraph: Election Day is 14 days away. Every day of the countdown, Times Insider will share an article about how our election coverage works. Today, the editor of the Politics team offers a bird’s-eye view.

headline: People Pleasing
abstract: Do you tend to prioritize others’ needs ahead of your own? When have you been able to stand up for yourself, even if it was hard?
lead_paragraph: Are you a people pleaser, someone who tends to prioritize other people’s wants and needs at the expense of your own? If so, how does this tendency play out in your life? Do you think it helps you? Hurts you? How do you balance it with taking care of yourself?

headline: You’re Being Lied To About Voter Fraud. Here’s the Truth.
abstract: Widespread cheating at the polls is a myth. So what are election deniers really after?
lead_paragraph: Widespread cheating at the polls is a myth. So what are election deniers really after?

headline: ‘We Are Still Afraid’: Life Inside Northern Israel
abstract: Homes in northern Israel along the Lebanon border have been under the constant threat of Hezbollah’s rocket attacks since October of last year. We look at life on the ground for the few Israelis who stayed behind.
lead_paragraph: Homes in northern Israel along the Lebanon border have been under the constant threat of Hezbollah’s rocket attacks since October of last year. We look at life on the ground for the few Israelis who stayed behind.

headline: What Life Looks Like for Israelis Living Near Lebanon’s Border
abstract: Homes in northern Israel along the Lebanon border have been under the constant threat of Hezbollah’s rocket attacks since October of last year. We look at life on the ground for the few Israelis who stayed behind.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli village of Shtula sits just south of the Lebanon border, so close that the outgoing thud of artillery permeating the town’s emptiness comes from the Iranian-backed militia Hezbollah, not the Israeli Defense Forces. I.D.F. tanks and armored vehicles can be seen moving into place on the Israeli side of the border as the military expands its ground operations in Lebanon.

headline: The Quest to Save the ‘King’ of Japanese Rice From Rising Temperatures
abstract: Scientists in Japan are mining DNA to try to make the country’s famous Koshihikari rice resistant to heat, after a broiling summer ravaged the crop.
lead_paragraph: Scientists in Japan are racing against time to save the country’s most popular rice from the devastating effects of climate change.

headline: Art to See at U.S. Museums, Galleries and Auction Houses This Fall
abstract: Many exhibitions around the country will showcase artists’ responses to political and social movements, and to their own histories.
lead_paragraph: This fall, museums and galleries across the country are exploring how art forms and styles have evolved at pivotal points in history. They are also celebrating the people who ushered in these changes, such as artists from the early to mid-1300s — at the dawn of the Italian Renaissance and the Black Death — and the 1970s — in the midst of the Watergate scandal and the Vietnam War. As history repeats itself, modern pioneers, too, reinvent and influence art in response to evolving societal and political issues, like threats to democracy and climate change.

headline: How to Bring People Back to New York City
abstract: The essential ingredient of urban living — the quality of life — has tanked in the city.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, New York City’s population fell by 823,000 people, a loss of more than 10 percent. Crime rose by a third. As people and businesses fled, the city got dirtier, parks deteriorated and subways were scrawled with graffiti. The quality of life ebbed and financial disaster loomed; by 1975, the city had run out of money and had to turn to the state and, ultimately, the federal government, to avoid bankruptcy. It took New York two decades to get all those people back.

headline: For Vance, an Idyllic Appalachian Startup Became a Hard Lesson
abstract: During JD Vance’s brief career as a venture capitalist, few startups attracted his support more than AppHarvest, a now bankrupt plan to build greenhouses across Appalachia.
lead_paragraph: For JD Vance, it seemed like the perfect investment.

headline: Are Organic Foods Really More Nutritious?
abstract: Here’s how they stack up against their conventional counterparts.
lead_paragraph: Q: Buying organic can get expensive. Does the higher price tag come with health benefits?

headline: Harris’s Early Career: Prosecutor by Day, Boldface Name by Night
abstract: As Kamala Harris toiled as a junior prosecutor in Alameda County, Calif., she developed important connections among San Francisco’s financial and social elite.
lead_paragraph: In August 1996, a jury in an Oakland, Calif., courtroom convicted a man of slicing off a portion of his girlfriend’s scalp. The prosecutor was Kamala Harris, and the gruesome case was one of the few that made news early in her career.

headline: An Artist’s Work Finds a Lasting Home
abstract: A new permanent exhibition in a house in Pittsburgh displays the creativity and artistry of Mark Dion.
lead_paragraph: The artist Mark Dion stood in the hallway of a three-story house in Troy Hill in Pittsburgh recently, ruminating on what was about to become a unique home for his wildly unusual array of creations.

headline: See the Ancient Creatures That Might Have Been Beneath Your Feet
abstract: Celebrating its 150th anniversary, the San Diego Natural History Museum has opened more of its vast paleontology exhibit to visitors.
lead_paragraph: “We found something.”

headline: John le Carré, With a Son’s Help, Comes Back In From the Cold War
abstract: Nick Harkaway’s novel “Karla’s Choice” revisits the British spy George Smiley a few years after the construction of the Berlin Wall.
lead_paragraph: In an intriguing afterword to John le Carré’s last novel, “Silverview” (2021), Nick Harkaway, the novelist’s son, wrote that he had promised to finish any work of fiction his father left incomplete at the time of his death. When le Carré died in 2020, Harkaway thought there might be quite a bit of work to do. Then he read “Silverview” and discovered that the book was “not incomplete, but withheld.” Why?

headline: How Developers Are Catering to Would-Be Homeowners With Rental Amenities
abstract: Families are choosing to rent for the foreseeable future  — some out of necessity, others for amenities.
lead_paragraph: In the traditional trajectory of living patterns, city dwellers tend to rent until they have children and continue to lease through their preschool years. Eventually, in pursuit of the classic American dream of owning a home, they buy within their city or decamp to the suburbs.

headline: 6 Books to Help You Understand the Reproductive Rights Debate
abstract: Journalists and scholars explore the issue at every level, from the movement that took down Roe to the human stories of women who had abortions, and those who were denied.
lead_paragraph: Around this time two years ago, political pundits were predicting an electoral blood bath. The 2022 midterms were supposed to prove ruinous for Democrats. Instead, they won a historic set of races — flipping state legislatures, gaining a Senate seat and minimizing losses in the House.

headline: In the Background, but at the Center of Founding MoMA
abstract: In a new publication, “Inventing the Modern,” and a companion exhibition, 14 women who shaped the institution come into definition themselves.
lead_paragraph: When three women founded the first museum in New York dedicated to Modern art in 1929, MoMA was an uncertain and scrappy project hardly assured of success. Visitors had to take an elevator to rented office space on the 12th floor of 730 Fifth Avenue to see paintings many considered controversial at best.

headline: Why the Philippines’ Vice President Talked About Beheading Her Boss
abstract: The alliance between Sara Duterte and President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr., which brought two notorious dynasties together, has unraveled in spectacular fashion.
lead_paragraph: Sara Duterte was fed up.

headline: Jeff VanderMeer Returns to the Uncanny World of Area X
abstract: The author’s Southern Reach trilogy, which began with “Annihilation” in 2014, now has a fourth installment, a prequel.
lead_paragraph: In a 1943 essay, the Argentine author Jorge Luis Borges wrote, “There is an untranslatable English epithet, ‘uncanny,’ to denote supernatural horror.” Instead of further defining it, Borges offered a few vivid illustrations.

headline: Chase Hall Wrestles With ‘Hybridity’
abstract: The artist, who is frank about the issues raised by his mixed race, has a solo show opening in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: It isn’t hard to get Chase Hall talking. Having grown up with a mother in and out of rehab and a father in and out of jail; attended eight schools before the age of 16; and achieved an enviable degree of fame for an untrained 31-year-old artist, Hall has a lot to say.

headline: Riding the Rails, Literally, on a Pedal-Powered Bike
abstract: Rail-biking uses specially designed vehicles that are pedaled along disused railway lines. It’s easy and fun and uses existing tracks for recreation. One writer gave it a try in the Catskills.
lead_paragraph: It’s always a thrill to pull out of a train station and feel yourself picking up speed, wheels click-clacking over the rails. It’s even more thrilling when your train has no roof or sides, is as low-slung as a Mazda Miata and comes with a warning to watch out for bears crossing your path.

headline: A New Roy Hargrove LP Reminds Us What the Trumpeter Left Behind
abstract: “Grande-Terre,” recorded in Guadeloupe in 1997, shows off the high-wire, from-the-gut jazz Hargrove played most nights of his life.
lead_paragraph: Unlike most “lost” posthumous jazz albums, “Grande-Terre,” a release from the trumpeter Roy Hargrove and his bebop-goes-Havana band Crisol that arrived on Friday, is no live recording, rehearsal tape or leftover session scraps best suited to die-hard fans. The LP, recorded in Pointe-à-Pitre, Guadeloupe, in 1998 as a sequel to “Habana” from the previous year, is an ambitious, studio-recorded, global jazz party, sun-kissed and island-hopping.

headline: Bethany Joy Lenz Wanted Community. She Ended Up in a Cult.
abstract: The “One Tree Hill” actor has written a memoir of the decade she spent beholden to the Big House Family — and her escape.
lead_paragraph: Bethany Joy Lenz knows cults have gone a little mainstream. “When I tell someone I was in a cult, their first response is: ‘Which one?’” she writes in her sharp, confessional memoir, “Dinner for Vampires.” People are hoping she’ll say one they recognize from a Netflix documentary; “I see the disappointment on their faces when I say, ‘Just a small Bible-based group in the Pacific Northwest.’” It may not be a household name, but that group, known as the Big House Family, preyed upon Lenz’s psychological and financial well-being for a decade, leeching her of any perceived free will.

headline: Blending Reality With Fiction in Video Game Horror
abstract: Although it’s an expensive, arduous process, developers are experimenting with live-action footage to intensify terror.
lead_paragraph: It is a video game horror renaissance.

headline: A Dinky Little Computer Program Is My Secret Weapon for Creativity
abstract: Remember Microsoft Paint? It’s more perfect than ever.
lead_paragraph: My generation may be the last to have childhood memories of a family “computer room” — though ours was really more of a computer nook: a perpetually dark, narrow corner, packed with tangled wires and plug-in speakers, discarded tchotchkes, dusty dishware and tumbleweeds of dog hair. This was also my sanctuary.

headline: Sorry, Trump. The Issue of Abortion Is Not Going Away.
abstract: It resists all attempts at moderation and compromise.
lead_paragraph: If there is one thing we have learned from Republicans during this election, it is that they would like the issue of abortion to disappear.

headline: Ducks Do More Than You Might Think to Help Save the Planet
abstract: At the Bruce Museum, an exhibition of duck stamp art tells a 90-year-old story about how paintings can contribute to land preservation.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to be a conservationist or a hunter to marvel at the portraits at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Conn. Each one is of a duck. Some show ducks flying — mergansers, pintails, mallards and eiders. Some show ducks swimming. One shows a dog with a duck in its mouth.

headline: A Reluctant Satirist Takes On the Bomb
abstract: Armando Iannucci, the mastermind behind “Veep,” has adapted “Dr. Strangelove” for the theater and insists that laughing at nuclear disaster couldn’t be more timely.
lead_paragraph: About two years ago, when Armando Iannucci began adapting “Dr. Strangelove” for the West End, he didn’t think the 1964 movie had many direct parallels to today.

headline: How Cheerleading Became So Acrobatic, Dangerous and Popular
abstract: For decades, the sport has been shaped in large part by one company — and one man.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Jennings started cheering when she was 4 years old. She was small and flexible and became a flyer, a human baton spinning and twisting through the air before being caught by teammates. Until sometimes she wasn’t: She got her first concussion in the third grade.

headline: The 17 Best Bagels in New York City Right Now
abstract: The age-old debate continues.
lead_paragraph: There are few things New Yorkers like to argue about more than bagels, especially now that we’re at a bagel inflection point.

headline: New York Was a Shopping Town. Is It Again?
abstract: Small, medium and large: There seem to be signs of life for brick-and-mortar operations of every size in the city … once again.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, the combination of uptown bankruptcies (Barneys) and downtown closures (Opening Ceremony) has challenged New York’s reputation as a shopping city. That was followed by the challenges brought to retailers by the pandemic, which precipitated the shuttering of a string of medium-size multibrand boutiques like Totokaelo, Jeffrey and Bird in quick succession.

headline: Which Republican Might Join a Harris Cabinet? We Asked Around.
abstract: In a text message, Mitt Romney sounded down on the idea. John Bolton said his chances were “substantially less than zero.” Liz Cheney remained silent on the matter.
lead_paragraph: The only real way Vice President Kamala Harris has said her administration would be different from President Biden’s is that she would appoint a Republican to her cabinet.

headline: How Would You Describe Your Style?
abstract: Check out 47 outfits from students across the United States. Then tell us about your look and what it says about you.
lead_paragraph: How would you describe your style?

headline: Russia’s Warming Arctic Is a Climate Threat. War Has Shut Scientists Out of It.
abstract: Climate science has been stymied as Russia continues its war in Ukraine. The stalled work threatens to leave the West without a clear picture of how fast the Earth is heating up.
lead_paragraph: Western scientists studying the Arctic are increasingly lost in the hunt for data, the result of the cutoff in relations with Russia.

headline: A Second Trump Administration Would Be a Carnival of Corruption and Greed
abstract: If we know anything about what life would be like if Trump wins again, we know this bottomless grifting would continue.
lead_paragraph: By now, the story has made the rounds. Back in June, Oklahoma’s superintendent for public instruction, Ryan Walters, ordered every classroom in the state to teach the Bible between fifth grade and high school. Three months later, when he released the guidelines for companies bidding to supply the Bibles, they included some unusually specific terms.

headline: A Mental Tightrope: When Instrumental Musicians Have to Sing, Too
abstract: Artists who take up contemporary music sometimes have to sing and play at the same time. The results can be extraordinarily powerful.
lead_paragraph: There are many difficult moments in Peteris Vasks’s Cello Concerto No. 2, “Klatbutne” (“Presence”). The opening cadenza is exposed and virtuosic; the second movement has intricately rhythmic, Shostakovich-inspired counterpoint. But for the renowned cellist Sol Gabetta, a simple chorale in D minor at the end is the really tricky part, because in that passage she has to not just play, but also sing.

headline: The Toughest Verdict in a Subway Killing
abstract: Madness in public life leads to a clash of two liberal principles: the sovereignty of individuals and the collective right to public order.
lead_paragraph: Jordan Neely was “gentle, earnest and stable” during his 15-month stay in a Rikers Island mental-observation unit, staff members told New York magazine. He took his medications and engaged in treatment. Mr. Neely’s severe mental illness had left him jobless, homeless and increasingly unstable before a 2021 assault arrest. Now he seemed a perfect candidate for an alternative to incarceration, a residential facility, where he would continue to receive treatment.

headline: What’s Wrong With Donald Trump?
abstract: I think there’s an answer. But it’s not age — or, at least, it’s not just age.
lead_paragraph: This is a transcript of an audio essay, and we recommend listening to it in its original form so you can hear the clips. You can do so using the player above or on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: U.S. and Europe Agree to Finalize $50 Billion Ukraine Loan Backed by Russian Assets
abstract: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said an agreement was close. She also rebuked China’s lending practices and called for more debt relief.
lead_paragraph: The United States and Europe are close to finalizing a plan to provide Ukraine with a $50 billion loan backed by Russia’s frozen central bank assets by the end of the year, Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said on Tuesday.

headline: You’re Being Lied To About Voter Fraud. Here’s the Truth.
abstract: Widespread cheating at the polls is a myth. So what are election deniers really after?
lead_paragraph: The United States is closer than ever to achieving the dream it’s been chasing since 1776: an inclusive democracy that lives up to the promise of one person, one vote. But since 2020, election deniers have sought to undermine America’s collective voice with lies about the security of our elections. In the Opinion video above, Neil Makhija — who will help oversee elections in his county in the battleground state of Pennsylvania — argues that our votes have never been safer or more secure. In fact, someone is more likely to be struck by lightning than to impersonate someone else at a polling site.

headline: New York’s Old Guard Meets a Sexy Newcomer
abstract: The literary establishment welcomes Feeld, a very sex-positive dating app, at a party on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: On an October evening, in the lobby of an old building just off Park Avenue in Manhattan, a uniformed doorman led a few writers and editors into a hand-crank elevator. They had come for a party that would bring together the literary establishment and people involved in Feeld, a kink-friendly dating app. When the doorman brought the elevator to a stop on the ninth floor, the guests could hear the din of boisterous conversation emerging from an apartment in the hall.

headline: Two Theories for Why the Polls Failed in 2020, and What It Means for 2024
abstract: To make polling better, you have to figure out what went wrong in the first place.
lead_paragraph: Will the polls be wrong again this cycle?

headline: Two Weeks to Go, but Only One Way to Stay Calm
abstract: The presidential race is close. For now, we have to live with that.
lead_paragraph: “Keep calm and throw it in the average” is the best way for a voracious consumer of polling data to stay sane this election season. The ups and downs that can come from seeing your preferred candidate pingpong back and forth, from day to day, become less stressful when placed into context — even when this presidential election is remarkable for just how little bouncing there has been in the polls on average.

headline: The Many Links Between Project 2025 and Trump’s World
abstract: Former president Donald J. Trump has attempted to distance himself from Project 2025, the conservative policy initiative. But well over half of its contributors have worked for him, and many of its policies overlap with his.
lead_paragraph: Former president Donald J. Trump has attempted to distance himself from Project 2025, the conservative policy initiative. But well over half of its contributors have worked for him, and many of its policies overlap with his.

headline: At the Algonquin, a Reading Pays Homage to the Famous Round Table
abstract: At the hotel where literary celebrities gathered decades ago, tarot cards featuring Broadway stars will be unveiled.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out about a tarot reading that has to do with the famous Algonquin Round Table. We’ll also get details on a defamation lawsuit filed by the Central Park Five against Donald Trump.

headline: Hamas’s Guerrilla Tactics in North Gaza Make It Hard to Defeat
abstract: Israel has decimated Hamas’s military wing, along with much of Gaza. But the group’s small-scale, hit-and-run approach poses a threat in the enclave’s north.
lead_paragraph: The top commanders of Hamas are mostly dead. The group’s rank and file has been decimated. Many of its hide-outs and stockpiles have been captured and destroyed.

headline: India and China Reach Border Deal That Could Ease Hostilities
abstract: Four years ago, several soldiers from both sides were killed in a bloody melee. Any thaw between the countries could have global implications.
lead_paragraph: India and China have reached an agreement on patrolling their shared Himalayan border, according to the two governments, potentially easing the icy hostility between the Asian giants after a deadly skirmish between their troops four years ago.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 500
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Oct. 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: As Marijuana’s Popularity Grows, So Do Its Harms
abstract: More Americans are consuming more potent forms of the drug more often. And some of the heaviest users are experiencing unexpected health effects.
lead_paragraph: Warning: this episode contains descriptions of a mental health crisis and violence.

headline: Early Voting Grows Among Republicans, and a Lithium Trove in Arkansas
abstract: Plus, the booming Halloween economy.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: America’s Flooding Problem
abstract: We explain how the country is responding in three different ways to disasters.
lead_paragraph: America has a flooding problem. When Hurricane Milton hit Florida, the images of inundation seemed shocking — but also weirdly normal: For what felt like the umpteenth time this year, entire communities were underwater. Since the 1990s, the cost of flood damage has roughly doubled each decade, according to one estimate. The federal government issued two disaster declarations for floods in 2000. So far this year, it has issued 66.

headline: ‘Smile 2’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: Parker Finn narrates a sequence from “Smile 2,” starring Naomi Scott.
lead_paragraph: Parker Finn narrates a sequence from “Smile 2,” starring Naomi Scott.

headline: Watch Dancers Haunt Naomi Scott in ‘Smile 2’
abstract: Parker Finn, the film’s writer and director, narrates a scene in which a pop star is chased through her apartment by evil dancers.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: This Theater Was a Haven for Bold Art. Then the Archdiocese Intervened.
abstract: The Connelly Theater has suspended operations after its church landlord began more carefully scrutinizing show scripts and its general manager resigned.
lead_paragraph: The Connelly Theater in New York’s East Village has for years been a shabby but warm haven for adventurous performing arts: the play “Job,” which is now wrapping up a Broadway run; Kate Berlant’s “Kate,” a one-woman show that went on to London and California after selling out downtown; and the satire “Circle Jerk,” a Pulitzer finalist in 2021.

headline: The Era of Outsized Market Rallies Could Be Over
abstract: The S&P 500’s huge gains over the past two years won’t be duplicated some analysts say, as a series of economic challenges piles up.
lead_paragraph: The S&P 500 is on pace to rack up back-to-back annual gains of at least 20 percent, a once-in-a-generation rally that has turbocharged investors’ portfolios and bolstered Wall Street profits.

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: Peace Prize, Europa Clipper, W.N.B.A. Title
abstract: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: Christine Boisson, French Actress in ‘Emmanuelle,’ Dies at 68
abstract: She got her start in an erotic 1974 film as a teenager and went on to star in dozens of other movies.
lead_paragraph: Christine Boisson, a French actress who became famous at 17 with her performance in the erotic film “Emmanuelle” and who starred in dozens of other titles throughout her four-decade career, died on Monday in Paris. She was 68.

headline: The Princess and the Justice
abstract: Princess Gloria von Thurn und Taxis bonded with Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. over Catholicism and ending abortion. She introduced him to her sumptuous world when he visited her Bavarian palace.
lead_paragraph: The princess was late for Mass.

headline: I.M.F. Says Inflation Fight Is Largely Over but Warns of New Threats
abstract: The International Monetary Fund said protectionism and new trade wars could weigh on growth.
lead_paragraph: The global economy has managed to avoid falling into a recession even though the world’s central banks have raised interest rates to their highest levels in years to try to tame rapid inflation, the International Monetary Fund said on Tuesday.

headline: Israeli Military Strikes Near Hospital Bordering Beirut
abstract: Officials said the attack damaged Rafik Hariri University Hospital, the largest public health facility in Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: Officials said the attack damaged Rafik Hariri University Hospital, the largest public health facility in Lebanon.

headline: HSBC Overhauls Bank, Seeking to Balance China and the West
abstract: The restructuring of Europe’s largest lender comes as it looks to cut costs and navigate a diplomatic minefield across its sprawling operations.
lead_paragraph: HSBC announced its biggest restructuring in a decade on Tuesday, splitting itself into four divisions, combining some of its commercial and investment banking operations and reshuffling management.

headline: Harris Will Campaign in Texas to Call Attention to Abortion Rights
abstract: The vice president will head to Houston on Friday, hoping to use the issue to peel moderate voters away from Donald J. Trump, who is almost certain to win the state.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris will visit Texas on Friday to campaign on abortion rights, an issue that has energized Democrats and that she hopes she can use to peel moderate voters away from former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Republicans Who Led 2020 Election Denial Now Sowing Doubt in 2024 Votes
abstract: The efforts could help lay the groundwork for what could become another push to undermine the results if former President Donald J. Trump loses again.
lead_paragraph: Starting in late 2020, Representative Scott Perry was one of the ringleaders of the Republican plot to use the House’s constitutional role in certifying the electoral count to delegitimize the results in a bid to help Donald J. Trump overturn the outcome.

headline: Passed Over by Harris, Shapiro Tries to Deliver Pennsylvania for Her
abstract: Pennsylvania’s governor may not be on the verge of the vice presidency, but he says he has everything — including his “heart and soul” — riding on a Kamala Harris victory.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania bounded off a big blue bus on Saturday afternoon with the other two governors of the critical “blue wall” states — Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan and Tony Evers of Wisconsin — and headed down a steep hill to greet a gathering of Democratic canvassers in a park outside Pittsburgh.

headline: F.B.I. Investigates Apparent Leak of Israel’s Plans to Attack Iran
abstract: The documents began circulating on Friday on the Telegram app, and U.S. officials are looking for the original source of the leak.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates as Israel launches retaliatory strikes against Iran.

headline: The Hard-Shell Taco Deserves Your Respect
abstract: The version that once thrived at the midcentury fast food stands of Los Angeles is now a regional treasure.
lead_paragraph: Bar A Tí is a serious taqueria: fresh blue-corn masa, a dark and cryptic mole that ferments for a full school year, duck confit, the works. The crispy taco, however, is a crinkled half-moon of braised beef shank flickering with garlic, chiles and cilantro under a heavy fringe of neon orange cheese.

headline: I Can’t Pass Up Paneer
abstract: The firm, fresh Indian cheese is put to delicious use in this streamlined, kid-favorite mattar paneer.
lead_paragraph: There are certain foods that have the power to stop me when I roll by them at the grocery store, even if they’re not on my shopping list.

headline: Rest Days Are Good. Active Recovery Days Can Be Better.
abstract: Low-impact, easy workouts can offer relief for sore muscles.
lead_paragraph: Rest is an important piece of any exercise routine, and on some days all your body needs is a long lounge on the couch. But active recovery, which falls somewhere between a full rest day and a workout, can help your body bounce back more quickly.

headline: Exploring the Failures in the Mideast
abstract: Readers respond to a guest essay by Peter Beinart. Also: Donald Trump’s lewd comments at a rally; lessons from baseball; Queen Esther’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘No Smoking’ Signs on Planes Can Now Stay On Forever
abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration did away with a rule that had required an off switch for the sign even though smoking on U.S. flights ended years ago.
lead_paragraph: The days of airplane cabins hazy with cigarette smoke are long gone, but a reminder of that era is still visible inside commercial jets.

headline: Trump Media’s Soaring Share Price Masks Internal Strife
abstract: Employees have complained to the board about hiring and management practices at the parent company of Truth Social, which serves as the main online megaphone for former President Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: The parent company of former President Donald J. Trump’s social media platform has soared on the stock market over the past month, despite growing turmoil behind the scenes.

headline: Jamie Dimon Privately Supports Kamala Harris. He Just Won’t Say So.
abstract: JPMorgan’s chief executive has told associates of his support for the vice president, and his dislike of Donald Trump. But fearful of blowback, he won’t say it publicly.
lead_paragraph: When Jamie Dimon surprised the political and financial elite early this year by praising some of Donald J. Trump’s policies, the longtime Democrat set off speculation that he had switched his allegiance to the Republican candidate.

headline: After a Deadly Strike Near Beirut, Ringtones Sound From Under Rubble
abstract: As search teams combed the ruins of residential buildings across from Rafik Hariri University Hospital just south of Lebanon’s capital, locals listened for signs of their loved ones in the wreckage.
lead_paragraph: The air was thick with dust. The wreckage beneath, mangled and smoldering. The overnight Israeli strike had come without warning, leaving no time to evacuate.

headline: The Harris Team Tries to Tether Trump to Project 2025
abstract: A television ad conveys a key part of Kamala Harris’s closing argument: that her rival is a right-wing authoritarian who will make life less affordable and threaten access to abortion.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign is running this 30-second ad on television stations across the battleground states at a cost of more than $4.9 million, according to AdImpact.

headline: North Carolina County Overcounted Hurricane Helene Deaths by 30
abstract: Buncombe County, which includes Asheville, miscounted the deaths during a period when communications were severely hampered by the storm, the sheriff’s office said.
lead_paragraph: The western North Carolina county that includes Asheville acknowledged on Tuesday that it had overcounted by 30 the number of people who died from the effects of Hurricane Helene last month.

headline: Former Abercrombie C.E.O. Is Charged With Running Sex-Trafficking Ring
abstract: Prosecutors said Michael Jeffries and two others coerced dozens of men into sex acts during Mr. Jeffries’s tenure at the clothing company.
lead_paragraph: Michael S. Jeffries, the former longtime chief executive of Abercrombie & Fitch, was indicted on Tuesday on charges of running an international sex-trafficking scheme during several years of his tenure at the company.

headline: In the Art Biennale’s Shadow, Venice Celebrates Music, Too
abstract: It may not be as big or run as long as its visual arts sibling, but the Music Biennale includes a wealth of commissions and premieres.
lead_paragraph: The glistening domes of St. Mark’s Basilica seem to billow over Venice’s largest plaza. In the 19th century, when the church was already almost a thousand years old, a mosaic was added above the main entrance, with two angels hovering near Jesus and blowing the trumpets that signal the Last Judgment.

headline: Time and Tide Sets Sail Near Madison Square Park
abstract: Soso’s offers New York-style tavern fare, Masa Madre bakes Latin American treats and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Jamal James Kent and his executive chef, Danny Garcia, set the details of this restaurant before Mr. Kent died last spring: The menu would take a steakhouse approach for seafood done simply. Think sauces and sides, with some fish dry-aged like meat. “It’s for flavor,” Mr. Garcia said, explaining the fish. “The fat under the skin penetrates the flesh.” An example is the halibut that fills a majestic pithivier. Kent Hospitality’s Harrison Ginsberg oversees drinks and Renata Ameni handles pastry, including Baby Birdee, a retail bakery connected to the space opening later. The generous dining room, book-ended by a bar and a raw bar counter, is fitted with woodland green corduroy banquettes and a wall of concrete blocks backlit in shifting tones as if by the artist James Turrell. (Opens Wednesday)

headline: U.S. Charges Iranian Revolutionary Guards Official in Assassination Plot
abstract: The failed plot to kill Masih Alinejad, a human-rights activist, had already led to murder-for-hire charges against members of an Eastern European criminal organization with ties to Iran.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan charged a senior official in the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps of Iran and three other men connected to the country’s government with participating in a failed plot to assassinate a human-rights activist in Brooklyn in 2022, according to a new indictment made public on Tuesday.

headline: Son of Singapore’s First Prime Minister Says He Was Granted Asylum in Britain
abstract: Lee Hsien Yang accused his brother, a former prime minister, of persecuting him politically, inflaming the feud in Singapore’s first family.
lead_paragraph: Lee Hsien Yang, a member of the family that led Singapore for decades after its independence from British rule, said on Tuesday that he had been granted political asylum in Britain and accused his nation of persecuting him throughout his brother’s tenure as prime minister.

headline: Seeking to Elude Sanctions, Putin and Xi Promise ‘A Just World Order’
abstract: The Russian leader wants to cast himself as a global statesman, even as the U.S. and its Western allies try to isolate him.
lead_paragraph: Isolated by the West for his war in Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia scored a diplomatic victory on Tuesday when he welcomed the leaders of China, India and South Africa at the opening of a summit of emerging market countries bidding to rebalance a world order now dominated by the United States.

headline: Vatican and China Extend Contentious Agreement on Naming Catholic Bishops
abstract: Critics argue the pact legitimizes China’s control over church affairs, while defenders say it helps support Catholics faithful to the Vatican in the Communist country.
lead_paragraph: The Vatican and China have agreed to extend an agreement aimed at ending a decades-old power struggle over the appointment of Roman Catholic bishops in China, both parties announced Tuesday.

headline: New Stroke Recommendations Call Out Risks Unique to Women
abstract: In a first, the guidelines link poor pregnancy outcomes to stroke and call on doctors to exercise greater vigilance.
lead_paragraph: New guidelines for preventing strokes spell out for the first time the risks faced by women, noting that pre-term births and conditions like endometriosis and early menopause can raise the risk.

headline: U.S. Fears Russia Might Be Planning Post-Election Chaos
abstract: Foreign powers including Russia and Iran could move quickly right after the vote to undermine the democratic process, intelligence agencies warn.
lead_paragraph: Russia is considering actions to stoke protests and even violence over the U.S. election results, intelligence officials said on Tuesday, as foreign powers appear to be moving aggressively to undermine the democratic process during what is already expected to be a contentious vote count.

headline: Bruce Springsteen Will Perform for Harris in Battleground States
abstract: The rocker will appear at a rally on Thursday in Atlanta alongside the vice president, and again at an event next week in Philadelphia with Barack Obama.
lead_paragraph: The rocker Bruce Springsteen will perform at a rally on Thursday in Atlanta, appearing alongside Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Barack Obama, as Democrats seek to energize voters with a series of concerts before Election Day.

headline: Abortions Have Increased, Even for Women in States With Rigid Bans, Study Says
abstract: A new analysis shows how many women in states with bans are seeking procedures or pills from out-of-state providers.
lead_paragraph: In nearly every state that has banned abortion, the number of women receiving abortions increased between 2020 and the end of 2023, according to the most comprehensive account of all abortions by state since the overturning of Roe v. Wade.

headline: Teenager Is in Custody After 5 Are Found Dead in Home Shooting
abstract: The teenager, a 15-year-old boy, was scheduled to appear in court on Tuesday after two adults and three juveniles were found dead at a home near Seattle.
lead_paragraph: A 15-year-old boy was taken into custody in Washington State after five people were found dead at a home near Seattle on Monday, officials said.

headline: OpenAI Hires Former White House Official as Its Chief Economist
abstract: Aaron Chatterji was chief economist at the Commerce Department under President Biden and served on President Obama’s Council of Economic Advisers.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI, where executives and researchers dream of building artificial intelligence that could one day change the world, has hired a chief economist with ties to two Democratic presidential administrations.

headline: Israel Says 7 People Planned to Carry Out Killings in Israel on Behalf of Iran
abstract: The suspects planned to assassinate two people, a senior Israeli scientist and the mayor of a large Israeli city, authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli authorities said on Tuesday that they had arrested seven residents of a predominantly Arab neighborhood of East Jerusalem who planned to assassinate, on behalf of Iran, a senior Israeli scientist and the mayor of a large Israeli city.

headline: U.S. Agrees to Give Ukraine Millions to Build More Long-Range Drones
abstract: The move, confirmed by a Pentagon official, is in line with a U.S. policy change aimed at shoring up Ukraine’s ability to fight the war against Russia with its own weapons.
lead_paragraph: The United States has agreed to give Ukraine $800 million in military aid that will go toward manufacturing long-range drones to use against Russian troops, Ukraine’s leader said on Monday, fulfilling a longtime Ukrainian goal of getting Washington to buy weapons from manufacturers in Ukraine instead of primarily in America.

headline: Pilot Killed in New Mexico Air Show Crash Instructed ‘Top Gun’ Actors
abstract: Charles Thomas “Chuck” Coleman was a flight instructor who prepared actors for the 2022 action movie “Top Gun: Maverick,” which starred Tom Cruise and Miles Teller.
lead_paragraph: An accomplished test pilot who was a flight instructor for the cast of the 2022 movie “Top Gun: Maverick” died in a crash of a small plane during an air show in New Mexico on Sunday, the authorities said.

headline: F.D.A. Names a New Chief of Medical Devices
abstract: Patient advocates hope Dr. Michelle Tarver will lead the agency to focus more on safety and less on rapid approvals.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday announced that Dr. Michelle Tarver, an agency veteran, will be the new director of the medical device division.

headline: 6 Social Media Accounts That Changed How I Rediscover Music
abstract: Hear songs surfaced by Ryley Walker, Drumeo and other feeds from Bring Me the Horizon, Lil Tecca and more.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, to listen to music, you have to do something more than just listen.

headline: A New Effort to Counter Threats to Election Workers
abstract: American officials are highly concerned about the potential for violence against election workers on and around Nov. 5.
lead_paragraph: The sheriff of Orange County, Calif., Don Barnes, warned the public that violence and intimidation around the election would not be tolerated.

headline: Filipino American Voters Could Decide Key Races in Nevada
abstract: Democrats in particular have tried to reach voters who are now part of the largest Asian American group in Nevada.
lead_paragraph: In Las Vegas, a growing number of Filipino Americans are teaching students, caring for the sick and keeping the casinos running. After work, many trickle into the off-strip California Hotel & Casino to enjoy oxtail soup and head to Filipino-owned businesses to shop.

headline: Inside the Harris Campaign’s Push to Win Back Muslim and Arab Voters
abstract: The campaign is hoping Facebook ads, WhatsApp channels and small meetings with disillusioned voters will help turn the tide.
lead_paragraph: With two weeks to go before the election, Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign is making a final push to win back Arab and Muslim voters.

headline: Despite Global Crises, Gas Prices Slide as U.S. Election Nears
abstract: Fuel prices, which had soared after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, have dropped to their lowest level since February.
lead_paragraph: Gasoline is approaching or has fallen below $3 a gallon in most states, returning to a national average not seen since February in one of the clearest examples of prices declining after a period of rapid inflation.

headline: Owner of Frank Lloyd Wright Skyscraper Sues Preservation Group
abstract: The owner of Price Tower says the Frank Lloyd Wright Building Conservancy has interfered with the proposed sale of the building by claiming a preservation easement on the property.
lead_paragraph: The owner of a Frank Lloyd Wright-designed skyscraper in Oklahoma is suing a nonprofit that works to protect the architect’s legacy, arguing that the preservation group’s efforts to enforce an easement on the property have affected its ability to sell the building.

headline: Zohran Mamdani, a Democratic Socialist, Will Run Against Mayor Adams
abstract: Zohran Mamdani, a state lawmaker from Queens, has entered the Democratic primary for mayor of New York City, joining a crowded field hoping to unseat Eric Adams.
lead_paragraph: Zohran Mamdani, a socialist New York State Assembly member from Queens, will announce on Wednesday that he is entering the race to unseat Mayor Eric Adams, who is facing growing doubts over his political future.

headline: The A.I. Power Grab
abstract: Big tech companies say A.I. can help solve climate change, even as it’s driving up their emissions and raising doubts about their climate goals.
lead_paragraph: Cleaning up the technology industry was supposed to be easy.

headline: They Sued Juul and Now It’s Payday
abstract: Unexpected payments from a class-action lawsuit have some TikTok users feeling flush.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2021, Drewe Raimi, then a college senior, filed a claim in a class-action lawsuit against Juul, the manufacturer of the popular e-cigarettes. News of the suit had been circulating on social media, and many of Ms. Raimi’s friends also filed claims.

headline: Trump to Go on Joe Rogan’s Podcast, a Play to Reach Less Likely Voters
abstract: Two campaign officials said former President Donald J. Trump will record an interview Friday with the podcast that is popular with young men, a demographic that likes him but might not vote.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump will record an interview on Friday with Joe Rogan, an enormously popular podcast host, according to two campaign officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,222
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Oct. 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: How a Knack for Provocation Fueled Mark Robinson’s Rise
abstract: Recklessness has characterized Mr. Robinson’s online persona, his personal life and his rocky campaign for governor in North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of 2007, Mark Robinson, now North Carolina’s Republican nominee for governor, made a decision that would change his life forever: He created a Facebook account.

headline: Stan Asofsky, Vociferous Courtside Superfan of the Knicks, Dies at 87
abstract: For decades, beginning in 1959, he was a regular presence at Madison Square Garden (in two locations), befriending players and heckling opposing players and refs.
lead_paragraph: Stan Asofsky was more than a rabid New York Knicks fan. He was a ticket holder with access, reflecting a time when professional sports venues were far less fortified and class-segregated. When one didn’t have to be Spike Lee, or Taylor Swift, to walk in a celebrity athlete’s world.

headline: Yehuda Bauer, 98, Scholar Who Saw Jewish Resistance in Holocaust, Dies
abstract: A leading historian of antisemitism, he countered the prevailing narrative of Jewish victimhood and later pushed back against efforts to diminish the Holocaust’s significance.
lead_paragraph: Yehuda Bauer, whose family narrowly escaped the Nazis in their flight to Mandatory Palestine from Czechoslovakia in 1939, and who later drew on that experience in becoming a leading scholar of the Holocaust and antisemitism, died on Friday at his home in Jerusalem. He was 98.

headline: Lebanese Exuberance Meets Brooklyn Cool at Sawa
abstract: A new restaurant in Park Slope serves elegant Levantine classics with a dash of hipster style and some New York pluck.
lead_paragraph: When Samaya Boueri Ziade moved to Park Slope, Brooklyn, in 2009, she found no restaurants with exactly the sort of Lebanese food she remembered from her hometown, Tabarja, a coastal village north of Beirut. So she thought about opening one herself.

headline: Israeli Military Says It Killed Top Hezbollah Leader
abstract: Hashem Safieddine, a cousin of Hassan Nasrallah, joined Hezbollah soon after the group was formed and rose quickly in its ranks.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said on Tuesday that it had weeks ago killed Hashem Safieddine, the presumed successor to Hezbollah’s recently assassinated leader, in an airstrike near Beirut, Lebanon.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: Casting Doubts on the U.S. Election
abstract: Plus, saving Japan’s most popular rice.
lead_paragraph: As Donald Trump makes widespread claims that the Nov. 5 election will be rigged, a handful of his allies are already questioning this year’s voting. Their efforts could help lay the groundwork to once again undermine the results, should Trump lose.

headline: An Australian Woman Trying to Rescue Her Phone Gets Stuck Between Boulders
abstract: And she was upside down.
lead_paragraph: Many people say they can’t live without their phones. But one Australian woman’s attempt to save hers left her fighting to get back to her life.

headline: E. Coli Outbreak Linked to McDonald’s Quarter Pounders
abstract: Nearly 50 people have become ill and one person has died, amid infections that may have been caused by slivered onions, the C.D.C. reported.
lead_paragraph: One person has died and 49 people have become ill following an E. coli outbreak linked to McDonald’s Quarter Pounder hamburgers, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Tuesday.

headline: More Republicans Appear to Be Voting Early, Despite Trump’s Mixed Messages
abstract: In 2020, Donald Trump convinced his supporters that anything but a vote cast in person on Election Day could not be trusted — and lost. In response, Republicans shifted their stance.
lead_paragraph: Republicans have spent months and millions of dollars on an effort to push former President Donald J. Trump’s most loyal supporters to change their minds about voting early.

headline: Judge Orders Giuliani to Forfeit Millions in Assets to Election Workers He Defamed
abstract: The onetime personal attorney to former President Donald J. Trump has seven days to turn over his Manhattan apartment, a vintage Mercedes-Benz and other possessions.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday ordered Rudolph W. Giuliani to turn over most of his possessions and available cash to a receivership controlled by the two Georgia election workers he defamed after the last presidential election.

headline: Bill Gates Privately Says He Has Backed Harris With $50 Million Donation
abstract: Mr. Gates said in a statement to The Times that “this election is different,” reflecting a significant change in his political strategy.
lead_paragraph: After decades of sitting on the sidelines of politics, Bill Gates, one of the richest people in the world, has said privately that he recently donated about $50 million to a nonprofit organization that is supporting Vice President Kamala Harris’s presidential run, according to three people briefed on the matter.

headline: Samuel L. Jackson, Megan Thee Stallion and Sarah Jessica Parker Pick Up Honors
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art hosted its film benefit, while God’s Love We Deliver drew comedians, fashion executives and restaurateurs to its annual gala.
lead_paragraph: Fall gala season is in full swing with its annual marathon of lavish events drawing influential and powerful figures. Across New York, actors, musicians, politicians, philanthropists and executives, dressed in their finest, schmooze over multicourse dinners and exclusive performances as major institutions appeal to some of the city’s wealthiest residents for financial support and cultural cachet.

headline: Britain and Germany Agree on New Defense Pact as Russia Threat Rises
abstract: The two governments said they will coordinate more on defense, with British and German troops conducting joint military exercises on NATO’s eastern border.
lead_paragraph: Britain and Germany have agreed to strengthen military cooperation and develop sophisticated weapons in a move that reflects growing concern in Europe over global security threats, particularly from Russia.

headline: Kurt Olsen Helped Trump Fight His 2020 Defeat. Trump Is Talking to Him Again.
abstract: Mr. Olsen, a lawyer, has spoken to the former president multiple times in recent weeks. He’s insisted it’s important to make legal demands concerning voting-machine data before Election Day.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer who tried to help Donald J. Trump overturn his 2020 presidential election loss has been in direct contact with Mr. Trump once again as his allies start to lay the groundwork for challenging this year’s election results in key battleground states, according to two people with knowledge of their discussions.

headline: More Republicans Appear to be Voting Early
abstract: Also, Israel said it killed a top Hezbollah leader. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: With two weeks until Election Day, well over 17 million people — roughly a tenth of all registered voters — have already cast their ballots. Many states have set daily records for early voting, offering the clearest sign yet that voting habits were forever changed by the pandemic.

headline: In Michigan, a Queer Retreat With Dancing in the Woods
abstract: The editor Ryan Fitzgibbon invited collaborators to toast “A Great Gay Book,” a new collection of pieces from his influential, now-defunct magazine, Hello Mr.
lead_paragraph: The independent gay magazine Hello Mr. released just ten issues, between 2013 and 2018. But neat stacks of the publication still feature prominently on plenty of queer people’s coffee tables.
