lead_paragraph: After Election Day, those who accurately called the outcome of the presidential race will most likely be hailed as oracles. With the race essentially a coin flip, the polls are less than useful in determining who the winner might be. Once every vote has been counted, those same polls will be looked at in a new light.

headline: A Pro-Harris Ad Aims to Woo Trump-Weary Republicans
abstract: A new commercial from the biggest super PAC in American politics makes a pitch for Republicans in Arizona and North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Future Forward, a pro-Harris super PAC that has raised $700 million, started airing this 30-second commercial, “For Regular People,” on Tuesday in Arizona and North Carolina, at a cost of about $1.2 million, according to AdImpact.

headline: Harris Sharpens her Message on Trump
abstract: Also, the U.S. said North Korea sent troops to aid Russia. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris delivered a short and searing statement today from the vice president’s official residence at the Naval Observatory, rarely a site for political events. She called Donald Trump “unhinged and unstable,” and said that reports that he made admiring remarks about Hitler offered voters “a window into who Donald Trump really is.”

headline: Harris Will Offer Closing Argument at Ellipse in Washington
abstract: The vice president will give a speech on Tuesday at the Ellipse, the park near the White House where Donald Trump encouraged supporters to march on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris plans to deliver a speech on Tuesday at the Ellipse, the park just south of the White House where former President Donald J. Trump encouraged his supporters to march on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to her campaign.

headline: Attention, Passengers: Someone Is Skipping the Line at Your Gate
abstract: American Airlines is testing a technology platform that will produce a sound when a passenger attempts to board a flight ahead of the assigned group.
lead_paragraph: Every airline traveler has been there. The boarding process begins, and the gate is swarmed with passengers before their zones have been called.

headline: Why Trump’s Closing Argument Is Full of ‘Locker Room Talk’
abstract: By all appearances, he’s embracing vulgarity to exploit the voter gender gap.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of the 2016 presidential campaign, the world learned about the “Access Hollywood” tape in which Donald Trump bragged about groping women.

headline: Will This New U.S. Project Make the World’s Children Smarter?
abstract: Biden takes aim at a neurotoxin all around us that impedes brain development.
lead_paragraph: First, a quiz:

headline: Israel Bombs Lebanese City as Blinken Hints at New Ideas for Gaza Cease-Fire
abstract: The Israeli military struck targets in the port city of Tyre on Wednesday, the latest phase of a bombardment campaign against the militant group Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: Israel attacked the ancient port city of Tyre in Lebanon on Wednesday after issuing its broadest evacuation order there so far, pressing on with its bombing campaign against Hezbollah even as Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken toured the region in pursuit of a diplomatic solution to the escalating conflict.

headline: Fernandomania Wasn’t a Fairy Tale. It Was Better Than That.
abstract: Fernando Valenzuela, who died on Tuesday at age 63, was a teenage phenomenon from Mexico who remade the Dodgers’ fan base and put his country on the baseball map.
lead_paragraph: The story seems like something from a fairy tale. A bashful, portly teenager from a tiny speck of a town in Mexico, the youngest of 12 children who grew up in a home with no running water, debuts with the Los Angeles Dodgers at 19.

headline: How the 2024 Election Became a Battle Fought by Podcast
abstract: Harris and Trump turn to digital venues with niche audiences to sway tiny slivers of the electorate.
lead_paragraph: Good evening! Tonight, my colleague Michael Grynbaum explains why the presidential candidates are spending so much time on podcasts. Plus, a story about a historian who once thought the label “fascist” shouldn’t be used to refer to Donald Trump. He has since changed his mind. — Jess Bidgood

headline: Five Dead After ‘Terrorist Attack’ on Turkish Aerospace Company
abstract: Attackers armed with explosives and rifles assaulted the headquarters of a Turkish state-run aerospace company on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Attackers armed with explosives and rifles assaulted the headquarters of a Turkish state-run aerospace company on Wednesday.

headline: L.A. Times Editorial Chief Quits After Owner Blocks Harris Endorsement
abstract: Mariel Garza said the editorial board was prepared to endorse Kamala Harris, but the paper’s owner, Patrick Soon-Shiong, decided not to make an endorsement in the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: The head of The Los Angeles Times’s editorial board resigned on Wednesday after the paper’s owner quashed a presidential endorsement for Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: Is There a Feud Between Martha Stewart and Ina Garten?
abstract: The lifestyle luminaries, who have been on the publicity circuit, were once close, but in a recent interview, Ms. Stewart doubled down on her contention that Ms. Garten abandoned her during a difficult period.
lead_paragraph: During an appearance this weekend on Andy Cohen’s messy and drama-prone Bravo talk show, “Watch What Happens Live,” Martha Stewart stoked the fires of a feud between herself and her fellow culinary mogul, Ina Garten.

headline: Review: Delia Ephron’s ‘Left on Tenth’ Treads Lightly
abstract: Julianna Margulies and Peter Gallagher star in this quasi romantic comedy adapted from Ephron’s memoir, which went deeper into her illness and grief.
lead_paragraph: The website for “Left on Tenth,” Delia Ephron’s new Broadway play, is approximately the last place I would have expected to encounter a content advisory, but there one is. From a marketing standpoint, it’s a sensible move — a tip-off, for anyone expecting pure romantic comedy, that the show also deals with life-threatening illness.

headline: Pennsylvania Supreme Court Allows Provisional Votes After Mail Ballot Rejections
abstract: The decision is likely to affect thousands of mail-in ballots among the millions that will be cast in Pennsylvania, a pivotal 2024 swing state.
lead_paragraph: The Pennsylvania Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that voters who submit mail-in ballots that are rejected for not following procedural directions can still cast provisional ballots.

headline: Therapist Is Charged With Distributing Child Sex Abuse Imagery
abstract: Renee Hoberman, a licensed social worker on Long Island, used messaging platforms to share graphic videos of infants being abused, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A child therapist on Long Island has been charged with distributing sexual abuse imagery of children as young as infants on social media, according to a federal complaint.

headline: Corrections: Oct. 24, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Oct. 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about defining the Midwest misstated where the Black Midwest Initiative began. It was at the University of Minnesota, not the University of Illinois Chicago.

headline: Lana Del Rey Married a Normie. Other Celebrities Have Too.
abstract: The pop singer and songwriter married her longtime boyfriend, Jeremy Dufrene, a swamp tour guide. Other celebrities have also wed someone who’s not rich or famous.
lead_paragraph: The pop superstar Lana Del Rey has made it official with her longtime boyfriend, Jeremy Dufrene, an alligator swamp tour guide in Louisiana.

headline: ‘The Best Is Yet to Come’
abstract: You may not know which way you’re going when you solve Ella Dershowitz’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Boeing Workers Resoundingly Reject New Contract and Extend Strike
abstract: The vote, hours after Boeing reported a $6.1 billion loss, will extend a nearly six-week-long strike at factories where the company makes its best-selling commercial plane.
lead_paragraph: Boeing’s largest union rejected a tentative labor contract on Wednesday by a wide margin, extending a damaging strike and adding to the mounting financial problems facing the company, which hours earlier had reported a $6.1 billion loss.

headline: Georgia Secretary of State Fends Off Cyberattack Targeting Absentee Ballot Website
abstract: The attack may have come from a foreign country, said a Georgia official.
lead_paragraph: Georgia’s secretary of state warded off a cybersecurity threat this month against what was most likely an attack by a foreign country targeting its website that voters can use to request absentee ballots.

headline: Man Is Arrested After Shootings at Democratic Campaign Office in Arizona
abstract: The authorities said they believed the suspect was “preparing to commit an act of mass casualty.”
lead_paragraph: An Arizona man has been arrested on terrorism charges in connection with three shootings at a Democratic Party campaign office in suburban Phoenix that wounded no one but rattled campaign workers in a bitter election season.

headline: Can Donald Trump or Kamala Harris Bring Back Manufacturing Jobs?
abstract: Both candidates tout plans that promise to help the country make things again. Canton, Ohio, is an example of the steep challenge.
lead_paragraph: Both candidates tout plans that promise to help the country make things again. Canton, Ohio, is an example of the steep challenge.

headline: A Wisconsin Mayor, a Former Republican, Endorses Harris
abstract: Shawn Reilly, the mayor of Waukesha, Wis., said he had never thrown his support behind a Democrat before.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Shawn Reilly of Waukesha, Wis., an independent who was a Republican for most of his life, said in an interview on Wednesday that he was endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris for president.

headline: Why It’s Getting Harder to Fly to China
abstract: European carriers are enduring higher costs because they have to avoid Russian airspace, while a sluggish economy and geopolitical tensions are hurting business travel to China.
lead_paragraph: For American and European travelers, the options of flights in and out of China are narrowing by the day.

headline: Quote of the Day: Building a Steel Curtain in Ireland
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, October 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I would sell a kidney for it.”

headline: 5 Key Questions Hanging Over the Lucy Letby ‘Killer Nurse’ Case
abstract: Ms. Letby, a neonatal nurse in England found guilty of murdering seven babies, has lost a fresh appeal bid. A growing number of experts have raised concerns about the evidence.
lead_paragraph: When Lucy Letby, a former nurse in a neonatal unit at a hospital in northern England, was found guilty last year of murdering seven babies and attempting to murder six others, Britain reacted with horror. She was convicted of attempting to murder another baby in a retrial of one charge earlier this year.

headline: She Embodied Japan’s #MeToo. With a Searing Film, She’s Ready to Move On.
abstract: “Black Box Diaries,” a documentary about Shiori Ito’s fight against Japan’s patriarchal justice system, opens on Friday in the United States.
lead_paragraph: If there’s one question Shiori Ito hates, it’s “What’s next for you?”

headline: Harris Calls Trump a Fascist: 6 Takeaways From Her CNN Town Hall
abstract: Entering new rhetorical territory, the vice president turned even unrelated questions into attacks on Donald Trump as she offered long, winding answers to questions from voters.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris called Donald J. Trump a fascist on Wednesday evening, elevating what until recently had been an argument made only in the lower ranks of a Democratic Party that has spent years attacking him as anti-democratic, unfit to serve and a criminal.

headline: Trump Calls Out Biden Remark on ‘Lock Him Up’
abstract: While President Biden quickly said he was referring to his predecessor’s politics and not to jail time, Donald Trump said it was proof of his unfounded claim the president is behind his criminal cases.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump on Wednesday seized on President Biden’s remark that he wanted to see his predecessor behind bars, citing the comment as evidence of Mr. Trump’s unsubstantiated claim that Mr. Biden had orchestrated the four criminal cases against him.

headline: Thursday Briefing: How Europe Sees the U.S. Election
abstract: Plus, the dark side of A.I. companionship apps.
lead_paragraph: Few American voters cite foreign policy as the deciding factor in how they cast their ballot. Yet the U.S. president has more international sway than virtually any other individual — especially at a time of immense geopolitical volatility.

headline: Is Afghanistan’s Most-Wanted Militant Now Its Best Hope for Change?
abstract: Sirajuddin Haqqani has tried to remake himself from blood-soaked jihadist to pragmatic Taliban statesman. Western diplomats are shocked — and enticed.
lead_paragraph: For the better part of two decades, one name above all others inspired fear among ordinary Afghans: Sirajuddin Haqqani.

headline: World Opens to the Taliban Despite Their Shredding of Women’s Rights
abstract: Taliban officials have scored a series of diplomatic victories this year that have started a subtle shift toward normalizing their government.
lead_paragraph: For most of the three years since the Taliban returned to power in Afghanistan, their erasure of women’s rights appeared to be setting them on course for near-total isolation in the world.

headline: What We Learned Talking to the Taliban’s Most Fearsome Leader
abstract: Sirajuddin Haqqani, who has a $10 million American bounty on his head, is now positioning himself as a figure of relative moderation.
lead_paragraph: For three years, there was one powerful, elusive figure I wanted to speak with in Afghanistan: Sirajuddin Haqqani.

headline: Word of the Day: detract
abstract: This word has appeared in 58 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word detract has appeared in 58 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 4 in “Too Scared to Watch Horror Movies? These 5 Tips May Help” by Maya Salam:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Democrats’ Best Shot at Flipping a House Seat Is in Upstate New York
abstract: After redistricting, Representative Brandon Williams of New York is the only House Republican whose race is considered “lean Democrat.”
lead_paragraph: When New York Democrats recently emerged from the scrum of redistricting with a map that largely did not tilt in their favor, there was one spot of consolation: a Republican-held district in Central New York that was redrawn broadly to the Democrats’ benefit.

headline: Her Job Was Talking on the Radio. Then Suddenly, Words Wouldn’t Come.
abstract: One day last winter, Alison Stewart, the host of “All of It” on WNYC, was alarmed to find herself speaking gibberish.
lead_paragraph: Alison Stewart’s health crisis began on Feb. 22, a day jump-started by a 6 a.m. workout with her personal trainer. She was pushing herself to get back in shape after having donated a kidney to her sister six months earlier. The workout was routine, though she barely spoke, which was unlike her.

headline: From Swing States to Drive-Throughs: On the Campaign Trail with Trump
abstract: Since 2023, the political correspondent Michael Gold has followed the former president’s campaign, which has proved to be anything but predictable.
lead_paragraph: Election Day is 12 days away. Every day of the countdown, Times Insider will share an article about how our election coverage works. Today, a reporter covering the Trump campaign shares the unique challenges of covering the former president.

headline: What Happened When a Barber Told Trump About His $15,000 Electric Bill
abstract: During the campaign stop, a barber made a complaint about his utility bill that was soon distorted online.
lead_paragraph: In the middle of a Donald J. Trump photo-op at a barbershop in the Bronx last week, a half-truth emerged from the scrum and gathered steam in the ensuing days of relentless campaign coverage.

headline: Beverage Order
abstract: Are there more and more coffee places in your area? Are the drink combinations growing? And, most important, what do you order?
lead_paragraph: From the giant Starbucks to upstarts like Scooter’s Coffee in Nebraska, the battle is joined for who can come up with the craziest, calorie-laden, not-really-coffee drink, writes The Times.

headline: The Liberty (and Their Fans) Celebrate With a New York City Parade
abstract: The W.N.B.A.’s newest champions were honored along the Canyon of Heroes on Broadway, the third time a women’s sports team has been granted that privilege.
lead_paragraph: New York City turned out on Thursday to celebrate the W.N.B.A.’s newest champions, the Liberty, with a traditional ticker-tape parade in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Late Night Condemns Trump for Stanning Hitler
abstract: On Wednesday, Seth Meyers said he was “starting to think Trump doesn’t watch the ends of documentaries.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Lucy Letby, Former U.K. Nurse, Loses Bid to Appeal Attempted Murder Conviction
abstract: Ms. Letby is serving 15 life sentences after the deaths and collapses of babies in the neonatal unit where she worked.
lead_paragraph: Lucy Letby, a former neonatal nurse who was convicted of the murder of seven babies and the attempted murder of seven others, was refused permission to appeal one of her convictions on Thursday.

headline: Cambodia Journalist Who Exposed Scams Is Released on Bail
abstract: Mech Dara spent three weeks in detention after he was charged for posts he made online. He still faces a charge of “incitement to provoke social chaos.”
lead_paragraph: A prominent Cambodian journalist known for his work exposing compounds in which people are forced to scam others online was released on bail on Thursday. He had been detained three weeks in a case that has been denounced by the United States and rights groups as an attack on press freedom.

headline: Pets Are Part of the Family, and Part of New York City’s Fabric
abstract: The New-York Historical Society explores the relationships between New Yorkers and their pets.
lead_paragraph: Animal companions have always been deeply ingrained in New York City’s culture and history, but they were not always treated as family members the way pets are today.

headline: A Game Designer Who Wants to See Ideas He’ll Hate
abstract: The founder of Giant Sparrow says creativity requires pushing boundaries. Its next game will explore “the strangeness of organic life.”
lead_paragraph: Ian Dallas, the founder and creative director of the video game studio Giant Sparrow, happened to be talking about food, but his gastronomical tastes are similar to his design philosophy. “I’m always interested,” he said, “in what’s the strangest, new intense experience that I can have.”

headline: Richard McGuire Knows Fans Want a Drawing When He Signs Their Books
abstract: Ten years ago he published the graphic novel “Here,” an instant classic depicting one room in one house over generations. Now Tom Hanks is starring in the movie.
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: Buy? Share? Borrow? Art Institutions Rethink Their Acquisition Strategies
abstract: A combination of money and the need to attract new audiences inspires new ways of collecting art.
lead_paragraph: Museums are always looking to acquire new works of art. A larger collection helps an institution draw audiences and build prestige and offers an opportunity to exchange art with other museums to keep variety in its galleries.

headline: Changing the DNA of Living Things to Fight Climate Change
abstract: By tweaking the DNA of bacteria, scientists aim to cut the use of chemical fertilizers that are worsening global warming. Some worry about unintended consequences.
lead_paragraph: With the push of a red button, a milky-colored liquid sprayed onto a load of corn seed at a warehouse in central Missouri. It was a hint of a revolution underway in American agriculture, driven by a desire to combat climate change while still feeding and fueling the world.

headline: Documenting the Stories of Migrants Detained at the Border
abstract: While working as a janitor at a U.S. customs station in Arizona, the artist Tom Kiefer photographed confiscated items, from rosary beads to wallets to love letters.
lead_paragraph: In May 2003, the photographer Tom Kiefer was living in Ajo, Ariz., an artist’s enclave not far from the U.S.-Mexico border, looking for a job. He had come to Ajo in 2001 from Los Angeles, where he worked for many years in advertising as a graphic designer and photographer and, after that, as the owner of an antiques store.

headline: By Ferry or Floatplane, 4 Enchanting Coastal Getaways From Vancouver
abstract: The largest city in British Columbia makes a perfect gateway to explore the rich marine wildlife and beauty of the region.
lead_paragraph: Canada’s westernmost province, British Columbia, is studded with 17,000 miles of coastline and 40,000 islands dispersed across its waters, many of them enchanting destinations on their own. Vancouver, the largest city of the province, serves as a gateway to the region, which is home to a host of marine life like Steller sea lions, sea otters and Pacific octopuses.

headline: Skeletons and Madonnas Lead Mexico’s Graphic Arts Revolution
abstract: The central role of printmaking in five centuries of Mexican art on view at the Met shows the weight of many minds.
lead_paragraph: The first thing you learn from “Mexican Prints at the Vanguard” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is that printmaking has been central to Mexico’s art and media since Spanish colonists arrived with devotional woodcuts in the 1500s. Three centuries later, letterpress madonnas and skeletons traveled to every corner of the vast, multicultural new nation on broadsheets and newspapers; during the Mexican Revolution (1910-1920), it was eye-grabbing posters of menacing plutocrats that incited the peasants.

headline: Steamy New Romance Books to Heat Up Your Fall
abstract: Romantasies, paranormals and fantasy romances, just in time for Halloween.
lead_paragraph: Visitors often wear out their welcome in tourist spots. But in Boneyard Key, the small Florida town in Jen DeLuca’s HAUNTED EVER AFTER (Berkley, 352 pp., paperback, $19), it’s the locals who are lingering. Turns out the “most haunted town” slogan is more than just a marketing shtick, and the place is unusually full of ghosts.

headline: Two Artists Capture Florida at the Met
abstract: This fall, the Met pairs images of Florida by Walker Evans and Anastasia Samoylova, the first living female photographer with a major show there in some three decades.
lead_paragraph: Last month, even with her long lens, Anastasia Samoylova didn’t particularly stand out among the several dozen people who had joined a boat tour of New York, many of whom also had cameras of all shapes and sizes trained on the coastal skyline.

headline: The Morgan Honors Its ‘Personal Librarian’
abstract: The subject of a bestseller who led a remarkable life as a scholar and cultural force while hiding her Black identity is the focus of an exhibition at the institution she headed.
lead_paragraph: Belle da Costa Greene wasn’t just a woman of the world but of several worlds.

headline: Inside the Effort to Change How Seeds Grow
abstract: Much of the food we eat is grown with synthetic fertilizer, which is a huge source of climate change. But now, a seed with DNA-modified bacteria is reducing the amount of synthetic fertilizer that farmers have to apply to their fields. Eric Lipton, an investigative reporter for The New York Times, explains.
lead_paragraph: Much of the food we eat is grown with synthetic fertilizer, which is a huge source of climate change. But now, a seed with DNA-modified bacteria is reducing the amount of synthetic fertilizer that farmers have to apply to their fields. Eric Lipton, an investigative reporter for The New York Times, explains.

headline: How Intel Got Left Behind in the A.I. Chip Boom
abstract: Intel was for decades Silicon Valley’s dominant chip company. But missed opportunities and poor execution left it on the sidelines in tech’s latest gold rush.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, there was no inkling of the artificial intelligence boom that would come years later. But directors at Intel, whose chips served as electronic brains in most computers, faced a decision that might have altered how that transformative technology evolved.

headline: The Low-Smell, Low-Stress Fish Recipe of Your Dreams
abstract: Concerned about odors and splatters? This simple dinner, infused with a silky scallion oil, is ready to allay any worries.
lead_paragraph: If you live in a small space, the lure of crispy fish skin — the bacon of the sea — can lead to fishy pillow cases until laundry day. (Totally worth it.)

headline: 5 Books to Read About Policing Before You Vote
abstract: Memoirists and scholars explore the issue at every level, from the origins of the war on crime to what comes after “broken windows.”
lead_paragraph: When did we stop talking about the cops? For several years, the problem of racialized policing was at the center of American life. Incidents of police brutality were covered in major newspapers. Celebrities, brands and sports franchises mourned its victims. Advocates demanded indictments for killer cops. Black Lives Matter protests erupted in cities across the country. Many Americans memorized a list of names — a litany of pointlessly snuffed-out lives — that we could recite by heart, as if naming our own children.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Eating Salad Greens by the Handful
abstract: Can you just reach into the box and go for it?
lead_paragraph: Arin writes: I recently saw my husband open a box of salad greens, grab a handful and stuff them in his mouth. He doesn’t like salads, and he says that this is the best way for him to reap the benefits of eating greens. I think this is unhinged. Should he be allowed to continue to eat lettuce by the handful?

headline: ‘Black Box Diaries’ Review: A Public Face for #MeToo in Japan
abstract: In a new documentary, Shiori Ito recounts her yearslong crusade for justice in Japan after accusing a powerful journalist of rape.
lead_paragraph: Not everyone gets to be the heroine of her own story, much less a champion for others. On May 29, 2017, a 28-year-old Japanese journalist, Shiori Ito, did just that when she announced at a news conference that she had been raped in a Tokyo hotel two years earlier by a powerfully connected journalist, Noriyuki Yamaguchi. (He has denied the allegation.) Ito had decided to speak her truth despite intense pressure to remain silent. “People need to know about the horrors of rape,” she told a room of reporters, “and how deeply it affects one’s life.”

headline: ‘Memoir of a Snail’ Review: Escaping the Spiral
abstract: An animated tragicomedy for adults tells the story of a woman breaking out of her shell.
lead_paragraph: First things first: “Memoir of a Snail” is not, in fact, the memoir of a snail. It is the memoir of an Australian woman named Grace Pudel (pronounced “Puddle”), who loves snails very much. Grace is voiced by Sarah Snook and rendered in slightly lumpy clay by Adam Elliot, who wrote, directed and produced this stop-motion animation film. It is a weirdly affecting tragicomedy, full of Dickensian turns and eccentric figures. (It is also, lest you be confused by the whimsy, definitely not for children.)

headline: Do People in ‘Blue Zones’ Actually Live Longer?
abstract: The premise is catchy, but some think it’s based on faulty data.
lead_paragraph: The concept is simple and alluring: There are special regions around the world — called blue zones — where people regularly remain vibrant and active into their 90s and 100s, thanks to a simple set of behaviors that anyone can follow.

headline: ‘Venom: The Last Dance’ Review: A Long and Winding Tongue
abstract: Playing both Eddie Brock and the alien parasite who possesses him, Tom Hardy gives another roiling one-man-band of a performance in this third installment of the franchise.
lead_paragraph: With the 2018 film “Venom,” Tom Hardy locked himself into a three-picture deal, giving his time, talents and torso to this saga about a man named Eddie Brock possessed by a fanged, body-snatching alien parasite named Venom who pops in and out of his skin like a hyper-violent prairie dog. The overly plotted “Venom: The Last Dance,” written and directed by Kelly Marcel, concludes the trilogy by hammering home all that Eddie has sacrificed to merge with this impulsive, smack-talking goo blob. In the first movie, Eddie was an ambitious San Francisco investigative journalist with a fiancée played by Michelle Williams; here, he’s a filthy drifter on a Mexican bender who’s lost his career, his woman and his reputation. Forced to go on the lam to flee a murder accusation, Eddie makes a running joke out of the fact that he can’t even hang on to a pair of shoes.

headline: ‘The Remarkable Life of Ibelin’ Review: More Real Than Reality
abstract: An unconventional documentary tells the story of a Norwegian gamer — and of how we live life on the internet.
lead_paragraph: Almost from the start, the internet scrambled our sense of reality. You could never really know if whoever you were talking to was the person they said they were. Now it’s hard to know if they’re even a person.

headline: ‘Your Monster’ Review: Beast Intentions
abstract: An aspiring Broadway musical star (Melissa Barrera) taps into her inner anger with some help from the creature who lives in her closet.
lead_paragraph: Caroline Lindy’s debut feature, “Your Monster,” claims to present a “true-ish story.” Presumably, the “true” aspect refers not to the monster, but to the cascading cruelty of the plot’s inciting breakup: While Laura (Melissa Barrera), an aspiring Broadway star, is recovering from cancer surgery, her boyfriend, Jacob (Edmund Donovan), a theater director, abandons her, then freezes her out of the lead in his new show, which she helped develop.

headline: Abortion Pills Are Safe. Post-Roe America Isn’t.
abstract: In many states, hospitals are delaying or denying standard reproductive care.
lead_paragraph: Once, when I was the obstetrician-gynecologist assigned to cover Christmas at my hospital, I was called to the emergency department for a patient undergoing a first-trimester pregnancy loss. Early pregnancy losses are common and generally uncomplicated. But this patient showed signs of possible infection.

headline: It’s the Inflation, Stupid: Why the Working Class Wants Trump Back
abstract: Inflation is driving working-class voters of all ethnicities to Trump.
lead_paragraph: Anti-Trumpers like me see the presidential election as a reckoning for American democracy. For many Donald Trump supporters, it is a simple matter of dollars and cents.

headline: On the Israel-Lebanon Border, a Town With a Past Worries for Its Future
abstract: Abandoned and off limits to civilians, Metula, a symbol of early pioneering Zionism, is left half-ruined by Hezbollah’s rockets and missiles.
lead_paragraph: Once a picturesque Israeli mountain resort with panoramic views into Lebanon, Metula is now off limits to civilians. Under fire for months from Hezbollah’s rockets and missiles, every other house has by now been damaged or lies in ruins. Over the past year of fighting, it has been one of the hardest-hit places in Israel.

headline: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
abstract: This week’s properties are a five-bedroom in Fairfield, Conn., and a four-bedroom in Pelham Manor, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A five-bedroom, four-full-and-three-half-bath, 5,730-square-foot residence is the marriage of two homes from the 18th and 19th centuries, with nine fireplaces, wide floorboards, blown-glass window panes, beamed ceilings, a large dining room, a kitchen with a spacious butler’s pantry, plenty of living and entertaining spaces, an office, a game room, a den, a library, a family room, a formal living room, a detached three-car garage and a post-and-beam barn, on 2.76 acres. Mary Phelps, 203-546-0315, William Pitt Sotheby’s International Realty; williampitt.com

headline: Where Are the Rats in New York City?
abstract: Among the five boroughs, Brooklyn has had the most complaints so far this year. But overall, the numbers appear to be trending down.
lead_paragraph: Rats, rats, rats — familiar and often feared creatures in many cities. New Yorkers may see them in the subway enjoying a slice of pizza, scurrying among trash bins or sometimes even inside their homes. After rat sightings by city inspectors doubled in 2022, Mayor Eric Adams appointed a director of rodent mitigation, aka a “rat czar,” to reduce their ranks — with some success. But the pests remain part of New York’s identity.

headline: It’s His First Vote for President. He’s Torn. And It’s Crunch Time.
abstract: Miguel Gomez, 21, leans Trump. His parents very much don’t. Their home is a miniature battleground, reflecting the fierce divides among Latino voters in Arizona.
lead_paragraph: Miguel Gomez, 21, could never fathom supporting a Republican, until this election. He grew up in a solidly Democratic middle-class home in Phoenix, the oldest son of a Mexican-born father and a mother who planted a Kamala Harris sign in the front yard.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
abstract: This week’s properties are in Manhattan Valley, East Harlem and Bedford-Stuyvesant.
lead_paragraph: A two-bedroom, two-bath, 1,031-square-foot apartment with a pass-through kitchen, an open living/dining room, marble bathrooms, a primary bedroom with a walk-in closet, a terrace and a vented washer/dryer, on the second floor of a four-story building with a live-in super. Melissa Leifer, Keller Williams NYC, 917-364-1274; kwnyc.com

headline: The Sisters Behind ‘Nobody Wants This’ Are in High Demand
abstract: Sara and Erin Foster took a short break to discuss the hit show loosely based on Erin’s life, everyone’s love of Adam Brody and their advocacy for reproductive rights.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday morning, Sara and Erin Foster, the sisters behind the Netflix series “Nobody Wants This,” joined a video call from their respective homes in Los Angeles. Sara, 43, was wearing an oversize sweatshirt, and Erin, 42, was in a bathrobe.

headline: The White House Bet Big on Intel. Will It Backfire?
abstract: A plan to revive U.S. chip manufacturing rests partly on a company that is firing workers and delaying factories, even as the government pushes for the opposite.
lead_paragraph: At an annual gathering of tech executives and billionaires in Sun Valley, Idaho, this past July, Gina Raimondo commandeered a table near a duck pond and tried to exert her influence as the U.S. secretary of commerce to help rescue an ailing national champion.

headline: It Really Does Feel Close in North Carolina
abstract: Democrats hope demographic changes bring them success. Republicans hope Hurricane Helene didn’t ruin all their plans.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what makes North Carolina, with its 16 Electoral College votes, unique among the electoral battlegrounds this year.

headline: Abortion Is at the Center of Ohio’s Senate Race as Brown Battles for Survival
abstract: Senator Sherrod Brown has spent his decades in Congress establishing a track record as a populist champion on economic issues. But in the closing days of his re-election race, abortion has become a key emphasis.
lead_paragraph: Senator Sherrod Brown, the raspy-voiced Democratic mainstay of Ohio, has spent decades building a political brand focused on opposing free-trade deals that harm local workers and working to raise wages and benefits at home.

headline: Prominent Lawyer Enters N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race Against Adams
abstract: Jim Walden, a political independent and a lawyer who has worked on high-profile cases, will run for mayor against Eric Adams.
lead_paragraph: Jim Walden, a prominent and well-regarded lawyer who has represented causes across the political spectrum, will announce on Thursday that he is entering the New York City mayor’s race.

headline: Here Is the Missing Context in Ta-Nehisi Coates’s ‘The Message’
abstract: Israel and its foes share one thing in common.
lead_paragraph: Why did pro-Palestinian protesters at Columbia University chant “N.Y.P.D., K.K.K.” and the Movement for Black Lives demand “an immediate end to Israel’s lethal settler-colonial project”? And how did the tables turn so quickly on Israel — even before its military retaliation — after Hamas attacked it on Oct. 7?

headline: ‘They Would Never Be Doing This Under Trump’: Two G.O.P. Foreign Policy Experts on What a Second Term Would Mean for the World
abstract: Two veterans of Trump’s term look ahead to a potential second term and what it would mean for the world.
lead_paragraph: In 2016 foreign policy was the arena where a Donald Trump presidency seemed likely to be the most destabilizing. Eight years later, he is campaigning on a promise to restore peace to a world that’s grown much more violent and chaotic on President Biden’s watch.

headline: Short on Time, Harris’s Labor Allies Sprint to Reach Working-Class Voters
abstract: Unions and their affiliates think they can still break through with the Democrats’ worst demographic, white working-class voters, by hustling on the ground. But it has been a slog.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s allies in organized labor have begun a late drive to help her with white working-class voters, her weakest demographic, in the face of great skepticism over inflation, old grudges about free trade, new ones about student-loan forgiveness, and a profound blue-collar affinity for Donald J. Trump.

headline: Elon Musk, Robert Kennedy and the Unconfirmables of a Second Trump Administration
abstract: Back in the White House, Trump would get input from a bestiary of nihilists, destructionists and even criminals.
lead_paragraph: If you watched any of Donald Trump’s recent rally in Butler, Pa., you probably noticed Elon Musk beside him — jumping, jiving, arms raised, belly bared — and wondered what in the name of Tesla the chronically overstimulated gazillionaire was doing. Impromptu aerobics? A cheerleading audition? Charades?

headline: Luxury Fashion as Political Propaganda
abstract: In fights to sway public sentiment, critics often point to costly clothes as evidence of moral corruption.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 19, three days after Israeli soldiers killed the Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar, the Israeli military released a video that was dated a year earlier, just before the attack that began the war in Gaza. It shows, among other things, Samar Muhammad Abu Zamer, whom the Israeli military says is the wife of Mr. Sinwar, moving into a tunnel carrying a black handbag.

headline: Jenny Slate’s Audiobook ‘Lifeform’ Delivers
abstract: Her collection of essays is made for the ear.
lead_paragraph: The actress and comedian Jenny Slate just published her second collection of essays, called “Lifeform.” The book is largely about becoming a mother and falling in love during the coronavirus pandemic. The audiobook critic Rhoda Feng says Slate brings “her chops as a stand up comedian” and her “unique voice” to these essays, creating “characters instantaneously, from sentence to sentence.” Listening to “Lifeform” is the most absorbing way to experience it, Feng says.

headline: What Is One Lesson About Love You Have Learned?
abstract: In honor of Modern Love’s 20th anniversary, we invite you to share what your relationships — platonic, familial or romantic — have taught you.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, The New York Times introduced a new weekly column about love and relationships called Modern Love. There, writers have shared hundreds of stories about relationships of all kinds — friendships, romances, familial bonds — and the lessons about love they have learned as a result.

headline: 36 Hours in Moab, Utah
abstract: Walk among sandstone towers, experience some of the darkest skies in North America and breathe in the solitude.
lead_paragraph: Walk among sandstone towers, experience some of the darkest skies in North America and breathe in the solitude.

headline: A Toast to a Night When 2 Women Made History
abstract: In 1973, the Pierre Hotel on Fifth Avenue would not serve unaccompanied women. A legal challenge overturned that ban.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll find out why two women who sued the Pierre Hotel in 1973 will be honored guests there tonight. We’ll also get details on a bill to regulate hotels that the City Council approved.

headline: There Are Four Anti-Trump Pathways We Failed to Take. There Is a Fifth.
abstract: Why have so many of our democracy’s defenses seemingly broken down, and which, if any, remain?
lead_paragraph: Democratic self-rule contains a paradox. It is a system premised on openness and competition. Any ambitious party or politician should have a shot at running for office and winning. But what if a major candidate seeks to dismantle that very system?

headline: Circe and Muse No Longer: A New Opera Reconsiders Alma Mahler
abstract: “Alma,” premiering this week at the Vienna Volksoper, views its often-vilified protagonist through a feminist lens: as a thwarted composer and mother.
lead_paragraph: At the end of 1901, the budding composer Alma Schindler received a 20-page letter from Gustav Mahler laying out the expected terms of their future life together.

headline: I Went Viral for Crying Over Hurricane Milton. I Couldn’t Help It.
abstract: When it comes to the climate crisis, sometimes feelings are as important as facts, even for meteorologists.
lead_paragraph: The meteorologist John Morales has been a hurricane specialist in Miami for decades, but he never found himself close to tears until he witnessed the intensification of Hurricane Milton while live on the air earlier this month. In the weeks since, the clip of Morales choking up has been viewed millions of times online. In this episode of The Opinions, Morales reflects on his emotional response to the Hurricane and urges Americans who share his climate anxiety to talk about how they feel — and vote accordingly.

headline: E.P.A. Toughens Requirements to Remove Lead Paint Dust Around Children
abstract: The new rules consider any detectable level of lead dust in a building a “lead hazard,” requiring property owners to pay for cleanup.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration said Thursday that it was strengthening requirements for homes and child-care facilities to remove lead-based paint dust, a move that could better protect more than 300,000 children a year from the toxic metal.

headline: On the Upper East Side, Was $800,000 Enough for a Dog-Friendly Two-Bedroom?
abstract: A young couple searched Yorkville and Lenox Hill for a place with enough space to make their guests and their pets a little more comfortable. Here’s what they found.
lead_paragraph: A young couple searched Yorkville and Lenox Hill for a place with enough space to make their guests and their pets a little more comfortable. Here’s what they found.

headline: Elon Musk Plots His Final Moves for Trump
abstract: With less than two weeks until Election Day, the richest person in the world is throwing himself into the effort to elect the former president.
lead_paragraph: He dined with Rupert Murdoch and a handful of other billionaires, for Donald Trump.

headline: Trump’s Election Reversal Dreams Are Dead
abstract: At least as far as the law goes.
lead_paragraph: As we approach Election Day, I’m cautiously optimistic — not so much about the outcome of the election (it’s way too close for either side to feel confident), but rather about the durability and integrity of the process itself. The legal arguments Donald Trump used to try to reverse the election outcome in 2020 have been decisively rejected, and the legal loopholes he tried to open have been closed.

headline: Harris Drops the F-Bomb on CNN’s Town Hall
abstract: But name-calling is less powerful than truth-telling.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris came out strong on Wednesday night in her CNN town hall with Anderson Cooper and an audience of undecided voters in Pennsylvania’s Delaware County. She began by citing the testimony of Donald Trump’s former chief of staff, John Kelly, along with his national security advisers, his secretaries of defense, his chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and his vice president — all of whom have spoken of his unfitness to serve as president.

headline: Listen: ‘The Push to Ban Phones in School’
abstract: More and more states are cracking down on students’ use of cellphones. Is that a good thing?
lead_paragraph: A growing number of states are cracking down on students’ use of phones in response to rising concerns over teenagers and their mental health. So far this year, at least eight states have passed laws, issued orders or adopted rules to curb phone use among students during school hours, including California, Indiana and Louisiana. Proponents of the restrictions argue that the small but ubiquitous digital devices distract students, impair learning and contribute to phone-related bullying and fights.

headline: Is McDonald’s Quarter Pounder Too Big to Fail?
abstract: After an E. coli outbreak, McDonald’s stopped selling the Quarter Pounder in 12 states. The burger might take a hit for now, but its hold on customers will prevail, experts say.
lead_paragraph: It’s bigger than a regular burger and easier to eat than a Big Mac. It’s venerated in “Pulp Fiction,” a symbol of American gluttony in Morgan Spurlock’s “Supersize Me” and a source of endless hacks on TikTok.

headline: Facebook Marketplace Chefs Deliver Homemade Tamales, Empanadas and Other Foods
abstract: Facebook Marketplace, a platform often used for furniture and electronics, is an increasingly popular place to buy and sell home-cooked meals.
lead_paragraph: In the cramped kitchen of a home in Queens, Tiana Webb slowly flipped empanadas in a pot of hot oil as they turned crispy and brown — just like her Jamaican-Puerto Rican family taught her.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,224
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Oct. 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 502
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Oct. 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: 12 Days to Go: French Fries and Fascism
abstract: We break down the latest developments in the presidential race, including the warning from John Kelly, Donald Trump’s longest-serving chief of staff, that the former president met the definition of a fascist, and Kamala Harris’s final plea that Trump is a threat to democracy.
lead_paragraph: We break down the latest developments in the presidential race, including the warning from John Kelly, Donald Trump’s longest-serving chief of staff, that the former president met the definition of a fascist, and Kamala Harris’s final plea that Trump is a threat to democracy.

headline: Harris Calls Trump a Fascist, and North Korea Has Sent Troops to Russia
abstract: Plus, American Airlines cracks down on “gate lice.”
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: 12 Days to Go: French Fries and Fascism
abstract: Watch or listen to our political round table.
lead_paragraph: Warning: this episode contains strong language.

headline: 12 Days to Go: French Fries and Fascism
abstract: Michael Barbaro sits down with the Times reporters Michael Schmidt, Lisa Lerer, Reid Epstein and Nate Cohn to discuss the latest developments in the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: Michael Barbaro sits down with the Times reporters Michael Schmidt, Lisa Lerer, Reid Epstein and Nate Cohn to discuss the latest developments in the presidential race.

headline: Fred Upton, Former G.O.P. Congressman Who Voted to Impeach Trump, Endorses Harris
abstract: The veteran Michigan Republican called the former president “unfit to serve,” and said Vice President Kamala Harris would work to bring people together.
lead_paragraph: Former Representative Fred Upton, the Michigan Republican who served three decades in the House and retired in 2022 after voting to impeach former President Donald J. Trump, endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris on Thursday, becoming the latest G.O.P. figure to cross party lines and vouch for her.

headline: America’s Embrace of Marijuana
abstract: Why public opinion has changed so quickly.
lead_paragraph: Twelve years ago, mainstream politicians opposed marijuana legalization. Recreational use was forbidden even in the most liberal states.

headline: Pope Francis, in New Letter, Urges Catholics to Reject Individualism
abstract: In an encyclical titled “He Loved Us,” Francis draws on spiritual themes in the hopes of helping people find deeper meaning while living in today’s hectic societies.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis issued a new pastoral letter on Thursday in which he urged Roman Catholics around the world to let go of consumerism and individualism, and rediscover the importance of opening up to others.

headline: ‘La Cocina’ Review: The Melting Pot Boils Over
abstract: This drama by Alonso Ruizpalacios takes a bitter look at the American dream from the perspective of the workers at a fast-paced diner.
lead_paragraph: “Somebody tell us a dream,” says Pedro (Raúl Briones), a charismatic line cook at a Times Square diner. He’s on a smoke break with co-workers — “the United Nations,” quips one of them, referring to their diverse origins. Nonzo, a Brooklyn-born dessert chef (Motell Foster) responds to Pedro, who is from Mexico, waxing philosophical about an immigrant who spends his sad, long days after passing through Ellis Island working at a pizza joint.

headline: ‘Magpie’ Review: An Unhappily Married Woman
abstract: Daisy Ridley plays a time bomb with a simmering fuse in this slow yet gripping adultery thriller.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, all it takes is pancakes. When you’re Anette (Daisy Ridley), a frustrated, stay-at-home mother of two, even a simple breakfast food can snap your last nerve. Anette’s instability, though, has been building for some time, as Sam Yates’s “Magpie” gradually reveals by way of brief encounters and deceptively casual conversations. There’s nothing offhand, though, about her mounting fury.

headline: ‘My Name Is Alfred Hitchcock’ Review: Director’s Commentary
abstract: A richly detailed essay film imagines Hitchcock commenting on his own oeuvre over a mesmerizing daisy chain of clips.
lead_paragraph: Alfred Hitchcock’s voice remains indelible, like a droll bloodhound trying to hypnotize you over tea. Mark Cousins’s richly detailed essay film “My Name Is Alfred Hitchcock” imagines the director commenting on his own oeuvre over a mesmerizing daisy chain of clips, with an insider’s knowledge of filmmaking.

headline: ‘Road Diary: Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band’ Review: A Mission
abstract: At 75, Springsteen is doggedly committed to live performance. This documentary chronicles how he keeps up on tour, and why.
lead_paragraph: While it was Lou Reed who coined the adage that one’s life could be saved by rock ’n’ roll, Bruce Springsteen embodies it.

headline: What to Know About North Korea’s Military Capabilities
abstract: The North’s nuclear forces have been the focus of global concern. But its conventional military is vast and empowered — even if it is hobbled by shortages, corruption and isolation.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Pyongyang’s growing nuclear arsenal has generated headlines. Now, as thousands of North Korean soldiers pour into Russia to help it fight the war in Ukraine, a much older threat has become relevant again: North Korea’s massive conventional forces, one of the largest in the world.

headline: Biden Administration Outlines Government ‘Guardrails’ for A.I. Tools
abstract: A national security memorandum detailed how agencies should streamline operations with artificial intelligence safely.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Thursday signed the first national security memorandum detailing how the Pentagon, the intelligence agencies and other national security institutions should use and protect artificial intelligence technology, putting “guardrails” on how such tools are employed in decisions varying from nuclear weapons to granting asylum.

headline: India Evacuates 1 Million as Tropical Cyclone Dana Nears
abstract: With the storm forecast to make landfall by early Friday, residents in parts of West Bengal and Odisha States took shelter in thousands of camps.
lead_paragraph: About a million people were evacuated from parts of India’s eastern coast on Thursday as Tropical Cyclone Dana approached, with airports, schools and train services shut down as the storm brought flooding and landslide risks to some of the country’s poorest communities.

headline: The French Connection to Online Bets on Trump
abstract: Polymarket said that it had linked a single trader to accounts that have wagered heavily on the Republican to win, pushing up his odds on the prediction market.
lead_paragraph: With the presidential race so tight, election watchers have become increasingly fascinated by political prediction markets, especially as the odds implied by wagers on their platforms suggest that Donald Trump is more likely to win the election.

headline: Lebanon Says Israeli Attack Killed 3 More of Its Soldiers
abstract: Israel’s military said it was looking into whether its forces had “accidentally harmed” Lebanese soldiers while conducting raids in southern Lebanon against Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: Lebanon’s military said Thursday that an Israeli attack had killed three more of its soldiers in the southern part of the country, hours after a new wave of airstrikes hit residential areas near Beirut overnight.

headline: What We Know About the Militant Attack in Turkey
abstract: After the assault on an aerospace complex in Ankara, Turkey struck sites of the Kurdistan Workers’ Party and its affiliates in Syria and Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Two armed militants attacked the headquarters of Turkey’s state-run aerospace company on Wednesday, killing five people and injuring 22 others in what the government called a terrorist attack. The attackers were killed.

headline: An American in Paris, Honored Like Nobody Before
abstract: The artist Barbara Chase-Riboud hadn’t had a show in her adopted city since 1974. Now she is being celebrated in eight museums, including the Louvre.
lead_paragraph: The Salle des Cariatides gallery at the heart of the Louvre is home to the museum’s finest examples of Greek and Roman statuary. And, until January, it’s also the showcase for a gleaming 1997 sculpture titled “Cleopatra’s Bed.”

headline: Putin Abandons Caution on North Korea in Pursuit of Victory in Ukraine
abstract: The invasion of Ukraine has led the Russian leader to jettison cooperation with the West over North Korea’s nuclear arsenal in favor of an ever-deepening military alliance with Pyongyang.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of North Korean men converged on Russia’s Pacific Coast six years ago. President Vladimir V. Putin had decided to punish North Korea for developing nuclear weapons, and the men — North Korean laborers used by Russian businesses — were being sent home.

headline: 3 Arrested in Sri Lanka Over Possible Threats Against Israeli Tourists
abstract: The arrests, all of Sri Lankans, came a day after the U.S. and Israel issued warnings to its citizens to avoid a popular tourist area.
lead_paragraph: The police in Sri Lanka have arrested three people over possible threats against tourists, specifically targeting visitors from Israel, Sri Lankan officials said on Thursday.

headline: England Plans to Ban Disposable Vapes Next Year
abstract: The measure, which echoes plans in Scotland and Wales, aims to protect young people’s health and reduce environmental damage.
lead_paragraph: Disposable vapes will be banned in England starting in June under a government plan announced on Thursday, a move aimed at protecting young people’s health and reducing waste.

headline: Teens to Hollywood: Enough Sex, Already
abstract: At least that is what they told researchers at U.C.L.A. The high popularity of romance plots in movies and shows suggests otherwise.
lead_paragraph: Movies and television shows about rich people are the last thing we want to watch. And skip the sex: We prefer content that focuses on platonic relationships. (There’s enough porn online as it is.) We do like fantasy as a genre, increasingly so. But please, pretty please, fix how you incorporate social media into story lines. It’s cringe.

headline: How Two Allies Wrestled Over a Crypto Giant and a Prisoner
abstract: The United States and Nigeria often collaborate. But the arrest of an American worker strained their diplomatic relations.
lead_paragraph: After eight months in custody in Nigeria, an American working for the cryptocurrency firm Binance is coming home, ailing but alive, in a case that had strained U.S. ties with one of Africa’s most influential countries.

headline: Read the Letter from Nobel Laureates Endorsing Kamala Harris for President
abstract: More than 80 American Nobel Prize winners in physics, chemistry, medicine and economics have signed an open letter endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris for president.
lead_paragraph: More than 80 American Nobel Prize winners in physics, chemistry, medicine and economics have signed an open letter endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris for president.

headline: 82 American Nobel Prize Winners Endorse Kamala Harris
abstract: The group of scientists and economists said they feared a Trump presidency would impede progress in science and technology and in fighting climate change.
lead_paragraph: More than 80 American Nobel Prize winners in physics, chemistry, medicine and economics have signed an open letter endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris for president.

headline: Why Democracy Lives and Dies by Math
abstract: A documentary filmmaker and a mathematician discuss our fear of numbers and its civic costs.
lead_paragraph: “Math is power” is the tag line of a new documentary, “Counted Out,” currently making the rounds at festivals and community screenings. (It will have a limited theatrical release next year.) The film explores the intersection of mathematics, civil rights and democracy. And it delves into how an understanding of math, or lack thereof, affects society’s ability to deal with the most pressing challenges and crises — health care, climate, misinformation, elections.

headline: The U.N.’s Verdict on Climate Progress Over the Past Year: There Was None
abstract: An annual assessment by the world body tracks the gulf between what countries have vowed to do and what they’ve actually achieved.
lead_paragraph: One year after world leaders made a landmark promise to move away from fossil fuels, countries have essentially made no progress in cutting emissions and tackling global warming, according to a United Nations report issued on Thursday.

headline: Mozambique’s Governing Party Candidate Wins Disputed Presidential Election
abstract: Daniel Chapo of the Frelimo party, which has governed the southern African nation for nearly 50 years, was declared the victor amid violence and widespread allegations of fraud.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Chapo was declared the winner of Mozambique’s presidential election on Thursday after a process marred by violence and widespread accusations that his party, Frelimo, which has run the country for nearly five decades, committed fraud.

headline: Trump Flirts With the Ultimate Tax Cut: No Income Taxes at All
abstract: The former president has repeatedly praised a period in American history when there was no income tax, and the country relied on tariffs to fund the government.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has spent much of the presidential campaign brainstorming new, and sometimes untested, ways to cut taxes. In the election’s final stretch, he raised the possibility of going even further: eliminating income taxes entirely.

headline: ‘Truly Just Divine’ Weeknight Tantanmen
abstract: Hetty Lui McKinnon’s hearty tantanmen with fried tofu is soothing, spicy and — crucially — doable after a busy day.
lead_paragraph: There are two seasons in my house: cold noodle season and hot noodle season. Cold noodle season, as you can probably guess, consists of spring and summer, when the temps are high, the days are long and my noodles are chilled: zaru soba, kongguksu, sesame noodles.

headline: Unexplained Enigmas in the Orion Nebula May Be Victims of Stellar Bullying
abstract: Astronomers offered a new hypothesis for what created pairs of objects nicknamed JuMBOs, while other scientists argue they may not really exist.
lead_paragraph: Some 1,350 light-years from Earth, astronomers detected strange pairs of unexplained objects orbiting in the Orion Nebula. Since then, about 12 months ago, other scientists have proposed a new potential explanation for these apparitions, while other researchers wonder whether they exist at all.

headline: Beyoncé Will Appear With Kamala Harris at Houston Rally
abstract: The pop superstar, whose song “Freedom” is already used by the Democratic nominee at her rallies, will appear with Ms. Harris at a Friday event focused on abortion rights.
lead_paragraph: The pop superstar Beyoncé will appear on Friday with Vice President Kamala Harris at a rally in Houston about abortion rights, according to two people briefed on the plans, adding another gold-plated name to the list of celebrities who have thrown their support behind Ms. Harris, including Taylor Swift, Oprah Winfrey and Robert De Niro.

headline: The Key to a Better Golf Swing? Loosen Up Your Spine.
abstract: By increasing the mobility of your upper back, you can both prevent injury and improve your game.
lead_paragraph: The average golfer will swing their club about 94 times over the course of 18 holes, and some 26.6 million golfers took to the links in 2023. All of those swings tend to add up to a lot of injuries.

headline: A 20-Minute Workout to Keep Your Body Limber
abstract: Throwing your back out is often caused by stiffness in the upper spine. Here’s how to prevent future pain.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans will throw out their back at some point — whether playing golf, grabbing a suitcase from an overhead compartment or simply reaching behind from the front seat of a car. And while the most common place to feel pain is the lower back, that pain can be caused by a lack of mobility in the upper spine.

headline: As Harris Courts Republicans, the Left Grows Wary and Alienated
abstract: The vice president’s tack to the right, support for Israel in the Gaza war and incremental policy proposals have alienated progressives and raised worries about waning liberal energy.
lead_paragraph: As Vice President Kamala Harris makes a broad play to the political center, some Democrats worry that she is going too far in her bid to win over moderates who are skeptical of former President Donald J. Trump. In private — and increasingly in public as Election Day fast approaches — they say she risks chilling Democratic enthusiasm by alienating progressives and working-class voters.

headline: Monique Knowlton, ’60s-Era Model and Provocative Gallerist, Dies at 87
abstract: A Vogue cover girl in the early 1960s, she later pivoted to contemporary art, opening a gallery where being “outrageous counts as a plus,” one critic wrote.
lead_paragraph: Monique Knowlton, a German-born model and Manhattan gallerist whose roguish glamour once elevated the covers of Vogue and the work of image-makers like the fashion photographer Bert Stern, died on Oct. 8 at her home in Manhattan. She was 87.

headline: Southwest Strikes a Truce With the Activist Hedge Fund Elliott
abstract: The airline will appoint six new directors to its board, avoiding a proxy fight with the activist investor Elliott Investment Management, one of its largest shareholders.
lead_paragraph: Southwest Airlines will appoint six new directors as part of a truce with Elliott Investment Management, the big activist investor seeking to shake up the airline.

headline: Met Opera and Singer Injured in Onstage Fall Settle Decade-Old Lawsuit
abstract: Wendy White, a veteran mezzo-soprano, was performing when she fell in 2011. Her suit, which claimed negligence, had been one of the company’s longest-running court cases.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade after she was injured in a fall from a platform on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera while singing in a production of “Faust,” the veteran mezzo-soprano Wendy White has settled her lawsuit against the company.

headline: 50 Artists, 50 Years: Marian Goodman Gallery Opens a New Chapter
abstract: One of the biggest small galleries tips its hat to its conceptual history, while bringing new artists and their market-friendly work into view.
lead_paragraph: In 1977, when Marian Goodman opened her gallery in Manhattan with a show by the Belgian poet turned conceptual artist Marcel Broodthaers, the asset managers hadn’t yet taken notice of the art world. There was some money around, of course. There certainly is now, as management of the Goodman Gallery has passed from the nonagenarian dealer to her five designated successors in waiting, and as it moves to an entire building in TriBeCa from its longtime home on West 57th Street.

headline: C.D.C. Expands Covid Vaccine Recommendations
abstract: The agency endorsed additional doses for people at high risk.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Wednesday expanded its Covid vaccine recommendations, urging some people to get additional doses of the updated shots.

headline: In This Biography, Mitch McConnell Hates Trump but Loves Power More
abstract: “The Price of Power,” by Michael Tackett, reveals a legislator for whom political survival has been a top priority — even when it means supporting a “sleazeball” for the presidency.
lead_paragraph: For months after the Jan. 6, 2021, rampage at the Capitol, the damaged window of Mitch McConnell’s office was left unrepaired, a graphic reminder of the moment when one of rioters bashed the fortified glass with a flagpole. McConnell, the Kentucky Republican who was the Senate majority leader at the time, professed his disgust at what happened, calling it “further evidence of Donald Trump’s complete unfitness for office.”

headline: Finger-Pointing if Trump Beats Harris
abstract: Readers discuss a column by Bret Stephens. Also: A flood of election mailers in Pennsylvania; speech on campus; fighting malaria.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Two Students Created Face Recognition Glasses. It Wasn’t Hard.
abstract: A Boston man had a strange encounter at a subway station. A month later, he discovered he was the star of the students’ viral video.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday afternoon, Kashif Hoda was waiting for a train near Harvard Square when a young man asked him for directions. Mr. Hoda was struck by the man’s nerdy, thick-framed glasses, but he did not realize that they were Ray-Ban Meta smart glasses and that a small white light indicated that they were recording.

headline: How 7 Friends Testing a Metal Detector Made Britain’s Most Valuable Treasure Find
abstract: A pastime in a farmer’s field led to the discovery of Norman-era coins valued at more than $5 million.
lead_paragraph: The group huddled together in the farmer’s field, staring at the dozen or so medieval silver coins. They had found one, then two, and a third — Adam Staples knew, then, this was something special.

headline: Onion Recall Linked to E. Coli and McDonald’s Spreads to Other Fast Food Chains
abstract: A deadly outbreak spurred removal of onions by a major food supplier in the Mountain West. Taco Bell, KFC, Burger King and Pizza Hut have stopped serving onions at various locations.
lead_paragraph: A sweeping onion recall linked to an E. coli outbreak involving McDonald’s Quarter Pounders has prompted several other major fast-food chains to remove raw onions from their menu offerings.

headline: Grizzly Bear 399, Mother of 18 Cubs, Is Killed by Driver
abstract: She lived to 28, roaming the Yellowstone area with her many offspring while becoming a favorite among both residents and visitors.
lead_paragraph: Grizzly bear 399, one of the best known bears in the world and the oldest recorded reproducing female grizzly in the greater Yellowstone area, was struck by a car and died Tuesday south of Jackson, Wyo. She was 28.

headline: Review: The Miraculous Simplicity of Patti Smith’s Childhood
abstract: At the Baryshnikov Arts Center, an adaptation of Smith’s poem-memoir “Woolgathering” features Smith reciting, others dancing and a surprise guest.
lead_paragraph: “Woolgathering” is a slim collection of prose poems that Patti Smith, the singer-songwriter and punk pioneer, published in 1992. It’s mostly a memoir of childhood — of a poet’s childhood, or of the way that all children have a poet’s imagination. “The mind of a child,” she writes, “is like a kiss on the forehead — open and disinterested.” It is “mystified by the commonplace” and “moves effortlessly into the strange,” glimpsing and gleaning, “piecing together a crazy quilt of truths.”

headline: Oy, This Ad: Jewish Stereotypes in Service of Trump as a Safer Option
abstract: A new commercial from the Republican Jewish Coalition tries to give Jewish voters a rationale for voting for the former president, based on fear.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Jewish Coalition has been airing this 30-second commercial, “Amen,” since last week. The group has spent about $360,000 broadcasting the spot in Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada and Pennsylvania, according to AdImpact.

headline: Why the World Fears a War Between Israel and Iran
abstract: An all-out war could entangle countries around the world and threaten the global economy.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates as Israel launches retaliatory strikes against Iran.

headline: Putin Appears to Say That North Korean Troops Are in Russia
abstract: “If there are images they are a reflection of something,” he said in a tongue-in-cheek answer to whether Pyongyang had sent troops to help with Russia’s war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appeared to acknowledge on Thursday that North Korean troops had been deployed to Russia, commenting for the first time on the assessment of Western officials that the reclusive Asian country had joined Russia’s war effort against Ukraine.

headline: District Attorney Will Ask Court to Resentence Menendez Brothers
abstract: The request from George Gascón, the Los Angeles County district attorney, could lead to Lyle and Erik Menendez being released from prison, decades after they were convicted of murdering their parents.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles County district attorney said on Thursday that he would request the resentencing of Lyle and Erik Menendez, who killed their parents in 1989, a step that could lead to their release from prison.

headline: Netflix Wanted ‘Wuthering Heights.’ Margot Robbie Wanted a Theatrical Release.
abstract: In the end, Ms. Robbie got what she wanted, signing a deal with Warner Bros.
lead_paragraph: In the latest Hollywood movie bidding war, the battle between a theatrical and a streaming release could not have been more stark.

headline: Trump Says He’ll Fire Jack Smith, Special Counsel Who Indicted Him, if He Wins Again
abstract: The former president’s remarks to a conservative radio host were his most pointed about the special counsel, Jack Smith, if he returns to the White House.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump said on Thursday that if elected again he would in “two seconds” fire the special counsel Jack Smith, who has brought two federal indictments against him in the past 18 months.

headline: As Election Looms, Justice Dept. Tries to Steer Clear of Politics
abstract: A department memo seeks to formalize a pre-election “quiet period” in which senior officials should avoid unnecessary high-profile moves.
lead_paragraph: Senior Justice Department officials are not generally known for public bluster or bold pronouncements, but this October in particular they are under explicit instructions to stay mostly quiet, in the hopes of avoiding the sort of political firestorms that engulfed the department in the last two presidential elections.

headline: Tucker Carlson Tells Crowd Trump Will Give Country a ‘Spanking’
abstract: The former Fox News host used a bizarre extended metaphor at a rally in Georgia where Donald J. Trump spoke.
lead_paragraph: The former Fox News host Tucker Carlson stirred up a crowd of Trump supporters on Wednesday night with a bizarre extended metaphor that cast former President Donald J. Trump as an angry father about to come home and give a “vigorous spanking” to his disobedient daughter.

headline: Easy Dinners That Don’t Cause a Mess
abstract: Creamy tomato beans and greens, maraq misir and golden potato soup won’t dirty all your dishes (or splatter your just-cleaned countertops).
lead_paragraph: Few things can redirect a bad mood or a bad week like basking in the glow of a freshly deep-cleaned kitchen. Sunlight refracts off glistening counter tops; the smell of synthetic lemon wafts in the air; every dish, rag, spice container and skillet idles in its rightful place.

headline: As Bird Flu Spreads, Additional Human Infection Is Reported in Missouri
abstract: Two people sharing a home caught the virus without known exposure to animals. More than 30 human cases have been reported in the United States.
lead_paragraph: A Missouri resident who shared a home with a patient hospitalized with bird flu in August was also infected with the virus, federal officials reported on Thursday.

headline: The Group at the Center of Trump’s Planning for a Second Term Is One You Haven’t Heard of
abstract: America First Policy Institute didn’t even exist four years ago. But it is poised to be more influential than Project 2025.
lead_paragraph: Late this summer, a prominent right-wing think tank invited conservatives from around the country to learn how to work in a second Donald J. Trump administration.

headline: ‘Conclave’ Review: Serpents and Doves Amok in the Vatican
abstract: This film, based on Robert Harris’s 2016 thriller of the same title, centers on a British cardinal (a sensational Ralph Fiennes), and a campaign for a new pope.
lead_paragraph: There are no Kamala Harris or Donald Trump bumper stickers embellishing the vans that occasionally zip through “Conclave.” The current presidential race is the far greater, more consequential nail-biter, yet there’s still much riding on the contest in this sly, sleek election potboiler about the selection of a new Catholic pope. With pomp and circumstance, miles of scarlet cloth and first-rate scene-stealers, the movie snakes through the marbled corridors of Vatican City, pauses in bedchambers as cold as mausoleums and tunnels into the deepest secrets of the human heart. It’s quite the journey, and as unpersuasive as it is entertaining.

headline: Can Biological Engineering Change the World?
abstract: Altering the DNA of living organisms could be an early step in re-engineering the natural world to help curb climate change.
lead_paragraph: Science is always focused on breakthroughs and the next big thing. And, too often, there is loads of hype about what benefits to society a particular breakthrough might bring.

headline: Union Votes to Reject Boeing Contract and Continue Strike
abstract: Workers in Boeing’s largest union voted by a wide margin to reject a second tentative contract and extend a nearly six-week-long strike.
lead_paragraph: Workers in Boeing’s largest union voted by a wide margin to reject a second tentative contract and extend a nearly six-week-long strike.

headline: Wildfires in the West Aren’t Just Getting Bigger. They’re Faster, Too.
abstract: In recent decades, fast-growing blazes were responsible for an outsize share of fire-related devastation, scientists found using satellite data.
lead_paragraph: Wildfires aren’t just tearing through larger swaths of the American West. They’re spreading more quickly, too.

headline: ‘Back to the Future’ to Close on Broadway, Rerouting DeLorean to Germany
abstract: The musical, which opened in London three years ago, is still going strong there and touring North America, while productions are planned in Japan and on a cruise ship.
lead_paragraph: “Back to the Future,” a nostalgia-rich and spectacle-laden musical adaptation of the much-loved 1985 film, will end its Broadway run on Jan. 5, succumbing to the difficult economics of the commercial theater business.

headline: Investigation of Georgia Movie Set Crash Finds No Violations
abstract: Eight people were taken to hospitals, three of them with serious injuries, in a crash on the set of “The Pickup” in April. A federal investigation found no health or safety violations.
lead_paragraph: An investigation into a crash that injured several crew members on the set of the movie “The Pickup” this year found no safety violations, federal officials said.

headline: Email From Boeing to Ethiopian Airlines Sheds Light on a Tragic Crash
abstract: Newly revealed correspondence indicates that a Boeing senior official counseled that the company could answer a pilot’s safety question, but it did not.
lead_paragraph: The questions came in the form of an email on Dec. 1, 2018, to Boeing from the chief pilot at Ethiopian Airlines. They were detailed and filled with aviation jargon. One of them was 452 words.

headline: In High-Stakes Pennsylvania, Local Officials Have a Big Hand in Voting Rules
abstract: Since 2019, every Pennsylvanian has had a vote-by-mail option. But policies on drop boxes and mail-in ballot errors can vary across the state’s 67 counties.
lead_paragraph: Election Day was still a few weeks away, and Renee Smithkors, the long-serving director of elections in Bradford County, Pa., had already had to call sheriff’s deputies 10 times to deal with people who were showing up at her office riled up by rumors about early voting or mail-in ballots.

headline: Canada Tightens Immigration After Years of Expansion
abstract: Saying that Canada had invited too many newcomers in, in too short a period of time, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced lower targets to slow population growth.
