lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, acknowledging that a rapid growth in Canada’s immigrant population over the past three years had strained resources, announced on Thursday significant cuts to the number of newcomers in coming years.

headline: Antonio Skármeta, Who Wrote of Chile’s Tears and Turmoil, Dies at 83
abstract: His literary career traced the arc of his country’s modern political journey in stories about ordinary citizens facing repression and arbitrary government.
lead_paragraph: Antonio Skármeta, a Chilean novelist, screenplay writer, playwright and television presenter who captured his country’s affections with warmhearted tales of its suffering and redemption through dictatorship and democracy, died on Oct. 15 at his home in Santiago. He was 83.

headline: Michael Jackson, British General Who Disobeyed U.S. Superior, Dies at 80
abstract: Labeled “the Prince of Darkness,” he refused to follow an order by NATO’s commander during the Balkans war, saying, “It’s not worth starting World War III.”
lead_paragraph: Gen. Michael Jackson, a former head of the British Army who was known as “the Prince of Darkness” for his heavy-hooded glare and gravelly voice, and who famously disobeyed an order by his American superior during the Yugoslav wars, saying it risked starting World War III, died on Oct. 15. He was 80.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 28, 2024
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Oct. 30, 2024
abstract: What issues are most important to U.S. voters? Who do you think swing voters are most likely to vote for?
lead_paragraph: In August, polls suggested that about 18 percent of American voters had not made up their minds between Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump. These voters are called swing voters.

headline: The Dilemma Iran’s Leader Faces
abstract: Iran’s supreme leader faces a critical choice: whether to pursue nuclear weapons.
lead_paragraph: If a person is fortunate enough to live into his ninth decade, life often turns toward quiet reflection, relaxation and the comforts of family and community. Not for the 85-year-old Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. The sunset years of Iran’s supreme leader have been defined by a series of daunting challenges: regional humiliations, domestic uprisings, the looming threat of war with Israel and a pivotal decision on whether to pursue nuclear weapons — a choice with profound implications for his political legacy and the country he has ruled for 35 years.

headline: This Library Book Was Due in 1923. It Was Returned Last Month.
abstract: A Colorado woman was decluttering, when she found something that had belonged to her grandmother: “Shakespeare’s Life of King Henry the Fifth.”
lead_paragraph: When a copy of Shakespeare’s “Henry V” was returned to the Paterson Public Library in Paterson, N.J., in September, there was one small problem that many tardy readers have encountered: It was a tad overdue.

headline: Despite Deadly Attack, Turkey Seeks Opening With Kurdish Militants
abstract: Recent gestures by Turkish leaders suggest the possibility of new peace talks with the group fighting for Kurdish autonomy.
lead_paragraph: This week, one of Turkey’s most powerful politicians made a surprising offer to the militant leader he has long branded a “baby killer” and “chief terrorist.”

headline: In Georgia, Harris’s Muslim Backers Push Her as Better Than the Alternative
abstract: The Mideast war is threatening Vice President Kamala Harris’s support among Muslim and Arab American voters, a traditionally Democratic constituency, in critical swing states.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, an influential group of 15 Muslim religious and business leaders convened at an office space in Dunwoody, Ga., a suburb north of Atlanta, to discuss Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: In Georgia, Harris Risks a Split in the Muslim and Arab Vote
abstract: Muslim and Arab voters were part of the coalition in Georgia who delivered victories to Democrats there in 2020 and in 2022. Maya King, a politics reporter for The New York Times covering the Southeast, describes how war in the Middle East is affecting their choice in 2024.
lead_paragraph: Muslim and Arab voters were part of the coalition in Georgia who delivered victories to Democrats there in 2020 and in 2022. Maya King, a politics reporter for The New York Times covering the Southeast, describes how war in the Middle East is affecting their choice in 2024.

headline: A Sweet Diwali, New York Style
abstract: For many New Yorkers from the Caribbean, Diwali is marked with sweet treats like prasad.
lead_paragraph: Even though Seema Singh’s home in Richmond Hill, Queens, will be filled with sweet treats this Halloween night, the offerings will be a far cry from miniature candy bars and packs of gum handed out to little ones in costumes.

headline: Tina S. Kaidanow, 59, Diplomatic Force in Kosovo and Guantánamo, Dies
abstract: She was the first U.S. ambassador to a newly independent Balkans nation and recently oversaw the transfer of cooperating Guantánamo prisoners to third countries.
lead_paragraph: Tina S. Kaidanow, a career diplomat who was the first U.S. ambassador to Kosovo following its independence in 2008, died on Oct. 14 in Washington. She was 59.

headline: It Sounded Like Dancing, Drinking and Sex. It Blew People’s Minds.
abstract: Critics have come a long way since “Maple Leaf Rag.” Just consider how “Cowboy Carter” rode into town.
lead_paragraph: Quick: What image comes to mind when you hear the word ragtime? Probably straw hats, lemonade and your kid trying to play “The Entertainer” on the piano. But in the 1890s and 1900s, the sound of the just-emerging musical style conjured something very different: dancing, drinking and sex. And Black people.

headline: With the Clock Ticking, Should Harris Define Herself or Her Opponent?
abstract: At a CNN town-hall meeting, Kamala Harris seemed more comfortable warning about the dangers of Donald J. Trump than describing her policies or continuing to introduce herself.
lead_paragraph: It was the most standard of job interview questions, in this case posed by Joe Donahue, a registered Republican and undecided voter, to an applicant for the post of leader of the free world: Vice President Kamala Harris, what weaknesses do you bring to the table?

headline: The Controversial World of Bagel Mods
abstract: The freaks come out at breakfast.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever eaten more than 70 bagels in a month? I can’t recommend it, gastrointestinally, but duty called: I was putting together our list of the best bagels in New York City.

headline: Sam Brown, G.O.P. Senate Candidate in Nevada, Gets Late Support From His Party
abstract: A Republican group supporting Senate races says it will spend $6.2 million on TV, radio and digital ads beginning this weekend.
lead_paragraph: After not spending any money in support of its Senate candidate in Nevada, the Republican Party’s main outside group supporting Senate races is making a large investment in hopes of unseating the state’s Democratic incumbent, Senator Jacky Rosen.

headline: The French Singer Who Won Over Iggy Pop
abstract: Zaho de Sagazan went viral for her performances at the Cannes Film Festival and the Paris Olympics. Next, she’s coming to America.
lead_paragraph: When the French singer-songwriter Zaho de Sagazan, 24, was a teenager she earned the nickname Petite Tempête — “Little Storm.” “I was crying all the time,” she says. “I didn’t know what to do with all my angst.” But after her twin sister introduced her to the work of the English singer-songwriter Tom Odell — with which she quickly became obsessed, learning all his lyrics and teaching herself to play his songs on the piano — she realized that music could be a means of processing her dark emotions. By 2020, she was sharing videos of her original songs, which blend elements of synth-pop, electronica and chanson Française, on Instagram. Her expressive, sometimes husky voice caught the attention of Warner Chappell/Virgin Music, which released her first album, “La Symphonie des Éclairs” (“The Symphony of Lightning”) in spring 2023. It went platinum in 2024 and earned four awards at Victoires de la Musique, the French version of the Grammys. Tomorrow, a reissued edition will hit streaming platforms with new material, including “Old Friends,” which de Sagazan recorded with Odell. “I basically slid into his DMs,” she says. “We’ve been friends since. Singing with him is one of the few things I dreamed of for myself.”

headline: ‘Somebody Somewhere’ Is Back for Its Final Season
abstract: The HBO dramedy about a Kansas woman finding love and community after tragedy returns for its third and final season on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: “Somebody Somewhere,” a perfect dramedy starring Bridget Everett as a Kansas woman finding love and community after her sister’s death, returns for its third and final season starting Sunday at 10:30 p.m., on HBO. The show is full of ecstatic tenderness and easy warmth, but it avoids pat tidiness.

headline: A Hurricane During Election Week? Don’t Worry Just Yet.
abstract: Maps spreading on social media show a storm hitting the United States the week of the election. But a lot more goes into a forecast than just one model run.
lead_paragraph: An illustration of a large storm approaching the United States can be scary at any time of year, but it becomes even more eye-popping when it shows a large storm approaching the United States on Nov. 5, when millions of Americans will be casting their ballots for their next president.

headline: Mailbox Arson Damages Ballots in Phoenix
abstract: Arizona’s secretary of state said affected voters would be contacted to make sure they could get a new ballot.
lead_paragraph: A curbside postal collection box in Phoenix was set on fire early Thursday, damaging an estimated 20 mail-in ballots before firefighters extinguished the blaze, the city’s Fire Department said.

headline: Lynda Obst, Producer, Dies at 74; Championed Women in Hollywood
abstract: She helped make films like “Sleepless in Seattle” and “Contact.” She also wrote widely about the industry, for The Times and other publications.
lead_paragraph: Lynda Obst, a New York journalist turned Hollywood producer who promoted women in films like “Sleepless in Seattle” and “Contact” while writing incisive dispatches from Tinseltown for outlets like The Atlantic and The New York Times, died on Tuesday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 74.

headline: Asheville Has Tap Water, but No One Knows When It Will Be Drinkable
abstract: People in the storm-hit area can resume flushing toilets and taking showers, but the water is often yellow or brown. Officials are asking for patience with repair efforts.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a month after the remnants of Hurricane Helene ravaged western North Carolina, running water has now been restored to most of the region around Asheville — but you can’t drink it yet.

headline: Mideast Peace Talks to Resume, but No Sign Yet That Hamas Will Take Part
abstract: Israel and the United States plan to send envoys next week to negotiations in Qatar, as the related wars in Gaza and Lebanon rage on.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the Middle East crisis here.

headline: Why Is North Korea Deploying Troops to Help Russia? Here’s What to Know.
abstract: The move gives Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, leverage to ask President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for a lot in return.
lead_paragraph: Heads of state rarely send thousands of their soldiers to fight in someone else’s war without expecting something in return.

headline: Why Boeing Workers Rejected a New Contract: Retirement Benefits
abstract: A large majority of more than 33,000 striking union members voted against a contract that included big raises but not the restoration of a frozen pension plan.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, Boeing stopped offering the gold standard of pension plans — one that pays out guaranteed sums to retirees. The loss of the pension still angers many members of the company’s largest union.

headline: Violence Surges in N.Y.C. Juvenile Jails After Influx of Older Teens
abstract: Since the Raise the Age law was passed, the number of older teenagers in juvenile centers has exploded, and workers have faced attacks, the Department of Investigation said.
lead_paragraph: Workers at New York City’s two juvenile detention centers are struggling to control an exploding population of minors charged with serious crimes, an influx that has led to assaults, threats and the discovery of weapons including ceramic blades, razors and scalpels, the Department of Investigation said Thursday.

headline: A Very New York Party for New York Nico
abstract: At Astor Place Hairstylists, an old-school barbershop, small-business owners feted a social media star who spotlights the city’s gritty character.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, Nicolas Heller, a filmmaker and social media creator known as New York Nico, was surrounded by friends and fans at Astor Place Hairstylists, a cash-only, subterranean barbershop in the East Village.

headline: Cheering for the New York Liberty’s Historic Victory
abstract: Why does women’s basketball feel so good?
lead_paragraph: Why does it feel so good to cheer for women’s basketball? It’s a question I asked myself at my first-ever W.N.B.A. game on Sunday night, which also happened to be the Game 5 championship final between the New York Liberty and the Minnesota Lynx. The Liberty clinched the final in a 67-62 nail-biter in overtime, bringing New York City its first basketball championship in 48 years.

headline: Friday Briefing: Stars Rally for Harris
abstract: Plus, an interview with the Taliban’s most fearsome leader.
lead_paragraph: With less than two weeks left before Election Day, Kamala Harris is pulling out big names to drive her supporters to the polls. She’ll hold a rally in Georgia with Barack Obama and Bruce Springsteen in the coming hours. And tomorrow, she’ll share the stage with Beyoncé at a rally in Texas.

headline: Iran Preparing for War With Israel, but Hoping to Avert It
abstract: Tehran has several plans for responding to a threatened retaliatory strike by Israel, depending on its severity, and might also do nothing, insiders say.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates as Israel launches retaliatory strikes against Iran.

headline: Patti McGee, Skateboarding’s First Female Champion, Dies at 79
abstract: She was on the cover of Life magazine and performed for Johnny Carson. She was, her daughter said, “a badass and a goody two-shoes at the same time.”
lead_paragraph: Patti McGee, whose thrill-seeking activities as a teenager included surfing off the coast of San Diego and skateboarding on the city’s streets, and who ultimately became skating’s first female national champion, died on Oct. 16 at her home in Brea, Calif., in northern Orange County. She was 79.

headline: The Menendez Brothers May Soon Be Free: The True Crime Boom and Changing Attitudes
abstract: A thriving genre built on podcasts and documentaries, coupled with younger generations’ more skeptical worldview, helped revitalize interest in this case and others like it.
lead_paragraph: There’s a montage during the new Netflix documentary “The Menendez Brothers” in which comedians, late-night hosts and other pop culture figures of the 1990s mock Lyle and Erik Menendez. The brothers had recently delivered testimony at their first murder trial, detailing their accounts of sexual abuse at the hands of their father, Jose Menendez, whom they had gunned down and killed in 1989, alongside their mother, Kitty.

headline: Jack Jones, a Suave, Hit-Making and Enduring Crooner, Dies at 86
abstract: With his smooth voice, he drew crowds to cabarets and music halls for six decades. He also sang the themes for films and TV shows, including “The Love Boat.”
lead_paragraph: Jack Jones, a crooner who beguiled concert fans and stage, screen and television audiences for decades with romantic ballads and gentle jazz tunes that even in large venues often achieved the intimacy of his celebrated nightclub performances, died on Wednesday in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 86.

headline: 7 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Our recommended books this week include histories of corporate mismanagement and misbehavior in the 19th century (“Savings and Trust”) and in the 21st (“Valley So Low”), along with a family memoir of mental illness, a true crime account of forgery in the world of absinthe enthusiasts, and a history of the botanists who preserved an important seed bank in the midst of war and starvation. In fiction, we recommend a new novel by Susan Minot and a story collection by Mark Haddon. Happy reading. — Gregory Cowles

headline: Philip Zimbardo, 91, Whose Stanford Prison Experiment Studied Evil, Dies
abstract: His provocative research made him a popular figure on campus. But his exploration of how good people can turn evil raised ethical questions.
lead_paragraph: Philip G. Zimbardo, a towering figure in social psychology who explored how good people turn evil in the infamous Stanford Prison Experiment, which devolved into chaos after college students acting as guards started abusing other students acting as prisoners, died on Oct. 14 at his home in San Francisco. He was 91.

headline: As Trump Campaigns, This Group Is Planning His Presidency
abstract: Also, the Los Angeles D.A. called for the Menendez Brothers to be resentenced. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump traveled to the Southwest this evening for campaign rallies in the battleground states of Arizona and Nevada. He appeared earlier on a conservative radio show, saying that if elected it would take him only “two seconds” to fire the special counsel Jack Smith, who twice indicted the former president.

headline: As Election Day Nears, Democrats Test Just How Powerful Abortion Really Is
abstract: They hope the issue helps their candidates. But some voters may support Republican candidates as well as abortion-rights ballot measures.
lead_paragraph: With Election Day closing in, there are signs that a small but crucial segment of voters may back both abortion rights and Republican candidates, a dynamic that could hurt Vice President Kamala Harris in swing states and other Democratic candidates in pivotal races.

headline: Aunt of 4-Year-Old Who Starved to Death Is Suing Child-Welfare Agency
abstract: Jahmeik Modlin’s parents have been charged with manslaughter in his death. His aunt’s suit accuses the city of failing to monitor his safety.
lead_paragraph: The aunt of a 4-year-old boy who starved to death in his parents’ Harlem apartment is suing the city’s child-welfare agency, her lawyers said on Thursday. The suit charges that the agency was on notice that children in the family were being underfed and that it negligently failed to prevent the boy’s death.

headline: Companies to Pay $101.9 Million to Settle Baltimore Bridge Collapse Lawsuit
abstract: The suit by the Justice Department was filed last month and laid out what investigators had learned about the ship’s short and catastrophic journey.
lead_paragraph: The owner and the operator of the container ship that slammed into the Francis Scott Key Bridge last March, killing six workers and shutting down the Port of Baltimore for weeks, agreed on Thursday to pay more than $100 million to settle a civil claim brought by the U.S. Justice Department.

headline: What ‘Chicken Shop Date’ Reminds Us About Flirting
abstract: Amelia Dimoldenberg and Andrew Garfield’s long-running flirtationship highlights what’s missing from dating (and dating content) today.
lead_paragraph: It all began in November 2022, when the actor Andrew Garfield approached Amelia Dimoldenberg at British GQ’s Men of the Year party and uttered four words before she had a chance to speak: “I think you’re great.”

headline: Former Prep School Baseball Coach Charged With Sex Crimes Against Minors
abstract: Nicolas Morton, who worked for the Packer Collegiate Institute in Brooklyn, made boys run to exhaustion unless they exposed themselves to him, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A former admissions officer and baseball coach at the Packer Collegiate Institute, a Brooklyn Heights private school, was charged on Thursday in what prosecutors said was the sexual abuse of several children who played on his teams.

headline: Trump Seeks to Challenge Jack Smith’s Appointment in Election Case
abstract: The former president’s request to file a new motion contesting how the special counsel got his job came on the same day he vowed to fire him if re-elected.
lead_paragraph: On the same day former President Donald J. Trump vowed that if elected he would immediately fire Jack Smith, his lawyers sought to move ahead with an effort to have the federal election interference case against Mr. Trump dismissed on the grounds that Mr. Smith had been illegally appointed to his job as special counsel.

headline: How Trump Could Bankrupt Social Security
abstract: Retirement benefits for millions of Americans are on the line.
lead_paragraph: Remember when George W. Bush tried to privatize Social Security? I was very involved in that debate, and one thing I learned was that well-off Americans, who typically have substantial sums stowed away in their 401(k)s and have other assets besides, often have little sense of just how important Social Security is to their less affluent fellow citizens. Benefits from the program make up more than half of many retirees’ incomes; a substantial number have almost nothing else to live on.

headline: The Election Is Happening Too Soon
abstract: When we all think we’re right, we stay perennially stuck in place.
lead_paragraph: I had hoped this election would be a moment of national renewal. I had hoped that the Democrats could decisively defeat MAGA populism and send us down a new national path.

headline: Biden to Apologize for Indian Boarding Schools Where Hundreds of Children Died
abstract: President Biden’s trip to the battleground state of Arizona will be the first time an American president has apologized for the abuses that happened at the schools over a period of 150 years.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Friday will formally apologize for the role of the federal government in running boarding schools where thousands of Native American children faced abuse, neglect and the erasure of their tribal identities.

headline: Army Sergeant’s Body Was Found in a Dumpster at a Missouri Base
abstract: A person of interest was taken into custody after Sgt. Sarah Roque, 23, was found dead at Fort Leonard Wood, according to Army officials.
lead_paragraph: The body of a 23-year-old Army sergeant was found in a dumpster at Fort Leonard Wood in Missouri this week, and a person of interest has been taken into custody, Army officials said Thursday.

headline: Judge Blocks Luxury Fashion Deal, Citing Risk of Higher Handbag Prices
abstract: The F.T.C. had sued to halt the merger of Tapestry, the parent of Coach and Kate Spade, and Capri, the owner of Versace and Michael Kors.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge moved on Thursday to block a merger of the fashion companies that own the Coach, Kate Spade, Michael Kors and Versace brands, ruling that the tie-up would “substantially lessen competition” among makers of accessible luxury handbags.

headline: Will It All Come Down to Michigan?
abstract: Operatives from both parties see the race as deadlocked, and both insist they have a clearer path.
lead_paragraph: Last month, I laid out four swing states that — at that time — seemed most likely to help you understand the election: Georgia, North Carolina, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin. They are all still very important. But, in a twist that was probably inevitable in a close and volatile election, another state may be emerging as do-or-die territory for Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: Harris Campaign Uses John Kelly’s Words in Stark New Ads
abstract: The ads are the latest attempt by Kamala Harris’s campaign to turn the 2024 race into a referendum on Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign is turning a recording of Donald J. Trump’s former White House chief of staff John F. Kelly, in which he describes the former president as meeting “the general definition of fascist,” into two stark new ads.

headline: Miriam Adelson Goes Searching for More Trump Donors
abstract: After financing a super PAC with $100 million of her own money, she is asking other billionaires to help keep the group funded through Election Day.
lead_paragraph: Miriam Adelson has been spending the final few weeks of the general election campaign doing something that might be unexpected for one of the richest people in the world: asking other people for money.

headline: Two Brothers Charged With Assaulting Officers in Jan. 6 Riot
abstract: Roger and Reynold Voisine, from upstate New York, used weapons that included a pipe, a police shield and a table leg studded with nails, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: Two brothers from upstate New York were arrested Thursday on charges of attacking law enforcement agents at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and of participating in the violent mob that attempted to overturn the 2020 presidential election.

headline: At a Town Hall in Detroit, Trump Asks Vance: ‘How Brilliant Is Donald Trump?’
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump phoned in during a televised town hall with voters, surprising his running mate.
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance of Ohio was about two-thirds of the way through a televised town hall — taking questions from voters in downtown Detroit on Thursday — when he received an unexpected cold call from his boss.

headline: No Corrections: Oct. 25, 2025
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Friday, Oct. 25, 2025.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Obama Rallies With Harris for First Time, to the Chords of Bruce Springsteen
abstract: At a star-filled rally in Georgia that also featured Tyler Perry and Samuel L. Jackson, the former president tried to give a jolt of energy to the vice president often seen as a successor.
lead_paragraph: Former President Barack Obama sought to transfer the energy of his political movement to Vice President Kamala Harris at a rally on Thursday night outside Atlanta — their first joint appearance of the campaign — as he tried to help propel her over the finish line.

headline: An Act of Congress
abstract: Alex Murphy makes his New York Times Crossword debut. Here are your smelling salts.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Tyler Perry Blasts Trump in Passionate Speech at Harris’s Atlanta Rally
abstract: The actor and filmmaker, who built his career in the Georgia capital, said he had realized that in the former president’s America, “there is no dream that looks like me.”
lead_paragraph: In underlining his support for Vice President Kamala Harris at a rally in Atlanta on Thursday night, the filmmaker and entertainment mogul Tyler Perry assailed former President Donald J. Trump in direct and somber terms.

headline: Kit Connor and Rachel Zegler Make Puppy Love in the Puppy Pile
abstract: The Broadway revival of “Romeo + Juliet” plays to the TikTok crowd. But maybe that’s a good thing.
lead_paragraph: Who can forget the classic first line of “Romeo and Juliet”: “How y’all doin’ today?”

headline: Maggie Haberman on What an Unleashed Trump Might Do
abstract: The New York Times political correspondent discusses Donald Trump’s past, present and possible future.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times political correspondent discusses Donald Trump’s past, present and possible future.

headline: A Love for Service and Each Other
abstract: Ana Lejava and Nickolas Calbos had dates all over the world. “I was acting out of my gut, not out of my brain,” Ms. Levaja said.
lead_paragraph: For their fourth date, in January 2019, Ana Lejava booked a commercial flight out of New York City; Nickolas Paul Calbos boarded a train from Germany. They met in Vienna and spent 24 hours together. At that early stage of the relationship, their trip was more exploratory than romantic: Did their connection justify this jet-setting?

headline: No More ‘Single Girl’ Posts for This Comedic Writer
abstract: Sara Runnels was known for her humorous stories and social media shares about the single life, but her dating status quickly changed after meeting Adam Zack.
lead_paragraph: The day after her second date with Adam Ryan Zack, on Dec. 20, 2022, Sara Katherine Runnels, a comedic writer, took to Twitter, writing, “My date last night bought a New Yorker subscription in the middle of our date so he could read all my articles later. Is this my husband now?”

headline: Sometimes, It’s Not You, or the Math
abstract: In this 2011 essay, a 39-year-old woman who hasn’t had a boyfriend in eight years is asked by a date, “What’s wrong with you?”
lead_paragraph: In celebration of Modern Love’s 20th anniversary this month, we published a special package of articles about the column’s history and impact. To learn about the origin of Modern Love, read about seven ways to love better, see how the longtime illustrator creates his images, and much more, go to nytimes.com/modernlove. In this space, as each week’s Modern Love column, we are republishing four “classic” essays from earlier years that especially moved us.

headline: They Were Just What They Needed
abstract: Jonathan Otcasek and Erin Kim connected 10 years ago over a gravesite. They’ve had the kind of relationship even their parents admire since.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Raven Otcasek and Erin Minji Kim met at the center of the world. It was September 2014, their junior semester of college while studying abroad in London, and they were on a class outing to Greenwich, England — a town on London’s outskirts where the Prime Meridian, point 0.0 in the longitudinal system, passes through.

headline: Malaria Is Surging in Ethiopia, Reversing a Decade of Progress Against the Disease
abstract: Climate change, civil conflict and growing resistance to insecticides and treatments are all contributing to an alarming spread of cases.
lead_paragraph: Malaria infection rates are soaring in Ethiopia, where a combination of armed conflict, climate change and mosquitoes’ growing resistance to drugs and insecticides has accelerated the spread of a disease the country once thought it was bringing under control.

headline: Quote of the Day: His Mission: To Restore Wilderness of Ireland
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, October 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Ireland really coasts on its reputation as the Emerald Isle.”

headline: In a Region of Majestic Beauty, Sunnis and Shiites Wage Bloody War
abstract: In Kurram, near the Afghan border, Pakistan has been helpless to stop the latest outbreaks of a sectarian conflict that goes back decades.
lead_paragraph: The deafening roar of rocket launchers and mortar explosions shattered the tranquillity of Kurram, a Pakistani district of majestic peaks, ancient maple forests and fertile fields bordering Afghanistan. People huddled in makeshift bunkers, exchanging desperate volleys as their villages became battlegrounds.

headline: Friday Briefing: Stars Rally for Harris
abstract: Plus, an interview with the Taliban’s most fearsome leader.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris held a rally with former President Barack Obama and Bruce Springsteen in Atlanta yesterday.

headline: Harris, Trump and Allies Spend Over a Half-Billion Dollars in 16 Days
abstract: Donald Trump has now raised $1 billion since announcing his run for president. And he has Elon Musk’s $119 million. But Kamala Harris has a huge cash advantage.
lead_paragraph: Candidates, empty your bank accounts.

headline: At Las Vegas Rally, Trump Grumbles About Obama’s Nobel Prize
abstract: With 12 days until Election Day, former President Donald J. Trump campaigned in Nevada and Arizona and sharpened his attacks on Vice President Kamala Harris about immigration.
lead_paragraph: On a night when Barack Obama joined Kamala Harris onstage at a star-studded rally in Georgia, Donald J. Trump was smarting on the other side of the country — asking why Mr. Obama had been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize and not him.

headline: Jimmy Fallon Rallies for Queen Bey
abstract: The “Tonight Show” host was excited about Beyoncé’s plans to appear with the vice president: “What a night — the most powerful woman in the world and Kamala Harris.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: exceedingly
abstract: This word has appeared in 293 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word exceedingly has appeared in 293 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 18 in “Study Reveals Bird-Migration Mystery” by Emily Anthes:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Twenty Election Cycles and Counting
abstract: Carl Hulse has covered congressional campaigns for four decades. Much has changed, but one thing remains constant: Journalists must be ready for the unexpected.
lead_paragraph: The first Senate race I covered was in 1986 for newspapers in Florida owned by The New York Times Company.

headline: Long Nose
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Kamala Harris Needs Young Voters. Her Envoy: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.
abstract: The New York congresswoman’s foray onto the presidential campaign trail may be a turning point for her and her party.
lead_paragraph: She leaped into office six years ago as a 29-year-old outsider intent on upending the Democratic establishment, and has used her platform to challenge party leaders at nearly every turn.

headline: New York’s 6 Pivotal House Races: Here’s What to Know
abstract: Six House seats, including five held by Republicans, may be the key in determining which party will control the chamber for the next two years.
lead_paragraph: New York may not be a presidential swing state. But there is perhaps no more important battleground in this year’s race for the House of Representatives than the Empire State.

headline: What to Know About New York’s Six Ballot Measures
abstract: The first, Proposition 1, is designed to enshrine abortion rights in the state Constitution. The rest would make changes to New York City’s governing charter.
lead_paragraph: Millions of people in New York will make their voices heard this election cycle, casting their votes for the presidency, the Senate, the State Legislature, and in a number of key congressional races that will help determine which party controls the House.

headline: Top Law Firms Shrink From the Heat of the Mideast Conflict
abstract: When a Columbia professor needed a lawyer because of her comments about the actions of former Israeli soldiers on campus, tensions over the Israel-Hamas war got in the way.
lead_paragraph: Late in January, Katherine Franke, a prominent Columbia Law School professor and active supporter of the Palestinian cause, appeared on television to talk about a rally demanding divestment from Israel that had taken place on the steps of Low Library a few days before. What marked this protest from the many others erupting on campuses around the country last winter was the release of a putrid smelling vapor into the crowd by a group of counterprotesters. It soon came out that at least one of them was a student and former member of the Israel Defense Forces. The university suspended him.

headline: Teenager Charged With Murder of 5 Relatives in Washington State
abstract: Prosecutors said a 15-year-old killed his parents and three siblings, then tried to convince the authorities his brother was responsible.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in Washington State charged a 15-year-old boy on Thursday with the murder of his parents and three siblings this week near Seattle.

headline: Israeli Strike Kills 3 Journalists in Southern Lebanon
abstract: The three worked for Lebanese news organizations, their employers said. Lebanon’s health ministry said they had been staying in a residence housing journalists.
lead_paragraph: Three staff members of Lebanese news organizations were killed in an Israeli airstrike early Friday in southern Lebanon, according to the country’s health ministry, the latest in a growing number of deaths among media workers covering Israel’s offensives in Lebanon and Gaza.

headline: Trump Is Telling Us What He Would Do. Believe Him.
abstract: The former president’s most disturbing statements are not bluster. They are a road map to what he will do if elected again.
lead_paragraph: The former president’s most disturbing statements are not bluster. They are a road map to what he will do if elected again.

headline: A Pivotal Election for Georgia, Explained
abstract: A parliamentary vote could decide whether the Caucasus nation will be oriented to the West or East for years to come. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: Georgia, a strategically important Caucasus country, will hold a parliamentary election on Saturday that could determine the country’s geopolitical orientation for years to come as it is pulled between Russia, China and the West.

headline: Toplines: Late October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters Nationwide
abstract: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll of 2,516 registered voters conducted from Oct. 20 to 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll of 2,516 registered voters conducted from Oct. 20 to 23, 2024.

headline: Cross-Tabs: Late October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of the Likely Electorate
abstract: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll of 2,516 likely voters conducted from Oct. 20 to 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll of 2,516 likely voters conducted from Oct. 20 to 23, 2024.

headline: For This Turkish Writer, the Flaws of Language Were Its Greatest Asset
abstract: Oguz Atay stretched the possibilities of fiction and critiqued his changing nation with playful, surreal stories.
lead_paragraph: Kafka warned us against the treachery of language, its many flavors of betrayal. In a 1914 letter, he cautioned his sister Ottla not to accept anything he wrote or said at face value: “I write differently from what I speak, I speak differently from what I think, I think differently from the way I ought to think, and so it all proceeds into deepest darkness.”

headline: The Other War for These Gazans Is Against Cancer
abstract: The small number of cancer patients from Gaza who are receiving care in Jordan’s capital, Amman, bear burdens beyond those of illness — deep feelings of guilt, along with fear and homesickness.
lead_paragraph: The skies were quiet and Mohammed Ashour was finally safe, but for days after leaving Gaza the 13-year-old was unable to sleep.

headline: For Sale: Hundreds of Abandoned Churches. Great Prices. Need Work.
abstract: As church congregations across the United States wither and disappear, the buildings they leave behind are becoming private homes.
lead_paragraph: When Louis Cahill was growing up in southern Virginia, a neighbor bought an old Catholic chapel and turned it into a home, which fascinated him. So in 2022, when he and his wife Kathy were looking toward retirement, they decided to do the same. They were enamored with the soaring ceilings and massive timber beams found in houses of worship across the South.

headline: Can an Avatar Display Human Emotion? This Documentary Believes So.
abstract: “The Remarkable Life of Ibelin” tells a moving narrative by visually recreating a dying player’s relationships within World of Warcraft.
lead_paragraph: One year and about 30 test screenings into his experimental documentary, Benjamin Ree realized his project was in crisis.

headline: Dispatches From the Middle East, With Cameos by Osama bin Laden
abstract: In “Night of Power,” Robert Fisk’s posthumous war stories focus on the victims and perpetrators in conflicts across the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Robert Fisk was the best-known British war correspondent of his generation, thanks in part to sheer persistence. He spent more than four decades running from one Middle Eastern death zone to the next, cataloging the horrors he saw in gruesome detail and railing against the West’s complicity in them. He was something of a cult figure on the British left, where his anti-imperial and anti-Zionist convictions were widely shared.

headline: As Georgia Decides Its Future, Artists Are Worried About Theirs
abstract: Two new laws, and a looming election, in the former Soviet republic of Georgia have artists reconsidering their livelihoods and even whether they can stay in the country.
lead_paragraph: On a sultry late summer night, in a horseshoe-shaped club cantilevered over the Mtkvari River that cuts Georgia’s capital, Tbilisi, in two, the artist and drag performer Andro Dadiani was belting out the last bars of his aria act a cappella.

headline: Two Photographers with an Eye for the Spiritual Meet in an Ohio Museum
abstract: Rotimi Fani-Kayode and Ming Smith grew up a world apart, but their images speak much the same language. This fall, their works collide in Columbus.
lead_paragraph: There’s a nostalgic game that, at times, can be tempting to play. It involves imagining the creative friendships that could have existed if history had gone differently.

headline: Conceptual Artist Plays True Detective
abstract: Sophie Calle’s first major North American career survey, opening at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, frames the acclaimed French artist as the original oversharer.
lead_paragraph: In “The Plastic Surgery,” a vignette from Sophie Calle’s ongoing “True Stories” series, the conceptual artist paired a framed photograph of her face in profile with a brief story divulging how her grandparents had strongly encouraged her to get a nose job when she was 14 — reassuring her that she could change her mind up to the last minute.

headline: The Guardrails Failed. Now It’s Down to Us.
abstract: Trump’s great accomplishment is to spread the dangerous lie that our problems can be blamed on the weakest and most vulnerable in our midst.
lead_paragraph: Mark Milley is not the only general to call Donald Trump a fascist.

headline: As A.I. Becomes Harder to Detect, Photography Is Having a Renaissance
abstract: Despite — or, perhaps, because of — the rise in artificially made images, photography is suddenly in the spotlight, in galleries in New York and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Planning to visit Pace Gallery soon? Be prepared for a tight squeeze.

headline: The Secret Ingredient Every Chili Needs Is Probably in Your Pantry
abstract: You can make an award-winning pot for Halloween parties, tailgates and dinner any night.
lead_paragraph: Tana Harter knows what she wants in her chili: creamy heartiness, a glisten and glow, melt-in-your-mouth meat and consistent spiciness. But half an hour before judging began at the 2018 International Chili Society World Championship Chili Cook-Off in St. Louis, her pot wasn’t meeting her personal criteria. She stirred in the one ingredient she knew would fix it.

headline: A Detroit Museum Focuses on the Islamic Dining Experience
abstract: An exhibition at the Detroit Institute of Arts tries to connect with the area’s large, vibrant Arab American community through a show about food.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit Institute of Arts has put on its share of blockbuster exhibitions, highlighting painters like Van Gogh, Rembrandt and its showpiece, the murals depicting the auto industry completed by the Mexican artist Diego Rivera in 1933.

headline: Poetry and a Lone Stag Help an Isolated Deaf Girl Connect
abstract: The young language-deprived protagonist of Ann Clare LeZotte’s novel “Deer Run Home” tells her own story, in verse.
lead_paragraph: Life is spiraling out of control for 12-year-old Effie, the protagonist of Ann Clare LeZotte’s “Deer Run Home.”

headline: Gay People Are Hunted Down and Beaten in a Country Once a Refuge
abstract: Ivory Coast, long considered one of West Africa’s most tolerant societies, has recently seen a string of assaults on L.G.B.T.Q. people after several social media influencers exhorted their followers to “hunt” gay men.
lead_paragraph: Ivory Coast had long been a haven for L.G.B.T.Q. people, even as they faced discrimination or persecution elsewhere in West Africa. But over the past two months, dozens of assaults, beatings and intimidation online and in the streets have shaken that sense of safety.

headline: A 185-Year-Old Building in the South Street Seaport Is Listed for $14.95 Million
abstract: The owners of the wine store Pasanella & Son, Vintners, are selling their five-story building on South Street, which includes the store, a loft and six rental apartments.
lead_paragraph: The 1839 Greek Revival building at 115 South Street is on the market for $14.95 million. The five-story property totals 13,119 square feet and comprises a full-floor penthouse loft, six half-floor rental apartments, and a commercial space on the ground floor, where the building’s owners, Marco Pasanella and Rebecca Robertson, run their celebrated wine store, Pasanella & Son, Vintners. Jim St. André of Compass is the broker.

headline: The Art World Explores Concrete Ways to Fight Climate Change
abstract: Museums, galleries and other art institutions are looking for measures to reduce their environmental footprints.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to the Hammer Museum’s show “Breath(e) Toward Climate and Social Justice” will be greeted by powerful works portraying the widespread impact of ecological degradation: photos of citizens in Flint, Mich., waiting for clean water, a painting of a fish created out of spilled crude oil and contaminated sediment.

headline: The Army of Election Officials Ready to Reject the Vote
abstract: A movement driven by disinformation about Trump’s 2020 defeat has taken over many of the boards that certify elections. It could cause chaos in the weeks ahead.
lead_paragraph: When Clara Andriola took her seat at the Washoe County, Nev., commission meeting room on July 9, she looked out at a sea of angry faces. The commission is Washoe’s main legislative body, and Andriola, a longtime local business executive, was appointed to fill a vacancy on the five-person board last year. She had just won a Republican primary that would almost certainly allow her to keep that seat in the November general election. The commission was required by law to certify elections at every level, from local primary to presidential election. What came next should have been a simple administrative procedure.

headline: ‘Dahomey’: A Daring Meditation on the Painful Legacy of Looted Artifacts
abstract: Mati Diop examines the fate of 26 treasures — sometimes from their point of view — looted from Benin in 1892.
lead_paragraph: There are many voices in Mati Diop’s new documentary, “Dahomey” (in theaters), and one of them belongs to Artifact No. 26. “I lost myself in my dreams, becoming one with these walls, cut off from the land of my birth as if I was dead,” it says in French, its timbre tweaked to contain both a low rumbling bass and a higher, more feminine sound. “Today, it’s me they have chosen, like their finest and most legitimate victim.”

headline: A Poem Hitches a Ride on a Rocket, to Infinity and Beyond
abstract: NASA and the U.S. Poet Laureate may not be obvious collaborators, but a Jupiter-bound mission helped them find common ground.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 14, at six minutes past noon, a group of people stood on a balcony overlooking a launchpad at Kennedy Space Center in Merritt Island, Fla. and watched Europa Clipper, the largest interplanetary craft NASA has ever built, blast off into the cosmos.

headline: The Many Faces of Rammellzee
abstract: How the multi-hyphenate, biracial artist from Far Rockaway influenced 1980s graffiti culture and the downtown New York art scene.
lead_paragraph: In the mid-1970s, a half-Black, half-Italian teenager from the projects in the Far Rockaway neighborhood of Queens started hitting the A train with a spray can. At 18, he legally changed his name to Rammellzee, and since then no conversation about graffiti culture or the late-20th-century New York art scene has been complete without mentioning his influence.

headline: New Covid Tests Are Here. They Test for Flu, Too.
abstract: So when and how should you use them?
lead_paragraph: Yet again this winter, millions of Americans will wonder if a nagging cough or body aches is a sign they’re coming down with Covid or the flu. This time, they’ll have an expanded array of tools to get an answer without leaving the house.

headline: Violence and Threats: How a Campaign of Fear Has Shaken Canada’s Sikhs
abstract: Tightly knit communities in Ontario and British Columbia have been rocked by violent events in the past 18 months. Now the authorities say the Indian government was behind them.
lead_paragraph: On a warm July night two years ago, Moninder Singh received a chilling message from special federal agents who showed up at his house in British Columbia: You are being formally warned that there is an imminent threat to your life. Avoid public spaces. Enhance security at home.

headline: $700,000 Homes in Ontario, Canada
abstract: A lakefront house in Muskoka, a cottage overlooking Beveridge Bay, and a log home on 50 acres in Parry Sound District.
lead_paragraph: Set 30 feet from the shore of Tooke Lake, in the regional district of Muskoka, this three-bedroom, one-bath house sits on a granite outcropping that dates to prehistoric times.

headline: It’s a Study. No, It’s a Guest Room.
abstract: A couple wanted a space to read and relax, but occasionally they had an overnight guest. Here’s how they made it work.
lead_paragraph: Designing a guest room can present a conundrum: It’s nice to have a place to host overnight visitors, but a dedicated room uses precious space that sits empty most of the time. That’s why turning a guest room into a space that is used year-round — as a study, library, home office or den — can be so appealing.

headline: There’s a Very Good Reason College Students Don’t Read Anymore
abstract: The world is sending a message about its priorities, and they do not appear to include “Moby-Dick.”
lead_paragraph: In 2011, I taught a college class on the meaning and value of work. It was a general-education class, the sort that students say they have to “get out of the way” before they move on to their major courses. Few of the students were avid readers, and many held jobs that constrained their study time.

headline: U.S. Bond Market Braces for the ‘Trump Trade’ of Large Tariffs and Deficits
abstract: As investors have focused on the potential fiscal and economic impact of the Republican candidate’s proposals, yields on Treasury debt have risen.
lead_paragraph: The $28 trillion Treasury market is arguably the most foundational financial market in the world. It’s where the U.S. government auctions its debt to investors who buy and trade that debt, influencing borrowing costs across the globe.

headline: From a Novelist, a Chilling True Fable of Anorexia
abstract: The English writer Sarah Moss brings her trademark subtlety and sense of the ominous to her harrowing memoir.
lead_paragraph: “You won’t think your way out of this, your therapist says,” Sarah Moss writes toward the end of her powerfully original and unsettling memoir about anorexia. “You have to act, and it will be difficult and uncomfortable and you will have to do it consistently.”

headline: Uruguay’s 2024 Election: What to Know
abstract: Crime, child poverty and an aging population are top issues as voters in one of Latin America’s most stable democracies head to the polls on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The small South American nation of Uruguay will hold elections on Sunday to choose a new president at a time when it is a model of political and economic stability in Latin America.

headline: Betting Markets Favor Trump. But Their Record of Accuracy Is Mixed.
abstract: Proponents believe that having real money on the line, and a large crowd of investors, encourages a more accurate election forecast than polling data can provide.
lead_paragraph: Organizations that track election polls, including The New York Times, currently show Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump in a dead heat. Election forecasters like FiveThirtyEight, which consider the polls and other data to calculate the candidates’ odds of victory, also see the race as essentially tied.

headline: Maggie Haberman on What an Unleashed Trump Might Do
abstract: The New York Times political correspondent discusses Donald Trump’s past, present and possible future.
lead_paragraph: This week, I released an audio essay on Donald Trump. And in a way, it was about Donald Trump’s mind and the peculiar ways in which it works, the degree to which he moves through the world without inhibition and the ways in which that is potentially worsening as he gets older. But more than that, it was about the relationship between Trump and the people and institutions that surround him.

headline: How the Storm Shook Up North Carolina’s Election
abstract: Astead W. Herndon, a national reporter for The New York Times and the host of the politics podcast “The Run-Up,” traveled to North Carolina to see how Hurricane Helene and the misinformation in its wake have reshaped the election landscape in this crucial battleground state.
lead_paragraph: Astead W. Herndon, a national reporter for The New York Times and the host of the politics podcast “The Run-Up,” traveled to North Carolina to see how Hurricane Helene and the misinformation in its wake have reshaped the election landscape in this crucial battleground state.

headline: Beyond Trump vs. Harris: These Races Will Shape Our Future
abstract: About those other Election Day matchups …
lead_paragraph: There’s a whole world of 2024 elections that don’t involve Donald Trump or Kamala Harris. These races will be key to determining America’s future. As we inch closer to Election Day, the “Matter of Opinion” hosts zoom in on the congressional races that reveal something deeper — and stranger — about our politics.

headline: Biden Has a Crucial Decision to Make on Ukraine
abstract: If he gives Ukraine the capability of striking deep into Russian territory, that decision would be hard for a new president to undo.
lead_paragraph: The kernel of the long-awaited “victory plan” for Ukraine that President Volodymyr Zelensky introduced this fall goes something like this: If you give me what I’ve been asking for — membership in NATO and permission to fire Western missiles deep into Russian territory — I could end the war by next year.

headline: Pulling Together a Last-Minute Halloween Costume?
abstract: You could take a lesson from Disney adults and others who turn to their own closets when they want to dress up.
lead_paragraph: Halloween is creeping closer. But a few days are more than enough for those with little time, energy or funds to pull together a costume of quality with panache. Think of the last-minute scramble as an opportunity to reimagine the items already stashed in your closet.

headline: 7 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: This trilogy wraps up with a final installment directed by Kelly Marcel in which Eddie and the alien parasite he shares a body with, Venom (both played by Tom Hardy), must work together against common enemies.

headline: Don Jr. Is Making Plans
abstract: Of all the figures who surround Donald Trump, his eldest son may offer the best window into the future of the MAGA movement.
lead_paragraph: In 2022, shortly before the midterm elections and the unofficial start of the 2024 presidential campaign, the conservative activist Christopher Rufo traveled to Maine to appear on Tucker Carlson’s Fox Nation streaming talk show. For the previous two years, he was a frequent guest of Mr. Carlson’s. He usually did his hits — on the evils of critical race theory, or the plague of “trans indoctrination” — from his home outside Seattle. This time, he was excited to meet Mr. Carlson in person. When Mr. Rufo arrived at the Fox host’s rustic studio, after a cross-country flight and a 90-minute drive from the Portland airport, he discovered someone else in the Maine backwoods: Donald Trump Jr.

headline: The Day the Music Stopped: A Virtuoso Cellist’s Journey Back From Long Covid
abstract: Joshua Roman was a musical prodigy at the top of his game. Then came a debilitating chronic illness.
lead_paragraph: Joshua Roman used to be able to play cello for 10 hours a day without skipping a beat. But months after contracting Covid-19 in 2021, debilitating brain fog and extreme fatigue had him questioning whether he would ever play again.

headline: The Crypto Website Where the Election Odds Swing in Trump’s Favor
abstract: Donald Trump, Elon Musk and CNN have cited election predictions from Polymarket, a betting site where crypto enthusiasts have wagered more than $100 million on who will win the presidency.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump posted a colorful graphic on social media this week, suggesting that he was headed for victory in the presidential election.

headline: For This Headless Horseman, October Is the Busiest Month
abstract: Hugh Francis plays the famous role from the Washington Irving story in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y., where the tale is set.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll meet a man who will saddle up to play the headless horseman of Sleepy Hollow this weekend in the very place where the famous short story was set. We’ll also find out why violence has surged in New York City’s juvenile jails.

headline: ‘Somebody Somewhere’ Is Going Out on a Bittersweet Note
abstract: Ahead of the final season, the creators discuss Midwestern humor, queer communities of faith and why they made a show “about people who aren’t very equipped to talk about their feelings.”
lead_paragraph: Hannah Bos and Paul Thureen met at Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., where they bonded over being displaced Midwesterners and began writing plays together. A few years later, in early-2000s Manhattan, they met a bawdy, big-voiced cabaret performer named Bridget Everett.

headline: Harris and Trump Deadlocked to the End, Final Times/Siena National Poll Finds
abstract: The electorate has rarely seemed so evenly divided. The latest New York Times/Siena College poll found Harris and Trump tied 48 to 48.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris and Donald J. Trump are locked in a dead heat for the popular vote, 48 percent to 48 percent, the final national poll by The New York Times and Siena College has found, as Ms. Harris struggles for an edge over Mr. Trump with an electorate that seems impossibly and immovably divided.

headline: ‘Conclave’: A Fly on the Wall Inside the Secret Process to Elect a Pope
abstract: A new drama by Edward Berger draws the audience inside this largely hidden tradition. How accurate is it?
lead_paragraph: When a pope dies, cardinals younger than 80 gather at the Vatican to elect his successor in what is known as a conclave. Recent papal elections have offered glimpses of this highly secretive process by allowing television cameras to capture some of the pomp and prayers leading up to the voting.

headline: What to Know About the Looming Election Certification Crisis
abstract: An investigation in four battleground states found that Republicans have taken control of election boards with the aim of challenging and overturning outcomes that don’t go their way.
lead_paragraph: The false narrative of a stolen election that inspired hundreds of Americans to storm the U.S. Capitol in 2021 is now fueling a far more sophisticated movement, one that involves local and state election boards across the country.

headline: Is Analog Better Than Digital Tech?
abstract: Young people are flocking to photo booths to experience a more physical kind of media. What old technology do you think is cool?
lead_paragraph: Vinyl records. CDs. Disposable cameras.

headline: Republicans Assumed a Nebraska Senate Seat Was Safe. Then This Candidate Came Along.
abstract: Nebraska’s Senate race is far closer than anyone predicted.
lead_paragraph: The first person I met at a Monday night meet-and-greet for Dan Osborn, the independent Nebraska Senate candidate, was a Donald Trump-voting Republican named Joe Hallett. He’d worked, alongside his wife, Sherri, with Osborn at Omaha’s Kellogg plant. Explaining Osborn’s appeal, Joe said, “He’s not a millionaire or anything like that.” Sherri added: “He works hard. We did the same thing.”

headline: Can the Row Keep Its Cool?
abstract: The luxury brand has maintained its allure through an air of exclusivity. Associations with discount chains and reality stars have broadened its reach.
lead_paragraph: What about the Row makes its take on a simple sweater that much better than a version by, say, the Gap?

headline: The ‘Greenest Governor’ Fights to Save a Landmark Climate Law
abstract: Environmentalists and one of the world’s biggest oil companies support Washington State’s cap on carbon. But voters are deciding whether to repeal the law amid concerns about energy costs.
lead_paragraph: Long before the League of Conservation Voters embraced him as the “greenest governor” in America, Jay Inslee of Washington had written a book about climate change that called for a clean-energy revolution that would be the equivalent of the Apollo space program in commitment and innovation.

headline: For Sale: A Painting the Monuments Men Rescued From the Nazis
abstract: The portrait by a French court painter is one of three displayed in a photo that came to depict the efforts of a U.S. Army unit that tracked legions of looted art.
lead_paragraph: It appears, memorably, in a snapshot taken in May 1945 of American soldiers on the steps of Neuschwanstein Castle in Bavaria — a painted portrait of a woman in a shimmering gown with porcelain skin and curly silver hair.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the HBO dramedy “Somebody Somewhere.”
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the HBO dramedy “Somebody Somewhere.”

headline: Many Wells in North Carolina Remain Unsafe After Helene’s Deluge
abstract: A third of state residents use private wells, and about four out of 10 wells tested after Hurricane Helene weren’t safe, highlighting the risks of extreme weather for millions of Americans.
lead_paragraph: A third of state residents use private wells, and about four out of 10 wells tested after Hurricane Helene weren’t safe, highlighting the risks of extreme weather for millions of Americans.

headline: 3 Ways to Make Your Commute Actually Enjoyable
abstract: Traffic jams and train delays happen, but they don’t have to ruin your trip.
lead_paragraph: When I take the train to the office, I usually sit in the quiet car, a magical place where no one conducts loud business meetings on Zoom at 7 a.m. I love it, not only because it’s relatively peaceful but because of the skirmishes that break out when someone violates the rules; I find them weirdly exciting.

headline: Why Harris (With Beyoncé in Tow) Is Heading to Solidly Red Texas
abstract: Appearing alongside a pop superstar and talking about abortion rights in a state with a strict ban, the vice president is hoping to deliver viral moments that will resound in faraway battlegrounds.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris might have traveled on Friday to Philadelphia or Milwaukee for the umpteenth time, but motivating tuned-out voters in battleground states required something different.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Oct. 25, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Could Trump Win the Popular Vote but Lose the Electoral College?
abstract: It’s not likely, but it’s not something that can be dismissed either, recent polling suggests.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris and Donald J. Trump are tied at 48 percent in the final New York Times/Siena College national poll of the cycle Friday.

headline: Here are the latest developments.
abstract: Israel launched a series of airstrikes against Iran on Saturday, the Israeli military said, fulfilling its vow to retaliate for an earlier Iranian attack.
lead_paragraph: Israel launched a series of airstrikes against Iran on Saturday, the Israeli military said, fulfilling its vow to retaliate for an earlier Iranian attack.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,225
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Oct. 26, 2024
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 503
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Oct. 26, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: The United States of Pennsylvania
abstract: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump are pouring more money, time and energy into the state than anywhere else.
lead_paragraph: Throughout this election, one state has been at the center of every imaginable path to victory: Pennsylvania. Both candidates have campaigned there relentlessly, and both parties have spent more money there than in any other state.

headline: Poll Shows Dead Heat, and Biden to Apologize for Native American School Abuses
abstract: Plus, a World Series with baseball’s biggest stars.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The Elon-ction + Can A.I. Be Blamed for a Teen’s Suicide?
abstract: The 2024 election has a new main character.
lead_paragraph: Note: This episode contains mentions of suicide.

headline: Autocracies Against Ukraine
abstract: We explain North Korea’s decision to send troops to help Russia.
lead_paragraph: The 3,000 North Korean troops boarded ships in the port city of Wonsan earlier this month and made the journey up the coast to Vladivostok, in Russia’s southeastern corner. From there, they moved to three military training sites in Russia’s Far East, according to U.S. officials. Ukrainian officials say that the troops have since traveled west to fight against Ukraine.

headline: Israel Says 5 Soldiers Were Killed in Southern Lebanon
abstract: As clashes with Hezbollah militants intensified, Israel’s public broadcaster reported that the soldiers had been killed when a rocket struck a building they were in.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said on Friday that five soldiers had been killed amid clashes with Hezbollah fighters in southern Lebanon, the latest indication that the conflict there is escalating despite diplomatic efforts by the Biden administration and others to calm the region.

headline: ‘Conclave’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Edward Berger narrates a sequence from his film, featuring Ralph Fiennes.
lead_paragraph: The director Edward Berger narrates a sequence from his film, featuring Ralph Fiennes.

headline: Watch Ralph Fiennes Deliver a Startling Speech in ‘Conclave’
abstract: The actor plays a cardinal who expresses doubts about his faith and the church in this drama from the director Edward Berger.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: What a Giant Hole Says About a Broad Parking Problem
abstract: There’s a powerful but obscure force operating in New York and elsewhere: the parking minimum.
lead_paragraph: To construct The Dime, a 23-story mixed-use apartment and office building in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the developer Charney Companies first had to dig a spectacular hole. It was about 30 feet deep, which is a perilous proposition in the middle of crowded New York. The neighboring properties included private homes and a 110-year-old bank building, which, it turned out, was resting on a foundation of stacked stones.

headline: The Perfect Red Lipstick Doesn’t Exist … Or Does It?
abstract: The makeup artist and influential YouTuber Lisa Eldridge may have cracked the code.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, Lisa Eldridge, a makeup artist in London best known for working with models and celebrities, woke up the morning after a fashion industry party looking, let’s say, less than Picture Day ready.

headline: Are Elon Musk and Vladimir Putin Talking?
abstract: The billionaire has reportedly been in regular contact with the Russian president, heaping more scrutiny on the power and influence the entrepreneur wields over the U.S. government.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk has ramped up his campaign to get Donald Trump elected in recent weeks, rallying hard in the battleground state of Pennsylvania, and controversially offering $1 million to registered voters who back one of his pet conservative political initiatives.

headline: Tracking Typhoon Kong-rey
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Kong-rey.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Kong-rey.

headline: On ‘The Great Impersonator,’ Halsey Channels Pop’s Past
abstract: The singer and songwriter’s fifth album processes intense pain through a high-concept homage to role models including Stevie Nicks, Bruce Springsteen and Britney Spears.
lead_paragraph: Pop stars start out as pop fans. Like countless other listeners, they find songs that move them, sounds they enjoy and public personas they identify with. Then, if they are talented and determined and lucky enough, they forge their own artistic identities and inspire new fans.

headline: Inside Putin’s Alternate Reality: Warm Embraces and a Veneer of Normalcy
abstract: At a meeting of emerging economies, Vladimir Putin positioned himself as a respected and powerful leader, ignoring the condemnation he receives from the West.
lead_paragraph: For three uninterrupted days this week, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia basked in the attention of other world leaders in the picturesque Russian city of Kazan, along the banks of the Volga River.

headline: Philip Glass’s Musical Impression of an Artist Cut Down by AIDS
abstract: Glass’s Fourth String Quartet, written after the death of the artist Brian Buczak, will be performed at the New York City AIDS Memorial.
lead_paragraph: The night Brian Buczak died, fireworks lit up the sky.

headline: DeSantis Is Going All Out to Defeat Florida’s Abortion Ballot Question
abstract: Gov. Ron DeSantis, who signed a strict abortion ban, has become the face of a campaign against the referendum, which would allow abortions “before viability.”
lead_paragraph: The campaign against the most contentious ballot question in Florida this year — an abortion-rights measure known as Amendment 4 — was relatively quiet until recently. But on its side all along was the most powerful figure in Florida politics: Gov. Ron DeSantis, who has gone all in on leveraging his considerable executive power to try to defeat the proposal.

headline: Fatal Drug Overdoses Are Dropping. Not Everyone Is Spared.
abstract: Federal officials have celebrated a striking drop in drug overdoses across the country. But state-level data shows that Black people are suffering significantly worse outcomes than white people.
lead_paragraph: Overdose deaths across the country decreased by more than 12 percent between May 2023 and May 2024, according to new federal data, a major development in the nation’s efforts to combat the effects of fentanyl. The decrease continued a trend observed in recent months, and was the largest on record, the White House said last week.

headline: Russia Raises Interest Rate to 21 Percent, Its Highest in Decades
abstract: Military spending and recruitment are causing the country’s economy to overheat, leaving regulators in a struggle to rein in rising prices.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s central bank raised the cost of borrowing in the country to its highest level in more than two decades on Friday in an effort to slow inflation that is being fueled by record military spending and recruitment.

headline: C.D.C. Lowers Age to Get Vaccine Against Pneumonia
abstract: Adults 50 and older can now get the shot, as rates of the illness climb.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has lowered the recommended age from 65 to 50 for adults to get vaccinated against a type of bacteria that causes pneumonia and other illnesses.

headline: Safeya Binzagr, 84, a Saudi Artist Celebrated but Long Unseen, Dies
abstract: Despite the gender restrictions of Saudi society, she claimed a place for herself, and other women, in the country’s art scene.
lead_paragraph: The Saudi Arabian artist Safeya Binzagr’s groundbreaking moment came in 1968, when she had her debut exhibit, at a girls’ school in the coastal city of Jeddah. It was the first time a woman had shown her art publicly in the country, and the distinguished group of attendees included Saudi royals, diplomats and intellectuals.

headline: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a time-travel thriller with Dylan O’Brien and a dystopian comedy with Awkwafina and John Cena.
lead_paragraph: Unlike the impossibly complicated German series “Dark,” this puzzle of a film doesn’t require you to draw up a chart to follow the various story lines. Still, there is a Byzantine complexity that requires your full attention to the plot, which revolves around twin events. One is the desperate search that Ellie (Eliza Scanlen, giving strong young Jodie Foster energy) is conducting for her younger stepsister, Anna (Caroline Falk), who has vanished on the titular bayou-like lake. The other is what happens to Paris (Dylan O’Brien), who works dredging the increasingly shallow waters but is really rooting through the muck of his past — he is haunted by a car accident that he survived but killed his mother. Eventually, Anna and Paris realize that some spots on the lake, which sits between Texas and Louisiana, allow people to travel in time when certain conditions are met.

headline: You Don’t Have to Deep-Fry Your Wings
abstract: Use Eric Kim’s new recipe for Atlanta-style oven-fried hot wings, sharp and fiery, salty and crisp.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. You’ll sometimes hear that you can’t make proper chicken wings in the oven, that the only true wing is deep-fried.

headline: That 800-Year-Old Corpse in the Well? Early Biological Warfare.
abstract: Archaeologists in Norway have confirmed that an ancient set of human remains known as the Well Man were intended to make the locals unwell.
lead_paragraph: In the dying days of the 12th century, with Norway in the grip of civil wars, the Baglers, a faction aligned with the archbishop, laid siege to Sverresborg, the castle stronghold of King Sverre Sigurdsson. The monarch was away, so the besiegers pillaged the castle, burned down houses and poisoned the water supply by heaving the corpse of one of the king’s men headfirst down the well and filling the shaft with stones.

headline: Tackling the Trent Alexander-Arnold Conundrum With Facts
abstract: Is the Liverpool star a good defender? It depends on your evidence.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Stewart Lee used to include, as part of his routine, a recollection of a conversation he once shared with a taxi driver.

headline: Susanna Clarke Wrote a Hit Novel Set in a Magical Realm. Then She Disappeared.
abstract: Twenty years after the publication of her fantasy debut, “Jonathan Strange and Mr. Norrell,” Clarke is returning to her richly imagined world of magical England.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, an editor at Bloomsbury took a big chance on a very unusual book.

headline: Election 2024 Polls: Nebraska C.D. 2
abstract: See the latest election polls and polling averages for Nebraska C.D. 2.
lead_paragraph: See the latest election polls and polling averages for Nebraska C.D. 2.

headline: Election 2024 Polls: Maine C.D. 2
abstract: See the latest election polls and polling averages for Maine C.D. 2.
lead_paragraph: See the latest election polls and polling averages for Maine C.D. 2.

headline: Election 2024 Polls: New Hampshire
abstract: See the latest election polls and polling averages for New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: See the latest election polls and polling averages for New Hampshire.

headline: Election 2024 Polls: New York
abstract: See the latest election polls and polling averages for New York.
lead_paragraph: See the latest election polls and polling averages for New York.

headline: Late Lawsuit Could Shape Political Ad Wars in Final Days of Campaign
abstract: House Democrats are suing to stop Republicans from using a legal loophole to bolster their Senate candidates.
lead_paragraph: A legal battle is playing out in Federal District Court in Washington that could determine how much money the Democratic and Republican Parties can pump into advertising in pivotal congressional races in the final week of the 2024 campaign and beyond.

headline: Kelly’s Comments About Trump, Fascism and Hitler
abstract: Responses to the former Trump chief of staff’s comments. Also: Election disinformation; a voter paradox; Harris donations; biodiversity; pandas.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: W.H.O Says It Has Lost Contact With Key Gaza Hospital After Israeli Raid
abstract: The facility, Kamal Adwan Hospital, was one of the last functioning hospitals in the north of the enclave.
lead_paragraph: The director of the World Health Organization said on Friday that it had lost contact with the staff at one of the last functioning hospitals in northern Gaza after health officials in the enclave said Israeli troops had raided the facility. The Israeli military said only that it was “operating in the area” of the hospital.

headline: Cornwall Is England’s Most Magical County. Here’s Where to Go.
abstract: Locals recommend the area’s best pies, wild gardens and coastal footpaths.
