lead_paragraph: Cornwall, England’s craggy southwestern tip is laden with myth and legend: Mermaids are said to have lured villagers into the sea here and piskies, a mischievous tribe of fairies, to skip across the area’s wind-whipped moors. Its real-life history includes Neolithic standing stones and the 13th-century Tintagel Castle, built on the cliff-top site where King Arthur was thought to have been conceived. No wonder the county has provided creative inspiration for hundreds of years. “Artists have been drawn to Cornwall since the time of [J.M.W.] Turner [in the 1800s] because of the natural light and the outstanding beauty of the landscape,” says Anne Barlow, the director of the Tate St. Ives art gallery.

headline: Review: A Standard Rushes Back to the Philharmonic
abstract: The New York Philharmonic has played Tchaikovsky’s “Pathétique” Symphony twice in two years. Rafael Payare led its latest outing.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the New York Philharmonic brought back two standards by Beethoven and Brahms after just a couple of years. And this week, under the conductor Rafael Payare, the orchestra did it again, playing Tchaikovsky’s “Pathétique” Symphony at David Geffen Hall not even two years after its last outing.

headline: Mithai Sheds Its Too-Sweet Reputation
abstract: Younger South Asian cooks are riffing on these classics, turning them into cookies, pies and ice cream, and (gasp!) adding salt.
lead_paragraph: The brightly hued sweets at a mithai shop — Barbie-pink spheres of chum chum, silver-glazed diamonds of kaju katli and golden laddoos glistening with ghee — are the stuff of childhood dreams.

headline: Has Hezbollah Been Weakened by Israel’s Recent Attacks?
abstract: Despite losing leaders and weapons stockpiles, the militant group remains resilient, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Assassinations of top leaders. Intense attacks on infrastructure and weapons supplies. A ground incursion. These moves by Israel have degraded Hezbollah’s capabilities in Lebanon, but so far have failed to block a steady stream of retaliatory strikes.

headline: Why Heat Waves of the Future May Be Even Deadlier Than Feared
abstract: The body’s cooling defenses fail at lower “wet bulb” temperatures than scientists had estimated.
lead_paragraph: Last month was the second-hottest September ever recorded; it came after the world’s warmest summer ever, in a year that is on track to be the most searing in recorded history.

headline: The One Benefit of Harris Winning While Losing the Popular Vote
abstract: It might be a first step toward ending a hugely undemocratic institution.
lead_paragraph: How do you get rid of the Electoral College? The easiest path is for both parties to suffer an Electoral College inversion — to win more popular votes nationwide but lose the election — in proximity to each other. That way everyone experiences the unfairness of the system, providing the necessary momentum for constitutional change.

headline: Washington Post Says It Will Stop Endorsing Presidential Candidates
abstract: The decision was made by Jeff Bezos, the paper’s owner, according to a person with knowledge of the talks. Will Lewis, the chief executive, said the paper was “returning to our roots” of not making endorsements for the office.
lead_paragraph: A debate inside The Washington Post continued for days among its top leaders: Should it make an endorsement in the presidential race, continuing a decades-long tradition?In the end, Jeff Bezos, the paper’s billionaire owner, decided that the answer was no.On Friday, Will Lewis, The Post’s chief executive, told the newsroom that the paper would no longer endorse presidential candidates. His announcement came after the debate and decision by Mr. Bezos, a person with knowledge of the talks said. By that time, the paper’s opinion section had drafted an endorsement of Vice President Kamala Harris, according to four people with knowledge of the process.

headline: Overlooked No More: Margaret E. Knight, Innovator of the Flat-Bottomed Paper Bag
abstract: She came up with a method of automation so that workers would not have to make the bags by hand. Then she fought for credit for her work.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Abercrombie, Pushing a New Image, Confronts Accusations Against Ex-C.E.O.
abstract: Recent sex trafficking charges against Michael Jeffries could entangle the retailer, too, as it tries to close a tumultuous chapter in its history.
lead_paragraph: Fran Horowitz, the chief executive of Abercrombie & Fitch, said it plainly: “We are no longer the company that we used to be.”

headline: New ‘RBG PAC’ Spending $19 Million From Secret Donors to Aid Trump on Abortion
abstract: A Republican super PAC is running ads invoking the name of Ruth Bader Ginsburg to help Donald Trump win voters who favor abortion rights. Her family denounced the effort as “nothing short of appalling.”
lead_paragraph: A new Republican super PAC is invoking the name of the deceased Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg in an audacious attempt to defuse the volatile issue of abortion as a liability for Donald J. Trump.

headline: Review: Porcupines of Plastic and Other Provocations
abstract: The choreographer Nadia Beugré, who brought her “Quartiers Libres Revisited” to New York Live Arts, likes to keep her audience close. And involved.
lead_paragraph: I saw Beyoncé dance at New York Live Arts on Thursday.

headline: Without Another Debate, the Campaign Became a Duel of TV Scenes
abstract: As the candidates raced to claim different corners of the national screen this week, it was “Undercover Boss” vs. “Roll the clip.”
lead_paragraph: In a typical election season — remember those? — right about now we would be preparing for, or recovering from, the final presidential debate. But Oct. 23, the date of a proposed CNN showdown that Kamala Harris accepted and Donald J. Trump declined, came and went without one.

headline: Russia Could Expand Its Assistance to Houthis, U.S. Says
abstract: The group’s attacks in the Red Sea have driven up shipping costs and forced the United States and its allies to increase their naval presence in the region.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the Middle East crisis here.

headline: The Policy Record Harris Isn’t Talking About
abstract: As vice president, Kamala Harris has targeted racial and gender gaps in health care, lending and other areas. She isn’t running on that part of her record.
lead_paragraph: Paging through intelligence reports just weeks after she was sworn in as vice president, Kamala Harris was struck by the way two female foreign leaders were described. The reports used adjectives that, in her view, were rarely used to describe male leaders.

headline: E. Coli Outbreak Tied to McDonald’s Widens to 75 People in 13 States
abstract: Health officials say that recalls of onions — the suspected source of the contamination — would help lessen the risk to consumers. Other major fast-food chains have also stopped offering onions.
lead_paragraph: The number of people hospitalized from the E. coli outbreak linked to raw onions on McDonald’s Quarter Pounder hamburgers has more than doubled, and those reporting they have been sickened rose to 75, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Friday.

headline: Barbara Dane, Who Fought Injustice Through Song, Dies at 97
abstract: She was highly regarded as a folk, blues and jazz singer. She was also ardently left-wing and prioritized social change over commercial success.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Dane, an acclaimed folk, jazz and blues singer whose communist leanings and fierce civil rights and antiwar activism earned her both critical plaudits and a thick Federal Bureau of Investigation file, died on Sunday at her home in Oakland, Calif. She was 97.

headline: History, Money and Glamour Define a New York vs. Los Angeles World Series
abstract: The two biggest cities in America have as many differences as similarities — including in public transportation, ballparks and payrolls
lead_paragraph: If you asked a Hollywood director or a New York writer to come up with a riveting World Series script for 2024, they would probably conjure the one we’ve got.

headline: The Early Bird Got the Cicada, Then an Evolutionary Air War Started
abstract: Fossils reveal that prehistoric cicadas’ wings evolved to help them evade hungry predators with feathers and beaks, scientists say.
lead_paragraph: Today, few critters are as abundant as cicadas. Thousands of different cicada species are found throughout the world, and some even periodically emerge by the trillions.

headline: Chinese Hackers Are Said to Have Targeted Phones Used by Trump and Vance
abstract: The targeting of the Republican presidential ticket’s phones is part of what appears to be a wide-ranging effort to gather information about American leaders.
lead_paragraph: Chinese hackers targeted data from phones used by former President Donald J. Trump and his running mate, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, as part of what appears to be a wide-ranging intelligence-collection effort, people familiar with the matter said on Friday.

headline: Former Tech C.E.O. Dan Price Is Charged With Rape in California
abstract: The former chief of Gravity Payments rose to prominence with the introduction of his company’s $70,000 minimum salary and a splashy social media presence.
lead_paragraph: Dan Price, a Seattle tech executive who rose to fame for publicly raising the salaries of his employees and as a progressive social media influencer, was charged with rape on Thursday in Riverside County, Calif., according to court records.

headline: U.N. Warns of ‘Atrocity Crimes’ in Gaza
abstract: Jordan’s foreign minister, Ayman Safadi, appearing with Secretary of State Antony Blinken, said that Israel was conducting “ethnic cleansing” in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations human rights chief said on Friday that Israel’s conduct in the Gaza Strip might amount to crimes against humanity, one of his most forceful public denunciations yet, reflecting the rising international backlash against the way Israel is waging war against Hamas.

headline: Lady Gaga’s Dance-Floor Antidote, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear Sade’s first new track since 2018, plus songs from Soccer Mommy, Tyler, the Creator and more.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes), and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: It’s Springsteen Season Again. Can Celebrities Give Harris a Meaningful Boost?
abstract: Bruce Springsteen performed at a rally for Vice President Kamala Harris. Beyoncé will appear at an event on Friday. It is hard to say if such events actually motivate people to go to the polls.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday evening, as the sun was setting behind the pine trees at a high school football stadium in Clarkston, Ga., Bruce Springsteen took the stage with an acoustic guitar. He played “The Promised Land,” his late-70s song of a young working man chasing a brighter future. Then he addressed the crowd.

headline: Former Model Accuses Donald Trump of Groping Her in 1993
abstract: The swimsuit model Stacey Williams said Jeffrey Epstein brought her to Trump Tower, where the future president groped her. Mr. Trump’s campaign denied it.
lead_paragraph: One day in 1993, the financier Jeffrey Epstein brought a model named Stacey Williams to Trump Tower in Manhattan to say hello to the building’s owner, Donald J. Trump. As he and Mr. Epstein chatted, Mr. Trump groped Ms. Williams, she said.

headline: Middle East War Hits Home in Michigan, Threatening Slotkin in Tight Senate Race
abstract: Anger among the battleground state’s sizable contingent of Arab American voters about violence in Gaza and Lebanon could hurt the Democratic congresswoman in a close contest.
lead_paragraph: When Representative Elissa Slotkin of Michigan announced her candidacy for Senate early last year, Democrats had high hopes that her record as a defense hawk and centrist with proven cross-party appeal would make her an ideal candidate for keeping the swing-state seat in Democratic hands.

headline: Our Robot Stories Haven’t Prepared Us for A.I.
abstract: ‘The Wild Robot’ and Data from ‘Star Trek’ are very different from our chatbots.
lead_paragraph: This week, my newsroom colleague Kevin Roose chronicled the heartbreaking story of Sewell Setzer III, a Florida teenager who took his own life — and whose mother blames Character.AI, a role-playing app where users interact with artificial intelligence chatbots, for his retreat from normal social life and then reality itself.

headline: Potentially Damaging Winds Expected to Return to Southern California
abstract: Northerly winds, slightly stronger than the most recent wind event earlier this month, will blow through Southern California in the days leading up to Halloween.
lead_paragraph: A change in weather patterns will bring the possibility of damaging winds, cooler temperatures and potentially some rain to Southern California, while also increasing the fire risk for the region in the coming days.

headline: The New York Times Is Looking for Flashback Contributors
abstract: The best clues for the weekly history quiz are tiny stories that combine the familiar with the surprising.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times is looking for contributors to create editions of Flashback, our weekly history quiz. Contributors would construct a quiz with nine clues, which are short descriptions of historical events that readers have to place on a timeline.

headline: Los Angeles D.A.’s Move in Menendez Case Comes Amid Tough Re-election Bid
abstract: The review of the high-profile murder case by George Gascón’s office began more than a year ago. But critics say the timing of the decision was political.
lead_paragraph: On his first day in office, George Gascón, the district attorney of Los Angeles, said that taking a fresh look at long prison sentences handed down during the high-crime 1990s would be a centerpiece of his agenda as a progressive prosecutor.

headline: In Wisconsin’s Senate Race, the Republican Highlights Baldwin’s Sexuality
abstract: Eric Hovde is closing out his challenge to Senator Tammy Baldwin, a low-key Midwesterner, with a new attack ad that appears to want to make sure voters know she’s gay.
lead_paragraph: The Senate campaign of Eric Hovde, a Republican in Wisconsin, has just begun running this 30-second ad on television stations in Madison, Wis., this week, so far at a cost of $30,000, according to AdImpact.

headline: 13 Ex-Trump Aides Back Kelly’s ‘Dictator’ Warning, Saying Trump Seeks ‘Absolute, Unchecked Power’
abstract: In a letter, the former aides wrote, “For the good of our country, our democracy, and our Constitution, we are asking you to listen closely and carefully to General Kelly’s warning.”
lead_paragraph: Thirteen former Trump administration officials released an open letter on Friday amplifying warnings from John F. Kelly, Donald J. Trump’s longest-serving White House chief of staff, that the former president would rule like a dictator if he returned to office.

headline: ‘The Economy, Stupid’? Not So Much Anymore.
abstract: Economic factors can tell us only so much about how presidential elections will turn out.
lead_paragraph: If every voter were an economist (ghastly thought), elections would be easy to forecast. The performance of the economy would reliably predict consumer sentiment, which in turn would predict approval ratings for the incumbent president, which in turn would predict the outcome of the election in the Electoral College.

headline: Is It OK to Keep Returning Purchases You’ve Worn for Months?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to exploit a store’s return policy.
lead_paragraph: My partner loves a large outfitting company that has a very generous return policy. The store will accept nearly any return within a year of purchase. My partner has been buying fairly expensive items from the store, using them while we travel and then returning them, even though they have accrued a good amount of wear and tear. Note that she would probably keep the items if they were exactly what she wanted, but there is almost always some imperfection: For example, she returned the backpack she used daily for international travel after nine months because it was slightly bigger than ideal. She returned the shoes that she wore almost daily for several months because they were not quite as comfortable as she desired.

headline: Biden Apologizes for U.S. Abuse of Indian Children, Calling It ‘a Sin on Our Soul’
abstract: From the early 1800s to the late 1960s, the federal government forced Native American children into boarding schools where they faced abuse and neglect that led in some cases to death.
lead_paragraph: President Biden ventured into Native American territory on Friday to offer a formal apology on behalf of the U.S. government for the mistreatment of generations of children who were taken away from their families in an effort to strip them of their culture, history and language.

headline: NASA Astronaut Leaves Hospital After ‘Medical Issue’ That Followed Return From Space
abstract: Three NASA astronauts and a fourth from the Russian space agency returned to Earth from the International Space Station on Friday morning in a SpaceX capsule.
lead_paragraph: A NASA astronaut experiencing a “medical issue” was hospitalized early Friday after returning from the International Space Station, the space agency said Friday. Citing privacy, NASA did not identify the astronaut or provide details about the medical issue.

headline: Airline Lost Your Bag? Here’s How to Reunite With Your Luggage.
abstract: Or at least be reimbursed if it’s gone for good.
lead_paragraph: We’ve all been there, waiting impatiently at the baggage carousel, anxiously hoping for that first glimpse of our checked luggage. Then we breathe a sigh of relief, collect it and get on with our travels.

headline: Phil Lesh, Bassist Who Anchored the Grateful Dead, Dies at 84
abstract: One of the first rock bassists whose instrument regularly took a lead role, he also had a hand in writing some of the band’s best-known songs.
lead_paragraph: Phil Lesh, whose expansive approach to the bass as a charter member of the Grateful Dead made him one of the first performers on that instrument in a rock band to play a lead role rather than a supporting one, died on Friday. He was 84.

headline: 25 Jump Scares That Still Make Us Jump
abstract: We ranked the most chilling, spine-tingling, utterly terrifying scenes that get us every time, and asked writers, filmmakers and stars to explain why.
lead_paragraph: We ranked the most chilling, spine-tingling, utterly terrifying scenes that get us every time, and asked writers, filmmakers and stars to explain why.

headline: Dozens Reported Killed in Attacks on Khan Younis
abstract: Thirteen children and a woman from the same family were among several Palestinians killed in overnight Israeli strikes on Khan Younis in southern Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Thirteen children and a woman from the same family were among several Palestinians killed in overnight Israeli strikes on Khan Younis in southern Gaza.

headline: Leon Cooper Dies at 94; Nobelist Unlocked Secrets of Superconductivity
abstract: He shared the 1972 physics prize for showing how some materials could convey electricity without resistance. He also did pioneering research in neuroscience.
lead_paragraph: Leon N. Cooper, a Nobel-winning physicist who helped unlock the secret of how some materials can convey electricity without resistance, a phenomenon called superconductivity, and who did pioneering work in understanding how memory and the brain work, died on Wednesday at his home in Providence, R.I. He was 94.

headline: Biden Administration Floats Student Loan Relief for Borrowers Facing Hardship
abstract: The proposal, which faces tough legal prospects, would offer forgiveness to millions of borrowers who are unable to pay back their loans because of financial setbacks.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has proposed another student debt relief plan for eight million people who cannot repay their loans because of “financially devastating hardships,” Miguel A. Cardona, the secretary of education, said on Friday.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, October 26, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Israel Pummels Gaza and Lebanon With Hundreds of Deadly Airstrikes
abstract: Gaza’s health ministry reported that dozens of people had been killed in a residential area of Khan Younis, as Israel launched a barrage of attacks across the region on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Israeli attacks across the Gaza Strip on Friday left dozens dead and cut off communications between the outside world and one of the last functioning hospitals in the enclave’s north, according to the Gaza health ministry and the World Health Organization.

headline: Election Officials Face Torrent of Threats as Nov. 5 Looms
abstract: Law enforcement’s task for Election Day this year goes far beyond providing physical security, to the essential mission of safeguarding democracy.
lead_paragraph: With less than two weeks until Election Day, law enforcement officials are confronting a rising wave of threats to election workers and political activists in a presidential contest hurtling toward a bitterly contentious coda and a potentially unsettled aftermath.

headline: What’s at Stake in the 2024 Election
abstract: A 14-day series highlighting our best coverage of the most important issues in this election.
lead_paragraph: A 14-day series highlighting our best coverage of the most important issues in this election.

headline: ‘Pure Hell’: The Painful Legacy of Boarding Schools for Native Americans.
abstract: President Biden apologized on Friday for the abuses children experienced at the government-run schools, which were designed to erase tribal ties and cultural practices.
lead_paragraph: Ron Singer, who is 67 and a member of the Navajo Nation, called it three years of “pure hell.” At age 7, he was sent to a Native American boarding school run by the federal government in Tuba City, Ariz., more than 40 miles from his home.

headline: Mississippi’s Absentee Ballot Measure Violates Federal Law, Appeals Court Rules
abstract: The law requires officials to count absentee ballots received by mail up to five days after Election Day. It appears unlikely that the ruling will affect the current election.
lead_paragraph: A Mississippi law requiring officials to count absentee ballots received by mail up to five days after Election Day violates federal law, an appeals court ruled on Friday.

headline: ‘Good Omens’ Season 3 Cut Short Amid Allegations Against Gaiman
abstract: The series is the third production linked to the author to face turmoil after allegations made by five women surfaced this summer.
lead_paragraph: “Good Omens,” a series based on a novel by the author Neil Gaiman written in collaboration with Terry Pratchett, will return for a third and final season, but it will consist of only one episode, Prime Video announced on Friday.

headline: Meet the New Home Kitchen Business
abstract: Starting in November, licensed home kitchens in Los Angeles County will be able to sell dine-in and to-go meals, as a 5-year-old state law expands.
lead_paragraph: What accomplished home cook hasn’t fantasized about opening a restaurant? Usually, that fantasy fizzles right at the point where hundreds of thousands of dollars are needed to sign a lease.

headline: Harris and Trump Hold Splashy Events Away From Swing States
abstract: Also, the C.D.C. lowered the age for the pneumonia vaccine. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: The race for president is deadlocked, according to The Times’s final poll before Election Day. And the winner will very likely be decided in one of the seven battleground states where neither candidate holds a clear edge. But instead of making another appearance in Wisconsin or Pennsylvania, Kamala Harris is spending the evening in Texas.

headline: Obama Tears Into Trump in North Carolina, Which Has Eluded Democrats
abstract: Barack Obama’s presence looms large in the state, which his party hasn’t won since his first presidential bid. He painted Donald Trump as a danger to the country, families and pocketbooks.
lead_paragraph: Former President Barack Obama offered a stark warning on Friday night of dangers posed by a second Donald Trump presidency, pleading with North Carolina voters to cast their ballots over the final days of early voting in the state.

headline: Gang Gunfire in Haiti Hits U.S. Embassy Vehicles and U.N. Aid Helicopter
abstract: The attacks this week point to an escalation of violence as the situation worsens and gangs overwhelm security forces, including a multinational force.
lead_paragraph: Armed gangs in Haiti opened fire on U.S. Embassy vehicles and a United Nations helicopter this week, an escalation of attacks as criminal groups overwhelm security forces in the country — including an international mission charged with taking on the gangs.

headline: Murals in Tehran Offer Tributes and Threats Against Israel
abstract: In the Iranian capital’s Palestine Square, a series of murals have telegraphed warnings to the country’s enemies.
lead_paragraph: As tension between Israel and Iran has escalated in recent months, a wall in central Tehran has become a message board for telegraphing threats against Israel.

headline: France’s Financial Morass Produces a Harsh Critique From Moody’s
abstract: The financial ratings agency, citing a “fiscal deterioration” with rising borrowing and a political logjam, downgraded its outlook for French debt.
lead_paragraph: Warnings over France’s financial situation grew on Friday when the Moody’s ratings agency issued a negative outlook for the country’s sovereign debt rating amid concerns about the nation’s rapidly rising debt and deficit.

headline: Media Organizations Criticize Israeli Strike That Killed Three Journalists
abstract: Israel says it was bombing a structure associated with Hezbollah and says it is reviewing the strike.
lead_paragraph: In calmer times, the Hasbaya Village Club was a leafy oasis in southern Lebanon, its vacation bungalows with their red tile roofs set near a small river, looking out over the stunning mountain vistas of the region close to the Israeli border.

headline: These Videos Appear to Show North Korean Troops in Russia
abstract: Footage was filmed in the Russian Far East, which the United States says is hosting thousands of North Korean soldiers.
lead_paragraph: “Here they are. The boys from North Korea.”

headline: Gary Indiana, Acerbic Cultural Critic and Novelist, Dies at 74
abstract: He made films, video art and photographs, but was best known as a pioneering art critic and mordant novelist.
lead_paragraph: Gary Indiana, the elfin novelist, cultural critic, playwright and artist whose crackling prose and lacerating wit captured the ravages of the AIDS crisis, Manhattan’s downtown art scene, lurid true crimes and his own search for love, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 74.

headline: How the Country’s Understanding of Abortion Could Change if Trump Wins
abstract: Activists on both sides say Trump could effectively ban abortion nationwide and establish fetal personhood, the longtime goal of the anti-abortion movement.
lead_paragraph: “Trump did this,” the campaign ads for Kamala Harris declare.

headline: The Culture Was Always Playing Catch-Up With Gary Indiana
abstract: From downtown New York, the writer both scrutinized and kept ahead of a turbulent world.
lead_paragraph: Crimes, deviations from the norm, the transgressive actions of human animals caught in the vises of history, loneliness, desperation, lust, psychosis, exhaustion or terror — these were the subjects (some of them) of Gary Indiana’s fiction, a tremendous outpouring left unfinished after his death on Thursday at 74.

headline: City Paves Over Bed-Stuy’s Hydrant ‘Aquarium’ and Puts Up a Sidewalk
abstract: The New York City Department of Environmental Protection poured concrete over a community-built goldfish pond, citing safety concerns, much to the disappointment of its Brooklyn neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: For months, Sallomé Hralima and her two young daughters watched as a fire hydrant in their neighborhood was transformed into a destination in Brooklyn.

headline: The Personal Plea Phil Lesh Made Every Time He Took the Stage
abstract: For the past 25 years, the founding member of the Grateful Dead made a nightly speech about a topic that helped him stay performing into his 80s.
lead_paragraph: The Grateful Dead and its various successors and offshoots were famous for making sure no two concerts were the same, changing their set lists with each performance. But since the late 1990s, at most every show featuring the original bassist Phil Lesh, who died Friday at 84, there was one thing that kicked off each encore.

headline: North Korean Troops Assemble in Russia’s Kursk Region, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: Thousands of soldiers from an elite unit of the Korean People’s Army began arriving on Wednesday and are expected to try to help expel Ukrainian forces from Russian territory.
lead_paragraph: Several thousand North Korean soldiers have arrived in Russia’s western Kursk region, where they are expected to participate in a coming counteroffensive meant to dislodge the Ukrainian troops who have occupied a portion of the region since August, one Ukrainian and two American officials said on Friday.

headline: Mega-Donors Pour $8 Million Into Late Push Against N.Y. Abortion Measure
abstract: Opponents of the so-called Equal Rights Amendment have cast it as a broad attempt by Democrats to grant rights to transgender athletes and migrants.
lead_paragraph: A late-stage effort to defeat a New York State ballot measure that would enshrine a right to abortion into the State Constitution has been bolstered by $8 million in donations from a handful of conservative donors.

headline: Republican Legal Challenges to Voting Rules Hit a Rough Patch
abstract: With voters already casting ballots, the two parties are still battling over the requirements for who gets to vote and which votes count.
lead_paragraph: The legal wars over election rules are raging even as voters around the country cast ballots. And several recent efforts by groups aligned with former President Donald J. Trump to challenge voting rules have been coming up short in federal and state courts.

headline: Trump Fumes Over Magazine Report at Rally With Slain Soldier’s Family
abstract: Relatives of Specialist Vanessa Guillén, who was murdered in 2020, joined Donald J. Trump at a rally days after The Atlantic reported he had made a racist remark about her.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump gave a fiery rebuttal on Friday to two damning quotations attributed to him by The Atlantic magazine, which accused him of disparaging fallen veterans and of making a racist remark about a murdered Mexican-American soldier.

headline: Your Guide to the Drama-Filled Race for Senate Control
abstract: The chamber had seemed like Republicans’ to lose, but a few surprises are playing out.
lead_paragraph: All year, control of the Senate has seemed like Republicans’ to lose. They are practically certain to pick up Senator Joe Manchin’s West Virginia Senate seat, and they need just one more of seven competitive seats held by Democrats or an independent to claim the majority.

headline: G.O.P. Lawmaker Voices Support for Giving North Carolina’s Electors to Trump
abstract: Representative Andy Harris walked back his remarks, later saying his rationale that Hurricane Helene disenfranchised some voters was “theoretical.”
lead_paragraph: Representative Andy Harris, Republican of Maryland, appeared to voice support for a plan for North Carolina’s Republican-controlled Legislature to award former President Donald J. Trump the swing state’s electoral votes, according to video of a conservative gathering on Thursday that was posted on social media.

headline: Phil Lesh Didn’t Hold Songs Down. He Lifted Them Higher.
abstract: The Grateful Dead bassist found new melodic byways through every song.
lead_paragraph: Some rock bassists make it their job to hold down the bottom of a song: to hone parts that crisply but unobtrusively stake out a harmonic and rhythmic foundation, that are felt as much as heard. Phil Lesh, a founding member of the Grateful Dead who died on Friday at 84, wasn’t one of them. Instead, Lesh’s playing carried songs aloft.

headline: Phil Lesh’s Life in Pictures
abstract: Looking back at the career of the Grateful Dead bassist, starting with when the band was clean cut and called the Warlocks.
lead_paragraph: Phil Lesh, the bassist and a charter member of the Grateful Dead who was 84 when he died on Friday, will be remembered as a versatile musician and a pioneer for his instrument of choice.

headline: Corrections: Oct. 26, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 26, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about Southwest Airlines appointing six new directors to its board misstated the surname of the retiring chairman of the airline. He is Gary Kelly, not Johnson.

headline: Musk Wins Appeal Over Tweet He Had to Delete About Union Push
abstract: The Fifth Circuit court ruled that the 2018 post was protected speech. It also vacated an order to reinstate a pro-union Tesla worker who was fired.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court handed Elon Musk a victory in a freedom-of-speech case on Friday by overturning an earlier ruling in a dispute between the billionaire and the National Labor Relations Board.

headline: Masters of Bad Impersonations?
abstract: Peter A. Collins puts solvers on with a witty Saturday challenge.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Peter A. Collins is a familiar byline on New York Times crosswords: This is his 120th, and his eighth Saturday, but only his second grid in 2024. I was happily struck by the triple stack of entries in this puzzle’s center, two of which make for an intriguing story line. (Mr. Collins has done this before in past themeless grids like this one from 2021, which was more romantic and less creepy.)

headline: Why Did Israel Attack Iran?
abstract: The two countries have been fighting a shadow war for years. Now, their conflict has burst into the open.
lead_paragraph: Israel carried out a series of airstrikes against Iran on Saturday, the Israeli military said.

headline: Video of Ballots Being Destroyed Was Faked by Russia, Federal Officials Say
abstract: The video, which purported to show mailed-in ballots in Pennsylvania being ripped up, was part of Moscow’s efforts to influence the U.S. presidential election, the officials said.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials said on Friday that a video showing mailed-in ballots in Pennsylvania being destroyed was a fake, created by Russia as part of Moscow’s efforts to influence the U.S. presidential election.

headline: Who Is Tommy Robinson, the Activist Behind a Far-Right London Rally?
abstract: The founder of the English Defence League, whose real name is Stephen Yaxley-Lennon, is at the forefront of a growing movement that was behind anti-immigrant riots this summer.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of supporters of the far-right British agitator known as Tommy Robinson marched through the streets of London on Saturday — many of them carrying flags or placards — before holding a rally in the city center.

headline: Quote of the Day: Sure, You Can Go to the World Series. Just Ditch the Anthropomorphic Suit.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 26, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “To have some dopey little guy in some costume? I don’t know. Just go play.”

headline: The Man Who Shaped China’s Strongman Rule Has a New Job: Winning Taiwan
abstract: Xi Jinping’s top adviser, Wang Huning, is credited with shaping the authoritarianism that steered China’s rise. But can he influence Taiwan?
lead_paragraph: When Xi Jinping held the first-ever talks in Beijing with a former president of Taiwan, seeking to press the island closer to unification, a bookish-looking official stood out for his ease around China’s leader.

headline: Beyoncé Campaigns With Harris in Texas
abstract: Beyoncé and Kelly Rowland expressed support for Vice President Kamala Harris at a campaign event focused on abortion rights in Houston on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé and Kelly Rowland expressed support for Vice President Kamala Harris at a campaign event focused on abortion rights in Houston on Friday night.

headline: Beyoncé Rallies for Harris in Houston With a Message for the Battlegrounds
abstract: Kamala Harris used Texas’ strict abortion ban as a cautionary tale as she sought to lay out the stakes of a deadlocked election.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris diverted from the presidential battlegrounds on Friday to receive the endorsement of the global superstar Beyoncé in Texas, in an event almost entirely focused on abortion rights.

headline: 6 Takeaways From Donald Trump’s 3-Hour Podcast With Joe Rogan
abstract: The former president repeated his debunked claims of election fraud and speculated that there could be life on Mars in an interview aimed at young male voters.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump taped a nearly three-hour episode of “The Joe Rogan Experience” on Friday. He courted the show’s young male audience by floating the idea of eliminating the income tax, talking about mixed martial arts fighters, praising the military skills of Gen. Robert E. Lee and speculating that there was “no reason not to think” there could be life on Mars and other planets.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: How Tom Llamas, an NBC Anchor, Spends His Sundays
abstract: Mr. Llamas, who has been racing between hurricanes and election coverage, makes time for baseball with his children and not-so-scary movies with his wife.
lead_paragraph: Five nights a week, Tom Llamas is one of the faces of election coverage for NBC News NOW.

headline: As U.S. Election Looms, Biden Aides Struggle With Middle East Wars
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken tried to get Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to envision a U.S.-backed plan for ending the war in Gaza, but there was no sign of progress.
lead_paragraph: It is not where the Biden administration wants to be less than two weeks before the U.S. presidential election.

headline: Presidents, Conventions and Nazis: A Political History of ‘The Garden’
abstract: Madison Square Garden, where former President Donald J. Trump will hold a rally on Sunday, has hosted many political events, some of them notorious.
lead_paragraph: Madison Square Garden, where Donald J. Trump and his running mate, JD Vance, are scheduled to hold a fund-raiser and rally on Sunday, has a long history of political events. Some have been peaceful. Some have not.

headline: These Japanese Baseball Fans Love Ohtani. They Love the Yankees More.
abstract: The best World Series outcome for one particular subset of fans? The Dodgers slugger hits four home runs in a game, and the Yankees win 5-4.
lead_paragraph: Masa Kawai wore his faded Yankees cap on Wednesday as he served customers at the Japanese doughnut shop he owns in Edgewater, N.J. It was two days before Game 1 of a World Series that would feature his Yankees against the Los Angeles Dodgers, and Mr. Kawai, who emigrated from Japan 20 years ago, left no doubt about his allegiance.

headline: Governing Party in Georgia Wins Election, as Opposition Calls for Protests
abstract: The Georgian Dream party won 54 percent of the vote, the electoral commission said Sunday, a result that critics of the government fear could derail the country’s pro-Western course.
lead_paragraph: The governing party in Georgia, the strategically important mountainous republic at the center of the Caucasus, has won a parliamentary election, the election commission said Sunday.

headline: Vatican Punts Question of Female Deacons at Major Meeting
abstract: A meeting four years in the making said the ordination of women required further study, but it called for women to have more leadership roles, even in seminaries.
lead_paragraph: A monthlong meeting of Catholic bishops and lay people at the Vatican ended on Saturday with a call for women to be given more leadership roles in the church. But on the question of whether women could be ordained as deacons, the church said the possibility “remains open” and required further meditation.

headline: Iran’s State Media Plays Down Israeli Attacks
abstract: Explosions woke Iranians up and rattled their windows as strikes targeted sites in at least three provinces.
lead_paragraph: Iranians awoke on Saturday to the sound of explosions that rattled their windows and shook their homes in the predawn hours as Israel carried out retaliatory strikes in at least three provinces, including Tehran.

headline: Toplines: October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters in New York City
abstract: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 853 registered voters in New York City from Oct. 20 to 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 853 registered voters in New York City from Oct. 20 to 23, 2024.

abstract: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 853 likely voters in New York City from Oct. 20 to 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 853 likely voters in New York City from Oct. 20 to 23, 2024.

headline: Cross-Tabs: October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters in New York City
abstract: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 853 registered voters in New York City from Oct. 20 to 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 853 registered voters in New York City from Oct. 20 to 23, 2024.

headline: Inmate Labor Tests the Limits on ‘Involuntary Servitude’
abstract: A work-release program for Alabama prisoners provides labor for corporations and income for the state. Lawsuits are challenging its constitutionality.
lead_paragraph: In the back of a nondescript industrial park on the outskirts of Montgomery, Ala., past the corner of Eastern Boulevard and Plantation Way, there is a manufacturing plant run by Ju-Young, a car-part supplier for Hyundai. On a Tuesday in May, about half of the workers there — roughly 20 — were prisoners.

headline: Connecting Sports and Art in an Eclectic Mix
abstract: In an exhibit this fall, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art explores social trends using sports-related art and design objects.
lead_paragraph: “Guernica” hangs prominently on the seventh floor of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, its haphazard forms, oversized limbs and frenetic energy urging visitors to pause and contemplate what it all means.

headline: This Florida Farmworker Is 75 and Still Toiling in the Heat
abstract: After two heat strokes and damaged kidneys, José Delgado remains stunned that Florida banned counties from enacting protections for outdoor workers.
lead_paragraph: The heat stroke that José Delgado suffered six years ago after working in a sweet potato field in South Florida left him with damaged kidneys. It happened again two years later. His doctor, he said, warned that his heart might not survive another episode.

headline: China Tightens Its Hold on Minerals Needed to Make Computer Chips
abstract: Already the dominant producer of rare minerals, Beijing is using export restrictions and its power over state-owned companies to further control access.
lead_paragraph: The vise-tight grip that China wields over the mining and refining of rare minerals, crucial ingredients of today’s most advanced technologies, is about to become even stronger.

headline: Art Museums Reach Out to Visitors From Behind Closed Doors
abstract: Museums have adopted creative engagement strategies when renovation work keeps visitors away.
lead_paragraph: When you think of museums or galleries or auction houses you can’t help but think of buildings. Sometimes old stately stone ones with statues lurking on high. Sometimes modern ones decked out with glass. But what happens when there isn’t a building — when it’s closed for reconstruction, reinvention or rethinking? Without a building what’s an art house to do?

headline: A Wave of Exhibits That Appeal to Visitors’ Noses
abstract: Museum and gallery shows in Seattle, New York, England and beyond are engaging visitors’ hearts and minds through all of their senses.
lead_paragraph: It’s rare to experience art in a nearly totally dark room. But last year at the National Nordic Museum in Seattle, that’s where visitors found themselves when they entered “FLØÐ (Flood),” a site-specific installation created by the Icelandic artist and musician Jonsi (Jon Birgisson).

headline: Alan Moore Beckons Readers Into a Rich New Fantasy World
abstract: With the first volume of a new series and an instructional book on magic, the “Watchmen” author wants an imaginary revolution.
lead_paragraph: “Have you got a name or should I just keep thinking of you as ‘the liability?’” a beautiful young woman named Grace asks the protagonist of Alan Moore’s THE GREAT WHEN (Bloomsbury, 315 pp., $29.99).

headline: Painting Is Dead? Long Live Painting.
abstract: A show at the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago challenges the timeworn critics’ contention that painting is dead, expanding the idea of what painting can be.
lead_paragraph: Back in 1838, Louis Daguerre captured the first photo of a human being with revolutionary technology. Not long after, the French painter Paul Delaroche purportedly made a startling, widely quoted declaration: “From today, painting is dead.”

headline: Museums Around the Country Explore Democracy
abstract: Inspired by the presidential election, there are exhibitions, forums and voter registrations.
lead_paragraph: It’s always nice to put a face to a name, and visitors to the new exhibition at Museum of Fine Arts, Boston — “Power of the People: Art and Democracy” — will have an opportunity to do just that.

headline: 4 Historical Novels Loaded With Witches, Fiends and Demons
abstract: These books are perfect for the spooky season.
lead_paragraph: It’s believed to be one of the oldest story collections in existence, recorded in Hindi a thousand years ago, but with haunting origins that are even more ancient. As Douglas J. Penick remarks in the introduction to his retelling of THE OCEANS OF CRUELTY: Twenty-Five Tales of a Corpse Spirit (New York Review Books, 176 pp., paperback, $17.95), it reminds us of “human propensities whose lasting power we may prefer to ignore.” Imagine “One Thousand and One Nights” as told not by a young woman but by a vetala, a demon whose “whisper is like the crackling sound of a burning house.”

headline: Bryan Ferry Enjoys the Kansas City Chiefs’ ‘Outfits’
abstract: As the Roxy Music frontman readies a boxed set of his solo work, he reflects on the cultural inspirations that keep him fueled with glamour and drama.
lead_paragraph: While Bryan Ferry was picking songs for “Retrospective: Selected Recordings 1973-2023,” — a new boxed set recapping his long solo career apart from Roxy Music, the pioneering British art-rock band he led — the singer noticed a recurring theme. “There’s a lot of love songs, a lot of romantic songs,” he said, speaking by video from his London recording studio.

headline: Did van Gogh Have a Goth Phase?
abstract: A major exhibition touring Europe argues that modern artists who turned to the dark side were inspired by Gothic art from the Middle Ages.
lead_paragraph: Why did Vincent van Gogh paint a skeleton smoking a cigarette? His 1886 painting doesn’t quite seem to fit into his larger output, one teeming with swirling landscapes and emotive portraits.

headline: A Trans Researcher’s Pursuit of Better Data on Detransition
abstract: Kinnon MacKinnon leads the world’s largest study on people who stop or reverse their gender transitions, a group embroiled in intense political fights.
lead_paragraph: Kinnon MacKinnon, a Canadian researcher, was only faintly surprised this spring when the website for an upcoming conference did not list his talk alongside the dozens of others. He was slated to discuss one of the most fraught topics in medicine: patients who transition to a different gender but later change their minds, known as detransition.

headline: Is Harris’s Race or Gender Affecting Her Support? ‘It’s Very Complicated.’
abstract: There are historical clues that pollsters and academics have been able to uncover, but it’s not a simple question to answer.
lead_paragraph: Could racism or sexism be playing a role in this presidential campaign? Asked about the notion in an interview with NBC News this week, Vice President Kamala Harris brushed it off. “I will never assume that anyone in our country should elect a leader based on their gender or their race,” she said.

headline: A Lesson From John Lennon
abstract: The ecstasy and agony of an original Beatles fan.
lead_paragraph: It started in April 1963, when friends of my parents returned to New Jersey from a trip abroad with a present for me. It was something a record shop clerk in London had recommended as the perfect thing for a 13-year-old girl.

headline: To All the Single Ladies and Men at Weddings
abstract: Weddings have long marginalized the dateless, especially as couples marry older, inviting already married friends. What are some solutions?
lead_paragraph: When the D.J. called all couples to the dance floor at a wedding this summer, Denise Nuzzo, 37, brought an unusual date: her dinner roll.

headline: 7 Podcasts to Inspire a New Hobby
abstract: These shows spotlight tips from experts and interviews with casual hobbyists that may move you to pick up a new pastime.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the pandemic lockdowns of 2020 inspired a wave of sourdough starters and Zoom drawing classes, hobbies have been having a resurgence. These seven podcasts spotlight their importance, featuring expert tips and interviews with casual hobbyists that may inspire you to pick up a new pastime.

headline: A Skeleton Bank of Understudied Species
abstract: With a new database of medical images, zoo and wildlife vets can finally see what healthy uncommon animals, from rhinos and tamarins to pangolins and sea stars, should look like on the inside.
lead_paragraph: Woe betide the rhinoceros radiologist.

headline: My Co-op Says It Can Take Away My Parking Spot. I Say No.
abstract: When a new management company comes in, it may try to make new rules.
lead_paragraph: Q: The garage in my Bronx co-op building has far fewer spaces than there are apartments, making them highly coveted. I’ve been in the building for 19 years and got my space 10 years ago. The shareholders who have spots were recently sent an 18-page lease agreement to sign. We have a new management company, and this new agreement was given to us without explanation. Most of the provisions seem fair, except for one that allows the building to revoke a shareholder’s spot for any reason or for no reason at all. This seems outrageous! Is it legal? What can we do?

headline: A Muslim Mayor Endorses Trump, and a City of Immigrants Finds Itself Undone
abstract: The endorsement has roiled Hamtramck, Mich., angering many in the Muslim community, as well as longtime residents who welcomed the newcomers.
lead_paragraph: Amer Ghalib has made a lot of national news as the leader of a small, Midwestern city.

headline: Would You Pay Someone to Teach You How to Be an Influencer?
abstract: Valeria Lipovetsky brings in millions of dollars as an online personality. Now she’s teaching aspirants what she’s learned — for a price.
lead_paragraph: In August, the energy inside the event space of a hotel in the Coconut Grove neighborhood of Miami, was first-day-of-school jitters meets sorority initiation ceremony. The room was bustling with about 50 women, mostly in their 30s, dressed in similar colors (neutrals with a pop of red) and similar silhouettes (trousers, maxi skirts and vested tops), per the styling mood board they received the previous week.

headline: Sean Combs’s Empire: Winnowed, but Still Weighty
abstract: The music mogul’s business portfolio has shrunk, in part because of multiple sex abuse allegations, but his wealth remains a critical factor as his criminal case unfolds.
lead_paragraph: In arguing to keep Sean Combs in jail until his trial on federal racketeering and sex trafficking charges, prosecutors have portrayed him as a lavishly wealthy, well-connected music mogul who would be well positioned to flee. In court papers, prosecutors cited media reporting that estimated his wealth at close to a billion dollars.

headline: Jessica Tarlov Is the Liberal That Fox News Viewers Love to Hate
abstract: A die-hard Democrat, she is a resident dissenter on “The Five,” the most-watched show in cable news. Does she have the hardest job on television?
lead_paragraph: It was a day after Bret Baier’s contentious interview with Vice President Kamala Harris, and the Fox News punditocracy on “The Five,” the network’s most popular show, was celebrating. “She’s ice-cold, she’s unlikable, and her arguments are incoherent,” sneered Jesse Watters. “The look and the tone of a D.M.V. clerk who wants to take her break,” scoffed Greg Gutfeld.

headline: How Donald Trump Is Making Big Promises to Big Business
abstract: Crypto. Big Oil. Tobacco. Vaping. The former president has been making overt promises to industry leaders, a level of explicitness rarely seen in modern presidential politics.
lead_paragraph: On a Friday in late September, Donald J. Trump took time off the campaign trail for a closed-door meeting at Mar-a-Lago with officials representing the vaping industry.

headline: How a Play About A.I. Lured Robert Downey Jr. to Broadway
abstract: In “McNeal,” the playwright Ayad Akhtar explores the way artificial intelligence is disrupting the literary world and raising questions about creativity.
lead_paragraph: This summer, Ayad Akhtar was struggling with the final scene of “McNeal,” his knotty and disorienting play about a Nobel Prize-winning author who uses artificial intelligence to write a novel.

headline: A New Era for Women in Rap
abstract: Our critic on the dynamic women dominating the charts.
lead_paragraph: For Lindsay Zoladz, a pop music critic at The Times, one of the most notable trends in music lately has been the number of female rappers on the charts.

headline: Majority Want Eric Adams to Resign, Times/Siena Poll Finds
abstract: Few approved of Mr. Adams’s job performance, and he trailed Andrew Cuomo and Letitia James in an early survey of potential mayoral candidates.
lead_paragraph: A majority of New York City voters believe Mayor Eric Adams broke the law and should resign from office after being indicted on bribery and corruption charges, according to a new survey from The New York Times and Siena College that showed a dangerous erosion in his political standing.

headline: Global Economic Leaders Confront a New Era of Industrial Policy
abstract: Policymakers brace for more protectionism and the demise of “neoliberalism” if Donald J. Trump is re-elected in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: At the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank this week, Kristalina Georgieva, the head of the I.M.F., expressed a mix of relief and trepidation about the state of the world economy.

headline: Anime on Broadway May Be a Perfect Match
abstract: “Attack on Titan: The Musical” showed what a crossover between two seemingly different types of fans could look like.
lead_paragraph: There are a few things that New York theatergoers can always expect to see on Broadway stages: some Disney, some Sondheim, some Hollywood stars. One may not expect to see the Colossal Titan.

headline: As the World Turns, So Do These Cameras
abstract: Whirling 360-degree photo booths have gone from red carpets to bat mitzvahs to tourist sites like the Cradle of Humankind.
lead_paragraph: Wild Adventure Corn Maze, since opening in 2010, has become a fall destination in Idaho Falls, Idaho. There are acres of farmland with corn planted in labyrinthine arrangements. There are more acres bursting with 25 varieties of sunflowers. There is a pumpkin patch, a rock climbing wall and a zip line.

headline: Readers Shared Hacks for Cheaper Teen Car Insurance. Do They Work?
abstract: Here’s what could happen if you don’t tell your insurer about any teenage drivers in your family — or try to get a separate policy for them altogether.
lead_paragraph: Drivers are getting a bit desperate.

headline: Michelle Obama, a Reluctant Campaigner, Hits the Trail With Harris
abstract: The former first lady, who is viewed warmly among some of the voters whom the Harris campaign is trying to reach, will appear alongside the vice president on Saturday in Michigan.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama, one of the Democratic Party’s most popular and elusive surrogates, will rally alongside Vice President Kamala Harris in Michigan on Saturday, making her return to the campaign trail less than two weeks before Election Day.

headline: They Used to Be Ahead in the American Economy. Now They’ve Fallen Behind.
abstract: One economic question that really matters in an election year: Are others doing better than you?
lead_paragraph: One economic question that really matters in an election year: Are others doing better than you?

headline: Medicaid Is Not a Top Campaign Issue. But for These Voters, It’s Crucial.
abstract: Medicaid has not been a big topic on the campaign trail, though it provides insurance for 73 million people. Still, some wonder how the program could change.
lead_paragraph: Medicaid has not been a big topic on the campaign trail, though it provides insurance for 73 million people. Still, some wonder how the program could change.

headline: Can 70 Moms Save a Species?
abstract: Here’s the story of Squilla, a rare North Atlantic right whale mother, and her firstborn. To help their species continue, they’d have to navigate an increasingly dangerous ocean.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the story of Squilla, a rare North Atlantic right whale mother, and her firstborn. To help their species continue, they’d have to navigate an increasingly dangerous ocean.

headline: Trump’s Gains in New York City Offer Clues to a Shifting Electoral Map
abstract: A new poll adds to evidence of post-pandemic divergences and a smaller Trump edge in the Electoral College.
lead_paragraph: This morning, we have a New York Times/Siena College poll in a place that might surprise you: New York City.

headline: John Fetterman Fears Trump Is Stronger Than Ever
abstract: The senator discusses the “astonishing” support for the former president in Pennsylvania, his rift with progressives over Israel and his own position in the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: The senator discusses the “astonishing” support for the former president in Pennsylvania, his rift with progressives over Israel and his own position in the Democratic Party.

headline: John Fetterman Fears Trump Is Stronger Than Ever
abstract: The senator discusses the “astonishing” support for the former president in Pennsylvania, his rift with progressives over Israel and his own position in the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: Whatever the result of this election, Democrats will be in a moment of transformation afterward. For nearly a decade, the party’s energies have been devoted to defeating Donald Trump. That common goal caused most Democrats to rally around Kamala Harris as soon as Joe Biden stepped aside. But their united front has masked real fissures in the party, and at the intersection of many of them sits John Fetterman.

headline: Israel’s Strike Marks New Phase of Conflict, but Stops Short of All-Out War
abstract: Iran’s initial reaction suggested that the sides had once again averted an uncontrolled war, even if the prospect looms larger than ever.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s retaliatory attack on Iran on Saturday morning marked the start of a new and more dangerous phase in the two countries’ yearslong conflict, but it appeared, at least for now, to have stopped short of prompting an all-out war, analysts said.

headline: In a Tight Election, Can the Weather Cast a Deciding Vote?
abstract: It tends to play a minor role in voter turnout, affecting only close elections — like the one coming up on Nov. 5.
lead_paragraph: Weather has always been an uncontrollable and slightly unpredictable factor in elections.

headline: Is Canada’s New Immigration Policy Really the End of an Era?
abstract: Critics say the review of the permanent and temporary residents’ programs amounts to the abandonment of decades of “welcome mat” policy. But globally, Canada is still peerless in its openness.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Letter will be a little unconventional.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 504
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Oct. 27, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,226
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Oct. 27, 2024
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Israel’s Response to Iran
abstract: An update on the fighting in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: First, we want to update you on the latest from the Middle East. The Israeli military struck Iran overnight, in response to the barrage of missiles that Iran had fired at Israel this month.

headline: Democrats Finally Did What Sherrod Brown Asked For. It Might Be Too Late.
abstract: Why Democrats in the Midwest are losing ground.
lead_paragraph: Twelve years ago, Senator Sherrod Brown, the Ohio Democrat, took the stage at his election night party in Columbus to celebrate winning a second term. Barack Obama had just carried Ohio for the second time, after emphasizing his administration’s rescue of the auto industry. Mr. Brown wanted to proclaim that success onstage, but he was losing his voice, so his wife, the writer Connie Schultz, took over for him.

headline: The Push to Fire Lina Khan Reveals a Serious Problem in Silicon Valley
abstract: Prominent venture capitalists’ bashing of the F.T.C.’s chair is evidence of a troubled tech market.
lead_paragraph: High-profile venture capitalists are demanding that Kamala Harris, if elected president, fire a top regulator for her aggressive policing of Big Tech. Not only do I disagree with them; I see their attacks as evidence of a bigger problem with the venture capital industry and, ultimately, our technology sector, which is a critical driver of our economy and society.

headline: You’ll Have to Take My Glass From My Cold, Wine-Stained Hand
abstract: People are turning away from drinking. But a glass of wine offers transcendent benefits that, for me, far outweigh the risks.
lead_paragraph: Everywhere you look these days, people are turning away from alcohol. First there was Dry January. Now there’s Sober October. Who knows what month the rhyme scheme will come for next? Parched March? Modest August?

headline: Trump Acts Erratically. Is This Age-Related Decline?
abstract: If he were my dad, I’d want to take away the car keys — and nuclear codes.
lead_paragraph: What should we think as Donald Trump urges people to vote in January, confuses places and names, fumbles for words, simplifies his speech patterns, describes recent experiences that did not happen and in public seems increasingly vulgar, menacing and unfiltered?

headline: Could Eminem Snap Gen X Voters Back to Reality?
abstract: 50-something white men and the idea of freedom
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Eminem stood at a podium in Detroit to introduce Barack Obama at a rally for Kamala Harris. Wearing a khaki Tigers hat, the rapper read some prepared remarks. “People shouldn’t be afraid to express their opinions, and I don’t think anyone wants an America where people are worried about retribution or what people will do if you make your opinion known. I think Vice President Harris supports a future for this country where these freedoms and many others will be protected and upheld,” he said.

headline: How Bad Do You Want It, Ladies?
abstract: Donald, your insecurity is showing.
lead_paragraph: Usually, I get political wisdom from Rahm Emanuel, not his brother Ari.

headline: In Deciding Whether to Retaliate, Iran Faces a Dilemma
abstract: If Iran strikes back at Israel, it risks further escalation at a time when its economy is struggling and its military is vulnerable. If it doesn’t, it risks looking weak.
lead_paragraph: Iran faces a dilemma after the Israeli strikes on Saturday.

headline: 2 Novels About Complicated Nuns
abstract: An atheist in a convent; a bloodthirsty reality show hostess.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: A New Business on Wall Street: Defending Against D.E.I. Backlash
abstract: Companies are conducting vulnerability assessments, compiling research reports and writing plans for what to do if their diversity efforts come under attack.
lead_paragraph: Someone you probably have never heard of has managed to scare virtually all of corporate America — and Wall Street is creating a new cottage industry around the fear.

headline: Hundreds Killed in Days as War in Sudan Surges
abstract: Paramilitary forces ransacked villages and killed hundreds of people, activists said, hastening calls for the United Nations to deploy a mission to protect civilians.
lead_paragraph: A major surge in fighting in Sudan has taken a searing toll on civilians, killing hundreds of people in aerial bombings and revenge attacks in the past week, as Africa’s largest war shifts into a higher gear after the end of seasonal rains.

headline: Israeli Attack Puts Iranians on Edge: ‘The Vibe Is Not Normal’
abstract: A sense of uncertainty prevailed in Iran after an Israeli retaliatory strike. Explosions kept some awake, while others hoped life would go back to normal.
lead_paragraph: Iranians voiced a sense of anxiety and uncertainty on Saturday after a round of retaliatory strikes by Israel on their country, but some said they felt a dim hope about what may lie ahead.

headline: Lil Durk Is Accused of Conspiring to Kill a Rival. What We Know About the Case.
abstract: The rapper Lil Durk was arrested at the airport in Miami this week after he had been booked on flights to three international destinations, federal prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: The Grammy-winning rapper Lil Durk was arrested on a federal charge near Miami International Airport on Thursday over accusations that he conspired to kill a rap rival, resulting in the fatal shooting of another person.

headline: Why Is Trump Holding a Rally at Madison Square Garden?
abstract: New York is not exactly a battleground state. Here are five reasons Donald J. Trump is holding a rally there in the final days of the presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: When former President Donald J. Trump decided to take a day off the battleground campaign trail in the waning days of the race to hold a rally Sunday at Madison Square Garden, it prompted a question from many political observers: Why?

headline: In Maine Battleground, Democrat Golden Grasps to Win Over Trump Voters
abstract: To win his toughest re-election bid yet, Representative Jared Golden needs Trump voters to back him over a young Republican prospect, a former NASCAR driver.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Sunday morning, Representative Jared Golden sat perched atop a bar stool inside a small-town Maine brewery, greeting supporters who had gathered to watch the New England Patriots game and meet their congressman.

headline: Barricades and Bulletproof Glass: A County Prepares for Election Day
abstract: With the specter of political violence looming, the Department of Homeland Security has advised hundreds of communities on election safety. Luzerne County, Pa., is at the center of the unrest.
lead_paragraph: With northeastern Pennsylvania awash again in the reds and oranges of a dazzling autumn, workers recently planted boulders around a government building in downtown Wilkes-Barre to address a seasonal ugliness. But this was no beautification project.

headline: Peanut Butter Walks Into a Chocolate Cookie Bar
abstract: And the result is a rich, fudgy-centered treat that’s somewhere between a cookie and a brownie.
lead_paragraph: One of my most favorite cookies in the whole wide world is the dark chocolate peanut butter chip cookie at Levain Bakery in New York. It’s the chocolate-peanut butter combo, of course, but it’s also the fact that this massive cookie, with its fudgy, soft center, kind of qualifies as a brownie. The crisp edges of the cookie hint at those corner brownie edges, and the peanut butter chips offer a little resistance to the otherwise yielding chocolate cookie dough. It is wonderful.

headline: Erykah Badu’s Fearless Evolution Has Made Her an Icon
abstract: A look at the singer and songwriter’s signature moments as she is set to receive one of fashion’s highest honors: the Council of Fashion Designers of America’s icon award.
lead_paragraph: It was nearly 15 years ago that Erykah Badu ignited an early version of an internet firestorm with the release of her risqué video for the song “Window Seat.” Shot as if it were a single long take, the video followed Ms. Badu, a Dallas-born singer, as she walked from her car through Dealey Plaza, roughly following the route taken by the motorcade carrying President John F. Kennedy when he was assassinated on Nov. 22, 1963.

headline: We’re Looking at the Wrong Gender Gap in Voting
abstract: Young women support Harris more than young men support Trump. That might make the difference.
lead_paragraph: Every election cycle has its own story lines. This year, one of them is that young men love Donald Trump. Consider a few recent headlines.

headline: The World According to Kamala Harris
abstract: The rise of Kamala Harris, the tenacious child of high-achieving immigrants, is atypical. But her story is also distinctly American.
lead_paragraph: In Kamala Harris’s closing argument at the Ellipse in Washington on Tuesday, she sought to cast herself in thoroughly relatable terms. “I’ve lived the promise of America,” she said near the end of her speech, repeating the sentence twice more, as if trying to weave herself into the fiber of an electorate that has yet to understand her.

headline: Daughter of L.A. Times Owner Says Endorsement Decision Stemmed From Harris Stance on Gaza War
abstract: After the paper canceled its planned endorsement of Kamala Harris, the owner, Patrick Soon-Shiong, said his daughter didn’t speak for the organization. But many staff members questioned his motives.
lead_paragraph: As the nation counted down this fall to a bitterly polarized election, the editorial board of The Los Angeles Times drew up a detailed outline for an endorsement that seemed obvious for an institution that had leaned liberal for generations: Vice President Kamala Harris should be the next president of the United States.

headline: U.K. Man Who Posed as a Girl to Extort Teens Online Gets 20 Years in Prison
abstract: The Northern Ireland resident sought explicit images from thousands of girls he had groomed and blackmailed, leading to the death of a 12-year-old girl in the United States.
lead_paragraph: A 26-year-old man from Northern Ireland, who pretended to be a teenage girl on the internet to target thousands of girls in a wide-reaching online pedophilia case and who was convicted of manslaughter in the death of a 12-year-old girl in the United States, was sentenced in Britain on Friday to at least 20 years in prison.

headline: Penny Hires Jury Consultant Who Aided O.J. Simpson and Kyle Rittenhouse
abstract: The courtroom presence of Jo-Ellan Dimitrius illustrates the pressure on the 12 people who will decide if Daniel Penny is guilty of manslaughter for choking a man on a New York subway train.
lead_paragraph: As lawyers for Daniel Penny, a former Marine accused of choking a homeless man to death in a New York subway car, vetted jurors Friday, a woman sat at a courtroom table, leaning toward the people being questioned and scribbling in a notebook.

headline: What to Know About the Chinese Hackers Who Targeted the 2024 Campaigns
abstract: A group that experts call Salt Typhoon is believed to be behind a sophisticated breach of major telecommunication companies that has taken aim at American leaders.
lead_paragraph: A sophisticated breach of American telecommunications systems has extended to the presidential campaigns, raising questions about the group behind the attack and the extent of its efforts at collecting intelligence.

headline: Why Are North Korean Troops in Russia?
abstract: Over the last month, North Korea’s role aiding Russia in its war in Ukraine has significantly escalated. U.S. officials reported that North Korean soldiers are already operating in the Kursk region in western Russia, where Ukrainian forces are staging a counteroffensive. Michael Shear, a White House correspondent for The New York Times, explains what the deeping relationship between Russia and North Korea means for the war in Ukraine and the world.
lead_paragraph: Over the last month, North Korea’s role aiding Russia in its war in Ukraine has significantly escalated. U.S. officials reported that North Korean soldiers are already operating in the Kursk region in western Russia, where Ukrainian forces are staging a counteroffensive. Michael Shear, a White House correspondent for The New York Times, explains what the deeping relationship between Russia and North Korea means for the war in Ukraine and the world.

headline: At First N.Y.C. Mayoral Forum, Five Democratic Candidates Attack Adams
abstract: The event, hosted at a church in the Bronx, served as the unofficial start of the city’s 2025 mayoral race.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams did not attend the first candidate forum for the New York City mayoral race, but his record — and the criminal charges he faces — received plenty of attention on Saturday from the Democrats who are running to unseat him.

headline: Just When You Thought Sneakers Couldn’t Get Any Weirder
abstract: Puffy, pricey, and strangely perfect for the moment, the $455 ERLs are billed as skateboard shoes — but maybe don’t try to skate in them.
lead_paragraph: Eli Russell Linnetz grew up skateboarding. Was he good at it? Perhaps it’s better not to ask.

headline: Trump Escalates Threats as Campaign Enters Dark Final Stretch
abstract: Top military leaders and high-ranking former officials from his administration have issued warning after warning that Donald J. Trump would rule as a dictator if given the chance.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

headline: Working the Night Shift
abstract: Jeffrey Martinovic and Jeff Chen’s Sunday puzzle will have you beaming.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Trump Attacks Bipartisan Semiconductor Law, a Key Policy Achievement for Biden
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump’s comments came during a nearly three-hour episode of “The Joe Rogan Experience.”
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump on Friday blasted the CHIPS and Science Act, a bipartisan law aimed at reducing America’s reliance on Asia for semiconductors by providing billions in subsidies to encourage companies to manufacture more chips in the United States.

headline: What We Know About Israel’s Strikes On Iran
abstract: After military-on-military attacks, will Israel and Iran be able to contain their conflict? Maria Abi-Habib, an investigative correspondent for The New York Times, looks at an unprecedented new chapter in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: After military-on-military attacks, will Israel and Iran be able to contain their conflict? Maria Abi-Habib, an investigative correspondent for The New York Times, looks at an unprecedented new chapter in the Middle East.

headline: New York Mayor Says Trump Should Not Be Called ‘Fascist,’ Breaking With Harris and Party
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams of New York, an embattled Democrat who has been indicted on federal corruption charges, has been careful in what he says about the former president.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams of New York said on Saturday that former President Donald J. Trump should not be called a “fascist” or compared to Adolf Hitler, a rejection of Democrats’ closing focus in the final days of the 2024 campaign on the eve of Mr. Trump’s rally in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Trump, Who Once Proposed a Muslim Registry, Now Courts Their Votes
abstract: The former president is reaching out to Muslim and Arab American voters in Michigan, a key battleground state.
lead_paragraph: When he ran for president eight years ago, Donald J. Trump floated the idea of creating a national registry of Muslims and proposed banning immigration from Muslim countries. So it was striking to see him on Saturday at a rally in suburban Detroit celebrating endorsements from a handful of Muslim and Arab American leaders.

headline: The Curious Case of a Temple Sweet: How Food Increasingly Divides India
abstract: A Hindu politician has accused his Christian predecessor of allowing a temple’s sanctity to be violated with an animal product.
lead_paragraph: It was a sensational charge in a country where food is yet another marker of political, religious and caste divides.

headline: Israel Struck Air Defenses Around Critical Iranian Energy Sites, Officials Say
abstract: Israeli attacks hit air-defense systems around important energy sites but avoided the facilities themselves, Iranian and Israeli officials said. The United States had urged Israel not to strike energy and oil facilities.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s attacks on Iran early Saturday destroyed air-defense systems set up to protect several critical oil and petrochemical refineries, as well as systems guarding a large gas field and a major port in southern Iran, according to three Iranian officials and three senior Israeli defense officials.

headline: Michelle Obama Makes a Searing Appeal to Men: ‘Take Our Lives Seriously’
abstract: The former first lady portrayed a second Trump administration as dire for American women. And she accused the media and many voters of holding Kamala Harris to a higher standard than Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama issued an impassioned plea to American voters on Saturday — and, in particular, American men — anchored in a searing and intimate depiction of women’s bodies and reproductive health, and what she described as the life-or-death stakes of returning former President Donald J. Trump to power.
