headline: ‘This Is Real’: Excerpts From Michelle Obama’s Speech on the Election
abstract: Michelle Obama made a striking speech about the consequences that the election will have for women’s bodies and reproductive health.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama made the case for Vice President Kamala Harris on Saturday night in Kalamazoo, Mich., with a striking speech about the consequences that the election will have for women’s bodies and reproductive health.

headline: Japan’s Long-Governing Party Loses Its Majority
abstract: The Japanese electorate appeared to punish the Liberal Democrats, leaving it unclear whether the party would be forced to expand its coalition to stay in power.
lead_paragraph: Japan’s governing party lost its majority in parliamentary elections on Sunday, as voters delivered an emphatic rejection of the status quo, throwing Japanese politics into its most uncertain period in years.

headline: Ukraine Invaded Russia. Here’s What It Was Like for Civilians.
abstract: Russians in the area of Ukraine’s invasion have described seeing signs of violent encounters, as well as respectful treatment from Ukrainian troops.
lead_paragraph: The drone flying over Korenevo village, in the Kursk region of Russia that Ukraine invaded in August, recorded a grisly scene: at least seven bodies lying on the road, most of them in civilian clothes.

headline: How Years of Government Failures Caused a Flood ‘Worse Than Boko Haram’
abstract: After a recent dam disaster, Nigerian officials blamed God, climate change and poor people. But experts had warned the dam was at risk well before it collapsed. The officials did nothing.
lead_paragraph: For years, villagers who lived near the Alau dam in northeastern Nigeria had told government officials that the structure was broken and the reservoir behind it too full.

headline: Quote of the Day: Ohtani’s Ruthian Feats Can’t Coax Japanese Yankees Fans to Turn Dodger Blue
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 27, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “The Dodgers are getting bigger for Japanese fans. But the Yankees are still the Yankees.”

headline: Living on a Volcano’s Edge, Italians Practice for Disaster
abstract: The Italian authorities carried out a drill of their plan to save a half-million people from toxic fumes, deadly quakes or a full eruption. Vesuvius isn’t the volcano they’re worried about.
lead_paragraph: A piercing alarm burst from millions of cellphones, a signal to hundreds of thousands of people to pack their bags and flee one of Europe’s most dangerous volcanoes. But most of the Italians who heard it shrugged.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Removing Moss and Grime From Gravestones, She Reveals Forgotten History
abstract: As she scrubs centuries’ worth of dirt and mold off gravestones, Katie DeRaddo tells her TikTok followers the stories of those buried beneath them.
lead_paragraph: Greenvale Rural Cemetery sits beside the Erie Canal in Fairport, N.Y., a suburb of Rochester. Massive oak trees cast leafy shade over the rows of graves — large tombstones, mausoleums, slanted markers and plaques.

headline: He Transformed the Red Carpet. Now What?
abstract: For Daniel Roseberry, getting attention for Schiaparelli was the easy part. Now he needs to build a business.
lead_paragraph: Of all the internet-breaking, meme-baiting, conversation-starting gowns the designer Daniel Roseberry has made in his five years at the house of Schiaparelli, it is possible that the most … well, shocking, was the strapless black sheath Kylie Jenner wore to its couture show in January 2023.

headline: ‘She Pulled a Packet of Tissues From Her Bag and Tried to Take One Out’
abstract: Taming a tantrum on the 4 train, a scoop that got away in Ridgewood and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: For Investors, What if This Time Is Different?
abstract: Disregarding politics has worked brilliantly in the United States for a century. But market history offers comfort only up to a point, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: The stock market is soaring, yet there is plenty to worry about: bubbling conflicts and outright wars around the world and a close and contentious election in the United States.

headline: The Newspaper That Almost Was
abstract: Reporters and editors at The New York Times had diligently prepared for one outcome of the 2016 presidential race. Then the election results poured in.
lead_paragraph: “Hillary Clinton is our next president. How do you think the founding mothers would feel if they heard the news?”

headline: Susan B. Anthony Was Arrested for Voting. Now Her Home Is a Poll Site.
abstract: The home in Rochester, N.Y., now a museum celebrating the women’s suffrage movement, is serving as a polling place for early voters.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks after Susan B. Anthony cast her ballot in the 1872 presidential election, an audacious act of defiance and a pivotal moment in the women’s suffrage movement, a deputy federal marshal visited her home in Rochester, N.Y.

headline: Joan Didion Remains as Elusive as Ever. These Books Want to Fix That.
abstract: Since her death, Didion has become a literary subject as popular for her image and writing as for the fascination she inspired for almost half a century.
lead_paragraph: It’s still bright afternoon when the writer Lili Anolik slips into the dim recesses of the Odeon restaurant. Here, at New York’s timeless destination for downtown cool, she prefers to sit in the same place every time, a small booth by the host’s stand.

headline: How the Sound of Music Can Be Healing. Literally.
abstract: Three new books make the case for music as medicine. In “The Schubert Treatment,” the most lyrical of the trio, a cellist takes us bedside with the sick and the dying.
lead_paragraph: My colleague Dwight Garner is a great connoisseur of the quotation. I find myself stumbling around this week in the dark corners of the misquotation. Music may indeed have charms to “soothe the savage beast,” as is oft-declared, but the line actually ends “a savage breast,” and is attributable not to William Shakespeare, but to William Congreve, from his 1697 play “The Mourning Bride.”

headline: Book Bans Live On in School District Now Run by Democrats
abstract: Democrats swept a school board election in Bucks County after Republicans instituted book bans and other changes. But the right-wing “parental rights” movement has left an indelible mark.
lead_paragraph: For two years, the Republican Pennridge School Board, north of Philadelphia, governed with a burst of ideological energy. It instituted book bans and curriculum rewrites — the sort of politics pushed nationwide by Moms for Liberty, the conservative advocacy group allied with Donald J. Trump.

headline: For Catholic Jubilee, Days of Joy and Sadness in Rome and Bethlehem
abstract: For Rome, the rare Christmas Eve rite of redemption is cause for celebration this year. For Bethlehem, it is another grim reminder of the generations of war and deprivation.
lead_paragraph: This Christmas Eve, hundreds of thousands of pilgrims are expected to flock to Rome for the start of the yearlong Jubilee, a rare Catholic tradition during which believers can have their sins forgiven.

headline: This Town Has More Faith in Football Than Politics. Can Walz Make a Difference?
abstract: In Aliquippa, Pa., residents have long believed more in their high school football team than in many politicians. Can combining the two make a difference?
lead_paragraph: In a small city northwest of Pittsburgh, once home to one of the largest steel manufacturing plants in the United States, players on the Aliquippa High School football team paused their practice last August for a few unexpected visitors.

headline: The Satanic Panic That Never Goes Away
abstract: New movies and TV shows are revisiting a “weird corner” of the ’80s — and offering lessons for today.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, the television writer Matthew Scott Kane sold “Hysteria!,” a scripted drama that takes place in the late 1980s. The series was inspired in part by the tumult of misinformation he found online and in the media of the late 2010s. Shows like these take time to make, and Kane worried the idea would pass its best-by date.

headline: Hear a Chopin Waltz Unearthed After Nearly 200 Years
abstract: An unknown work in the composer’s hand has emerged in a New York museum, the first such find in more than a half century. The pianist Lang Lang plays it here.
lead_paragraph: Deep in the vault of the Morgan Library & Museum in Manhattan on a late-spring day, the curator Robinson McClellan was sorting through a collection of cultural memorabilia. There were postcards signed by Picasso, a vintage photograph of a French actress and letters from Brahms and Tchaikovsky.

headline: Massachusetts, Famed for Tough School Standards, Rethinks Its Big Test
abstract: A ballot measure would do away with the requirement that high schoolers pass a test to graduate. Opponents say it could water down academics for struggling students.
lead_paragraph: Deep blue Massachusetts is far from the presidential campaign trail. But a high-stakes campaign has flooded the state with social media and television ads, pressing voters to consider a major change to the public school system widely seen as the nation’s best.

headline: Their Son’s Death Was Devastating. Then Politics Made It Worse.
abstract: After Aiden Clark was killed in a school bus accident in Springfield, Ohio, his death inspired conspiracy theories, campaign lies and  anti-immigrant hate. Now his family is the latest target.
lead_paragraph: A sheriff’s deputy arrived at Nathan and Danielle Clark’s front door on the outskirts of Springfield, Ohio, last month with the latest memento of what their son’s death had become. “I’m sorry that I have to show you this,” she said and handed them a flier with a picture of Aiden, 11, smiling at the camera after his last baseball game. It was the same image the Clarks had chosen for his funeral program and then made into Christmas ornaments for his classmates, but this time the photograph was printed alongside threats and racial slurs.

headline: With Criminal Cases Looming, Trump Has a Personal Stake in the Election
abstract: If he wins the White House, Donald J. Trump, who has a sentencing hearing three weeks after Election Day, could disrupt or even dispose of the various cases he is facing.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has a uniquely personal interest in the outcome of the election: If he wins the White House, he could disrupt or even dispose of the various criminal cases he is facing. But if he loses, he could become the first former president to lose his liberty, too.

headline: Where Kamala Harris and Donald Trump Stand on Crime
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump, who has 34 felony convictions and is facing three other indictments, wants to stretch the limits of executive power in the name of fighting crime if he is re-elected president. Vice President Kamala Harris, a former prosecutor and California attorney general, has evolved somewhat on crime issues since her first presidential campaign in 2019 and has a more typical Democratic checklist. Maggie Astor, who covers campaign issues for The New York Times, details their stands on guns, policing and crime.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump, who has 34 felony convictions and is facing three other indictments, wants to stretch the limits of executive power in the name of fighting crime if he is re-elected president. Vice President Kamala Harris, a former prosecutor and California attorney general, has evolved somewhat on crime issues since her first presidential campaign in 2019 and has a more typical Democratic checklist. Maggie Astor, who covers campaign issues for The New York Times, details their stands on guns, policing and crime.

headline: T-Shirts for the Female Gaze
abstract: A handful of small brands founded by women are gaining recognition for their takes on a wardrobe staple.
lead_paragraph: You could buy eight T-shirts from Hanes for the price of a single T-shirt from Flore Flore, a small brand that in recent years has popped up in fashionable boutiques across the world.

headline: Watches That Look Similar in Everything but the Price Tag
abstract: Patek Philippe’s first new collection in 25 years came as a particular shock to a British watchmaker who already had a (far less expensive) doppelgänger on the market.
lead_paragraph: At first, Benjamin J. Adams thought the image must have been Photoshopped.

headline: New-York Historical Society Gets a New Name and a New Wing
abstract: The museum will now be called the New York Historical and will name a new Wing for American Democracy after two major benefactors, H.M. Agnes Hsu-Tang and Oscar L. Tang.
lead_paragraph: After 220 years of existence, New-York Historical Society is changing its name to the New York Historical, and will christen a new wing devoted to American democracy after H.M. Agnes Hsu-Tang and Oscar L. Tang, in honor of their $20 million gift, the museum announced on Sunday.

headline: Trump and Harris Scrap for Georgia as Supporters Brace for a Photo Finish
abstract: Georgia has seen a flurry of activity underlining both parties’ recognition that, once again, the state is anyone’s to win.
lead_paragraph: Fewer than 12,000 votes in Georgia were the difference between Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s 2020 victory in the state and Donald J. Trump’s defeat. Apart from Arizona, there was no thinner margin in the nation.

headline: First Images of the Sun’s Flares Released From a New Space Telescope
abstract: Forecasters will soon be able to use the instrument, a coronagraph, to better monitor the effects of solar storms.
lead_paragraph: Before the northern lights fill the night sky on Earth with their eerie neon glow, a blast of electrified gas flares up from the sun’s surface. And scientists are now getting a powerful new view of how those ejections move through the corona, the sun’s tempestuous outer atmosphere.

headline: Amid Talk of Fascism, Trump’s Threats and Language Evoke a Grim Past
abstract: Plenty of presidents have been called dictators by their political opponents, but none until now has been publicly accused of being a “fascist” by his own handpicked advisers.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

headline: Voters Are Deeply Skeptical About the Health of American Democracy
abstract: Nearly half say it does not do a good job representing the people, and three-quarters say it is under threat, according to a Times/Siena poll.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half of all voters are skeptical that the American experiment in self-governance is working, with 45 percent believing that the nation’s democracy does not do a good job representing ordinary people, according to a new New York Times/Siena College poll.

headline: Hear a Chopin Waltz Unearthed After Nearly 200 Years
abstract: An unknown work in the composer’s hand has emerged in a New York museum, the first such find in more than a half century. The pianist Lang Lang plays it here.
lead_paragraph: An unknown work in the composer’s hand has emerged in a New York museum, the first such find in more than a half century. The pianist Lang Lang plays it here.

headline: Donald Trump Will Never Be Done With New York
abstract: Sunday’s rally at Madison Square Garden, the self-styled “world’s most famous arena,” is a remarkable gambit, even by the former president’s standards — and a show of force.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

headline: Inside The Washington Post’s Decision to Stop Presidential Endorsements
abstract: Post owner Jeff Bezos ended the decades-long practice, weeks after a discussion at a meeting in Miami. The move has drawn criticism in and outside the newsroom.
lead_paragraph: A tropical storm was heading toward Florida’s Gulf Coast in late September when senior news and opinion leaders of The Washington Post flew into Miami for a periodic meeting with Jeff Bezos, the newspaper’s billionaire owner.

headline: Tropical Storm Trami Hits Vietnam After Killing Dozens in the Philippines
abstract: The storm made landfall near Danang on Sunday after leaving at least 80 people dead last week.
lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Trami made landfall in Vietnam on Sunday, days after causing widespread flooding and leaving at least 80 people dead in the Philippines, officials said.

headline: What Football Can Teach Politics
abstract: Dwight Eisenhower learned leadership in an early job as a football coach. His success as president offers a few important lessons.
lead_paragraph: It’s certainly possible that we Americans have become so aggrieved and politically polarized that we’re no longer capable of operating a responsible democracy. But for those still clinging to hope, I have a theory about a potential way forward.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,227
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Oct. 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 505
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Oct. 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Four Lessons From Nine Years of Being ‘Never Trump’
abstract: What do I wish my 2024 self could travel back and say to 2015 me?
lead_paragraph: I’ve been wrong about many things, but here are two of the bigger whiffs of my professional life.

headline: Nevertheless, Ted Cruz Persists
abstract: Many voters see the Texas senator as their unapologetic fighter.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz is looking cocky. Rocking Ray-Bans and an “I voted” sticker on his lapel — it’s the first day of early voting in Texas — he is easing his way across the parking lot of his local polling place, toward TV cameras set up beside his campaign bus. Backed by sign-waving fans, he starts his brief remarks, only to be interrupted by an angry man shouting from a few yards away: “You’re a traitor to democracy!”

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘How Everyone Got Lost in Netflix’s Endless Library’
abstract: Ten years after Silicon Valley remade TV, it’s clear how the streaming revolution distorted our collective viewing habits — and sense of the culture.
lead_paragraph: If you take a journey deep within Netflix’s furthest recesses — burrow past Binge-worthy TV Dramas and 1980s Action Thrillers, take a left at Because You Watched the Lego Batman Movie, keep going past Fright Night — you will eventually find your way to the platform’s core, the forgotten layers of content fossilized by the pressure from the accreted layers above.

headline: Two Billionaires, Two Newspapers, Two Acts of Self-Sabotage
abstract: The Washington Post and The Los Angeles Times have made a terrible decision on presidential endorsements.
lead_paragraph: I can think of some compelling reasons that leading independent newspapers should not be in the business of endorsing candidates for president.

headline: A Classical Music Discovery
abstract: An unknown waltz by Chopin has been found.
lead_paragraph: As The Times’s classical music reporter, I don’t often get “news” from long-dead composers.

headline: Joseph J. Ellis: The Ideals of the Founders Are on the Ballot
abstract: If Trump is president on July 4, 2026, the celebration will become a eulogy, for we will be honoring the corpse of the American republic.
lead_paragraph: The jury remains out on the verdict of the American electorate. While historians are virtually omniscient at predicting the past, we are not much better than most observers at predicting the future.

headline: No One Told Me This Would Happen to My Body in My 40s
abstract: The decline in strength and increase in injuries is little recognized and far too infrequently discussed.
lead_paragraph: I was lying on my side at physical therapy, halfway through a set of leg raises to strengthen a butt muscle gone soft, when a therapist attending to a 41-year-old woman with knee pain said something that made my ears perk up.

headline: Political Crisis Looms for Republic of Georgia After Disputed Election
abstract: The ruling Georgia Dream party won a majority in the vote. The opposition, which fears the country is moving away from the West, says the voting was not fair and that it will not sit in Parliament.
lead_paragraph: Georgia, a strategically-located republic at the center of the Caucasus, plunged into political crisis on Sunday as the ruling party celebrated victory in a pivotal election that the pro-Western opposition declared as falsified, vowing to boycott the new parliament.

headline: Behind the Tactical Gains Against Iran, a Longer-Term Worry
abstract: Experts inside and outside the Biden administration fear that Iran may conclude it has only one defense left: racing for an atomic weapon.
lead_paragraph: When Israeli fighter jets roared off the runways on Friday night, on a thousand-mile run to Iran, they headed for two major sets of targets: the air defenses that protect Tehran, including Iran’s leadership, and the giant fuel mixers that make propellant for Iran’s missile fleet.

headline: David Harris, Actor in the Cult Classic ‘The Warriors,’ Dies at 75
abstract: He played Cochise, a member of the Warriors gang who navigated a panoply of costumed aggressors in New York City.
lead_paragraph: David Harris, who played a member of a street gang in the 1979 cult classic movie “The Warriors,” died on Friday at his home in New York City. He was 75.

headline: This 41-Year-Old Chicken Is Still Going Strong
abstract: Craig Claiborne’s smothered chicken is a New York Times Cooking classic, simple to make and ready for improvisations.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I went over to Rockefeller Center in Manhattan the other morning to smother a chicken on the “Today” show. It was Craig Claiborne’s recipe (above), a taste of his Mississippi childhood that he brought to The Times in 1983, and one that I think sits near the heart of what we’re doing here: bringing the delicious to bear seven days a week.

headline: Jill Stein’s Third-Party Candidacy
abstract: Readers discuss Democrats’ concerns that her bid will throw the election to Donald Trump. Also: Harris ads; drug-free treatments; regretting email.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: ‘Il Trovatore’ at the Met Opera Doesn’t Catch Fire
abstract: The energy in Verdi’s classic must come from the singing, but the cast of this revival fails to convey the work’s passion.
lead_paragraph: Verdi’s “Il Trovatore” begins with a group of soldiers keeping a weary patrol. “Drive off the sleep that hangs heavy on our eyelids,” they sing, begging their commander to entertain them with a story.

headline: Tom Jarriel, Globetrotting ABC News Reporter, Is Dead at 89
abstract: In his 37 years at the network, he was a White House correspondent, weekend anchor and correspondent for “20/20.” He won 19 Emmy Awards.
lead_paragraph: Tom Jarriel, a globetrotting, Emmy-winning reporter who was best known for his work on the ABC newsmagazine “20/20” but also served as the network’s chief White House correspondent and weekend news anchor, died on Thursday at a nursing facility in Annapolis, Md. He was 89.

headline: ‘Trump 2024’ Was Projected on a Town’s Water Tower. A Standoff Ensued.
abstract: After a resident of Hanson, Mass., projected the logo on town property, local officials fined him $100 per day for violating its bylaws.
lead_paragraph: When a resident of Hanson, Mass., flouted a local ordinance this month, using a light projector to beam a giant “Trump 2024” logo onto a water tower, some in the small town south of Boston thought it would be easy enough to address.

headline: Beyoncé? Springsteen? Trump Fans Feel Both Anger and A-List Envy
abstract: Kamala Harris has many celebrities campaigning for her. It has uncorked complicated feelings for Donald Trump and his supporters.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

headline: California Governor Proposes $750 Million in Annual Film Tax Credits
abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom wants to more than double the amount the state offers in incentives, which would make its program one of the nation’s most generous.
lead_paragraph: Responding to pleas from California’s film industry, which has struggled to rebound from labor unrest and industry disruption, Gov. Gavin Newsom on Sunday announced a proposal to more than double the size of the state’s film tax incentive program to $750 million annually.

headline: Israeli Strike in Sidon Kills Eight People, Lebanon’s Health Ministry Says
abstract: Israel’s military did not provide an immediate comment on the strike, but said earlier on Sunday that it was carrying out “targeted ground raids” in southern Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli strike near the coastal city of Sidon in southern Lebanon killed eight people and wounded 25 others, the country’s health ministry said on Sunday.

headline: Mr. Bezos Went to Washington. But He Never Arrived.
abstract: The billionaire made splashy purchases of The Washington Post and a mansion in Washington. But his status as a power player in the nation’s capital was never realized.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, Jeff Bezos was expected to make a splash in Washington.

headline: An Israeli Strike in Beit Lahia Killed and Injured Dozens of People, Gazan Officials Say
abstract: Israel began a military offensive in the northern part of the enclave several weeks ago, targeting what it said was a regrouped Hamas presence in the area.
lead_paragraph: Israeli strikes on a residential block in Beit Lahia, a town in northern Gaza, killed and wounded dozens of people on Saturday night, according to the Palestinian civil defense, the enclave’s emergency response service.

headline: Michelle Obama’s Plain Words in a Plain Suit
abstract: Who needs a slogan tee when your outfit can say it all?
lead_paragraph: There were no frills. No jewel tones or sunshine shades. No florals.

headline: Advisers Propose That Trump Give Security Clearances Without F.B.I. Vetting
abstract: A memo circulating in Donald Trump’s orbit says that if elected he should use private firms to check appointees’ backgrounds and give them immediate access to classified secrets after taking office.
lead_paragraph: A memo circulating among at least half a dozen advisers to former President Donald J. Trump recommends that if he is elected, he bypass traditional background checks by law enforcement officials and immediately grant security clearances to a large number of his appointees after being sworn in, according to three people briefed on the matter.

headline: Supporting Trump, JD Vance Calls Some Democrats More Dangerous Than Foreign Adversaries
abstract: Mr. Vance made the remark as he sought to defend Donald J. Trump from former members of his administration who said he posed a threat to democracy.
lead_paragraph: JD Vance, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, said on Sunday that he agreed with former President Donald J. Trump that some of his Democratic opponents posed a bigger threat to the United States than foreign adversaries.

headline: Nobody Walks in L.A.? Don’t Tell These Baseball Fans.
abstract: Anticipating the mess of traffic and parking at Dodger Stadium, many of the people who attended the first two games of the World Series found creative ways to get there.
lead_paragraph: A Lakers game at Crypto.com Arena, a U.S.C. game at the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum, a concert at the new Intuit Dome and a rivalry high school football matchup at SoFi Stadium added to the gridlock on L.A.’s freeways on Friday and Saturday. But that didn’t stop Dodgers fans from making their way to Chavez Ravine to see their team battle the Yankees in the first two games of the World Series — with the home team coming away with the win on both nights.

headline: U.S. Navy Apologizes for the 1882 Bombardment of an Alaska Village
abstract: The bombardment and burning of Angoon, in southeastern Alaska, led to widespread suffering and “inflicted intergenerational trauma,” an official said.
lead_paragraph: A U.S. Navy commander on Saturday offered what he called a “long overdue” apology for a bombardment of a native Alaskan community 142 years ago that killed six children and led to widespread suffering during a winter in which residents lacked food and shelter.

headline: Trump Supporters Line Up Early to Fill Madison Square Garden
abstract: Many of the sights of a Trump rally were familiar, if the setting was not: the heart of Manhattan, where registered Democrats outnumber Republicans by about 10 to 1.
lead_paragraph: Outside Madison Square Garden in Manhattan, the streets Sunday afternoon were a sea of red, white and blue. Some people had arrived Saturday morning for former President Donald J. Trump’s rally scheduled for 5 p.m.

headline: Pro-Harris Super PAC Raises Concerns About Focusing on Trump and Fascism
abstract: The group, Future Forward, warned that attacking Donald J. Trump as a fascist or questioning his character or stamina are less effective than highlighting Kamala Harris’s proposals.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

headline: Claire Daly, Master of the Baritone Saxophone, Dies at 66
abstract: She was celebrated for both her playing and her love of the jazz community. “My life in music,” she said recently, “is the smartest thing I’ve done.”
lead_paragraph: Claire Daly, who was regarded by both her fellow musicians and critics as a standard-bearer on the baritone saxophone, died on Tuesday on a friend’s farm in Longmont, Colo. She was 66.

headline: Far-Right Figures Escalate Talk of Retribution and Election Subversion
abstract: Michael Flynn has said “hell” will be unleashed if Donald J. Trump wins. Mr. Flynn’s close associate has discussed plans to overturn the election if Mr. Trump loses.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks after the 2020 election, retired Gen. Michael T. Flynn, Donald J. Trump’s former national security adviser, was a key figure in efforts to subvert the election outcome. In recent interviews and speeches, he and an associate are warning that this year’s election will be stolen from Mr. Trump, advising supporters to take action to prevent a theft and vowing retribution once Mr. Trump is back in power.

headline: Mimi Hines, a Replacement Star in ‘Funny Girl,’ Dies at 91
abstract: She was best known as half of a comedy team with her husband, Phil Ford, until her hall-filling voice earned her raves in a role made famous by Barbra Streisand.
lead_paragraph: Mimi Hines, a powerful singer and live-wire comedian who etched her name in Broadway lore as the replacement for Barbra Streisand in the original production of “Funny Girl,” died on Oct. 21 at her home in Las Vegas. She was 91.

headline: Monday Briefing: A Majority of U.S. Voters Say Democracy is Under Threat
abstract: Plus, a long-lost Chopin waltz.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half of all U.S. voters believe that American democracy does not do a good job of representing ordinary people, according to a new New York Times/Siena College poll.

headline: Woman Who Left Boyfriend Zipped in a Suitcase Is Convicted of Murder
abstract: The woman, Sarah Boone, said the two were drinking and playing hide-and-seek when she zipped him inside the suitcase and then left him overnight.
lead_paragraph: A Florida woman who zipped her boyfriend in a suitcase and then left him to die in it was found guilty of second-degree murder on Friday, according to prosecutors.

headline: Measured Comments From Israel and Iran on New Round of Strikes
abstract: Israel’s prime minister said Israeli airstrikes on Iran had achieved their goals, and Iranian officials did not threaten retaliation.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s leaders emphasized on Sunday that they had a right to respond to Israel’s airstrikes a day earlier but appeared to take a measured tone, as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said that the assault had achieved its objectives.

headline: Operatic Highlight
abstract: Michael Lieberman’s latest puzzle is a real trip.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Tim Walz and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Play Video Games and Talk Politics
abstract: Playing Madden football and Crazy Taxi, Mr. Walz discussed building coalitions and opposing the Senate’s filibuster with Ms. Ocasio-Cortez on Twitch.
lead_paragraph: Wearing a camouflage Vikings hat, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota joined Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Democrat of New York, on Sunday to play Madden NFL 25 and talk about the election.

headline: Trump Rally Opens With Insults Aimed at Latino, Black, Jewish and Arab American Voters
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s rally at Madison Square Garden began with warm-up speakers who made a litany of racist remarks, vulgar insults and profanity-laden comments.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s rally at Madison Square Garden on Sunday opened with a standup comic who called Puerto Rico an “island of garbage” in a set that also included derogatory remarks about Latinos generally, African Americans, Palestinians and Jews.

headline: UnitedHealthcare fee revenue
abstract: In a 2018 presentation, UnitedHealthcare noted the substantial fees it collected per year for its out-of-network savings programs.
lead_paragraph: In a 2018 presentation, UnitedHealthcare noted the substantial fees it collected per year for its out-of-network savings programs.

headline: Pushing employers to ‘more aggressive programs’
abstract: In a 2020 presentation, UMR outlined plans to push employers to potentially more lucrative cost-savings offerings.
lead_paragraph: In a 2020 presentation, UMR outlined plans to push employers to potentially more lucrative cost-savings offerings.

headline: Review: ‘We Live in Cairo’ Falls Short of Being Revolutionary
abstract: Egyptians stand up to their government in a play that excels in its design but rings hollow when its subtext and character development are scrutinized.
lead_paragraph: Building a new world is just as difficult, maybe even more so, as tearing down an old one. Just ask the Arab Spring revolutionaries of “We Live in Cairo,” whose solidarity fractures after they get what they were fighting for.

headline: A Trump Rally Speaker Trashed Puerto Ricans. Harris Reached Out to Them.
abstract: Her campaign moved swiftly to highlight that even as a speaker at Donald Trump’s rally in New York made offensive remarks about Puerto Rico and Latinos, she was visiting Puerto Rican voters in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign moved quickly on Sunday to elevate and denounce racist and inflammatory remarks made by speakers at a rally for former President Donald J. Trump at Madison Square Garden in New York.

headline: Hoaxing Yourself
abstract: People who tell lies and then believe the lies more than anyone else.
lead_paragraph: On This Week’s Episode:

headline: DJ Clark Kent, Who Introduced Jay-Z to Notorious B.I.G., Dies at 58
abstract: He was a producer and club D.J. who helped rappers find their voices and fortunes, and who later became known as a raconteur of hip-hop history.
lead_paragraph: Antonio Franklin, known as DJ Clark Kent, who as a widely respected hip-hop insider for four decades had influential relationships with many leading rappers, died on Thursday at his home in Green Brook, a township in northern New Jersey. He was 58.

headline: McDonald’s Says Tests Rule Out Beef Patties as Source of E. Coli Outbreak
abstract: The company said it would put Quarter Pounders back on the menu, without the raw onions that were considered the likely source of the bacteria.
lead_paragraph: McDonald’s announced on Sunday that tests in Colorado had ruled out its Quarter Pounder beef patties as the source of a deadly E. coli outbreak, and said that the popular burger would be back on the menu at thousands of locations in a dozen states.

headline: Corrections: Oct. 27, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Oct. 27, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 14 this weekend about the comedian Seth Meyers misspelled the name of one of Meyers’s children. It is Ashe, not Ash.

headline: Trump at the Garden: A Closing Carnival of Grievances, Misogyny and Racism
abstract: The inflammatory rally was a capstone for an increasingly aggrieved campaign for Donald Trump, whose rhetoric has grown darker and more menacing.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s closing rally at Madison Square Garden on the second to last Sunday before the election was a release of rage at a political and legal system that impeached, indicted and convicted him, a vivid and at times racist display of the dark energy animating the MAGA movement.

headline: Quote of the Day: There’s Much More To A Midmajor Star Than Meets the Eyes
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I want kids to know it’s OK to be you. You don’t have to change.”

headline: In England’s Most Haunted Village, Halloween Means Screams and Skeptics
abstract: Pluckley is said to count at least 12 spirits among its 1,000 residents. Come October, ghost hunters arrive in droves to a place where even nonbelievers concede they’ve had eerie encounters.
lead_paragraph: Whether or not you believe in the phantom coach and horses, the screaming man, the “watercress lady” engulfed in flames or the legend of the highwayman killed at “fright corner,” it’s hard to ignore ghost stories in Pluckley, England.

headline: Britain Braces for ‘Painful’ Budget Meant to Recharge the Economy
abstract: The new Labour Party government said it had inherited a challenging financial position and warned of tax increases and spending cuts when it reveals its budget this week.
lead_paragraph: As Britain’s Labour Party government prepares to deliver its first budget this week, the message to Britons for the past few months has been a dispiriting warning that they may not like what they hear.

headline: Bullied by China at Sea, With the Broken Bones to Prove It
abstract: A violent attack on a Vietnamese fishing boat tests Hanoi’s muted but resolute approach to China’s aggression in the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: Nguyen Thanh Bien winced as he rubbed his side, turning toward a portrait of Ho Chi Minh in a living room filled with conch shells. He said he was still dealing with internal injuries two weeks after the Chinese authorities boarded his fishing boat and bashed him with iron pipes in a patch of the South China Sea claimed by both China and Vietnam.

headline: Israel Calls the Shots in the Mideast as U.S. Plays a Lesser Role
abstract: A once pivotal player has seen its influence become limited.
lead_paragraph: As the dust settles from Israel’s latest military strikes against Iran, analysts and former diplomats say one thing is clear: Israel, for better or worse, is dictating events in the Middle East. The United States has been relegated to the role of wing man, as its ally wages war on multiple fronts.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Grotesquerie’ and Halloween Movies
abstract: FX airs the finale of Ryan Murphy’s latest show. And various channels celebrate the spooky frights and delights of the holiday.
lead_paragraph: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, Oct. 28-Nov. 3 Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: Americans’ fears about the future of democracy.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half of all U.S. voters believe that American democracy does not do a good job of representing ordinary people, according to a new New York Times/Siena College poll.

headline: Word of the Day: logistical
abstract: This word has appeared in 424 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word logistical has appeared in 424 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 10 in “What’s on the Menu? These Restaurants Aren’t Telling” by Rachel Sugar:

headline: Uruguay’s Presidential Election Is Headed to a November Runoff
abstract: Yamandú Orsi, a center-left former mayor, finished first on Sunday but fell short of the 50 percent threshold needed to avoid another round of voting.
lead_paragraph: Uruguay’s presidential election was pushed into a second round of voting on Sunday, as a center-left former mayor finished ahead of the center-right governing coalition’s candidate.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: In the Race for Congress, a Reporter Starts ‘With a Blank Notebook’
abstract: Catie Edmondson, who has been covering Capitol Hill for The New York Times since 2018, tries to glean patterns that will determine control of the House.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 5, constituents will cast their final ballots for the next president of the United States. But as Electoral College votes are counted, hundreds of races for seats in Congress will play out, too, with their own ability to reshape the national political map.

headline: How New York City’s Migrant Crisis Became a Potent Campaign Issue
abstract: Across New York State, Republican and Democratic candidates are using the city’s migrant crisis to attract voters fearful of its effects on their districts.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of miles from New York City, Republicans desperate to protect a House seat in Central New York aired television ads vilifying Mayor Eric Adams, splicing in images of migrants sleeping on city sidewalks.

headline: When Brian Cashman, the Yankees’ General Manager, Loved the Dodgers
abstract: As the two teams face off in a crucial game at Yankee Stadium on Monday, the longtime Yankees executive recalls a different baseball loyalty.
lead_paragraph: It was one of the best days that Brian Cashman had growing up. He was in sunny Florida, surrounded by his childhood heroes, and he got to wear a Los Angeles Dodgers uniform.

headline: Cross-Tabs: October 2024 Times/Siena Polls of the Likely Electorate in Nebraska and Nebraska’s 2nd C.D.
abstract: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 1,194 voters in Nebraska, including 500 voters in Nebraska’s Second Congressional District, from Oct. 23 to 26, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 1,194 voters in Nebraska, including 500 voters in Nebraska’s Second Congressional District, from Oct. 23 to 26, 2024.

headline: Cross-Tabs: October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of the Likely Electorate in Texas
abstract: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 1,180 voters in Texas from Oct. 23 to 26, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 1,180 voters in Texas from Oct. 23 to 26, 2024.

headline: Toplines: October 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters in Texas
abstract: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 1,180 voters in Texas from Oct. 23 to 26, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 1,180 voters in Texas from Oct. 23 to 26, 2024.

headline: Toplines: October 2024 Times/Siena Polls of Registered Voters in Nebraska and Nebraska’s 2nd C.D.
abstract: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 1,194 voters in Nebraska, including 500 voters in Nebraska’s Second Congressional District, from Oct. 23 to 26, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 1,194 voters in Nebraska, including 500 voters in Nebraska’s Second Congressional District, from Oct. 23 to 26, 2024.

headline: How a Refuge on Rails Inspired Jazz Classics
abstract: For Duke Ellington, Count Basie and Louis Armstrong, even their fame couldn’t fully protect them from the terrifying violence of Jim Crow. But the railroad, particularly the elegant Pullman sleeping car, provided a “home away from home.”
lead_paragraph: Jazz lovers worldwide know well the passion that Duke Ellington, Count Basie and Louis Armstrong had for trains, especially for the elegant Pullman cars that toted them to gigs across the country. Within the velvet-appointed sleeping carriages, African American porters shined the musicians’ shoes, nursed their hangovers, clipped their hair and served them mint juleps and Welsh rarebit — the same service afforded wealthy white passengers.

headline: Why I’m Voting
abstract: Editorial members reflect on their personal stakes in the 2024 election
lead_paragraph: Any candidate for president must make the case to Americans that their vote will make a difference to their communities and to the rest of the country. The stakes of any election are also deeply personal. Members of the Times editorial board explain what is motivating their vote in 2024.

headline: Ella Emhoff, Second Daughter of New York’s Downtown
abstract: The stepdaughter of Vice President Kamala Harris, Ms. Emhoff has largely made a name for herself in New York’s creative scenes, far from Beltway politics.
lead_paragraph: “How can you be ‘childless’ when you have cutie pie kids like Cole and I,” Ella Emhoff, Vice President Kamala Harris’s stepdaughter, posted on Instagram over the summer.

headline: The Mysterious ‘Ketamine Queen’ at the Center of the Matthew Perry Case
abstract: One year after Mr. Perry’s death, Jasveen Sangha is in jail awaiting trial on charges that she sold him the ketamine that killed him.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks after Matthew Perry was discovered floating facedown in a hot tub, the woman who prosecutors say supplied the ketamine that killed the actor was indulging in afternoon tea at a five-star hotel in Japan and taking mirror selfies while modeling a kimono. Several months later, she posted highlights from a trip to Mexico, where she enjoyed caviar at the airport, sitting poolside at the beach and admiring a drink within a coconut.

headline: How Beijing Tamed a Lawless Industry and Gained Global Influence
abstract: State-controlled companies now run an industry once known for its acid pits, radioactive waste and smugglers.
lead_paragraph: As recently as 2010, few industries were as lawless, and yet as central to the global economy, as China’s production of rare earth metals.

headline: What We Lose When Pharmacists Are Forced to Act Like Cops
abstract: How the opioid crisis changed pharmacists’ relationships with their patients.
lead_paragraph: When I entered a tiny pharmacy 11 miles outside of Jackson, Miss., in 2009, the pharmacist, Raymond Bauer, was distraught. Patients were coming “out of the woodwork” to fill opioid prescriptions written in other states. Mr. Bauer feared he was caught in a drug ring. “I’m getting prescriptions from clinics from Houston, Texas,” he said. “I’ve got people coming to this little podunk town from Louisiana by the dozens for thousands of units of hardened narcotics: Oxycodone, other stuff, too.”

headline: Ukrainian Civilians in Once Safe City Fear Growing Menace of Glide Bombs
abstract: Cities in eastern and southern Ukraine are increasingly being hit by Russian glide bombs, converted gravity bombs that can be guided to targets, often landing without detection, residents and officials say.
lead_paragraph: There was no warning, no whistling sound of a missile or buzz of a drone that usually heralds a Russian attack. There was just an explosion, a resident said, and then a pile of smoldering rubble where a small shopping center once stood.

headline: How Taxpayers Are Helping Health Insurers Make Even Bigger Profits
abstract: Local governments often face extra fees when employees get out-of-network medical care, but some don’t track the insurance charges or even know about them.
lead_paragraph: Health insurers have made an enticing pitch to local governments across the country: When your workers see doctors outside your health plan’s network, costs can balloon, but we offer a program to protect against outrageous bills.

headline: In Western North Carolina, Helene’s Devastation Is Threatening Health Care Access
abstract: Dozens of volunteer doctors, nurses and psychologists traveled to the region to treat people whose routines, including medical appointments, were disrupted by the storm.
lead_paragraph: Tina Abbott had already been struggling to stay on top of her medical issues. There was the pain from a tear in her arm tissue, the cyst on her spine and the chronic breathing problems that required a portable oxygen tank, which she had refinanced her car to afford.

headline: If You Think You Can Hold a Grudge, Consider the Crow
abstract: The brainy birds carry big chips on their shoulders, scientists say. And some people who become subjects of their ire may be victims of mistaken identity.
lead_paragraph: Over and over, the crows attacked Lisa Joyce as she ran screaming down a Vancouver street.

headline: A Capitalist for the Little Guy? How Harris Is Pitching Small Business.
abstract: Kamala Harris has leaned in with promises to aid start-ups, but proprietors are often more focused on taxes and regulations.
lead_paragraph: Presidential campaigns often use the backdrop of small businesses — record stores, diners, machine shops — to emphasize their candidates’ authenticity and hometown values. But this election cycle has taken those businesses a bit more seriously.

headline: Piet Mondrian: An Orderly Painter, a Deeply Eccentric Man
abstract: A new biography of one of the quintessential artists of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: The painter David Salle once wrote — he was quoting a friend — that you could recognize one of Alex Katz’s canvases if it fell out of an airplane at 30,000 feet. The same is true of the Dutch-born painter Piet Mondrian (1872-1944). His grids and super-luminous yellows, reds and whites are instantly identifiable.

headline: For a Stalwart Voice of Liberal Catholicism, a Complicated Centennial
abstract: Commonweal magazine, founded in 1924, wrestles with its mission at a moment of a continuing loss of faith in both the church and liberalism.
lead_paragraph: In the Morningside Heights section of Manhattan, near Columbia University, stands a blocky 19-story limestone tower known to some as the “God box.”

headline: The Music Industry Is Hoping Halloween Can Be the New Christmas
abstract: Eyeing the big business of holiday music, a few of pop’s major players are trying to expand the market for Halloween hits.
lead_paragraph: When Ashnikko was growing up in North Carolina, their family told them that Halloween was satanic. But for each of the last six years, the alt-pop rapper and singer (who uses she/they pronouns) has observed what remains a fairly unusual tradition: releasing a single tied to a day better known for costumes and candy.

headline: Broadway Is Singing Louis Armstrong’s Songs. Here Are 6 Classics.
abstract: By exploring Armstrong’s offstage struggles and tensions, “A Wonderful World” wants to shatter the image of an entertainer who was far more than just affable.
lead_paragraph: When Christopher Renshaw was growing up in England in the 1950s and ’60s, everybody knew about Louis Armstrong. “He was an icon for me as a child,” he said. “He was just there — he’s smiling, he’s funny.”

headline: Free Electricity, Anyone? Britain Tries New Tricks to Green Its Grid.
abstract: A utility sends phone alerts when wind power is cheap. A builder sells “zero bill” houses. They’re among several experiments to redefine how people value electricity.
lead_paragraph: Were Heathcliff to roam the blustery moors around Wuthering Heights today, he might be interrupted by a ping on his cellphone saying something like this: The wind is raging, so power is cheap. It’s a good time to plug in the car.

headline: A Pivotal Choice: Trump vs. Harris on Climate Change
abstract: Kamala Harris calls global warming an “existential threat.” Donald Trump dismisses it as a “scam.”
lead_paragraph: The window is closing for nations to reduce enough of the pollution that is heating the planet to avoid the most dangerous levels of climate change, according to scientists across the world. And the outcome of next week’s presidential election could determine whether the United States and other countries meet that challenge.

headline: Japan Is Entering a New Era of Instability
abstract: The Liberal Democrats, long the guiding force for Japan, are in disarray just when their country needs them the most.
lead_paragraph: The political dominance of Japan’s Liberal Democratic Party has been remarkable.

headline: An Unlikely Winner in the Office Real Estate Slump? A Dance Troupe.
abstract: The Paul Taylor Dance Company joins a very short list of dance troupes with substantial real estate in one of the world’s most expensive markets.
lead_paragraph: Likely you’ve heard about the proliferation of empty urban office space since the pandemic and the rise in remote and hybrid work. But if you’ve given any thought to who might fill some of that space, you’ve probably overlooked a promising group: dancers.

headline: $1.75 Million Homes in California
abstract: A new four-bedroom mountain house near Lake Tahoe, a midcentury split-level house in Oakland, and a 1938 Mediterranean-style house in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: This newly built four-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath house is in Tahoe Donner, a homeowners association in the town of Truckee where amenities include swimming pools, downhill and cross-country ski trails, and access to a private beach on Donner Lake. The property has its own trail linking it to the community’s trails. The bars and restaurants in downtown Truckee are 10 minutes away by car.

headline: What Role Does Fear Play in Your Life?
abstract: R.L. Stine, the author of the “Goosebumps” series, shares how he turned his fear into a positive force in his life. What can you learn from him?
lead_paragraph: It’s spooky season, a time of year when people lean into fears and frights with scary movies, haunted houses and gory costumes.

headline: What Threats Does My Vote Really Face?
abstract: Follow your vote from the ballot box to the Electoral College to understand our election system and what obstacles might stand in its way.
lead_paragraph: Follow your vote from the ballot box to the Electoral College to understand our election system and what obstacles might stand in its way.

headline: Trump’s Changing Messages on Abortion, in 660 Quotes
abstract: Donald Trump has softened his rhetoric, contradicted himself and nearly dropped “pro-life” from his vocabulary. Yet there is no evidence that his views on abortion have changed.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has softened his rhetoric, contradicted himself and nearly dropped “pro-life” from his vocabulary. Yet there is no evidence that his views on abortion have changed.

headline: Anita Hill: The Smearing of Kamala Harris
abstract: The insults hurled at Ms. Harris are a reminder of how Republican senators tried to shame me when I challenged Clarence Thomas’s fitness.
lead_paragraph: It’s not easy to remain calm and collected in the glare of intense public scrutiny, especially when the opposition is set on denying your integrity, competence and accomplishments. But call it grace, poise or dignity, Kamala Harris has managed to make a positive case for her candidacy every day since President Biden endorsed her to take his place on the Democratic ticket. Think about it: No presidential nominees in modern history have faced such a direct challenge to the authenticity of their identity and by extension their qualifications to be the president.

headline: The Real Reasons the G.O.P. Is Spending Millions on Anti-Trans Ads
abstract: Republicans are banking on an issue that isn’t a priority for voters: trans rights.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Party has been investing millions of dollars in anti-trans advertisements in a play to reach moderates and voters on the left who feel uncomfortable with or confused by transgender rights. In this episode of “The Opinions,” the New York Times Opinion deputy editor, Patrick Healy, and the columnist M. Gessen discuss these ads and the fear they’re tapping into in American society.

headline: Inside the Movement Behind Trump’s Election Lies
abstract: For years, Republican activists have huddled in video meetings to talk about remaking democracy and plan for the election. The New York Times has obtained the recordings.
lead_paragraph: For years, Republican activists have huddled in video meetings to talk about remaking democracy and plan for the election. The New York Times has obtained the recordings.

headline: Inside a Pro-Trump Network Ready to Challenge the Election
abstract: For years, right-wing activists have huddled in video meetings to talk about how to remake democracy. They’ve spread conspiracy theories about illegal voting and planned meticulously for next week’s election. The New York Times has obtained the recordings. Alexandra Berzon, an investigative reporter covering American politics and elections for The New York Times, explains.
lead_paragraph: For years, right-wing activists have huddled in video meetings to talk about how to remake democracy. They’ve spread conspiracy theories about illegal voting and planned meticulously for next week’s election. The New York Times has obtained the recordings. Alexandra Berzon, an investigative reporter covering American politics and elections for The New York Times, explains.

headline: Clark Art Institute Receives ‘Princely’ Collection of European Treasures
abstract: The Berkshires museum is getting a transformative gift: 331 artworks from the Renaissance on, worth several hundred million dollars, and money to build a new wing.
lead_paragraph: Museums are lucky if they receive either a large collection of valuable artworks or a big check. Getting both at the same time is rare.

headline: What Is the Perfect Length for a Winter Coat?
abstract: Looking ahead to colder weather, a reader wonders if there is an ideal cut for coats. Our fashion critic offers advice on balancing fashion and function.
lead_paragraph: Of all the garments in a wardrobe, a coat may be the most fraught. Especially a winter coat.

headline: Happy 120th Birthday, New York City Subway!
abstract: The first subway train left from City Hall on Oct. 27, 1904. Riders on the C train say the subway is essential to their lives as New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at a very important New York City institution that is 120 years old.

headline: Democrats Won the Ad War. Will It Be Enough?
abstract: Here’s what we learned after analyzing 3.7 million election ads.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what we learned after analyzing 3.7 million election ads.

headline: Michelle Obama: ‘I Am Asking You, From the Core of My Being, to Take Our Lives Seriously’
abstract: The former first lady shares an emotional appeal about how reproductive rights are on the line in this election.
lead_paragraph: The following is excerpted from Mrs. Obama’s speech on Saturday at a Kamala Harris rally in Kalamazoo, Mich.

headline: ‘Crazy’ Is Beginning to Sound Like an Understatement
abstract: Election Day can’t come soon enough.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. We are a week out from the election. Kamala Harris said the other day that she thinks Donald Trump is a fascist. Do you agree?

headline: State of the Race: National Polls Tighten With 8 Days to Go
abstract: State polls remain steady, and two new polls in Texas and Nebraska show Senate control may still be in play.
lead_paragraph: Results and analysis of new polls in the Senate races in Texas and Nebraska are at the bottom of this article.

headline: Republicans Cling to Slim Leads in Nebraska and Texas Senate Races
abstract: In Nebraska, Dan Osborn, an independent, is in a tight race with Senator Deb Fischer, and in Texas, Representative Colin Allred is four percentage points behind Senator Ted Cruz.
lead_paragraph: Dan Osborn, a union leader and political independent, is within striking distance of Senator Deb Fischer, Republican of Nebraska, while in Texas, Representative Colin Allred, a Democrat, has more ground to make up against Senator Ted Cruz, according to new polls from The New York Times and Siena College.

headline: Your questions about The Times’s election coverage: ‘Sane-washing’
abstract: Our journalists answer questions from readers
lead_paragraph: First of all, thank you for reading The Times and for the question, which I have heard from other readers during this election cycle.

headline: Your questions about The Times’s election coverage: Choosing which reporters cover which candidates
abstract: Our journalists answer questions from readers.
lead_paragraph: We have a mix of campaign-coverage veterans and fresh-eyed newcomers writing about the candidates in not only the presidential contest, but in other races across the country. Some of our political reporters bring decades of experience — like Adam Nagourney, who has covered 10 presidential elections — while others are on campaign trails for the first time in their careers.

headline: Your questions about The Times’s election coverage: False claims about election integrity
abstract: Our journalists answer questions from readers.
lead_paragraph: We have several reporters focused on Trump’s false claims about the legitimacy of the 2020 election and false claims made during this campaign cycle, such as about Haitian immigrants eating pets — and their many consequences. First and foremost, we try to debunk any false claim as quickly as possible. But we also go much deeper, looking into the source, tracking how something spreads across social media and examining real-world consequences.

headline: Your questions about The Times’s election coverage: When do we call races?
abstract: Our journalists answer questions from readers.
lead_paragraph: The Times will not call a race before all polls are scheduled to close in a state. A claim of victory — or a concession — by a candidate is not the same as a race call.

headline: Your questions about The Times’s election coverage: Polling and 2016
abstract: Our journalists answer questions from readers.
lead_paragraph: The 2016 polls have, understandably, left a lot of people feeling anxious about the performance of the polls this time around. Interestingly, in 2016 the national polls were actually fairly accurate, but polls in key states underestimated Donald Trump’s support by a wide margin. Pollsters did correct for those errors by accounting for the fact that voters were increasingly polarized by education. (More non-college-educated voters were moving toward Republicans, and polls were not adjusting by education level to account for that.) But then in 2020, polling again had a big miss, and this time the reasons were less clear. It could have been that the coronavirus pandemic scrambled the ways in which people voted, or that there was record turnout that year.

headline: Your questions about The Times’s election coverage: Choosing the top story
abstract: Our journalists answer questions from readers.
lead_paragraph: Reporters are responsible only for covering the stories they are assigned or the candidates whose campaigns they follow. They don’t get a say in where their stories run, or how their stories are displayed. Neither do their immediate editors, whose sole responsibility is to edit stories for content, style and grammar.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,228
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Oct. 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 506
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Oct. 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: A Final Week of Campaigning, and Measured Words After Airstrikes on Iran
abstract: Plus, hear a long-lost Chopin waltz.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The Trump Campaign’s Big Gamble
abstract: A look inside the operation’s field office in Maricopa County, Ariz.
lead_paragraph: Warning: this episode contains strong language.

headline: Duterte Says He Takes ‘Full Legal Responsibility’ for Philippine Drug War
abstract: Former President Rodrigo Duterte was defiant in Senate testimony about the years of bloodshed that left thousands dead. “I did it for my country,” he said.
lead_paragraph: The former Philippine president Rodrigo Duterte defended his so-called war on drugs in testimony before the country’s Senate on Monday, saying he took “full legal responsibility” for the campaign of extrajudicial killings that left thousands dead and is being investigated by the International Criminal Court.

headline: Scott Durkin, C.E.O. of Douglas Elliman Realty, Fired Amid Company Turmoil
abstract: Scott Durkin, president and chief executive of Douglas Elliman Realty, has left the company, following the sudden retirement of Howard Lorber, the chief executive of the parent company.
lead_paragraph: The president and chief executive of the Douglas Elliman brokerage has been terminated, less than a week after the sudden retirement of Howard Lorber, the parent company’s chief executive officer.

headline: The 2024 Stakes on Health Care
abstract: We explore the presidential candidates’ health policy proposals.
lead_paragraph: After several elections with health care at the forefront, the issue has faded into the background this cycle. But the stakes are still high.

headline: Meloni Battles Judges in Italy Over Her Anti-Migrant Plan
abstract: Conservatives in the country have often accused the courts of overreach. Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni’s plan to outsource asylum requests is now part of that longstanding battle.
lead_paragraph: Italy’s prime minister, Giorgia Meloni, had scored a coup. She pushed through a tough anti-migration plan that would force some asylum seekers headed for Italy instead into a detention center in Albania while their claims are heard. At a time when anti-immigration sentiments are rising in Europe, the program caught the eyes of other European leaders who viewed it as a potential blueprint.

headline: New Horror for Readers Who Want to Be Completely Terrified
abstract: Our columnist reviews October’s new horror books.
lead_paragraph: The town at the center of Yvonne Battle-Felton’s new novel, CURDLE CREEK (Holt, 292 pp., $27.99), is a small, all-Black, separatist community with a strict population policy: “One in, one out.” To keep the enclave safe, there are many yearly rituals required of residents, including Moving On, Warding Off, the Calling and the Running of the Widows.

headline: A Seismic Election Sends Asia’s Most Stable Democracy Into Chaos
abstract: Deep-seated grievance among Japanese voters has put the Liberal Democrats, longstanding custodians of the status quo, on notice.
lead_paragraph: For years, Japan has managed to resist the populist waves that have swept Europe and the United States as disaffected electorates have demanded radical change.

headline: What Japan’s Political Uncertainty Means for Its Market Rally
abstract: The long-ruling Liberal Democratic Party has lost its parliamentary majority, raising questions about the policy stability that has lured investors.
lead_paragraph: The steady course of the Japanese economy and business environment that has helped attract a torrent of investment in the past two years could be undercut by the political turmoil resulting from the country’s parliamentary elections on Sunday.

headline: Democrats Use Gas Station Kiosks to Say Trump Will Make Life More Expensive
abstract: The Democratic National Committee will run the 15-second ads in Michigan, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Iowa and Nebraska.
lead_paragraph: Americans bagging up their purchases at hundreds of gas stations and convenience stores across the Midwest will hear a message from Democrats that former President Donald J. Trump’s policies will increase the price of fuel and add thousands of dollars to the cost of raising a family.

headline: Corporate America Hedges on Trump 2.0
abstract: The race for the White House is deadlocked, but business leaders aren’t taking chances, reaching out to the former president to rebuild relations.
lead_paragraph: As the presidential race nears its end next week, the most notable public sound from many C.E.O.s and businesses on the election has been silence — and Donald Trump’s camp is increasingly interpreting that as a sign that corporate America may be preparing for him to win.

headline: Tommy Robinson, Anti-Immigrant Agitator in Britain, Sentenced to Jail
abstract: The founder of the English Defence League was sentenced to 18 months for ignoring a court order to stop making false claims about a teenage Syrian refugee.
lead_paragraph: Tommy Robinson, Britain’s best-known far-right and anti-immigrant agitator, was sentenced on Monday to 18 months in prison for defying a court order by repeating false claims about a teenage Syrian refugee who had successfully sued him for libel.

headline: Israeli Forces Withdraw From Northern Gaza Hospital After 3-Day Raid
abstract: The Gaza health ministry said the staff of the facility, Kamal Adwan Hospital, had been expelled or detained and urged people in Gaza with surgical skills to go there to save those patients they could.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said on Monday that its forces had withdrawn from a hospital in the northern Gaza Strip after a three-day raid during which Palestinian health officials said nearly all of the medical workers at the complex were detained and two children died.

headline: Ukraine Braces for Russians to Assault With North Korean Troops
abstract: Several thousand North Korean soldiers have arrived in Russia’s western Kursk region, where they are expected to support Moscow’s efforts to dislodge invading Ukrainian forces.
lead_paragraph: The United States warned on Monday that North Korean soldiers were moving toward Russia’s western Kursk region, which Ukraine invaded in August, as Ukrainian forces braced for what they said could be imminent assaults involving the new troops.

headline: This Three-Ingredient Fish Dish Is Minimalist Magic
abstract: Eric Kim’s scallion-oil fish turns olive oil, alliums and white fish fillets into a simple, luscious dinner.
lead_paragraph: Who isn’t stirred by the ease and brevity of a three-ingredient recipe? Minimalist dishes are kitchen haikus — short, focused compositions that get right to the essence of their ingredients.

headline: How Are the World’s Trees Doing? A New Assessment Has Answers.
abstract: They play an essential role in supporting life on Earth, but many species are in decline, researchers found.
lead_paragraph: More than a third of the world’s tree species are threatened with extinction, according to the first comprehensive assessment of trees by the world’s leading scientific authority on the status of species.

headline: Boeing Will Sell $19 Billion in Stock as Strike Weighs on Finances
abstract: The aerospace company, locked in a standoff with striking workers, is seeking to shore up its balance sheet and avoid a credit rating downgrade.
lead_paragraph: Boeing on Monday began to raise roughly $19 billion by selling stock, an attempt to shore up its finances as a costly and disruptive worker strike weighs on the plane maker’s balance sheet.

headline: Paul Morrissey, Andy Warhol’s Cinematic Collaborator, Dies at 86
abstract: In films like “Trash” and “Women in Revolt,” he brought movement, character and something resembling a story line to the Warhol film aesthetic.
lead_paragraph: Paul Morrissey, whose loose cinéma-vérité films made with Andy Warhol in the late 1960s and early ’70s captured New York’s demimonde of drug addicts, drag queens and hipsters and turned an unlikely stable of amateur actors into underground stars, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: As Gaza Talks Resume, Little Progress Is Expected Before the U.S. Election
abstract: Analysts said Israel was expected to wait until the outcome of the election before deciding on its stance on a cease-fire in Gaza. Hamas officials seem reluctant to compromise.
lead_paragraph: As the Biden administration makes a final diplomatic push in the Middle East before next week’s U.S. presidential election, little is expected to be achieved before the result is known, officials and analysts in the region said on Monday.

headline: The Rebellious Scientist Who Made Kamala Harris
abstract: The presidential candidate’s mother, Shyamala Gopalan Harris, was a breast cancer researcher whose egalitarian politics often bucked a patriarchal lab culture.
lead_paragraph: On her first day of work, the young bioengineering major climbed down the basement steps of a cancer laboratory in Berkeley, Calif., and caught sight of someone summarily beheading a mouse.

headline: How Well Do You Know Classic Books for Halloween Reading?
abstract: Magic, madness and supernatural horror have driven many book plots over the centuries. This short quiz scares up several popular novels to test your knowledge.
lead_paragraph: Magic, madness and supernatural horror have driven many book plots over the centuries. This short quiz scares up several popular novels to test your knowledge.

headline: That’s a Lot of Cheddar: Scammers Steal $390,000 of British Cheese
abstract: Neal’s Yard, a leading cheese retailer in London, said that a shipment of 22 metric tons of rare Cheddar had disappeared in the con.
lead_paragraph: It’s been called “the grate cheese robbery.”

headline: Wages Have Outpaced Inflation. But Not for Everyone.
abstract: On average, pay has risen faster than prices in recent years. But the overall picture is complicated — and it’s not just facts versus “vibes.”
lead_paragraph: Have Americans’ paychecks kept up with the cost of living over the past several years?

headline: Corrections: Oct. 28, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Timothée Chalamet Showed Up at His Own Look-Alike Contest
abstract: No, he didn’t enter. But he still caused a stir in Washington Square Park, where four people were arrested.
lead_paragraph: It was a bit of fun in Washington Square Park: a contest to see who looked the most like the actor and heartthrob Timothée Chalamet.

headline: 5 Eerie Games to Haunt During Halloween Week
abstract: Everyone has secrets to conceal in Life Is Strange: Double Exposure, a supernatural thriller with parallel timelines.
lead_paragraph: You’re utterly alone. Blood drips onto snow. A fanged entity slashes your significant other. A monstrous chase ends in death. Just in time for Halloween, five affecting horror games are full of harrowing alienation and loneliness.

headline: Trump’s Vast Tariffs Would Rock Global Businesses and Shake Alliances
abstract: Economists said Donald Trump’s plan to return trade barriers to levels not seen in generations would be “a grenade thrown in the heart” of the international system.
lead_paragraph: At a rally in Latrobe, Pa., earlier this month, former President Donald J. Trump paused in front of a crowd holding signs that read “Save Our Steel” to pay homage to one of his favorite concepts.

headline: Bloomberg, After Months of Pressure, Donates $50 Million to Help Harris
abstract: The former mayor of New York City is known for making political donations late in the campaign season. Democrats had been lobbying him to spend more.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York City, under extraordinary pressure from friends and fellow billionaires to do more to help Vice President Kamala Harris, recently donated about $50 million to a nonprofit organization that is supporting her presidential run, according to four people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Why a Key Biden Effort to Boost Affordable Housing Has Faced Hurdles
abstract: The Biden administration rolled out a plan last year to create more housing by unlocking more than $35 billion in lending capacity. It has yet to close on any loans that would support housing-related projects.
lead_paragraph: When company officials at Resia, a multifamily housing developer based in South Florida, first heard about a new Biden administration effort to provide low-interest loans for housing projects near transit stations, they thought it was a “very attractive opportunity.”

headline: Timothée Chalamet Crashes Look-alike Contest
abstract: The Oscar-nominated actor showed up unannounced to a look-alike contest for himself in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The Oscar-nominated actor showed up unannounced to a look-alike contest for himself in New York City.

headline: The Presidential Endorsements That Weren’t
abstract: Readers both decry and praise the decision by The Washington Post and The Los Angeles Times not to endorse. Also: An early voter; the New York Historical.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: MAGA Unchained in Madison Square Garden
abstract: Trump’s big rally featured unadulterated racism and more talk of “enemies from within.”
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s MAGA Lollapalooza at Madison Square Garden on Sunday began with an iconic scene from the 1970 biopic “Patton” on the jumbotron. Strutting in front of a giant American flag, George C. Scott, playing the legendary World War II general, growled, of the Nazis, “We’re not just going to shoot the bastards. We’re going to cut out their living guts and use them to grease the treads of our tanks.” While it was nice, I suppose, to hear anti-Hitler rhetoric at a Trump rally, the belligerent talk of total war was unnerving in the context of a campaign focused on crushing internal enemies.

headline: Volkswagen May Close German Plants for First Time in Its History
abstract: The auto maker’s top employee representative told workers that management planned to shutter three German factories to cut costs amid slumping sales.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen could shut down as many as three factories in Germany and lay off tens of thousands of workers as it seeks to regain its edge in Europe amid slumping sales and increased competition from China, the company’s top employee representative said Monday.

headline: ‘Lady Blogs’ Would Have Had a Field Day With This Election
abstract: The robust feminist blogosphere of 2016 is all but gone. Some of the creators are missing its perspective.
lead_paragraph: It was 2016, and the future was female.

headline: Investigators Identify ‘Suspect Vehicle’ in Ballot Drop Box Fires in the Pacific Northwest
