abstract: Hundreds of ballots may have been destroyed in Washington, while a fire suppressant protected most of the ballots in Portland.
lead_paragraph: Two ballot drop boxes in the Pacific Northwest were set ablaze in apparent cases of arson in the early morning hours on Monday, and elections officials at one site said they feared that hundreds of ballots had been destroyed.

headline: The Misogynistic, Bigoted and Crude Rally Remarks Trump Hasn’t Disavowed
abstract: A range of speakers at Madison Square Garden on Sunday disparaged Latinos, Black people, Palestinians and Jews, and made vulgar references to Kamala Harris. The Trump campaign has distanced itself from only one of these statements.
lead_paragraph: By the time former President Donald J. Trump took the stage at Madison Square Garden on Sunday, a parade of speakers had already spent hours disparaging Latinos, Black people, Palestinians and Jews; directing misogynistic comments at Vice President Kamala Harris; and echoing language used by the Ku Klux Klan.

headline: Recruiting Gen Z Voters With ‘Poll Dancers’ and Yung Gravy
abstract: The Party to the Polls Purple Tour, a nonpartisan event series geared toward young voters, aims to make voting rowdy.
lead_paragraph: The rapper Yung Gravy has a pitch for young people who may be on the fence about voting.

headline: Jon Stewart Extends ‘Daily Show’ Run Through 2025
abstract: Stewart, who returned to the show in February as a host on Monday nights, originally planned to work through the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Jon Stewart is sticking around. After nearly nine months with Stewart back at the desk of “The Daily Show,” Comedy Central announced on Monday that he would continue to host the show on Monday nights through 2025.

headline: Whether Harris or Trump Wins, Seeking Asylum in the U.S. May Never Be the Same
abstract: As administrations of both parties have failed to overhaul the nation’s immigration laws, a reckoning for the asylum system, which some say is overdue, seems inevitable.
lead_paragraph: For decades, granting political asylum has been part of the story that the United States has told about itself. As a Western democracy and a nation of immigrants, that national ethos goes, America has an obligation to offer safe harbor to people fleeing persecution in their home countries.

headline: Adam Schiff, Not Yet a Senator, Deploys to Bolster Potential Future Colleagues
abstract: With his election in California all but assured, the prominent Donald Trump antagonist is spending the final days of the race trying to help Democrats in the battlegrounds over the finish line.
lead_paragraph: On Friday night, Steve Garvey, the former Major League Baseball star and current Republican candidate for Senate in California, was at Dodger Stadium cheering on the home team as it faced off against the New York Yankees in this first game of the World Series.

headline: He Was 5 When Border Agents Took Him From His Father. He Hasn’t Forgotten.
abstract: Seven years after a Trump policy ruptured his family and landed him in foster care, José is a star student. But he is still scarred. “I don’t trust anyone.”
lead_paragraph: For José and his family, the moment still feels raw, all these years later.

headline: Harris Campaign Distances Itself From Biden in the Crucial Final Days
abstract: Joint events with an unpopular incumbent would “only hurt” the vice president at this stage of the campaign, as one of her advisers put it. But the president does not want to be sidelined.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

headline: Harris Aides Quietly Grow More Bullish on Defeating Trump
abstract: While still cautious, advisers and allies believe that casting Donald Trump as a fascist is working, and that their expansive ground game and appeals on abortion rights may carry the day.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

headline: Gérard Depardieu’s Sexual Assault Trial in France Is Postponed Until March
abstract: The French movie star’s lawyer said poor health kept his client from court on Monday.
lead_paragraph: For years, accusations of groping, sexual harassment and sexual assault have been made against the French movie star Gérard Depardieu — all of which he has denied.

headline: Israel’s Parliament Opens With Passage of Bill Banning U.N. Agency
abstract: Israel’s Knesset began its winter session on Monday against a backdrop of war in Gaza and Lebanon and with some contentious matters on the agenda.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s Knesset opened its winter session on Monday by passing bills that could threaten the work of the main U.N. agency that assists Palestinians, UNRWA.

headline: Who Is Tony Hinchcliffe, the Trump Rally Comedian?
abstract: Known for insult-style comedy, he took aim at Latinos, African Americans, Palestinians and Jews at Madison Square Garden on Sunday, and called Puerto Rico a “floating island of garbage.”
lead_paragraph: The stand-up comedian Tony Hinchcliffe took the stage early in former President Donald J. Trump’s rally at Madison Square Garden on Sunday, hurling a wave of insults and vulgar statements at minority groups including Jews, Latinos and African Americans.

headline: Man Who Made Violent Threats Skirted Arrest and Then Shot a Neighbor
abstract: “We failed this victim 100 percent,” the Minneapolis police chief said after criticism that the shooter, who had active arrest warrants, was not taken into custody sooner.
lead_paragraph: A man in Minneapolis hit a neighbor with a stick and threatened others with a knife and a gun, according to court records, and though warrants were issued, the police never arrested him. Then he shot a neighbor.

headline: Where to Travel This Winter, Whether You Want Sun or Snow
abstract: Here are five places, from coastal Norway to Marrakesh, with exceptional hotels that still have availability for the holidays.
lead_paragraph: Planning a vacation for the week between Christmas and New Years can feel anything but festive. Hotel and rental rates are generally at their peak, many properties require weeklong or 10-night minimums and rooms book up fast. But below are 15 great hotels in enticing destinations that — at press time — still have openings for at least a few days between Dec. 21 and Jan. 1 and, while minimum stays vary widely during that period, many of the places included here don’t insist on more than a two- or three-night stay. (The rates listed below are for Christmas week.) Better still, use this list as inspiration for a getaway in January, February or early spring and enjoy the perks of shoulder season: lower prices and fewer tourists.

headline: Man Gets Life Without Parole in Kidnapping and Murder of Memphis Teacher
abstract: Cleotha Abston’s guilty plea in the September 2022 killing of Eliza Fletcher spared him a possible death sentence, his lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: A Tennessee man who kidnapped and killed a teacher in September 2022 was sentenced on Monday to life in prison without parole after pleading guilty in an arrangement that spared him from a possible death sentence.

headline: It Shouldn’t Be This Easy to Sign Away Your Right to a Trial
abstract: Arbitration caught on for good reason, but it has drifted too far from its original purpose.
lead_paragraph: A century ago, arbitration was a hot item. President Calvin Coolidge signed the Federal Arbitration Act on Feb. 12, 1925. It recognized private dispute resolution as a valid alternative to trials, and the arbitrator’s decisions in such disputes as binding, albeit subject to limited judicial review.

headline: John F. Keenan, U.S. Judge in Myerson and Marcos Trials, Dies at 94
abstract: He was impatient with courtroom theatrics, and the Manhattan trials of the commissioner and ex-beauty queen Bess Myerson and the former Philippines first lady Imelda Marcos had plenty.
lead_paragraph: John F. Keenan, a longtime federal judge in Manhattan who presided over the high-profile trials of Bess Myerson, a popular former cultural-affairs commissioner in New York City and ex-beauty queen, and Imelda Marcos, the extravagant former first lady of the Philippines, died on Sunday at his home in the Bronx. He was 94.

headline: Waymo Raises $5.6 Billion From Outside Investors
abstract: Alphabet’s driverless car unit now has vehicles operating in San Francisco, Phoenix and Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Amid its push to grow its fleet of autonomous robot taxis and expand into new cities, Waymo has raised $5.6 billion from outside investors, its largest funding round to date.

headline: ‘Dahomey’ Celebrated Looted Art’s Return. What Happened Next?
abstract: Since the documentary’s cameras stopped rolling, plans for a new museum to showcase the treasures have stalled, and the artifacts are once again off limits to the public in Benin.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the movie “Dahomey,” the eerie voice of a 19th century West African king emerges from the depths of history.

headline: Jeff Bezos Defends Decision to End Washington Post Endorsements
abstract: Mr. Bezos, the newspaper’s owner, said that presidential endorsements “create a perception of bias” and that “my views here are, in fact, principled.”
lead_paragraph: Jeff Bezos, the billionaire owner of The Washington Post, whose decision to end presidential endorsements at the paper set off a firestorm inside and outside the paper last week, said on Monday in his first comments about the change that it had been done to improve the newsroom’s credibility, not to protect his own personal interests.

headline: Bannon’s Release From Prison Will Unleash an Agitator Into a Heated Campaign
abstract: Allies say Stephen K. Bannon, one of the right’s most influential voices, has been tracking the race from prison and is ready to push Trump supporters to the polls.
lead_paragraph: When Stephen K. Bannon reported to federal prison almost four months ago, he left his podcast in the hands of lesser-known pundits and a void in the right-wing messaging machine behind Donald J. Trump.

headline: Biden Waits in Line and Casts His Vote for Harris
abstract: The president and onetime nominee stood with more than a hundred early voters on Monday in Delaware. He said the moment was “just sweet,” not bittersweet.
lead_paragraph: With eight days to Nov. 5, President Biden on Monday stood in line with more than a hundred early voters in Delaware and cast his ballot for Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: In Montana, Republican Tim Sheehy Tries to Outrun Jon Tester, and Scrutiny
abstract: The novice Republican candidate’s honesty has come into question in a race that could decide Senate control.
lead_paragraph: Tim Sheehy, the novice Republican candidate in perhaps the most important Senate race in the country, was not downplaying his lack of a political pedigree when he stepped in front of a welcoming audience at the American Legion hall in downtown Big Timber, Mont.

headline: Harris Ties Trump to the Fatal Fallout of Abortion Bans
abstract: An ad from the Harris campaign highlights the death of Amber Nicole Thurman, a Georgia woman whose delay in medical care was reportedly tied to the state’s post-Roe abortion restrictions.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign has been running this 60-second ad on television stations in Georgia this month, and has spent $348,367 on it since it first aired on Oct. 16, according to AdImpact.

headline: British Labour Lawmaker Suspended After Punches Thrown
abstract: Video that emerged over the weekend appeared to show Mike Amesbury, a Labour party lawmaker, hitting a man in the face and then repeatedly landing more body blows.
lead_paragraph: A British lawmaker was suspended by the governing Labour Party on Monday, after video appeared to show him punching a man in the face, knocking him down, and then repeatedly hitting him as he was lying in the street.

headline: Philadelphia District Attorney Sues Musk Over $1 Million Voter Giveaways
abstract: Larry Krasner, the top prosecutor in Philadelphia, sued Elon Musk and his Trump-supporting super PAC, saying the giveaways amounted to an “unlawful lottery.”
lead_paragraph: District Attorney Larry Krasner of Philadelphia filed a lawsuit on Monday to stop Elon Musk and his Trump-supporting organization, America PAC, from continuing their $1 million daily giveaway in Pennsylvania, calling it an illegal lottery scheme to influence voters in the presidential election.

headline: Republicans Distance Themselves From Puerto Rico Insult at Trump’s Rally
abstract: A comedian who spoke at Donald Trump’s campaign rally at Madison Square Garden referred to the U.S. territory as a “floating island of garbage,” prompting immediate backlash.
lead_paragraph: Republicans moved quickly to distance themselves from remarks disparaging Puerto Rico made on Sunday by a comedian at the Madison Square Garden rally for Donald J. Trump, a reflection of growing party concern that fallout from the event could hurt Mr. Trump with a critical voting constituency in the final days of this campaign.

headline: The Cookies You Want to Bake on Election Day
abstract: Rich with browned butter pecans and chewy with oats, these foolproof cookies are the perfect thing to make — and eat — while results roll in.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of the 2020 presidential election, interest in election cake resurfaced from its heyday more than 200 years ago. While mentions of the cake predate the American Revolution, the first-known published recipe is in the 1796 book “American Cookery” by Amelia Simmons. That yeast-risen butter cake called for a pint of wine and quart of brandy, which sounds pretty great.

headline: Trump Hints at ‘Little Secret’ With House Republicans, Setting Off a Panic
abstract: The former president seemed to delight in fueling speculation about what he is cooking up with House Republicans, prompting Democrats to worry about election fraud. Speaker Mike Johnson refused to explain.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Mike Johnson was taking in former President Donald J. Trump’s grievance-fueled closing rally at Madison Square Garden on Sunday afternoon when the main actor onstage turned to him and drew him into the drama.

headline: Trump Team Fears Damage From Racist Rally Remarks
abstract: The Trump campaign issued a rare statement distancing itself from a comedian’s offensive joke about Puerto Rico at his rally on Sunday, a sign that it was concerned about losing crucial votes.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and his allies are full of bravado over his chances of victory in the closing days of the 2024 campaign. But there are signs, publicly and privately, that the former president and his team are worried that their opponents’ descriptions of him as a racist and a fascist may be breaking through to segments of voters.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: The U.S. Campaign’s Final Stretch
abstract: Plus, the “Ketamine Queen.”
lead_paragraph: With one week to go until Election Day, Kamala Harris is centering her closing argument on the stakes of another Trump presidency. Donald Trump held a provocative closing rally in New York City.

headline: Gaza Cease-Fire Talks Resume, but Are Overshadowed by U.S. Election
abstract: Envoys from Israel, Egypt, the United States and Qatar took part in the negotiations, but no agreements are expected until American voters choose their next president.
lead_paragraph: As international negotiators discussed a cease-fire in the Gaza Strip on Monday, officials and analysts said there was little expectation that Israel and Hamas would agree to a truce before the American presidential election next Tuesday.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Chief Stirs Criticism With Newsmax Appearance at Trump Rally
abstract: John Chell also went on other networks, but struck a nerve by appearing on a channel that has boosted conspiracy theories and misinformation.
lead_paragraph: A high-ranking New York City police chief drew criticism after appearing on a conservative news channel in full uniform at Donald J. Trump’s Madison Square Garden rally, with detractors saying he seemed to lend support to the Republican presidential nominee.

headline: Iran Executes German-Iranian Opponent Who Lived in U.S.
abstract: Jamshid Sharmahd had been accused of helping in a deadly terrorist bombing in 2008. Another Iranian prisoner, the Nobel laureate Narges Mohammadi, is in the hospital.
lead_paragraph: Iran on Monday executed an Iranian-born opponent of the government who had German citizenship and lived in the United States, the country’s judiciary announced, four years after Iranian agents abducted him in Dubai, according to members of his family.

headline: How Bad Are Gas Stoves for My Health?
abstract: They emit harmful pollutants, which makes good ventilation crucial.
lead_paragraph: However much you may love cooking on your gas stove, it’s bad for your health.

headline: U.S. Officials Sweep Troubled Brooklyn Prison Where 2 Were Killed
abstract: Two inmates were fatally stabbed this summer at the federal Metropolitan Detention Center, where Sean Combs is awaiting trial in his sex-trafficking case.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Department of Justice and other law enforcement agencies on Monday morning conducted a sweep of a dangerous federal prison in Brooklyn where two detainees were fatally stabbed this summer.

headline: Musk Repeatedly Raises the Idea That Harris, or He, Could Be Assassinated
abstract: The billionaire and his PAC have used foreboding language about the vice president in their support of former President Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: In speeches to pro-Trump voters across Pennsylvania, Elon Musk has repeated a line he uses about the assassination of Vice President Kamala Harris — saying it would be pointless because she is a “puppet” of unnamed Washington power brokers.

headline: Steve Mariotti, Whose Trauma Led Him to Help Youths at Risk, Dies at 71
abstract: After he was mugged, he took a therapist’s advice to work with “difficult students at a difficult school.” They ignored him until the lessons turned to business.
lead_paragraph: Steve Mariotti, a teacher in some of New York’s roughest schools who discovered that his bored, disrespectful students suddenly tuned in when he talked about running a business, inspiring him to create an organization that has taught business skills to more than 1 million at-risk youths in the U.S. and abroad, died on Oct. 20 in Union City, N.J. He was 71.

headline: Rally Backlash Puts Trump on the Defensive
abstract: Also, North Korean troops were deployed to help Russian forces. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump and his allies are full of bravado over his chances of victory in November. But there are signs that the former president and his team are worried that their opponents’ descriptions of him as a racist and a fascist may be breaking through to segments of voters.

headline: A Caller Told 911 a Bear Had Chased Him Off a Cliff. The Police Say It Was Murder.
abstract: The sheriff in a rural Tennessee county said his office is searching for a man who used a stolen identity to pose as a victim.
lead_paragraph: The 911 caller in rural Tennessee told a dispatcher on Oct. 18 that he had been injured when a bear chased him off a cliff and into water. But when emergency workers arrived, the authorities said, they found something entirely different.

headline: Michelle Obama Decries a ‘Double Standard’ in Treatment of Trump and Harris
abstract: As Donald Trump’s rhetoric grows more extreme, liberals say Kamala Harris is being held, unfairly, to a higher bar by voters and the media. One is “allowed to be lawless while the other one has to be flawless,” a congresswoman said.
lead_paragraph: For three months, as Vice President Kamala Harris has pressed her case for the White House, some voters have insisted they just don’t know enough about her. Pundits have grumbled that she is light on specifics; journalists have lamented that she wasn’t doing more interviews, or answering tougher questions, or answering easy questions more crisply. Her opponents have cast her as an “empty suit,” a lightweight with dangerous ideas.

headline: Latinos Blast Disparaging Remarks Made at Trump’s N.Y.C. Rally
abstract: Latinos warned that the racist and vulgar insults made by some speakers at Donald J. Trump’s rally in New York City — particularly those by a stand-up comic — could cost the former president votes this election.
lead_paragraph: Latinos warned that the racist and vulgar insults made by some speakers at Donald J. Trump’s rally in New York City — particularly those by a stand-up comic — could cost the former president votes this election.

headline: Louisiana State Trooper Avoids Jail in Death of Ronald Greene
abstract: In an agreement with prosecutors, Kory York, a former state trooper, pleaded no contest to misdemeanor battery charges in exchange for one year of probation in the death of a Black man who was stopped for a traffic violation in 2019.
lead_paragraph: A former Louisiana state trooper who had faced felony charges in the 2019 death of a Black man who was beaten while in police custody pleaded no contest to significantly reduced charges on Monday, allowing him to avoid jail time in a case that drew protests and spurred a federal civil rights investigation.

headline: Woman Charged With Hate Crime in Pepper-Spraying of Muslim Uber Driver
abstract: Prosecutors said the woman, Jennifer Guilbeault, attacked Shohel Mahmud without provocation after he began to pray in Arabic while stopped at a traffic light. She has pleaded not guilty.
lead_paragraph: Shohel Mahmud had no obvious reason to worry when he picked up two young women who had ordered an Uber around midnight on July 31.

headline: Trump’s Biggest Con: Pretending He’s on the Side of Working Men and Women
abstract: He’s even more antilabor and pro-plutocrat than orthodox Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has always been a con man. As a businessman, he left behind a trail of investors who lost money in failed ventures even as he profited, students who paid thousands for worthless courses, unpaid contractors and more. Even amid his current presidential campaign he has been hawking overpriced gold sneakers and Trump Bibles printed in China.

headline: Trump Repeatedly Refers to CNN’s Anderson Cooper as ‘Allison’
abstract: The former president, who often uses disparaging nicknames for people he dislikes, has referred to the host by a woman’s name on at least three occasions since Friday.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has spent the past several days calling the CNN host Anderson Cooper by a woman’s name, as he devotes much of the final stretch of a close presidential campaign to increasingly unfiltered displays of grievance and bigotry.

headline: Israel’s Parliament Passes Bills Banning Agency That Aids Palestinians
abstract: Most of the provisions of the laws, which could threaten UNRWA’s work by barring its operations in the country, will not take effect for three months.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s Parliament passed two laws on Monday that could threaten the work of UNRWA, the main U.N. agency that aids Palestinians, by barring its operations in the country. In doing so, Israel defied calls from the Biden administration, which has warned that the legislation could prompt an even greater humanitarian crisis in Gaza.

headline: Obama Is the Same. His Coalition Isn’t.
abstract: Democrats failed to preserve his coalition, and Harris is now trying to assemble a different one.
lead_paragraph: Tony Jones, 58, a truck driver and a member of the Teamsters union, drove from his home in rural Maybee, Mich., to see former President Barack Obama campaign for Vice President Kamala Harris last week in Detroit.

headline: Why Trump Uses Comics Like Tony Hinchcliffe to Spread His Message
abstract: Like the former president, these stand-ups loathe the news media, delight in transgression and harbor a deep-seated love of cruel insult jokes.
lead_paragraph: The stand-up of Tony Hinchcliffe, a popular insult comic, became an immediate issue in the presidential campaign on Sunday after his racist lines at a Donald J. Trump rally earned immediate blowback and criticism from, among others, the Democratic vice-presidential candidate, Tim Walz.

headline: Doug Emhoff Condemns Antisemitism as Democrats Court Jewish Voters
abstract: In a speech in Pittsburgh a day after the sixth anniversary of the Tree of Life shooting, he vouched for Kamala Harris’s commitment to Jewish security and issued a warning about Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish second spouse, warned on Monday that another term for former President Donald J. Trump would gravely threaten American Jews, as he also vouched for Ms. Harris’s commitment to a community on edge over rising antisemitism.

headline: ‘Bob’s Burgers’ Actor Sentenced to One Year in Prison for Role in Jan. 6 Riot
abstract: The actor, Jay Johnston, pleaded guilty in July to obstructing police during the riots at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: Jay Johnston, a comedian and actor who voiced Jimmy Pesto Sr. on the Fox sitcom “Bob’s Burgers,” was sentenced to a year and a day in prison over his involvement in the attack on the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: ‘Bad Kreyòl’ Review: Dueling Cultural Identities Make for a Weighty Comedy
abstract: Dominique Morisseau’s new play explores the tensions between a Haitian American woman and her Haitian-born cousin.
lead_paragraph: Concluding a four-show run as one of Signature Theater’s writers-in-residence, Dominique Morisseau looks beyond her usual American petri dish in the comic and contemplative “Bad Kreyòl.” It’s the second world premiere of her seven-year tenure (stretched from five because of the Covid pandemic) with the company, which has staged her explorations of 1940s jazz (“Paradise Blue”), campus race relations and slavery (“Confederates”) and the aftershocks of revolutionary movements (“Sunset Baby”).

headline: Puerto Ricans in Philadelphia Are Angered by Bigoted Remarks at Trump Rally
abstract: Many Puerto Ricans in the crucial battleground state said the remarks, such as one deriding Puerto Rico as “a floating island of garbage,” fit a common disrespectful attitude toward the island territory.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rican residents of Philadelphia reacted with shock and anger on Monday at racist remarks against Puerto Rico and Latinos made by a speaker at former President Donald J. Trump’s rally on Sunday at Madison Square Garden, joining a growing public backlash.

headline: Secret Files in Election Case Show How Judges Limited Trump’s Privilege
abstract: The partly unsealed rulings, orders and transcripts open a window on a momentous battle over grand jury testimony that played out in secret, creating important precedents about executive privilege.
lead_paragraph: Court documents unsealed on Monday shed new light on a legal battle over which of former President Donald J. Trump’s White House aides had to testify before a grand jury in Washington that charged him with plotting to overturn the 2020 election, showing how judges carved out limits on executive privilege.

headline: Harris Dives Into a Frenetic Final Week With a Swing Through Michigan
abstract: The vice president finished her day in the battleground state at a rally near the University of Michigan’s campus in Ann Arbor, where she sprinkled her speech with outreach to progressive Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris raced across Michigan on Monday, making three stops in the battleground state to begin a furious final week of her presidential campaign.

headline: Trump Long Ago Crossed the Line From Propriety to Profanity. Then Came the Garden.
abstract: In former President Donald J. Trump’s third campaign for the White House, his speeches have grown coarser and coarser.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

headline: Corrections: Oct. 29, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Oct. 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: A news analysis article on Sunday about the route Iran could go following the Israeli strikes on Saturday, overstated what is known about the current health of Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. He was said to have been seriously ill in 2022; there have been no recent reports about his health.

headline: Ford Foundation Gives $10 Million to Studio Museum in Harlem
abstract: The grant will support the museum’s director and chief curator, a position held for the last 20 years by Thelma Golden.
lead_paragraph: The Ford Foundation has awarded the Studio Museum in Harlem a grant of $10 million to endow its director and chief curator, a position held for the last 20 years by Thelma Golden.

headline: Trump Attacks Michelle Obama, Days After She Criticized Him
abstract: At a rally in Atlanta, Donald Trump called the former first lady a “hater,” in response to her comments saying he had displayed “erratic behavior” and “obvious mental decline.”
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump said that Michelle Obama had made a “big mistake” by criticizing him, as he responded on Monday for the first time to her recent searing comments about his mental state.

headline: Repeat Word for Word
abstract: Kathy Lowden shows off her collections.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Vivek Ramaswamy Has a Different Vision for Trumpism From JD Vance
abstract: Vivek Ramaswamy Has a Different Vision for Trumpism From JD Vance
lead_paragraph: Vivek Ramaswamy Has a Different Vision for Trumpism From JD Vance

headline: No, poll workers aren’t handing out Sharpies to invalidate ballots.
abstract: The writing utensils figured prominently in conspiracy theories in previous elections. But they’re often fine to use on paper ballots.
lead_paragraph: Some people have falsely claimed that election workers have provided Sharpies, markers or other writing utensils to certain voters in an attempt to somehow invalidate their ballots.

headline: No, noncitizens are not voting in droves.
abstract: Studies have shown that noncitizen voting is essentially nonexistent in federal elections in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump and his allies have falsely claimed that scores of noncitizens — including illegal immigrants — are voting or trying to vote in the United States presidential elections.

headline: Quote of the Day: Village So Spooky, Even Skeptics Get the Jitters
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, October 29, 2024
lead_paragraph: “I didn’t smell anything, I didn’t see anything, I just felt something.”

headline: How Russia, China and Iran Are Interfering in the Presidential Election
abstract: Eight years after Russia interfered in the 2016 presidential election, foreign influence with American voters has grown more sophisticated. That could have outsize consequences in the 2024 race.
lead_paragraph: When Russia interfered in the 2016 U.S. presidential election, spreading divisive and inflammatory posts online to stoke outrage, its posts were brash and riddled with spelling errors and strange syntax. They were designed to get attention by any means necessary.

headline: Arrests and Spying Charges Alarm Diplomats and Aid Workers in Yemen
abstract: The Iran-backed Houthi militia has detained dozens of Yemenis linked to the U.S. Embassy or international organizations recently.
lead_paragraph: Friends and former colleagues of Shaif al-Hamdani did not know if they would ever see him again.

headline: Part-Time Farmers, Part-Time Rock Stars: A Chinese Band’s Unlikely Rise
abstract: The band, Varihnaz, has gained fans by offering an alternative to China’s hyper-polished, fast-paced modern life, with songs about pesticides and poultry raising.
lead_paragraph: Before setting out on his band’s first national tour, before recording another album and before appearing on a major television network, Ba Nong had one task: finishing the summer harvest.

headline: The New Threat to Brazil’s Forests: Chemicals
abstract: Authorities use satellites to track deforestation caused by chain saws or fire. Now criminals are using chemicals to degrade trees — and evade detection.
lead_paragraph: Brazil’s satellites did not detect anything alarming. Yet down on the ground, the trees were dying.

headline: After Shaky Start for Labour, First Budget Brings Chance for Reset
abstract: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s government has stumbled since his party won a landslide victory, but the financial plan to be announced on Wednesday offers a possible relaunch.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, a British government rolled out a fiscal plan that rattled financial markets, drove up mortgage rates, torpedoed the pound and doomed the prime minister, Liz Truss, who would later resign after less than two months in office.

headline: Puerto Rico’s G.O.P. Chairman Demands Apology From Trump for Comic’s Remarks
abstract: The island’s Catholic archbishop also wrote a letter to Donald Trump condemning a racist comedy routine during his Madison Square Garden rally.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico’s Republican Party chairman said on Monday that he would withhold his support from former President Donald J. Trump unless he apologized for racist remarks that an insult comic made about the U.S. territory on Sunday during Mr. Trump’s rally at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: In the closing days of the 2024 campaign, Donald Trump and his allies have sought to tamp down criticism of inflammatory, racist remarks by speakers at a Trump rally at Madison Square Garden in New York City, including a comedian’s reference to Puerto Rico as “a floating island of garbage.”

headline: Why Trump Has an Edge With These 11 Michigan Voters — Even Though They Don’t Like Him
abstract: The group participants discuss the state of the race and what may drive them toward a given candidate.
lead_paragraph: The group participants discuss the state of the race and what may drive them toward a given candidate.

headline: Word of the Day: pagoda
abstract: This word has appeared in 16 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word pagoda has appeared in 16 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 5 in “An Architect Who Builds Community Wins the Pritzker Prize” by Robin Pogrebin:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Fake Blood Isn’t Cheap: Why It Costs $45 to Enter This Haunted House
abstract: It’s not as if Blood Manor can just transform into an office after Halloween.
lead_paragraph: It’s not as if Blood Manor can just transform into an office after Halloween.

headline: What Ants and Orcas Can Teach Us About Death
abstract: A philosopher journeys into the world of comparative thanatology, which explores how animals of all kinds respond to death and dying.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2018, off the coast of British Columbia, an orca named Tahlequah gave birth. When the calf died after just half an hour, Tahlequah refused to let go. For more than two weeks, she carried her calf’s body around, often balancing it on her nose as she swam.

headline: A House Divided
abstract: How is the election affecting the relationships in your family, school or community?
lead_paragraph: Do your family and friends hold similar political views — especially on which presidential candidate they believe would best serve the country?

headline: What Giuliani Is Losing: The Co-op. The Yankees Swag. The Convertible.
abstract: The trappings of Rudolph W. Giuliani’s New York life are slipping away to pay $148 million to two election workers who sued for defamation.
lead_paragraph: The items read like a treasure trove of riches for New York royalty.

headline: A Modest Monument to the Dodgers’ Days in Brooklyn
abstract: It would be easy to miss the plaque in a parking lot that was once Ebbets Field, but the managers of a nearby apartment complex are happy to help.
lead_paragraph: Every now and then, someone will wander into the parking lot of the sprawling apartment complex in Brooklyn where Ezra Askotzky works and start staring inquisitively at the ground.

headline: Jon Stewart Fears Madison Square Garden Will Never Be the Same
abstract: After Donald Trump’s rally, Stewart showed an image of Billy Joel and asked, “How dare they desecrate the stage that the Piano Man has consecrated?”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Stepping Into a Hidden World in the Everglades
abstract: “Tree islands” deep in a sea of grass once helped Native Americans elude capture by U.S. troops. A tour of these refuges reveals a rich culture and a new risk: rising water.
lead_paragraph: Deep within the seemingly endless saw-grass marshes of the Florida Everglades, I found myself standing on an unexpected speck of dry land on a bright spring day. The boat ride to this spot had fully exposed my tour group to the blustery wind and midday sun, and the island, by contrast, felt lush and welcoming, ringed by trees that cast shadows and tempered the gusts and insulated us from the elements beyond.

headline: These Are the Weirdest Houses We’ve Ever Covered
abstract: Eleven brilliantly wacky homes that make conventional ideas of good taste seem boring.
lead_paragraph: For a pair of avant-garde artists, immortality wasn’t just a dream — it was a possibility. As long, that is, as you were committed to an uncomfortable existence.

headline: Extra Extra!The End Times, Onscreen
abstract: When the world as we know it ends in films and on television, newspapers are often used to convey what was known in those final days.
lead_paragraph: Alien invasions, viruses, zombies, meteors, natural or human-caused catastrophes. When the end is nigh in apocalyptic, dystopian, disaster or horror films and television shows, there is often a distinct moment that offers audiences a glimpse of what was known in those last days before civilization was forever changed: the front pages of newspapers.

headline: What Should I Eat While Taking Antibiotics?
abstract: The drugs can wreak havoc on your gut. Here’s what may be key to restoring it.
lead_paragraph: Q: I was recently prescribed antibiotics and I’m worried that it might kill the “good” bacteria in my gut. What can I do to minimize the damage?

headline: How Will Harris Make a Last Plea to Voters? Here Are Clues From the Courtroom.
abstract: The New York Times unearthed transcripts from Kamala Harris’s years as a prosecutor. Her approach during trials offers hints about how she will make her final case to voters.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris gave a speech on Tuesday in Washington that she billed as the closing argument of her presidential campaign.

headline: E.P.A., Just Rebounding From Trump Years, Faces an Uncertain Future
abstract: Perhaps more than any other federal agency, the one responsible for protecting air, water and public health is a target for Donald Trump and his allies.
lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency has largely recovered from many of the staff exits and budget cuts that occurred during the Trump administration and, in some ways, has swiftly rebounded.

headline: Taking on Nora Ephron, Movie by Movie and Book by Book
abstract: Ephron’s entire oeuvre — “When Harry Met Sally,” “You’ve Got Mail,” “Heartburn” and more — is examined in a new book.
lead_paragraph: Late afternoon was still too early to have what Nora Ephron would have been having when she went out to dinner at Cafe Luxembourg, on Manhattan’s Upper West Side: the pan-seared lamb chops, served with some off-menu mint jelly the brasserie kept in a jar in the kitchen especially for her.

headline: How Election Coverage Extends Beyond Politics
abstract: Nearly every team at The Times has some hand in election coverage. Journalists from the Styles, Culture, Business and National desks shared how they’re tackling the moment.
lead_paragraph: Election Day is seven days away. Every day of the countdown,  Times Insider will share an article about how our election coverage works. Today, journalists from across the newsroom discuss how the political conversation affects their beat.

headline: The 25 Best Pizza Places in New York Right Now
abstract: Some of the city’s most famous pies didn’t make the list, while some unexpected spots delivered superlative examples of the form.
lead_paragraph: If you were to dig deep below New York City’s streets, past the subway tunnels, you might expect to find thick layers of schist, gneiss and marble. But what you’d actually find is pizza, the cultural and emotional bedrock of a city that can’t even coalesce around a single baseball team. Here, finding a decent slice is as easy as jaywalking. But finding a great slice, one that’s worth eating down to that last bite of crust, is much harder.

headline: Florida Stopped Being a Swing State Slowly, Then All at Once
abstract: Once a top presidential battleground, the state is lost to Democrats. The party’s missteps, along with demographic change, led to every one of Florida’s 67 counties becoming more red.
lead_paragraph: Florida’s days as a presidential battleground are bygone. No longer do candidates drop in every few days during campaign season. No longer do voters get bombarded with their ads. Nor is there more than a whisper of doubt that the state will vote Republican.

headline: Trump Says the Country Is ‘Dying.’ The Data Says Otherwise.
abstract: Look at trends, not anecdotes.
lead_paragraph: Narratives of national decline have intensified in recent years. Most prominent, of course, is Donald Trump’s vow to “make America great again,” in response to what he has called “a nation that is dying.” But there is also doomsaying on the far left, which sees a “late-stage capitalist hellscape” (to quote the journalist Taylor Lorenz) and is often resigned to voting in protest for a long-shot candidate or sitting out the election altogether.

headline: I’ve Been Through a Lot of Election Nights. Here’s How Nov. 5 May Go.
abstract: Declaring a winner may take some time.
lead_paragraph: Get ready for a long election night — or nights.

headline: A Dying Artist Left His Legacy to MoMA. Today He’s Almost Forgotten.
abstract: Scott Burton, one of America’s leading sculptors, entrusted his estate to the museum in 1989, when he was sick with AIDS, to ensure his place in art history. It turned out to be a bad idea.
lead_paragraph: When the artist Scott Burton decided on his deathbed to leave his estate to the Museum of Modern Art in 1989, he thought he was securing a permanent place in art history books. Instead, the decision made him a mere footnote — almost invisible.

headline: Elon Musk Wants Big Families. He Bought a Secret Compound for His.
abstract: As the billionaire warns of population collapse and the moral obligation to have children, he’s navigating his own complicated family.
lead_paragraph: On a quiet, leafy street of multimillion-dollar properties, one stands out: a 14,400-square-foot mansion that looks like a villa plucked from the hills of Tuscany and transplanted to Austin, Texas.

headline: The Game Theory of Democracy
abstract: Countries where democracy is in trouble share a common pattern, and it’s a worrying one for the United States.
lead_paragraph: Adam Przeworski, a political scientist, left his native Poland a few months before the 1968 Prague Spring uprising and found he could not return home. To avoid being arrested as a dissident by the Communist government, he accepted a job abroad at a university in Santiago, Chile — only to watch his adopted country collapse into autocracy a few years later. In 1973, a violent coup installed a military dictatorship, led by Gen. Augusto Pinochet, wiping out Chilean democracy in one brutal stroke. “Nobody expected that it would be as bloody as it was,” Przeworski told me. “Or that it would last for 17 years.”

headline: Climate Change Should Make You Rethink Homeownership
abstract: Renting is quickly becoming a better way for many people to enjoy high-risk places with much less financial baggage.
lead_paragraph: As the Southeast begins to recover from back-to-back hurricanes, potential home buyers across the country should take notice of the billions of dollars in property damage from the storms, some of it uninsured. The tremendous loss in places such as Swannanoa, N.C., and Keaton Beach, Fla., shows that homeownership in a world of growing disaster risk is less of an asset than it once was.

headline: For This Goth, Halloween Is Her Christmas
abstract: The beauty editor Tish Weinstock wrote a book about “undead style.”
lead_paragraph: “October is my favorite month,” said the writer Tish Weinstock, who was sitting on a bench in the cemetery of Trinity Church in Lower Manhattan staring out at the grave of Alexander Hamilton.

headline: What We Learned From Democrats’ Ads for Senate
abstract: What’s the strategy of Democrats in U.S. Senate races in red and purple states? David Leonhardt, a senior writer at The New York Times who runs The Morning daily newsletter, looks at their ads.
lead_paragraph: What’s the strategy of Democrats in U.S. Senate races in red and purple states? David Leonhardt, a senior writer at The New York Times who runs The Morning daily newsletter, looks at their ads.

headline: How Protest Pins Taught Me About My Family History
abstract: A consideration of the big ideas on small political buttons.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, at my grandfather’s 98th birthday party, someone asked him to share the secret of longevity. He still had the energy of a man half his age. “The ultimate thing,” he said to the family and friends gathered around his cake, “is engaging in the social struggle of the moment. If you want to live a fulfilled life, you have to make sure the world survives.” Beside him, my grandmother nodded.

headline: He Knows What Men Want (to Buy)
abstract: Ven. Space, an in-person-only boutique in Brooklyn, can’t seem to keep the clothes on the racks.
lead_paragraph: All was going as Chris Green had hoped.

headline: At 200, Bruckner Is More Popular Than Ever With Conductors. Why?
abstract: Seven conductors share what it’s like to lead Anton Bruckner’s monumental symphonies, and why they resonate today.
lead_paragraph: Bruckner, Bruckner, everywhere.

headline: In a Decisive Election, a Jewish Group Focuses on Climate Voters
abstract: Dayenu, a nonprofit group, is mobilizing Jews around a threat that organizers warn every walk of life on earth must confront: climate change.
lead_paragraph: Last week, dozens of Jewish volunteers gathered on a Zoom call to prepare to call voters for a get-out-the vote campaign called Chutzpah 2024.

headline: Migrants in New York Have Become a Campaign Trope
abstract: The migrant crisis has emerged as a dominant theme in House races across New York State and even in the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at how the migrant crisis in New York City became a campaign issue that candidates from both sides of the aisle in the state are using to attract voters.

headline: Why This Senate Candidate Is a Potential ‘Shock to the System’
abstract: Michelle Goldberg went to Nebraska and found political hope in an independent.
lead_paragraph: Much of the country is laser focused on the presidential election, but control of the Senate is also up for grabs in November. One of the seats in contention is, surprisingly, in deep-red Nebraska, where the independent Dan Osborn is running against the Trump-endorsed Republican Deb Fischer. In this episode of “The Opinions,” the columnist Michelle Goldberg travels to Nebraska to report on Osborn’s appeal and argues that his decision to run lays the groundwork for a “potential new avenue for a left-wing style of populist politics.”

headline: Who Do You Hope Will Win the 2024 Presidential Election?
abstract: Who do you think will make a better president? What is at stake for you and for the nation?
lead_paragraph: Please keep in mind that this forum is for teenagers only. While there are many places on NYTimes.com for adults to comment, this is the only dedicated spot for the voices of young people.

headline: My Fellow Republicans, It’s Time to Say Enough With Trump
abstract: G.O.P. members need to put country above party.
lead_paragraph: We Americans live in faith with our Constitution and with the past generations of Americans who swore to protect it and fought to defend it. One week from today, we will decide whether Donald Trump is fit to be president of the United States again. He is not. When we entrusted our Constitution and our democracy to him before, he betrayed us. Campaigning for the presidency again, he now promises to exact vengeance against his fellow Americans whom he deems “the enemy from within,” those who have dared to challenge his betrayal, an enemies list that includes Republicans and Democrats alike.

headline: Inside Trump’s Truth Social Conspiracy Theory Machine
abstract: An analysis of thousands of Donald Trump’s Truth Social posts reveals that the former president directly promoted false conspiracy theories in at least 330 instances and amplified at least 145 conspiracists.
lead_paragraph: An analysis of thousands of Donald Trump’s Truth Social posts reveals that the former president directly promoted false conspiracy theories in at least 330 instances and amplified at least 145 conspiracists.

headline: Trump Uses Thumbs-Up Video From Sept. 11 Event for a Snapchat Ad
abstract: After months of ignoring Snapchat, Donald Trump’s campaign has begun using the platform, urging people to vote by promoting a viral clip of him flashing a thumbs-up at a somber memorial service.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has released ads on the popular social media platform Snapchat for the first time in this year’s election — and one of them features him flashing a thumbs-up at a memorial for the nearly 3,000 victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

headline: Vivek Ramaswamy Has a Different Vision for Trumpism From JD Vance
abstract: The former Trump primary challenger discusses the ideological divides he sees within Trumpism.
lead_paragraph: In 2020 very few people had heard the name Vivek Ramaswamy. That was before he ran for president as a not-that-well-known biotech executive and anti-woke crusader, before he was one of the breakout stars of the Republican primaries, a guy who proved to be a lot faster on his feet at a debate and in front of a crowd than a lot of the much more experienced politicians who were competing against him.

headline: Trump Is Less Confident Than He Says. His Rally at Madison Square Garden Proves It.
abstract: Reminder: Trump is not the world spirit incarnate.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s rally at Madison Square Garden on Sunday night was supposed to be the capstone event of his campaign, a triumphant celebration of authoritarian strength. With millions watching, he would march into the final week of the contest as a conquering champion, so popular he could fill an arena in deep-blue New York twice over.

headline: An Apartment in the Center of Paris, Inspired by Venice
abstract: A couple who own an interior design firm found a residence that could also serve as a showroom for their work.
lead_paragraph: When Nathan Litera and Lyatt Samama began looking for a new home in the heart of Paris, they needed a place that would serve as more than just as a residence. The couple also wanted something that would double as a showroom for their interior design firm, where they could put the full breadth of their talents on display.

headline: An Ethical Minefield Awaits a Possible Second Trump Presidency
abstract: With business ties to foreign governments and holdings in industries overseen by federal regulators, Donald Trump would likely be the most conflicted president in U.S. history.
lead_paragraph: Days before Donald J. Trump became president in 2017, he promised to rein in his company’s freewheeling ways, assuring the American people that his family business would not “take advantage of” his presidency.

headline: Halloween TV, Where Things Are Even Worse
abstract: This year’s horror series take us to damned villages, cursed towns and countries fallen into anarchy.
lead_paragraph: This selection of shows from October’s annual parade of horror series will take you on a tour of places where the world appears to be out of control: a South Korea going through a religious frenzy, a Georgia farm under attack, a bucolic English village visited by aliens, a Japanese seaside town haunted by spirals. Just keep telling yourself it’s fiction.

headline: We’ve Just Had a Glimpse of the World to Come
abstract: Last week’s BRICS summit showed how the balance of global power increasingly eludes the West’s grasp.
lead_paragraph: Last week at a lavish global summit in the Russian city of Kazan, Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed of Ethiopia, once a darling of the West — winner of the Nobel Peace Prize and formerly a staunch ally of the United States — spoke up to heap praise on his host: Vladimir Putin, the bête noire of the rules-based order.

headline: Stephen Bannon, Released From Prison, Says He Is ‘Empowered’
abstract: Mr. Bannon, the combative right-wing strategist, said if Trump’s vote totals on Election Day look like 2020, he should once again declare himself the winner.
lead_paragraph: Stephen K. Bannon, the combative and calculating strategist who helped elect Donald J. Trump to the White House and later used his influence as one of the most powerful voices of the hard right to sow baseless doubts about the 2020 election, was released from federal prison early Tuesday.

headline: With Limited Options, Zelensky Seeks a Path Forward for Ukraine
abstract: A muted response to Ukraine’s “victory plan” and steep challenges on the battlefield leave Kyiv searching for a Plan B.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has pushed Western leaders to support his so-called victory plan, which he claims will end the country’s war with Russia next year. But Mr. Zelensky has received only lukewarm rhetorical support.

headline: ‘Standing Tall:’ Why ‘Perfect Strangers’ Keeps Coming Back
abstract: From “The Leftovers” to “Only Murders in the Building,” “Perfect Strangers,” the wacky 1980s sitcom with a bombastic theme song, is enjoying a strange afterlife.
lead_paragraph: In the latest season of “Only Murders in the Building,” the show’s trio of amateur detectives are investigating yet another murder and discover a theme — and a song — from an unlikely source: another TV show.

headline: Inside the Colorful and Cultish World of Nerds Gummy Clusters
abstract: Sales of Nerds have greatly increased in recent years, the company says. The secret? A multicolored orb.
lead_paragraph: How does a candy brand that was started 40 years ago suddenly become one of the most popular treats in America, with a cult following, a Super Bowl ad and TikTok fame?

headline: Hezbollah Names Naim Qassem as Its New Leader
abstract: Mr. Qassem had been the Lebanese militant group’s longtime deputy. He replaces Hassan Nasrallah, who was assassinated in an Israeli airstrike last month.
lead_paragraph: Hezbollah, the Lebanese militant group, named Naim Qassem, its longtime deputy leader, as its new secretary general on Tuesday, replacing Hassan Nasrallah, who was assassinated in Israeli airstrikes south of Beirut last month.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 507
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Oct. 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,229
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Oct. 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Foreign Election Interference, and Volkswagen May Close Factories
abstract: Plus, why you should never cross a crow.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: On the Ballot: An Immigration System Most Americans Never Wanted
abstract: The complicated history of trade-offs and compromises behind U.S. border control.
lead_paragraph: If Donald J. Trump wins next week’s election, it will be in large part because voters embraced his message that the U.S. immigration system is broken.

headline: A Book that Explains the 2024 Campaign
abstract: We’re covering America’s working-class majority.
lead_paragraph: If you want to understand this year’s election, a book published in 1970 turns out to be surprisingly useful. Both liberal and conservative analysts have recently cited its ideas, and the Harris and Trump campaigns have embraced its arguments in different ways.

headline: McDonald’s Seeks to Resolve E. Coli Crisis and Return Focus to Value
abstract: The fast-food giant’s earnings results did not reflect the potential fallout from an E. coli outbreak that the company said it moved quickly to contain.
lead_paragraph: McDonald’s is aiming to move past the E. coli outbreak that has sickened dozens of people in recent weeks, projecting the food safety scare will not affect its full-year finances.

headline: Jeff Bezos, Jerome Powell, Serena Williams and More at the DealBook Summit
abstract: The conference on Dec. 4 will bring together the biggest names in business, politics and culture.
lead_paragraph: We are pleased to announce our lineup for the DealBook Summit, which will be held on Dec. 4 at Jazz at Lincoln Center in New York. Andrew will host a series of conversations with the biggest newsmakers in the world of business, politics and culture. We hope you can join us in person.

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: N.B.A. First, Formal Apology, Election
abstract: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: In 1930s Rwanda, a Black Savior Is Coming, and She Might Be a Woman
abstract: The eponymous healer in “Sister Deborah” inspires a Black feminist uprising.
lead_paragraph: In Scholastique Mukasonga’s new novel, “Sister Deborah,” Black American evangelists arrive in 1930s Rwanda with good tidings: A “Black Savior” — perhaps a “Celestial Woman” — is coming to the village of Nyabikenke, and soon, to bring Black people a bountiful harvest and salvation. The chief bearer of this joyful message is the eponymous healer-prophet, a charismatic woman of mysterious origin and powers who can speak in tongues. Her powerful Black feminist vision earns her scores of women followers; this book is not only her tale, but also theirs. As they search, strive, wait and hope, they disrupt their own lives as well as longstanding systems of patriarchy and colonialism; and this remarkable, recursive book about the power of belief — like its heroines — finds new form again and again.

headline: Who Won the Oscars of American Fashion
abstract: A new generation of designers is on the rise.
lead_paragraph: The 2024 Council of Fashion Designers of America awards, otherwise known as the Oscars of American fashion, were held in the Museum of Natural History, in the atrium under the great blue whale, but the coming election was the elephant in the room. How could it not be?

headline: A Rural Missouri Town Fights Big Tech, and Itself
abstract: Residents of Peculiar battled developers and some of their local officials to keep a giant data center out of their community.
lead_paragraph: They had already planted yard signs, volunteered at the farmers’ market booth and signed each and every one of the petitions, so now the residents of Peculiar, Mo., took to the field outside their homes to pray.

headline: BP Profit Falls, but It Still Sees ‘Potential to Grow’ in Oil and Gas
abstract: The energy giant’s chief executive, Murray Auchincloss, has taken a profit-oriented approach and said in an interview that the company’s “principal aim” was increasing earnings.
lead_paragraph: BP’s share price fell more than 3 percent on Tuesday after the energy giant reported its lowest quarterly earnings in almost four years and suggested it might change its generous share buyback policy.

headline: Vatican Issues First Report on Sexual Abuse, to Immediate Criticism
abstract: The report is intended to assess efforts by the Roman Catholic Church to safeguard minors and others. Advocates for survivors called it an exercise in obfuscation.
lead_paragraph: Ten years after it was established, a Vatican commission on clerical sexual abuse issued its first report on Tuesday, a limited step in self-accounting by some bishops that was immediately criticized by victims advocates as toothless and lacking independent verification.

headline: Where’s Ivanka?
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s oldest daughter and former top aide was once one of his most prominent campaign surrogates. Lately, she’s noticeably absent.
lead_paragraph: Ivanka Trump has been surfing. She’s posed in front of the Eiffel Tower, and attended a Formula 1 party in Miami in a race-car red dress. She took a dip with her children in a hot tub, hung out with Kim Kardashian in Malibu, and smiled alongside her husband, Jared Kushner, at the Acropolis.

headline: Trump’s Environmental Claims Ignore Decades of Climate Science
abstract: The former president says he wants “clean air and clean water,” but he has rolled back environmental rules and dismissed the scientific consensus on climate change.
lead_paragraph: In the final throes of the presidential campaign, Donald Trump is trying to cast himself as a protector of mother nature, even as he calls climate change a hoax.

headline: In Closing, Harris Casts Herself as the Unifier and Trump as a ‘Petty Tyrant’
abstract: In a plain-spoken but forceful speech at the Ellipse in Washington, Kamala Harris presented herself as a protector of the public good and used the arc of history to attack her Republican rival.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

headline: The World’s Doomsday Plant Vault Gets Thousands of New Seeds
abstract: A storage facility in Norway built to safeguard crop diversity recently received more than 30,000 samples as concerns grow about climate change and food insecurity.
lead_paragraph: The Svalbard Global Seed Vault, in the far reaches of northern Norway, is meant to be humanity’s last resort. Imagine it as the world’s doomsday garden shed: a secure genetic capsule, kept safe in case some catastrophe — a meteor strike or climate disaster, perhaps — threatens the planet’s crops.

headline: Dozens Are Killed in an Israeli Strike in North Gaza, Local Authorities say
abstract: Gaza’s health ministry said that at least 25 children were among those killed in an Israeli strike on a residential building in Beit Lahia, in northern Gaza. The Israeli military said it was looking into the strike.
lead_paragraph: Gaza’s health ministry said that at least 25 children were among those killed in an Israeli strike on a residential building in Beit Lahia, in northern Gaza. The Israeli military said it was looking into the strike.

headline: A New Insult Reminds Puerto Ricans of How Trump Treated Them
abstract: As president, Donald Trump fought bitterly with Puerto Rican officials, ridiculed them and resisted sending aid to the territory after devastating hurricanes.
lead_paragraph: Carmen Yulín Cruz’s cellphone started buzzing on Sunday while she was at the airport in Connecticut, waiting for a flight to Puerto Rico. A standup comic at former President Donald J. Trump’s rally in New York had called Puerto Rico a “floating island of garbage.”

headline: The Threats to The Presidential Election, Explained
abstract: Nick Corasaniti, a New York Times reporter covering voting, describes how the 2024 election could be complicated by litigation, disinformation and battles over certifying the vote.
lead_paragraph: Nick Corasaniti, a New York Times reporter covering voting, describes how the 2024 election could be complicated by litigation, disinformation and battles over certifying the vote.

headline: Could the Vote Be Contested Again? 5 Threats to a Smooth Election.
abstract: Litigation, disinformation and battles over certifying the vote all have the potential to complicate the process.
lead_paragraph: For the past four years, Donald J. Trump has been proclaiming the American electoral process “rigged,” decrying events that displease him as “election interference” and laying the groundwork to contest another loss at the polls.

headline: This Toad Is So Tiny That They Call It a Flea
abstract: A “toadlet” in Brazil is the second-smallest vertebrate known to exist on the planet.
lead_paragraph: At 6.95 tiny millimeters in length, this creature could fit on your fingertip. It is smaller than several ant species. While it sounds like a cricket, it’s not an insect: It’s an extremely small frog.

headline: ‘Ragtime’ Crushed Brandon Uranowitz’s Dream. Now It’s Healing His Wounds.
abstract: Nearly 30 years after being let go from the Broadway-bound show, this Tony Award winner is taking a lead role in a new revival at City Center.
lead_paragraph: In 1997, Brandon Uranowitz was a 10-year-old from West Orange, N.J., who dreamed of being on Broadway. He got one small foot in the door that year when he replaced Paul Dano as the wide-eyed little boy Edgar in the musical “Ragtime” during its premiere in Toronto.

headline: Autumn in New York Has Been One of the City’s Driest Ever
abstract: That’s despite a tiny shower on Tuesday, which broke a rain-free streak.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, Sarah Antebi, a 19-year-old sophomore at Barnard and Columbia, paused for a moment while running through Central Park to take in the fall foliage at the lake. It’s unusually resplendent for this time of year, with many of the trees just starting to turn orange and yellow.

headline: Gnocchi’s Crispy — Let’s Eat
abstract: “I’m always impressed with simple recipes that taste this good.”
lead_paragraph: Hello! Ali here, filling in for Emily Weinstein this week.

headline: ‘Hatred and Vitriol’ at the Trump Rally in New York
abstract: Readers react to the Trump rally at Madison Square Garden and a tragedy in Springfield, Ohio. Also: Gut feelings about the election; benefits of electric cars.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Dozens Killed in Israeli Strikes in Eastern Lebanon, Lebanese Officials Say
abstract: The barrage of Israeli airstrikes in the Bekaa Valley on Monday night killed at least 60 people, officials said. It appeared to be the deadliest attack in the area since the war escalated last month.
lead_paragraph: Israeli airstrikes on Monday killed at least 60 people in the Bekaa Valley, in eastern Lebanon, Lebanese officials said, in what appeared to be the deadliest barrage of strikes in the area since the conflict between Israel and the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah escalated last month.

headline: A ‘Crime and Punishment’ Ballet? It’s Not as ‘Ludicrous’ as It Seems.
abstract: “Why can’t ballet be a roller coaster?” Helen Pickett said of her and James Bonas’s full-length work, premiering this week at American Ballet Theater.
lead_paragraph: To make a narrative ballet based on “Crime and Punishment” might seem, in the words of the director James Bonas, “sort of ludicrous.”

headline: Help! Budget Charged Us $450 to Clean Our Rental Car. Can They Do That?
abstract: Sure, there were footprints and some dirt, but days after a family from Ireland returned a car to Kennedy Airport, they were hit with the maximum cleaning fee.
lead_paragraph: We rented a car from the Budget agency at Kennedy Airport in New York this past August for a two-week family vacation. When we returned it, the staff member who checked it in told me everything was fine. But four days later Budget sent a letter saying it was charging my credit card $450 for “Excessive Interior Dirt — Sand.” I complained multiple times via email, sending them time-stamped photos and video I had taken of the car’s interior, to no avail. Can you help? Arden, Kells, Ireland

headline: Ford Took an Early Lead in Electric Vehicles. Now G.M. Is Surging.
abstract: Ford is struggling to make money on battery-powered models while General Motors, which started more slowly, says it is getting close to that goal.
lead_paragraph: In the race to be second to Tesla in the U.S. electric vehicle market, Ford Motor leaped to an early lead four years ago over its crosstown rival, General Motors, with the Mustang Mach E, an electric sport utility vehicle with a design and a name that nodded to its classic sports car.

headline: How Elon Musk Might Use His Pull With Trump to Help Tesla
abstract: Although Donald Trump has opposed policies that favor electric cars, if he becomes president he could ease regulatory scrutiny of Tesla or protect lucrative credits and subsidies.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has promised, if he is re-elected, to do away with Biden administration policies that encourage the use and production of electric cars. Yet one of his biggest supporters is Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, which makes nearly half the electric vehicles sold in the United States.

headline: C.D.C. Warns of Unusual Rise in Walking Pneumonia Cases
abstract: The agency said infections had increased significantly among children ages 2 to 4.
lead_paragraph: Infections with the bacteria that causes walking pneumonia have risen significantly this year, particularly among young children, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention warned this month.

headline: Putin Flexes Nuclear Capabilities at Delicate Moment for Ukraine
abstract: The Russian leader’s emphasis on nuclear prowess has been seen as an attempt to deter Western military aid to Kyiv.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia presided over a nuclear training exercise on Tuesday that included practice launches of ballistic missiles, a move widely seen as an attempt to show force amid the ongoing war in Ukraine.

headline: Urban Hell, a Place to Find God or Just Another New York City Street?
abstract: A viral photo of three fast-food chains on a Brooklyn street corner is something of a Rorschach test on social media. It has multiple meanings for New Yorkers, too.
lead_paragraph: The photograph is of three fast-food chain restaurants as glimpsed from a pedestrian overpass at night.

headline: Your questions about The Times’s election coverage: Endorsing presidential candidates
abstract: Our journalists answer questions from readers.
lead_paragraph: The Times editorial board first endorsed a presidential candidate in 1860 (our pick then was Abraham Lincoln). In every presidential race since then, the board has weighed in. This year we endorsed Kamala Harris for president.

headline: New Vehicles, Face Paint and a 1,200-Foot Fall: The U.S. Army Prepares for War With China
abstract: The big and cumbersome Army is trying to transform itself to deploy quickly to Asia, if needed. It is an inherently dangerous business.
lead_paragraph: Early one morning this month, 864 Army paratroopers bundled into C-17 transport planes at a base in Alaska and took off for a Great Power War exercise between three volcanic mountains on Hawaii’s Big Island.

headline: A Celebrated Pianist’s Final Recording, Made With His Son
abstract: Maurizio Pollini didn’t think his farewell on disc would be an album of music by Schubert with his son, Daniele. Now, it serves as an emotional coda.
lead_paragraph: The pianist Maurizio Pollini was still exploring, right to the end.

headline: Automatic Refunds for Significant Flight Disruptions: New Airline Rule Goes Into Effect
abstract: The Transportation Department’s new rule also sets the definition for what constitutes a “significant” delay in air travel.
lead_paragraph: The Transportation Department’s new rule requiring airlines to provide prompt, automatic refunds to passengers enduring significant flight disruptions is now in effect.

headline: What Happened When Chicago’s Mayor Followed a Teachers’ Union Playbook
abstract: In Chicago, the mayor and the teachers’ union are tightly connected. The relationship has ushered in generous spending and led to political turmoil.
lead_paragraph: For years, Chicago was ground zero for the Democratic Party’s big transition on education.

headline: TSMC Chips Ended Up in Devices Made by China’s Huawei Despite U.S. Controls
abstract: The U.S. government has tried to keep Chinese companies from obtaining certain advanced technologies, but concerns have been growing that some products may have been routed to Huawei.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. government has spent years weaving a web of controls to prevent Chinese companies from being able to buy or make cutting-edge computer chips.

headline: CNN Bars Pro-Trump Guest After His ‘Beeper’ Remark to Mehdi Hasan
abstract: After Mr. Hasan voiced support for Palestinians, the CNN guest, Ryan James Girdusky, said, “I hope your beeper doesn’t go off.”
lead_paragraph: CNN barred a conservative commentator from its programs after he made on-air remarks on Monday that seemed to imply that another guest, the pundit Mehdi Hasan, was a member of Hezbollah.

headline: Two Horror Authors on the Scary Books You Should Read
abstract: Stephen Graham Jones and Joe Hill with their recommendations for this Halloween season.
lead_paragraph: Halloween is just around the corner, so we turned to two great horror authors — Joe Hill (“The Fireman,” “NOS4A2”) and Stephen Graham Jones (“The Only Good Indians,” “My Heart Is a Chainsaw”) — for their recommendations of books to read this season.

headline: In ‘Empty Beds,’ a Stark Reminder of War’s Youngest Victims
abstract: A mural spanning an entire city block in Manhattan symbolizes the thousands of Ukrainian children who have been taken by Russian forces.
lead_paragraph: On a quiet block in Manhattan’s Little Ukraine in the East Village, passers-by are confronted with haunting reminders of war. A 100-foot-long mural shows children’s beds lined with stuffed animals and toys, but no children, symbolizing the thousands of Ukrainian children who were separated or taken from their families since Russia invaded their country in 2022.

headline: Immense Deluge Floods Parts of Southern and Eastern Spain
abstract: The region of Andalusia received four times the amount of rain that usually falls in October in a single day.
lead_paragraph: The region of Andalusia received four times the amount of rain that usually falls in October in a single day.

headline: In Botswana’s Election, Diamond Profits Are a Defining Issue
abstract: The party that has governed the country since 1966 could lose power as the economy struggles from a slump in demand for diamonds, which made Botswana an African success story.
lead_paragraph: The Botswana Democratic Party, which has governed the southern African nation since its independence in 1966, enters Wednesday’s national elections facing an unlikely threat to its grip on power: diamonds.

headline: Is There a Moral Choice for Catholic Voters?
abstract: Why are we being asked to choose between the lesser of two evils?
lead_paragraph: In advice last month for Catholic voters in America, Pope Francis said that both Donald Trump and Kamala Harris “are against life, be it the one who kicks out migrants or be it the one who kills babies.” Following this, Francis urged voters to choose the “lesser evil,” though the moral math was up to the individual voter.

headline: Teri Garr, Comic Actress in Offbeat Roles, Is Dead at 79
abstract: An Oscar nominee for her role in “Tootsie,” she was also a favorite guest of David Letterman and Johnny Carson and a three-time host of “Saturday Night Live.”
lead_paragraph: Teri Garr, the alternately shy and sassy blond actress whose little-girl voice, deadpan comic timing, expressive eyes and cinematic bravery in the face of seemingly crazy male characters made her a star of 1970s and ’80s movies and earned her an Oscar nomination for her role in “Tootsie,” died on Tuesday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 79.

headline: 13 Scary Good Halloween Songs
abstract: Fill up your holiday playlist with spooky and satisfying tracks from Yeah Yeah Yeahs, the Sonics, Geto Boys and more.
lead_paragraph: Hello from your guest playlister for the day — I’m Dave Renard, an editor on the Culture desk who writes about music occasionally and tries to keep his record collection from outgrowing its allotted shelf space (currently failing).

headline: Why Is Harris So Passionate About Abortion Rights? Her Past Work Holds Clues.
abstract: For a politician who has been criticized for shifting positions on some issues, this is an area where she has shown unwavering conviction.
lead_paragraph: In April 2004, Kamala Harris was less than four months into her new job as San Francisco’s district attorney, a high-profile position that thrust her into the local headlines, when she flew to Washington, D.C., to become one face in a sea of more than a million.

headline: A Month’s Worth of Rain Falls in a Single Day in Parts of Spain
abstract: The deluge flooded streets, breached rivers and destroyed crops along the Mediterranean coast. There could be more rain still to come.
lead_paragraph: Manuel Yerai, a farmer in southern Spain, watched helplessly on Monday night as hail the size of tennis balls ripped through the plastic sheeting covering his pepper plants, as Spain faced one of its most destructive rainfalls this year.

headline: Despite Covid ‘Amnesia,’ the Pandemic Simmers Beneath the 2024 Race
abstract: Dueling Trump and Harris rallies outside Atlanta offer a case study in how anger and anxiety over Covid-19, a proxy for the larger debate over trust in government, have shaped the 2024 race.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. walked onstage after a parade of pyrotechnics at former President Donald J. Trump’s rally outside Atlanta last week and immediately invoked a name that became a bugaboo of the right and a subject of wild conspiracy theories during the coronavirus pandemic: Bill Gates.

headline: Regional Indian Flavors in the Flatiron District
abstract: The great New York outdoors inspires a new Brooklyn restaurant, New England seafood at Smithereens and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: At some of the newest Indian restaurants, regional fare is the focus. The same is true at Passerine. The chef Chetan Shetty is from Pune, near Mumbai, and he relies on spice blends his mother concocts and sends over. Chile-fueled kolhapuri ignites lamb tartare, ajwain masala adds pungency to baked oysters, and malwani spices dancing with vadouvan season fish. Greenmarket maitake mushrooms, sweet potatoes, collards, broccoli rabe and cabbage figure as well. There are surprising touches, too, like Comté and Hollandaise.
