The restaurant’s lounge, called the Drawing Room, has its own brief menu and leads to the well-upholstered dining room. The space was formerly occupied by Sona, which closed earlier this year. (Opens Friday)

headline: Bad Bunny Responds to Racist Remarks at Trump Rally With a Message of Puerto Rican Pride
abstract: The pop superstar posted a video lauding the island’s “kings and queens,” two days after he shared a clip of Vice President Kamala Harris addressing Puerto Rican voters.
lead_paragraph: Bad Bunny, the Puerto Rican rapper, singer and international pop phenomenon, stepped up on Tuesday his condemnation of disparaging remarks about Puerto Rico that were made by a comedian at a rally for former President Donald J. Trump on Sunday.

headline: Judge Refuses to Recuse Herself From Trump Assassination Case
abstract: The man accused of plotting to shoot Donald J. Trump at his golf course had asked the judge to step aside, saying she had been praised by the former president and listed as a possible Trump appointee.
lead_paragraph: Aileen M. Cannon, the federal judge overseeing the prosecution of a man accused of trying to assassinate former President Donald J. Trump, rejected the man’s request that she remove herself from the case, saying on Tuesday that she has no relationship with Mr. Trump even though he appointed her to the bench and she has ruled in his favor in a separate criminal matter.

headline: Teri Garr Found the Soul in Memorable Ditsy Blondes
abstract: In “Tootsie,” “After Hours” and other films, she played truly unhinged characters while also layering in sadness or drama.
lead_paragraph: In “Tootsie,” Teri Garr perfected the polite way to say you had a bad time at a party. Bidding a friend good night, her character, a struggling actress named Sandy, tells him, “It was a wonderful party, my date left with someone else, I had a lot of fun, do you have any seconal?”

headline: One Defendant Accepts a Plea Deal Amid Young Thug’s RICO Trial
abstract: Prosecutors have accused the star Atlanta rapper of leading a gang in the longest trial in Georgia history. The case has been further delayed by plea negotiations.
lead_paragraph: A defendant in the racketeering and gang conspiracy case against the Atlanta rapper Young Thug and members of his YSL crew agreed to a plea deal in court on Tuesday.

headline: Teen Accused in U.K. Dance Class Stabbing Is Charged With Terror Offenses
abstract: The police said that they found Ricin and an Al Qaeda training manual in the suspect’s home. The attack on little girls at a Taylor Swift-themed event stoked anti-immigrant sentiment.
lead_paragraph: The teenager accused of fatally stabbing three young girls at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class in England has been charged with additional offenses linked to terrorism, the police said on Tuesday.

headline: How Trump Exploits Divisions Among Black and Latino Voters
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s anti-immigrant message is exposing longstanding tensions and challenging Democrats’ hopes for solidarity.
lead_paragraph: In the Democratic imagination, “people of color” is a unifying term, a label for a durable coalition of Black and Latino voters, as well as Asian Americans, Arab Americans and Native Americans.

headline: Musk’s PAC Hints at Vulgar Taunt Against Harris in Ad
abstract: One version of the ad, first posted by the group on Friday evening, remained active on Tuesday, with more than 430,000 views.
lead_paragraph: The ad from Elon Musk’s PAC begins, “Kamala Harris is a C Word.”

headline: Ahead of Harris’s Speech in Washington, Trump Tries to Focus on Immigration
abstract: The former president believes his focus on illegal immigration is the reason he won in 2016, and this year, he has pushed his advisers to add content related to it.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump described immigration as the most important issue of the election in a speech on Tuesday that his aides cast as a closing argument hours ahead of Vice President Kamala Harris’s remarks at the Ellipse in Washington.

headline: San Jose State Women’s Volleyball Team Finds Itself at Center of Transgender Debate
abstract: After reports that the team includes a transgender player, several schools have forfeited matches against the university out of protest.
lead_paragraph: The San Jose State University women’s volleyball team is trying to make the N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time in 23 years. But first, it must find schools willing to play against it.

headline: Trump Family Members and Biden Aides Among China Hack Targets
abstract: Phones used by Jared Kushner and Eric Trump were among those that hackers sought access to as part of a counterintelligence effort carried out by a hacking group associated with China.
lead_paragraph: Members of former President Donald J. Trump’s family, as well as Biden administration and State Department officials, were among those targeted by the China-linked hackers who were able to break into telecommunications company systems, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Barbara Bush, Scion of Republican Royalty, Knocks on Doors for Kamala Harris
abstract: Ms. Bush, whose father and grandfather were the last two Republican presidents before Donald J. Trump, is backing his Democratic opponent.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Bush, whose father and grandfather were the last two Republican presidents before Donald J. Trump, said she was backing his opponent, Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: What a ‘Tennessee Three’ Member Thinks She Can Achieve by Running for Senate
abstract: Gloria Johnson’s bid to unseat Senator Marsha Blackburn appears destined to fail, but she still sees an opening to start chipping away at Republican dominance in the state.
lead_paragraph: As Gloria Johnson, the Democratic candidate for Senate in Tennessee, has driven from diner to coffee shop to restaurant across the state, she has been met with a chorus of enthusiasm that a Democrat has shown up — and resignation that it most likely still won’t matter.

headline: The Runza, a Favorite Nebraska Sandwich, Has a Cameo in the Campaign
abstract: Tim Walz, the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, is a fan of the ground-beef treat. On a recent stop at a Runza restaurant in Omaha, he managed to spend $600.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a busy few months in Nebraska for the makers of what is most decidedly not a Hot Pocket.

headline: Trump’s Extraordinarily Negative TV Ads
abstract: The contrast to the Harris campaign has been stark.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump are neck-and-neck in terms of how many television ads they’ve aired in battleground states. The tones of those ads, however, have been worlds apart from each other.

headline: A New Celebrity Podcast Host Who Might Be a Surprise
abstract: Armie Hammer’s career sunk after he was accused of sexual assault and making shocking comments about cannibalism. He said he hopes to learn from his show’s guests.
lead_paragraph: Armie Hammer announced this week that he started a podcast.

headline: Devices With ‘Free Gaza’ Messages Found at Ballot Box Fires
abstract: The police said they had not determined a motive for the arson fires in Portland, Ore., and Vancouver, Wash. But the messages have heightened the sensitivity of the investigation.
lead_paragraph: Investigators responding to arson fires at two ballot boxes in the Pacific Northwest this week found devices at both scenes marked with the words “Free Gaza,” according to two law enforcement officials.

headline: Alphabet Revenue Jumps 15% to $88.3 Billion
abstract: The tech giant’s 34 percent increase in quarterly profit topped Wall Street expectations, driven by its advertising and cloud businesses.
lead_paragraph: Alphabet, Google’s parent company, reported strong revenue growth on Tuesday, as its business continued to excel despite tough regulatory scrutiny and growing competition.

headline: 44 Million Voters Have Already Cast a Ballot. Most Voted Early in 2020, Too.
abstract: The fixed nature of the early vote makes it difficult to predict whether overall turnout will be as high as in 2020 and 2022, or whether either party is truly building an edge.
lead_paragraph: More than 44 million Americans have cast an early ballot so far this election cycle, a substantial total that cements how voting patterns have changed in the country since the 2020 election.

headline: Man Who Attacked Paul Pelosi Is Sentenced to Life in Prison
abstract: David DePape broke into the San Francisco home of Nancy Pelosi, the former speaker of the House, in 2022 and beat her husband with a hammer.
lead_paragraph: David DePape, the intruder who broke into the home of Nancy Pelosi two years ago and bludgeoned her husband with a hammer, was sentenced on Tuesday to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

headline: Trump Media Stock Jumps Again as Traders Bet on Election
abstract: Shares of the Truth Social parent company continue to soar, pushing the market value of the firm above $10 billion.
lead_paragraph: Shares of former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company are soaring on the expectation he will win next week’s presidential election.

headline: Israel Hits Gaza Town for Third Time in Days, Killing Dozens, Officials Say
abstract: Gazan agencies said that children were among those killed in the strike in Beit Lahia. A U.S. State Department spokesman called the strike “a horrifying incident with a horrifying result.”
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military on Tuesday hit a town in the northern Gaza Strip for the third time in just over a week, striking a residential building and killing dozens of people, Gazan officials said, as Israel intensified its offensive in the territory after more than a year of war.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: Trump’s Worrisome Business Deals
abstract: Plus, what happened to repatriated art in Benin.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is cashing in on a variety of new ventures as he seeks a second term. But unlike in his first term, when he halted new international deals and hired an outside ethics adviser, he is making no promises to rein in his company’s freewheeling ways.

headline: Trump Ad Claims Harris Will ‘Doom Medicare’
abstract: With older Americans making up a major share of voters in battleground states, the Trump campaign casts Kamala Harris as a threat to programs that benefit them.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign has spent more than $9.6 million since Oct. 16 to run this 30-second ad, “Doom Medicare,” on television stations, according to AdImpact. And the campaign has put more than $1 million behind the ad in each of Georgia, North Carolina, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin.

headline: Is Trump a Fascist? This Time, Mayor Adams Dodges the Question.
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City bristled at questions about the former president and said there was a need to “turn down the rhetoric.”
lead_paragraph: The strange political courtship between Mayor Eric Adams of New York City and former President Donald J. Trump has taken another odd turn.

headline: Israeli Airstrikes in Lebanon’s Bekaa Valley Kill Dozens, Officials Say
abstract: The Baalbek district bore the brunt of Israel’s barrage, which officials said killed at least 60 people in the Bekaa Valley, in eastern Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: The Baalbek district bore the brunt of Israel’s barrage, which officials said killed at least 60 people in the Bekaa Valley, in eastern Lebanon.

headline: What Are the Implications of Israel Banning UNRWA?
abstract: Humanitarian agencies fear the new Israeli laws could have catastrophic effects for Gazans. They are already drawing sharp criticism from Israel’s allies.
lead_paragraph: Many humanitarian agencies have expressed fears that two measures enacted in Israel on Monday that ban UNRWA, the U.N. agency aiding Palestinians, from operating in the country could cripple its aid deliveries.

headline: Harris Is Trying to Win Voters by Laying Out the Alternative
abstract: Also, Teri Garr found the soul in memorable ditsy blondes. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: With just a week left until Election Day, Kamala Harris is set to deliver a speech at 7:30 p.m. Eastern time that her campaign is calling a closing argument. She will speak at the Ellipse, the park in the shadow of the White House where Donald Trump rallied the crowd that eventually stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: Judge Tosses Republican Suit Over Military and Overseas Ballots in Pennsylvania
abstract: A judge said six Republican members of the state’s congressional delegation could not rely on “phantom fears of foreign malfeasance” to justify initiating a legal action so close to Election Day.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday dismissed a lawsuit filed by six Republican members of Pennsylvania’s congressional delegation that challenged the state’s handling of ballots for military and overseas voters. The judge tossed the suit on procedural grounds, including that the plaintiffs had waited too long to initiate legal action and could not rely on “phantom fears of foreign malfeasance” to justify their late challenge.

headline: John Gierach, Fly Fishing Author With Wit and Wisdom, Dies at 77
abstract: Writing for anglers and amateurs alike, he found that the sport can reveal as much about people as it does about fish.
lead_paragraph: John Gierach, a fly fisherman who was as skilled with a rod and reel as he was with words, producing hundreds of articles and more than 20 books, including “Even Brook Trout Get the Blues” and “Sex, Death and Fly-Fishing,” died on Oct. 3 in Longmont, Colo. He was 77.

headline: Au Pair Pleads Guilty to Manslaughter in Double Homicide
abstract: As part of a plea agreement, Juliana Peres Magalhães, 24, has agreed to cooperate with prosecutors, who have charged her ex-lover with murdering his wife and another man in 2023.
lead_paragraph: A Brazilian au pair who was having an affair with her employer pleaded guilty to manslaughter on Tuesday and will cooperate with prosecutors when they try her ex-lover on murder charges in the 2023 killings of his wife and another man, the authorities said.

headline: Ex-Leader of Black Transgender Group Is Charged With Stealing Its Money
abstract: After Dominique Morgan said her group would start a bail fund for poor defendants, she instead took nearly $100,000 for personal expenses, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: The former executive director of a Brooklyn nonprofit dedicated to helping Black transgender people stole nearly $100,000 from the group and spent it on Mercedes-Benz payments, a home renovation and other personal expenses, prosecutors said on Tuesday.

headline: A Closing Argument for an Abnormal Election
abstract: A divided and deadlocked country faces big questions about what presidential power is actually for.
lead_paragraph: Tonight, Vice President Kamala Harris stood on the Ellipse, a lawn by the White House that dates back to the 19th century, and urged Americans to consider the country’s more recent past.

headline: What Can a Celebrity Endorsement Do? Ask Shonda Rhimes.
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris has plenty of big-name backers, but one of the eternal questions is how much star power ultimately matters to voters.
lead_paragraph: At first, the showrunner Shonda Rhimes seemed to go nearly unnoticed at the strip mall in suburban Atlanta.

headline: Supreme Court Declines to Remove R.F.K. Jr. From Ballot in Two Key States
abstract: Since throwing his support behind former President Donald J. Trump, Mr. Kennedy has sought both to be removed from and to remain on various state ballots.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Tuesday declined to remove Robert F. Kennedy Jr. from the presidential ballots in two key battleground states, Wisconsin and Michigan.

headline: Teri Garr’s Life in Pictures
abstract: Garr, who could easily command attention onscreen with her expressive eyes, later became known as a spokeswoman for multiple sclerosis research.
lead_paragraph: Teri Garr, who died on Tuesday at 79, will be remembered for her strong comedic chops and for her ability to act with her eyes, displaying a wide range of emotions.

headline: Democrats Highlight Puerto Rico Insult on Billboards Near Trump Rally
abstract: The party invested in two digital highway billboards in Allentown, Pa., which has a significant Puerto Rican population.
lead_paragraph: As former President Donald J. Trump tries to move past a speaker’s ugly insult of Puerto Rico at his Madison Square Garden rally, Democrats are working to elevate it — literally.

headline: Amid Backlash, Trump Claims No President Has Done More for Puerto Rico Than He Has
abstract: The former president made the claim at a round-table discussion in Pennsylvania on Tuesday, days after a comic disparaged Puerto Rico during Sunday’s Trump rally in New York.
lead_paragraph: Days after a comedian described Puerto Rico as a “floating island of garbage” at Donald J. Trump’s Madison Square Garden rally, the former president’s team seemed to manufacture a moment for him on Tuesday to pledge allegiance to the territory.

headline: Fani Willis Takes the Stand as a Victim of Racist Threats
abstract: Ms. Willis spoke of the fear she felt after a man made “vile” calls targeting her and another Black official in Georgia. The man was sentenced to almost two years in prison.
lead_paragraph: Fani T. Willis, the district attorney in Fulton County, Ga., went before a federal judge on Tuesday in downtown Atlanta. Not as a prosecutor, but as a victim.

headline: A Conservative Case Against Trump
abstract: In a choice between misfortunes, one is clearly worse.
lead_paragraph: With a week to go before the election, Kamala Harris has yet to come up with a compelling rationale for her candidacy, other than to accuse her opponent of being a fascist. Ask her a question to which she doesn’t have a canned answer and she struggles for a coherent response. The most notable difference between her current presidential bid and her previous one in 2019 is that she has repudiated many of her past views. Is it because she’s hiding her real convictions — or because she has few real convictions at all?

headline: A Harris Presidency Is the Only Way to Stay Ahead of A.I.
abstract: We must make sure that superintelligent machines remain aligned with human values and interests as they use their powers to go off in their own directions.
lead_paragraph: There are many reasons I was deeply disappointed that The Washington Post’s owner, Jeff Bezos, chose to kill his newspaper’s editorial endorsing Kamala Harris for president, but none more than the fact that Bezos loves science. And this election coincides with one of the greatest scientific turning points in human history: the birth of artificial general intelligence, or A.G.I., which is likely to emerge in the next four years and will require our next president to pull together a global coalition to productively, safely and compatibly govern computers that will soon have minds of their own superior to our own.

headline: Jaywalking Is a New York Tradition. Now It’s Legal, Too.
abstract: New Yorkers can cross the street wherever they please without fear of a summons. Some fear the new law could lead to more pedestrian deaths.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 70 years ago, New York City began a campaign to warn pedestrians of the dangers of jaywalking.

headline: Elon Musk Sees Trump’s Economic Plans Causing ‘Temporary Hardship’
abstract: Mr. Musk agreed with an X post saying there would be an “initial severe overreaction in the economy” before returning to sustainable growth if Mr. Trump is elected and follows through on his plans.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the world’s richest man, has become perhaps the most prominent business backer of Donald J. Trump’s campaign. But even he has doubts that the former president’s economic plans will swiftly supercharge the United States economy.

headline: Solange Knowles, Danny Meyer and Darren Walker Honor the Studio Museum in Harlem
abstract: Artists, business executives and museum leaders turned out for the annual benefit, which raised more than $3.7 million for the museum.
lead_paragraph: After thinking about it for a moment, Thelma Golden estimated she’d had already attended about a dozen galas this season.

headline: When Will the Presidential Race Be Called? Here’s What to Know.
abstract: It could take days to know the winner, as it did in 2020, because counting mail ballots takes time. But returns on election night could also offer clarity.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, the world knew that Donald J. Trump had won the presidency by the time it woke up the morning after Election Day. In 2020, the race wasn’t called for Joseph R. Biden Jr. until the following Saturday.

headline: Wisconsin Pizzeria Error Led Dozens to Eat Cannabis Oil Pizza
abstract: At least five customers sought medical attention after eating pizza from the store, Famous Yeti’s Pizza, which accidentally used a legal THC oil, health officials said.
lead_paragraph: At least five people sought medical attention and dozens were reportedly affected last week after a Wisconsin pizza parlor accidentally used cannabis oil on some of its pies, officials said.

headline: Nikki Haley Says She Is ‘on Standby’ to Campaign for Donald Trump
abstract: Ms. Haley, a former rival of Mr. Trump, has repeatedly offered advice and criticism to Mr. Trump and other Republican candidates from the sidelines.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley, Donald J. Trump’s last rival standing in the fight for the Republican nomination earlier this year, once again had sharp words of criticism for his campaign on Tuesday, saying that the rhetoric surrounding his effort was driving away the women and minorities he needs to put him over the top in battleground states. Nevertheless, she said she was “on standby” to campaign for the man she endorsed after a bruising primary season.

headline: Corrections: Oct. 30, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Oct. 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about a call for women to be given more leadership roles in the Catholic Church misstated the given name of a female bishop whose ordination is not recognized by the Vatican. She is the Rev. Bridget Mary Meehan, not Mary Bridget. The article also misstated the organization that Pat Brown belongs to. It is the Catholic Women’s Ordination, not the Women’s Ordination Conference.

headline: Satellite Images Suggest Israel Struck a Major Iranian Missile Plant
abstract: Analysts said the Shahroud Space Center was likely used to produce intermediate-range ballistic missiles that could be used to target Israel.
lead_paragraph: New satellite photographs suggest that the Israeli military’s attack on Iran on Saturday struck an array of sensitive military sites, including a major missile production facility.

headline: China’s Latest Security Target: Halloween Partygoers
abstract: Last year, the Shanghai government said Halloween celebrations were a sign of “cultural tolerance.” This year, the police rounded up people in costume.
lead_paragraph: The police escorted the Buddha down the street, one officer steering him with both hands. They hurried a giant poop emoji out of a cheering dance circle in a public park. They also pounced on Donald J. Trump with a bandaged ear, and pushed a Kim Kardashian look-alike, in a tight black dress and pearls, into a police van, while she turned and waved to a crowd of onlookers.

headline: Home With a Dome
abstract: Josh M. Kaufmann speaks his Crossword debut into existence.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: As Trump Sows Doubt on Pennsylvania Voting, Officials Say the System Is Working
abstract: Donald Trump is using reports about suspicious voter registrations to cast the election as already flawed. County officials say the episodes are being distorted.
lead_paragraph: With about a week to go before Election Day, officials from two Pennsylvania counties announced that they had found large batches of suspicious voter registration forms. While at least some of the documents appeared to be fraudulent, there is no indication that any of them are ballots, though officials clarified that they were continuing to investigate.

headline: Partial Breach of Election Machine Passwords in Colorado Poses No Risk, State Says
abstract: The secretary of state said that the machines are not online, require a second set of passwords and are under constant surveillance in locked rooms.
lead_paragraph: Partial passwords for election machines that were accidentally leaked on the Colorado secretary of state’s website pose no threat to the system’s security, the secretary’s office said in a statement on Tuesday night.

headline: Michelle Obama, Rallying Young Voters Near Atlanta, Warns of ‘Apathy’
abstract: With just a few days left to vote early in Georgia, the former first lady offered a bracing tutorial in the realities of political power, beseeching young people to reach out to the undecided voters in their lives.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama, the former first lady and among the Democrats’ most popular surrogates, offered a bracing tutorial in the realities of political power on Tuesday night, beseeching thousands of people near Atlanta to vote and to “stop the spiral of disillusionment and apathy.”

headline: 20 Years of Impossible Choices in ‘Saw’
abstract: The low-budget 2004 horror movie captured audiences and spawned a franchise by asking tough moral questions.
lead_paragraph: The low-budget 2004 horror movie captured audiences and spawned a franchise by asking tough moral questions.

headline: 'Stop Pointing Fingers and Start Locking Arms,' Harris Says
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris delivered a speech from Washington’s Ellipse, where former President Trump exhorted his followers on Jan. 6, 2021, highlighting their differences in front of about 75,000 people.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris delivered a speech from Washington’s Ellipse, where former President Trump exhorted his followers on Jan. 6, 2021, highlighting their differences in front of about 75,000 people.

headline: Biden Appears to Insult Trump Supporters as ‘Garbage,’ but Quickly Tries to Clarify
abstract: In a posting on social media, President Biden said he was talking about racist language, not Trump supporters.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Tuesday denounced racist language at former President Donald J. Trump’s recent rally but appeared to insult Trump supporters as “garbage,” prompting waves of criticism from Republicans.

headline: Trump and His Allies Link Biden’s ‘Garbage’ Comment to 2016 ‘Deplorables’ Remark
abstract: Within minutes of the clip of President Biden’s remarks going viral, the Trump campaign and others were using it to attack Kamala Harris and Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and his allies are trying to recreate a moment that resonated deeply with his supporters in the 2016 campaign: when Hillary Clinton referred to Trump supporters as a “basket of deplorables.”

headline: How TikTok Saved Its E-Commerce Business in Indonesia
abstract: When the government effectively forced TikTok to shut down its Shop feature, the company quickly struck an unusual deal with a local company to bring it back.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, TikTok’s e-commerce business in Indonesia was thriving. With its viral videos, TikTok had become a worldwide phenomenon, and it was translating its influence into a powerful new revenue stream by letting users buy and sell things while its videos played.

headline: Delivering a Package in a Country With 17,000 Islands
abstract: When TikTok needed an e-commerce partner in Indonesia, Tokopedia was an obvious candidate for the vast network of warehouses, motorbikes and “sprinters” it uses.
lead_paragraph: Iksan knows the roads around his hometown on the Indonesian island of Sumatra like the back of his hand. He runs a package sorting center from his garage, a small but essential piece of a sprawling network delivering goods bought on Tokopedia, the country’s biggest homegrown e-commerce company.

headline: Spain Opens Its Doors to China as a European Trade War Looms
abstract: Spain is forging a path as a “connector” country, drawing Chinese investment as it abstained from taking a position on European tariffs on electric cars.
lead_paragraph: In January, the Catalan regional government in Spain created a specialized desk dedicated to increasing investment and trade with China, the world’s second-largest economy.

headline: Quote of the Day: In Brooklyn, Humble Touch of Home for the Long-Gone Dodgers
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, October 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “New people don’t always understand the gravity of the fact that we’re walking where legends walked.”

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: A closing address by Vice President Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: Appearing in Washington a week before the U.S. election, Vice President Kamala Harris urged the nation to move beyond violent division and “to stop pointing fingers and start locking arms” for a future of shared responsibility.

headline: Six Days Left: Closing Arguments, Racist Jokes and Burning Ballots
abstract: Michael Barbaro sits down with the Times reporters Lisa Lerer, Astead Herndon and Shane Goldmacher to discuss the final week of the presidential race
lead_paragraph: Michael Barbaro sits down with the Times reporters Lisa Lerer, Astead Herndon and Shane Goldmacher to discuss the final week of the presidential race

headline: Giorgia Meloni Knows Exactly What She’s Doing
abstract: In a country where cabinets and positive approval ratings are infamously short-lived, Italy’s prime minister is becoming a rare paragon of stability.
lead_paragraph: When Italy recently passed a law to punish people who seek a surrogate birth abroad with large fines and prison sentences, there was some outrage. But it didn’t seem to last very long.

headline: Can John Green Make You Care About Tuberculosis?
abstract: With a forthcoming nonfiction book and an online army of Nerdfighters, the young-adult author aims to eliminate an entirely curable global scourge.
lead_paragraph: You can roughly guess a person’s age based on how they know John Green. Older millennials met Mr. Green and his brother, Hank, on YouTube in the late 2000s, when they were performing songs about Harry Potter and cultivating a fan base of “Nerdfighters.” Younger millennials probably know him as the author of “The Fault in Our Stars,” “Looking for Alaska” and other best-selling young-adult novels that feature complex and frequently tragic teenage characters. Generation Z-ers herald Mr. Green as a beloved professor: Since 2012, he has hosted video lessons on history, literature and religion for an educational web series called “Crash Course.”

headline: Super Typhoon Kong-rey Moves Toward Taiwan
abstract: The storm prompted closures and raised the risk of landslides as it approached the island. It was expected to hit as the equivalent of a Category 4 hurricane.
lead_paragraph: Go here for the latest on Typhoon Kong-rey.

headline: Word of the Day: tinny
abstract: This word has appeared in 20 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word tinny has appeared in 20 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 28 in “A New Fitness Craze With Big Drama” by Calum Marsh:

headline: Jimmy Kimmel: ‘Tonight’s Monologue Is for Republicans’
abstract: Kimmel made a 19-minute case against Donald Trump on Tuesday, asking viewers to “send it to a Republican you love.” (He did throw in a Biden joke.)
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: This Waterfront District Is a Developer’s Dream. Could It Come True?
abstract: The Red Hook waterfront in Brooklyn used to be home to some of the busiest piers on the East Coast. Developers say the land could fit thousands of housing units.
lead_paragraph: On one of the most desirable tracts of waterfront land in Brooklyn, underwater pests have eaten through the wood pilings of two piers. A freight terminal is in a state of disrepair. Four out-of-order cranes stand rusting and are about to be sold for scrap.

headline: Was Stone Age Scandinavia Struck by Plague?
abstract: New research by geneticists hints at the deadly work of Yersinia pestis 5,000 years ago.
lead_paragraph: At the end of the Stone Age, some 5,300 years ago, the populations of Scandinavia and northwest Europe plummeted, and farming communities evaporated. “People stopped building megaliths, like Stonehenge,” said Frederik Seersholm, a geneticist at the University of Copenhagen. “Settlements were abandoned. Everyone vanished.”

headline: Homeless People Sue New York City for Throwing Away Their Property
abstract: The lawsuit, which could become a class action, argues that the city’s cleanups, or “sweeps,” violate constitutional protections against illegal searches and seizures.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of times a year, a crew of New York City workers approaches an outdoor place where a homeless person is staying. A park bench. A stretch of sidewalk. The doorway of an abandoned building.

headline: In New York, Democrats See Glimmer of Hope After Stinging Midterm Losses
abstract: Their congressional candidates have fixed key political missteps. But are voters upset about inflation and the migrant influx ready to take the party back?
lead_paragraph: Two years after Democrats suffered embarrassing midterm losses in New York that cost them control of the House of Representatives, the state is poised to once again play a pivotal role — this time, the party hopes, in its favor.

headline: Subway Wedding
abstract: Some couples are embracing the gritty, chaotic appeal of the subway system for their wedding ceremonies and receptions. Where might you want to get married someday?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever pictured your own wedding? What do you imagine it to be like? Are you atop a mountain with the sun shining down? At a small, intimate gathering with a few family and friends? Do you picture a lavish, spare-no-expense affair or a traditional walk down the aisle in a church, synagogue or mosque?

headline: If You Think Biden and Harris Were Weak on the Border, Think Again
abstract: Behind the scenes, Biden and Harris conducted a campaign to secure the border.
lead_paragraph: Behind the scenes, Biden and Harris conducted a campaign to secure the border.

headline: Europe Imposes Higher Tariffs on Electric Vehicles Made in China
abstract: The tariffs, some as high as 45 percent, are intended to protect Europe’s automotive sector, but they could escalate a trade war with China.
lead_paragraph: Consumers in Europe may face higher prices for electric vehicles made in China after tariffs on the cars came into effect on Wednesday as part of an effort by European leaders to create what they call a level playing field for domestic auto companies.

headline: The Piano Trio: (Still) a Powerful Force in Jazz
abstract: New releases from Tyshawn Sorey, Kim Cass, Bill Charlap, Tarbaby, Matthew Shipp, Kris Davis and others are showcasing how a classic format can still feel fresh.
lead_paragraph: Two of the most engrossing jazz tracks in recent months, the Tyshawn Sorey Trio’s “Your Good Lies” and Kim Cass’s “Slag,” share a classic trio instrumentation and the presence of Sorey behind the kit.

headline: A Couple Are Captivated by Nature. They Think You Should Be, Too.
abstract: They have cataloged natural life online and have developed board games and walking tours to help people deepen their knowledge of the world around them.
lead_paragraph: Apparently the die was cast the day Matt Cohen and Elizabeth Hargrave met 25 years ago, when their first conversation turned to composting with worms. This would be a relationship between two people for whom the natural world was always front of mind.

headline: The Menopause Queen’s Gambit
abstract: Dr. Mary Claire Haver has amassed a following in the millions, all on the promise that women can thrive through menopause. Not everyone is celebrating her rise.
lead_paragraph: It was 10 in the morning, and Dr. Mary Claire Haver, an OB-GYN, had already recorded a video in her pajamas on solutions for low sex drive for her combined four million followers on Instagram and TikTok. Now Dr. Haver, 56, was walking briskly on her Peloton treadmill while reading a study on female sexual dysfunction.

headline: Can Crosswords and Games Prevent Dementia?
abstract: Experts say the answer is a puzzle.
lead_paragraph: It makes sense in principle: You exercise your muscles to make them stronger and prevent frailty and decline; shouldn’t your brain work the same way?

headline: At a Glitzy Saudi Investment Forum, Almost No Mention of War
abstract: Saudi Arabia and its Gulf neighbors are seeking to reassure foreign investors that it’s still safe to do business amid the turmoil around the Mideast.
lead_paragraph: When senior Saudi officials took the podium this week at the kingdom’s glitzy annual investment forum, there was barely a mention of the war unsettling the Middle East for more than a year now.

headline: 24 Hours in Mumbai With an Airline Pilot
abstract: Flight crews see the world in 24- to 48-hour bites between international flights. On this trip, the stop is the crowded city on India’s west coast.
lead_paragraph: One of the perks of my job as a Boeing 787 pilot for British Airways is the opportunity to explore the cities I fly to around the world. The challenge is to make the most of my frequent short layovers — typically 24 or 48 hours — and to balance favorite hangouts and precious downtime with new adventures.

headline: A Psychic to the Stars Would Retire, if His Clients Would Let Him
abstract: Frank Andrews did readings for John Lennon, Princess Grace and other celebrities. At 83, he is still talking to ghosts, providing “weather forecasts” and making friends.
lead_paragraph: Frank Andrews wants people to know something about being a psychic: It is exhausting. Picking up random energy, being visited by unexpected phantasmas, listening to the troubles of the very much alive. It’s emotionally draining, especially if you’ve been doing the job for nearly 60 years.

headline: 12 Books Coming in November
abstract: Novels by Haruki Murakami and Rebecca Yarros, memoirs by Angela Merkel and Cher, and more.
lead_paragraph: Ten years after retiring from “The Tonight Show,” Carson talked with Zehme for a 2002 Esquire piece that stands as his only public discussion of life after TV superstardom. Plans for a biography were stalled, then cut short, when Zehme, the author of books about Frank Sinatra and Andy Kaufman, died in 2023. Finished by his former research assistant, “Carson the Magnificent” promises to capture an entertainer who remained at once familiar and remote.

headline: Martha Stewart Gives Netflix’s ‘Martha’ a Scalding Review
abstract: When a reporter phoned about her new documentary, the lifestyle star didn’t hold back: “I hate those last scenes. Hate them.”
lead_paragraph: Most business titans spout niceties — insipid, banal, stale — when speaking to reporters on the record. It can be impossible to get them to say what they really think, and if they accidentally let something colorful slip, a saw-toothed publicist inevitably arrives to try to scrub it away.

headline: Democratic Lawyer Stymied Trump in 2020. Other Efforts Played Into G.O.P. Hands.
abstract: Marc Elias, hired to help Kamala Harris in election-related fights, helped to pave the way for big money in politics.
lead_paragraph: In January, the law firm of the powerful Democratic lawyer Marc Elias launched a gambit intended to help his party.

headline: How FTX’s Young Executives Shattered Their Parents
abstract: As their children are sentenced for fraud, the parents of FTX’s top leaders have described their disbelief at how the crypto exchange upended their lives.
lead_paragraph: The week that FTX collapsed in 2022, the father of Nishad Singh, one of the crypto exchange’s top executives, arrived at the airport to pick him up.

headline: 6 Classic College Football Towns to Visit
abstract: Go for the energy of the mascots, marching bands and touchdown cheers, but don’t miss the museums, art, nightlife and more that make these places special.
lead_paragraph: Each autumn, in college towns across the United States, the fervor for football can almost feel religious as students, alumni, families and other fans fill stadiums, rooting for their teams to reach a bowl game and, just maybe, the College Football Playoff National Championship Game on Jan. 20 in Atlanta.

headline: A Chef Embraces an Elusive Fruit of Her Ancestors
abstract: Her take on beautifully ripe ‘ulu, or breadfruit in Hawaiian, is worth the wait.
lead_paragraph: Is it skill, gift or mystic power to know when a fruit is truly, perfectly ripe? Robynne Maii, a chef and co-owner of Fête in Honolulu, remembers her grandmother’s keeping vigil over a bunch of bananas, checking them every two hours. The banana appears obliging, the green ebbing from the peel and the yellow growing brighter, like a sun in bloom. Then — blink! — the swift collapse into freckled mush begins. Like bankruptcy in a Hemingway novel, ripening happens gradually and then suddenly.

headline: These Progressive Ideas Flopped. They’re Still Dangerous.
abstract: Just because an idea never became law doesn’t mean we should shrug it off.
lead_paragraph: If Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign ends in defeat, one of her responses during her Oct. 16 Fox News interview will make a fitting epitaph. Asked about her former advocacy for giving driver’s licenses, college tuition and free health care to undocumented immigrants, she replied, “Listen, that was five years ago.” Those words hold a valuable lesson for a progressive movement more often heard quoting the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s famous and rather different declaration that “the arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends toward justice.”

headline: The Weird Persistence of the Victoria’s Secret ‘Angel’
abstract: The company has tried to shed its retrograde standards of beauty aspiration and perfection. But many women miss the old bombshell fantasy.
lead_paragraph: In the 2014 Victoria’s Secret Fashion Show, there is a quiet moment before the models walk the runway in their costume lingerie: The women huddle around the corporate executive Ed Razek, a man instrumental in choosing them for the final lineup. He is in his 60s, graying, with a rich person’s tan; the women glow with body shimmer and would tower over him if he were not standing on a low stage. “This is simply the most special runway in the world,” he tells them, “and it has no equivalent.”

headline: Clean Energy Is Booming in the U.S. The Election Could Change That.
abstract: Trump has suggested he would dismantle the Inflation Reduction Act, which has reshaped America’s energy landscape. It won’t be easy.
lead_paragraph: Over the last two years, a surge in clean energy manufacturing has helped push U.S. factory construction to the highest level in half a century. Solar power installations and electric car sales are breaking records. Even Republican-led states like Montana and Utah are writing climate plans to secure federal cash.

headline: Flash Floods in Spain Leave at Least 95 Dead
abstract: About 1,000 soldiers from emergency response units deployed to the affected areas, and the death toll was expected to rise after one of the worst natural disasters to hit the country in recent years.
lead_paragraph: At least 95 people have died and others were missing after devastating flash floods hit eastern Spain, according to the local authorities, in one of the worst natural disasters to hit the country in recent years.

headline: Padma Lakshmi’s St. Christopher Necklace
abstract: The Emmy-nominated television host, author and editor rarely takes off this piece of jewelry, a reminder of a significant relationship in her life.
lead_paragraph: For over a decade, Padma Lakshmi has worn a Tiffany gold necklace with a medallion of St. Christopher, patron saint of travelers, around her neck. She rarely takes it off.

headline: What if Democrats Win the White House and Congress on Tuesday?
abstract: If Democrats win the White House and Congress, they might finally make lasting changes to voting rights and abortion access.
lead_paragraph: Call it a political upset for the ages or just a pipe dream, but Democrats should put aside their anxiety for a moment and imagine this scenario next week: Kamala Harris wins the presidency, Democrats take the House and they beat the odds by holding most of their Senate seats and pulling off at least one surprise victory (Texas? Florida? Nebraska?) that lets them maintain power in that chamber.

headline: Why This Nuclear Power Plant Is Restarting
abstract: Three Mile Island, known for being the site of the worst U.S. nuclear energy accident, is now at the forefront of efforts to expand nuclear capacity to meet rising electricity demand. Rebecca F. Elliott, a reporter covering energy for The New York Times, explains.
lead_paragraph: Three Mile Island, known for being the site of the worst U.S. nuclear energy accident, is now at the forefront of efforts to expand nuclear capacity to meet rising electricity demand. Rebecca F. Elliott, a reporter covering energy for The New York Times, explains.

headline: A Democratic and a Republican Pollster Agree: This Is the Fault Line That Decides the Election
abstract: How college-educated women and non-college-educated men are defining the contours of the 2024 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: How college-educated women and non-college-educated men are defining the contours of the 2024 presidential election.

headline: How Many Continents Are There? You May Not Like the Answers.
abstract: Recent earth science developments suggest that how we count our planet’s largest land masses is less clear than we learned in school.
lead_paragraph: Your kids may have come home from school singing this infectious ditty, or another like it. But are there really seven continents?

headline: What It Means to Make Art About Nazis Now
abstract: And is the culture telling the right stories about them, at a time when it’s never felt more urgent?
lead_paragraph: A MAN IN a tie and suspenders smokes a cigar thoughtfully, its ash end hot orange in an otherwise cool blue shot. Its fiery pock is the most lurid thing we see in Jonathan Glazer’s “The Zone of Interest,” even though there’s a crematorium next door.

headline: $750,000 Homes in Illinois, New Hampshire and Tennessee
abstract: A Craftsman-style house from 1913 in Evanston, Ill., a two-bedroom condo in a converted mill building in Peterborough, N.H., and a Queen Anne Revival-style house from 1899 in Knoxville, Tenn.
lead_paragraph: This three-bedroom, one-and-a-half bathroom house is a short walk from three parks and from the Central Street train station, putting it around half an hour from Chicago via public transit. A Whole Foods and an outpost of the local Walker Bros. Original Pancake House chain are also within walking distance. Driving to beaches along the shoreline of Lake Michigan takes less than 10 minutes. Public elementary, middle and high schools are all within a 10-minute drive.

headline: My Dad Is George Lopez. We Healed Our Relationship With a Sitcom.
abstract: Mayan Lopez found a way to turn her family drama into laughter.
lead_paragraph: The actress and producer Mayan Lopez has seen a majority of her life play out on television.

headline: The Myth of the Mad Artist Is Harmful. I Should Know.
abstract: The presumption of emotional instability has made it not easier but more difficult for artists to be forthright about our mental health.
lead_paragraph: Many of the indelible experiences of my life have come while performing Robert Schumann’s works. His music is poetic, emotionally direct even in its stranger moments and suggestive of deep vulnerability: a unique and potent combination. On the concert stage, where everything becomes more highly charged, it can be overwhelming.

headline: Three Mile Island, Notorious in Nuclear Power’s Past, May Herald Its Future
abstract: The Pennsylvania plant, site of the worst U.S. nuclear energy accident, is at the forefront of efforts to expand nuclear capacity to meet rising electricity demand.
lead_paragraph: The concrete cooling towers that rise from a sliver of land south of Pennsylvania’s capital became symbols nearly a half-century ago of the risks of nuclear energy.

headline: Why a Wealthy University Is Selling 2 of Its Paintings
abstract: Rockefeller University will auction off two works by Joan Mitchell, an Abstract Expressionist painter. They could sell for $32 million.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll find out why a university with endowment assets of $2.5 billion is selling two Abstract Expressionist paintings that it has owned for nearly 70 years. We’ll also get details on a twist in Mayor Eric Adams’s unusual political relationship with former President Donald Trump.

headline: 6 Performances Our Classical Critics Can’t Stop Thinking About
abstract: Watch and listen to symphonies by Mahler, a new opera by Missy Mazzoli, Ray Chen’s take on video game music and more.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times’s classical music and opera critics attend far more performances than they review. Here are some that hooked them during the past month.

headline: Let’s Set the Record Straight on Biden, Harris and the Border
abstract: Behind the scenes, the president and vice president conducted a campaign to get the crisis under control.
lead_paragraph: Immigration is a top issue on voters’ minds. When people talk about President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris’s handling of immigration, they usually say something like: Record numbers of migrants poured across the border over the past three years, and Mr. Biden and Ms. Harris ignored the crisis until recently. They were weak on the border. Or worse, inept.

headline: The Wild, Wild West Makes for an Oddly Tame Yarn
abstract: Tom Clavin’s “Bandit Heaven” takes us down the “Outlaw Trail” with Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid.
lead_paragraph: Around 2 a.m. on June 2, 1899, the engineer of an eastbound train outside of Wilcox, Wyo., spotted someone waving a red lantern. As he braked, a masked man with a gun crawled into the cab from behind and said, “Now, you son of a bitch, do what I say, or I will put light through you!”

headline: Somewhere Amid the Frappuccinos, Fans Say Starbucks Lost Something
abstract: Customers are turning away from the coffee giant, and its new chief executive, Brian Niccol, has to figure out how to get them back.
lead_paragraph: For 32 years, Greg Tutunjian, 73, has picked up his coffee at Starbucks. He’s partial to its dark-roast Red Eye, but starting to question his loyalty to the chain that serves it up.

headline: This Time, It May Actually Come Down to Turnout
abstract: Democrats have gained among high-turnout voters, while Donald Trump has made gains among groups that tend to show up only for presidential races, or not at all.
lead_paragraph: Every four years, the pundits say “it all comes down to turnout.” The line is such a cliché — it’s never inaccurate but also means nothing — that it’s sometimes a joke on social media.

headline: The Polls Show a Dead Heat, but They Don’t All Tell the Same Story
abstract: Either way, it’s too close to make a prediction.
lead_paragraph: I have to admit, I laughed when I saw that Donald Trump and Kamala Harris were tied at 48 to 48 among likely voters in the final New York Times/Siena College national poll. Despite untold sums spent on advertising, a cavalcade of wild events — from felony convictions to assassination attempts to the incumbent president withdrawing from the race — here we sit, right on a razor’s edge.

headline: What Do You Like Most About Halloween?
abstract: Elaborate lawn decorations. Bags of candy. Creative costumes. What’s your favorite part of the holiday? What could you do without?
lead_paragraph: Do you love Halloween?

headline: The D.N.C. Targets Regional Newspapers in New Ad Campaign
abstract: The ads seeking to define Donald Trump as “unhinged, unstable, unchecked” are running in smaller suburban newspapers.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Committee is turning to an age-old advertising medium — regional hard copy newspapers — in a final push to define former President Donald J. Trump before Election Day.

headline: Michigan Clerk Removed From Election Duty Over Plans for a Hand Count
abstract: The clerk had said he wanted to count votes by hand, as Trump-aligned activists push misinformation about problems with voting machines.
lead_paragraph: Two local election officials in Michigan have been removed from overseeing the vote, state officials said on Tuesday, in a forceful move to keep Trump-aligned officials from trying to subvert election rules.

headline: Once Top Advisers to Trump, They Now Call Him ‘Liar,’ ‘Fascist’ and ‘Unfit’
abstract: Some of the strongest criticisms of former President Donald J. Trump have come from those who knew him as commander in chief.
lead_paragraph: Some of the strongest criticisms of former President Donald J. Trump have come from those who knew him as commander in chief.

headline: Harris’s Mission: Disqualify Trump, but Extend a Hand to His Voters
abstract: Kamala Harris, in her closing argument to voters, acknowledged an inescapable political reality: Donald Trump is not a fringe figure within his own party or the nation.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

headline: Let Me Ask a Question We Never Had to Ask Before
abstract: Election Day is only the beginning.
lead_paragraph: As the contest for the White House draws to a close, I asked a wide range of scholars and political strategists where they think the blame will go, whether it is Kamala Harris or Donald Trump who wins.

headline: Ukrainians Tell of Brutal Russian Repression in Occupied Territories
abstract: Moscow is employing a variety of tactics, including torture and forced Russian citizenship, to try to obliterate Ukrainian identity, former detainees and human rights groups say.
lead_paragraph: For months after the Russian military occupied his hometown in southern Ukraine, Yevheny made plans to leave. But each time, the 48-year-old lawyer said, he was thwarted, by warnings of gunfire on the roads and, once, when a hired driver disappeared.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 508
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Oct. 31, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,230
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Oct. 31, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Six Days Left: Closing Arguments, Racist Jokes and Burning Ballots
abstract: Our final round table before Election Day features three of The New York Times’s top campaign reporters — Astead Herndon, Shane Goldmacher and Lisa Lerer — discussing the big events of the past several days.
lead_paragraph: Our final round table before Election Day features three of The New York Times’s top campaign reporters — Astead Herndon, Shane Goldmacher and Lisa Lerer — discussing the big events of the past several days.

headline: Six Days Left: Closing Arguments, Racist Jokes and Burning Ballots
abstract: Watch or listen to our final round table before Election Day.
lead_paragraph: In the final week of the race for president, Donald J. Trump’s big rally in New York appeared to backfire, while Kamala Harris’s closing message cast her as a unifier. Fears about election interference also resurfaced after arsonists burned ballots in three states.

headline: Harris Makes Her Final Case, and Trump Seizes on ‘Garbage’
abstract: Plus, refunds for canceled flights.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Israel Widens Hezbollah Strikes, Hitting Lebanese Cities Beyond Border Area
abstract: Israel’s military warned civilians to leave Baalbek in the Bekaa Valley via three routes. The city had largely been spared Israeli bombardment until this week.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military widened its campaign against the militant group Hezbollah on Wednesday, launching airstrikes around the eastern Lebanese city of Baalbek and forcing large numbers of people to flee.

headline: Trump’s Hostility to Democracy
abstract: We explore the ways that Trump could undermine democratic traditions.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has shown more hostility to American democracy than any other president in the country’s history. He tried to overturn an election result. He celebrates political violence. The list goes on, and it is familiar by now.

headline: Here is the letter from Sam Bankman-Fried’s parents to Judge Kaplan.
abstract: Over the past nine months, the parents of Mr. Bankman-Fried, Ms. Ellison and Mr. Singh have written letters to Lewis A. Kaplan, the judge overseeing the FTX case, pleading for leniency for their children. They described the emotional toll of FTX’s collapse, recounting wrenching conversations and endless stress.
lead_paragraph: Over the past nine months, the parents of Mr. Bankman-Fried, Ms. Ellison and Mr. Singh have written letters to Lewis A. Kaplan, the judge overseeing the FTX case, pleading for leniency for their children. They described the emotional toll of FTX’s collapse, recounting wrenching conversations and endless stress.

headline: Read a letter from Sam Bankman-Fried’s father.
abstract: Over the past nine months, the parents of Mr. Bankman-Fried, Ms. Ellison and Mr. Singh have written letters to Lewis A. Kaplan, the judge overseeing the FTX case, pleading for leniency for their children. They described the emotional toll of FTX’s collapse, recounting wrenching conversations and endless stress.
lead_paragraph: Over the past nine months, the parents of Mr. Bankman-Fried, Ms. Ellison and Mr. Singh have written letters to Lewis A. Kaplan, the judge overseeing the FTX case, pleading for leniency for their children. They described the emotional toll of FTX’s collapse, recounting wrenching conversations and endless stress.

headline: Here is the letter from Caroline Ellison’s parents to Judge Kaplan.
abstract: Over the past nine months, the parents of Mr. Bankman-Fried, Ms. Ellison and Mr. Singh have written letters to Lewis A. Kaplan, the judge overseeing the FTX case, pleading for leniency for their children. They described the emotional toll of FTX’s collapse, recounting wrenching conversations and endless stress.
lead_paragraph: Over the past nine months, the parents of Mr. Bankman-Fried, Ms. Ellison and Mr. Singh have written letters to Lewis A. Kaplan, the judge overseeing the FTX case, pleading for leniency for their children. They described the emotional toll of FTX’s collapse, recounting wrenching conversations and endless stress.

headline: Here is the letter from Nishad Singh’s father to Judge Kaplan.
abstract: Over the past nine months, the parents of Mr. Bankman-Fried, Ms. Ellison and Mr. Singh have written letters to Lewis A. Kaplan, the judge overseeing the FTX case, pleading for leniency for their children. They described the emotional toll of FTX’s collapse, recounting wrenching conversations and endless stress.
lead_paragraph: Over the past nine months, the parents of Mr. Bankman-Fried, Ms. Ellison and Mr. Singh have written letters to Lewis A. Kaplan, the judge overseeing the FTX case, pleading for leniency for their children. They described the emotional toll of FTX’s collapse, recounting wrenching conversations and endless stress.

headline: Big Fire Breaks Out at Nuclear Submarine Plant in Britain
abstract: The authorities said there was no nuclear risk. Two people with smoke inhalation received treatment at a hospital.
lead_paragraph: A large fire broke out at a nuclear submarine plant in northwestern England early Wednesday morning. Two people were taken to the hospital for smoke inhalation, according to a spokesman for BAE Systems, the company that owns the plant, but the police said that there was no nuclear risk.

headline: Rescue Operations Underway as Flash Floods Kill Dozens in Spain
abstract: More than 1,000 soldiers from an emergency response team were deployed, and officials said that many more residents were waiting for help, after more than a month’s worth of rain fell in less than 24 hours in some areas across southern and eastern Spain.
lead_paragraph: More than 1,000 soldiers from an emergency response team were deployed, and officials said that many more residents were waiting for help, after more than a month’s worth of rain fell in less than 24 hours in some areas across southern and eastern Spain.

headline: Germany Avoids Recession, but Weak Growth Weighs on Europe
abstract: The continent’s economy continued to limp along, expanding just 0.4 percent in the latest quarter, dragged down by a loss of competitiveness.
lead_paragraph: Europe struggled to turn around its economic fortunes in autumn, as Germany, the region’s powerhouse, reported weak growth, offsetting stronger expansion in the continent’s southern countries, the European statistical agency reported on Wednesday.

headline: The Musk Campaign Steps Up
abstract: The tech mogul is pushing even harder in the final days of the presidential race to get Donald Trump re-elected, with plenty at stake for his businesses.
lead_paragraph: Less than a week out from Election Day, both campaigns and their supporters are pulling out all of the stops. Few are doing as much as Elon Musk.

headline: Consumers Keep U.S. Economy Growing at Healthy Pace
abstract: In a key economic report released just days before the presidential election, gross economic product rose at a 2.8 percent rate in the third quarter.
lead_paragraph: Consumers are spending. Inflation is cooling. And the U.S. economy looks as strong as ever.

headline: Israel Demolished Hundreds of Buildings in Southern Lebanon, Videos and Satellite Images Show
abstract: At least 1,085 buildings have been destroyed or badly damaged since Israel’s invasion targeting the Hezbollah militia, including many in controlled demolitions, a New York Times analysis shows.
lead_paragraph: Satellite imagery and videos show widespread destruction in six villages along Lebanon’s southern border with Israel, revealing 1,085 buildings that have been leveled or badly damaged since its Oct. 1 invasion aimed at crippling the militant group Hezbollah.

headline: Our Fun Friend Bails on Dinner Dates but Still Sends Her Dull Husband. Help!
abstract: Tired of being saddled with “dud” husbands when their more exciting wives bow out of plans, a reader wonders if there’s a way to delicately insist that both members of a couple attend.
lead_paragraph: In our circle, many couples consist of one partner who is dynamic and interesting and one who is … well, a dud. Usually, it’s the husbands who are dull. When we make plans with these couples, the lively wives often drop out at the last minute because of suspicious work crises or illnesses. When they inform me, they say, “But my husband will still be there.” Or if I’m inviting them to dinner, the wife will say, “I have plans that night, but my husband would love to come.” I feel used. I’m all for giving harried spouses a break from each other, but with one couple, the fun wife has been a no-show three times in two months! It feels risky to invite them. How can we address this problem without hurt feelings?

headline: Massachusetts Is Making Its High School Diplomas Meaningless
abstract: A ballot initiative targets tests rather than fixing problems in the system.
lead_paragraph: On Election Day, Massachusetts voters will have a chance to get rid of the state’s high school exit exam, which involves standards-based tests in math, sciences and English. The ballot measure is known as Question 2, and voting yes “would eliminate the requirement that students pass the Massachusetts Comprehensive Assessment System in order to graduate from high school but still require students to complete coursework that meets state standards.”

headline: David Salle’s Ghost in the A.I. Machine
abstract: At Gladstone Gallery, the painter’s experiments with artificial intelligence yield compelling results and big questions.
lead_paragraph: Since the 1980s, the artist David Salle has been developing his liberal use of both pictorial space and source material, drolly collaging images plucked from magazines and art history with a magpie’s blithe indifference. His paintings display an icily cerebral, postmodern understanding that images can exist simultaneously across multiple contexts, or none at all.

headline: Instead of Going Boldly on Space, Harris Has Taken a Steady Approach
abstract: As chair of the White House’s National Space Council, the vice president largely emphasized continuity with policies set by the Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: For America’s direction in space, the course set by Vice President Kamala Harris during the Biden administration has been less to boldly go where no one has gone before and more like when on “Star Trek” Captain Kirk gave the command “Steady as she goes.”

headline: Elon Musk’s SpaceX, Already a Leader in Satellites, Gets Into the Spy Game
abstract: The Pentagon needs what the company offers to compete with China even as it frets over its potential for dominance and the billionaire’s global interests.
lead_paragraph: The breakthrough came last month, about 600 miles above Earth.

headline: In Election’s Final Days, Dark Money and ‘Gray Money’ Fund Hidden Agendas
abstract: Big-money operatives are taking advantage of lax rules at the end of the campaign to hide the true source of their money until after the election is called — or for forever.
lead_paragraph: The campaign literature that landed in Republican mailboxes in North Carolina this week was jarring. On one side was a sonogram image of a human fetus, with this message: “Her heart is beating. We all know it. Only the courageous few will protect her.” On the other side was a call to action: “You have the courage and the conviction to vote for Randall Terry.”

headline: Volkswagen Profit Shrinks as Unions Threaten Strike
abstract: Germany’s biggest automaker said its profit dropped 42 percent in the third quarter, as union leaders warned that workers were ready to walk out over a wage dispute.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen reported a 42 percent drop in quarterly profit on Wednesday, while emphasizing an “urgent need” to cut costs and gain efficiency in a challenging marketplace as it considers plant closures and layoffs in Germany.

headline: Was This Scrap of Cloth Once a Tunic Worn by Alexander the Great?
abstract: A Greek researcher says a piece of purple-and-white fabric discovered decades ago in a tomb in northern Greece may have belonged to Alexander. Others disagree.
lead_paragraph: Could it be a scrap of Alexander the Great’s clothing?

headline: How Donald Trump Is Making Big Promises to Big Business
abstract: Crypto. Big Oil. Tobacco. Vaping. Former President Donald J. Trump has been making overt promises to industry leaders. Shane Goldmacher, a national political correspondent for The New York Times, explains.
lead_paragraph: Crypto. Big Oil. Tobacco. Vaping. Former President Donald J. Trump has been making overt promises to industry leaders. Shane Goldmacher, a national political correspondent for The New York Times, explains.

headline: A ‘Glorious’ Economy
abstract: The economy is a remarkable success, even if Biden and Harris aren’t getting credit for it.
lead_paragraph: Polling suggests that as we go into Election Day, the Republicans’ advantage on the economy is substantially smaller than it was a few months ago. But if you look at the numbers, what’s astonishing is that the advantage doesn’t go the other way.

headline: No, counting votes for several days is not a sign of fraud.
abstract: While the presidential winner was once usually known on election night, closer races and more mail voting have made it harder to make the call as quickly.
lead_paragraph: Influencers and social media users have falsely claimed that voter fraud is the reason it took days to count all votes and decide the winner in the 2020 election, and that it could again in 2024.

headline: New U.K. Government Raises Taxes by Over $50 Billion to Shore Up Finances
abstract: Rachel Reeves, the finance minister, announced substantial tax increases in her first budget as she sought to strengthen public finances and services.
lead_paragraph: The new British government, led by the Labour Party, said it would substantially raise taxes and borrow more for investment as it sought to steer the country out of a long run of economic stagnation.

headline: Fossil Reveals Oldest Known Tadpole That Grew to the Size of a Hot Dog
abstract: A 161 million-year-old fossil, linked to a line of extinct frog-like amphibians, is the oldest tadpole ever found.
lead_paragraph: The metamorphosis of a frog from baby to adult is one of nature’s most remarkable transformations. Tadpoles are born with oversized heads and long tails. Soon the tails vanish, swapped out for tiny legs and a more frog-like shape.

headline: Looking for the Next Streaming Cult Classic? Try Arrow.
abstract: Horror is well-represented on this service, which makes it an ideal spooky season addition to your streaming menu.
lead_paragraph: Over the past several months, we’ve examined and recommended several streaming services for the discriminating movie lover — sites and apps for those whose tastes run toward titles a bit more esoteric than the likes of Netflix and Amazon Prime Video. Our latest entry spotlights a terrific subscription streamer for genre film fans.

headline: Beautiful Badam Burfi Bark for Diwali
abstract: And for Halloween: sheet pan chicken and cheesy broccoli to fuel your trick-or-treaters.
lead_paragraph: Though your week may have started on a rough note (mine began with dental work), it’s looking to end on a sweet note, as Halloween and Diwali overlap. Although they celebrate entirely different things — Halloween the dark and the spooky, Diwali the light and the good — they both do it with dessert, which is something that I can absolutely get behind (despite the dental work).

headline: Heart-Valve Patients Should Have Earlier Surgery, Study Suggests
abstract: The results of a new clinical trial have overturned the “wait and see” approach that cardiologists have long favored for symptom-free patients.
lead_paragraph: For decades, people with failing heart valves who nevertheless felt all right would walk out of the cardiologist’s office with the same “wait and see” treatment plan: Come back in six or 12 months. No reason to go under the knife just yet.

headline: At Dueling Rallies, Harris Stresses Unity as Trump Attacks Biden’s ‘Garbage’ Remark
abstract: In three battleground states, Kamala Harris geared her message toward moderate Republicans and independents, while Donald J. Trump accused Democrats of demonizing him and his supporters.
lead_paragraph: With six days left in the 2024 presidential race, Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump hopscotched the battleground states on Wednesday as they sought to wring support from an electorate already in the full throes of early voting.

headline: Johnson’s ‘No Obamacare’ Remark Draws Attention to Unpopular Stance
abstract: Speaker Mike Johnson said a Trump victory would allow Republicans to embark on a “massive overhaul” of the Affordable Care Act. He said the party wants to “take a blowtorch to the regulatory state.”
lead_paragraph: Speaker Mike Johnson said Tuesday that Republicans would embark on a “massive reform” of the Affordable Care Act if former President Donald J. Trump is elected again, putting an unpopular policy position back in the spotlight just days before the election.

headline: Robert Lighthizer: Trump’s China Trade Warrior and ‘Food Fight’ Referee
abstract: If Donald J. Trump regains the presidency, his former U.S. trade representative could lead his quest to slap punishing tariffs on foreign trading partners.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps nowhere in the Trump White House was the jockeying for ideological influence more raw than what staff members described as the “food fights” during trade meeting Tuesdays.

headline: I Work in Data Security. Is It a Problem That My Boss Believes in Lizard People?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what to do when people in positions of power espouse harmful conspiracy theories.
lead_paragraph: I work in the I.T. department of a town government, where our small team is led by a director who is a fervent conspiracy theorist. In casual conversations, the director frequently discusses bizarre ideas in a hushed, serious manner, as if revealing hidden truths: lizard people infiltrating the federal government, the Rothschilds as vampiric blood drinkers and J.F.K. Jr. secretly controlling Trump with plans for a 2024 comeback.

headline: Where Some See Taboos, They See Opportunity
abstract: The founders of Starface took the shame out of blemishes. Now, they’re hoping to make it less risky to use recreational drugs and alcohol.
lead_paragraph: A poster plastered to a wall in Los Angeles shows a woman flipping two middle fingers at the camera. Her tongue sticks out, and her zebra-print bikini top is discarded on the grass beside her.

headline: Supreme Court Allows Virginia to Purge Possibly Ineligible Voters for Now
abstract: A divided court sided with Republicans, allowing the state to cull about 1,600 voters less than a week before Election Day.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Wednesday allowed Virginia to purge about 1,600 people from its voter rolls, handing a temporary victory to Republican officials in the state who said the move was necessary to prevent noncitizens from voting.

headline: Can Democrats Win Back Voters From Trump on Trade Policy?
abstract: The Biden administration has pursued a big shift in trade policy, but it’s not clear whether that will be enough to win votes.
lead_paragraph: Since Donald J. Trump won over many working-class voters in 2016 with his vows to impose tariffs and rework “disastrous” trade deals, Democrats have been scrambling to win back supporters by taking a more protectionist trade approach.

headline: Policing, Abortion, Trump: Inside a Tightening Race for a Key House Seat
abstract: Sue Altman, a Democrat, has focused on reproductive rights as she seeks to unseat a Republican incumbent, Representative Thomas Kean Jr., in a New Jersey swing district.
lead_paragraph: Sue Altman has made a name for herself by taking on political heavy hitters in New Jersey.

headline: Jeff Bezos, Elon Musk and the Billions of Ways to Influence an Election
abstract: The world’s richest men have their own rocket fleets, their own media and their own schemes to succeed with Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Entrepreneurs become legends when they make big bets on technology that pay off in a huge and dramatic way. Elon Musk is now applying that all-or-nothing philosophy to a presidential election, tying his reputation and perhaps his future to a win by Donald J. Trump.

headline: When War Becomes an Aesthetic, Nobody Wins
abstract: There are fun missions in Call of Duty: Black Ops 6, set during the U.S.-Iraq war of the 1990s. But the conspiratorial plot refuses to engage actual politics or history.
lead_paragraph: Unlike the contemporary context of Call of Duty’s Modern Warfare series, its Black Ops titles are usually set during Cold War conflicts. The first game has you attempting to assassinate Fidel Castro. You join forces with Jonas Savimbi’s Angolan rebellion in the sequel. And Russia dutifully rears its head as a perennial boogeyman throughout. In Black Ops Cold War, you even get to infiltrate the K.G.B.’s headquarters and glad-hand with Gorbachev.

headline: This Is Your Body on Sugar
abstract: Excessive consumption of sugar can increase the risk of health problems. Here's what that looks like in the body.
lead_paragraph: Excessive consumption of sugar can increase the risk of health problems. Here's what that looks like in the body.

headline: Fact-Checking Harris’s Closing Argument
abstract: The vice president has stuck largely to the facts when highlighting the words of her rival, former President Donald J. Trump, but has on occasion omitted context or erred when describing policies and statistics.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates of the 2024 election here.

headline: Walking Away From the Tunnel Walk
abstract: Kyle Kuzma unleashed an arms race of pregame N.B.A. style. Now he plans to wear a bland sweatsuit to every game. Will others follow suit?
lead_paragraph: Last week, the N.B.A. was rocked by a surprise retirement announcement — though no one actually left the league.

headline: Rudy May, a Stingy Master of the Curveball, Dies at 80
abstract: He overcame a dip in velocity to find pitching success with four teams, including the Yankees and Orioles, and had a dominant season in 1980.
lead_paragraph: Rudy May, a crafty and well-traveled left-handed pitcher whose 16-year major league career included two stretches with the Yankees — one in the mid-1970s, when he found success despite a strained relationship with the volcanic manager Billy Martin, and the other starting in 1980, the year he led the American League in earned run average — died on Oct. 19. He was 80.

headline: Public Art Leader to Step Down
abstract: After steering the art program in Madison Square Park for 11 years, Brooke Kamin Rapaport is turning her focus to research on democracy and civic space.
lead_paragraph: Brooke Kamin Rapaport, a leader in public art who has steered the program in Madison Square Park in New York for the last 11 years, is stepping down at the end of December as artistic director and chief curator of the Madison Square Park Conservancy, the organization announced Wednesday. It also said its board has formed a committee to conduct an open call for her successor.

headline: Being a College Athlete Now Means Constant Travel and Missed Classes
abstract: Players are dealing with far-flung travel, jet lag and the pressures of trying to balance the roles of student, athlete and entrepreneur more than ever before.
lead_paragraph: Playing football this season for the U.C.L.A. Bruins means being a frequent (and distant) flier. The team began the campaign in August with a win at the University of Hawaii. Their next road games sent the Bruins to Louisiana State, then Penn State, and back across the country to Rutgers. Then, a trip to Nebraska on Saturday and a jaunt up to Washington.

headline: Two Climate Change Plays Keep the Flames of Hope Alive
