headline: ‘Blitz’ Review: Love in the Ruins
abstract: Steve McQueen’s World War II drama may appear conventional on the surface, but don’t miss what it’s really doing.
lead_paragraph: World War II is almost certainly the big screen’s most immortalized conflict, and for good reason. It broke just as cinema was beginning to mature as a form of entertainment, and footage from the front narrated by peppy tales of victory was part of many people’s moviegoing experience. What’s more, though, the outlines of World War II could be boiled down to clean tales of good versus evil, bravery versus cruelty — the sort of stories that make good two-hour feature films.

headline: Comcast Explores Spin-Out of Cable Business
abstract: The company’s president, Mike Cavanagh, said the company was also considering finding a partner for its Peacock streaming service.
lead_paragraph: Comcast, one of the nation’s biggest television companies, said on Thursday that it was weighing whether to cleave its cable networks from the rest of the company, a move that could put it in position to shake up the struggling cable industry.

headline: How a Tiny Panel, Up for Election, Could Steer Arizona Away From Clean Power
abstract: The vote, in a sunny state with huge solar potential, reflects a growing nationwide fight over America’s energy transition.
lead_paragraph: As Arizona voters go the polls, they have more control over their state’s power plants and climate policies than they might realize.

headline: Those Voters Who Are Still Undecided
abstract: Readers express surprise that some voters are still uncertain and urge them to vote. Also: Michelle Obama’s plea; marijuana reform; family policies.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Pierre Franey Turkey Chili
abstract: Five stars, over 17,000 ratings, one hour, perfect chili.
lead_paragraph: “I was thinking I’d make chili this week.”

headline: They’re Giving Scammers All Their Money. The Kids Can’t Stop Them.
abstract: One son couldn’t prevent his father from giving about $1 million in savings to con artists, including one posing as a female wrestling star. The two became estranged.
lead_paragraph: When Chris Mancinelli walked into his father’s home for the first time after the 79-year-old man died last summer, he stopped to look at family photos displayed on the refrigerator door. Near a crayon drawing spelling out “grandpa” in rainbow colors were photos of his father’s three granddaughters at a swimming pool.

headline: After Turmoil, Royal Danish Ballet Taps Veteran Dancer as Leader
abstract: Amy Watson will helm the storied company as it grapples with the sudden departure of its previous artistic director and accusations of abuse at its school.
lead_paragraph: For months, the Royal Danish Ballet, one of the world’s premier dance troupes, has been in turmoil. Accusations of abuse have shaken its 253-year-old school. Then, last week, the company said its star artistic director, Nikolaj Hübbe, was abruptly resigning after 16 years.

headline: Why a Memphis Community Is Fighting Elon Musk’s Supercomputer
abstract: Residents say Mr. Musk’s data center for artificial intelligence is compounding their pollution burden and adding stress on the local electrical grid.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the world’s richest man, is building what he says will be the world’s largest supercomputer. Its electricity needs will rival those of 100,000 homes.

headline: Can Stories About Abortion Break Through the Noise?
abstract: The reproductive rights activist Cecile Richards started a media project that merges activism and journalism on Instagram and TikTok, just days ahead of the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Last week, an Instagram account with fewer than 3,500 followers published a video of a Florida woman named Deborah Dorbert. She described carrying a baby diagnosed with Potter syndrome, a fatal condition, to full term after being denied an abortion. Her son lived for 94 minutes, she said in the video.

headline: One Frame, Thousands of Snails
abstract: This image, from the animated feature about a woman who hoards snail-related items, includes a bevy of tiny, handcrafted artifacts.
lead_paragraph: This image, from the animated feature about a woman who hoards snail-related items, includes a bevy of tiny, handcrafted artifacts.

headline: A Texas Judge’s Fight to Keep a High Profile Case Out of His Court
abstract: A battle over a new rule to limit credit card late fees has spiraled into a larger skirmish about how much power litigants should have to maneuver their cases into friendly courtrooms.
lead_paragraph: When legal activists want to challenge the federal government’s reach, they frequently head to Texas. By filing cases in the state’s smaller divisions, they can be guaranteed a Republican-appointed district judge and an appeals court widely regarded as the most conservative federal court in the country. The state is often the launchpad from which aggressively unorthodox arguments reach the Supreme Court.

headline: Search and Rescue Efforts Continue in Spain After Worst Flooding in Decades
abstract: The flooding left more than 150 dead, and an unknown number of people missing.
lead_paragraph: The flooding left more than 150 dead, and an unknown number of people missing.

headline: Trump’s Transition Team Head Says R.F.K. Jr. Converted Him to Vaccine Skeptic
abstract: Howard Lutnick told CNN that he believed Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who could have a position in a possible Trump administration, was right about debunked vaccine claims.
lead_paragraph: Howard Lutnick, the head of the team planning former President Donald J. Trump’s potential White House transition, said on Wednesday that Robert F. Kennedy Jr. had convinced him to embrace Mr. Kennedy’s anti-vaccine claims, which have been widely debunked.

headline: Authors Call for a Boycott of Israeli Cultural Institutions
abstract: Thousands of people, including prize winning writers, signed a letter pledging not to work with “complicit” organizations. Many others opposed the call in a separate letter.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of writers and members of the entertainment industry signed two opposing letters this week, one pledging to boycott Israeli cultural institutions, and the other condemning the call for a boycott, in the latest sign of the deep divisions that have erupted in the literary world over the conflict in the Middle East.
